headline: Brian Stelter Returns to CNN as Chief Media Analyst
abstract: Mr. Stelter, who left CNN two years ago, will be helming his newsletter for the network, but without a Sunday show.
lead_paragraph: CNN’s “Reliable Sources” is back. Kind of.

headline: Trump Says There Was ‘No Conflict’ at Cemetery, Despite Official Accounts
abstract: Speaking to Sean Hannity, Donald Trump contradicted his campaign’s prior statements about a confrontation involving his campaign at Arlington National Cemetery last week.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump insisted in a radio interview on Tuesday that “there was no conflict” between members of his campaign team and an official at Arlington National Cemetery, contradicting his campaign’s previous statements about the episode last week and Army officials’ account.

headline: How Self-Driving Cars Get Help From Humans Hundreds of Miles Away
abstract: Zoox, a self-driving car company owned by Amazon, is deploying robot taxis without steering wheels, driver seats or drivers. But like all other self-driving cars, they still need help from humans.
lead_paragraph: Zoox, a self-driving car company owned by Amazon, is deploying robot taxis without steering wheels, driver seats or drivers. But like all other self-driving cars, they still need help from humans.

headline: Tim Sheehy Was Recorded Using Racist Stereotypes About Native Americans
abstract: Mr. Sheehy, a Republican, is the nominee for a Senate seat in Montana, where Indigenous residents make up about 6 percent of the population.
lead_paragraph: Tim Sheehy, the Republican nominee for U.S. Senate in Montana, made comments perpetuating racist stereotypes about Native Americans during private fund-raisers last year, according to recordings of the events published by a local news outlet late last week and obtained by The New York Times.

headline: House Republican Subpoenas Blinken Over Afghanistan Withdrawal
abstract: The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee summoned the secretary of state for testimony just days before an expected report on the U.S. exit, in which 13 American service members were killed.
lead_paragraph: The Republican chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Tuesday issued a subpoena for Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s testimony, threatening to hold him in contempt if he failed to address the panel later this month about the chaotic U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.

headline: New York Official Is Charged as Chinese Agent
abstract: Linda Sun, a former aide to Gov. Kathy Hochul, was charged with 10 criminal counts that included visa fraud, money laundering and other crimes.
lead_paragraph: Linda Sun, a former aide to Gov. Kathy Hochul, was charged with 10 criminal counts that included visa fraud, money laundering and other crimes.

headline: Some Navels
abstract: Kareem Ayas waxes poetic.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Wall Street Is Unsettled Again, After Fueling a Global Sell-Off
abstract: Another day of anxiety hit stock markets around the world, with technology stocks the focus of attention.
lead_paragraph: Markets remained unsettled on Wednesday as technology stocks continued to fall, dragging down stock indexes across the world for a second consecutive day.

headline: Japan’s Era of ‘Free’ Mortgages Is Coming to an End
abstract: Homeowners are gearing up to pay more on their loans as the Bank of Japan’s rate increases signal the end of decades of ultralow interest rates.
lead_paragraph: For years, mortgages in Japan have been nearly cost free. Homeowners are now bracing for that to change.

headline: Two Years After Deadly Floods Hit Pakistan, It’s Happening Again
abstract: Millions of people still recovering from the devastation of 2022 are bracing for the possibility of losing what they’ve rebuilt.
lead_paragraph: One recent evening, as heavy monsoon rains pounded down, Fauzia and her extended family of 15 huddled under a makeshift tent, its top patched with large plastic sheets.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Casualties from a Russian strike in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russian missiles yesterday struck a military academy and a neighboring hospital in Poltava, about 100 miles from the Russian border, killing more than 50 people, wounding some 200 others and underscoring Moscow’s superior firepower. It was the latest in a string of deadly Russian strikes.

headline: Electing Judges in Mexico? It’s a Bad Idea.
abstract: The judicial overhaul in Mexico could harm government accountability, undermine the justice system and give even greater power to drug cartels.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Mexico has been in turmoil over President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed constitutional amendment for judges to be elected by popular vote. Fifty-five thousand judicial employees went on strike as legislators pushed the law forward; the peso fell, and international banks issued dire warnings about the effect of the proposal on the economy.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Extreme Weather Is Increasing Risk of Collapse for U.S. Bridges
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s getting so hot that the pieces that hold the concrete and steel, those bridges can literally fall apart like Tinkertoys.”

headline: Missile and Drone Attacks Across Ukraine Kill at Least 7 in Lviv
abstract: Russia attacked a number of cities a day after a devastating strike in the country’s east, Ukrainian officials said.
lead_paragraph: Russia bombarded a swath of Ukraine early Wednesday, killing at least seven people in the western city of Lviv, local Ukrainian officials said, a day after a ballistic missile attack in the eastern city of Poltava left dozens of people dead.

headline: Word of the Day: ensemble
abstract: This word has appeared in 609 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word ensemble has appeared 609 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 24 in The New York Times Magazine article “The Mysterious, Deep-Dwelling Microbes That Sculpt Our Planet” by Ferris Jabr:

headline: Pope Praises Indonesia’s ‘Delicate Balance’ of Unity in Diversity
abstract: Speaking in Jakarta, the pontiff said “mutual respect” was the key to harmony in the majority-Muslim country, where a pluralist tradition has been put to the test by extremist groups.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Wednesday praised Indonesia’s founding principles of unity in diversity in his first public address in the country but also stressed vigilance against intolerance and extremism.

headline: Stephen Colbert Takes Stock of Harris Leading in the Polls
abstract: Colbert reacted to a survey showing the vice president ahead of Donald Trump, 48 percent to 43 percent, saying it “really restores my faith in almost half of humanity.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Summer Bucket List
abstract: What items did you cross off your list of summer pleasures this year?
lead_paragraph: What makes summer feel like summer to you? How many of those things did you get to do this year?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The View From the Nosebleeds at the U.S. Open: Not Too Shabby
abstract: It’s a long way to Row Z. But once you get there, there are advantages, tennis fans say.
lead_paragraph: To reach the last row of Section 323 in Arthur Ashe Stadium — one of the highest vantage points from which to watch U.S. Open matches — is something of a marathon.

headline: Pope Francis Kicks Off Asia Tour in Indonesia
abstract: The 87-year-old will also visit Papua New Guinea, East Timor and Singapore during his 11-day Asia trip to reach faraway Catholics.
lead_paragraph: The 87-year-old will also visit Papua New Guinea, East Timor and Singapore during his 11-day Asia trip to reach faraway Catholics.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 4, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about the president of Mexico’s plan for transforming the judiciary misstated which judges could be fired or impeached under a planned Tribunal for Judicial Discipline. Supreme Court justices could not be.

headline: Two Florida Moms, One Congressional Seat and the Future of MAGA
abstract: Representative Anna Paulina Luna, a Trump acolyte, is vulnerable to her challenger, Whitney Fox, in Florida’s 13th District.
lead_paragraph: On a steamy weekend in June, I went to St. Petersburg to report on the race for Congress in Florida’s 13th Congressional District. In a heavily gerrymandered and polarized country, it’s one of the few congressional races that the nonpartisan Cook Political Report highlighted as even vaguely competitive. They described the race as “likely Republican,” as Republicans typically receive six more points of the vote share than Democrats.

headline: An Agonizing Dilemma: When Obesity Prevents a Joint Replacement
abstract: Many doctors say it is too dangerous to perform the common surgeries on people with high body mass indexes, but patients say they are facing discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The last time Alicia Kline walked unassisted was in January 2021. She is in constant pain from hip arthritis and uses a walker and a wheelchair.

headline: Waymo’s Robot Taxis Are Almost Mainstream. Can They Now Turn a Profit?
abstract: Now that its technology is showing it can work on city streets, Alphabet, which owns Waymo, plans to invest billions more.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few months, Waymo’s robot taxis have become an unmistakable part of the San Francisco experience.

headline: Harry Styles’s Favorite Designer Returns
abstract: Also, everything else you need to know about what’s happening this fashion month.
lead_paragraph: Even in the context of end-of-summer, back-to-school Septembers, this September is going to be a doozy. Not just a return to real life, but crammed with attention-demanding events: the U.S. Open finals, the Harris-Trump debate, the Emmys (which have turned into a mini-Oscars, thanks to streaming). How will fashion month, which begins in New York this week before moving on to London, Milan and Paris, ever compete?

headline: Read Your Way Through Buenos Aires
abstract: Buenos Aires is a literary city: Its residents like to boast about its many bookstores and independent publishers. Samanta Schweblin suggests which books and authors to start with.
lead_paragraph: When I started traveling, I came to realize just how different Buenos Aires was from other literary cities. Maybe we all have similar thoughts about our hometowns, or maybe my revelation is just one more confirmation of the arrogance for which we porteños — people raised in the port city of Buenos Aires — are famous throughout the rest of Latin America.

headline: A Ruling, Finally, on the Fate of the Palisades in Union City, N.J.
abstract: After being tied up in litigation for years, an assemblage of 13 properties on the cliffs west of Hoboken will see what the market has in store for them.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare for a sizable parcel of land to come up for sale in Union City, N.J., the third most densely populated city in America, according to the census.

headline: Daniel Dae Kim Isn’t Afraid to Fail
abstract: In the new Broadway production of “Yellow Face,” the “Lost” and “Hawaii Five-0” star is taking a risk. “I am aware,” he says, “that people have not usually seen me in this way.”
lead_paragraph: It’s tough to see the resemblance.

headline: It’s Party Time on the Stockholm-Helsinki Ferry
abstract: The 16-hour trip between the two northern European cities is a festive summer ritual, with plenty of singing, gambling, limbo contests and maybe a bit too much to drink.
lead_paragraph: The party started an hour before the M/S Gabriella ferry slipped out of Stockholm harbor for its overnight voyage to Helsinki. At the outdoor bar on Deck 9, passengers had gathered for the 4 p.m. sailing. Talking excitedly over drinks, they reveled in the Nordic summer weather — bright sun, cool breeze, electric blue sky with cotton-ball clouds — while a D.J. mixed bass-heavy Eurodance and vintage disco. Kids on holiday with their families dashed about.

headline: Sitting All Day Can Cause Dead Butt Syndrome
abstract: The name might make you snicker, but addressing “gluteal amnesia” can help you avoid chronic pain.
lead_paragraph: After a long workday at your desk or hours in a car, it’s normal to feel a little stiff. It may just be that your hip flexors and lower back are tight. But you could also be experiencing a potentially debilitating condition called gluteal amnesia, or dead butt syndrome.

headline: Mk.gee, an Unlikely Guitar God, Chases the Promise of Pop
abstract: At 27, he has a desire to rethink how music is made, and the confidence to do it. Stars including Eric Clapton, Frank Ocean and Justin Bieber are buying in.
lead_paragraph: On first listen, or even fourth, the songs of Michael Gordon, a guitarist, producer and vocalist who performs as Mk.gee, are not the sort one imagines generating a modern frenzy.

headline: Oversize Coats Are the Season’s Biggest Trend
abstract: Giant, tailored wool outerwear is a cozy yet polished choice this fall.

headline: A House That Memorializes a Vanished New York
abstract: In Lower Manhattan, the former residence of an artist couple remains unchanged years after their deaths.
lead_paragraph: IN OCTOBER 1976, the artists Geoffrey Hendricks and Brian Buczak met at a SoHo loft party. Hendricks, then 45, was associated with the Fluxus movement, a loose affiliation of 1960s conceptual artists, including Joseph Beuys, John Cage and Yoko Ono, who rejected traditional practices like abstract painting in favor of elaborate performances. Five years earlier, he’d co-starred in a notable one: In the summer of 1971, Hendricks and his wife of 10 years, the artist Nye Ffarrabas (then Bici Forbes), who were both gay, staged a piece called “Flux Divorce,” which involved taking a chain saw to their marriage bed and dividing the entryway to their home with barbed wire. (Their young children, Tyche and Bracken, weren’t around for the actual show; they only observed the cleanup afterward.) Buczak, a painter who was 23 years Hendricks’s junior, had recently relocated from Detroit, where he was raised. As luck would have it, Hendricks had been staying in a dilapidated townhouse in Hudson Square, then a manufacturing neighborhood on the west side of Lower Manhattan, which he’d eventually buy from his younger brother Jon, a Fluxus artist and archivist who lived next door. Buczak moved in a few months later.

headline: Can I Lower My Cholesterol Without Taking a Statin?
abstract: Here’s what the evidence suggests can work.
lead_paragraph: Q: I have high cholesterol, but when I tried statins, I didn’t like the side effects. What are non-pharmaceutical ways to lower my cholesterol?

headline: A Democracy With Everything but a Choice
abstract: A new analysis of American elections finds that in half of all races for partisan offices, a candidate runs unopposed. Democrats are the biggest no-shows.
lead_paragraph: This November, voters in rural Perry County, Mo., will face a ballot with candidates for a bevy of local offices: state senator, state representative and circuit judge; two county commissioners, sheriff and many more.

headline: Who Gets to Kill in Self-Defense?
abstract: Self-defense laws were written for men. This is how they fail women who fight back.
lead_paragraph: Self-defense laws were written for men. This is how they fail women who fight back.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Big Band Jazz
abstract: Big bands were built in the 1920s and ’30s to blast young dancers with layers of rhythm, but creative composers seeking a larger canvas have kept the form alive. Hear 12 big selections.
lead_paragraph: “Big band music” isn’t everybody’s first thought when they’re pondering what to punch into Spotify, we’ll grant you that. But if all big bands make you think of is “jazz hands” and flappers and early black-and-white films, let’s take five minutes to change that.

headline: 6 European Cities Where You Can Swim in the Wild
abstract: Looking to take a dip in or near a city center? Here are some urban areas that have successfully opened up waterways for swimmers.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic Games in Paris generated a lot of excitement around the cleanup project of the Seine River, where triathlon and swimming competitions took place. And there’s more to come: Mayor Anne Hidalgo plans to open three public swimming spots on the Seine by next summer, and similar projects are in the works in Boston, London and Amsterdam.

headline: The Biggest Lie About Baking
abstract: There’s actually room to have fun, and this stunning, simple clafoutis recipe is one to play with.
lead_paragraph: Clafoutis, the rustic, eggy beauty from France, most certainly stands alone. It’s easy to whip together, delicious whether rewarmed or freshly baked and still gooey or left over for a few days and eaten as cold, firm petits fours with your hot morning coffee. It comforts while exuding an unpretentious elegance. Yet it is not original in technique or ingredients, one of many dishes sharing lineage in the Family of the Delicious.

headline: The Secret to Deeper Friendships Is in Your Calendar
abstract: A standing meeting at the diner has led to new levels in connection and community.
lead_paragraph: Every Sunday morning, I walk to my local diner and order a stack of three pancakes, a bowl of fruit, two scrambled eggs and a black coffee. Two friends almost always meet me there. Ty — whom I first got to know in San Francisco, where we both volunteered at a music-events company — gets the corned-beef hash with melted cheese on top. David, whom I met through Ty, drifts from eggs benedict to a breakfast burrito to the occasional chopped cheese. What’s for breakfast doesn’t really matter much, though. That we meet — at the same time and place — does. Recently, we marked almost 40 Sundays running.

headline: The First Movie About Pop Music to Nail Its Mediocrity
abstract: This summer’s “Trap,” from M. Night Shyamalan, works hard to turn its fictional star — and her fans — into heroes.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I went with friends to see a popular British rock band at Madison Square Garden. I went in a fan of the group, but with every interchangeable song, every self-important gesture, I grew farther apart from the crowd around me: The more they enjoyed the music, the more it bored me. I had been pulled into a conversation with 20,000 other people, but I had nothing to say. By the first set break, I wanted to leave; by the third, I needed to escape.

headline: The Truth About Patti LuPone and Mia Farrow
abstract: The longtime friends are appearing together in the new Broadway play “The Roommate.” Everything you think you know about them may be wrong.
lead_paragraph: “Sweet and sour?” Patti LuPone suggested, as if considering options on a menu. She looked questioningly at Mia Farrow, who was sitting next to her in a small atelier in a Midtown Manhattan hotel. We were in the heat-soaked throes of early August, and the women had just arrived, depleted, from what they described as an “airless” rehearsal room nearby.

headline: How Harris Wins (and Trump and the Republicans Blow It)
abstract: To understand Harris’s success, you have to think about Marie Kondo and her ruthless minimalism about clutter.
lead_paragraph: It’s Nov. 6, 2024, the morning after Election Day.

headline: Andy Cohen Lists His Light-Filled West Village Duplex for $14 Million
abstract: The TV host is trading his 3,500-square-foot apartment, painstakingly assembled over nearly 21 years, for a penthouse in the same neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Andy Cohen, the TV host, author and longtime producer, spent 21 years building his dream West Village home — a fantastical assemblage of four apartments that he turned into a single 3,500-square foot home where light floods nearly every room.

headline: Yuval Noah Harari: What Happens When the Bots Compete for Your Love?
abstract: The world will soon be flooded with fake humans.
lead_paragraph: Democracy is a conversation. Its function and survival depend on the available information technology. For most of history, no technology existed for holding large-scale conversations among millions of people. In the premodern world, democracies existed only in small city-states like Rome and Athens, or in even smaller tribes. Once a polity grew large, the democratic conversation collapsed, and authoritarianism remained the only alternative.

headline: These Chemicals Are Hurting Us. Why Aren’t We Regulating Them?
abstract: Erin Brockovich is sounding the alarm on forever chemicals.
lead_paragraph: They’ve been found in our milk, our eggs, our water supply and our bodies.

headline: Climate Change Is Making ‘Last Chance Tourism’ More Popular, and Riskier
abstract: More tourists are eager to visit vanishing glaciers and ice caves, but warming is also making the sites unstable.
lead_paragraph: An American tourist was visiting an ice cave in one of Europe’s largest national parks last month when a frozen arch collapsed, killing him and injuring his girlfriend.

headline: Could a Cup Count Predict the Election Result?
abstract: A shop in the Hamptons sells presidential campaign cups. The top seller usually also wins the race.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at a shop that is once again selling presidential campaign cups and keeping track of the sales numbers. It has done this since 2004, and its final count has been wrong only once — in 2016. We’ll also get details on a former aide to Gov. Kathy Hochul who is accused of acting as a Chinese agent.

headline: $925,000 Homes in New York, Virginia and Missouri
abstract: A saltbox-style house in Ancram, a Tudor Revival cottage in Richmond and a four-bedroom home in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: This property is on a picturesque country road and has a series of terraced gardens, some devoted to wildflowers, and a swimming pool with sweeping views of the Berkshires. The town has a wine shop and a small general store and coffee shop, about five minutes away by car. Copake Lake is about 15 minutes away. Mount Washington State Forest is 20 minutes away, across the Massachusetts border.

headline: As Groups Have Shifted, Has It Become a ‘Normal’ Election?
abstract: Unusual demographic patterns are fading, but there are still some differences from the 2020 race.
lead_paragraph: Labor Day usually marks the start of the heart of campaign season, but this year it felt like a lull — a brief respite after two tumultuous months.

headline: How the Presidential Election Got This Close
abstract: Polarization doesn’t just pull us apart; it holds coalitions together.
lead_paragraph: As Donald Trump turns to obscenity, racial disparagement and sexual innuendo to blunt Kamala Harris’s surge in the polls, he faces a daunting obstacle: the intense hostility among Democrats to all things Republican.

headline: Do You Get the ‘September Scaries’?
abstract: How are you feeling as summer ends and a new school year begins?
lead_paragraph: It’s September and, for many, that means back to school — back to responsibilities, a regular schedule and waking up early. Do you look forward to this time of year? Or does it make you stressed and anxious?

headline: Gazans Grapple With Prospect of Israeli Presence Postwar
abstract: Some say they will reluctantly stomach a postwar Israeli military presence in the territory if that allows them to go home. Others worry about another long-term occupation.
lead_paragraph: Cease-fire talks in Gaza have stalled again, in part over Israel’s demand to retain a military presence in the territory, which Hamas and Egypt oppose. But the view among some Gazans on that point is less clear-cut.

headline: How Trump Wins (and Harris and the Democrats Blow It)
abstract: The former president’s campaign comes down to the “five turbines of Trumpism.”
lead_paragraph: It’s Nov. 6, 2024, the morning after Election Day.

headline: Aftermath of Military Academy Strike Drains Ukraine’s Seasoned Rescuers
abstract: Repeated air-raid alerts have punctuated the search through the rubble in Poltava, in eastern Ukraine, after an attack that killed more than 50 people.
lead_paragraph: A day after a devastating Russian missile attack that killed more than 50 people in the Ukrainian city of Poltava, bricks splayed out from the stricken military academy building as exhausted rescue workers searched for bodies in the rubble, stopping every so often to listen for cries for help.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,174
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, September 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 452
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Sept. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level, and whether you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.

headline: Trump’s Federal Election Case to Go Back Before a No-Nonsense Judge
abstract: If her record is any guide, Judge Tanya Chutkan will try to keep pretrial proceedings moving along after a lengthy hiatus and the Supreme Court’s decision granting former presidents broad immunity.
lead_paragraph: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan wasted no time last month when the biggest case of her career — the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on election interference charges — was handed back to her.

headline: N.Y. Official Accused of Aiding China, and Zelensky Plans Cabinet Shake-Up
abstract: Plus, robot taxis — with human helpers.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Battle to Control the World’s Most Powerful Technology
abstract: Nvidia chips, which are crucial to artificial intelligence, are traded actively in China, despite U.S. restrictions, The Times found.
lead_paragraph: The American company Nvidia has created one of the world’s most sought-after inventions: a computer chip that powers artificial intelligence.

headline: Deregulation and Dishonesty Led to Deadly Grenfell Fire, Inquiry Finds
abstract: A damning final report into Britain’s worst residential fire since World War II blamed a litany of cost-cutting, dishonest sales practices and lax regulation for the blaze that killed 72 people.
lead_paragraph: Seven years after flames engulfed Grenfell Tower, a public housing block in West London, killing 72 people, a public inquiry on Wednesday blamed unscrupulous manufacturers, a cost-cutting local government and reckless deregulation for the disaster, Britain’s worst residential fire since World War II.

headline: Who the Swing Voters Are
abstract: We analyze the voters who could decide the election.
lead_paragraph: About 18 percent of American voters have not made up their minds between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump, recent polls suggest.

headline: Hounded From a Beauty Pageant in South Africa, Then Crowned in Nigeria
abstract: A South African beauty pageant contestant with Nigerian heritage was forced to withdraw from the competition after her participation fueled anti-immigrant sentiments.
lead_paragraph: On only her second visit to Nigeria, Chidimma Adetshina won that country’s Miss Universe beauty pageant.

headline: Netflix Adds Disclaimer to Indian Show After Anger Over Hijacker Names
abstract: The series, based on a 1999 plane hijacking, prompted backlash on social media. Critics claimed it wrongly portrayed the Islamist hijackers as Hindus.
lead_paragraph: Netflix expanded a disclaimer for Indian audiences with a fictional series inspired by the 1999 hijacking of a plane by Islamist militants, after social media users and a high-ranking member of India’s ruling party accused it of portraying the hijackers as Hindus.

headline: With Hopes Frayed in Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Mediators Plan a New Push
abstract: The latest proposals to bridge the remaining gaps between Israel and Hamas have yet to be finalized. Both Israel and Hamas have expressed pessimism over the prospects for an agreement.
lead_paragraph: International mediators are finalizing a new cease-fire proposal to narrow the gaps between Israel and Hamas, U.S. and regional officials said, even as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu insists he will not give up control of Gaza’s border with Egypt — a key stumbling point for a deal.

headline: Slowdown Déjà Vu Rattles Global Markets
abstract: Investors sent technology stocks and other assets tumbling on concerns that the U.S. economy could be headed for a hard landing.
lead_paragraph: September is known as the worst month of the year for stocks, and so far it’s living up to that reputation — especially for Nvidia shareholders.

headline: Mexico’s Lower House of Congress Approves President’s Judicial Overhaul
abstract: The vote was the first step toward shifting the country to a system in which nearly every judge would be elected to office. The bill now moves to the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Legislators in Mexico’s lower house of Congress on Wednesday morning approved a sweeping proposal to redesign the entire judiciary, the first step toward shifting the country to a system in which nearly every judge is elected to office.

headline: The Black List Helped Reshape Hollywood. Can It Change Publishing?
abstract: Almost 20 years after Franklin Leonard created the Black List, which has helped little-known screenwriters break into Hollywood, it is expanding into fiction.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 20 years, Franklin Leonard has made it his mission to help undiscovered writers find an audience.

headline: Shootings on Highway Near Seattle Injure 5 People
abstract: Washington State Patrol officers arrested a suspect in the string of shootings, which occurred late on Labor Day along a stretch of Interstate 5.
lead_paragraph: A string of seemingly random shootings along Interstate 5 in Washington State on Monday injured at least five people and struck up to seven vehicles, the police said Tuesday.

headline: Inside the Pope’s Visit Across Asia and Oceania
abstract: Francis is undertaking an 11-day journey to Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, East Timor and Singapore.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis began an 11-day tour of four island nations across Southeast Asia and Oceania last week, an ambitious trek to faraway corners of the Roman Catholic world.

headline: What a Puppy Kindergarten Revealed About Raising Exceptional Dogs
abstract: Brian Hare and Vanessa Woods are studying how the canine mind develops and what makes a successful service dog.
lead_paragraph: Most students at the Biological Sciences Building at Duke University are trying to master the finer points of cellular biology, genetics or evolution.

headline: A New ‘Red Hot’ Album Tackles a Hot Topic: Transgender Awareness
abstract: “Transa,” with 46 tracks due Nov. 22, brings together artists including Sam Smith, Sade, André 3000 and Jayne County.
lead_paragraph: Over a soft piano riff wafts the unmistakable voice of Sade, singing a song to her son. The lyrics she wrote for the piece — her first new track in 14 years, titled “Young Lion” — are steeped in empathy and regret. “Young man, it’s been so heavy for you/You must have felt so alone,” she sings. “I should have known.”

headline: Our Granddaughter’s Boyfriend Is Too Old for Her. What Can We Do?
abstract: A reader and her husband are united in disapproval of the 14-year age gap in their granddaughter’s relationship. What they don’t agree on is whether to invite him to dinner.
lead_paragraph: My 22-year-old granddaughter is in love with a man who is 36. They have been dating for a year. I want to maintain my closeness with her, so I hide my concern about the age gap. My husband (her grandfather) does not. Recently, our granddaughter told me that she would like to bring her boyfriend to a family dinner, but she is afraid of what her grandfather might say. I’ve tried to ask him to be open about this, but before we get anywhere, he changes the subject. I perceive a commitment looming, and I would like to meet this boyfriend. Our daughter met him, and she likes him. What should I do?

headline: Phoenix Marks 100 Straight Days of 100-Degree Temperatures
abstract: The city reached the sweaty milestone on Tuesday. The previous record of 76 straight days was set in 1993.
lead_paragraph: For Phoenix, a city accustomed to intense heat, the dog days of summer have been exceptional this year. On Tuesday, the city reached a milestone, marking its 100th straight day with temperatures of at least 100 degrees Fahrenheit, meteorologists said, adding there was no end in sight.

headline: Joaquin Phoenix and the Big Question at the ‘Joker: Folie à Deux’ Premiere
abstract: At the Venice Film Festival with his co-star, Lady Gaga, would the actor answer questions about dropping out of a Todd Haynes movie?
lead_paragraph: Joaquin Phoenix has never been eager to face the press. The 49-year-old actor grants few interviews, speaks with great reluctance about his process, and once walked out on a journalist when asked whether his film “Joker” might inspire copycat violence.

headline: Luca Guadagnino Gets Crafty
abstract: The film director and designer did double duty in Venice, Italy, debuting a film at the Venice Film Festival along with his curation of Homo Faber, the craftsmanship exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Luca Guadagnino has added creative director to his list of jobs.

headline: TikTok Expands Its ‘How to Vote’ Resources Ahead of the Election
abstract: The company is an increasingly popular source of political news. It’s adding more content about how elections work and media literacy.
lead_paragraph: TikTok is pushing to improve information about the upcoming U.S. presidential election on the app, it said Wednesday.

headline: Trump Media Shares Are Down 74% From Their March Peak
abstract: The stock price of the former president’s social media company has often moved in tandem with investor perception of his standing in the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company have fallen so much that his onetime $6 billion stake is now worth about $2 billion.

headline: Pedro Almodóvar, Julianne Moore and Tilda Swinton on ‘The Room Next Door’
abstract: The director’s first English-language feature inspires talk of beauty, hope and more collaborations.
lead_paragraph: At Monday night’s Venice after-party for “The Room Next Door,” Pedro Almodóvar beamed at his leading ladies as they beamed back.

headline: Harris and Biden Will Visit World Trade Center Site on Sept. 11, as Trump Mulls the Same
abstract: This year, the anniversary of the 2001 attacks will come just hours after a presidential debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and President Biden are set to visit the World Trade Center site in New York City on Sept. 11 to memorialize the 2001 terrorist attacks, while former President Donald J. Trump is considering doing so too.

headline: Ukraine’s Top Diplomat Has Become a Familiar Face, Rallying Wartime Support
abstract: Dmytro Kuleba has lobbied Kyiv’s allies to supply missile defense systems. He was among several Ukrainian ministers who offered to resign on Wednesday, an official said.
lead_paragraph: When Russian forces rolled across the border into Ukraine at the start of their full-scale invasion in February 2022, Dmytro Kuleba, Ukraine’s foreign minister, compared the assault to Nazi Germany’s in World War II.

headline: Earthy Eggplant That Whispers of Summer and Fall
abstract: Hetty Lui McKinnon has just the recipe for this time of seasonal change.
lead_paragraph: I’ve done my best in these missives this summer to highlight all of the season’s seemingly endless bounty. Corn, tomatoes, watermelon! Zucchini, too! But there has been a glaring omission, I hate to say, and that’s eggplant.

headline: Desperate Bid to Save J.F.K. Shown in Resurfaced Film
abstract: The footage from 1963, taken by a Texas businessman and seen only by a few, shows the president’s limousine speeding to a Dallas hospital. It is being auctioned this month.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 61 years ago, Dale Carpenter Sr. showed up on Lemmon Avenue in Dallas, hoping to film John F. Kennedy as his motorcade passed. But the president’s car had already gone by, and he recorded only some of the procession, including the back of a car carrying Lyndon Johnson and the side of the White House press bus.

headline: Ms. Taddeo Goes to Hollywood
abstract: A writer’s success today may be measured in film and television adaptations. Lisa Taddeo, whose book “Three Women” is now a Starz series, hates that.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood couldn’t resist Lisa Taddeo’s book “Three Women” when it was published in 2019.

headline: Iran Emerges as a Top Disinformation Threat in U.S. Presidential Race
abstract: With a flurry of hacks and fake websites, Iran has intensified its efforts to discredit American democracy and possibly tip the race against former President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: A website called Savannah Time describes itself as “your trusted source for conservative news and perspectives in the vibrant city of Savannah.” Another site, NioThinker, wants to be “your go-to destination for insightful, progressive news.” The online outlet Westland Sun appears to cater to Muslims in suburban Detroit.

headline: Biden’s Asylum Restrictions Were Meant to Be Temporary. That Could Change.
abstract: The Biden administration is considering actions that would make the tough restrictions the president ordered in June almost impossible to lift.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is considering actions that would make President Biden’s tough but temporary asylum restrictions almost impossible to lift, people familiar with the plans said on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Announces Plan to Counter Russian Influence Ahead of 2024 Election
abstract: American spy agencies have assessed that the Kremlin favors former President Donald J. Trump, seeing him as skeptical of U.S. support for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The United States on Wednesday announced a broad effort to push back on Russian influence campaigns in the 2024 election, as it tries to curb the Kremlin’s use of state-run media and fake news sites to sway American voters.

headline: Elton John Says a Serious Eye Infection Limited His Vision in One Eye
abstract: The entertainer said on social media that it would “take some time” before sight returned to his eye.
lead_paragraph: Elton John said he was recuperating from a severe eye infection that limited his vision in one eye, but that he was optimistic about his recovery.

headline: In Deciding When to Sentence Trump, Judge Faces ‘Impossible’ Task
abstract: Justice Juan M. Merchan has tried to treat Donald J. Trump like the hundreds of other defendants whose fates he has decided. But his decision could alter American history.
lead_paragraph: As Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial wrapped up in May, one of his lawyers wanted to give the jury unusual instructions that would have made it harder to convict him. A special case warranted special rules, the lawyer argued, and the first prosecution of a former American president was “obviously an extraordinarily important case.”

headline: Noel Parmentel Jr., Essayist, Polemicist and Apostate, Dies at 98
abstract: A self-described “reactionary individualist,” he mentored Joan Didion and was credited with famously comparing Nixon to a used-car salesman.
lead_paragraph: Noel E. Parmentel Jr., a splenetic polemicist and political apostate who mentored Joan Didion, helped persuade Norman Mailer to run for mayor of New York and, as the son of a part-time automobile salesman, was credited with distilling Americans’ doubts about Richard M. Nixon into a single question — “Would you buy a used car from this man?” — died on Saturday in West Haven, Conn. He was 98.

headline: Nordstrom Family Offers $3.8 Billion to Buy Its Namesake Retailer
abstract: The $23-per-share offer by the department store’s founding family comes as retailers struggle to navigate new shopping trends and costly real estate.
lead_paragraph: The family behind Nordstrom, one of the country’s oldest department stores, is offering to take it private for $3.8 billion, the company announced in a regulatory filing on Wednesday, as retailers struggle to navigate new shopping trends and their costly store bases.

headline: With New Taliban Manifesto, Afghan Women Fear the Worst
abstract: Three years into its rule, the movement has codified its harsh Islamic decrees into law that now includes a ban on women’s voices in public.
lead_paragraph: No education beyond the sixth grade. No employment in most workplaces and no access to public spaces like parks, gyms and salons. No long-distance travel if unaccompanied by a male relative. No leaving home if not covered from head to toe.

headline: Jim Riswold, Creator of ‘Bo Knows’ and Air Jordan Ads, Dies at 66
abstract: His work for Nike — particularly commercials starring Michael Jordan and Spike Lee — blurred the line between advertising and entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Jim Riswold, a visionary and irreverent adman whose playful and occasionally provocative Nike commercials featuring Michael Jordan, Tiger Woods and Bo Jackson redrew the playing field for product endorsements and propelled athletic footwear into the cultural stratosphere, died on Aug. 9 at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 66.

headline: Is It OK to Vote for My Third-Party Fave This Presidential Election?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the efficacy of voting your conscience.
lead_paragraph: I’m caught in a bind between two parties, the Democratic Party and the Green Party. I believe in the message and values of the Green Party candidate; however, they never seem to get elected, so many suggest voting for them is moot. This feels like a catch-22. But with the upcoming presidential election, my peers suggest that voting for a third party ensures a Republican victory, akin to supporting the opposition.

headline: JD Vance’s Conversion to Catholicism
abstract: Readers discuss an article about how he discovered his faith. Also: The Hamas tunnels; prioritizing child care; accessibility in Paris and Barcelona.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Russia Launches Deadly Missile and Drone Attacks on Ukraine
abstract: At least seven people were killed in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, a day after a devastating attack on the eastern city of Poltava left dozens of others dead.
lead_paragraph: At least seven people were killed in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, a day after a devastating attack on the eastern city of Poltava left dozens of others dead.

headline: ‘Path to Disaster’: 4 Takeaways From the U.K. Grenfell Fire Final Report
abstract: An extensive public inquiry found that the causes of the Grenfell Tower tragedy stretched back decades, and that the deaths of 72 people were avoidable.
lead_paragraph: More than seven years after 72 people were killed and dozens more injured when a devastating fire tore through Grenfell Tower, an official inquiry on Wednesday blamed “decades of failures” by the government, dishonesty by companies and a flawed response from London’s fire service.

headline: Trump Buried the Hatchet With Brian Kemp. Will He Dig It Up Again?
abstract: Donald Trump needs to win Georgia. That probably means he needs to keep a fragile peace with its popular Republican governor, even as election denialism again courses through the state.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has reached an uneasy truce with Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia, setting aside a yearslong grudge over his Republican counterpart’s refusal to help him overturn the state’s 2020 election results.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Legal Woes Return to Spotlight Ahead of Tax Trial
abstract: As both sides prepare for the start of jury selection on Thursday, there are no indications that any deal is likely, according to several people with knowledge of the situation.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden’s trial on tax charges in Los Angeles turned into a political afterthought the moment President Biden withdrew from the 2024 race in July. But the personal stakes for his son, who is staring down the possibility of prison time, have never been higher.

headline: Prosecutor Says Manslaughter Case Against Alec Baldwin Should Be Revived
abstract: The special prosecutor asked a judge in New Mexico to reconsider her decision to toss the charge against the actor during his trial.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor who oversaw the involuntary manslaughter case against Alec Baldwin has asked a judge in New Mexico to reconsider her dismissal of the charge during the trial.

headline: A Perfect Match for a Sexy Brand?
abstract: Haider Ackermann, a coolly sensual designer, is the new creative director at Tom Ford.
lead_paragraph: Tom Ford, a brand long associated with the sexy, glamorous aesthetic of its eponymous founder, has a new creative director: Haider Ackermann, a designer known for his superb tailoring skills and mastery of varied materials.

headline: ‘Terminator Zero’ Reinvigorates a Weary Franchise
abstract: The Netflix anime series channels familiar themes without feeling like a retread.
lead_paragraph: “Terminator 2: Judgment Day” was a megahit in 1991, and every installment of the franchise since has been at least a little disappointing. Until now: The Netflix anime series “Terminator Zero” is a smart take on the lore, channeling familiar themes without feeling like a retread.

headline: Las Vegas Places a Bet on a New Art Museum, With Help From L.A.
abstract: The city agreed to give land to a museum championed by the casino magnate Elaine Wynn, which will be a partnership with the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Las Vegas has the Neon Museum, the Mob Museum, the Punk Rock Museum and the Pinball Hall of Fame, among others. But it is currently the largest city in the United States without a major art museum, despite several attempts over the years.

headline: Biden Expected to Block U.S. Steel Takeover
abstract: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is expected to raise national security concerns about selling the iconic steel producer to Japan’s Nippon Steel.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is preparing to soon block an attempt by Japan’s Nippon Steel to buy U.S. Steel on national security grounds, according to three people familiar with the matter, likely sinking a merger that became entangled in election-year politics in the United States.

headline: Trudeau’s Hold on Power Slips After Collapse of Governing Agreement
abstract: A left-leaning party that helped Canada’s Liberals build a majority in Parliament announced it was ending its support, making it possible an election is called early.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada may be forced into an election earlier than expected after a left-leaning political party that had been propping up his government in Parliament announced on Wednesday that it was abandoning the arrangement.

headline: Boeing Starliner Set to Leave Space Station Without Its Crew
abstract: The troubled spacecraft is scheduled to undock on Friday for a trip back to Earth while two NASA astronauts will stay in orbit.
lead_paragraph: Leaving behind the two NASA astronauts it took to the International Space Station three months ago, Boeing’s troubled Starliner spacecraft is set to begin its return to Earth on Friday evening.

headline: Anna Sorokin Goes From High-Society Impersonator to ‘Dancing With the Stars’
abstract: The woman who impersonated a German heiress will reprise her false identity on season 33 of the show, becoming the latest contestant with legal or other troubles.
lead_paragraph: It’s a familiar lineup for this season’s “Dancing With the Stars.”

headline: J. Richard Munro, Who Oversaw the Creation of Time Warner, Dies at 93
abstract: As chief executive, he expanded Time Inc.’s offerings, fended off a hostile takeover and built the world’s largest media company.
lead_paragraph: J. Richard Munro, who as chief executive of Time Inc. navigated the company from its home in magazine publishing through the stormy media seas of the 1980s and ultimately to its momentous purchase of Warner Communications in 1989, creating the world’s largest media corporation, died on Aug. 11 in Naples, Fla. He was 93.

headline: Short Notice and Blocked Exits Proved Lethal in Strike in Ukraine
abstract: When two Russian ballistic missiles struck a military academy in Poltava, debris blocked corridors and exits. Cadets near a bomb shelter survived. Others did not.
lead_paragraph: The Russian missiles that tore into a Ukrainian military academy on Tuesday proved so lethal because cadets had barely two minutes to seek safety in a bomb shelter and because debris from explosions then blocked emergency exits, the academy director said Wednesday.

headline: Linda Deutsch, The A.P.’s Dean of Courtroom Reporting, Dies at 80
abstract: Covering notorious trials, she offered readers an unvarnished view of the sordid side of celebrity, told through many of the country’s most riveting legal dramas.
lead_paragraph: Linda Deutsch, who covered high-profile trials in nearly 50 years as a reporter with The Associated Press, starting with the one surrounding the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy and including the defendants O.J. Simpson, Michael Jackson and Charles Manson, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 80.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Below Deck Mediterranean’ and More
abstract: I’m the reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve recently heard, seen and watched.
lead_paragraph: I’m the reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve recently heard, seen and watched.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in September
abstract: This week in Newly Reviewed, Andrew Russeth covers a group show of self-portraits, Gina Beavers’s collaged sculptures and Hannah Villiger’s beguiling photographs.
lead_paragraph: This week in Newly Reviewed, Jillian Steinhauer covers Bernice Bing’s fluid, vibrant paintings, Hồng-Ân Trương’s mattress installation and Teresa Baker’s sublime abstractions.

headline: Seashell Art Is Shedding Its Kitschy Reputation
abstract: No longer confined to beachy souvenir shops, works encrusted with oysters and mussels are showing up in galleries and interiors.
lead_paragraph: Few symbols of death enchant like seashells, the calcified exoskeletons of mollusks, washed ashore after their tenants’ demise. Often lustrous and intricately patterned, shells have served as passports, currency, navigation aids, jewelry and decoration. In Renaissance Italy, for instance, they were used to adorn artificial grottos built on the grounds of prominent villas, including those of the Medicis. These heavily adorned faux caves — often outfitted with hidden water spouts, stalactites, glass gems and sculptures of mermaids and other mythical sea dwellers — provided refuge from summer heat and counterpoints to the formal gardens that surrounded them. Later, in Victorian Britain, shell mania boomed among the general public as the empire expanded into tropical regions. Women integrated their collections into handicrafts, affixing them to picture frames and boxes and creating shell bouquets. In the time since, shells have remained on the fringes of contemporary art and décor, largely deemed kitsch and relegated to coastal souvenir shops. But now — amid renewed appreciation for organic media in art-making and a climate crisis that renders ocean life ever more precious — artists are once again embracing the shell as both a raw material and muse.

headline: House Republicans Pivot to Attacking Walz With Subpoena Over a Nonprofit’s Fraud
abstract: The move was the latest sign that House Republicans were moving from investigating and attacking President Biden to taking aim at the new Democratic ticket.
lead_paragraph: A top House Republican on Wednesday issued a subpoena to Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, for details about a years-old fraud scheme in his state in which a nonprofit organization used a pandemic-era program aimed at feeding hungry children to steal $250 million.

headline: Russia Imprisons Top Physicists, Even as Putin Touts Their Technology
abstract: A Moscow court sentenced Alexander Shiplyuk, the director of a physics institute who specializes in hypersonic flight, to 15 years in prison. It was the latest treason case against a leading scientist.
lead_paragraph: Russian scientists helped make their country a leader in developing cutting-edge missiles that fly at least five times as fast as the speed of sound. Then Russia started calling them traitors.

headline: Shooting at Georgia High School Leaves Four Dead
abstract: The police responded to a shooting at Apalachee High School in Winder, Ga. At least nine others were injured.
lead_paragraph: The police responded to a shooting at Apalachee High School in Winder, Ga. At least nine others were injured.

headline: Harris Tells the Business Community: I’m Friendlier Than Biden
abstract: The vice president on Wednesday proposed an increase on the capital gains tax that was far less than what President Biden has floated, one of several moves meant to win over business owners.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris on Wednesday sought to put daylight between herself and President Biden on tax policy, making it the first issue on which she is trying to stand apart from an administration in which she holds a key role.

headline: How Media Outlets on the Left and Right Covered Trump’s Arlington Cemetery Visit
abstract: Liberal outlets criticized Mr. Trump for turning his visit into a photo opportunity, while conservative ones falsely suggested the altercation never happened.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s visit to Arlington National Cemetery and his campaign’s attempt to film gravesites there last week reignited questions surrounding his politicization of the military. Liberal outlets criticized Mr. Trump for turning his visit into a photo opportunity, while conservative ones falsely suggested that an altercation with a cemetery official hadn’t happened — a line that Mr. Trump echoed on Tuesday, contradicting his campaign’s original account.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Reshuffles its Government
abstract: Plus, Daniel Dae Kim takes a risk.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, laid out plans for the broadest reshuffling of his cabinet since the war began two years ago. The country’s foreign minister was one of half a dozen senior officials who offered their resignation yesterday, and a new list of minsters is expected today.

headline: Ukraine Names Candidates for Its New Cabinet in Major Overhaul
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky said that he was acting to bring a “new energy” to state institutions at an important diplomatic juncture.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky pushed ahead with his sweeping overhaul of the senior government ranks as the head of Ukraine’s ruling party released a slate of nine candidates for top cabinet positions Wednesday evening.

headline: Hamas Releases Hostage Video of Two Slain Israeli Captives
abstract: Release of the video of Carmel Gat, 40, and Alexander Lobanov, 32, appears designed to inflame divisions in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Hamas on Wednesday released a video of two hostages, recorded before their deaths, whose bodies were among those recovered earlier this week by the Israeli military from a tunnel in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Trump Says His Son Barron Is Attending N.Y.U.
abstract: Donald J. Trump had teased his youngest child’s choice of school for months, but on Wednesday, he was photographed on the university’s campus in Manhattan’s Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Barron Trump, the youngest child of former President Donald J. Trump, has enrolled as a freshman at New York University in Manhattan, his father said in an interview that was published on Wednesday.

headline: Watching Movies Like It’s 1999
abstract: A multimedia Culture desk series, “Class of 1999,” revisits a group of mold-breaking, star-studded films released that year.
lead_paragraph: A sci-fi film whose climactic choice — red pill or blue pill? — has become so famous that it’s a meme. A found-footage style documentary horror film that achieved cult-classic status. A “Star Wars,” a “Toy Story” and two Tom Cruise movies.

headline: Dispatches From the Courtroom: Linda Deutsch Breaking the News
abstract: Covering some of America’s most sensational trials, she produced urgent, pithy “ledes” in the best tradition of wire-service reporting. Here’s a sampler.
lead_paragraph: Linda Deutsch, one of the deans of American courtroom reporting, covered criminal trials for The Associated Press for nearly 50 years. She was a master of the concise opening paragraph — known as the lede — and the evocative sentence or two that followed, in the best tradition of wire-service reporting.

headline: Will North Carolina’s MAGA Extremists Doom Trump?
abstract: There’s a whiff of Republican panic in this battleground state.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was in North Carolina just two weeks ago. And a week before that. And on Friday he’ll be back. Again. It seems he can’t get enough of my state.

headline: 21 Reported Missing After Boat Carrying Migrants Capsizes
abstract: Italian rescuers said that seven Syrian migrants survived a shipwreck about 10 miles from the island of Lampedusa, in the Central Mediterranean. The survivors told officials that 21 fellow travelers, including three minors, had fallen off during the crossing because of rough seas.
lead_paragraph: Italian rescuers said that seven Syrian migrants survived a shipwreck about 10 miles from the island of Lampedusa, in the Central Mediterranean. The survivors told officials that 21 fellow travelers, including three minors, had fallen off during the crossing because of rough seas.

headline: The Hurricane Season Was Supposed to Be Busy. What Happened?
abstract: An intermission in hurricanes across the Atlantic has people wondering where the predicted storms are.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through an Atlantic hurricane season that forecasters expected would be one of the most active on record, there has been a considerable interlude in storms during what is typically the busiest portion of the season, leaving observers to wonder if the forecast was a bust — or if the worst may be yet to come.

headline: A Campus Protest Movement Seeks to Regain Momentum but Faces Hurdles
abstract: Pro-Palestinian demonstrations appeared at some U.S. campuses, but new restrictions and a new set of students may slow momentum for the type of mass protests seen in the spring.
lead_paragraph: The 50 or so pro-Palestinian demonstrators picketing outside Columbia University’s main gates on the first day of the semester urged students to boycott classes and handed out fliers accusing Columbia of being complicit in genocide.

headline: Internet Archive Loses Court Appeal in Fight Over Online Lending Library

lead_paragraph: When libraries across the country temporarily closed in the early days of the pandemic, the Internet Archive, an organization that digitizes and archives materials like web pages and music, had the idea to make its library of scanned books free to read in an online database.

headline: Four People Were Killed in a School Shooting in Georgia
abstract: Also, Zelensky is preparing to shake up his cabinet. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old student opened fire today in the hallway of a Georgia high school, killing two students and two teachers and injuring at least nine others, the authorities said. The shooting — the deadliest episode of school violence in Georgia’s history — took place at Apalachee High School in Winder, roughly 50 miles from the center of Atlanta. Here’s the latest on what we know.

headline: 21 Migrants Missing at Sea as Boat Capsizes in Rough Seas Off Italy
abstract: Seven survivors were rescued from the boat that sank after leaving Libya. A crackdown by Italy has reduced migration, but not the high death rates that come with crossing the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-one migrants were missing at sea on Wednesday, according to survivors rescued from a sinking boat about 10 miles from the Italian island of Lampedusa, Italy’s Coast Guard said.

headline: Venezuelan and Proxy Forces Linked to at Least 6 Protester Deaths, Rights Group Says

lead_paragraph: Venezuelan security forces and armed groups aligned with the government committed widespread violence against protesters and killed some of them following the country’s disputed presidential election, according to a report on Wednesday by Human Rights Watch.

headline: There have been three mass shootings in the U.S. this year.
abstract: Here is how The New York Times tallies this type of shooting.
lead_paragraph: The shooting at a high school in Winder, Ga., in which a gunman killed two teachers and two students, and wounded nine more people was the third mass shooting in the United States this year. It is also the deadliest school shooting in Georgia’s history.

headline: Families of Patients Who Died Sue Hospital After Fentanyl Was Swapped With Water

In the clip, Walz says: “When I was in Afghanistan, you know what our troops were worried about? They were worried about their family’s health care, and they were worried about their pensions.”

headline: Winder, a Rural, Middle-Class City in Georgia, Is in a Rapidly Developing Area
abstract: The site of a school shooting is in a county that has nearly doubled in population since 2000, according to census data.
lead_paragraph: The shooting at Apalachee High School on Wednesday took place in a rural, unincorporated area between the cities of Atlanta and Athens in Georgia.

lead_paragraph: Months after a low-level aide in the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo returned from a visit to China in 2019, she got a curious inquiry from federal investigators.

headline: Mother and Daughter Endure Lockdowns in Separate Schools After Georgia Shooting

lead_paragraph: Anetra Pattman, 43, was teaching social sciences at the alternative school in Barrow County, Ga., when she received a text on Wednesday at 10:24 a.m.

headline: Why Trump’s Unity Picks Are Not Very Unifying
abstract: Trump is betting that the political fringe will help him win.

Trump sought to instill doubt that the debate would be fair, downplayed his need to prepare and suggested he was more worried about the network hosting the debate than his opponent.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Sept. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a former aide to Gov. Kathy Hochul who was charged with 10 criminal counts that included visa fraud and money laundering misspelled the name of Linda Sun’s lawyer. It is Jarrod Schaeffer, not Jerrod Schaeffer. The article also misstated who was New York governor when salted ducks were delivered to the parents of Linda Sun. It was Andrew M. Cuomo, not Kathy Hochul; Ms. Hochul became governor the following month.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

lead_paragraph: The participants discussed Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, the economy, abortion and other issues important to them.

abstract: Kimmel mocked Donald Trump for flubbing words before doing so himself on Wednesday, saying, “That’s why I’m not going to be president.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

abstract: This word has appeared in 856 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: Super Typhoon Yagi Nears Southern China With Heavy Rain and Strong Winds
abstract: The storm has killed at least 13 people in the Philippines and is forecast to be the strongest to hit Hainan Province in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Super typhoon Yagi moved toward southern China on Friday, packing heavy rain and strong winds, closing schools and business, and disrupting travel.

headline: When a Real Estate Boom Came to a Toxic Corner of Brooklyn
abstract: Dozens of new buildings are going up along the famously polluted Gowanus Canal. The discovery of an underground chemical plume hasn’t slowed the development.
lead_paragraph: The artists at 543 Union Street knew all about the famously toxic canal that runs next to their building, a former box factory in Gowanus. But in the decades since they converted the factory to broad, timber-beamed lofts, the artists’ most pressing concerns were typical for a century-old building in Brooklyn — broken pipes, hallways in need of a fresh coat of paint, a perpetually damp basement.

headline: Inside the Great Gap Glow-Up
abstract: Can Zac Posen, known for over-the-top glamour, reinvent the American mall brand — and change his reputation in the process?
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, just at the start of New York Fashion Week, more than 1,000 designers, models, factory workers, editors, retailers and influencers will gather in front of Macy’s Herald Square and march up Broadway to Bryant Park to get out the vote. Most of them will be wearing the same thing: a white T-shirt (or T-shirt dress) with black letters that spell out the doodled slogan “Fashion for Our Future.” The designer: Zac Posen, for Old Navy.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Migrants Have Been a ‘Godsend,’ New York Schools Chief Says
abstract: In an interview, Chancellor David C. Banks said migrants had helped schools that were bleeding students. He also promised a big new role for artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: As the school year opens for an American education system facing multiple crises, one education leader is staking out a curious stance. He is sublimely optimistic.

headline: Red and Blue
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: The Bands and the Fans Were Fake. The $10 Million Was Real.
abstract: Federal prosecutors charged a North Carolina musician with gaming the system to win royalties from streaming services including Spotify, Apple Music and Amazon Music.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina man used artificial intelligence to create hundreds of thousands of fake songs by fake bands, then put them on streaming services where they were enjoyed by an audience of fake listeners, prosecutors said.

headline: Rebecca Cheptegei, Olympic Runner From Uganda, Dies After Gasoline Attack
abstract: The athlete, who officials said was set on fire in Kenya by a man with whom she was in a relationship, competed in the women’s marathon at the Paris Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Cheptegei, a Ugandan long-distance runner who competed in the women’s marathon at the Paris Olympics before she was severely burned in a gasoline attack this week, died Thursday in Kenya. She was 33.

headline: New Zealand’s Maori Name a New Queen
abstract: Nga Wai Hono i te Po, 27, is the second woman to assume the ceremonial role. She takes the throne as some of the country’s pro-Maori policies are being pared back.
lead_paragraph: The Maori of New Zealand named a new monarch on Thursday, selecting a 27-year-old queen in a symbolic but weighty role as some of the Indigenous group’s hard-fought rights have been rolled back.

headline: New Zealand’s Maori Crowns New Queen as King Is Laid to Rest
abstract: Nga Wai Hono i te Po took her place on the throne next to the coffin of the late king, her father.
lead_paragraph: Nga Wai Hono i te Po took her place on the throne next to the coffin of the late king, her father.

headline: Harris or Trump? The Prophet of Presidential Elections Is Ready to Call the Race.
abstract: Allan Lichtman’s method for predicting election winners has an impressive track record.
lead_paragraph: Allan Lichtman’s method for predicting election winners has an impressive track record.

headline: After Years of Depression, a Best-Selling Author Confronts What Haunted Him
abstract: In his new novel, Matt Haig goes back to the place where he fell apart — Ibiza, Spain — and reclaims it.
lead_paragraph: As a young man suffocating under the weight of his depression, the author Matt Haig almost walked off a cliff.

headline: Garth Greenwell: A Classic Can Be Both ‘Homophobic’ and ‘Lifesaving’
abstract: James Baldwin’s “Giovanni’s Room” has been meaningful for “generations of queer people (including for me),” says the novelist, who argues for “less facile” literary conversations. His new book is “Small Rain.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Solar Farms Have a Superpower Beyond Clean Energy
abstract: The sites fight climate change and can help with another global crisis: the collapse of nature. But so far, efforts to nurture wildlife habitat have been spotty.
lead_paragraph: It’s not your average solar farm.

headline: Should All Schools Provide Free Lunch?
abstract: Over the past decade, many more public schools started to offer free meals to all children, regardless of family income. Does your school? If not, should it?
lead_paragraph: Do you eat breakfast, lunch or snacks from your school’s cafeteria? If so, what do you eat? Are they good, healthy or satisfying meals?

headline: Art Exhibitions That Don’t Look Away From the Rocky Realities
abstract: A New Orleans triennial and a suite of “Panafrica” exhibitions at the Art Institute of Chicago promise fresh ideas and global conversations.
lead_paragraph: Another epochal election. Another horrific backdrop, from the nightmare in Gaza — however you analyze it — to Sudan, Congo and Ukraine. Another season of demagoguery and bad-faith argument gone global.

headline: The 10 Most Anticipated Art Shows This Season
abstract: Sublime Sienese art at the Met, Pan-African art throughout Chicago, a 200th anniversary at the Brooklyn Museum: These extravaganzas are not to be missed.
lead_paragraph: Several of the art events I’m most psyched for in the season ahead aren’t neatly packaged and cataloged shows. They’re multi-venue extravaganzas, institutional self-celebrations or, in one case, the return of a monumental collection to view.

headline: In ‘Nobody Wants This,’ Adam Brody Keeps the Faith
abstract: His breakout role was as the nerdy Jewish heartthrob in “The O.C.” Now in the rom-com “Nobody Wants This,” he goes full rabbi.
lead_paragraph: Adam Brody’s bar mitzvah was held six months late. It was barely held at all. This was in San Diego, Calif., in the early 1990s, and Brody, who spent most of his free time surfing, attended Hebrew school only under duress. He knew few other Jews.

headline: Trump-Vance Is Making Something Very Clear About Trumpism
abstract: Some of the most institutionally destabilizing aspects of Trump-style populism may be inseparable from its core appeal.
lead_paragraph: Since his selection as Donald Trump’s running mate, Senator JD Vance has performed poorly on most metrics by which we judge vice-presidential nominees. He has never been noted for his charisma, and his attacks and insults have rendered him exceptionally unpopular.

headline: The 96-Year-Old Who Defied a Ban on Female Genital Cutting
abstract: Yassin Fatty, a traditional practitioner of female genital cutting in the West African nation of Gambia, became the first to be convicted there. But her case led to a backlash and a popular campaign to make it legal again.
lead_paragraph: There were young girls, sitting nervous and excited in new clothes under the afternoon sun. There were musicians, dancing and plates of food. There were old handmade knives and bright new razor blades.

headline: 6 Mistakes New Runners Make
abstract: Running experts and coaches share their best advice for avoiding these common pitfalls.
lead_paragraph: Running can be remarkably simple and impressively complex.

headline: The 25 Men’s Fashion Collections That Changed the Way We Dress
abstract: A group of experts — designers, editors and a street-style photographer — debate which clothes truly changed men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: In 2022, we compiled a list of the 25 most influential postwar women’s wear collections. To do the same for men’s wear, we first had to assemble a group of esteemed jurors: the Colombian-born French fashion designer Haider Ackermann; Emily Adams Bode Aujla, the American founder of Bode, a brand known for its vintage-inspired men’s wear; T’s men’s style director, David Farber; the New York-based stylist, creative consultant and T contributor Carlos Nazario; and the New York-based Canadian photographer and creative director Tommy Ton. This past April, on a video call that lasted almost three hours, the group debated the merits of 50 collections, with each panelist making the case for the 10 or so that they’d been asked to nominate beforehand. Although there were favorites (four jurors picked at least one Giorgio Armani and Comme des Garçons collection), there were also some upsets (the inclusion of Helmut Lang over his minimalist peers Calvin Klein and Jil Sander) and a few difficult conversations. Could the group, for example, justify putting Abercrombie & Fitch, a mall retailer with a checkered past, on the same list as Junya Watanabe and Dries Van Noten?

headline: A Mexico City Apartment Complex Where Dozens of Artists Live and Work
abstract: The 174-unit Edificio Mascota in the Colonia Juárez neighborhood covers an entire city block.
lead_paragraph: “I came to Edificio Mascota for the first time thanks to my mother, who bought her place here in 1999. It was very different then. The gates from the privadas [the three internal lanes where many of the apartments are located] onto the main roads were always open. There was a gang of kids who’d hang out and smoke pot by the fountain and an old man who collected dogs. In 2017, after the earthquake, I lost the apartment I’d been renting in Colonia Roma Sur and this became my home-studio. (These days, I keep my studio elsewhere.) The previous tenant told me my apartment had been a studio for an important actor and singer, Pedro Vargas, and that he’d composed some of his songs here — and perhaps brought his lovers here. I think there’s always been some sort of mix with the world of the arts.

headline: How to Dress Up an Outfit With an Unexpected Accessory
abstract: Easy, monochromatic wardrobe staples get a boost from a structured handbag, an elegant cap or leather opera gloves.

headline: Boredom Almost Killed the N.F.L. Kickoff. New Rules Are Trying to Save It.
abstract: The league wants to bring excitement back but keep an emphasis on safety.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, the N.F.L. season will begin with a new and unusual-looking version of the play that’s as old as the league itself: the kickoff.

headline: Kamala Harris Wasn’t the First Veep to Experience a Major Vibe Shift
abstract: In “Making the Presidency,” Lindsay M. Chervinsky argues that John Adams established what it means to be America’s commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: Given the excitement around Tim Walz and JD Vance, it is a useful corrective to remember how dismal the vice presidency has long felt to those saddled with the task. As John Adams, the very first veep, wrote to his wife, Abigail, in 1793, “My Country has in its Wisdom contrived for me, the most insignificant Office that ever the Invention of Man contrived or his Imagination conceived.”

headline: I’m Just a Human Sitting in Front of a Stack of Blank Paper, Sketching as Fast as I Can
abstract: My nine months as a generative art model.
lead_paragraph: Last December, I announced the creation of the very first non-artificial-intelligence generative art model.

headline: What Does a Couple Do When One Partner Is Deported?
abstract: American citizens whose spouses have been deported face wrenching decisions on what is best for their future, especially when they have children.
lead_paragraph: Hector Reyes parked his truck in the Mexican border town of Ciudad Juárez, his phone lighting up with photos and videos of his son Daniel receiving his high school diploma.

headline: What’s the Best Wedding Favor? Let Your Guests Decide.
abstract: A growing number of couples are including gifting suites that allow their wedding attendees to pick a souvenir they’ll actually use.
lead_paragraph: Giving gifts to wedding guests is still a common tradition. A 2023 study by the Knot showed that 52 percent of nearly 10,000 couples who were surveyed handed out wedding favors.

headline: There Are Only Two Shakers Left. They’ve Still Got Utopia in Their Sights.
abstract: Their numbers have dwindled, but the remaining members are imagining what comes next.
lead_paragraph: The youngest Shaker in the world is 67 years old, and his name is Arnold. He lives alongside Sister June, 86, in a magnificent brick building designed to sleep about 70 — the dwelling house of the last active Shaker village in the world, at Sabbathday Lake in Maine. Together they constitute one of the longest-running utopian experiments in America.

headline: He Was Riding His Mower When Suddenly He Couldn’t Breathe
abstract: After a lifetime of severe asthma and allergies, this felt different — and far worse.
lead_paragraph: Cars sped past the 51-year-old man as he trundled along the grass-flanked highway outside Peekskill, N.Y., on his industrial-size riding tractor-mower. The early-summer sun beat down, and sweat stung his eyes. The air was dense with fragments of cut grass that dotted his clothes and face. Suddenly he couldn’t breathe. There was just no room in his chest for a new breath, because the old air wouldn’t come out. Panic seized him. He tightened the muscles in his stomach and chest to carefully push the used air out. He felt as if he were blowing through a narrow, crimped straw. Too much pressure only made it worse. He had allergies and bad asthma and worried that something he’d mowed was triggering everything. He forced himself to breathe slowly and struggled to calm his racing heart.

headline: 36 Hours in Door County, Wis.
