abstract: Spend a weekend exploring the forest preserves, cliff-lined shores and walkable towns of this peninsula that juts out into Lake Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Spend a weekend exploring the forest preserves, cliff-lined shores and walkable towns of this peninsula that juts out into Lake Michigan.

headline: Republicans Seize on False Theories About Immigrant Voting
abstract: Activists, party lawyers and state officials are mobilizing behind a crackdown on a supposed scourge of noncitizens’ casting ballots. Voting rights advocates say the effort is spreading misinformation.
lead_paragraph: In late July, a group of Republican activists met on a Zoom call to discuss preparations for the November election. The topic was how to keep undocumented immigrants from voting in November, a problem they claim, inaccurately, to be a looming threat to a fair election.

headline: ‘My First Film’ Review: Arriving Where You Started
abstract: Zia Anger’s movie about her first movie is full of nested layers, but mostly it’s a meditation on how, and why, we create.
lead_paragraph: A cursor appears on a blank screen, blinking, waiting. And then text appears: “This probably shouldn’t be a film … but it is.”

headline: Michael Keaton Michael Keaton Michael Keaton
abstract: In “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice,” the actor returns to a role now enshrined in pop culture — with 35 years of ups and downs and an Oscar nomination under his belt.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in the upcoming indie dramedy “Goodrich” where Michael Keaton’s character, a Los Angeles art dealer lost in the weeds of a late-midlife crisis, agrees to attend a breath workshop to win over a New Age-y prospective client. As setups go, it’s something of a soft target: a fish-out-of-water Boomer, drowning in California woo-woo.

headline: Where Are New York City Buyers Coming From?
abstract: Fewer buyers are coming from New Jersey and more are coming from California, according to a study that tracked sales during the first half of the year.
lead_paragraph: Buying a home in New York City is expensive, but out-of-state buyers are still moving to the city, just in smaller numbers than they were 10 years ago.

headline: In the Paralympic Fix-It Shop, Plenty of Fractures but No Blood
abstract: Repair technicians at the Paris Games fix everything from bent wheelchair frames to broken sunglasses.
lead_paragraph: Spend some time watching the Paralympics and it will soon become obvious from seeing wheelchair athletes bash into each other while playing rugby and basketball that their flattened tires and dented frames might need multiple repairs over their tournaments. But at the Games’ fix-it shop in the Paralympic Village, repair requests can and do come from every sport.

headline: 15 Unforgettable Looks at the Venice Film Festival
abstract: The event, held not long after the couture shows in Paris, has been a showcase for new designs as well as vintage pieces.
lead_paragraph: No amount of star power can truly outshine the beauty of La Serenissima, the ancient republic better known as the city of Venice. But the Venice Film Festival, with its parade of A-listers arriving for movie premieres in water taxis, comes close.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Debate Conundrum
abstract: Donald Trump seems to wish he could still run against Joe Biden. Harris probably wishes she didn’t have to.
lead_paragraph: When Kamala Harris walks onto the debate stage at the National Constitution Center in Philadelphia next week, her toughest opponent will not be Donald Trump. After all, she is quite familiar with his type, as the vice president frequently reminds us. No, Harris’s most complicated antagonist will be one that she can’t criticize, question or contradict, one that she must both deflect and defend.

headline: The Solution to New York’s Transit Problem Is So Obvious Nobody Wants to Hear It
abstract: Too many bus and subway passengers don’t pay. The best solution is more policing.
lead_paragraph: Traveling recently on the London Tube and on the city’s double-decker buses, I wondered, as I have many times before, why New York City can’t have a comparable public transit system: safe, clean platforms; turnstiles that function with smart technology; a functioning messaging system and schedules that operate largely on time. Why are such basics unimaginable in New York?

headline: First Day of School Is OMNY Day in New York
abstract: The schoolchildren who travel by subway and bus will be using OMNY student cards for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday, the first day in class for students in public schools in New York City. We’ll also look at how the judge in Donald Trump’s hush-money case has tried to treat a landmark proceeding no differently from any other.

headline: As Judge Weighs Landmark N.C.A.A. Settlement on Pay, Not All Athletes Approve
abstract: A hearing Thursday will include arguments on a proposal that would allow colleges to pay athletes directly. But detractors say the deal still doesn’t offer players enough.
lead_paragraph: Click here for recent developments on this story.

headline: ‘The Front Room’ Review: A Force Too Malevolent for This Movie
abstract: Kathryn Hunter is enjoyably creepy in this new horror film starring Brandy Norwood. Too bad the rest of the freakouts are predictable.
lead_paragraph: The first time that Kathryn Hunter appears in the ho-hum horror movie “The Front Room,” her head is forebodingly obscured by a veil. She’s at the funeral of her husband, who, you suspect, probably left this mortal coil unwillingly. It’s too bad that he couldn’t stick around longer because if he had, the poor guy would have been able to watch Hunter — as a flamboyantly malicious force named Solange — rapidly get her weird on, inching into the shadows like a malevolent spider while weaving a progressively stickier, ickier web.

headline: ‘The Goldman Case’ Review: Sticking to the Facts
abstract: An electrifying courtroom drama based on a real 1976 case calls the very nature of equality and justice into question.
lead_paragraph: Few settings are as omnipresent in screen entertainment as the courtroom. The halls of justice, the argumentation of lawyers, dramatic backroom dealings, the telling facial expressions of the jury — all of it makes for very good drama. (And sometimes comedy, too.)

headline: Interest Rates Have Dropped, but Homeowners Are Not Moving
abstract: Homeowners are afraid to leave behind great deals they locked in years ago, tethered to their property by “the rate-lock effect” or “golden handcuffs.”
lead_paragraph: On an earnings call earlier this summer, the chief executive of the online real estate brokerage Redfin was asked whether he had a contingency plan if interest rates did not come down? His answer was maybe a bit too frank.

headline: Racing the Clock to Document ISIS Genocide of Iraq’s Yazidis
abstract: For years, a U.N. team has painstakingly exhumed mass graves, but now the Iraqi government is ordering it to leave. Many sites remain unexamined.
lead_paragraph: The hours have been long, the heat extreme and the work painstaking for forensic experts extracting human remains from a mass grave in northern Iraq, evidence of one of this century’s most blatant cases of genocide: the murder of the Yazidi people by the Islamic State.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Midtown, Union Square and Bedford-Stuyvesant.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, roughly 1,700-square-foot apartment with a windowed kitchen, a dining area, a step-down living room, a large primary bedroom with a washer/dryer, a den/home office, ample closets and PTAC heating and air-conditioning, on the seventh floor of a 15-story prewar doorman building with a dedicated basement storage locker, shared laundry, bike storage, a roof deck, a garden and a live-in super. Frederick Warburg Peters and David Harris, Coldwell Banker Warburg, 212-327-9645; cbwarburg.com

headline: All Your Questions About New Covid Shots, Answered
abstract: We asked experts where and when you should get them, and how to lessen the side effects.
lead_paragraph: New Covid-19 vaccines, which can help protect against the most common variants of the virus currently circulating, are now widely available.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Rye, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Ocean City, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 2,193-square-foot home from 1909, newly renovated, with a stone front porch with pillars, a Dutch front door, a stone fireplace, pine floors, a bright dining room that flows into a kitchen with stainless steel appliances and quartz countertops, a quaint family room with a sliding door to the yard, an upper-level en suite primary bedroom that fits a king-size bed and has a walk-in closet, a lower level with storage and recreation space and a detached one-car garage, on 0.1 acres. Sandy Chittenden, 914-879-1837. Julia B Fee Sotheby’s International Realty, williampitt.com

headline: Netanyahu Is Trying to Save Himself. Will He Sink Harris?
abstract: The columnist Thomas L. Friedman explains what Netanyahu’s three key goals mean for the upcoming U.S. election.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s drive to stay in power is harming Israel’s global reputation and complicating the U.S. presidential election for Democrats, the Opinion columnist Thomas L. Friedman argues. In this audio essay, Friedman offers a new name for the ongoing conflict in the Middle East and explains why Netanyahu might be rooting for Donald Trump this November.

headline: Why This Jobs Report Could Be the Most Pivotal One in Years
abstract: It’s tough to overstate how much hinges on Friday’s employment update, from the path for interest rates to the economic outlook.
lead_paragraph: A fresh jobs report set for release on Friday could mark a turning point for the American economy, making it one of the most important and closely watched pieces of data in years.

headline: Harris or Trump? The Prophet of Presidential Elections Is Ready to Call the Race.
abstract: Allan Lichtman’s method for predicting election winners has an impressive track record.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris are scheduled to debate on Sept. 10, but the 2024 presidential election is already in the bag — at least according to Allan Lichtman, the American University historian who’s been dubbed the Nostradamus of presidential election predictions for his near-perfect 40-year track record.

headline: Leaked Reports and Political Heat Are Testing Trust in Economic Data
abstract: The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which tracks prices and employment, faces scrutiny after several missteps. Some questions have gone unanswered.
lead_paragraph: It has been a rough year for the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: What Evangelicals Think of Trump’s Abortion Flip-Flop
abstract: They aren’t voting for Harris, but they might stay home.
lead_paragraph: Former president Trump frequently takes credit for helping to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: The Hot Labor Market Has Melted Away. Just Ask New College Grads.
abstract: Unemployment is still low, but job seekers are competing for fewer openings, and hiring is sluggish. That’s a big turnaround from recent years.
lead_paragraph: For much of the last three years, employers were fighting one another for workers. Now the tables have turned a bit. Few employers are firing. Layoff rates remain near record lows. But fewer employers are hiring.

headline: How Much Space Could They Find in Greater Philadelphia for Less Than $500,000?
abstract: Looking for a change of scenery, a family left the Nevada desert for the cooler climes of the East Coast. These were the houses they considered.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a change of scenery, a family left the Nevada desert for the cooler climes of the East Coast. These were the houses they considered.

headline: Titus Kaphar’s Homecoming
abstract: Plus: an Art Deco hotel reopening in Manhattan, a celebrity facialist’s skin care routine and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I do in the morning if I’m washing my hair is put in an Olaplex hair mask. I shower and do my face massage as I’m cleansing, usually with the Cleansing Complex from iS Clinical. I use Oribe Hair Alchemy Resilience Shampoo and Conditioner or Rōz Foundation Shampoo and Conditioner. One or two times a week I’ll use C & the Moon Malibu Made Body Scrub. I like Nécessaire Eucalyptus Body Wash and I really like Le Labo Santal 33 Shower Gel or Body Bar. I always apply my skin care to the face, neck and chest. First, the iS clinical Pro-Heal Serum Advance+ and then a targeted serum for a concern I’m having. Next I use Skin Better Techno Neck Perfecting Cream. I’ve used MBR CytoLine Eyecare Cream 100 for years. For my final skin-care steps, I apply Reparative Moisture Emulsion from iS clinical and EltaMD UV Clear. On my hair I use the Roz Hair Milk Serum and Santa Lucia Styling Oil every day, even if I haven’t washed my hair, because it helps with frizz. My latest obsession has been the Dyson Supersonic hair dryer. It’s worth every penny. I also love the ColorWOW Dream Coat Supernatural Spray. Every time I use it, people ask if I got a professional blowout, and it lasts for days.

headline: The Viral Blackout Challenge Is Killing Young People. Courts Are Finally Taking It Seriously.
abstract: What should we do when TikTok’s algorithm turns deadly?
lead_paragraph: Rarely will you read about a case with more heartbreaking facts. In 2021, a 10-year-old girl named Nylah Anderson was viewing videos on TikTok, as millions of people do every day, when the app’s algorithm served up a video of the so-called blackout challenge on its For You page. The page suggests videos for users to watch. The blackout challenge encourages people to record themselves as they engage in self-asphyxiation, sometimes to the point of unconsciousness. Nylah saw the challenge, tried it herself and died. She accidentally hanged herself.

headline: Tax Policy Becomes a Fault Line for Harris
abstract: The vice president is relying on tax proposals as a way to show she is different from both President Biden and her Republican rival, Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris is turning to tax policy as a way to differentiate herself from both her Republican rival and her Democratic boss, an attempt to simultaneously project a more moderate image and stand by the soak-the-rich populism that animates much of her party.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 453
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Sept. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level, and whether you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,175
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, September 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A School Shooting in Georgia, and 2 High-Profile Cases Return to Court
abstract: Plus, bogus bands, fake fans and $10 million.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Kamala Harris’s Record on Immigration
abstract: The vice president’s role in border policy has come under intense scrutiny as the election nears.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris moves into the final stretch of her campaign, one of the biggest issues both for voters and for Republicans attacking her is the surge of migrants crossing the southern border over the past four years.

headline: Pope Finds Fervent Fans Among Indonesia’s Transgender Community
abstract: For many trans women living on the fringes of the nation’s society, the Catholic Church is a haven, and Pope Francis a personal hero.
lead_paragraph: The group of trans women in South Jakarta were putting on their Sunday best. They wore feathers, silk, glitter and long eyelashes. Each one draped a rosary around her neck.

headline: The Coming Election Battles
abstract: Polls suggest the presidential contest will be close. Both sides expect a fight over the outcome.
lead_paragraph: There are some big clashes coming in November, both before and after Election Day.

headline: Fugitive Ex-Mayor Whose Case Gripped the Philippines Is Arrested in Indonesia
abstract: Officials have accused Alice Guo of helping criminal syndicates involved in online scams and human trafficking, and have questioned her about whether she was born in China.
lead_paragraph: The case of a former mayor of a small town in the Philippines who is accused of working with organized crime and has been questioned about whether she was born in China has gripped the country for months. This week, she was arrested in Indonesia after fleeing, the Philippine authorities said, and faced extradition.

headline: ‘I’ll Be Right There’ Review: Her Maternal Commitment is Apparent
abstract: Edie Falco plays a matriarch bending over backward for her grown children in this uneven character study.
lead_paragraph: Early in Barbara Loden’s classic indie film “Wanda” (1971), the emotionally dysregulated title character hitches a ride to the courthouse to surrender custody of her children.

headline: ‘Hoard’ Review: Dirty Romancing
abstract: A spiraling teenager and a tenderhearted garbage collector bond over debris in this stunningly unconventional drama.
lead_paragraph: Mothering and madness, trash and trauma erect an empire of filth in “Hoard,” Luna Carmoon’s gut-punchingly original first feature. In scenes that can shift from warily unsettling to plainly disgusting, Carmoon rubs our noses in the dreadful consequences of maternal dysfunction.

headline: ‘Lover of Men’ Review: The Heart of President Lincoln
abstract: Subtitled “The Untold History of Abraham Lincoln,” the film gathers an array of historians to argue that Lincoln had romantic relationships with men.
lead_paragraph: About a century ago, the poet and biographer Carl Sandburg remarked upon the “streaks of lavender” in Abraham Lincoln and a Southern gentleman named Joshua Speed. Aspiring beyond suggestion, Shaun Peterson’s “Lover of Men” mobilizes an impressive array of historians to argue that Lincoln had romantic relationships with men that affected his life deeply.

headline: ‘Look Into My Eyes’ Review: Emotional Rescue
abstract: This fascinating documentary that profiles seven New York City psychics is both profoundly sad and surprisingly hopeful.
lead_paragraph: Before seeing “Look Into My Eyes,” Lana Wilson’s fascinating portrait of seven New York City psychics, I had vague expectations of a humorous overview of human gullibility. Or maybe a useful primer on how to identify the grifters from the gifted. What I did not expect was to emerge with not only a deeper understanding of this strange calling, but far greater empathy for those who seek out its practitioners.

headline: ‘Red Rooms’ Review: A True Crime Obsession Unravels
abstract: A mysterious young woman becomes deeply invested in the trial of an accused serial killer in this courtroom thriller.
lead_paragraph: “Red Rooms,” a disturbing courtroom thriller from Quebec, explores the fascination with serial killers and true crime from an enticingly fresh perspective. Directed by Pascal Plante, it takes the genre’s ingredients — vulnerable girls, male sickos — and adjusts them to the loneliness of the internet age.

headline: Breaking Impasse, Macron Names a Right-Wing Prime Minister
abstract: The president’s choice of Michel Barnier, after an extraordinary delay, inflamed opponents on the left who came out on top in an inconclusive election.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France appointed Michel Barnier, a veteran right-wing politician and the European Union’s former top negotiator on Brexit, as the new prime minister on Thursday, in hopes of breaking a political deadlock that has gripped the country since inconclusive snap parliamentary elections almost two months ago.

headline: Blinken Visits a Haiti Wracked by Corruption and Gangs
abstract: The United States has played a supporting role behind Kenya’s deployment of a security force tasked with helping the Haitian police combat gangs.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken visited Haiti on Thursday in a display of American support for international efforts to wrest the nation from the grip of tyrannical violent gangs.

headline: Astro Bot Review: All History Lessons Should Be This Fun
abstract: About 150 PlayStation characters, including the dragon Spyro and the cylinder-headed prince from Katamari Damacy, make appearances in a paean to Sony’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: Astro Bot, a generally exceptional, imaginative game, features a heroic robot with pixelated eyes of blue who waddles tentatively through the universe like a toddler. But Astro is an ardent puzzle-solver, too, in a game that is a mammoth, interactive pop culture history.

headline: Harris’s Shift on Tax Cheers Her Corporate Backers
abstract: The vice president has proposed raising the levy on capital gains, a break from President Biden’s economic agenda, as she tries to keep big donors and progressives on side.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of largely sticking to President Biden’s economic agenda, Vice President Kamala Harris has made her first break in policy: scaling back a proposed increase of the capital gains tax.

headline: An American Church Thrived in Nicaragua. Then Its Pastors Went to Prison.
abstract: Evangelical pastors led by a Texas missionary in Nicaragua were accused of money laundering, in a widespread crackdown on religious groups.
lead_paragraph: As Nicaragua has come under the tightening grip of its authoritarian government, religious leaders have been among the biggest targets, harassed, arrested and forced into exile.

headline: ‘Rebel Ridge’ Review: Their Corruption, His Destruction
abstract: This crime drama from Jeremy Saulnier stars Aaron Pierre as a man whose run-in with small-town police officers uncovers uncomfortable secrets.
lead_paragraph: A veteran arrives in a rural town to find his friend. He comes in peace — but the police demand submission. “Rebel Ridge,” written and directed by Jeremy Saulnier, wears its “First Blood” inspirations as boldly as John Rambo sported a patch of the American flag. That franchise distended into Afghanistan, where Sylvester Stallone machine-gunned the Red Army during the long Soviet war there. But Saulnier (“Blue Ruin,” “Green Room”), a specialist in thrillers set in the margins of society, keeps this efficient tale of ethical outrage as simple as a punch to the throat — or rather, given its stark cinematography, like a shot of someone patiently walking up to a bully and then punching them in the throat.

headline: That’s a Great Reality TV Set. Let’s Use It Again.
abstract: “The Circle” is one of many current shows using the same state-of-the-art production hub to shoot a variety of international versions.
lead_paragraph: In “The Circle,” a reality competition show on Netflix, a group of strangers are sequestered for days inside a multistory apartment complex, angling to survive rounds of eliminations to win a cash prize, much like “Big Brother.” The twist is that the players can’t see or hear one another, and must communicate via text — people might not be what they seem, and anyone, at any time, could be catfishing.

headline: Judge Sets Deadlines in Trump Election Case, Saying Campaign Is ‘Not Relevant’
abstract: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan laid out a swift schedule for the election interference case against Donald J. Trump after lawyers on both sides shared how they believed the case should proceed.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge declared at a court hearing on Thursday that she would not let former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign for the White House affect the schedule of the criminal case in which he stands accused of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 2, Episode 4: The Trees Have Thoughts
abstract: This week’s episode, which included several Tolkien fan-favorite characters and creatures, is the best of the season thus far.
lead_paragraph: “Rings of Power” Season 2 debuted last week with three plot-heavy episodes, which was probably necessary given that the show had been on hiatus for nearly two years — and given that it took all three to get each of Season 1’s story lines back into play. Unfortunately, Episode 3 was easily the dreariest of the first batch, ending last week’s three-part premiere on a sour note. Light on action and heavy on earnest proclamations, the episode represented “Rings of Power” at its stiffest.

headline: Start-Up Investors Push Back Against Venture Capital’s Bigger-Is-Better Mantra
abstract: A small but vocal group is forming new funds and taking new approaches to counter the swell of money into venture capital in recent years.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 10 years running his own venture capital firm, Nick Chirls decided to call it quits this year.

headline: Nicaragua Releases 135 Political Prisoners on Humanitarian Grounds
abstract: Among those freed under the deal brokered by the U.S. government were 13 affiliated with Mountain Gateway, an American evangelical church.
lead_paragraph: Nicaragua released 135 political prisoners — including 13 people affiliated with an American evangelical church — on humanitarian grounds on Thursday in a deal brokered by the U.S. government, the White House announced.

headline: Here’s why Trump’s lawyers are in court for the election interference case.
abstract: The judge has to begin sorting out which parts of the indictment of the former president must be tossed out because of a Supreme Court ruling on presidential immunity. She’s seeking input on how to do it.
lead_paragraph: The hearing Thursday in the case accusing former President Donald J. Trump of seeking to overturn the 2020 election is largely being held to answer a single question: How should the presiding judge, Tanya S. Chutkan, move the matter forward in light of the Supreme Court’s recent ruling granting Mr. Trump broad immunity from criminal prosecution?

headline: U.K. Prosecutors Drop Indecent Assault Case Against Harvey Weinstein
abstract: The Crown Prosecution Service said that it had “decided that there is no longer a realistic prospect of conviction.”
lead_paragraph: British prosecutors have dropped a case against Harvey Weinstein, the disgraced movie mogul, just two years after authorizing indecent assault charges against him.

headline: California Man Arrested After Shooting Spree Kills at Least 80 Animals
abstract: The hourslong episode in the middle of the night triggered a shelter-in-place order in Monterey County. One official described the scene as “horrible.”
lead_paragraph: A bloody shooting spree in California this week left at least 80 animals dead and sent neighbors fleeing to safety in the middle of the night, the authorities said.

headline: In Michigan, an ‘Unhinged Werewolf’ Will Make It Clear Who Voted
abstract: A contest for the state’s next “I Voted” sticker yielded several winning designs, but a seventh grader’s stood out from the rest.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of the submissions in a statewide contest to design Michigan’s next “I Voted” sticker featured cherry blossoms or American flags fluttering in the wind.

headline: How Swing State Politics Are Sinking a Global Steel Deal
abstract: As the Biden administration nears a decision to block the proposed acquisition of U.S. Steel, the debate over national and economic security is being dwarfed by presidential politics.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has spent the past three years promoting a policy of “friend-shoring,” which aims to contain China and Russia by forging closer ties with U.S. allies like Europe and Japan.

headline: Can We Have Basic Food for Dinner?
abstract: Maybe crispy-edged quesadillas, caramelized roast vegetables and fluffy rice, no marinating or multitasking.
lead_paragraph: Hi everyone, Ali here filling in for Mia. The recipes I develop at New York Times Cooking tempt you with sparkles — jalapeño honey, caper-raisin vinaigrette, sizzled mint — but you know what else I like to cook? Obvious, plain, basic food.

headline: Israeli Raids Paralyze Daily Life for Many in the West Bank
abstract: As an Israeli offensive against Palestinian militant groups stretched to a 10th day, residents said many people were trapped in their homes out of fear.
lead_paragraph: Five Palestinians were killed by an Israeli airstrike on their vehicles early Thursday, Palestinian news media said, as one of the longest and most destructive recent Israeli military raids in the occupied West Bank stretched into a ninth day across several cities.

headline: Are Some Ultraprocessed Foods Worse Than Others?
abstract: A new study may offer the biggest clues yet.
lead_paragraph: Name a common condition — heart disease, Type 2 diabetes, cancer, dementia, irritable bowel syndrome — and chances are good that following a diet high in ultraprocessed foods has been linked to it.

headline: Boulder Mass Shooting Trial Focuses on Accused Gunman’s Mental State
abstract: Lawyers for the accused gunman are using the state’s insanity defense, arguing that he was mentally ill at the time of the 2021 shooting that left 10 people dead at a supermarket.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than three years since a gunman rampaged through a grocery store in Boulder, Colo., killing 10 people before surrendering and being taken into the parking lot, bleeding from his leg and asking to speak with his mother.

headline: The 1980s Art Carnival Luna Luna Will Come to New York
abstract: Avant-garde fairground attractions, including a Basquiat Ferris wheel and a Keith Haring carousel, will fill up the Shed in November.
lead_paragraph: An original Basquiat Ferris wheel and a Keith Haring carousel are two of the high-art-meets-fairground attractions coming to New York this fall when Luna Luna, the once lost art carnival, travels to the Shed in Hudson Yards.

headline: Putin Drives Home a Perilous Point: Ukraine’s East Is Russia’s Main Goal
abstract: Dismissing Ukraine’s recent invasion of Kursk, the Russian leader said Kyiv made a mistake in trying to force Moscow to divert its forces from the Donbas region.
lead_paragraph: As Kyiv raced reinforcements to eastern Ukraine to try to stabilize its buckling defensive lines there, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia amplified his threats against the region on Thursday, calling Moscow’s offensive in the area his military’s “first-priority goal.”

headline: Steve Silberman, 66, Dies; Writer Deepened Understanding of Autism
abstract: Prodded by Oliver Sacks, he wrote a humane, award-winning book about the condition. A music maven, he also wrote liner notes for the Grateful Dead and his friend David Crosby.
lead_paragraph: Steve Silberman, a science journalist whose award-winning book about the history of autism helped broaden the public’s understanding of that often-misunderstood condition and those diagnosed with it, died on Aug. 29 at his home in San Francisco. He was 66.

headline: U.N.C. Reports Declines in Black and Hispanic Enrollment
abstract: Along with Harvard University, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill was one of two schools defending affirmative action in Supreme Court cases last year.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen months after the Supreme Court struck down affirmative action at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the university on Thursday reported sharp declines in enrollment of new Black and Hispanic students compared with a year ago.

headline: Picasso Prints and Brazilian Brilliance at the Independent
abstract: The fair’s third 20th-century-focused edition charts a careful line between safety and excitement.
lead_paragraph: Despite oversaturation, market wobbles, the relentless pace, the sheer expense and every other complaint you may hear this week from a gallerist on a cigarette break, it’s art fair time again in New York — but that’s not without its merits. Fairs like Spring Break, Volta and Clio give younger and less established artists chances to see and be seen while providing city dwellers glimpses of what’s happening elsewhere.

headline: Trump Calls for an Efficiency Commission, an Idea Pushed by Elon Musk
abstract: Donald Trump, in a speech in New York, said the commission would conduct a sweeping audit of the federal government and recommend “drastic reforms” for cutting waste.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump called for the creation of a government efficiency commission in an economic speech in New York on Thursday, adopting a policy idea that was pitched to him by the billionaire businessman Elon Musk.

headline: ‘The Wizard of the Kremlin’ Review: Putting Putin’s Rise Onstage
abstract: The best-selling, much discussed French novel is now a play. It gives a similarly humanizing view of the Russian leader and his inner circle.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was just a matter of time before Vladislav Y. Surkov became a stage character. Surkov, an influential ideologist who spent two decades in the orbit of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, once trained as a theater director; in 2011, the novelist Eduard Limonov described Surkov as having refashioned Russia “into a wonderful postmodernist theater,” according to the London Review of Books.

headline: Hunter Biden Pleads Guilty in Tax Case
abstract: The guilty plea now exposes President Biden’s son to a likely outcome that once seemed unthinkable: significant time behind bars.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden pleaded guilty on Thursday to nine federal tax charges in Los Angeles after telling his legal team that he refused to subject his family to another round of anguish and humiliation after a gut-wrenching gun trial in Delaware three months ago.

headline: Report Details Interview of Georgia Suspect in Prior School Shooting Threat
abstract: The sheriff’s office report reveals more about how investigators were able to trace the online post to the teenager’s account, and why they could not definitively link it to him.
lead_paragraph: The anonymous tips were sent to the F.B.I. last May from as far away as Australia, warning that a user on Discord, a social media platform, had threatened in a chat group to possibly “shoot up a middle school.” The authorities were led to a 13-year-old living in Jackson County, Ga.

headline: They Thought It Was Safe to Go Home. Then They Were Slaughtered.
abstract: Boko Haram killed at least 170 villagers in northeastern Nigeria, community leaders say, in what is likely one of the deadliest attacks in recent years.
lead_paragraph: After Boko Haram fighters threatened them, they could not risk staying. Over a decade, the extremist group had killed tens of thousands of people in the cross-border scrubland around them. So the residents of Mafa, a village in northeast Nigeria’s Yobe State, fled in terror.

headline: At 30, The Armory Show Asks, Can Art Fairs Still be Relevant?
abstract: Among its 235 exhibitors from 30 countries, our critic finds these standout booths — and hails three local curators who have brought some sections exciting new life.
lead_paragraph: The Armory Show was founded 30 years ago by a handful of art dealers who treated the art fair format as a playful, ironic, even experimental affair. Held at the Gramercy Hotel in Manhattan, artworks were displayed on the beds, and viewers wandered from room to room taking in the cheeky display.

headline: 10 Dynamic Wines From Spain to Drink Now
abstract: Great bottles are being made all over the world, but right now no country’s are as exciting or compelling as Spain’s.
lead_paragraph: Spain is the most dynamic wine-producing country in the world.

headline: There’s an Eggplant for That
abstract: Eggplant croquettes, Bolognese, adobo and pretty much everything you could want for aubergine season.
lead_paragraph: At a birthday dinner last week, a pool of satiny, smoky eggplant pried my attention from an otherwise lively conversation. The dish was unassuming, dolloped with a bit of yogurt and a smattering of scallions and herbs. But my eyes ballooned cartoonishly with each bite, this slump of olive oil-drenched, simply seasoned pulp a redheaded bombshell to my Tex Avery wolf.

headline: U.S. Charges American Commentator Who Works for Russian State TV
abstract: Dimitri K. Simes, who was an adviser to Donald J. Trump’s first campaign, and his wife, Anastasia Simes, are accused of violating U.S. sanctions.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department indicted an American commentator for Russian television on Thursday as part of a broader effort by the government to crack down on Russia’s attempts to influence American politics ahead of November’s presidential election.

headline: ‘Beetlejuice Beetlejuice’ Review: Delightfully Undead Again
abstract: Tim Burton has brought the band back together — Michael Keaton, Winona Ryder, even Bob the shrunken head guy — for a fun but less edgy sequel.
lead_paragraph: After more than three decades and assorted ups, downs and spinoffs like an animated series and Broadway musical, most of the key players in the original “Beetlejuice” band — Tim Burton, Michael Keaton, Winona Ryder, Catherine O’Hara, Bob the shrunken-head guy — are back together. A lot has predictably changed along the way, yet one of the enjoyable aspects about reunion tours is that when a group has charmed its way into your consciousness, like this one did back in the day, a.k.a. 1988, you don’t mind (too much) its sporadically sour notes and slack timing.

headline: Teenage E-Cigarette Use Drops to a 10-Year Low
abstract: The percentage of middle and high school students reporting that they vaped tobacco products declined to about a third of the peak levels in 2019, a new survey shows.
lead_paragraph: The number of teenagers who reported using e-cigarettes in 2024 has tumbled from a worrisome peak reached five years ago, raising hopes among public health officials for a sustained reversal in vaping trends among adolescents.

headline: German Police Shoot Gunman Dead Near Israeli Consulate in Munich
abstract: The shootout with an 18-year-old Austrian came on the anniversary of the attack on the Munich Olympics that left 11 Israelis dead, and was being investigated as a possible terrorist attack.
lead_paragraph: Police officers in Munich shot and killed a gunman not far from the Israeli Consulate and a museum about the city’s Nazi-era history on Thursday, the anniversary of the terrorist attack on the 1972 Olympic Games in the city, in which 11 Israelis athletes were killed.

headline: How Georgia’s Gun Laws Compare With Those of Other States
abstract: The state does not have universal background checks for gun purchases, safe storage laws or a so-called red-flag law — measures instituted elsewhere in response to gun violence.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Brian Kemp signed a law in 2022 that allowed most Georgia residents to carry a firearm without a concealed carry permit, he celebrated the expansion of gun rights in the state.

headline: The School Shooting Horror in Georgia
abstract: Readers discuss gun laws, trying the suspect as an adult, defining mass shootings and more. Also: A view from AIPAC; an anti-family Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mayor Eric Adams Faces Crisis as U.S. Investigations Reach Inner Circle
abstract: As federal agents seize the phones of the mayor’s top aides, multiplying inquiries threaten to destabilize Mr. Adams’s ability to run New York City.
lead_paragraph: Federal agents on Wednesday zeroed in on the highest ranks of Mayor Eric Adams’s administration, searching a home and seizing the phones of the New York City police commissioner, the first deputy mayor, the schools chancellor and others, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: New Pencils, New Folders … and New Schools
abstract: Some students in New York City public schools returned to class in brand-new schools or buildings.
lead_paragraph: A new school year often means new notebooks, pencils and folders. For some New York City students this year, it means a new school or building, too.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 9, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Surprising New Research Links Infant Mortality to Crashing Bat Populations
abstract: Without bats to eat insects, farmers turned to more pesticides, a study found. That appears to have increased infant deaths.
lead_paragraph: The connections are commonsense but the conclusion is shocking.

headline: Reporting From Row Z at the U.S. Open
abstract: Two New York Times reporters climbed their way to the nosebleed sections of Arthur Ashe Stadium, where they met dedicated tennis fans.
lead_paragraph: The ascent to the top row of Arthur Ashe Stadium is arduous, and not for those without strong legs — or a strong dedication to watching really good tennis.

headline: Large Storm Could Bring 10 Inches of Rain to Parts of Gulf Coast
abstract: Heavy rain was expected to last through the weekend in parts of Mississippi and Louisiana, including New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Flood watches were issued on the Gulf Coast from Galveston Bay in Texas to Gulfport, Miss., on Thursday as a storm threatened the region with heavy rain that could last through the weekend, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Georgia Shooting Might Have Been ‘Way Worse’ Without Security Steps
abstract: Measures like a new alert system did not prevent a shooting, but did save lives, according to law enforcement officials.
lead_paragraph: The deadliest episode of school violence in Georgia’s history could have ended with even more bloodshed, if not for the school’s newly installed security systems, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Generating Electricity
abstract: America isn’t making electricity the way it did two decades ago. How have energy sources changed since 2001?
lead_paragraph: The above graph of the power produced by energy source between 2001 and 2023 was previously published in a New York Times article. Comparable graphs were published for each of the 50 states.

headline: Democrats Hope Abortion Will Save the Senate, but It Might Not Be Enough
abstract: The party’s candidates are likely to benefit from running alongside ballot measures to protect abortion rights. But the deeply conservative nature of many of these states poses a serious challenge.
lead_paragraph: As Debbie Mucarsel-Powell revved up the Democratic faithful in a restaurant named for Thomas Edison, she was looking for a little electricity in her campaign to unseat Senator Rick Scott of Florida.

headline: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s (almost) the autumn of a presidential election year, which means that the political publishing season is suddenly upon us: Two of our recommended books this week cast an eye back on Donald Trump’s time in office, one from an insider’s vantage and one from the perspective of an experienced national security reporter. Also up this week, a Pulitzer-winning poet’s new collection, a satirical novel of race and class, a wide-ranging celebration of the Bronx and an expansive, admiring biography of the writer Christopher Isherwood. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: How Much Screen Time Should Toddlers Have? None, Sweden Says.
abstract: Children under the age of 2 should not be exposed to any screens, Swedish public health authorities said, part of a growing effort to limit phone use by youngsters.
lead_paragraph: Swedish public health authorities recommended this week that children under the age of 2 should not use any digital media, as parents, pediatricians and governments struggle to respond to the challenges of today’s tech-soaked world.

headline: Funeral for Nigerians Killed in Boko Haram Attack
abstract: A funeral in Yobe, Nigeria, for residents killed in the village of Mafa. Thirty-four bodies were brought to the nearest town, but community leaders say many more were buried locally.
lead_paragraph: A funeral in Yobe, Nigeria, for residents killed in the village of Mafa. Thirty-four bodies were brought to the nearest town, but community leaders say many more were buried locally.

headline: A Barrier-Breaking Conductor Will Lead the Seattle Symphony
abstract: Xian Zhang will be the first woman and person of color to lead the Seattle Symphony, and one of only two women leading a top-tier American orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Xian Zhang, a renowned conductor who has helped bring the New Jersey Symphony to new heights over the past eight years, will be the Seattle Symphony’s next music director, the orchestra announced on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Indicts Members of Russian Military Intelligence Over Cyberattack on Ukraine
abstract: The indictment unsealed on Thursday comes as the United States expands its hunt for Russia’s most elite cyberwarriors.
lead_paragraph: The United States expanded its hunt on Thursday for Russia’s most elite cyberwarriors, indicting five members of the country’s military intelligence agency for attacks on Ukraine and American companies in the run-up to the invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

headline: Fact-checking JD Vance’s Attacks on Tim Walz Over a Transgender Sanctuary Law in Minnesota
abstract: It was the latest effort by the Trump campaign to use Mr. Walz’s record on transgender rights to attack him as a far-left liberal.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio on Wednesday attacked Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, his Democratic rival, for a Minnesota law enshrining rights for transgender children to gender-affirming care, promoting a baseless claim that the law allows a state to engage in “legalized kidnapping” of transgender children.

headline: 47-Year-Old Man Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn Subway Station
abstract: The man, who a neighbor said had recently started a new job, was shot in the head inside the Rockaway Avenue train station late Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: A 47-year-old man was fatally shot in the head inside the Rockaway Avenue train station in Brooklyn late Wednesday night, the police said.

headline: The State Wanted Hotels and Golf Courses in Florida Parks. Floridians Revolted.
abstract: Faced with intense bipartisan opposition, Gov. Ron DeSantis shelved the plan. It was a rare policy setback for a leader used to getting his way.
lead_paragraph: A plan to build golf courses, pickleball courts and hotels in some of Florida’s popular state parks, which became public late last month when a state employee decided to leak it, has set off extraordinary backlash against the administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis.

headline: Saudi Arabia and Allies Delay Plan to Increase Oil Output
abstract: OPEC Plus will extend its cuts until at least December. Demand has weakened, and other countries, including the United States, are expected to continue to increase production.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and seven other members of the oil-producing group known as OPEC Plus said on Thursday that they would extend production cuts until at least December, amid recent pressure on oil prices.

headline: What if I’m the ‘Friend’ Donald Trump Referred To?
abstract: His “weave” conveys meaning, I’ll give him that. But it says something he does not intend.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s word-salad oratory has always been a distinctive feature of his public life, leaving some observers to grasp for a novel way to describe it. Last week Trump himself gave it a name, one that sounds kind of like a ’70s dance: “the weave.”

headline: Federal Judge Temporarily Blocks Another Pillar of Biden’s Student Debt Plan
abstract: The plan would affect millions of borrowers struggling with runaway interest and others who were still paying off loans after decades. It was set to take effect this fall.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge placed a temporary hold on another component of President Biden’s student debt relief plan on Thursday, siding with a coalition of seven Republican states that filed a lawsuit to halt the program on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Election Looms Over Climate Talks With China
abstract: Experts believe the outcome of the race for the White House could determine how ambitious China’s climate efforts will be.
lead_paragraph: As John Podesta, President Biden’s climate envoy, wraps up three days of talks in Beijing, China’s willingness to fight global warming could depend on the outcome of this fall’s presidential election in the United States, energy experts said.

headline: The Electric Vehicle Future Is Coming. Just a Little More Slowly.
abstract: Though large automakers are delaying their plans to introduce new all-electric models, the E.V. industry is still the future, experts say.
lead_paragraph: The race to electrify America’s cars is looking more like a slog these days. In the past few months, several automakers announced plans to pull back on introducing new electric models or have scaled back some of their decarbonization goals.

headline: It’s the Hottest Neighborhood in All of Los Angeles. (Bring Water.)
abstract: Woodland Hills has become the poster child for sweltering temperatures in the Los Angeles area, a mere 15 miles from the Pacific Ocean.
lead_paragraph: It was once touted as a paradise “tempered by ocean breezes” — or so went the sales pitch of an ambitious developer more than a century ago.

headline: Breakfast for Dinner With a Glass of Wine
abstract: Montague Diner, NoMad Diner and Bubby’s have all the pancakes, syrup and eggs you need at 8 p.m.
lead_paragraph: When I was in elementary school, my dad often traveled for work. My sister and I whined and moaned about it, but there were two silver linings: 1. We’d each be getting new Beanie Babies, purchased at whichever airport he was flying out of, and 2. Our mom would make breakfast for dinner while he was gone.

headline: For Unforgettable Outfits From Fashion Week, Look to the After-Parties
abstract: Inside Boucheron’s garden soiree, a packed club for LaQuan Smith, Off-White’s bash in SoHo, Graydon Carter’s love letter to Italy and an early 2000s throwback.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week brought a ripple of parties across the city, where urban cowboys, indie-sleaze-aspiring revelers and stylish, timeworn New Yorkers strutted their stuff. It was not just vamping models and eager spectators pumping out looks. Off the runways, a less curated undercurrent (or at least one carefully chosen to appear so) took over after sundown. See who was out and what they wore.

headline: 4 Big Airlines Face U.S. Inquiry Over Frequent Flier Programs
abstract: The Transportation Department ordered American, Delta, Southwest and United to share more information about their rewards practices to ensure they are fair to consumers and rivals.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department announced on Thursday that it was investigating the rewards programs of the country’s four biggest airlines, part of the agency’s continuing efforts to bolster protections for air travelers.

headline: Illegal Police Stops Have Risen Under Mayor Adams, Despite Court Mandate
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams promised police reforms, but a monitor found that officers, including the anti-gun units the mayor revived, continue to illegally stop, frisk and search people.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Mayor Eric Adams of New York ordered the Police Department to revive specialized units focused on getting firearms off the streets, the squads are stopping, frisking and searching too many people in violation of the law, according to a court-appointed monitor.

headline: Suspect Claimed Online Threats Had Come From Hacked Account
abstract: The father of the Georgia school shooting suspect told investigators he would be “mad as hell” if his son had made the threats, according to a transcript. “Then all the guns will go away.”
lead_paragraph: The father of the teenager accused of Georgia’s deadliest school shooting told investigators looking into an online threat last year that he had been teaching his son about guns and hunting, and that the boy claimed that his account had been hacked.

headline: Larry Ellison Will Control Paramount After Merger
abstract: An F.C.C. filing shows that companies affiliated with Mr. Ellison will own most of the voting interest currently held by Shari Redstone.
lead_paragraph: When the takeover of Paramount was announced in July, the Skydance founder David Ellison was introduced as the new mogul atop the parent company of CBS and MTV.

headline: Friday Briefing: A Judge Weighs a Monumental Trump Decision
abstract: Plus, the clothes that changed men’s fashion.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than two months away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Anti-Polio Campaign in Gaza Enters New Phase, Hours After Deadly Strike
abstract: As the mass vaccination campaign shifted Thursday from central to southern Gaza, an Israeli strike reportedly killed four in an area where inoculations had just concluded.
lead_paragraph: Hours before families in Gaza lined up on Thursday to start the second phase of an emergency polio vaccination campaign, a deadly Israeli airstrike hit near a hospital in an area where a previous round of inoculations had just concluded.

headline: Hunter Biden Pleaded Guilty
abstract: Also, teenage vaping dropped to a 10-year low. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, pleaded guilty today to nine federal tax charges in Los Angeles. He told his lawyers that he did not want to subject his family to another round of humiliation after his wrenching gun trial in Delaware nearly three months ago.

headline: Trump Praises Tariffs, and William McKinley, to Power Brokers
abstract: In an address about the kind of economy he hopes to build for the 21st century, the former president harked back to the end of another century: the 19th.
lead_paragraph: The titans of finance who gathered on Thursday at the Economic Club of New York may have hoped to hear how former President Donald J. Trump would take the nation into the era of artificial intelligence, private space travel and self-driving electric cars.

headline: Rich Homie Quan, Melodic Atlanta Rapper, Dies at 34
abstract: At one time affiliated with Young Thug, he had a hit in 2015 with “Flex (Ooh, Ooh, Ooh),” which spawned a dance craze.
lead_paragraph: Rich Homie Quan, an Atlanta rapper who played a role in the city’s thriving hip-hop scene in the 2010s, died on Thursday in Atlanta. He was 34.

headline: Woman in France Testifies Against Husband Accused of Bringing Men to Rape Her
abstract: Gisèle Pelicot spoke of the horror of being told by the police that they had evidence her husband had drugged her for years and brought men into their home to join him in raping her.
lead_paragraph: If the sight of dozens of men accused of raping her, including her husband of many decades, upset Gisèle Pelicot, she did not let it show. She swept into a packed courtroom on Thursday with steely poise, her face composed, her eyes dry beneath sunglasses. Her adult children trailed behind her.

headline: The TikTok to Hollywood Pipeline
abstract: Tareasa Johnson captivated millions on social media with a multipart story about her ex-husband’s lies. Now, it’s slated to become a TV show.
lead_paragraph: What happens after you go viral is almost as uncertain as the possibility of going viral in the first place. You could get dragged. You could get milkshake-ducked. You could also get a Hollywood deal.

headline: Georgia Governor Faces New Pressure Over Far-Right Elections Board Takeover
abstract: A bipartisan alliance looks to rein in what it sees as a rogue board aligned with the far right.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! This election is a contest for votes — but there are also battles brewing over how those votes will be counted. Tonight, we’re looking at three stories about democracy and the fight over election integrity — beginning with some news from my colleague Nick Corasaniti. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Brian Ketcham, Effective Foe of Traffic and Smog, Dies at 85
abstract: An engineer and influential environmentalist in New York, he fought for bus lanes, bridge tolls and limits on parking and against more highways, as in the aborted Westway plan.
lead_paragraph: Brian T. Ketcham, an engineer and influential environmentalist who promoted mass transit and favored bridge tolls, bus lanes, limits on parking and other curbs on vehicular traffic in New York City, died on Aug. 21 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Bacon Prices and the Windmills of Trump’s Mind
abstract: Who you gonna believe, him or your lying eyes?
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve become obsessed with bacon — or, more accurately, with Donald Trump’s obsession with the price of bacon, which has long been his favorite gauge of inflation. For it seems to me that Trump’s false claims about bacon prices, and his assertions about what’s driving them, offer a window into his judgment. And the view isn’t pretty.

headline: The Junkification of American Life
abstract: Why we want the wrong things.
lead_paragraph: Back in February, the music historian Ted Gioia wrote an essay on the state of American culture. He argued that many creative people want to create art (work that puts demands on people), but all the commercial pressures push them to create entertainment (which gives audiences what they want). As a result, for the past many years, entertainment (superhero movies) has been swallowing up art (literary novels and serious dramas).

headline: Tip on School Shooting Threat Last Year Led to Suspect’s Door
abstract: The teenager charged with killing four people at his Georgia high school on Wednesday denied making an online threat, and the authorities could not prove he did. He, and now his father, face murder charges.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON, Ga. — The threat posted online last year to “shoot up a middle school” was the kind that the authorities have become all too familiar with in the United States.

headline: Telegram’s Founder, in First Comments Since Arrest, Defends the App
abstract: Pavel Durov, held in France since last month, blamed “growing pains” for the company’s problems and pledged to make improvements.
lead_paragraph: Pavel Durov, the founder of the online communications tool Telegram, said on Thursday that it was a “misguided approach” to hold him personally responsible for the spread of illicit content on the platform.

headline: Purported Rembrandt Painting Found in a Maine Attic Sells for $1.4 Million
abstract: “Portrait of a Girl,” a 17th-century work believed to be by the Dutch master, had been hiding in a home in Maine.
lead_paragraph: The attic, long a repository of discarded toys and the like, can sometimes turn up treasures.

headline: Florida Health Agency Targets Abortion Rights Ballot Measure
abstract: A state agency claimed that the referendum “threatens women’s safety.” Critics say the website is unethical and may violate the law.
lead_paragraph: The Florida agency charged with regulating health care providers, including abortion clinics, publicly opposed a proposed ballot amendment that would guarantee abortion rights, a move that critics say is unethical and also, perhaps, a violation of state law.

headline: Walz’s Pennsylvania Campaign Swing Underscores Challenges in the Battleground
abstract: With his daughter, Hope, in tow, Gov. Tim Walz made stops in red-leaning parts of a state that both parties see as critical to victory, but his events featured limited interactions with voters.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota on Thursday capped two days of crisscrossing Pennsylvania, talking up Vice President Kamala Harris’s experience, taking shots at former President Donald J. Trump and making his now familiar pleas to voters that they fight for freedom with optimism.

headline: 2 Brothers Sentenced to More Than 17 Years in Prison in Sextortion Scheme
abstract: The brothers from Nigeria helped run an operation that solicits nude photographs and holds them as ransom. Prosecutors said it resulted in the death of a high school student.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Michigan on Thursday sentenced two brothers from Nigeria to 17 and a half years in prison for their roles in a social media sextortion scheme that claimed more than 100 victims across the United States and resulted in the death of a high school student.

headline: Father of Accused Georgia Shooter Charged With Two Counts of Second-Degree Murder
abstract: He was also charged with four counts of involuntary manslaughter and eight counts of cruelty to children, all “directly connected with the actions of his son and allowing him to possess a weapon,” an official said.
lead_paragraph: The father of the 14-year-old accused of killing four people at his Georgia high school was arrested and charged on Thursday with two counts of second-degree murder in connection with the attack, the state’s Bureau of Investigation said.

headline: Judge Rejects Key Part of N.C.A.A. Antitrust Settlement With Athletes
abstract: The concern over restrictions on some payments raises uncertainty on whether a landmark agreement on compensating athletes can be reached and approved.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a key element of a proposed $2.8 billion settlement of an antitrust lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. and the major athletic conferences, throwing into uncertainty an agreement that had been largely seen as ushering in a new era in college sports.

headline: What Female Llamas Do
abstract: Adrian Johnson opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: It’s Been the Hottest Summer on Record, European Officials Say
abstract: The excessive heat worldwide suggests the full year will also be a record-breaker, according to Copernicus, the E.U. agency that tracks global warming.
lead_paragraph: The summer of “brat,” the Paris Olympics and political conventions may be winding down, but the heat in 2024 is still going strong.

headline: Vance Calls School Shootings a Grim ‘Fact of Life’ as He Backs Increased Security
abstract: Democrats seized on his comments, arguing that JD Vance was resigned to the reality of school shootings.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio said on Thursday that school shootings were an unfortunate “fact of life,” and he called for strengthened security measures in public schools while he spoke at a campaign event in Phoenix.

headline: 7-Eleven Rejects Takeover Bid From Big Canadian Chain
abstract: Japan’s Seven & i Holdings, the operator of 7-Eleven, has rebuffed a buyout offer that would have been the largest foreign-led acquisition of a Japanese company.
lead_paragraph: The owner of 7-Eleven has rejected a buyout offer from a Canadian convenience store giant, snubbing a deal that most likely would have been the largest foreign-led acquisition of a Japanese company.

headline: Quote of the Day: It’s the Hottest Neighborhood in All of Los Angeles. (Bring Water.)
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 6, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Family-friendly area, big lots for homes, good schools — I think it’s enough, no?”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 6, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a South Dakota cavern in which particle physicists are working to study neutrinos misspelled the surname of a project official. He is Mike Headley, not Headly. Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Two Souls in the Same Orbit Finally Collide
abstract: Kimberly Stokes and Dexter Mason were connected in several ways as adolescents, but didn’t connect until college and, later, an auto event.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Lauren Stokes and Dexter Clay Mason did not meet until adulthood, but their paths could have crossed much earlier in life.

headline: A Courtship Filled with Dijon Chicken and Love Notes
abstract: Molly Shoemaker and Cody Wymore met at a community theater in 2018. He impressed her by bringing in home-cooked meals.
lead_paragraph: During the 2018 production of “Ragtime” for the AfterWork Theater in Manhattan, Molly Antoinette Shoemaker and Cody James Wymore were determined to keep things professional. She was the show’s director and he, the music director.

headline: Like Jay Gatsby, He Threw Parties to Get Her Attention. It Finally Worked.
abstract: After Andrew Quintero spotted Sophia Babai on Instagram in 2016, it took four years and the help of a mutual friend to finally meet her in person.
lead_paragraph: In November 2020, Andrew Quintero rented Blu Mar, a seafood restaurant in the Hamptons, to host a large dinner party in hopes that Sophia Farah Babai would attend. That night he watched Ms. Babai’s friends walk in, but she wasn’t among them. Again.

headline: From Hostel Bunk Mates to Life Partners
abstract: As backpackers who met in Australia in 2017, Ryan Hawkins wrote to Naina Rishiraj: “One day I hope we can be in the same place for a long time.” His hope came true.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Naina Rishiraj’s uncle died from a heart attack at 60. He had been working his entire life with the dream of traveling the world once he retired. But, despite being “fit as a fiddle,” Ms. Rishiraj said, he passed away suddenly and never got to live that dream.

headline: Japan Tries to Reclaim Its Clout as a Global Tech Leader
abstract: Japanese chip companies are tapping billions of dollars and collaborating with foreign firms as part of new government policies that look outward.
lead_paragraph: China’s envy-inducing success in using industrial policy to expand its economy and finance green manufacturing has helped kick off a fevered scrimmage among nations to develop and protect their own hometown businesses.

headline: Touching My First Time for the Last Time
abstract: He couldn’t speak or move, but the sexual energy between us was still palpable.
lead_paragraph: I lost my virginity in New Jersey at a strip mall motel replete with a red heart-shaped bathtub and a water bed. I thought it was the most romantic place in the world because I was with the first man I ever trusted, Johnnie.

headline: In the Pacific, a ‘Dumping Ground’ for Priests Accused or Convicted of Abuse
abstract: Over a decades-long period, more than 30 Catholic priests and missionaries moved to remote island nations after they had allegedly abused children in the West, or had been found to do so.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis will be welcomed by children bearing flowers, a 21-gun salute and a candlelight vigil after he lands in Papua New Guinea on Friday. It will be the first papal visit in three decades to the Pacific Islands, a deeply Christian region — but one that has played a little-known role in the clergy abuse scandal that has stained the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Nurses Win a Bigger Role as Doctors Strike in South Korea
abstract: As hospitals struggle from a monthslong walkout, nurses have picked up some of the slack. A new law gives them more responsibilities and, they say, greater recognition.
lead_paragraph: Tensions between doctors and nurses can often simmer underneath the surface. In South Korea, they have spilled into the open as a monthslong doctors’ strike strains the nation’s hospitals.

headline: How Priests Accused of Abuse End Up in Pacific Nations
abstract: Over a period of decades, at least 34 priests and missionaries left their home countries in the West for the Pacific Islands after they allegedly sexually abused children, or were found to have done so, according to court records, government inquiries, survivor testimonies, news media reports and comments by church officials. The pattern suggests that in some cases, Catholic organizations saw Pacific nations as a “dumping ground” for abusive clergy. Pete McKenzie, a freelance journalist, explains.
lead_paragraph: Over a period of decades, at least 34 priests and missionaries left their home countries in the West for the Pacific Islands after they allegedly sexually abused children, or were found to have done so, according to court records, government inquiries, survivor testimonies, news media reports and comments by church officials. The pattern suggests that in some cases, Catholic organizations saw Pacific nations as a “dumping ground” for abusive clergy. Pete McKenzie, a freelance journalist, explains.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump’s sentencing on federal charges.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than two months away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: China Stops Foreign Adoptions, Ending a Complicated Chapter
abstract: Beijing said the move was in line with international trends, as more countries have limited such adoptions. Many would-be adoptive families were left in limbo.
lead_paragraph: For three decades, China sent tens of thousands of young children overseas for adoption as it enforced a strict one-child policy that forced many families to abandon their babies. Now the government will no longer allow most foreign adoptions, a move that it said was in line with global trends.

headline: Housing in Ireland Is Broken
abstract: Are the thousands of empty properties scattered across the country any kind of solution?
lead_paragraph: Frank O’Connor and Jude Sherry wanted to show me another side of Cork.

headline: Is Brisbane Ready to Be the Equal of Sydney and Melbourne?
abstract: Many don’t see Brisbane in the same light as the other two cities, but the Queensland capital is showing it, too, has cultural heft.
lead_paragraph: Brisbane has always been behind Sydney and Melbourne as Australia’s No. 3 city, both in population and international renown. But last week it trumped the other two to be the top choice of Jean Paul Gaultier, the international fashion icon.

headline: Typhoon Yagi Expected to Strengthen Before Hitting Vietnam
abstract: Yagi, one of 2024’s strongest storms, hit the southern Chinese island of Hainan on Friday. It is forecast to make landfall in Vietnam on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Yagi made landfall in southern China on Friday as it forced more than a million evacuations, shuttered schools and businesses, disrupted travel and raised alarms about the risks of landslides and floods.

headline: Word of the Day: bastion
abstract: This word has appeared in 214 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word bastion has appeared in 214 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 3 in “For Lithuania, Unease Over a Growing Russian-Speaking Diaspora” by Anatoly Kurmanaev, Alina Lobzina and Tomas Dapkus:

headline: Seth Meyers: Trump and Vance ‘Can’t Beat the Weird Charges’
abstract: The “Late Night” host said that Republican efforts to turn the accusations back on Democrats are “only making things worse.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Fire at School Dormitory in Kenya Kills at Least 18 Children
abstract: At least 70 students are still unaccounted for, although officials urged people not to jump to conclusions about their fate.
lead_paragraph: At least 18 children died when a fire ripped through the dormitory of their boarding school north of the Kenyan capital of Nairobi, officials said on Friday, and there were concerns that the death toll could rise.

headline: Judge Delays Trump’s Sentencing Until Nov. 26, After Election Day
abstract: The decision by Justice Juan M. Merchan means voters will be left in the dark about whether the former president will face time behind bars.
lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal case in Manhattan postponed his sentencing until after Election Day, a significant victory for the former president as he seeks to overturn his conviction and win back the White House.

headline: Facing Entrenched School Segregation, New Jersey Tries Something New
abstract: New Jersey is holding mediation sessions to settle a segregation lawsuit. If an agreement is reached, other states may take notice.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Latino and Black families in New Jersey filed a lawsuit that landed like a gut punch to the state’s progressive reputation. Public schools in New Jersey were alarmingly segregated, the plaintiffs argued, in violation of the state Constitution.

headline: 40 Years Later, Does ‘Bright Lights, Big City’ Still Resonate?
abstract: Remembered for capturing ’80s downtown decadence, Jay McInerney’s iconic novel predicted the mood of New York City today.
lead_paragraph: Late in the summer of 1984, as Nancy Reagan was bringing her “Just Say No” campaign to potential teenage drug hounds around the country, the publishing world was transfixed by a first novel set amid the fleeting, febrile pleasures of yes. Jay McInerney’s “Bright Lights, Big City” arrived 40 years ago this week with an initial print run of 15,000 and a future that was hard to envision.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Bootmobile
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: In Need of a Change, He Bought a Bespoke Airstream Trailer
abstract: The customized home has a propane range, an incinerating toilet and movable solar panels (for off-the-grid travel). Now the only question is where to go next.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Walsh left a 20-year career as an English teacher and administrator for the New York Education Department, he was looking for the same thing many people are: a little excitement.

headline: 100 Degrees at Midnight: California Coast Swelters in ‘Concerning’ Heat
abstract: Temperatures in the region were forecast to remain high into the weekend, with more than 31 million people under excessive heat warnings.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures hovered above 100 degrees Fahrenheit along parts of the California coast early Friday, creating unbearable conditions past midnight as officials warned that the excessive heat would last through the weekend.

headline: 12 Video Games Coming This Fall
abstract: The calendar brings a Legend of Zelda game with Zelda in charge, an Assassin’s Creed set in Japan and new role-playing games.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Assassin’s Creed Shadows has been delayed until Feb. 14, 2025.]

headline: Classical Music and Opera This Fall: Programs, Premieres and More
abstract: Osvaldo Golijov’s Lorca-inspired opera comes to New York, and the pianist Igor Levit plays with the Cleveland Orchestra, among other highlights.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera’s gamble on contemporary work continues. Celebrations of big anniversaries for two musical innovators, Charles Ives and Pierre Boulez, are worth seeking out. And Carnegie Hall will host world-class orchestras. But don’t expect Gustavo Dudamel, the New York Philharmonic’s next music director, to be a fixture yet; until 2026, he is dedicated to the Los Angeles Philharmonic, which opens Carnegie’s season with a three-night residency. Here are highlights from this fall’s performance calendar. (Locations are in Manhattan unless otherwise specified; dates are subject to change.)

headline: Art Shows and Exhibitions to See This Fall
abstract: This packed season features Scott Burton, Alvin Ailey and the Brooklyn Museum’s 200th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Dance is in vogue this fall, with a pair of major museum shows for the choreographers Alvin Ailey and Ralph Lemon. Prints are having a moment, too, as Mexican and Japanese examples show up in New York and Washington, D.C. Otherwise, the onrushing season is the usual wild mix of Renaissance painting, innovative video art, subway car graffiti, documentary photography and quietly subversive corporate lobby art, from New York City to Columbus, Ohio, and on to California. (Dates are subject to change; locations are in Manhattan unless otherwise specified.)

headline: Dance Performances, Festivals and More Coming This Fall
abstract: The season brings new works by Kyle Abraham and Helen Pickett, as well as revivals of City Ballet’s “Coppélia” and Bill T. Jones’s “Still/Here.”
lead_paragraph: The dance world is in a festive mood this fall: It seems like everyone has a big anniversary to celebrate. All that attention on the past may explain why the programming sometimes tilts conservative, especially in ballet, where evening-length storytelling remains de rigueur. But the stories are getting more ambitious, the voices telling them more varied. And there are still plenty of artists pushing in the opposite direction. Some of the season’s most exciting dances can’t even be contained by theater walls, finding their stages in parks, museums, historic buildings, farm fields. (Locations are in Manhattan unless otherwise specified; dates are subject to change.)

headline: Do You Love a Good Tear-Jerker?
abstract: When was the last time you cried during a movie? Do you wish more films were made to bring their audiences to tears?
lead_paragraph: What’s your favorite kind of movie? Action-adventure? Science fiction? Comedy?

headline: 27 TV Shows to Watch This Fall
abstract: A “WandaVision” spinoff, Colin Farrell in “The Penguin” and Alfonso Cuarón’s “Disclaimer” are among the season’s tantalizing offerings.
lead_paragraph: The fall television season is short on blockbuster titles — a “Star Wars” extension, “Skeleton Crew,” from Disney+, and perhaps HBO’s as-yet-unscheduled “Dune: Prophecy.” But there is plenty that’s of interest, including Alfonso Cuarón’s return to television with “Disclaimer” on Apple TV+, Colin Farrell’s incarnation of the Penguin for HBO and Kathryn Hahn’s reboot of her “WandaVision” character in “Agatha All Along” for Disney+. There will also be new seasons of offbeat but proven comedies like “Bad Sisters” on Apple TV+, “Somebody Somewhere” on HBO and “What We Do in the Shadows,” which, unlike its vampire heroes, will perish after its sixth season on FX. Here are 25 shows to keep an eye out for this fall, in chronological order; all dates are subject to change.

headline: How a Single Family Was Shot Dead on a Street in Gaza
