abstract: The European Union, facing a shrinking share of the global economy, needs to increase its spending by nearly $900 billion a year, according to a long-awaited report from Mario Draghi.
lead_paragraph: Europe must increase public investment by nearly $900 billion a year in sectors like technology and defense, according to a long-awaited report published Monday in response to growing anxieties about the continental economy’s lagging behind that of the United States and China.

headline: A Tug Between Russia and Europe Divides a Tiny Balkan Nation
abstract: A falling-out between former political allies in Montenegro has complicated the country’s efforts to join the European Union and curb pro-Russian influence.
lead_paragraph: Elected last year on promises to accelerate a shift out of Russia’s orbit of influence and into the European Union, the government of Montenegro recently nominated a curious candidate as its ambassador in Moscow — a Russian citizen.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,179
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, September 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 457
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Sept. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Taliban Have Reached a New Low. How Can the World Respond?
abstract: New rules that make a woman’s voice illegal in public show why the world must make gender apartheid a crime against humanity.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Taliban retook control of Afghanistan in 2021 with promises that — this time — they would be more moderate, they have played a deceitful game.

headline: The Harris Honeymoon Is Over
abstract: Almost 30 percent of voters said they needed to learn more about her.
lead_paragraph: Is Kamala Harris’s surge beginning to ebb? That’s the question raised by the recent New York Times/Siena College poll, which finds Donald J. Trump narrowly ahead of Ms. Harris among likely voters nationwide.

headline: Trump and Harris Neck and Neck in a New Poll, and a Manhunt in Kentucky
abstract: Plus, a Pulitzer-winning Super Bowl halftime headliner.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Abortion on the Ballot
abstract: We explain the 10 measures that would let voters decide abortion policy in their states.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing that captures how the abortion debate has changed in the last two years, it’s ballot initiatives. In the five decades that Roe v. Wade was the law of the land, almost every abortion question on state ballots was put there by anti-abortion groups. Now the reverse is true. In the last two years, abortion rights activists won seven out of seven ballot initiatives. So this fall, they’re swinging big, asking voters in 10 states to establish a constitutional right to abortion.

headline: Patti Scialfa, Bruce Springsteen’s Wife and Bandmate, Reveals Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: Ms. Scialfa, 71, revealed she was diagnosed with blood cancer in 2018, which has curtailed her appearances onstage with the E Street Band.
lead_paragraph: Patti Scialfa, wife of the rock star Bruce Springsteen and a longtime member of his E Street Band, revealed in a new documentary that she was diagnosed with a form of blood cancer in 2018, which has led to her curtailing her public appearances and band performances in the years since.

headline: Google’s Next Antitrust Battle
abstract: The tech giant has lost a series of legal fights that investors have largely shrugged off. But a new trial over its advertising business could carry big consequences.
lead_paragraph: For months, investors have largely shrugged off the mounting regulatory threat hanging over Big Tech. That calm could be tested with the Justice Department set to lock horns with Google on Monday a landmark antitrust trial on its profit engine that could add to calls that the group be broken up.

headline: Palestinian Militants in the West Bank Flex New Capabilities
abstract: The increased Palestinian attacks, coupled with the expansion of Israeli military raids and increased settler violence, have created a spiral of violence that analysts say is set to worsen.
lead_paragraph: In the shadow of the war in Gaza, conflict in the Israeli-occupied West Bank has intensified with Palestinian attackers carrying out bolder and more sophisticated assaults as the Israeli military increases the scope of its raids on Palestinian cities.

headline: The Best View of New York
abstract: Off-White celebrates the allure of the melting pot.
lead_paragraph: New York is rarely seen as a shining city on a hill (or island) these days, what with news story after news story about rats and subway crime and potential problems with the Adams administration. So it was unexpectedly stirring on Sunday afternoon to experience the city from a different perspective — as a place of potential and possibility, courtesy of Off-White.

headline: Manhunt Continues for Highway Shooting Suspect Charged With Attempted Murder
abstract: At least seven counties in southeastern Kentucky closed schools on Monday as the authorities continued to comb a remote region of the state.
lead_paragraph: Joseph A. Couch spent $2,914.40 to buy an AR-15-style semiautomatic rifle and a thousand rounds of ammunition on Saturday, and then sent a series of alarming text messages.

headline: Hedge Fund Pushes for End of Murdochs’ Control at News Corp
abstract: Starboard Value, a fund that takes stakes in companies and agitates for changes, said political disagreements among Rupert Murdoch’s children could be “paralyzing” for the media firm.
lead_paragraph: The Murdoch family’s control over its media empire has long been the subject of intrigue and drama. It is also the latest target of the prominent shareholder activist Jeffrey C. Smith.

headline: Russian Forces Capture 2 Villages in Eastern Ukraine, Analysis Shows
abstract: Russia appears to be trying to cut off Ukrainian soldiers around the strategic city of Pokrovsk, a focal point of the war in recent months.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces have captured two villages in eastern Ukraine and are now pressing to encircle Ukrainian soldiers at two locations along the front line, according to an analysis of the battlefield on Monday.

headline: John Mulaney to Star in a Broadway Comedy About Love and Marriage
abstract: “All In: Comedy About Love,” a new play by Simon Rich, includes a celebrity cast taking on the roles of pirates, dogs and other zany characters.
lead_paragraph: John Mulaney is coming back to Broadway.

headline: Do You Know These Sports Books That Became Movies?
abstract: Try this short quiz about screen adaptations and the source material that inspired them.
lead_paragraph: Try this short quiz about screen adaptations and the source material that inspired them.

headline: Bird Flu Has Already Appeared in New York’s Animal Markets. What’s Next?
abstract: It’s not just rural farms. Urban animal markets are fertile grounds for viral transmission, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of chickens are squeezed into rows of tiny stacked wire cages, urine and feces dribbling onto the ducks, the geese and the rabbits confined below. The stench spreads even outside, to the sidewalk, where a mixture of feathers and blood sticks to the shoes of children walking to school.

headline: The 23 Words Harris Needs to Say to Win
abstract: It’s OK to admit that reality has changed her mind on the big issues.
lead_paragraph: “Joe and I got a lot of things right, but we got some things wrong, too — and here is what I have learned.”

headline: Paralympic Marathoner Loses Medal After Helping Her Guide Yards From Finish
abstract: A visually impaired runner briefly let go of the tether to her guide after he cramped near the finish line, costing her a bronze medal.
lead_paragraph: A visually impaired runner was disqualified from receiving a medal at the Paralympics after helping her guide who had stumbled just yards from the marathon’s finish line.

headline: What to Know About the Mercury in Your Dental Fillings
abstract: The European Union banned mercury amalgam fillings to protect the environment. Should you worry about protecting your health, too?
lead_paragraph: When the European Union adopted a ban on dental amalgam fillings earlier this year, its aim was to eliminate one of the last remaining intentional uses of mercury in Europe. The regulation is part of the Zero Pollution Action Plan, an initiative that includes removing microplastics, chemical pesticides and even noise pollution from the environment.

headline: The Miracle of the One-Pot Recipe
abstract: Dan Pelosi’s new chicken and rice dish is a master class in ratios and timing.
lead_paragraph: The paradox of a one-pot chicken and rice recipe is that while it’s wondrously simple to cook, it can be fiendishly difficult for a recipe developer to create. Adjusting the ratio of liquid to other ingredients, calibrating the timing so that the rice, chicken and vegetables all come out nicely seasoned and perfectly cooked — it takes hard work to keep things easy for you. When a recipe strikes that balance, that fragrant pot on your stove will delight everyone at the table, especially whoever’s on dish duty.

headline: The Terrifying Way That Eels Escape a Hungry Fish’s Stomach
abstract: X-ray videos showed that some young Japanese eels demonstrated that they were not content to become a predator’s meal.
lead_paragraph: For most animals, ending up in a predator’s stomach means all is lost. But not for Japanese eels.

headline: Tracking Tropical Depression Francine
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Francine.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Francine.

headline: What to Expect From Tropical Depression Francine
abstract: Francine became a Category 2 storm just before making landfall on Wednesday afternoon, then weakened. Here’s what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Defying the odds and the weather conditions that were expected to weaken Hurricane Francine, the storm intensified to a low-end Category 2 hurricane just before it made landfall in southern Louisiana on Wednesday.

headline: Peter Nygard, Former Fashion Mogul, Is Sentenced to 11 Years in Prison
abstract: Mr. Nygard was convicted in Toronto of sexually assaulting four women in his company’s headquarters. He also faces trials in Montreal, Winnipeg and New York.
lead_paragraph: The hearing was meant to decide a prison sentence for a convicted rapist, Peter Nygard, the former Canadian fashion mogul. But for a woman who had been sexually assaulted by Mr. Nygard, being one of his victims had long made her life a prison.

headline: With Trump Media Stock Cratering, Donald Trump Has a Decision to Make
abstract: A lockup provision has kept him from being able to sell Trump Media shares. With that prohibition about to expire, the price is down more than 70 percent from its peak.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has a big decision to make.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’ Gets Zero CMAs Nominations
abstract: The country-plus-everything-else album was given only limited promotion on country radio, with the success of the song “Texas Hold ’Em” driven by streaming and downloads.
lead_paragraph: When the Country Music Association announced the nominations for its 58th CMA Awards on Monday, there were plenty of expected names.

headline: Catherine, Princess of Wales, Has Completed Her Chemotherapy for Cancer
abstract: In a video message, Catherine said she would return to more of her duties, a positive development, but many questions remain about her condition and treatment.
lead_paragraph: Catherine, the Princess of Wales, announced on Monday that she had completed chemotherapy for her cancer, lifting a cloud from the British royal family after an anguished period in which she and her father-in-law, King Charles III, had both been stricken with serious illness.

headline: The Life-Changing Journey of ‘My Brilliant Friend’
abstract: The four actresses who played Lenù and Lila from adolescence to middle age discuss the end of the HBO series.
lead_paragraph: In the fourth season of “My Brilliant Friend,” premiering Monday on HBO, the childhood friends and fierce rivals Lila and Lenù navigate marriage and divorce, motherhood, loss and middle age.

headline: The Trade-Off for Mountain Tranquillity in California? Increasing Fire Risk.
abstract: Many Southern Californians have moved to San Bernardino County for more affordable homes and calmer lifestyles, but some also face disaster risks.
lead_paragraph: Through the window of her hotel room, Helene Forman monitored the wooded mountainside where encroaching flames on Monday threatened her mobile home in the foothills of the San Bernardino Mountains.

headline: Criminal Charge Against Outspoken Short Seller Unsettles Wall St.
abstract: Andrew Left is fighting a range of criminal and civil charges related to his trading practices, and other investors who make money by betting on a decline in stock prices are watching closely.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Left built a reputation on Wall Street as an outspoken investor skilled at making money by uncovering corporate frauds and betting against overvalued stocks. But federal authorities claim that Mr. Left sometimes misled his loyal followers about his intentions.

headline: Dozens Killed in Collision Between Fuel Tanker and Truck in Nigeria
abstract: The traffic accident was the latest disaster to highlight how roads across many African countries are some of the world’s deadliest.
lead_paragraph: At least 59 people were killed in Nigeria on Sunday after a fuel tanker collided with a passenger truck about 80 miles west of the capital, Abuja, emergency officials said.

headline: How Trump Has Used Debates to Belittle Women
abstract: Over nine years in politics, Donald J. Trump has honed a playbook of explicitly gendered attacks in clashes with female candidates and journalists.
lead_paragraph: It seems a strange twist of American history that the only man to have run against two female nominees in two presidential elections is one with a long and explicit record of denigrating women.

headline: Trump’s Latest Photo Book Offers Gossip, Boasting and a Threat
abstract: “Save America” is the third coffee table book from the former president since 2021. Ten pages are given over to pictures of him with Kim Jong-un, the North Korean dictator.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has tried all manner of ways to monetize his post-presidency. He has sold chocolate bars, sneakers, Bibles, NFT trading cards and even scraps of fabric from the suit he wore when his mug shot was taken last year at a jail in Atlanta. He has also been, a bit under the radar, cranking out coffee table books.

headline: Givenchy Appoints Sarah Burton as Creative Director
abstract: The British designer will be the second woman to oversee collections for the 72-year-old French brand.
lead_paragraph: The British designer Sarah Burton is the new creative director at Givenchy, filling a vacancy atop the French brand that opened when the American designer Matthew M. Williams stepped down in January after fewer than four years in the role. Ms. Burton’s appointment, which was announced in a news release on Monday by LVMH, the French multinational that owns Givenchy, makes her the eighth designer to lead the 72-year-old house, and only the second woman.

headline: Advice for the Trump-Harris Debate
abstract: Readers discuss strategies, the debate rules and possible questions. Also: Migrants in New York schools; household chores; exploiting animals, and humans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Battery Maker Northvolt to Cut Costs as E.V. Demand Slumps in Europe
abstract: The Swedish battery manufacturer said it would eliminate jobs and seek partnerships as it grappled with competition from China.
lead_paragraph: Northvolt, a Swedish battery manufacturer, said it would cut jobs, seek partnerships and merge some operations as it tried to streamline its business in the face of declining demand for electric vehicles in Europe.

headline: Evacuations Ordered as Wildfire Spreads in Southern California
abstract: The Line fire has burned more than 20,500 acres in San Bernardino County since it started on Sept. 5, California officials said.
lead_paragraph: The Line fire has burned more than 20,500 acres in San Bernardino County since it started on Sept. 5, California officials said.

headline: Apple Unveils New iPhones With Built-In Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The company also showcased a new Apple Watch and AirPods that can reduce noise at concerts or near construction sites.
lead_paragraph: The iPhone has grown predictable. Over the past seven years, it has generally looked the same, with incremental improvements to its cameras, processors and battery life.

headline: How to Turn Your Old iPhone Into an A.I. Phone (and Skip the Upgrade)
abstract: Apple is using Apple Intelligence, a suite of tools for generating images and text, to upsell the iPhone 16. But you can get similar features elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The latest iPhones, unveiled by Apple at a marketing event on Monday, look virtually identical to last year’s models. But Apple hopes that what’s underneath — new software that brings what it describes as artificial intelligence to the new phones — will persuade people to upgrade.

headline: Germany to Tighten Border Controls as Anti-Immigrant Parties Gain Votes
abstract: The government said it would expand patrols as part of a ‘hard line’ on illegal migration following two deadly stabbings by rejected asylum seekers and a surge in support for the far right.
lead_paragraph: The German government announced Monday that it would expand border patrols in a bid to stop illegal crossings, after four people were killed in two attacks by rejected asylum seekers this year and anti-immigrant parties made substantial gains in two state elections.

headline: House Panel Faults Cuomo’s Covid Response in Nursing Homes
abstract: A House subcommittee detailed how Andrew M. Cuomo, then the governor of New York, and his aides sought to undercount and deflect blame for deaths in nursing homes early in the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A congressional report released Monday criticized former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s handling of the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic, particularly his administration’s efforts to conceal the true number of New Yorkers who died in nursing homes and shift blame for the deaths.

headline: What Do You Believe In?
abstract: We want to hear from you — whether you’re religious or not.
lead_paragraph: I know the power of belief. I was raised a devout Mormon in Arkansas, where my religion shaped every aspect of worldview. It gave my small, ordinary childhood purpose and meaning. It gave me a place in the world. Then I left.

headline: Walt Ehmer, Former Waffle House C.E.O., Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Ehmer steered the diner chain through the pandemic and preached spending more time in one of his 24-hour restaurants than in his office.
lead_paragraph: Walt Ehmer, the former chief executive of Waffle House who steered the diner chain through the pandemic and preached spending more time in one of his 24-hour restaurants with the ubiquitous yellow sign than in his office, died on Friday. He was 58.

headline: Palestinians Hold Funeral for American Slain in West Bank
abstract: Aysenur Ezgi Eygi, a 26-year-old from the Seattle area, was shot and killed, when Israeli forces opened fire during a protest she was attending in a village in the West Bank, witnesses and Palestinian officials said.
lead_paragraph: At a funeral procession on Monday in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the body of an American woman killed at a protest was carried out of a hospital morgue, wrapped in a Palestinian flag, as dozens of mourners erupted in chants demanding justice for her killing.

headline: Jamie Heller to Be Next Top Editor of Business Insider
abstract: Ms. Heller spent two decades at The Wall Street Journal, most recently leading corporate coverage.
lead_paragraph: Business Insider on Monday named Jamie Heller, the business editor of The Wall Street Journal, to lead its newsroom as its next editor in chief.

headline: U.S. Argues Google Created Ad Tech Monopoly
abstract: The tech giant went to court on Monday in a second antitrust trial, this one focused on its dominance in advertising technology software. The case could reshape its business.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department told a federal judge on Monday that Google had built a monopoly in lucrative technology that delivers online ads, kicking off a second federal antitrust trial against the tech giant amid mounting scrutiny of the industry.

headline: How a Philippine Televangelist Ended Up on the F.B.I.’s Most-Wanted List
abstract: Here is what to know about the powerful doomsday preacher Apollo Carreon Quiboloy and his arrest.
lead_paragraph: The doomsday preacher who stands accused of sexual abuse and human trafficking wielded major influence not only over his devoted followers around the world but also on politicians in his own country, the Philippines.

headline: Here’s What’s Keeping Democrats Up at Night Ahead of the Debate
abstract: Heading into the high-stakes debate on Tuesday, the mood in the party remains upbeat. But with polls looking tight, concerns are starting to seep in.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of Democratic exuberance surrounding Vice President Kamala Harris’s sudden rise to the presidential nomination, the party’s joyous August has given way to a season of anxiety, as it braces for another nail-biter against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Higher Taxes Are on the Horizon. Don’t Let Them Spoil Your Retirement.
abstract: Unsustainable deficits will likely force an end to this era of low taxes, but you can plan for it.
lead_paragraph: Financial advisers often harangue their clients to contribute to Roth I.R.A.s, or to convert regular I.R.A.s into Roths. There are plenty of good reasons for “Rothification,” which I’ll get to. But let me first add a big reason that doesn’t get enough attention.

headline: 10,000 Feet Up, Scientists Found Hundreds of Airborne Germs
abstract: In 10 flights over Japan, researchers found a host of bacteria and fungi. These high-altitude germs could help spread disease around the world.
lead_paragraph: The sky may not seem like a promising place to find life. But in the 1920s, scientists flew planes across the United States and caught floating spores.

headline: Teen Girls’ Brains Aged Rapidly During Pandemic, Study Finds
abstract: Neuroimaging found girls experienced cortical thinning far faster than boys did during the first year of Covid lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: A study of adolescent brain development that tested children before and after coronavirus pandemic lockdowns in the United States found that girls’ brains aged far faster than expected, something the researchers attributed to social isolation.

headline: As Debate Looms, Trump Is Now the One Facing Questions About Age and Capacity
abstract: With President Biden no longer in the race, former President Donald J. Trump would be the oldest person ever to serve in the Oval Office. But his rambling, sometimes incoherent public statements have stirred concern among voters.
lead_paragraph: The last time the nation held a debate with the presidency on the line, a candidate with about eight decades of life behind him faced the challenge of proving that he was still up to the job of running the country. He failed.

headline: 7 Takeaways From the Seemingly Endless Fire Season
abstract: While the Line fire burns in Southern California, what can we learn from how a changing climate has affected an expanding fire season?
lead_paragraph: The Line fire had burned through more than 21,000 acres of Southern California when officials announced Monday morning that it was only 3 percent contained. Amid record temperatures, the blaze quickly ate through dry vegetation, injuring three firefighters and leading to evacuation orders for more than 6,000 people across San Bernardino County.

headline: Wander Lonely, Never Die and Other Things a Cloud Might Do
abstract: Whether as metaphors, decorations or (literal) forces of nature, clouds are everywhere in poetry.
lead_paragraph: One of my earliest memories is a memory of clouds. I went to preschool in a church with a big glass atrium, and one day, we were playing in the open area under the giant panes when I suddenly dropped my jump rope and cried out: “Look! The clouds are moving!” Huge fluffy white clouds were getting blown across the sky right in front of us, as if on an IMAX screen. We all stopped and stared up in awe. At the age of 4 or so, I had never noticed that clouds move before. Had I not looked up at them long enough to notice — too distracted by the world in reach? Somehow those windows framed the clouds, and made me able to see them. They seemed to bring the sky closer.

headline: Los Angeles Is Obsessed With These Cult Seasonal Melons
abstract: Let’s be honest, so am I.
lead_paragraph: Alex Weiser popped a single, half-squashed, dark Persian mulberry into his mouth and started to dance on the spot, the rim of his straw hat bouncing in the sun. It was an exceptionally delicious batch of mulberries, but we’re not here to talk about mulberries.

headline: Searches in Adams’s Inner Circle Suggest Investigations Are Intensifying
abstract: Former corruption prosecutors said that dramatic moves by federal agents hint that U.S. inquiries have made a significant step forward.
lead_paragraph: When the federal authorities last week seized the phones of top City Hall officials in New York, it was another stunning public move by investigators who had already taken Mayor Eric Adams’s devices, searched his aides’ homes and issued subpoenas to members of the mayor’s staff.

headline: Harvey Weinstein Is Hospitalized for Emergency Heart Surgery
abstract: The disgraced Hollywood mogul, who has been held on Rikers Island since April, is scheduled to return to court in New York later this month.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein, the disgraced Hollywood mogul who has been held at the Rikers Island jail complex in New York City since April, was rushed on Sunday evening to Bellevue Hospital for emergency heart surgery, according to his lawyer.

headline: Trump Campaign Amplifies False Claim About Haitian Migrants in Ohio
abstract: A local official said there was “absolutely no evidence” that Haitian migrants have stolen and eaten pets, an outlandish claim amplified by the Trump campaign on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Trump campaign promoted an outlandish false claim on Monday that Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, have abducted and eaten their neighbors’ pets, again demonizing migrants as the campaign seeks to attack Vice President Kamala Harris on immigration.

headline: Yale Settles With Patients Who Sued Over Painful Egg Retrievals
abstract: Patients received “substantial” payments, their lawyers said, and the clinic agreed to staffing changes.
lead_paragraph: Yale agreed on Monday to pay dozens of patients who had filed lawsuits claiming that they had endured excruciatingly painful egg retrieval procedures after a nurse at its fertility clinic secretly swapped their anesthesia for saline.

headline: James Earl Jones, Whose Powerful Acting Resonated Onstage and Onscreen, Dies at 93
abstract: He gave life to characters like Darth Vader in “Star Wars” and Mufasa in “The Lion King,” and went on to collect Tonys, Golden Globes, Emmys and an honorary Oscar.
lead_paragraph: James Earl Jones, a stuttering farm child who became a voice of rolling thunder as one of America’s most versatile actors in a stage, film and television career that plumbed race relations, Shakespeare’s rhapsodic tragedies and the faceless menace of Darth Vader, died on Monday at his home in Dutchess County, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Trump and Harris Prepare to Debate
abstract: Plus, is it A.I. or real life?
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 60 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Adams Tests Positive for Covid, Prompting Him to Scale Back Schedule
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams canceled two planned events as federal investigations swirl around him and his inner circle.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York tested positive for Covid on Monday, prompting him to cancel two scheduled events and withdraw from the public eye as federal investigations swirl around him and members of his inner circle.

headline: Maria E. Redo, Who Won Discounts for Older Adults, Dies at 99
abstract: She started a nonprofit in New York City in 1971 by asking stores if they would offer reduced prices for people 65 and over. Thousands of retailers said yes.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, a tenacious activist named Maria E. Redo was walking in her Upper East Side neighborhood chatting with a friend about the many older people she knew who were struggling financially on fixed incomes, especially as inflation was taking hold.

headline: Harris Said She Is Ready for the Debate
abstract: Also, the U.S. argued that Google has an ad-tech monopoly. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has spent much of the past several days holed up in a Pittsburgh hotel, practicing for her debate tomorrow night against Donald Trump. There’s a stage, replica TV lighting and an adviser acting as Trump.

headline: Lawyer Is Charged With Burning Israeli Flag at Columbia Protest
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney filed arson and criminal mischief charges against a Brooklyn lawyer who was arrested in a university administration building.
lead_paragraph: As protests over the war in Gaza raged and led to mass arrests at Columbia University and other New York City colleges this past spring, some elected and law enforcement officials claimed that much of the unrest was spurred by agitators from outside the Ivy League campus.

headline: A Clear Choice on the Issue Voters Care About Most
abstract: Both Kamala Harris and Donald Trump have plans to address the high cost of living. The differences between them are stark.
lead_paragraph: The most important distinction between the two candidates for the White House is that Vice President Kamala Harris is committed to democracy and the rule of law and Donald Trump is not. It’s a race that is, fundamentally, about who has the right temperament and is fit to be the next president, and the answer is not in question.

headline: 12 Great Films of James Earl Jones
abstract: A look at standout movies featuring the actor, who died on Monday at the age of 93.
lead_paragraph: James Earl Jones died on Monday at the age of 93. Like his contemporary Sidney Poitier, Jones helped change the perception of Black actors in Hollywood, creating indelible movie and TV characters who defied the prevailing stereotypes.

headline: Jorge Ramos to Leave Univision After 40 Years at the Network
abstract: TelevisaUnivision announced on Monday that Mr. Ramos and the network had mutually agreed not to renew his contract.
lead_paragraph: Jorge Ramos, who is among the most recognized journalists in Spanish-language television and is known for questioning leaders around the world, including Fidel Castro and former President Donald J. Trump, will leave Univision at the end of 2024 after 40 years at the network.

headline: Kennedy Will Be on Ballot in Michigan, State’s Supreme Court Rules
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. had ended his presidential campaign and endorsed Donald J. Trump last month. His presence on the ballot could be significant in the crucial battleground state.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan Supreme Court on Monday dismissed an effort by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to be taken off the ballot in the state, reversing an earlier appeals court decision that could have significant implications for the crucial battleground state.

headline: Kagan Sees Threats to Everyday Rights Beyond Abortion
abstract: The justice said the Supreme Court’s reasoning in the Dobbs case called into question access to contraception as well as gay and interracial marriage.
lead_paragraph: Justice Elena Kagan said on Monday that Americans were right to worry about the future of rights that form the fabric of their everyday lives — such as access to contraception and interracial and gay marriage — since the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion.

headline: Airstrikes Hit Syrian City Said to Be a Weapons Research Hub, Killing 18
abstract: Syria accused Israel of carrying out the attacks in and around Masyaf, where experts say missiles and unconventional weapons are developed. Israel did not comment.
lead_paragraph: Airstrikes in Syria killed at least 18 people and injured dozens of others, Syria’s state news media reported on Monday, blaming Israel for the attacks in and around a city known as a center for the development of weapons, including missiles.

headline: Former Project 2025 Leader Accuses Trump Campaign Advisers of ‘Malpractice’
abstract: The remarks from Paul Dans, the former director of the policy initiative, revealed discontent on the right about what some see as a pivot to the center.
lead_paragraph: The former director of Project 2025, a right-wing plan for what Donald J. Trump could do in a second term as president, is sharply criticizing Mr. Trump’s campaign, accusing its two top advisers of a series of missteps, lack of preparation and overconfidence that he says have jeopardized Mr. Trump’s chances in November.

headline: Facing Criticism After Striking Singer, a Maestro Forms New Ensembles
abstract: John Eliot Gardiner, who hit a singer during a tour in France last year, said he was starting a new choir and orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The renowned conductor John Eliot Gardiner, who has faced widespread criticism since he struck a singer during a tour in France last year, announced on Monday that he had formed a new choir and orchestra as he attempts a comeback on the global stage.

headline: Tainted Chicken Bribery Scheme Gets Ex-School Official 2 Years in Prison
abstract: Eric Goldstein, who ran food services for the New York City Education Department, took bribes to put tainted chicken tenders back on the lunch menu, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Plastic shards began showing up inside the chicken tenders in late 2016 almost immediately after they were added to the lunch menu for New York City public schools.

headline: Ed Kranepool, a Teenage Met Who Lasted 18 Seasons, Dies at 79
abstract: “Steady Eddie” joined the team at 17, played in more games than any Met and in 1969 helped a once-woeful franchise pull off a “miracle” — a World Series title.
lead_paragraph: Ed Kranepool, a Bronx-born first baseman whose long career with the Mets began in their first season, in 1962, when they were a comically awful expansion franchise, continued through their World Series championship seven years later and lasted long enough for their return to the cellar, died on Sunday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Video Shows Police Confrontation With Miami Dolphins Player Escalating Quickly
abstract: Body camera footage showed an officer pulling Tyreek Hill out of his car on Sunday after repeatedly ordering him to keep the window down during a traffic stop, apparently for speeding.
lead_paragraph: A traffic stop that led to Tyreek Hill, a wide receiver for the Miami Dolphins, being handcuffed outside the team’s stadium on Sunday escalated quickly after a police officer knocked on the player’s car window and he objected, body camera footage of the incident shows.

headline: Donald Trump on the Dollar, in His Own Words
abstract: Another day, another bizarre tariff proposal.
lead_paragraph: This is the first in an occasional series about Donald Trump’s statements and language and what’s at stake in the election.

headline: Colombia Is the Deadliest Country for Environmental Activists, Report Finds
abstract: As Colombia prepares to host a global biodiversity summit, killings of environmental defenders in the country rose again last year, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: Protecting the world’s most pristine ecosystems is essential to curb climate change and prevent biodiversity loss, but it also continues to be deadly. At least 196 people were killed last year defending the environment, according to a report by Global Witness, an environmental watchdog group.

headline: White House Says G.O.P.’s Afghanistan Report Offers ‘Little or Nothing New’
abstract: President Biden’s spokesman denounced the House Republican investigation of the chaotic 2021 withdrawal as partisan and one-sided.
lead_paragraph: The White House dismissed on Monday a new House Republican investigative report castigating President Biden’s administration for the chaotic 2021 withdrawal from Afghanistan, saying that it offers “little or nothing new” and ignores critical facts.

headline: I Rewatched the Trump-Clinton Debates So You Don’t Have to
abstract: In 2016, Trump used sexist attacks to turn his opponent’s perceived strengths into weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump will take part in a debate that could shape the rest of the presidential race and perhaps the country’s future. It’s the first time they are so much as meeting in person, a fact that imbues the coming confrontation with a jolt of unpredictability.

headline: 2 Charged With Inciting Violence and Promoting Hate Crimes Around the World
abstract: Dallas Humber and Matthew Allison are accused of soliciting hate crimes through the terrorist network they led on the platform Telegram, according to federal prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: Two people who federal prosecutors say ran a transnational terrorist group on the messaging app Telegram have been charged with promoting violent and deadly hate crimes around the world, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Deshaun Watson Is Accused of Sexual Assault
abstract: In a lawsuit filed Monday, a woman said the N.F.L. quarterback, who faced numerous accusations of sexual misconduct several years ago, assaulted her in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Cleveland Browns quarterback Deshaun Watson settled 23 lawsuits filed by massage therapists who said he had turned massage appointments sexual without their consent, another woman has accused Watson of sexual assault and battery.

headline: James Earl Jones: A Life in Pictures
abstract: Onstage and in movies and television, Jones delivered with a deep, authoritative, powerful and sometimes menacing voice.
lead_paragraph: If it seemed at times that James Earl Jones was everywhere, it was perhaps because he really was. Over a 50-year career, Jones — who died on Monday at the age of 93 — acted prolifically on television, in movies and under the spotlight of Broadway stages, one of which is now named after him.

headline: Trump Steps Up Threats to Imprison Those He Sees as Foes
abstract: The former president is vowing to prosecute those he sees as working to deny him a victory, while laying the groundwork to claim large-scale voter fraud if he loses.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has long used strongman-style threats to prosecute people he vilifies as a campaign tactic, dating back to encouraging his 2016 rallygoers to chant “lock her up” about Hillary Clinton. And during his term as president, he repeatedly pressed the Justice Department to open investigations into his political adversaries.

headline: Where Kamala Harris and Donald Trump Stand on the Issues
abstract: Here’s what Vice President Harris and former President Donald J. Trump have done and want to do on abortion, crime, democracy, the economy, immigration, Israel and Gaza, and Social Security and Medicare.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what Vice President Harris and former President Donald J. Trump have done and want to do on abortion, crime, democracy, the economy, immigration, Israel and Gaza, and Social Security and Medicare.

headline: Why Trump Can Afford to Disrespect His Anti-Abortion Voters
abstract: The ex-president has remade the religious right in his image.
lead_paragraph: The Babylon Bee, which is like The Onion for conservative Christians, last month ran a despairing story about the presidential options anti-abortion voters have before them. “Pro-Lifers Excited to Choose Between Moderate Amount of Baby Murder and High Amount of Baby Murder,” said the headline. It was a dark joke, but it spoke to something real: a disquiet among some anti-abortion activists over Donald Trump’s attempts to distance himself from the abortion bans enabled by his Supreme Court appointees. Albert Mohler, the president of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, told my Times colleague Astead W. Herndon that declining evangelical enthusiasm for Trump could be a “grave danger” to his campaign.

headline: City Hall Seeks New York Police Commissioner’s Resignation
abstract: Edward Caban has faced increasing pressure since last week, when federal agents searched the homes of top officials in the Adams administration and confiscated electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s administration is seeking the resignation of Edward A. Caban, New York’s police commissioner, less than a week after agents seized the commissioner’s phone in one of several federal investigations that have engulfed City Hall, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Wildfire Erupts in Orange County, Forcing Evacuations
abstract: A small brush fire in Southern California quickly grew to over 5,000 acres, threatening nearby suburban neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the wildfires in Southern California.

headline: Francine Could Be Fueled by Gulf of Mexico’s Warm Waters
abstract: Francine is forecast to become a Category 2 hurricane before landfall this week, but an even stronger hurricane isn’t out of the question.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon, Francine spun above water, its temperature nearly ideal for a bathtub, primed to fuel, strengthen and sustain a hurricane.

headline: Conservative German Princess Says She Hosted Justice Alito at Her Castle
abstract: Princess Gloria von Thurn und Taxis said Justice Alito and his wife were guests at St. Emmeram Palace for a summer music festival. She called the couple her “friends” and the justice “a hero.”
lead_paragraph: An eccentric German princess who evolved from a 1980s punk style icon to a conservative Catholic known for hobnobbing with far-right figures said on Monday that she hosted Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. and his wife at her castle during a July 2023 music festival.

headline: Give or Take
abstract: Daniel Bodily shows himself to be a man of letters.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Man Dies During River Trip in the Grand Canyon
abstract: His death is the seventh reported in Grand Canyon National Park since July 31.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado man was found dead in Grand Canyon National Park on Saturday, according to the National Park Service. It is the seventh death reported there in less than two months.

headline: Quote of the Day: Skulls are Returned to Finland, Righting a 19th-Century Wrong
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 10, 2024
lead_paragraph: “When we find out more about these people, their lives, they really become part of history, not just as skulls, but as human beings.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 10, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about China stopping foreign adoptions misstated the circumstances of Courtney Moore’s time in China. It is not where she met her husband; they were already married when living there as students.

headline: Polaris Dawn Astronauts Launch on Ambitious Private Mission
abstract: The mission is taking people farther from Earth than anyone has traveled since the end of NASA’s Apollo moon missions.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, Jared Isaacman, a billionaire entrepreneur, launched to space for a second time. The mission, known as Polaris Dawn, is a collaboration between Mr. Isaacman and SpaceX, the rocket company led by Elon Musk.

headline: The Bomb Shelters Are Busy. So Are the Nail Salons.
abstract: In Ukraine, even a visit for a manicure, which often involves navigating power outages and air-raid sirens, can turn into an act of defiance.
lead_paragraph: Viktoria Gulieva sat in a hot-pink armchair wearing a denim tube dress over her pregnant belly and her dark hair slicked back in a tight bun. Her white Pomeranian dog perched on her lap. A salon worker delicately painted pale pink polish onto her toenails, which were spread apart by heart-shaped foam separators.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A preview of the U.S. presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: The first and only scheduled debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump will take place on Tuesday evening in the U.S., and Americans are bracing for a nail-biter.

headline: China’s Huawei Shows the World Its $2,800 ‘Trifold’ Phone
abstract: The latest announcement from Apple’s China rival came just hours after the unveiling of iPhone 16.
lead_paragraph: Over successive administrations, the U.S. government has used stiff trade restrictions to try to stifle the Chinese telecom giant Huawei. In turn, the company never misses an opportunity to show that it is still standing.

headline: ‘It’s Not Pandering When You Tell the Truth’: Five Columnists Game Out the Debate
abstract: What does success or failure look like for Donald Trump and Kamala Harris in Tuesday’s debate?
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Jamelle Bouie, Ross Douthat, David French, Michelle Goldberg and Tressie McMillan Cottom about Tuesday’s debate between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump.

headline: Ukraine Fires Deadly Drone Barrage at Russia, Taking War Closer to Moscow
abstract: A woman in the capital region was killed during the attack, officials said. Russian air defenses shot down 20 drones around Moscow and almost 150 nationwide, according to the Defense Ministry.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine struck Russia with one of its largest drone attacks of the war on Tuesday, killing a woman in the Moscow area, setting off fires in high-rise buildings and forcing the closure of major airports near the capital, Kremlin officials said.

headline: Word of the Day: impunity
abstract: This word has appeared in 256 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word impunity has appeared in 256 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 1 in “Worked to the Bone, India’s Doctors Fear for Their Safety, Too” by Anupreeta Das and Pragati K.B.:

headline: Late Night Observes ‘Debate Night Eve’
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel predicted Kamala Harris and Donald Trump will face questions “on all the big issues: the economy, immigration, electrocution, sharks.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Athletes and Anime
abstract: What fandoms are you a part of that might surprise people?
lead_paragraph: Young professional athletes are increasingly sharing their fascination with anime like “Pokémon” and “Naruto,” and, in the process, upending preconceptions about certain kinds of fandom.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Google and Apple Face Billions in Penalties After Losing E.U. Appeals
abstract: The cases had established the European Union as the world’s leading tech watchdog, but have since raised questions about its protracted appeals process.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s highest court delivered the 27-nation bloc a major victory on Tuesday in its yearslong campaign to regulate the technology industry, ruling against Apple and Google in two landmark legal cases.

headline: Australia Plans to Bar Young Children From Social Media
abstract: The government is considering setting a minimum age for platforms like TikTok and Instagram that could be as high as 16.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia on Monday took to his social media accounts to announce that his government wants to set a minimum age to use social media platforms, like TikTok and Instagram, in a move he said was designed to reduce online risks for children.

headline: Venezuelan Election Observers Forced Into Exile in Colombia
abstract: Volunteer election observers who collected vote tallies at precincts across Venezuela found that the opposition candidate Edmundo González had received more votes than President Nicolás Maduro did in July’s election. The New York Times spoke to several volunteers who fled the country after facing death threats from Mr. Maduro’s supporters.
lead_paragraph: A group of five Venezuelan election observers found themselves hiding in a tight, cramped and temporary room in Cúcuta, Colombia. They included a bread maker, a salesman, a chef and an engineer, and, together, they were among the first political exiles to flee across the Venezuela-Colombia border in the days after the July 28 election.

headline: These Venezuelan Election Observers Got Death Threats. Now They’re in Hiding.
abstract: The New York Times spoke to several election volunteers for Venezuela’s opposition party who found that Edmundo González defeated Nicolás Maduro in July. They fled the country after facing death threats from Maduro’s supporters.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times spoke to several election volunteers for Venezuela’s opposition party who found that Edmundo González defeated Nicolás Maduro in July. They fled the country after facing death threats from Maduro’s supporters.

headline: Why Do Americans Want to Dress Like Swedes?
abstract: The Stockholm fashion label Toteme has a no-nonsense, “pragmatic” look — and a lot of fans in New York.
lead_paragraph: Toteme, the fashion label, is not a word. But it comes from one.

headline: The Origin Story of Astro Bot’s Likable Little Guy
abstract: Astro, a babylike robot designed to show off the power of PlayStation hardware, has graduated to his own full-length adventure game.
lead_paragraph: If PlayStation’s next big character succeeds, it will be in part because he is a really, really cute little guy.

headline: How to Make Squats Easier on Your Knees
abstract: You can still work out, even if your joints aren’t what they once were.
lead_paragraph: Most exercise scientists today say the squat is one of the most beneficial exercises you can do as you age. Just think about all the ways we squat throughout the day: grabbing dish soap from under the sink, crouching to hug your children and even sitting down on the toilet.

headline: It’s Hard to Beat a Cozy Window Seat in the Fall
abstract: The best ones have several things in common, according to the pros. Here’s how to design yours.
lead_paragraph: When a window has a beautiful view or floods a room with sunlight, it’s tempting to pull up a chair and sit next to it. A better idea? Build a window seat.

headline: In ‘Still Life,’ a Trans Woman’s Homecoming Is Shaped by Grief
abstract: In Katherine Packert Burke’s debut novel, a woman is haunted by change while grappling with the death of a friend.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Packert Burke’s debut novel, “Still Life,” opens with a homecoming. Edith, the story’s protagonist, has briefly returned, after eight years, to Boston, where she lived after college. She’s arrived as a stranger. Before she left, she was living as a man; she’s come back living openly as a trans woman. And, to Edith’s dismay, her core friend group has fractured in the time she’s been gone. Edith has scheduled her visit under the pretense of giving a talk about her writing career to her friend’s undergraduate literature class. In truth, she’s there to see her former best friend, Tessa, whom she misses and to whom she’s barely spoken during her time away.

headline: He’s Known as ‘Ivan the Troll.’ His 3D-Printed Guns Have Gone Viral.
abstract: From his Illinois home, he champions guns for all. The Times confirmed his real name and linked the firearm he helped design to terrorists, drug dealers and freedom fighters in at least 15 countries.
lead_paragraph: After an attempted gang murder in the French city of Marseille last year, the police found what appeared to be a toy assault rifle, seemingly crafted from plastic and Lego parts.

headline: Yesterday’s Broadway Warhorses, Saddled With Today’s Concerns
abstract: Revivals of “Romeo and Juliet,” “Our Town,” “Gypsy” and “Sunset Boulevard” aim to show that rethinking for the present is what makes classics classic.
lead_paragraph: Two cheers for new voices! Of the 16 productions scheduled to open on Broadway between now and the end of the year, 12 are new to the Boulevard of Broken Budgets.

headline: Are Art and Science Forever Divided? Or Are They One and the Same?
abstract: The sprawling California festival “PST Art” promises a dialogue between “two cultures.” But painting and physics may have more in common than their practitioners know.
lead_paragraph: One spring morning, one wet English morning, John Keats looked up at a rainbow and felt nothing.

headline: In Liane Moriarty’s Bustling New Novel, Fate Takes Flight
abstract: There are stakes on the plane in “Here One Moment,” the latest from the Australian fiction powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: Nine novels in, Liane Moriarty’s output falls somewhere between empire and institution: a reliable bastion of breezy yet propulsive storytelling, smartly informed by relevant issues of the day (infertility, wellness culture, domestic abuse). Her books claim prime real estate at chain stores and airports kiosks and regularly go on to become glossy television fodder, more often than not fronted by her fellow Australian Nicole Kidman (see “Big Little Lies,” “Nine Perfect Strangers” and the upcoming “The Last Anniversary,” which she’ll produce).

headline: An Unlikely Pair’s Difficult Pilgrimage From Rural Alabama to the White House
abstract: In Jamie Quatro’s Southern Gothic novel “Two-Step Devil,” a dying “Prophet” and a former sex-trafficking victim make the same journey for two very different reasons.
lead_paragraph: Lookout Mountain, Ala., 2014. A 70-year-old man called the Prophet lives alone in a dilapidated cabin in the woods. A former welder and drinker with possible wet brain and lung cancer he is reluctant to treat, the Prophet grows and sells fruits and vegetables — potatoes, beans, peaches, squash — sometimes with a healing song. The Prophet’s wife died of cancer years ago. His only son, a singer, has left him for Nashville. The Prophet owns a shotgun, but he “did not believe in any kind of killing, not capital punishment, abortion, suicide.” He trusts no formal church.

headline: Donald Trump and the Meaning of a Raised Fist
abstract: A history of the appropriation of a political gesture.
lead_paragraph: This is an installment of Visual Studies, a series that explores how images move through and shape culture.

headline: For Some Sex Assault Accusers, This Local Law Has Become a Last Resort
abstract: The law, which underpins several civil suits against Sean Combs, is the only remaining tool for reviving older claims in New York.
lead_paragraph: In New York, where state laws that extended the time to file sex abuse suits have lapsed, plaintiffs have found one remaining tool: Section 10-1105 of New York City’s administrative code.

headline: Liane Moriarty Has Sold 20 Million Books. She Would Rather Not Talk About It.
abstract: The author of “Big Little Lies” and several other best-sellers has a new novel, “Here One Moment.” Promoting it — doing any publicity — remains a challenge, she said.
lead_paragraph: Liane Moriarty has reached a level of success few authors can claim. She has written eight best sellers, including “Big Little Lies,” “Apples Never Fall” and “The Husband’s Secret.” Several of her novels have been adapted for television, in limited series that star actors including Nicole Kidman, Reese Witherspoon, Annette Bening and Meryl Streep. All told, Moriarty has sold more than 20 million books.

headline: Why Can’t I Get This Song Out of My Head?
abstract: Here’s why earworms are never gonna give you up.
lead_paragraph: Q: I have had a Kacey Musgraves song stuck in my head for two weeks and it’s making me crazy. Why is this happening?

headline: Lured by a Promising Job, He Was Forced to Scam People
abstract: A Ugandan man named Jalil Muyeke traveled to Thailand for a promising job opportunity. He ended up being trafficked into a cybercrime operation.
lead_paragraph: Internet scammers steal billions from Americans each year. In one workroom in Southeast Asia, where dozens of fraudsters trolled dating apps for fresh victims, they would beat a giant drum and chant each time they successfully duped someone into sending them money.

headline: What Makes the Far Right Tick?
abstract: In “Stolen Pride,” Arlie Russell Hochschild explores the emotional lives of Americans who vote for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: On an unseasonably hot day in April 2017, a caravan of vehicles full of white supremacists rolled into Pikeville, Ky. The neo-Nazis, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan and other self-described racists were emboldened by the election of Donald Trump and dressed to the hilt with jackboots, shields, sunglasses and firearms. They had come to recruit from America’s whitest congressional district, which is also one of its poorest and most conservative.

headline: Man vs. Trees: How a Rancher’s Bulldozing Project Cost Utah Taxpayers
abstract: The state footed a big bill for the owner of a hunting retreat to knock down trees on his and nearby properties. He made big environmental promises, but the science was lacking.
lead_paragraph: Mike Siaperas, a wealthy software executive, was looking for a change. He found it 10,000 feet above sea level in Utah, buying a ranch that he would turn into a luxury hunting retreat. But there was a problem.

headline: Our Reporter on How the FGC-9 Is Spreading Across the World
abstract: The FGC-9 is a semiautomatic weapon that can be assembled with a commercial 3-D printer and some metalworking skills. Here’s how The New York Times linked the FGC-9 to terrorists, drug dealers and rebels in at least 15 countries and tracked down a main figure responsible for the gun design and its increasing popularity.
lead_paragraph: The FGC-9 is a semiautomatic weapon that can be assembled with a commercial 3-D printer and some metalworking skills. Here’s how The New York Times linked the FGC-9 to terrorists, drug dealers and rebels in at least 15 countries and tracked down a main figure responsible for the gun design and its increasing popularity.

headline: The Surprising French City Where Pizza Rules
abstract: Experience Marseille through its favorite street food, whether it’s topped with raw garlic, sweet Corsican sausage, Emmental cheese or anchovies.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy night in Marseille, France’s second-largest city, crowds move through the graffiti-toned streets of the central Cours Julien neighborhood. Buildings are splashed in color as if the nearby Mediterranean had washed up, ebbed out and left behind pigments of a shattered rainbow.

headline: You Don’t Have to Be Perfect to Live Like a Saint
abstract: Set aside the notion of flawless miracle workers. Focus instead on their exuberance and compassion, inner balance and commitment to a meaningful vocation.
lead_paragraph: I was young when I first heard the murmurings of a fear that I still carry around with me. It’s rooted in a vision of the world that I do not actually think will come to pass, but that I can’t help picturing every spring. “What if,” the fear will hiss in my ear. “What if this is the year that nothing greens or grows. No grass, no flowers, no leaves on the trees. What if the landscape stays as stripped and lifeless as a body on a cross, as a hideous mirror held up to your soul?”

headline: A Student’s Wisdom Helped This Teacher Win $200,000
abstract: Diana Imbert-Hodges, who runs Defying Legal Gravity, is one of the winners of the David Prize. She credited a student for inspiring her to start the organization.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out what someone who is splitting a $1 million prize plans to do with the money. We’ll also get details on a House subcommittee report about how Gov. Andrew Cuomo and his administration tallied nursing home deaths early in the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Just Miles from Kroger’s Court Battle, a Food Desert Shows What’s at Stake
abstract: Federal regulators are trying to block Kroger’s merger with Albertsons. In a Portland suburb, residents already know what deteriorating access to fresh food looks like.
lead_paragraph: In a courthouse in Portland, Ore., the federal government is challenging the biggest supermarket consolidation in U.S. history.

headline: What to Know About the FGC-9 and Other 3D-Printed Guns
abstract: Homemade firearms are spreading faster than governments can keep up. For many gun designers, that’s the idea.
lead_paragraph: Homemade weapons have been around for centuries, but the appearance of 3D-printed firearms a decade ago revolutionized how guns are acquired and distributed on a global scale.

headline: Forum 1 | How Does Your Identity Inform Your Political Beliefs and Values?
abstract: We invite you to introduce yourself and to think about when you first became aware of having political opinions. What do you think shaped them? Have they changed over time?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the first of our Election 2024 Student Conversation Forums, in which teenagers from around the world are invited to explore their political and civic identities, values and beliefs and discuss them with others.

headline: Should We Be Receiving Mystical Truths on Our Phones?
abstract: The algorithm of entertainment was not built for ancient knowledge extracted from sacred spaces.
lead_paragraph: At age 25, as the story goes, Jagadish Vasudev rode his motorcycle up into the Chamundi Hills near Mysore, India, sat on a stone and dropped into his first mystical experience. Tears of “indescribable ecstasy” streamed down his face, and when he emerged from meditation, many hours later, he had begun a new life as a spiritual leader. His mission was to teach all people how to achieve the blissful liberation he first came to know in those hills.

headline: Trump Wants to Shut Down the Department of Education? Is That Possible?
abstract: Donald Trump has argued he would use the department to further his priorities — or close it. But the agency has relatively limited power, and any plan to shutter it would face major hurdles.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump has depicted the nation’s public schools as purveyors of an extreme ideology on gender and race. One of his proposed remedies is to revive a Reagan-era call to shut down the federal Department of Education, founded in 1979.

headline: How to Talk to Colombia’s Largest Criminal Group
abstract: Cautious negotiations with the Gaitanistas could be the country’s best chance at safety for its people.
lead_paragraph: In late December 2023, Colombia’s largest armed group began to overrun Briceño, a village in the Andes. Residents later told me that the militants carried latest-issue weapons and called themselves the Gaitanista Self-Defense Forces. Briceño’s inhabitants said the camouflaged fighters gathered them with a simple message: “We’re in charge now.”

headline: Super Emmy: Is the Time Now Right for This Former Disaster?
abstract: Fifty years ago, the Emmys created an uber-award in a widely derided stunt. But amid today’s category confusion, perhaps a super solution is required.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Emmy Awards.

headline: Seeing the Fashion World Through the Eyes of an 8-Year-Old
abstract: An interest in design and a knack for sewing have earned Max Alexander celebrity fans and millions of social media followers.
lead_paragraph: “Look at you in linen,” the designer Isaac Mizrahi said to a young fan he was meeting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, on a Thursday in August, to see the “Sleeping Beauties: Reawakening Fashion” exhibition.

headline: Has the Tide Turned for TikTok, Telegram and X?
abstract: They are facing legal pushback that may signal a new era of accountability for social media titans.
lead_paragraph: Three major events have shaken up the social-media world in the past two weeks. First, French authorities detained Pavel Durov, the iconoclastic billionaire behind the online platform Telegram. Then, a judge suspended the microblogging service X in Brazil. Soon after, a federal appeals court in Pennsylvania ruled that the mother of a 10-year-old child who died copying a TikTok self-asphyxiation video can sue the service, circumventing a blanket legal immunity the company has long claimed.

headline: Pulling Back the Silicon Curtain
abstract: Yuval Noah Harari’s study of human communication may be anything but brief, but if you can make it to the second half, you’ll be both entertained and scared.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2022, a software engineer named Blake Lemoine was fired by Google after an interview with The Washington Post in which he claimed that LaMDA, the chatbot he had been working on, had achieved sentience.

headline: After Decades of Dry Martinis, It’s Great to Go Wet
abstract: The wet martini served by a new restaurant in Manhattan reflects an appreciation of vermouth that’s been a long time coming.
lead_paragraph: Many adjectives have been attached to martinis over the years. Bartenders have plied drinkers with dirty martinis and filthy martinis, smoky martinis and flaming martinis, red-pepper martinis and blue-cheese martinis, breakfast martinis and midnight martinis. Midcentury advertising executives along Madison Avenue were weaned on dry martinis, grew into very dry martinis and graduated to extra dry. Inevitably, this produced a backlash, and in the 1990s it was common to find not just apple martinis but melon martinis, kiwi martinis, lychee martinis and other fruits.

headline: Charging Parents Won’t Stop Mass Shootings
abstract: Focusing on parental responsibility allows the state to shift blame from weapons laws to families.
lead_paragraph: After school shootings in Michigan, southern Virginia, and now Georgia, parents have been charged in connection to their children’s actions. Megan Stack, a Times contributing opinion writer, argues that states should turn their attention to gun storage and access laws instead of criminalizing parents.

headline: Our Reporter on How Trump Is Preparing for the Debate
abstract: Ahead of Donald J. Trump’s debate against Vice President Kamala Harris, Jonathan Swan, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, learned how Mr. Trump is preparing.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of Donald J. Trump’s debate against Vice President Kamala Harris, Jonathan Swan, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, learned how Mr. Trump is preparing.

headline: ‘I’m Speaking’: What Harris’s Top Debate Moments Could Tell Us About Tonight
abstract: In 2019, she attacked Joe Biden and was rattled by Tulsi Gabbard. In 2020, she cut off Mike Pence as he interrupted her. On Tuesday, some of the same strategies and weak points may come into play.
lead_paragraph: During the 2020 election cycle, Kamala Harris participated in five Democratic primary debates and, as the vice-presidential nominee, one general-election debate. Her performances in the primary debates showed that she was unafraid to instigate attacks, but could be unsteady when on the receiving end of one.

headline: For Trump, Tariffs Are the Solution to Almost Any Problem
abstract: The former president has proposed using tariffs to fund child care, boost manufacturing, quell immigration and encourage use of the dollar. Economists are skeptical.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than five years since former President Donald J. Trump called himself a “Tariff Man,” but since then, his enthusiasm for tariffs seems only to have grown.

headline: The Stakes of a Harris vs. Trump Debate
abstract: Some voters are still trying to make up their minds. Here’s what they’re listening for.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris will face off in Philadelphia on Tuesday night for the second presidential debate of 2024. It will be the first time the two candidates meet on a debate stage.

headline: Almost 50 Million Americans Have Had an Obamacare Plan Since 2014
abstract: The Biden administration released data showing roughly one in seven U.S. residents had been covered by the Affordable Care Act at some point over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 million Americans have been covered by health insurance plans through the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces since they opened a decade ago, according to tax data analyzed by the Treasury Department and published on Tuesday.

headline: 7 Apple Picking Tips From the Guy Behind Apple Ratings
abstract: Brian Frange has been pontificating on apples since 2016. He has a few things to say before you hit the orchards.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Brian Frange’s favorite fruit was “probably a grape or a mango.” Then one day, at a Whole Foods in New York, he stumbled on a SweeTango apple for the first time. Curious, he tried it.

headline: What Polls Say About a Key Group: Begrudging Trump Voters
abstract: In Tuesday’s debate, the vice president needs to win over this slice of the electorate.
lead_paragraph: The race for the White House couldn’t be much closer. With less than two months to go until Election Day, the latest New York Times/Siena College polling has Kamala Harris and Donald Trump in a campaign with no clear front-runner. Beyond the national numbers, there are key battleground state polls that suggest the same state of play, with Ms. Harris and Mr. Trump essentially evenly matched.

headline: Trump Makes No Sense and Is Full of Meaning
abstract: On the question of his political opponents, he’s clear. He will punish them, if we give him the power to do so.
lead_paragraph: You must keep two things in mind if you hope to watch — and successfully parse — a Donald Trump speech, news conference, interview, social media post or debate.

headline: Hostages Still Held by Hamas Are in ‘Grave Danger,’ Families Warn
abstract: Six hostages who were found dead in Gaza recently had been held in narrow tunnels and suffered from malnutrition, family members said, citing an Israeli military investigation.
lead_paragraph: A group representing the families of hostages in Gaza — including six captives whose bodies the Israeli military recently retrieved from a tunnel there — say that harrowing details about the conditions of their captivity indicate that those still held by Hamas are in “grave danger.”

headline: Killing of Tanzanian Opposition Official Adds to Fears of Pre-Election Crackdown
abstract: Ali Mohamed Kibao was beaten and acid had been poured on his face, according to an autopsy, his party said.
lead_paragraph: The abduction and killing of an opposition official over the weekend in Tanzania has kindled fear and consternation in the East African country, with activists saying it has added to questions about the democratic credentials of the nation’s pathbreaking president as elections loom.

headline: Louisiana Prepares for Hurricane Francine to Make Landfall
abstract: Forecasters warned that cities along the Louisiana coast could see heavy rainfall and a “dangerous” storm surge. Many residents were rushing to get supplies as the storm neared.
lead_paragraph: Local officials across southern Louisiana were clearing storm drains and distributing sandbags to prepare for Hurricane Francine, which was churning in the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday. Forecasters said that the storm was expected to make landfall on Wednesday, bringing the potential for heavy rainfall and a dangerous storm surge.

headline: Unwilling to Be Human Shields, Some Gazans Turn Gunmen Away From Shelters
abstract: Residents, already forced to flee their homes by intense bombardment, want to avoid becoming a target for Israeli forces hunting Hamas.
lead_paragraph: When the war forced Nasser al-Zaanin to flee his home in northern Gaza in October, he, along with his adult sons and grandchildren, moved to a school that had been turned into a shelter.

headline: Polio Shots Begin in Northern Gaza Despite Israel’s Detaining U.N. Convoy
abstract: The U.N. said that Israeli forces had held staff members at gunpoint for several hours. The Israeli military said that it had intelligence suggesting there were “Palestinian suspects” with the convoy.
lead_paragraph: United Nations officials said that health workers began vaccinating children in northern Gaza against polio on Tuesday, but noted that convoys carrying critical supplies of fuel and medicine were facing increasing obstruction and delays caused by Israeli forces.

headline: Man Accused of Killing Ugandan Olympic Runner in Gasoline Attack Dies
abstract: Dickson Ndiema died from injuries he sustained when he set Rebecca Cheptegei, his partner, on fire. The police had planned to charge him with murder.
lead_paragraph: The Ugandan man who was accused of killing Rebecca Cheptegei, his partner and Olympic long-distance runner, by dousing her with gasoline and setting her on fire, died Monday evening from burns he sustained in the same attack.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,180
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, September 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 458
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Sept. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Inside Trump-Harris Debate Prep, and Israel Strikes Humanitarian Zone
abstract: Plus, remembering an iconic Hollywood voice.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Judge Delays Trump Sentencing Until After Election
abstract: Explaining a legal win for the former president, and its limits.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a judge in Manhattan announced that he was delaying the sentencing of Donald J. Trump until after the election. It is the only one of the four criminal cases against the former president that will have gone to trial before voters go to the polls.

headline: Questions for Donald Trump
abstract: Twenty-four questions on issues including the economy, abortion and foreign policy we wish Trump would answer.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, The Morning published a list of questions that we wished Kamala Harris would answer. Today — the day of the debate between Harris and Donald Trump — we’re publishing questions for Trump. As before, my Times colleagues who are covering the campaign helped put this list together.

headline: Trump Mocks Harris’s Height. But Her Fans See a Certain Stature.
abstract: Kamala Harris is modest in stature, but is considered by some to have Tall Energy. Donald Trump has insisted she shouldn’t be allowed to use “boxes or artificial lifts” during the debate.
lead_paragraph: With Tuesday night’s debate approaching, Kamala Harris’s height — she is 5 feet 4¼ inches tall — came up over the weekend as a potential issue during the event.

headline: What Wall Street Wants to Hear at the Debate
abstract: Taxes, tariffs, trade and regulation: Business leaders have a long list of topics they want addressed in Tuesday’s presidential showdown.
lead_paragraph: With less than two months until the presidential election, there isn’t much time left for singularly impactful moments. Tuesday’s debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump will be one of them — and the corporate world will be paying attention.

headline: Kamala Harris Could Be in Trouble
abstract: Her momentum stalled after a lackluster CNN interview. The debate is her best chance to restart it.
lead_paragraph: In 20 years of covering presidential politics, I never saw a run of buoyant campaign rallies, boffo fund-raising, ecstatic social media and rank-and-file rapture for a candidate like Kamala Harris had in July and August, capped off by her Democratic convention speech. The next day, I sounded a note of caution about how joy is not a strategy, an argument that some readers disagreed with and some colleagues saw differently.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Record Heat, Chicken Nuggets, Summer Song
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Predicting the Debate Ratings: Super Bowl? Nah. ‘Seinfeld’ Finale? Maybe.
abstract: A semi-scientific theory about how many Americans will tune in to watch Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to pinpoint how many Americans will tune in Tuesday night to watch the first and only scheduled debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Orange County Leader Faces Scrutiny Over Charity’s Pandemic Spending
abstract: Andrew Do, an Orange County supervisor, has been asked to resign after directing more than $13 million to a nonprofit run by his daughter and allies. The group was supposed to spend the money on meals for vulnerable residents.
lead_paragraph: The money, more than $13 million, was meant to feed seniors and other vulnerable residents of Orange County, Calif., including the growing population of older Vietnamese Americans scraping by on fixed incomes.

headline: Renowned Scholar of Islam Is Convicted of Rape in Switzerland
abstract: An appeals court in Geneva overturned a previous acquittal and found Tariq Ramadan guilty. He faces separate charges in France.
lead_paragraph: Tariq Ramadan, a prominent Swiss-born scholar of Islam, was found guilty on appeal of raping and sexually coercing a woman in Geneva in 2008, reversing a previous acquittal, the Swiss authorities said on Tuesday.

headline: U.K. Hedge Fund Tycoon Buys The Spectator Magazine
abstract: Paul Marshall, a multimillionaire founder and investor in upstart conservative media outlets, has bought the right-wing British magazine in a deal worth about $131 million.
