lead_paragraph: The Spectator, a 196-year-old magazine with a prominent place in British political life and longstanding ties to the Conservative Party, was on Tuesday sold to a hedge fund tycoon whose media interests also include a right-wing TV channel that has antagonized the country’s broadcasting regulator.

headline: Israel Says Its Forces Likely Shot American Activist as U.S. Issues Rebuke
abstract: The Israeli military said the killing of Aysenur Eygi in the occupied West Bank was unintentional. The top U.S. diplomat said the shooting was “not acceptable,” and Israel’s conduct must change.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Tuesday that it was highly likely that a slain American activist was “unintentionally” struck by Israeli gunfire last week at a protest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the killing was “not acceptable.”

headline: Doctors Give Black Women Unneeded C-Sections to Fill Operating Rooms, Study Suggests
abstract: Healthy Black women with low risk factors were far more likely to get C-sections than white women with similar medical histories, a large new study found.
lead_paragraph: Obstetricians are more likely to give Black women unnecessary cesarean sections, putting those women at higher risk for serious complications like ruptured surgical wounds.

headline: The Rules for the Harris-Trump Presidential Debate on ABC
abstract: The campaigns agreed to the same guidelines that were used in June, when former President Donald J. Trump and President Biden faced off.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump will meet for their first debate — which will also be the first time they meet in person.

headline: U.S., Imposing Sanctions, Accuses Iran of Sending Missiles to Russia
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke in London, where his British counterpart also promised a punitive response. They plan to visit Ukraine together.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken accused Iran on Tuesday of shipping short-range ballistic missiles to Russia for use in Ukraine and said that the Biden administration was imposing more sanctions against Tehran. The penalties include measures against Iran Air, the country’s main airline, he said.

headline: Fires Near Los Angeles May Intensify Before They Are Contained
abstract: Mountainous terrain, dry weather and winds are making it difficult to fight the wildfires threatening communities near Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The wildfires swelling in the mountains near Los Angeles on Tuesday are expected to get larger before weather conditions improve in the next few days.

headline: Husband on Trial in Rape and Drugging Case in France Is Taken to a Hospital
abstract: Dominique Pelicot, 71, was due to testify on Tuesday over charges he invited dozens of men to his home to abuse his wife, Gisèle Pelicot. His condition was not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: A man who confessed to drugging his wife for years and bringing dozens of men into their home to join him in raping her was taken to the hospital on Tuesday just hours before he was due to testify in his trial, his lawyer said.

headline: Harris Economic Plan Focuses on Prices, a Key Vulnerability
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has been balancing the challenges of defending “Bidenomics” and charting her own course on the economy.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris unveiled her economic plans in recent weeks, former President Donald J. Trump has accused her of being a Marxist, a communist and a socialist.

headline: Johnson’s Spending Plan Falters, Facing Resistance From Both Parties
abstract: The speaker’s first effort to avert a government shutdown ran into a buzz saw of opposition from both far-right and mainstream Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson’s initial plan to avert a government shutdown has run into a wall of Republican opposition, as lawmakers from an array of factions in his party balk at a six-month stopgap funding measure that Democrats have already rejected.

headline: Love on Aisle 9? A TikTok Fad Fills Grocery Stores With Singles.
abstract: How the Spanish grocery chain Mercadona got a reputation as an unlikely dating hub, with its upside-down pineapples as props.
lead_paragraph: As a scorching summer draws to its close in Spain, love is in the air in an unexpected place — in air-conditioned supermarket aisles. But only for an hour a day, and with an unusual accessory: an upturned pineapple in your shopping cart to let fellow lonely hearts know you’re available.

headline: Women Making Waves
abstract: Tory Burch plays to win, and Rachel Scott of Diotima has a star-making show.
lead_paragraph: One year ago, when it was announced that Sarah Burton was leaving Alexander McQueen after 26 years (13 as creative director), that she would be replaced by a young guy named Seán McGirr, and that that meant that all of the designers at Kering, the second largest fashion group in the world, would be men, the news caused a rare moment of breast-beating and introspection in the fashion world. Why were all the big jobs going to men? Why did there seem to be so few women designers?

headline: Art Institute of Chicago Receives $75 Million Gift
abstract: The donation from Aaron I. Fleischman and Lin Lougheed will support the museum’s new galleries.
lead_paragraph: The Art Institute of Chicago on Tuesday announced a gift of $75 million that will support new galleries for its collection of late-19th-century, modern and contemporary art.

headline: Southwest Airlines Agrees to Board Changes After Pressure From Elliott
abstract: The airline has been under pressure from the hedge fund Elliott to replace its top management and make other changes to increase its profits.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines on Tuesday announced an overhaul of its board of directors, including the planned departure of its executive chairman, Gary Kelly, after a meeting with a hedge fund that has called for sweeping changes at the company.

headline: ‘Emily in Paris’ Goes on a Roman Holiday
abstract: The frothy Netflix show frustrated Parisians with its portrait of their city. Now its heroine is heading to Rome — and the showrunner doesn’t care if residents there feel the same way.
lead_paragraph: “Emily in Paris,” the hit Netflix series about a young American living a life of romance and luxury in France, has ignited a blaze of indignation since it premiered in late 2020.

headline: 5 Climate Questions for the Candidates Ahead of the Presidential Debate
abstract: Here’s what the Times climate team would ask Harris and Trump about climate change, energy policy and the environment.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump take the stage for their first, and possibly only, debate ahead of the election on Nov. 5, it’s unclear whether or not climate change will be one of the topics they address.

headline: Was It Written by ChatGPT, or by a Novelist?
abstract: Three readers could pick the story written by Curtis Sittenfeld; another calls the experiment unfair. Also: Afghan women; athletes and crowds; pro-union workers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lincoln Center Theater Chooses Lear deBessonet as Artistic Director
abstract: DeBessonet, currently the artistic director of Encores!, will work alongside Bartlett Sher, who will serve as executive producer.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center Theater, a leading nonprofit theater with a long track record of producing luxe Broadway musical revivals as well as contemporary plays, has chosen new leadership for the first time in more than three decades.

headline: Tortellini to the Rescue
abstract: Ali Slagle’s tortellini with prosciutto and peas turns a refrigerated staple into a surprisingly luxurious one-pan dinner.
lead_paragraph: I took one of my kids to the grocery store last week with the specific goal of divining what she might happily eat at home for dinner and in her lunchbox at school, as opposed to what she vehemently claims she won’t eat under any circumstances.

headline: Inside the Funeral Home for New York’s Luminaries
abstract: Everybody dies. But not everybody is embalmed at Frank E. Campbell, a discreet mortuary on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. John Lennon. Greta Garbo. Jean-Michel Basquiat. Mae West. Arthur Ashe. Ivana Trump. Luther Vandross. Heath Ledger. George Balanchine. George Gershwin. Mario Cuomo. Biggie Smalls. Nikola Tesla. Celia Cruz. Joan Rivers. Aaliyah. Ayn Rand. Lena Horne. Norman Mailer. Philip Seymour Hoffman. Logan Roy.

headline: After Fierce Lobbying, Regulators Soften Proposed Rules on Banks
abstract: A top Federal Reserve official said blowback to proposed rules on capital requirements had led him to “relearn the lesson of humility.”
lead_paragraph: After a yearslong war of words, regulators on Tuesday watered down an effort to layer new oversight on banks, all but conceding that they had reached too far.

headline: JD Vance Appears to Backtrack on False Claim About Haitian Migrants in Ohio
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential nominee acknowledged that an outlandish claim he had amplified about Haitian immigrants stealing and eating pets could “turn out to be false.”
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate, appeared to backtrack on Tuesday on an outlandish false claim that he had promoted a day earlier saying that Haitian residents of Springfield, Ohio, were abducting and eating their neighbors’ pets.

headline: Here Are the Key Debate Attacks to Expect. Hint: It May Get Personal.
abstract: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris have never met, and may not meet again onstage during this campaign. Tonight they have a huge, fleeting spotlight to change how voters see their rival.
lead_paragraph: At their first, and possibly only, debate, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump will have a chance to paint the picture of their opponent that they want voters to see.

headline: How to Protect Yourself From Wildfire Smoke
abstract: Monitor air quality, prepare to stay inside and pay close attention to people with chronic conditions.
lead_paragraph: Several rapidly spreading wildfires in Southern California have generated unhealthy levels of smoke in areas close to where the blazes are burning. And millions of people across Southern California are also under an excessive heat warning. Here’s how people can stay safe.

headline: Longtime MoMA Director Will Step Down Next Year
abstract: After 30 years at the helm of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, Glenn Lowry will depart in September 2025.
lead_paragraph: After 30 years of leading the Museum of Modern Art, during which he moved one of the country’s leading museums from the 20th century into the 21st, Glenn D. Lowry announced on Tuesday that he would step down as its director in September 2025.

headline: Tracking Typhoon Bebinca
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Bebinca.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Bebinca.

headline: Volkswagen Quits Labor Agreement, Paving Way for Job Cuts
abstract: A week after the automaker announced it was considering closing factories in Germany, the company said it was exiting a labor contract that protected workers from layoffs.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen told union leaders on Tuesday that it was ending a labor agreement that protected workers from layoffs, a week after the automaker said it was considering closing factories in Germany amid slumping sales and rising costs.

headline: Trump Is Making Promises That Many Economists Call Unrealistic
abstract: Economists and analysts are dubious of Trump’s promises to slash gas prices or prod interest rates lower.
lead_paragraph: As he seeks to return to the White House, former President Donald J. Trump has pledged to cut Americans’ energy costs in half in the span of a year, part of a plan to reduce inflation and drive mortgage rates back toward record lows.

headline: ‘Imminent Threat’ Found at Boar’s Head Plant 2 Years Before Fatal Listeria Outbreak
abstract: U.S. inspectors listed serious problems in 2022 that could have resulted in strict measures like a pause in production. But the plant continued operating, and some conditions persisted.
lead_paragraph: Two years before a deadly listeria outbreak, U.S. inspectors warned that conditions at a Boar’s Head plant posed an “imminent threat” to public health, citing extensive rust, deli meats exposed to wet ceilings, green mold and holes in the walls.

headline: Jordan Holds Election With Domestic Issues and Gaza in Focus
abstract: The Muslim Brotherhood has campaigned on opposition to the Gaza war, but analysts say it won’t be as decisive a factor in parliamentary elections as high unemployment.
lead_paragraph: Voters went to the polls for a parliamentary election in the Arab kingdom of Jordan on Tuesday, with domestic concerns such as unemployment high on their agenda, although an Islamist party has tried to ride a wave of popular anger about Israel’s war in Gaza to challenge the pro-Western government.

headline: Delta Plane Strikes Another Jet on Atlanta Airport Tarmac
abstract: The incident involving two planes getting ready to take off was the latest in a series of mishaps and near accidents at the country’s airports.
lead_paragraph: Two Delta Air Lines planes collided on the tarmac at an airport in Atlanta on Tuesday morning. There were no reports of injuries.

headline: How a Tuesday Rush Hour Became a Doom Loop for New Jersey Commuters
abstract: On Tuesday morning, trains and buses from New Jersey were stymied by a power outage and traffic accidents.
lead_paragraph: Amtrak’s antiquated system for powering trains in the New York City region disrupted the morning rush again on Tuesday, a day that was already off to a bad start for thousands of city-bound commuters.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the First Harris-Trump Debate?
abstract: On Tuesday night, the candidates met for their only scheduled debate. Did you watch?
lead_paragraph: Please note: Our Student Opinion questions specifically invite the voices of young people. We ask that adults respect the intent of this forum and refrain from posting here.

headline: Gunman Who Shot Trump Was Not Spotted as Early as Reported
abstract: A law enforcement officer at the rally where the former president was shot now says he misidentified a man he saw earlier that day as Thomas Crooks.
lead_paragraph: A local law enforcement officer recently told investigators that he was mistaken when he said that the man he spotted near a warehouse complex more than 100 minutes before former President Donald J. Trump was shot at a rally in Butler, Pa., was the gunman.

headline: Ukrainian Drone Attack Hits Apartment Buildings Near Moscow
abstract: One woman was killed in the Moscow suburb of Ramenskoye after Ukraine launched one of its largest drone attacks of the war, Kremlin officials said.
lead_paragraph: One woman was killed in the Moscow suburb of Ramenskoye after Ukraine launched one of its largest drone attacks of the war, Kremlin officials said.

headline: The Riches of Northern France in Fort Greene
abstract: Plus cocktails inspired by red sauce standards, bistro fare for the East Village and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: There are raw bars across the dinnerscape; a bistro tuned in to Northern France can’t be without one. Cali Faulkner, an alum of Crown Shy and Eleven Madison Park and the owner and chef of Third Falcon, spent time in the region while working in Paris. Sole meunière, a dish that wowed Julia Child when she first arrived in France, here comes with summer squash, evidence also of Ms. Faulkner’s passion for local produce. Lush desserts include buckwheat sticky toffee pudding, and brown butter-Calvados ice cream. Also on the concise menu in the light, spare restaurant trimmed in marine blue, are kouign-amann with caviar and côte de veau with apples. The wine list is brief, and there are ciders.

headline: Maps: Tracking the Wildfires Around Los Angeles
abstract: Here’s a look at where fires are burning and where smoke is expected.
lead_paragraph: Several wildfires are burning in Southern California, prompting evacuations and threatening homes as they continue to grow quickly.

headline: Harris Ad Features Obama’s Oblique Joke About Trump
abstract: The spot, which focuses on Barack Obama’s remark about a “weird obsession with crowd sizes” and accompanying gesture, is airing in media markets where Donald Trump is likely to be.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign is running a trolling ad ahead of the debate Tuesday directed at exactly one person: former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Cast Is Set for ‘Saturday Night Live’ Season 50
abstract: Ashley Padilla, Emil Wakim and Jane Wickline will be the show’s new faces in its landmark season.
lead_paragraph: The cast for Season 50 of the NBC sketch comedy series “Saturday Night Live” is in place, with the up-and-coming comedians Ashley Padilla, Emil Wakim and Jane Wickline joining as featured players, the network announced on Tuesday. The new season is scheduled to premiere on Sept. 28.

headline: Pakistani Police Arrest Lawmakers Allied With Former Prime Minister Imran Khan
abstract: In an overnight raid on the Parliament, police arrested at least 10 members of Khan’s party, deepening the political battle between the imprisoned ex-leader and the country’s powerful military.
lead_paragraph: Pakistani police arrested at least 10 lawmakers belonging to the imprisoned former Prime Minister Imran Khan’s political party, in an hourslong raid on the Parliament building in Islamabad that began Monday night, officials said.

headline: Trump and Democrats Agree: U.S. Needs a National Wealth Fund for Investments
abstract: Donald Trump has suggested he wants one, and the White House indicated that it has been quietly working on a proposal to set one up.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and the Biden-Harris administration have little common ground on the policy front, but one unexpected area of agreement is the idea that the United States might be ready for a sovereign wealth fund.

headline: James Earl Jones’s Stage Career Was Rich, and Startlingly Diverse
abstract: In addition to Broadway crowd-pleasers, the actor deftly navigated classics, experimental theater and new works by major contemporary playwrights.
lead_paragraph: The world will remember James Earl Jones, who died Monday at the age of 93, for his contributions to film, some of which are secure in the pop-culture canon.

headline: Congress Honors U.S. Service Members Killed During Afghanistan Withdrawal
abstract: Leaders awarded the Congressional Gold Medal to the families of 13 military service members killed during the evacuation, as Republicans seek to use the attack to tarnish Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Top lawmakers on Tuesday presented the Congressional Gold Medal to the families of 13 U.S. service members killed in a terrorist attack during the evacuation of Afghanistan, as Republicans make an election-season push to blame Vice President Kamala Harris for their deaths.

headline: The Midlife Marriage Tuneup
abstract: Therapists and relationship researchers share 6 questions that can bring couples closer during this stage.
lead_paragraph: Midlife can be a weird time. Maybe you’re grappling with new aches and pains or brain fog. Perhaps you’re one of the 2.5 million sandwich generation caregivers simultaneously caring for children and aging parents. Maybe you’re having an identity crisis, maybe not.

headline: Readers Pick Their Song of the Summer
abstract: You sent in an eclectic mix of tracks from Chappell Roan, Bad Bunny, Lawrence and more.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I asked you to share your 2024 song of the summer. Not necessarily your favorite of the pop smashes that defined the balmiest months of this year — because I’ve already compiled a playlist of those — but the song that served as your personal soundtrack to the season. The song that will conjure a montaged rush of summer of ’24 memories when you hear it years from now.

headline: 2,000-Pound Bombs Likely Used in Al-Mawasi Strike
abstract: The large size of the two craters left in the aftermath of the attack suggest that Israel used the powerful bombs, according to experts and a New York Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: Large craters and a bomb fragment from an Israeli airstrike on a camp for displaced people early Tuesday provide strong evidence that Israel used 2,000-pound bombs, according to three weapons experts.

headline: Israeli Military Reveals Brutal Conditions 6 Hostages Endured in a Gaza Tunnel
abstract: The hostages, whose bodies were recently recovered, appear to have spent the last weeks of their lives in a tight and humid tunnel about 20 meters underground.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military released new information on Tuesday about the six hostages whose bodies were recently discovered in a tunnel in Gaza, including video of the tunnel and details that shed light on the brutal conditions in which they were held.

headline: White House Is Drawn Into Dispute Over Chinese Doping
abstract: World Anti-Doping Agency officials, furious at U.S. investigations into the handling of positive tests, have sought to exclude a Biden administration representative from its board meetings.
lead_paragraph: The fight between the United States and the world’s antidoping regulator over the handling of positive tests by elite Chinese swimmers has escalated in recent weeks and drawn in a powerful new player: the Biden White House.

headline: ‘You Do Need to Tell a Story’: Why U.K.’s Leader Faced Revolt Over Retiree Benefit Cut
abstract: Prime Minister Keir Starmer survived a test of his authority, but more than 50 Labour lawmakers did not back his plan to reduce fuel aid.
lead_paragraph: Nine weeks into his new job as Britain’s prime minister, Keir Starmer suffered his first big parliamentary rebellion on Tuesday, in a vote that exposed unease about his center-left government’s austere tone and focus on belt-tightening.

headline: Ex-Music Teacher Who Sexually Abused Middle Schoolers Gets 30 Years
abstract: Jesus Concepcion, a teacher at a Bronx middle school, gave cellphones to girls so he could contact them without their parents’ knowledge, and he bought them gifts to lure them in.
lead_paragraph: A former music teacher at a Bronx middle school was sentenced on Tuesday to 30 years in prison for sexually abusing five female students decades ago, plying them with phones and gifts and manipulating them into thinking he was in love.

headline: The Mirage of $2 Gas
abstract: Trump is promising something he can’t possibly deliver.
lead_paragraph: Political speeches are often worth skipping, not conveying much new information. But Donald Trump’s speech last week at the Economic Club of New York was quite newsworthy, in several ways.

headline: Kamala Harris Visited a Spice Shop. Her Critics Flooded Yelp With Bad Reviews.
abstract: Penzeys, a chain of spice stores in more than 20 states, has frequently criticized Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris preached unity when she took a break from debate prep and visited a spice shop in Pittsburgh on Saturday.

headline: Missouri High Court Restores Abortion Measure to Ballot
abstract: The court ruled hours before the state’s deadline for printing ballots for absentee voters, reversing the secretary of state who had invalidated the measure weeks after certifying it.
lead_paragraph: The Missouri Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected a bid to strike a question on the November ballot that will ask voters whether to establish a right to abortion in the State Constitution.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Delaware primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Delaware primary elections.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Rhode Island primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Rhode Island primary elections.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 New Hampshire primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 New Hampshire primary elections.

headline: Poverty Increased in 2023 as Prices Rose and Pandemic Aid Programs Expired
abstract: More faced hardship in the United States last year, the Census Bureau said, as inflation and the end of subsidies outweighed higher incomes.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s poverty rate rose last year even as incomes improved, the government reported on Tuesday, reflecting higher prices and the expiration of the last pandemic relief programs.

headline: Two ABC News Anchors Will Steer the Harris-Trump Debate
abstract: The moderators, David Muir and Linsey Davis, have the difficult task of guiding a high-stakes encounter.
lead_paragraph: ABC News, the sponsor of Tuesday’s debate, wants the evening’s stars to be the candidates onstage, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Chris Christie: I’ve Debated Trump 6 Times. Here’s What Harris Needs to Do Tonight.
abstract: Millions of Americans are waiting for her to earn their vote. Here’s how she can do that.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of Americans will be watching the first debate between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on Tuesday night. Many of these folks will be Republicans and independents who, like me, have decided that they are unwilling to vote for Mr. Trump.

headline: Those Keurig Coffee Pods? They’re Not So Recyclable, the S.E.C. Says.
abstract: The agency said Keurig, in its financial filings, had claimed its pods could be “effectively recycled” but didn’t note that two big recycling companies wouldn’t accept them.
lead_paragraph: Financial regulators on Tuesday charged Keurig Dr Pepper, the maker of popular K-Cup single-use coffee pods, with making inaccurate claims about the recyclability of the plastic pods.

headline: ‘Flip-Flop’ or Evolution: Trump and Harris and Their Reversals on Issues
abstract: Kamala Harris has backed away from some progressive positions she took in the 2020 primaries. Donald Trump has changed his stripes on a host of issues big and small, sometimes repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris face off in their debate Tuesday night, one likely area of contention will be their mutual accusations of flip-flopping — a charge that politicians have long deployed to portray their opponents as lacking principle.

headline: Kim Kardashian, Katy Perry and Lindsay Lohan in Their Fashion Week Best
abstract: At a gala and auction in Midtown, the Kering Foundation drew one of the starriest crowds of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood met fashion in force at a gala and auction on Monday night in Midtown Manhattan, where Kim Kardashian bid on Balenciaga couture, a nude photograph of Madonna sold for $70,000, and “How do you know Jeff and Lauren?” (Bezos and Sanchez) was a common refrain over cocktails.

headline: I.C.C. Prosecutor Presses Court for Arrest Warrants for Hamas Chiefs and Israeli Leaders
abstract: The prosecutor, Karim Khan, asked the court to make its decision on the warrants with the “utmost urgency” because of “the worsening situation in Palestine.”
lead_paragraph: The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, Karim Khan, called in a filing made public this week for a swift decision on issuing arrest warrants for a top Hamas official in connection with the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel and the Israeli prime minister and defense minister over Israel’s response and conduct of the war in Gaza.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: A Guide to the Harris-Trump Debate
abstract: Plus, the great films of James Earl Jones.
lead_paragraph: It’s the moment an entire nation has been waiting for: debate night.

headline: In the South of France, a Utopian Town Inspired by Ancient Pyramids
abstract: Once derided, La Grande Motte, a surreal 1960s resort in the South of France, is increasingly seen as having been ahead of its time.
lead_paragraph: How do you build a town from scratch? For an answer, you might look to two metropolises that sprang up in just a handful of years during the 1950s and ’60s: Chandigarh, the Swiss French architect Le Corbusier’s planned city in northern India, and Brasília, the sprawling capital of Brazil, designed by the urban planner Lúcio Costa and the architect Oscar Niemeyer. Far less well known, but inspired by the same modernist belief in architecture’s utopian potential, is La Grand Motte, an otherworldly resort town of curving white concrete towers spread across nearly 2,000 acres of former marshland in the South of France.

headline: Will Jennings, Oscar Winner for ‘My Heart Will Go On,’ Dies at 80
abstract: As an in-demand lyricist, he won a shelf of awards for hits with Steve Winwood, Eric Clapton and Dionne Warwick, as well as for the theme song for “Titanic.”
lead_paragraph: Will Jennings, an English professor turned lyricist whose 1998 Academy Award for “My Heart Will Go On,” the theme song from the movie “Titanic,” capped a long career writing hits for musicians like Steve Winwood, Eric Clapton and Dionne Warwick, died on Sept. 6 at his home in Tyler, Texas. He was 80.

headline: A Weather Change Could Spark New Wildfires, Then Help Contain Them
abstract: A system that will bring a beneficial shift in temperatures and humidity to California later in the week could first drive winds that send sparks into dangerously dry undergrowth.
lead_paragraph: Southern California started to slowly cool off Tuesday after days of mercilessly hot weather. The moderating temperatures — in the 90s after a brutal heat wave had pushed temperatures as high as 110 degrees — aided firefighting efforts.

headline: Francisco Lopera, Pioneer in Alzheimer’s Research, Dies at 73
abstract: A neurologist in Colombia, he worked with the world’s largest extended family with Alzheimer’s and helped fuel research to prevent or delay dementia symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Francisco Lopera, a trailblazing neurologist who identified the world’s largest extended family with Alzheimer’s and spent decades working with them in his native Colombia, died on Tuesday at his home in Medellín. He was 73. The cause was metastatic melanoma.

headline: Officer Demoted After Writing Traffic Tickets Gets $175,000 Settlement
abstract: Matthew Bianchi said he was transferred after he angered a high-ranking official of the New York Police Department by ticketing a friend.
lead_paragraph: New York City on Tuesday reached a $175,000 settlement with a Staten Island police officer who said he had been a victim of retaliation for giving traffic tickets to people with connections to the upper echelons of the Police Department.

headline: Matt Damon, Robert De Niro, Oprah and Other Celebrities Pitch in for Harris
abstract: Fund-raisers held by Hollywood stars over the next few weeks will be particularly helpful for Vice President Kamala Harris, who has limited time to headline big-money events.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that Hollywood is firmly behind Vice President Kamala Harris?

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Had a Crush on the Teacher’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: He was a handyman referred to me during the pandemic by a neighbor. I opened the door with unbrushed hair while wearing pajamas. During that lonely time he seemed to be the prettiest man I had ever seen, and I wanted to close my front door again so I could pull myself together. Over the next three months, I found thousands of dollars of work for him to do in my house. When I ran out of projects and hadn’t seen him for a few weeks, I had no alternative but to ask him out. — Shay-Ann Heiser Singh

headline: The Internet Spent Years Searching for Her. She Had No Idea.
abstract: A mysterious woman came to be known on Reddit as Celebrity Number Six. She told us she is not sure how to feel about the sudden crush of attention.
lead_paragraph: Leticia Sarda is 43 and lives on the Spanish island of Tenerife in the Canary Islands. She has two children and used to travel the globe working as a model for brands like Burberry. For nearly the last five years, thousands of people on the internet have been trying desperately to find her.

headline: How False Claims About Immigrants and Dead Pets Became a Trump Talking Point
abstract: Falsehoods claiming migrants in Ohio are killing cats and decapitating ducks went viral this week. The Trump campaign embraced them.
lead_paragraph: A falsehood that migrants have killed wild animals and household pets for food ricocheted around the internet this week, vaulting from fringe social media posts to the presidential debate stage in a matter of days.

headline: Tonight’s Debate Will Focus on Defining Kamala Harris
abstract: Also, Louisiana is bracing for Francine. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump will square off tonight at 9 p.m. Eastern for their first, and likely only, debate during this unusually compressed presidential campaign. You can watch the event live on The Times website, alongside real-time analysis from reporters.

headline: Was James Earl Jones an EGOT Winner? It’s Complicated.
abstract: The actor won just about every award he could — but his Oscar was an honorary one. Is that enough for an EGOT?
lead_paragraph: When James Earl Jones died on Monday, some headlines called the prolific actor — known for his deep, mellifluous voice — an EGOT winner. But whether he’s really in the elite club isn’t so clear.

headline: Israeli Bombing in Gaza Humanitarian Zone Kills at Least 19, Officials Say
abstract: The Israeli airstrike, which the military said targeted Hamas militants, appeared to use 2,000-pound bombs, which Israel has been criticized for using in heavily populated areas.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes early on Tuesday slammed into a part of the Gaza Strip that Israel had declared a humanitarian zone, killing at least 19 people and wounding 60, according to Gazan officials, in an area where tens of thousands of Palestinians forced from their homes had sought refuge in tents and makeshift shelters.

headline: Firm Run by Brother of Top N.Y.C. Officials Is Focus of Bribery Inquiry
abstract: Terence Banks opened a consulting firm and soon found work with companies that do business with the city agencies overseen by his older brothers.
lead_paragraph: Federal agents are investigating a possible bribery scheme involving New York City contracts and a consulting firm run by the brother of two top officials in the administration of Mayor Eric Adams, two people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Illinois Man Wrongly Convicted of 2008 Murder Is Awarded $50 Million
abstract: Marcel Brown, 34, spent nearly 10 years in prison after he was coerced into making a false confession in connection to a 2008 murder, a jury decided Monday.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in Chicago on Monday awarded an Illinois man who spent nearly 10 years in prison after he was wrongfully convicted of murder more than $50 million, among the largest rewards for such a case in the United States.

headline: Melania Trump, Silent for Months, Re-emerges in a Series of Cryptic Videos
abstract: In one, released online on Tuesday, she muses conspiratorially about the attempt on her husband’s life. The videos are intended to promote a new memoir.
lead_paragraph: What’s up with Melania?

headline: Skeptical House Panel Grills Cuomo on New York’s Covid Response
abstract: The Republican-led subcommittee sought to blame the former governor for the state’s early-pandemic guidance that may have left New Yorkers more vulnerable to dying in nursing homes.
lead_paragraph: During the early days of the coronavirus pandemic, Andrew M. Cuomo, the pugilistic former governor of New York, was initially hailed as a national model for his leadership of the state’s response.

headline: The Optimism and Anxiety Ahead of Tonight’s Debate
abstract: I asked again how you’re feeling about the debate. You responded with new worries and hopes.
lead_paragraph: For Beth Anne Riches of South Bend, Ind., the presidential debate tonight between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump can’t come soon enough.

headline: Tracking Attacks in the First Harris-Trump Debate
abstract: See how the candidates used their speaking time to discuss the issues or criticize their opponent.
lead_paragraph: See how the candidates used their speaking time to discuss the issues or criticize their opponent.

headline: Inmate’s Wife Subjected to Cavity Search Will Get $5.6 Million in Settlement
abstract: Christina Cardenas of California was subjected to the search after going to visit her husband at a state prison in 2019, according to her lawsuit. “It left me traumatized,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Christina Cardenas hadn’t seen her husband in more than a year when, after a four-hour drive in September 2019, she finally reached the state prison in Tehachapi, Calif., where he was being held.

headline: PGA Tour Meets With Saudi Fund in Hopes of Getting Closer to Deal
abstract: More than a year has passed since the tour agreed to a deal with LIV Golf, but there is some hope an in-person gathering in New York could create momentum.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after the PGA Tour announced plans to combine forces with the Saudi Arabian sovereign wealth fund’s upstart LIV Golf league, the two sides met in Manhattan on Tuesday in hopes of — finally — making headway on getting to a deal.

headline: Here Are Some of the Prominent Surrogates at the Debate Site
abstract: Anthony Scaramucci and Tulsi Gabbard are there. But you might be surprised which candidate they’re supporting.
lead_paragraph: The campaigns of Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump said they would have an eclectic mix of recent converts and party-line-crossers at the debate in Philadelphia on Tuesday.

headline: Adams’s Pick for Top Lawyer Withdraws His Nomination
abstract: Randy Mastro, a former federal prosecutor and aide to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said he had been denied a fair hearing by the City Council.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s choice to become the city’s top lawyer asked on Tuesday for his nomination to be withdrawn after the City Council questioned his fitness for the office during a bruising 11-hour hearing last month.

headline: Transgender Lawmaker Wins Democratic Primary for Delaware’s Only House Seat
abstract: Sarah McBride, a Delaware state senator, is favored to win in November. She would become the first openly transgender member of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Sarah McBride, a state legislator, won the Democratic primary for Delaware’s only U.S. House seat, The Associated Press reported, making her the heavy favorite to win in November in the deep-blue state. If elected, she would become the first openly transgender member of Congress.

headline: Lawyer Wins Democratic Primary in New Hampshire’s Second District
abstract: Maggie Goodlander, who has deep Washington ties, edged out Colin Van Ostern, who unsuccessfully ran for New Hampshire governor in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Goodlander, a former Justice Department official and political newcomer, won the Democratic primary for New Hampshire’s Second Congressional District on Tuesday after a close race against Colin Van Ostern, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Polaris Dawn Astronauts Reach Record High Orbit Above Earth
abstract: After launching early on Tuesday, the billionaire Jared Isaacman and his crew traveled to altitudes not visited by any astronaut since the Apollo moon missions of the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Four private astronauts aboard an ambitious space mission led by a billionaire entrepreneur traveled farther from Earth on Tuesday than any other human being in more than half a century.

headline: Part of a Club
abstract: Barbara Lin reflects on common sayings.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Harris Blames Trump for State Abortion Bans in Contentious Debate
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris went on offense over abortion policy. “The government and Donald Trump, certainly, should not be telling a woman what to do with her body,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris laced into former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday over his role in the overturning of Roe v. Wade, blaming him for subsequent state-level abortion bans that, she said, have had painful consequences for many American women and their families.

headline: ‘They’re Eating the Cats’: Trump Repeats False Claim About Immigrants
abstract: Donald J. Trump amplified an outlandish internet theory from the debate stage, drawing laughter from his opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump repeated a false and outlandish claim that Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, have abducted and eaten their neighbors’ pets.

headline: Trump Ties Harris Critically to Her Father, a Professor Who Studied Marxism
abstract: Donald J. Trump called Kamala Harris a “Marxist” because her father taught the subject at Stanford University, though she has repeatedly made clear that she supports capitalism.
lead_paragraph: Early in Tuesday’s debate, former President Donald J. Trump attacked Vice President Kamala Harris by tying her to her father.

headline: Over 90 Minutes, Trump Descended to His True Self
abstract: He fell right into the traps Harris set for him.
lead_paragraph: For the first 10 minutes or so of Tuesday night’s debate, it looked as though the restrained version of Donald Trump might have shown up in Philadelphia, the one who learned his lesson from his failure to curb his impulses in the 2020 debates with Joe Biden. He stayed silent while Kamala Harris ripped up his economic plan, which she correctly noted was based on a tax cut for the wealthy and a sales tax on all imported goods. When it was his turn to respond, he accurately pointed out that the Biden administration had made no attempt to end the tariffs he imposed on China.

headline: Taylor Swift Endorses Kamala Harris
abstract: Her Instagram post backing the vice president came shortly after Ms. Harris and former President Donald Trump had stepped off the debate stage.
lead_paragraph: Look what they made her do.

headline: Yes, Kamala Harris Owns a Handgun
abstract: In rebutting a claim from former President Donald J. Trump during their debate, the vice president asserted that she owned a gun, adding, “We’re not taking anybody’s guns away.”
lead_paragraph: Late during the presidential debate on Tuesday, Vice President Kamala Harris asserted something that might have surprised some viewers: She owns a gun.

headline: Rep. Joe Wilson Is Hospitalized
abstract: Mr. Wilson, 77, a Republican running for re-election in South Carolina, “experienced stroke-like symptoms,” his son said.
lead_paragraph: Representative Joe Wilson, Republican of South Carolina, was taken to a hospital on Tuesday, according to a social media post.

headline: Quote of the Day: Amid Bombs, Nail Salons Can Soothe a Country
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes you sit down and cry. But in the morning you get up, put on lipstick, go out looking beautiful and water the flowers.”

headline: Cholera Deaths Soar Worldwide Despite Being Easily Preventable
abstract: Fatalities spiked 71 percent last year, far outpacing the 13 percent rise in cases, the World Health Organization said.
lead_paragraph: The cholera outbreaks spreading across the globe are becoming more deadly. Deaths from the diarrheal disease soared last year, far outpacing the increase in cases, according to a new analysis by the World Health Organization.

headline: Family of American Woman Held in China for 10 Years Asks for Help
abstract: Dawn Michelle Hunt, who is serving a life sentence, says she was duped into carrying drugs. Her family says she is seriously ill and should be sent home.
lead_paragraph: Dawn Michelle Hunt loved sweepstakes. A 42-year-old temp worker in Chicago, she entered almost every contest she encountered. So when she got an email from someone who described himself as a British lawyer saying she had won a trip to Australia, she was elated.

headline: How Russia’s Steady Advance Threatens Ukraine’s East
abstract: Russia is getting closer to cutting critical supply lines for troops in the remaining Ukrainian strongholds across the region.
lead_paragraph: Russia is getting closer to cutting critical supply lines for troops in the remaining Ukrainian strongholds across the region.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: A contentious U.S. presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris took the debate stage on Tuesday night, shook the hand of former President Donald Trump and then spent the next 90 minutes making every effort to burrow under his skin. She hammered him over his criminal convictions, his handling of the Covid-19 pandemic, the size of his rally crowds and the foreign and military leaders who she said have called him a “disgrace.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 11, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the growing community of Catholic priests in Indonesia misidentified the island of Flores. It is part of one of the poorest provinces in Indonesia, East Nusa Tenggara; it is not a province on its own. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

headline: After Questioning Harris’s Race, Trump Tries to Walk It Back at Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump tried to soften his claim that Vice President Kamala Harris had changed her racial identity. She called his divisive remarks a ‘tragedy.’
lead_paragraph: In late July, Donald J. Trump said at a gathering of Black journalists in Chicago that “all of a sudden,” Vice President Kamala Harris had “made a turn and she became a Black person.”

headline: The Moment Trump Couldn’t Resist Bungling
abstract: A four-minute stretch, in which the former president wandered from crowd sizes to cat conspiracy theories, seemed to alter the evening’s trajectory.
lead_paragraph: She looked faux-fascinated, as if coaxing him into thinking he was onto something — nodding, head-tilting, performatively squinting, smiling a little, then a little more — a reel of soon-to-be memes, screaming silent bemusement with a hand on her chin.

headline: Trump Walked Into the Media ‘Spin Room’ Himself After the Debate
abstract: It was an unusual move for a presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump said he would spin the reporters himself.

headline: Best, Worst and Most Surprising Lines From the Presidential Debate
abstract: Kamala Harris reminded viewers she owns a gun. Donald Trump repeated a debunked internet rumor about immigrants eating cats.
lead_paragraph: In the 105-minute titanic showdown between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday in Philadelphia, there were pointed barbs, missed opportunities and puzzling tangents — and a worrying number of animal mentions.

headline: Who Won the Debate? A Sharp Harris Rattled Trump
abstract: Commentators, even Republicans, concluded that Kamala Harris had succeeded in provoking Donald Trump into veering off message.
lead_paragraph: In the first, and perhaps only, presidential debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump, the two candidates verbally sparred in often deeply personal terms, with policy arguments largely being overshadowed by fiery exchanges over character and crowd size.

headline: Harris Put Trump on Defense Over Abortion — and Kept Him There
abstract: For Trump, anger seemed to be the feeling of the night.
lead_paragraph: Debating Hillary Clinton in 2016, former President Donald Trump said that if he were elected president, he would appoint two or three anti-abortion Supreme Court justices who would “automatically” overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: Harris Dominates as Trump Gets Defensive: 6 Takeaways From the Debate
abstract: Laying out bait that Donald Trump eagerly snatched, the vice president owned much of the night, keeping him on the back foot and avoiding sustained attention on her own vulnerabilities.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: Trump Looked Livid. Harris Looked Amused. It Was No Contest.
abstract: Donald Trump can be beaten. That was the clearest takeaway on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: In Kamala Harris’s big general-election debate four years ago, she faced off against an opponent with a fly on his head.

headline: As Trump Links Her to Biden, Harris Says, ‘You’re Running Against Me’
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris largely deflected former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to tie her to President Biden.
lead_paragraph: After former President Donald J. Trump had tried several times during the debate to tie Vice President Kamala Harris to President Biden and his policies, she decided to try to make something abundantly clear.

headline: In Debate With Trump, Harris’s Expressions Were a Weapon
abstract: Tuesday’s debate was expected to center on defining Kamala Harris. Instead, with words and with body language, she turned it into a referendum on Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates and debate analysis on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: Word of the Day: volatile
abstract: This word has appeared in 684 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word volatile has appeared in 684 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 22 in “The Trials of a Paralympian Whose Disability Doesn’t Always Show” by John Leland and Kaitlin Balasaygun:

headline: Mexico’s Judicial Overhaul Overcomes Its Biggest Obstacle: The Senate
abstract: The chamber’s approval clears away the last major hindrance to the sweeping proposals championed by the president, which have prompted nationwide strikes.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s Senate on Wednesday narrowly passed a sweeping proposal to revamp the judiciary system, effectively clearing the last major obstacle to a measure that the country’s president had vowed to push through before stepping down at the end of this month.

headline: ABC’s Matter-of-Fact Moderators Built Factual Guardrails Around Trump
abstract: Calmly and firmly, Linsey Davis and David Muir pursued the kind of real-time fact-checking missing from many previous debates.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: Why Nearly All Judges in Mexico Could Soon Be Chosen by Voters
abstract: The legislation passed by Congress could produce one of the most far-reaching judicial overhauls in any major democracy.
lead_paragraph: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico leaves office at the end of September. But before he does, he will see one of his final missions largely fulfilled: a sweeping redesign of the judiciary that he says is needed to fight corruption.

headline: ‘The End of Our Country’: Trump Paints Dark Picture at Debate
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump offered a dire portrait of America, often relying on false and debunked claims as he described “a failing nation.”
lead_paragraph: For most of the 90-minute debate between former President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris, the former president bellowed into the microphone, practically spitting at moments as he took the bait time and again and got knocked off his goals.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: 23 Years After 9/11, Families of Cancer Victims Fight for Benefits
abstract: Some families are still pushing for recognition after their loved ones died from cancer that they believe is linked to Sept. 11, but that the federal government won’t recognize as such.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks that followed Sept. 11, 2001, when David Skiba came home from lengthy search-and-rescue shifts at ground zero, his wife would take his shoes and place them outside.

headline: Late Night Hosts Declare Harris the Winner in the Debate
abstract: Stephen Colbert said that the vice president needed to “rattle Trump’s cage. And now that it is over, they are still looking for pieces of his cage in low orbit.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Trump and Harris Clash in a Fiery Presidential Debate
abstract: In their first face-to-face meeting, Kamala Harris put Donald Trump on the defensive as the former president tried to tie her to unpopular Biden administration policies.
lead_paragraph: In their first face-to-face meeting, Kamala Harris put Donald Trump on the defensive as the former president tried to tie her to unpopular Biden administration policies.

headline: Pundits Said Harris Won the Debate. Undecided Voters Weren’t So Sure.
abstract: Voters said the vice president talked about a sweeping vision to fix the country’s most stubborn problems. But they wanted the fine print.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: Sleep Routine
abstract: What do you do to get ready for a good night’s rest?
lead_paragraph: What is your bedtime routine?

headline: Iran’s New President, Tending to a Pivotal Alliance, Visits Iraq
abstract: In a region in turmoil, Tehran’s ties to its neighbor are more important than ever.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s president, Masoud Pezeshkian, arrived in Iraq on Wednesday for his first trip abroad since taking office in July, a demonstration of the value the Iranians place on the strategic alliance with their neighbor as tensions rise in the region around them.

headline: In Kyiv, Blinken Discusses Ukraine’s Push for Deep Missile Strikes into Russia
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and his British counterpart, David Lammy, made a rare joint trip to Ukraine to show allied solidarity as the American presidential election looms.
lead_paragraph: In a rare joint visit abroad, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and his British counterpart, David Lammy, met with the top leaders of Ukraine in Kyiv on Wednesday to discuss bolstering the Ukrainian military and whether to allow it to use imported long-range missiles to strike deep into Russia.

headline: Hanoi Floods as Landslides and Rising Rivers Push Typhoon Death Toll to 143
abstract: Days after the storm made landfall, northern Vietnam was being battered by incessant rain. A landslide buried a whole village in a mountainous province.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in Vietnam from Typhoon Yagi has risen to 143, with dozens more missing, the government said on Wednesday, as relentless rain continued to cause landslides in small villages and flooding in the capital of Hanoi.

headline: The Book That Prepared This Veteran Editor for a Literary Life
abstract: A 1966 novel captures a publishing world full of chronic malcontents, strategic lunches and ideas that mattered.
lead_paragraph: I’ve read Wilfrid Sheed’s novel OFFICE POLITICS (McNally Editions, 300 pp., paperback, $18) three times in my life, at three very different stages and with three very different takeaways.

headline: Sacred Sites and Sun-Dappled Canals: Kyoto from the Water
abstract: The Japanese city is famous for its temples and gardens, but it is laced with waterways that can offer a different, and no less enchanting, view.
lead_paragraph: For more than a millennium, Kyoto flourished as the imperial capital of Japan. But in a seismic upheaval known as the Meiji Restoration, in which feudal shogunates gave way to a modern nation-state, the capital was moved to Tokyo in 1868. And Kyoto fell into decline.

headline: The Best True Crime to Stream: All the Cool Kids Are Wearing It
abstract: Four picks across television, film and podcasting that examine dark stories about some of the most trendy clothing brands.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, several popular apparel brands have made news for troubling reasons. Most often, they have been accused of corporate greed, having predatory practices that exploit young women, and propagating abusive systems at all levels of production, promotion and distribution. These headlines have, in turn, inspired a string of documentaries, docuseries and podcasts.

headline: In These Four Enticing Novels, Escape Takes Many Forms
abstract: A medieval heist, a Halifax murder, a Dutch wartime winter and a daring 1939 journey to Shanghai provide egress for any taste.
lead_paragraph: It would be easy to assume that M.T. Anderson was paying homage to “Monty Python and the Holy Grail” in his comic novel, NICKED (Pantheon, 240 pp., $28). But this uproarious saga was actually inspired by a real expedition that sailed from the Italian port of Bari in 1087, intent on stealing the remains of St. Nicholas, which had lain in an Anatolian crypt for 700 years, attracting an enticing stream of well-endowed pilgrims.

headline: The Fight Over a Black Samurai in Assassin’s Creed Shadows
abstract: The video game franchise long emphasized its historical accuracy in settings such as Athens, Florence and London. Then details of its first foray to Japan were attacked online.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Assassin’s Creed Shadows has been delayed until Feb. 14, 2025.]

headline: In Montana, This Wheat Field Is Art
abstract: An acre of wheat designed by the artist Agnes Denes has cropped up at a new exhibition space in Montana, where agriculture is rapidly giving way to development.
lead_paragraph: As youthful wheat shimmied in the Montana breeze, it looked a lot like grass. Logically, I knew wheat is a grass, cultivated to yield the plump, glutinous makings of pasta and beer. But it took an encounter with living crops to understand.

headline: Kit Connor and Rachel Zegler Are Star Crossed in Central Park
abstract: As the stars of the “Romeo + Juliet” that opens on Broadway, they will die for love. And to make that convincing, they need to become friends first.
lead_paragraph: On a morning in mid-August, a breeze stirred Central Park’s midsummer leaves. Children skipped, dogs lolloped, a bunny peeked out from a hedge near the Great Lawn while a nearby saxophone ruined “Isn’t She Lovely.” It was a very nice day to fall in love.

headline: They Said Her Music Was Too Exotic. Now She’s a Classical Star.
abstract: Gabriela Ortiz, Carnegie Hall’s composer in residence this season, has spent her career channeling the sounds and sensibilities of Latin America.
lead_paragraph: In a bustling public square in Mexico City on a summer day, as hummingbirds feasted on honeysuckle and candle sellers hawked remedies for broken hearts and anxious minds, the composer Gabriela Ortiz stood in the shadow of the San Juan Bautista church and closed her eyes.

headline: The Defense Secretary Revoked a Plea Deal in the 9/11 Case. Or Did He?
abstract: How the latest controversy in the long-running death-penalty case at Guantánamo Bay could play out.
lead_paragraph: In rapid succession, two dramatic decisions jolted the Sept. 11 case this summer: a plea agreement that exchanged life sentences for guilty pleas, and its reversal.

headline: Thinking About a Solo Cruise? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: As solo cruising becomes more popular, pricing and cabin types are changing. Deals can be found, especially with advance planning, but it takes a little know-how.
lead_paragraph: When cruising resumed after Covid-era travel restrictions were lifted, cruise lines wanted to fill ships fast. Some, like Windstar Cruises, which operates small ships carrying 148 to 342 passengers, pursued solo travelers with discounts on the penalties singles usually pay to occupy a cabin alone.

headline: Paul Smith’s Roads Less Traveled
abstract: At 78, the designer, who stumbled into fashion when an accident ended a competitive cycling career, is still hurtling along at full speed.
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Paul Smith explains, in his own words, what continues to motivate him.

headline: Missing Summer? Let This Shrimp Take You Back
abstract: Smoky saganaki can inspire the feeling of a seaside vacation.
lead_paragraph: My summer holiday in the Mediterranean has just ended, and like many others, I am thinking hard about how to extend the serenity that vacation brings and not jump straight back into the daily business of work and domestic duties.

headline: Trump’s Obsession With Oil Could Destroy America’s Auto Industry
abstract: If Donald Trump wins a second term, America would be at risk of falling even further behind China.
lead_paragraph: There is a curious cognitive dissonance in how a lot of us think about the last decade’s climate policies and this decade’s economic problems.

headline: ‘Trump Brought Darkness; Harris Brought Light’: 14 Writers on Who Won the Presidential Debate
abstract: Our columnists and contributors rate Trump’s and Harris’s debate performances.
lead_paragraph: Times Opinion asked 14 of our columnists and contributors to watch the presidential debate on Tuesday night and assess who won and who lost. We also asked them to weigh in on the quality of the debate. Were the candidates inspiring, or was their face-off a depressing sign of everything that’s wrong with American politics?

headline: Sex, Drugs, Raves and Heartbreak
abstract: In a new memoir, the journalist Emily Witt delivers a coolly precise chronicle of Brooklyn’s underground party scene and her romance with a fellow partygoer.
lead_paragraph: The “breakdown” in the subtitle of Emily Witt’s haunting new book, “Health and Safety,” isn’t hers. It belongs to Andrew, her boyfriend of four years; he started behaving erratically when pandemic lockdowns in 2020 put an end to the underground party scene in Brooklyn’s Bushwick neighborhood, where Witt and Andrew had danced, done drugs and found friends.

headline: There Is a Right and a Wrong Way to Wield Sanctions
abstract: Individual sanctions offer a rare form of accountability for autocrats.
lead_paragraph: Pascale Solages, an anti-corruption activist from Haiti, burst into tears of joy last month when she heard that the U.S. Treasury Department had finally slapped sanctions on Michel Martelly, a former president of Haiti who is accused of drug trafficking, money laundering and fueling violent gangs in Port-au-Prince. It was a sign that the U.S. government, which once supported Mr. Martelly, was actually listening to the Haitian people. And it raised her hopes that Mr. Martelly, who lives in Miami, might finally lose his political influence and be brought to justice.

headline: The Fire Department’s Painful 9/11 Legacy
abstract: Since 2001, the department has lost more than 360 men to 9/11-related illnesses, a number greater than its death toll on Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at a sad milestone: The number of firefighters who have died of illnesses related to their work at the World Trade Center in 2001 now exceeds the number of those killed in the 9/11 attacks. We’ll also get details on one of the investigations swirling around Mayor Eric Adams’s administration.

headline: When Self-Driving Cars Don’t Actually Drive Themselves
abstract: An immersive article shows readers what a New York Times reporter has tracked for nearly a decade: Robot taxis still need human help.
lead_paragraph: I took my first ride in a self-driving car nearly a decade ago. Like most people who experience this brave new world, I felt a deep sense of awe that machines had mastered a skill that once belonged solely to humans.

headline: ‘I Feel Like She Humiliated Him’: How Trump Lost the Debate
abstract: Two Opinion writers break down the Trump-Harris debate.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Goldberg, the Times Opinion columnist, and Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, discuss the best and worst moments of the debate between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump. Will Harris’s apparent debate night victory matter to the swing state voters who can make the difference?

headline: Making Music (and a Home) in Montclair
abstract: Christian McBride, the Grammy-winning bassist, was reluctant to move out of New York, but his wife, Melissa Walker, a jazz vocalist, turned a century-old house in New Jersey into a sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: Christian McBride, the Grammy-winning bassist, was reluctant to move out of New York, but his wife, Melissa Walker, a jazz vocalist, turned a century-old house in New Jersey into a sanctuary.

headline: Inflation Cooled in August, Keeping the Fed Poised to Cut Rates
abstract: Consumer Price Index inflation continued to cool, reaching a new three-year low. But signs of stubbornness lingered under the surface.
lead_paragraph: Inflation continued to recede in August, paving the way for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates for the first time since early 2020 at their meeting next week.

headline: 3 Shel Silverstein Poems to Read With Your Children
abstract: Hilarious and tender, he was ahead of his time.
lead_paragraph: Shel Silverstein was best known for children’s classics like “The Giving Tree” and his books of poetry, including “Where the Sidewalk Ends,” “Falling Up” and “A Light in the Attic.” Though most of his books came out decades ago, Elisabeth Egan, a writer for The New York Times Book Review, says: “They really do still hold up today in a different century. All these years later, they’re just as appealing and funny and true.”

headline: MAGA vs. Science Is No Contest
abstract: A substantial number of Republican voters are losing faith in science.
lead_paragraph: A substantial number of Republican voters are losing faith in science.

headline: Dozens of Homes Burned in California as Wildfires Rage in the West
abstract: Three fires in Southern California exploded in size overnight, and the authorities arrested a man suspected of starting one of them. Large blazes continued to burn in Oregon and Idaho.
lead_paragraph: Fueled by dry and windy weather, three massive fires in Southern California have now burned dozens of homes and forced tens of thousands of people to flee from communities east of Los Angeles.

headline: The Question Kamala Harris Couldn’t Answer
abstract: Some voters may still be left looking for an answer.
lead_paragraph: Even before Taylor Swift endorsed Kamala Harris, it was clearly the vice president’s night. In more than 90 minutes of contentious debate, Harris continued to prosecute the case against a second Donald Trump presidency more effectively than perhaps any of his other rivals has since 2015. But was it enough to satisfy those voters who say they still need to know more about her in order to cast a ballot in her favor this November?

headline: His Poems Are a Joy to Hear, Even When Their Meanings Aren’t Clear
abstract: In his latest collection, Paul Muldoon continues his longtime trick of marshaling obscure references into fluent, fun and rollicking lyrics.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks after my editor assigned me this review, I came close to sending him a panicked email. “I can’t pretend to have any idea what Paul Muldoon is talking about,” I wanted to say. “The book is clogged with so many arcane references that my brain lapses into fog when I open to a random page.”

headline: Native Landscapes Can Be Hard to Plant. But Help Is Here.
abstract: The nonprofit group Wild Ones offers a free library of designs, with plants specific to your area — and you don’t have to be a member to use it.
lead_paragraph: Turning your front yard into something other than a manicured greensward sounds like a bold new idea, even today. Imagine how it felt, in 1992, to see former lawns in Wisconsin that were already many years into their transition to prairie-like spaces, with no turf grass in sight.

headline: $1.4 Million Homes in Utah, Georgia and California
abstract: An 1890 Queen Anne Revival house in Salt Lake City, an 1872 brick townhouse in Savannah and a 1938 Spanish-style home in Albany.
lead_paragraph: This home, known as the Charles Baldwin House, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It retains many of its original details, including interior woodwork and exterior stonework framing a street-facing window.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,181
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, September 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 459
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Sept. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Key Debate Moments, and the Gulf Coast Braces for Hurricane Francine
abstract: Plus, the truth about recycling coffee pods.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Harris Baits Trump: Inside Their Fiery Debate
abstract: Commentators, even Republicans, concluded that the vice president succeeded in provoking the former president.
lead_paragraph: In their first and possibly only presidential debate, Vice President Kamala Harris dominated and enraged former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Prices at the Pump Fall, a Win for Efforts to Fight Inflation
abstract: A gallon of regular gasoline in August was down nearly 12 percent from a year earlier, reflecting a fall in oil prices as well as a decline in demand.
lead_paragraph: The cost of gasoline and diesel has been falling in the United States, welcome news for efforts to reduce inflation.

headline: The Harris-Trump Debate
abstract: Kamala Harris seemed to win the debate with Donald Trump, but didn’t have a perfect night.
lead_paragraph: Debating has long been a Kamala Harris strength. It resembles courtroom argument, a core part of her career as a prosecutor. A debate helped her win her first statewide race in California, 14 years ago. In her only vice-presidential debate four years ago with Mike Pence, polls showed that she won.

headline: Violence Resurges in Indian State Locked in Bloody Conflict for 16 Months
abstract: Ethnic tensions have turned Manipur into an open war zone. Struggling to contain the unrest, the authorities have reimposed a curfew and internet blackout.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after it became an open war zone, deadly ethnic violence has resurged this month in the northeastern Indian state of Manipur. The local authorities have reimposed a curfew and an internet blackout as Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government struggles to quell the unrest.

headline: Asked if He Wants Ukraine to Defeat Russia, Trump Doesn’t Say Yes
abstract: At Tuesday’s debate, Mr. Trump repeated his claim that he can end the war and refused to say if defending Ukraine was in America’s national security interests.
lead_paragraph: “Do you want Ukraine to win this war?”

headline: Trump Media’s Stock Plunges After Debate
abstract: Shares of the parent company of Truth Social, which have traded like a proxy for former President Donald Trump’s election prospects, set a new low for the year.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street gave a thumbs down to former President Donald J. Trump’s debate performance on Tuesday night, judging by trading on Wednesday in shares of his social media company.

headline: Biden Says He Is ‘Outraged’ Over Killing of American Activist in West Bank
abstract: In his first extensive remarks on the death of Aysenur Eygi, the U.S. president called for accountability from Israel.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Wednesday that he was “outraged and deeply saddened” over the killing of an American activist by an Israeli soldier at a West Bank protest last week and that there must be “full accountability” from Israel.

headline: The Big Takeaways for Business from Debate Night
abstract: The showdown between Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump was light on policy, but there were still sparks as they laid out different visions for the economy.
lead_paragraph: For business leaders and others, last night’s presidential debate was more notable for how the candidates performed rather than for the policy measures they discussed.

headline: With New Prime Minister, a ‘Rupture’ in French Politics and Barbs for Macron
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron’s newly picked prime minister wasted no time in putting a pointed distance between himself and France’s weakened leader.
lead_paragraph: Michel Barnier, the new French prime minister, did not thank President Emmanuel Macron for appointing him in his first remarks upon taking office last week. This was a declaration of independence.

headline: Where Do Trump and Harris Stand on Israel-Gaza Conflict?
abstract: The war in Gaza merited a few scant mentions in the presidential debate. Here’s a look at where Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump stand.
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza merited a few scant mentions over less than five minutes of the American presidential debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump on Tuesday night. But the words they used to describe how they would each handle the conflict were carefully noted in Israel.

headline: Battle of the Political Brands
abstract: When Donald Trump and Kamala Harris faced off on the debate stage, governing style was on display.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the ABC presidential debate began on Tuesday night, Donald J. Trump, the Republican candidate, brought up one of the telling points of the evening. His brand, he said, was “great.” He had built a fantastic brand.

headline: My Cousin’s Young Children Are Hellions! What Can I Do?
abstract: A reader is unsure how best to help a cousin she sees as a little sister but who so far hasn’t asked for any parenting advice.
lead_paragraph: My cousin’s young children are out of control: They hit one another, run in circles around the dinner table and nearly topple their grandmother. My cousin seems stressed and bone-tired as she tries to negotiate better behavior. (She rarely says no. It’s more like: “Honey, would you like to sit down?” Apparently not.) Meanwhile, her husband is usually off in a corner talking about hockey. My cousin and I have always been close. I’d say I’m a big sister figure to her, but she hasn’t asked for my advice about parenting. My children are grown. But when they were small, we did a good job balancing limits and fun. I’ve offered to take the kids for the day so she could have some time to herself, but she hasn’t taken me up on it. I certainly don’t want to give unsolicited advice, but I’d love to help. Thoughts?

headline: With Strong Memories of Katrina, Mississippi Braces for Francine
abstract: The governor declared a state of emergency as residents sandbagged homes and considered evacuating.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Francine pushed northeast through the Gulf of Mexico, preparations were underway in Mississippi, a state with only a short coastline — but one that has been repeatedly battered by hurricanes in the past.

headline: Europeans Used Cocaine Much Earlier Than Previously Thought, Study Finds
abstract: In human remains buried in an Italian crypt, researchers found evidence of cocaine use from the 17th century.
lead_paragraph: Descending for the first time into the large, vaulted crypt of a centuries-old hospital in Milan in 2019, Gaia Giordano grew overwhelmed.

headline: Parenting Has Always Been Hard
abstract: Accepting that is the first step toward making it more tolerable.
lead_paragraph: “Parenthood and the care of children is now a highly self-conscious affair in which the maintenance of a high standard is insisted upon, and the pitfalls are forever being exposed,” wrote the sociologist Hannah Gavron. The situation for parents, Gavron explained, is made more difficult because “The family today is an isolated unit unable and unwilling to seek assistance in its distress from wider circles of kin (as it has always done in the past).”

headline: Will There Be Another Debate? Trump Isn’t Sure.
abstract: The former president suggested immediately after the debate and in a call-in to Fox News on Wednesday morning that he was not inclined to agree to another.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after Tuesday’s debate — in which Vice President Kamala Harris repeatedly baited former President Donald J. Trump on abortion, the size of his rally crowds, his reputation with foreign leaders and more — Ms. Harris’s campaign said she was on board for another.

headline: Grieving Ohio Father Tells Trump and Vance to Stop Talking About His Son
abstract: Nathan Clark says the candidates are exploiting his son’s death in a crash caused by an immigrant outside the small city of Springfield. “This needs to stop now.”
lead_paragraph: Barely an hour before the presidential debate the father of an 11-year-old Ohio boy killed when an immigrant’s minivan crashed into a school bus lashed out at Donald J. Trump and his running mate, JD Vance.

headline: Trump Assails ABC, but He’s Not Thrilled With Fox News, Either
abstract: The former president played media critic during a Wednesday morning interview on “Fox & Friends.”
lead_paragraph: By Wednesday morning, former President Donald J. Trump had settled on a clear message about his defensive and scowling performance in the ABC News debate with Vice President Kamala Harris:

headline: The ‘Country Doctor’ Who Upended Our Understanding of Dementia
abstract: Francisco Lopera defied rebels, cartels and vampire bats to become a pioneering researcher of Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, Dr. Francisco Lopera did what recent medical school graduates in Colombia and much of Latin America have long done: He set out for an obligatory year of work in a remote part of the country, where an inexperienced médico rural might be the only physician for miles. Dr. Lopera, who was born in the Andean region of Antioquia and knew mostly mountains and farm life before medical school, carried out his service in the Darién Gap, on the Caribbean coast near Panama.

headline: Harris and Trump Bet on Their Own Sharply Contrasting Views of America
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump is gambling that Americans are as angry as he is, while Vice President Kamala Harris hopes voters are exhausted by the Trump era and ready to move on.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s America is a grim place, a nation awash in marauding immigrants stealing American jobs and eating American cats and dogs, a country devastated economically, humiliated internationally and perched on the cliff’s edge of an apocalyptic World War III.

headline: After Debate, Harris and Trump Shake Hands at Sept. 11 Memorial
