abstract: The morning after their first face-to-face meeting, the two candidates attended a ceremony on the 23rd anniversary of the terror attacks. Vice President Kamala Harris appeared to say “thank you” to her rival.
lead_paragraph: Setting aside the rancor of their debate, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump met again Wednesday morning at the hallowed ground of the World Trade Center site, shaking hands and standing nearly side by side to mark the 23rd anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Ohio Dad Asks Trump Ticket to Stop Using Son’s Death for ‘Political Gain’
abstract: Aiden Clark was killed when an immigrant’s minivan crashed into a school bus he was travelling in last year.
lead_paragraph: Aiden Clark was killed when an immigrant’s minivan crashed into a school bus he was travelling in last year.

headline: Trump Dismisses Taylor Swift’s Endorsement of Harris
abstract: “She’ll probably pay a price for it in the marketplace,” the former president said in an interview on “Fox & Friends” regarding the pop star, who backed Biden in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was not happy that Taylor Swift endorsed his opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, though perhaps he was not surprised.

headline: Frankie Beverly, Frontman of the Soul Group Maze, Is Dead at 77
abstract: A consistent hitmaker on the R&B charts for almost 50 years, he had announced just this year that he would be retiring.
lead_paragraph: Frankie Beverly, the lead singer and songwriter of the soul and funk band Maze, whose songs, including “Golden Time of Day,” “Joy and Pain” and “Happy Feelin’s,” provided the soundtrack to countless summer cookouts and family reunions for more than five decades, died on Tuesday. He was 77.

headline: Climate at the Debate: Trump Ignored the Question and Harris Hedged
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris nodded to the urgency of climate change but also highlighted the country’s record levels of oil and gas production.
lead_paragraph: At the tail end of the hottest summer in recorded history, as wildfires tear through California and a hurricane heads toward Louisiana, both Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump failed to say how they would fight climate change during their debate Tuesday night.

headline: Restaurant-Fancy Pasta for a Worn-Out Wednesday
abstract: Andy Baraghani’s minimalist crispy artichoke pasta keeps the prep time doable, with Parmesan, garlic and red pepper to round everything out.
lead_paragraph: Of all the foods I’ll willingly heat up a pot of oil for, fried artichokes are at the top of my list. From that first kiss of sizzling oil, the petals crisp, the heart softens and the flavors concentrate, becoming even sweeter and more intense. Steamed artichoke leaves dunked in butter are tidy and wonderful, but the fried version is actually worth wiping down a stove after.

headline: Harvard’s Black Student Enrollment Dips After Affirmative Action Ends
abstract: Defying expectations, a Supreme Court decision curtailing race-based admissions still had a relatively small impact at some highly selective schools like Harvard, even as other schools saw big changes.
lead_paragraph: The predictions were dire. In the course of a bitterly contested trial six years ago, Harvard University said that if it were forced to stop considering race in admissions, the diversity of its undergraduate classes would be badly compromised.

headline: The No. 1 Breaker in the World Is … Raygun?
abstract: The Australian breaker who was mocked at the Olympics for her kangaroo-hopping routine is now atop the official world rankings. Here’s how it happened.
lead_paragraph: The breaker known as Raygun did terribly at the Olympics, losing all three of her head-to-head battles, each by scores of 18-0. Her unusual routines also made her an unexpected face of the Paris Games and earned her mockery worldwide.

headline: North Korean Missiles Rain Down on Ukraine Despite Sanctions
abstract: Russia has received new shipments of Hwasong-11 short-range ballistic missiles, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: North Korea has continued to supply advanced short-range ballistic missiles to Russia in defiance of sanctions meant to prevent Pyongyang from developing such weapons and Moscow from importing them, according to a report by a weapons research group.

headline: When States Banned Abortion, Sterilizations Rose Among Women
abstract: Experts said the new research finding underscored how abortion bans had affected women’s contraceptive choices.
lead_paragraph: A new study published Wednesday found an increase in the use of tubal sterilization, in which women have their fallopian tubes tied or removed to permanently prevent pregnancy, in the six months after the June 2022 Supreme Court decision that overturned Roe v. Wade. The increase was most pronounced in states that effectively banned abortion, where sterilizations rose 39 percent by December 2022.

headline: Gulf Coast States Have Been Battered by Hurricanes in Recent Years
abstract: Here’s a look at storms that have hit the area in the last few years.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Francine is the sixth named storm of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season, and one of a number of hurricanes to take aim at the Gulf Coast over the last several years.

headline: Juilliard Receives $20 Million to Unite Disciplines and Support Jazz
abstract: The donations, from John and Jody Arnhold, will expand creative work across disciplines, help pay for an annual fall festival and support the jazz program.
lead_paragraph: The Juilliard School is home to some of the best young musicians, dancers and actors in the world. But they rarely come together to create and perform across disciplines.

headline: Live From San Francisco: Mark Zuckerberg Tapes a Podcast With 6,000 Friends
abstract: Mr. Zuckerberg talked to a packed house Tuesday night for the “Acquired” podcast. It’s a sign of how tech titans reach the public now.
lead_paragraph: More than 6,000 techies streamed on Tuesday evening into San Francisco’s Chase Center, a cavernous event space that is home to the Golden State Warriors and hosts pop stars like Olivia Rodrigo. Engineers, venture capitalists and other Silicon Valley digerati chatted as they found their seats, with Modelos and slices of pizza in hand. The anticipation was high.

headline: Greener Steel at Britain’s Largest Plant Comes With Heavy Job Losses
abstract: The British government and Tata of India said they would invest 1.25 billion pounds in a plan to convert the steel mill at Port Talbot in Wales to an electric furnace.
lead_paragraph: The British government and the Indian conglomerate Tata said on Wednesday that they would jointly invest 1.25 billion pounds, or about $1.6 billion, in the country’s largest steel mill, in Port Talbot, Wales, to make operations there less polluting.

headline: ‘It’s Still Overwhelming’: Mourners Across New York City Remember 9/11
abstract: Commemorations for those killed in the attacks 23 years ago took place throughout the city, with politicians joining those assembled at ground zero.
lead_paragraph: Mourners gathered in Lower Manhattan and across New York City on Wednesday to commemorate the nearly 3,000 people who died in the Sept. 11 attacks 23 years ago and the many who have died from related illnesses since.

headline: How to Stay Safe When the Power Goes Out
abstract: Improper use of portable generators carries several risks, including carbon monoxide poisoning.
lead_paragraph: Strong hurricanes bring the potential for floods and damaging winds that can knock out power to millions.

headline: For Wendell Pierce and Courtney B. Vance, James Earl Jones Loomed Large
abstract: The two actors talk about how the stage and screen great was a one-of-a-kind inspiration to them, and many others.
lead_paragraph: James Earl Jones had already made a lifetime impression on Wendell Pierce by the time Pierce patiently waited in a receiving line to meet Jones after his opening night performance of August Wilson’s “Fences” nearly 40 years ago.

headline: Kamala Harris Produced the Show She Wanted
abstract: In Tuesday’s debate, the vice president made herself the studio audience for a cringe comedy starring her opponent.
lead_paragraph: At the ABC presidential debate, Kamala Harris had a programming challenge. Working against an experienced reality-TV professional, a savant of live broadcasts, she had to pull off a successful reboot of Democrats’ least-favorite TV show of the 2024 season: the June debate that saw the self-immolation of President Biden.

headline: Dr. Chatbot Will See You Now
abstract: Americans are already turning to A.I. for health information in large numbers, new research suggests.
lead_paragraph: Susan Sheridan had heard of ChatGPT but had never used it, so the first question she asked the artificial intelligence chatbot was a bit garbled: “Facial droop, facial pain and dental work.”

headline: Johnson Scraps Vote on Spending Extension Amid Bipartisan Resistance
abstract: The scuttling of the six-month stopgap measure, which includes a requirement to show proof of U.S. citizenship when registering to vote, sets back Republicans’ plan to avert a government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson on Wednesday abruptly canceled a vote on his initial plan to avert a government shutdown, as opposition to the six-month stopgap funding measure piled up in both parties.

headline: Edward Johnson, C.I.A. Hero in Iran Hostage Crisis, Dies at 81
abstract: He was a secret partner who helped rescue six American diplomats in 1980 by passing them off as a film crew. The caper inspired the movie “Argo.”
lead_paragraph: Edward B. Johnson, who as an anonymous C.I.A. officer in 1980 helped rescue six American diplomats during the Iran hostage crisis by casting them as a Hollywood crew scouting a Mideast location — an audacious escape that itself became grist for an Oscar-winning movie — died on Aug. 27 at his home in Fairfax, Va. He was 81.

headline: Harris Put Trump on Defense at the Presidential Debate
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris baited traps for Donald J. Trump in their debate on Tuesday night — and he walked right into them, spinning into conspiracy theories. But did she say enough about her plans? Jonathan Weisman, a politics reporter for The New York Times, gives his analysis of how each candidate fared in the ABC News presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris baited traps for Donald J. Trump in their debate on Tuesday night — and he walked right into them, spinning into conspiracy theories. But did she say enough about her plans? Jonathan Weisman, a politics reporter for The New York Times, gives his analysis of how each candidate fared in the ABC News presidential debate.

headline: Danity Kane Singer Sues Sean Combs, Alleging Threats and Groping
abstract: The lawsuit was filed by Dawn Richard, a member of groups assembled by Mr. Combs. A lawyer for Mr. Combs called the suit “manufactured” to get a “payday.”
lead_paragraph: Dawn Richard, a singer who came to prominence on the MTV reality show “Making the Band,” filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against the music mogul Sean Combs, accusing him of threatening her, groping her and flying into “frenzied, unpredictable rages” while he oversaw her career.

headline: The Debate Was About Trump. That Was Good for Harris.
abstract: It can be hard to tell when a debate bounce will last, but there are rough parameters that can guide us.
lead_paragraph: On Monday’s episode of “The Daily,” I was asked what we should look for during Tuesday’s debate. Here’s what I said:

headline: Harris vs. Trump: Assessing a Fierce Debate
abstract: Readers analyze the candidates’ performances, the moderators, the likely impact and claims of pet-eating.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Debate May Widen the Money Gap Between Harris and Trump
abstract: Large donors to former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign expressed concern after his performance. The Democrats raised big money in the hours after the debate.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s performance in Tuesday night’s debate is likely to exacerbate the widening financial gap that he faces with Vice President Kamala Harris, who is now enjoying her eighth week of momentum with big and small donors alike.

headline: Donald Sheppard, British D-Day Veteran, Dies at 104
abstract: He helped liberate Bergen-Belsen, the Nazi concentration camp where Anne Frank had died.
lead_paragraph: Donald Sheppard, a British veteran of World War II who landed on the beaches of Normandy during D-Day, helped liberate the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp and then spent his old age striving to keep the memory of his fellow soldiers’ sacrifices alive, died on Saturday in Basildon, Essex, England. He was 104.

headline: Art Museum Fires 3 Employees for Wearing Kaffiyehs
abstract: The Noguchi Museum said the headscarves, a symbol of Palestinian identity, violated a dress code that recently banned “political messages, slogans or symbols.”
lead_paragraph: Three employees of the Noguchi Museum were fired last week for defying its updated dress code by wearing kaffiyehs, a symbol of Palestinian identity. A fourth employee, the Queens museum’s director of visitor services, was also terminated after the dress code changes.

headline: Is Europe Turning Its Back on the Left?
abstract: The elections went well. It’s what came afterward that is worrying.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, anxious American liberals told themselves a cautionary tale about politics in Europe: A seemingly inevitable rightward surge in this summer’s elections there was a dark portent of the political future, for Europeans and for Americans.

headline: How Taylor Swift Surprised Harris, and Entered a New Political Era
abstract: The pop star capped a big night for Kamala Harris with an unexpectedly timed endorsement that could draw in more young voters. Ms. Swift’s political message, too, was newly direct and personal.
lead_paragraph: Just before midnight on Tuesday, Vice President Kamala Harris was about to greet supporters at a post-debate party in Philadelphia when aides pulled her aside with some news she had not been ready for: Taylor Swift had just endorsed her.

headline: Lloyd Kaufman, Who Saw Answers Behind the ‘Moon Illusion,’ Dies at 97
abstract: He advanced the study of a millenniums-old mystery: why the moon appears larger on the horizon than it does high in the night sky.
lead_paragraph: Lloyd Kaufman, a leading figure in the study of a phenomenon called the moon illusion, an optical trick puzzled over for millenniums by the likes of Aristotle and Kepler, died on Aug. 20 at his home in the Floral Park neighborhood of Queens. He was 97.

headline: A Temporary Truce in the Political Wars as Harris, Trump and Biden Mark 9/11
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump joined President Biden and other dignitaries in a daylong journey to sites of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: Barely 10 hours earlier, they had been at each other’s throats, calling one another a “disgrace,” “horrible” and “grossly incompetent.” Then they put down their political swords on Wednesday morning and stood just a few feet apart to mark one of the most solemn moments on the modern American calendar.

headline: A Rock Star’s Mystery Baby Offers a Lesson in Crisis Communication
abstract: The timing and content of Dave Grohl’s admission that he had a child outside his marriage was complimented for addressing the issue and relying on short memories.
lead_paragraph: Dave Grohl — the Nirvana drummer and Foo Fighters founder — is as close as America gets to a rock ’n’ roll father figure: funny and family-oriented, beloved by his fans and his fellow musicians and seemingly as steady as the drumbeats that made him famous. His nickname? “The nicest dude in rock.”

headline: Trump’s Alternative for Obamacare Is Now Just ‘Concepts of a Plan’
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump once promised to replace Obamacare with “something terrific.” But as the 2010 law has become more popular, he has sounded less confident about a repeal.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s suggestion in Tuesday’s debate that he had “concepts of a plan” to replace the Affordable Care Act instantly became one of the night’s most memorable lines, transposed into memes across social media.

headline: 4 Climbers Are Found Dead on Mont Blanc in the French Alps
abstract: The climbers from Italy and South Korea were found on Tuesday after they went missing three days earlier during a period of bad weather on the peak.
lead_paragraph: Four climbers were found dead on Tuesday on Mont Blanc, the highest peak in the Alps, the French authorities in the region said. The climbers, who were from Italy and South Korea, had been missing since Saturday.

headline: Islamists Gain in Jordan, Reflecting Public Anger Over Gaza War
abstract: The political arm of the Muslim Brotherhood won a sizable share of seats in Parliament, though not enough to challenge the government’s pro-Western tilt.
lead_paragraph: An Islamist party that made opposition to the Israeli invasion of Gaza the centerpiece of its campaign scored a significant success in elections in Jordan, results released in the kingdom on Wednesday showed, giving the Muslim Brotherhood a bigger foothold in Jordan’s Parliament.

headline: Guards Say Top Adams Aide Threatened Them After Having Them Arrested
abstract: Two security guards said the aide, Timothy Pearson, attacked them then had them arrested. Federal agents seized his cellphone last week as part of a separate investigation.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, a senior adviser to Mayor Eric Adams was seen physically attacking several security guards at a Midtown migrant shelter. Under his apparent command, the police arrested two of the guards.

headline: Trump Undermines Vance on Abortion Ban Veto: ‘I Didn’t Discuss It With JD’
abstract: Scrambling to shelter himself on abortion, Donald J. Trump disavowed his running mate’s pledge that, if re-elected, the former president would veto a national abortion ban.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody speaks for Donald J. Trump except for Donald J. Trump.”

headline: Why Venezuelan Election Observers are Exiled in Colombia
abstract: As the government of Nicolás Maduro doubles down on declaring him the winner of Venezuela’s presidential election, political opponents are fleeing to neighboring countries to escape threats to themselves and their families. Alex Pena, a senior video journalist at The New York Times, describes his experience on the border of Venezuela and Colombia.
lead_paragraph: As the government of Nicolás Maduro doubles down on declaring him the winner of Venezuela’s presidential election, political opponents are fleeing to neighboring countries to escape threats to themselves and their families. Alex Pena, a senior video journalist at The New York Times, describes his experience on the border of Venezuela and Colombia.

headline: 13 Fast (and Fancy!) Shrimp Dishes We Love
abstract: These recipes come together quickly enough for dinner on a busy night and feel special enough for a party.
lead_paragraph: Lightning fast to cook and always satisfying to eat, shrimp is a hero in the kitchen and, if there’s a stash in the freezer, it can be dinner any night of the week. Best of all, it has so much range, standing on its own in a delicious shrimp cocktail, pairing beautifully with a rich sauce or cozying up to vegetables, rice, grits or pasta. Below are 13 recipes that put it to use expertly and deliciously.

headline: Justin Timberlake to Plead Guilty to Lesser Charge in D.W.I. Case
abstract: The singer, who was charged after an erratic drive in Sag Harbor, N.Y., is expected to appear in person in court on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The singer and actor Justin Timberlake, who faced drunken-driving charges after an erratic drive in the Hamptons led to his arrest, is expected to plead guilty to a lesser offense, according to the Suffolk County district attorney’s office.

headline: Our 10 Favorite Butternut Squash Recipes
abstract: These dishes show off the natural earthy sweetness of winter squash using a range of flavors and techniques.
lead_paragraph: If tomatoes are summer’s long-awaited gems, then it may be fair to say that sweet, amenable butternut squash, its orange flesh the color of autumn leaves, is fall’s jewel. But unlike tomatoes, whose peak is fleeting, sturdy squash lingers, staying fresh for months if kept at the right conditions (in a cool, dark place at room temperature, or in the refrigerator). The recipes below enhance squash’s understated beauty, bringing out its best whether roasted, blitzed into a soup or topping flaky pastry.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Who Won the Harris-Trump Debate?
abstract: Plus, a video game provokes outrage.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris dominated much of Tuesday’s debate against Donald Trump, mostly by successfully targeting the former president’s ego.

headline: Online Legions for Trump and Harris Clash, Wielding Images of Cats and Aliens
abstract: Supporters of Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris are taking the debate’s spiciest moments for inspiration in memes, video reels and fake photos.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump responded online to the presidential debate on Tuesday with a torrent of jokey memes, video reels and surreal, computer-generated art that reached a whole new level of strange.

headline: Trump May Not Have Met His Waterloo, but He More Than Met His Match
abstract: The election is too close to call, but the vice president has exposed the former president.
lead_paragraph: Being drunk on hubris and narcissism is the surest way to lose a confrontation to a clever, clearheaded opponent. It’s a story that’s been repeated throughout history.

headline: A Debate Recap With Song, Dance and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
abstract: The debate analysis you didn’t know you needed.
lead_paragraph: The debate analysis you didn’t know you needed.

headline: A Debate Recap With Song, Dance and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
abstract: The debate analysis you didn’t know you needed.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Donald Trump and Kamala Harris spent 90 minutes trading blows in a fierce debate. Out of duty to a weary electorate eager for change, we enlisted the musical talents of the Gregory Brothers and a special guest, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, to provide the debate recap you didn’t know you needed.

headline: Why a YouTuber’s Drastic Weight Loss Went Viral
abstract: Nikocado Avocado, a popular vlogger known for his mukbang videos, said he spent the last two years plotting the reveal.
lead_paragraph: Nikocado Avocado, a YouTuber who rose to internet fame for his mukbang content, posted a video the other day that wasn’t quite like others he had shared over the last several years.

headline: In New Orleans, Streets Turn Quiet as Water Builds Ahead of Francine’s Landfall
abstract: As Francine, a Category 1 hurricane, barreled toward Louisiana, many residents stayed indoors, concerned about potential flooding and power outages.
lead_paragraph: As residents awaited Hurricane Francine’s impact in New Orleans on Wednesday, it was so quiet at times the only sound was raindrops falling.

headline: The Hurricane Season Is Suddenly Looking More Active
abstract: Forecasters are watching more than just Francine, as several other storm systems could become the next named storm in the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, forecasters were discussing a significant lull at the height of what was supposed to be a very active hurricane season. On Wednesday, with Francine barreling toward the Gulf Coast, and several other potential storms on the horizon, the Atlantic was looking increasingly more active.

headline: Popcast: Kendrick Lamar at the Super Bowl, Sabrina Carpenter on Top
abstract: Plus: A conversation about the career of Rich Homie Quan, who died last week.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s episode of Popcast, the pop music critic Jon Caramanica and the pop music reporter Joe Coscarelli discuss the week in music:

headline: James Sasser, Senator and Clinton’s Envoy to China, Dies at 87
abstract: He became ambassador after three terms as a senator from Tennessee. In 1999, he was made a virtual prisoner in the embassy in Beijing during a siege by protesters.
lead_paragraph: James Sasser, a three-term Democratic senator from Tennessee who, with no background in diplomacy or Chinese affairs, thrived as President Bill Clinton’s ambassador to China in the late 1990s until a bombing in Europe left angry mobs besieging his embassy, died on Tuesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 87.

headline: Trump’s Playbook on Abortion Includes This False Charge
abstract: During the debate, the former president used the phrase “execute the baby” to attack Kamala Harris for her support of abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: Even in a presidential debate packed with shocking charges, the bombshell phrase stood out.

headline: England’s Health Service Is in Deep Trouble, Report Finds
abstract: A government-commissioned review into the National Health Service laid bare the challenge Prime Minister Keir Starmer faces after years of underinvestment.
lead_paragraph: England’s National Health Service, one of the country’s most revered institutions, is in “critical” condition, according to a government-commissioned report that cited long waits for treatment, crumbling hospitals, mental health patients in “vermin-infested cells” and far fewer M.R.I. scanners than in comparable countries.

headline: OpenAI’s Fund-Raising Talks Could Value Company at $150 Billion
abstract: The San Francisco start-up hopes to raise $6.5 billion as part of an aggressive push for more investment.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI is in talks to raise about $6.5 billion as part of a deal that would value the company in the vicinity of $150 billion, a nearly $70 billion increase from its valuation nine months ago, according to five people with knowledge of the conversations.

headline: Harris Reveled in Her Debate Reviews
abstract: Also, Hurricane Francine is pelting southern Louisiana. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Early indications suggested that Kamala Harris prevailed in last night’s debate: Viewers gave her the nod in a poll and many commentators, even Republicans, concluded that Harris had succeeded in getting Donald Trump to veer off message.

headline: Prison Where Capote Interviewed Killers for ‘In Cold Blood’ Will Open to Tourists
abstract: The historical society in Lansing, Kan., hopes to attract visitors to the city of about 11,000 residents by welcoming visitors to the former Kansas State Penitentiary.
lead_paragraph: Truman Capote once described the Kansas State Penitentiary in Lansing, Kan., as a “turreted black-and-white palace” with “a dark two-storied building shaped like a coffin,” where prisoners were held on death row, awaiting execution.

headline: Harris Had a Theory of Trump, and It Was Right
abstract: The vice president successfully baited Trump’s angry, conspiratorial, free-associating side. But what wasn’t said was just as telling.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday night was the first — perhaps the only — debate between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris. And it proved one of Harris’s stump speech lines right: Turns out she really does know Trump’s type. She had a theory of who Trump was and how he worked, and she used it to take control of the collision. But this was a substantive debate, too. The candidates clashed on abortion, health care, the economy, energy, immigration and more. And so we delve into the policy arguments to untangle what was really being said — and what wasn’t.

headline: ‘Before I Let Go’ and 5 More Essential Frankie Beverly and Maze Songs
abstract: The singer, who died on Tuesday at 77, had a smooth, sunny delivery that turned at least one track into a lasting anthem of Black celebrations.
lead_paragraph: The song is a call to action from its opening notes. There’s only a brief stomping riff before Frankie Beverly, the lead singer and songwriter of the soul and funk band Maze, intones “woah-ohhh.” By the time he actually gets to the song’s opening lyrics, “You make me happy,” audiences at barbecues, family reunions, weddings, block parties and musical festivals know they should already be on the dance floor.

headline: Francine Arrives in a Region With Painful Memories of Past Storms
abstract: Francine could cut a somewhat similar path as Hurricane Ida, which left a trail of devastating consequences in 2021.
lead_paragraph: The anxious shiver that the projected path of Hurricane Francine induced in many Louisiana residents can be traced directly back to the last major storm to hit the state, which caused billions of dollars in damage and left a trail of devastating consequences that are still being widely felt years later.

headline: Trump’s False Tale of Immigrants’ Eating Pets Draws Pushback and Derision
abstract: The city manager in Springfield, Ohio, said it was disappointing that the presidential race was amplifying a bizarre narrative about the city’s immigrants.
lead_paragraph: A day after former President Donald J. Trump, in a debate watched by millions, doubled down on his campaign’s debunked position that immigrants are eating people’s pets in Springfield, Ohio, a local official on Wednesday pushed back on the outlandish claim.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein on the Harris-Trump Debate
abstract: The September 11, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, with Claire Gordon, on the presidential debate between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: French Ship That Sank in 1856 Disaster Is Found Off Massachusetts Coast
abstract: Le Lyonnais was discovered in the Atlantic Ocean about 140 miles east of Nantucket, Mass. More than 100 died after the French passenger steamship sank.
lead_paragraph: A French passenger steamship that sank in 1856, killing over 100 people, was found last month at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean, D/V Tenacious, a New Jersey-based shipwreck hunting group, said.

headline: Top Election Officials Warn Postal Service of Mail Ballot Issues
abstract: Democratic and Republican secretaries of state highlighted incidents of voters being disenfranchised by ballots not being delivered on time.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of election officials sounded the alarm on Wednesday about significant problems in the Postal Service in delivering mailed ballots, highlighting previous cases “in nearly every state” of ballots being delivered “well after Election Day.”

headline: Israeli Strike in Gaza Kills 18, Officials Say, Including 6 U.N. Workers
abstract: While resuming its offensive against militants in the West Bank, Israel also kept up its bombardment of the Gaza Strip, striking a school building used as a shelter for displaced people.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike on Wednesday killed at least 18 people, Palestinian officials said, at a school turned shelter in the Gaza Strip that Israel said Hamas used as a command post, and a United Nations agency said six of the dead were its employees.

headline: Norfolk Southern Fires C.E.O. After Ethics Investigation
abstract: The railroad company’s board said it dismissed Alan Shaw and an executive he had a consensual relationship with.
lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern, the beleaguered freight railroad giant, said on Wednesday that it had fired its chief executive, Alan H. Shaw, for having an affair with the company’s chief legal officer.

headline: How Trump Uses Vitriol for Migrants to Sideline Other Issues
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has long tried to stoke fear about immigration. Now, he’s doubling down as the presidential race heats up.
lead_paragraph: For years, former President Donald J. Trump has tried to stir up fears about immigrants with claims of caravans full of criminals and rapists heading toward America’s southern border.

headline: Is Donald Trump Too Emotional for This?
abstract: Kamala Harris sought to rattle Trump — and flip a gender dynamic on its head.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris said that former President Donald Trump had been fired, his stony face broke into a scoff. When she said that world leaders had called him a disgrace, his eyes revealed a flash of anger. And then, as she cast doubt upon his “temperament,” he became the show to her tell.

headline: Former Realtor Employee Files Sexual Harassment Suit Against Trade Group
abstract: A woman who worked for the National Association of Realtors says she was fired after she reported instances of sexual harassment and discrimination, according to a federal lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: A year after the National Association of Realtors was rocked by sexual harassment allegations against its president, a former product manager for the organization has filed a federal lawsuit claiming that several male leaders at the group’s headquarters frequently objectified her.

headline: 67.1 Million People Watched Harris and Trump, Outdrawing Last Debate
abstract: The TV audience for the Harris-Trump matchup was roughly comparable to the second Trump-Clinton debate in 2016.
lead_paragraph: There is a new most-watched moment of the 2024 presidential campaign.

headline: Trump Says He Had a Great Debate. His Allies Privately Say Otherwise.
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s aggressive spinning of his debate performance suggested he knew it was suboptimal, and left aides considering how to move ahead with eight weeks to go.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump went into sales-pitch mode immediately after Tuesday night’s debate, walking into the spin room to extol his own performance, crowing on Fox News and going on a late-night posting spree to hype unscientific online polls that he said showed he had crushed Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Debate Puts Trump’s Affinity for Putin Back in the Spotlight
abstract: The former president’s refusal to back Ukraine’s war effort showed the likely limits of U.S. support for Kyiv if he returns to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s refusal to say that he hopes Ukraine will win its war against Russia has cast a spotlight on what promises to be an abrupt U.S. policy shift toward the conflict — and Washington’s relations with Moscow — if Mr. Trump returns to the White House.

headline: Alberto Fujimori, 86, Leader of Peru Imprisoned for Rights Abuses, Dies
abstract: During his decade in power, he revived the economy and crushed two violent leftist insurgencies. But he was forced out in a corruption scandal and later imprisoned for human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: Alberto Fujimori, the former president of Peru who in his decade in office rebuilt the nation’s economy and quelled two deadly leftist insurgencies, but who was forced out by a corruption scandal and later imprisoned for human rights abuses, died on Wednesday in Lima, the capital. He was 86.

headline: After a Bruising Debate, Trump Is Warmly Embraced in Lower Manhattan
abstract: On 9/11, firefighters greeted the former president with high fives and hugs. But across the street, other New Yorkers were icy.
lead_paragraph: This is a tale about two sides of the same street.

headline: First Private Spacewalk in SpaceX Capsule Achieves New Milestone
abstract: Jared Isaacman, the billionaire leading the Polaris Dawn mission, and Sarah Gillis, a SpaceX engineer, exited and re-entered their spacecraft in a test of commercial space technologies.
lead_paragraph: Two private astronauts moved outside their spacecraft early Thursday morning, conducting the first-ever commercial spacewalk.

headline: Certification of Election Will Get Extra Security to Try to Prevent Another Capitol Attack
abstract: The Homeland Security Department approved adding federal, state and local resources to help protect the counting of Electoral College votes on Jan. 6, 2025.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to prevent another attack on the Capitol, the Department of Homeland Security has declared Jan. 6, 2025, to be a special event that requires added security measures when Congress meets to certify the winner of the 2024 presidential election.

headline: Citing Gaza Help, Blinken Waives Human Rights Conditions on Aid to Egypt
abstract: Cairo will receive its full military aid allotment of $1.3 billion after the secretary of state also said it had made progress on releasing political prisoners and protecting Americans.
lead_paragraph: For the first time under the Biden administration, the United States will send Egypt its full allotment of $1.3 billion in annual military aid, waiving human rights requirements on the spending mainly in recognition of Cairo’s efforts to reach a cease-fire deal in Gaza, U.S. officials said.

headline: Officers Beat Tyre Nichols as ‘Run Tax’ for Trying to Flee, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Federal prosecutors began their case against three former Memphis police officers with an explosive accusation, while defense lawyers said that the officers had acted in line with their training.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Wednesday opened their case against three former Memphis police officers involved in the fatal beating last year of Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old FedEx worker, accusing them of having doled out the blows to punish him for leaving a traffic stop.

headline: Rewards for a ‘Good Boy’
abstract: Parker Higgins needs our help making good matches.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Man Charged With Drugging and Raping Women He Met Online
abstract: The man, Andrew J. Gallo, 40, of Bristol Township, Pa., a Philadelphia suburb, is accused of raping or sexually assaulting six women he met on dating sites.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania man accused of drugging at least six women he met online and raping or sexually assaulting them while they were impaired was arrested on Wednesday, the authorities said.

headline: Rising Storm Water From Francine Threatens Marina on Louisiana Coast
abstract: Tropical Storm Francine has battered homes and businesses in southern Louisiana with heavy rain. Even stilts six feet above the ground may not be enough to save one marina.
lead_paragraph: Rising waters threatened homes and businesses in communities along the Louisiana coast as Tropical Storm Francine lashed the area with heavy rain and intense winds.

headline: Quote of the Day: Will Automation Replace Jobs? Port Workers May Strike Over It.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 12, 2024
lead_paragraph: “You don’t have to pay pensions to robots.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 12, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Sept. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about Donald J. Trump’s legal resources and political status gave an incorrect middle initial for a retired State Supreme Court justice. He is Michael J. Obus, not Michael D. Obus.

headline: Young Chinese Émigrés Confront America’s Brutal Visa Lottery
abstract: For Chinese seeking educational opportunity, the United States has long been the top spot, but as more want to stay to work, their paths are full of roadblocks.
lead_paragraph: For the past three years, luck failed David Zheng in the lottery for the American work visa known as the H-1B. He was in good company: Hundreds of thousands of immigrants apply for a limited number of H-1B visas every year, and a vast majority fail to make the cut.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: The aftermath of the Harris-Trump debate.
lead_paragraph: The first — and perhaps only — debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump continued to reverberate across the U.S. yesterday, spawning memes across the political spectrum and shaking up donors.

headline: In S​outh Korea, Misogyny Has a New Weapon: Deepfake Sex Videos
abstract: Men in chat rooms have been victimizing women they know by putting their faces on pornographic clips. Some Korean women say the only thing new about it is the technology.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, as the South Korean authorities were pursuing a blackmail ring that forced young women to ​make sexually ​explicit videos for paying viewers, they found something else floating through the dark recesses of social media: pornographic images with other people’s faces crudely attached.

headline: MTV Video Music Awards: 7 Memorable Moments
abstract: Taylor Swift set a record and Chappell Roan, Sabrina Carpenter and Katy Perry delivered noteworthy performances as the show struck a balance between past and present.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday night’s MTV Video Music Awards marked the show’s 40th anniversary, and much of the festivities strived for déjà vu by honoring memorable performances and moments from shows past. Montages of “V.M.A. flashbacks” like Michael Jackson heartily kissing Lisa Marie Presley, Madonna writhing through “Like a Virgin,” and Eminem storming the building with a regiment of bleached look-alikes peppered the telecast.

headline: Word of the Day: consternation
abstract: This word has appeared in 149 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word consternation has appeared in 149 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 6 in “Can Foreigners Handle the Heat? Mexico City Debates Milder Salsas” by James Wagner:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Chides Trump for His Debate Performance
abstract: “More than 67 million Americans watched the debate on television last night, and of that 67 million, the only one who seems to think Trump did a good job is Donald Trump,” Kimmel said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Calvin Klein Tries Something New
abstract: The buzzy designer Nensi Dojaka will offer a moodier take on the famous underwear. No tight white briefs or sweaty six-packs in sight.
lead_paragraph: Nensi Dojaka has achieved fashion’s rising-star trifecta: the prestigious LVMH Prize, which she won in 2021; celebrity patronage from the likes of Zendaya and Bella Hadid; and rumors flying that she was in contention for top jobs at major fashion houses.

headline: Happy the Elephant Hasn’t Been Seen in Months. What’s Going On?
abstract: The star attraction of the Bronx Zoo hasn’t been seen since July. The zoo says she’s fine. Animal rights activists are not so sure.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing is wrong with Happy.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Cuomo Legal Bills Have Cost N.Y. Taxpayers $25.4 Million and Counting
abstract: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his aides have mounted a forceful defense, paid for by state taxpayers, against accusations of sexual harassment and other misconduct.
lead_paragraph: In one sexual harassment lawsuit, former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s legal defense has gone so far as to seek records from the accuser’s gynecologist, college and family therapist.

headline: Smiley Faces
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Clothes That Command Attention
abstract: The breadth of people in the streets at New York Fashion Week meant there was no shortage of great outfits.
lead_paragraph: The latest installment of New York Fashion Week possessed a quality that can separate good fashion weeks from great ones: diversity. This was not the contrived kind, when brands will nod to inclusivity by inviting certain guests or casting certain models in their shows. It was more natural. The people of various backgrounds in the crowds outside shows didn’t telegraph as one-offs. They looked as if they were meant to be there.

headline: U.N. Says Gaza’s Anti-Polio Campaign Is Ending With High Hopes
abstract: Health workers have reached many vulnerable children. But for the effort to be considered a success, they must also be able to administer a booster round of vaccinations in a few weeks.
lead_paragraph: The first phase of a large-scale polio vaccination campaign in Gaza is set to conclude on Thursday, with organizers hopeful of soon fulfilling their goal of inoculating 640,000 children under 10.

headline: How a Survival Shooter Built in Ukraine Evolved as a War Rages On
abstract: The Ukrainian developers of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 are trying to distance the video game from Russia’s invasion, but the conflict inevitably altered the creative process.
lead_paragraph: Air raid sirens ring sporadically throughout the gleaming, irradiated landscape of the video game S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2: Heart of Chornobyl, a brutal open-world adventure littered with the landmarks of the nuclear power plant’s real exclusion zone.

headline: To Put It Bluntly
abstract: Much ado has been made of euphemism inflation. While it’s easy to make fun of it, it’s worth examining its logic.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump ends up serving a term in prison (there’s still hope!), I’d relish the chance to refer to him as an ex-con. Like “felon,” the brute force of the term, with its hard-boiled matter-of-factness, would be extremely satisfying.

headline: We Have Taken a Monumental Step to Protect America’s Public Lands
abstract: You can now lease federal property to restore it, not just to mine, cut or graze it.
lead_paragraph: Each fall and winter, thousands of elk from Yellowstone National Park leave behind the deep snows of the park’s harsh and unforgiving high country and descend to surrounding ranch lands to feed on native grasses. Access to this forage is vital to maintaining the health of these herds. But because this food is often on private land, there is no guarantee that elk will continue to have access to it, or even that the native grasses will remain.

headline: Ketanji Brown Jackson Looks Forward to Reading Fiction Again
abstract: The Supreme Court justice has been drawn to American history and books about the “challenges and triumphs” of raising a neurodiverse child. She shares that and more in a memoir, “Lovely One.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Real-Life ‘Golden Bachelorettes’ Would Like a Word
abstract: The series is selling a fantasy. But straight women in their 60s and 70s say the dating scene is anything but rosy.
lead_paragraph: When “The Golden Bachelorette” premieres on Wednesday, the latest reality TV spinoff in the long-running “Bachelor” franchise will once again be selling a fantasy.

headline: Hollywood Is Heading for Broadway (and Off). Here’s a Cheat Sheet.
abstract: George Clooney as Murrow! Denzel Washington as Othello! Mia Farrow as a larcenous landlord! So much to see!
lead_paragraph: New York’s stages have long drawn talent from Hollywood, but this is shaping up to be an exceptionally starry season. Why? Producers have determined that limited-run plays with celebrities are more likely than new musicals to make money. And some musicals are also hoping big names will help at the box office. Here’s a sampling of stars onstage this season.

headline: This Novel Has Fewer Periods Than This Headline. It’s 400 Pages Long.
abstract: Laszlo Krasznahorkai’s single-sentence tale unearths the catastrophe lurking inside the mundane.
lead_paragraph: The first Laszlo Krasznahorkai book I ever purchased happened to be the first of his novels translated into English. I found it at a used-book store in St. Louis around the turn of the millennium. I knew nothing about the author, but dug the expressionist painting on the cover and the Susan Sontag quote on the back: the “Hungarian master of apocalypse.” And in light of the just-finished 2000 election, Krasznahorkai’s title — “The Melancholy of Resistance” — seemed to speak to some transnational condition.

headline: Debt Was Supposed to Cure Poverty and Help Pay for College. What Went Wrong?
abstract: Three new books examine debt’s fraught politics and history.
lead_paragraph: “Going back to biblical times,” a man in the money-lending business once told me over beers in downtown Manhattan, “there was something dirty about charging for money.”

headline: Forum 2 | How Often Do You Have Meaningful Conversations With People Who Don’t Share Your Views?
abstract: More and more of us are living in bubbles with like-minded individuals. What have been your experiences in having conversations across divides?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the second of our Election 2024 Student Conversation Forums, in which teenagers from around the world are invited to explore their political and civic identities, values and beliefs and discuss them with others.

headline: 36 Hours in Lima, Peru
abstract: Swim with sea lions, cycle along the coast, and gorge on ceviche and fried-fish sandwiches in Peru’s underappreciated capital.
lead_paragraph: Swim with sea lions, cycle along the coast, and gorge on ceviche and fried-fish sandwiches in Peru’s underappreciated capital.

headline: The Truth About ‘Man Flu’
abstract: Videos and memes mock men for overreacting when they catch an everyday illness. But is there a biological reason for men’s behavior?
lead_paragraph: According to the Cambridge Dictionary, man flu is “an illness such as a cold that is not serious, but that the person who has it treats as more serious, usually when this person is a man.”

headline: A Double Homage for James Baldwin’s 100th. Will It Ever Be Enough?
abstract: At the New York Public Library, two exhibitions add little to a very public writer’s mystique. But our critic dived deeper.
lead_paragraph: Among the 20 artifacts at the 42nd Street Public Library commemorating the centenary of James Baldwin, the novelist, essayist and playwright who died in 1987, two typewritten sheets seem startlingly site-specific. They suggest that had Baldwin given in to his childhood fears, America’s great watchman of race and alienation might never have stepped foot into the building at all.

headline: Could Your Favorite TV and Movie Characters Afford Their Homes Today?
abstract: From “Friends” to “Breaking Bad” to “Twilight,” a study looked at current rents and home prices to see who could still live in the homes viewers know and love.
lead_paragraph: For many iconic fictional on-screen characters, memorable moments take place at home — be it Kevin McCallister fighting off the Wet Bandits in “Home Alone,” or Chandler Bing proposing to Monica Geller on “Friends.” The homes are important backdrops in these stories, but could the characters afford them today? Probably not, according to a new study.

headline: After Being Shot, Slovakia’s Leader Targets His Enemies
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Fico has purged prosecutors, cultural officials, journalists and others he believes fueled “hatred and aggression” against him.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia returned to work this summer after recovering from gunshot wounds from a May assassination attempt, he released a video message titled “I forgive and I warn.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Sharing Drinks With an Unwilling Spouse
abstract: What if you’re comfortable and the fridge is really far away?
lead_paragraph: Erin writes: My husband gets upset when I take a sip of his drink while we are watching TV. He says that he sees backwash going into his cup. I say we swap spit all the time when we’re kissing, and I don’t want to have to get up off the couch to fix myself a drink. Who’s right?

headline: How a U.N. Agency Became a Flashpoint in the Gaza War
abstract: UNRWA, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees, has survived 75 years of Israeli-Palestinian strife. Can it survive the latest conflict?
lead_paragraph: In mid-January, Philippe Lazzarini, the head of the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, was handed a piece of paper that threatened to doom his organization. It was already in deep crisis. Three months had passed since Hamas militants burst through the barrier between Gaza and Israel, killing about 1,200 people and dragging 250 back as hostages. In retaliation, Israel rained bombs on Gazan cities, killing tens of thousands as it vowed to eradicate Hamas.

headline: The Song That Connects Jackson Browne, Nico and Margot Tenenbaum
abstract: Browne wrote “These Days” at 16. Now 75, he and some famous admirers reflect on his unexpected mainstay: “If a song is worth anything, it’s about the life of the listener.”
lead_paragraph: When he was 16, Jack Browne sat down at his parents’ kitchen table in Fullerton, Calif., and started picking out a tune on an old Kay guitar.

headline: How Colleges Are Changing Their Rules on Protesting
abstract: Ahead of a new school year, colleges across the country have adopted a wave of new rules around protest and speech.
lead_paragraph: At Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, students now must receive approval from the administration before they can protest. Rutgers students will need to acquire a permit from the school. And at Indiana University, students may no longer engage in what school leaders call “expressive activity” between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m.

headline: ‘My Old Ass’ Review: If She Could Turn Back Time
abstract: A buoyant comedy with a big heart follows a teen girl who meets her older self the summer before college.
lead_paragraph: That summer before college can be strange, a moment suspended between life stages, and Elliott (Maisy Stella) is right in the thick of it. She’s turning 18 in the tiny picturesque community in Muskoka, Ontario, where her family has farmed cranberries for generations. She has a janky little motorboat, two best friends and a massive crush on the girl behind the counter at the local coffee shop. And she’s looking forward to heading to Toronto in a few short weeks to start the next chapter of her life.

headline: Walking From Manhattan to the Catskills on the ‘Long Path’
abstract: Intrigued by a trail marker he spotted upstate, a photographer set out to follow a meandering — and little-known — hiking route north from New York City.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of summer, I stepped out into the blistering heat from my apartment building in Alphabet City and headed west on 4th Street, bound for my home in the Catskills, some 130 miles north. I carried a 35-pound backpack filled with camping gear and little idea of what lay ahead.

headline: Trump, Tariffs and the Truth About His Economic Plans
abstract: Binyamin Appelbaum on why Harris’s ill-defined plan is still better than Trump’s.
lead_paragraph: For voters whose top issue is the economy, the choice is clear, argues Binyamin Appelbaum, a member of the Times Editorial Board. Though Vice President Kamala Harris’s plans may be ill-defined, he says, Donald Trump’s plans — curbing immigration, raising tariffs and cutting taxes — would actually leave consumers worse off than they are today.

headline: Harris Can Win on the Economy, but She Needs a Stronger Message
abstract: Optimistic words and some admirable proposals aren’t enough to overcome the discontent and anger that a large majority of Americans feel about the economy.
lead_paragraph: In Tuesday’s debate against Donald Trump, Kamala Harris emphasized her middle-class background, her admiration for small-business owners and her plans for an “opportunity economy.” She promised tax credits for young families and support for first-time homeowners. Those attempts to put meat on the bones of her economic plan will not be enough to win the presidential election.

headline: Dating After 40: It’s Not for the Weak of Heart
abstract: But neither is it hopeless. Forty-somethings describe their dips into the dating pool, ranging from horror stories to happy endings.
lead_paragraph: By the time Winter Harris was in her early 40s, she had begun to accept a reality in which she might be single for the foreseeable future.

headline: What Undecided Voters Are Thinking
abstract: 105 minutes on a Philadelphia debate stage wasn’t enough for some people to fully make up their minds.
lead_paragraph: For the people still on the fence about whom to vote for in the 2024 presidential race, Tuesday night’s debate was an important data point.

headline: These Monkeys Call One Another by Name
abstract: Marmosets are the first nonhuman primates known to use name-like labels for individuals, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: The common marmoset is a certified chatterbox. The small, South American monkey uses an array of chirps, whistles and trills to defend its territory, flag the discovery of food, warn of impending danger and find family members hidden by dense forest foliage.

headline: September Is a Summer Month
abstract: Die-hard fans of the season say the best part starts after Labor Day.
lead_paragraph: The vacationers were gone. Signs of fall were everywhere. There were football games on TV and pumpkins for sale at farm stands. And yet Lexi Schultz, 25, and her friend Kate Krstevska, 22, were at Lighthouse Beach in Chatham, Mass.

headline: Layoffs Are Few. So Why Are Jobs Harder to Find?
abstract: Past economic cycles show that unemployment starts to tick up ahead of a recession, with wide-scale layoffs coming only later.
lead_paragraph: As job growth has slowed and unemployment has crept up, some economists have pointed to a sign of confidence among employers: They are, for the most part, holding on to their existing workers.

headline: ‘Speak No Evil’ Review: He Seemed So Nice
abstract: In this horror remake, James McAvoy plays an aggressively friendly British stranger who extends a dubious invitation to an American couple. Suckers!
lead_paragraph: Given the travel horror stories that fill the news — cruise-ship contagion, passengers trying to open plane doors mid-flight — the movies have some serious competition when it comes to fear mongering. Yet filmmakers keep trying to top reality with familiar stories about the terrors that await you when you venture into the world. Characters keep heading down dark roads. They visit weird hotels and isolated cabins (come on!), invite creeps into their homes and enter those of people they scarcely know (as if!). These travelers don’t ask for trouble; they beg for it.

headline: First Comes Marriage. Then Comes the Rehearsal Dinner.
abstract: Some couples are opting to get the wedding out of the way first, so they can relax and enjoy the rest of the festivities.
lead_paragraph: Harrison Chad and Charlotte Marks, a couple in Park Slope in Brooklyn, have been guests at numerous weddings. Their takeaway was that the traditional structure — a rehearsal dinner the first night and the ceremony and reception the next — was flawed.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Hell’s Kitchen, the financial district and Forest Hills.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 670-square-foot apartment with a foyer, a galley kitchen with marble countertops, central air-conditioning, floor-to-ceiling windows, electric window shades, a washer/dryer and a dedicated basement storage cage, on the 11th floor of a 12-story doorman building with a live-in super, a gym, a conference room, an event space, a library, roof terraces, a rooftop pool, outdoor kitchens, a dog run and guest suites. Patrick Mills, Core NYC, 917-657-5607; corenyc.com

headline: ‘The Americans’ Made the Photographer Robert Frank a Star. What Came Next?
abstract: MoMA’s centenary exhibition of the artist revered for a groundbreaking book makes the case for his later work.
lead_paragraph: Robert Frank never recovered from the success of “The Americans.” On its publication in the United States in 1959, the book was initially excoriated as un-American, particularly in the photography magazines, for its sour, disillusioned take on life in this country. The rich looked bored, the poor desperate, the city fathers fatuous, and the flags threadbare or soiled. What’s more, specialists in photography faulted his technique for muddiness, grain and blur.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are three-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and Huntington, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, four-bath, 3,018-square-foot home built in 1952, with white oak flooring, an open kitchen and living area with a 15-foot vaulted ceiling, a 75-inch TV framed in oak and a porcelain double-sided fireplace adjoining a dining room; an en suite primary bedroom with automatic blinds, an oversized dressing room, a steam shower and radiant heat floors; an office with built-ins; a lower level with a climate-controlled wine cellar and a bonus room; and an attached two-car garage with an EV charger, on 0.3 acres. Jennifer Leahy, 917-699-2783, Douglas Elliman; elliman.com

headline: I’m a Doctor. The Conversations About IUD Insertions Are Long Overdue.
abstract: Doctors underestimate the pain of IUD insertion.
lead_paragraph: An intrauterine device, or IUD, insertion can be very, very painful. Not for all women but for many. In recent TikTok videos documenting the experience, women grimace, cry and clutch the exam table. Often a provider can be heard in the background reminding a woman to breathe or chirping, “Almost done, OK?”

headline: A Science Museum in Queens Names a New President
abstract: Lisa Gugenheim, the former director of the natural history museum, makes a move to the New York Hall of Science.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at the new leader of the New York Hall of Science, which opened 60 years ago this week. We’ll also get details from two security guards who said a senior adviser to Mayor Eric Adams attacked them and then had them arrested.

headline: Broken Blades, Angry Fishermen and Rising Costs Slow Offshore Wind
abstract: Accidents involving blades made by GE Vernova have delayed projects off the coasts of Massachusetts and England and could imperil climate goals.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of a giant wind turbine blade off the Massachusetts coast confirmed Peter Kaizer’s worst fears about the dangers a new clean energy business could pose to fishermen like him.

headline: Reform or the End of Justice? Mexico Is Split on Plan to Elect Judges.
abstract: Even as a sweeping proposal to elect nearly 7,000 judges inches toward law, some Mexicans have protested it. Others welcomed the chance to vote in judges.
lead_paragraph: Outside Mexico’s Senate building on Tuesday, university students wearing masks and dressed as the country’s Supreme Court justices took turns smashing a black piñata with a stick. The piñata, covered in the word “justicia,” or justice, was filled with fake money — a performance staged to illustrate the supposed corruption plaguing the country’s judiciary.

headline: Should Ukraine Launch Western Weapons Deep Into Russia?
abstract: President Biden has refused to allow Ukraine to use long-range Western missiles on Russian military targets, but he appears to be wavering.
lead_paragraph: A deadly uptick of Russian guided glide bombs slamming into Ukrainian cities — as many as 800 in a single week this summer — has injected new urgency into a long-running debate over whether Ukraine should be allowed to launch missiles supplied by the West at military targets deep in Russian territory.

headline: Harris, After a Debate Success, Confronts a Battleground ‘Game of Inches’
abstract: Her campaign is riding high, but still sees the race as an exceedingly close grind. Her aides have new hopes of focusing the race squarely on Donald Trump’s fitness for office.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: They Wanted a House in Chicago for Their Growing Family. Would $650,000 Be Enough?
abstract: When a couple learned they were expecting, finding a bigger home became a priority. Could they afford an extra bedroom, a decent kitchen and some outdoor space?
lead_paragraph: When a couple learned they were expecting, finding a bigger home became a priority. Could they afford an extra bedroom, a decent kitchen and some outdoor space?

headline: The Deeper Meaning of Taylor Swift’s Democratic Mic Drop
abstract: Some regarded the timing as brilliant, others as bizarre. I promise you, she doesn’t care.
lead_paragraph: For a certain swath of America, the big news of Tuesday night’s presidential debate wasn’t made by Donald Trump or Kamala Harris but by Taylor Swift. As you’ve probably heard by now, mere moments after the candidates left the stage, she went on Instagram and, in a move many Democrats had prayed for, endorsed Ms. Harris. “She fights for the rights and causes I believe need a warrior to champion them,” Ms. Swift wrote to her 283 million followers.

headline: MAGA Will Fall for Anything
abstract: Apparently, this election is about … pets.
lead_paragraph: It was the strangest thing I’ve ever seen during a presidential debate, and I’m exactly the kind of nerd who has watched every general election debate since he was 11 years old.

headline: Conversations With Journalists: An Invitation for Teenagers
abstract: This fall we’re choosing some teen-friendly Times articles and inviting students to talk to the people who made them. Post your thoughts, ask questions or suggest ideas, and the reporters will reply!
lead_paragraph: Would your students be excited if your curriculum included this article?

headline: Francine Floods New Orleans Areas Scarred by Past Storms
abstract: Southern Louisiana residents braced for floods as the storm passed through. Many were in neighborhoods that were battered by Katrina and Ida.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Stevens anxiously watched floodwater creep closer to her doorstep in suburban New Orleans early Thursday, as Tropical Storm Francine made its way through Louisiana, dumping up to nine inches of rain in some parts.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,182
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, September 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 460
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Sept. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: G.M. and Hyundai Plan to Work Together on New Vehicles
abstract: General Motors and the South Korean automaker say they will collaborate on new vehicles, buying parts and clean energy technologies.
lead_paragraph: General Motors and Hyundai said on Thursday that they would look for areas where they could collaborate on new vehicles, supply chains and technologies in a bid to cut costs and move faster.

headline: Harris and Trump’s Next Moves, and Francine Lashes Southern Louisiana
abstract: Plus, debunking claims about immigrants in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: How the Election Is Sinking a $15 Billion Business Deal
abstract: The Biden administration is expected to block a takeover of U.S. Steel by Japan’s Nippon Steel.
lead_paragraph: In a highly unusual move, the Biden administration signaled last week that it would block a Japanese company from buying an iconic American company in a critical swing state.

headline: The Stakes on Presidential Power
abstract: We explain the contrasting approaches Donald Trump and Kamala Harris take to the executive office.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every president has pushed the limits of the office’s power by taking actions that some legal scholars consider an overreach — in directing a military strike, issuing an executive order or filling a job without Congress’s approval. Checks and balances can frustrate a leader who wants to get stuff done. And in an era of polarized politics that can paralyze Congress, presidents often believe that their success hinges on unilateral action.

headline: The Grenfell Fire and the Unbearable Slowness of Public Inquiries
abstract: Holding an inquiry has become one of the British government’s go-to responses to outrageous harm. But that approach can sometimes stall change and delay justice.
lead_paragraph: If in doubt, hold an inquiry.

headline: ‘The 4:30 Movie’ Review: Jersey Boys
abstract: The writer-director Kevin Smith looks back fondly on his New Jersey childhood in this semi-autobiographical coming-of-age comedy.
lead_paragraph: “The 4:30 Movie,” a nostalgic period comedy about teenage cinephiles coming of age in small-town New Jersey, is alternately juvenile and sentimental. It’s an awkward tonal balance familiar from the writer-director Kevin Smith’s early features, including “Mallrats” and the ’90s cult classic “Clerks.”

headline: ‘The Critic’ Review: Dangerous Liaisons
abstract: Ian McKellen stars as a drama critic in 1930s London who has much higher standards for the theater than for his own professional ethics.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who works in the arts can be forgiven for casting a critic as a villain. But a reviewer who dangles potential praise as leverage in a blackmail scheme? That’s going a step too far.

headline: ‘Matt and Mara’ Review: Will They or Won’t They?
abstract: Two former college friends reconnect for a possible romance in this irritatingly vague and vapid drama.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the bond between the title characters of “Matt and Mara” (Matt Johnson and Deragh Campbell), it’s an uncomfortable one. How could it be otherwise when one of them is constitutionally unable to recognize her needs and the other is clearly accustomed to satisfying his?

headline: ‘Girls Will Be Girls’ Review: Surviving High School
abstract: The filmmaker Shuchi Talati’s debut feature follows a model student and her stifled mother, who are both vying for the attention of a new crush.
lead_paragraph: “Girls Will Be Girls,” the debut feature from the Indian filmmaker Shuchi Talati, is a careful, naturalistic coming-of-age story with a clunky title.

headline: ‘Winner’ Review: Not Like Other Girls
abstract: This dramedy starring Emilia Jones depicts the life and times of Reality Winner, a former National Security Agency contractor and whistle-blower.
lead_paragraph: “Winner,” an oddly perky dramedy by the director Susanna Fogel (who wrote “Booksmart”), is loosely based on the life of Reality Winner, the former National Security Agency contractor and Air Force linguist who was arrested in 2017 for leaking a top-secret report about Russian interference in the 2016 United States presidential election. (She was released from prison in 2021.)

headline: ‘The Power Broker’ Is Finally Getting a Digital Edition. What Took So Long?
abstract: Robert Caro’s mammoth study of the urban planner Robert Moses is coming out as an e-book this month, on the 50th anniversary of the biography’s publication.
lead_paragraph: Robert Caro is obsessed with paper. He’s spent decades meticulously combing through the pages of archives. He writes his books on legal pads, then types them up on an electric Smith-Corona typewriter, making paper carbon copies as he goes. His mantra — cribbed from advice he received as a young investigative reporter — is “turn every page.”

headline: Robert Caro Reflects on ‘The Power Broker’ and Its Legacy at 50
abstract: Caro’s book on Robert Moses, a city planner who reshaped New York, is also a reflection on “the dangers of unchecked power,” and remains more resonant and relevant than ever.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Caro was writing “The Power Broker,” his 1974 biography of the urban planner Robert Moses, he often heard a deflating refrain.

headline: What Taylor Swift’s Endorsement Means for Kamala Harris
abstract: Taylor Swift endorsed Kamala Harris for president shortly after her fierce debate with former President Donald Trump on Tuesday. Writing on Instagram, where she has hundreds of millions of followers, Ms. Swift encouraged her fans to do their own research and to register to vote.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift endorsed Kamala Harris for president shortly after her fierce debate with former President Donald Trump on Tuesday. Writing on Instagram, where she has hundreds of millions of followers, Ms. Swift encouraged her fans to do their own research and to register to vote.

headline: American Activist Killed in West Bank Will Be Buried in Turkey
abstract: The body of Aysenur Ezgi Eygi, a Turkish American dual citizen, was being sent to Turkey for her funeral. Her fatal shooting by Israeli forces has sparked outrage in both countries.
lead_paragraph: The body of a Turkish American activist killed by Israeli gunfire was expected to arrive in Turkey on Friday for her funeral and burial in a town on the Aegean coast.

headline: OpenAI Aims for a $150 Billion Valuation
abstract: The ChatGPT maker is closing in on another mega funding round as investors bet the boom in artificial intelligence has plenty of room to grow.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a few days make. OpenAI is now in talks to raise about $6.5 billion at a valuation of around $150 billion, The Times reports. Those numbers vastly exceed what ChatGPT’s parent company had been seeking not too long ago.

headline: European Central Bank Cuts Rates for Second Time in Three Months
abstract: The reduction, to 3.5 percent from 3.75 percent, comes as inflation has slowed and the bank faces pressure to bolster the region’s flagging economy.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank cut interest rates on Thursday for the second time in three months, as it continued the slow unwinding of the aggressive stance the bank took to stamp out high inflation in the eurozone.

headline: Absentee Ballots Are Mailed in Alabama, the First State to Send Them Out
abstract: Mail ballots in North Carolina are also set to go out soon. In-person voting is set to start next week in parts of Pennsylvania and in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: The first ballots of the 2024 general election are in the mail.

headline: A Corporate Minimum Tax Aimed at Closing ‘Loopholes’ Leaves Gaps
abstract: The Treasury Department estimates that a new law requiring big companies to pay a 15 percent tax will raise $250 billion from large corporations over the next 10 years.
lead_paragraph: When Democrats created a new corporate tax regime two years ago, their goal was seemingly simple: rein in the ability of large companies to pay little or no federal income tax.

headline: Inside a Storm Center Rebuilt After Hurricane Katrina’s Destruction
abstract: In 2005, the center operated out of an old bowling alley in the town of Bay St. Louis, right next to the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Brian Adam has spent a lot of long nights in the Hancock County emergency operations center, where he managed response efforts for the Mississippi county as Hurricane Francine roared ashore Wednesday in neighboring Louisiana.

headline: Youth Group Asks Supreme Court to Revive a Landmark Climate Lawsuit
abstract: The case argues the government violated young people’s constitutional rights by failing to curb the use of fossil fuels. A lower court had thrown it out.
lead_paragraph: A group of young people who filed a landmark climate change lawsuit in 2015 against the federal government, only to have their suit thrown out, are turning to the Supreme Court in an attempt to revive the case and get their day in court.

headline: ‘Real Women Have Curves’ Musical Plans Broadway Bow Next Year
abstract: The show, adapted from the play and movie, was first staged last winter at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.
lead_paragraph: A musical adaptation of “Real Women Have Curves,” Josefina López’s exploration of immigrant experiences through the story of a group of Latina women working at a Los Angeles garment factory, will run on Broadway next year, the show’s producers said Thursday.

headline: Jon Bon Jovi Helps Woman Off Ledge of Bridge
abstract: The singer, who was filming a music video nearby, helped coax a woman to safety in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Jon Bon Jovi helped talk a woman off the ledge of a bridge in Nashville earlier this week, the police said.

headline: My Ailing Mom Hates Pot. Do I Tell Her What’s in Her Gummies?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to notify an unsuspecting woman that she’s been consuming medicinal cannabis.
lead_paragraph: My 78-year-old mother has moderate dementia and suffers from mood swings, depression, anxiety, agitation and disturbed sleep. One of her doctors recommended a low-dosage CBD/THC gummy to alleviate these problems. She takes one daily and, combined with other therapies, now experiences more stable moods and better sleep.

headline: No Shoes, No Phones Allowed at This Brooklyn Shop
abstract: Plus: Sardinian furniture, a Jordan Casteel exhibition and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 2012, the Copenhagen-based clothing brand Baserange has become a go-to for its bodywear and undergarments with minimalist silhouettes. Co-founders Blandine Legait and Marie-Louise Mogensen started it with the goal of creating pieces that would allow movement and provide comfort. Now, they’re expanding into homewares with a similar mission. The Baserange Home collection is launching with towels, tablecloths and bed linens in the brand’s signature earthy hues (including terra cotta, dusty pink and foggy gray), made with organic cotton and EcoVero viscose, a material composed of wood fibers harvested from forests that are certified sustainable by the Forest Stewardship Council. The designers intend the line to be adaptable: The Yoga Mat towel announces its multiple uses in its name, while Mogensen imagines “taking a home on the go” by bringing the striped Shell towel out of the bath and onto the beach or rolling it up to stuff in the oblong Shell pillowcase while traveling. The Baserange Home collection launches Sept. 18; from $40, baserange.com.

headline: Michael Kiwanuka Makes the Simple Profound. The World Is Listening.
abstract: The English songwriter will follow up his Mercury Prize-winning 2019 LP with his fourth album, “Small Changes,” in November.
lead_paragraph: “A song can make you hear or understand things that you don’t know how to say,” the English singer and songwriter Michael Kiwanuka said. “I think of songs as ways to communicate without conversation.”

headline: Weinstein Faces a New Sealed Indictment in New York, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The disgraced Hollywood mogul, who underwent emergency heart surgery this week, was not present in court Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein, the disgraced Hollywood mogul whose conviction for sex crimes in New York was overturned in April, is facing a new indictment, Manhattan prosecutors said in a hearing on Thursday.

headline: In Narrowly Divided North Carolina, a Light Blue County Is Key for Harris
abstract: For 16 years, the state has been a heartbreaker for Democrats, and so has Mecklenburg County — a reliably blue area that just hasn’t been blue enough.
