lead_paragraph: Ask any Democrat knocking doors, hosting debate watch parties or making phone calls in the blue pockets of North Carolina over the last several weeks, and they’ll say 2024 feels a lot like 2008.

headline: Phony Romeos? Email Threats? Dissecting the Anatomy of an Online Scam.
abstract: In a series for the Business desk, a reporter is chasing down sophisticated online scams that target Americans, particularly older adults.
lead_paragraph: Cyberscam artists are lurking everywhere, and most of us are targeted by them regularly. Just last week, I received an email from someone I didn’t know with a suspicious attachment that included a photo of where I live.

headline: Ukraine Says Russian Missile Hit Grain Ship in Black Sea
abstract: If confirmed, the attack would be the first on a commercial vessel in open waters since the 2022 invasion, and a sharp escalation of hostilities in the Black Sea.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said on Thursday that a Russian missile struck a cargo ship in the Black Sea that was carrying wheat to Egypt in an attack off the coast of Romania.

headline: Map: 4.7-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Los Angeles
abstract: View the quake’s shake area and aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: View the quake’s shake area and aftershocks.

headline: Earthquake Rattles Coastal Area Near Los Angeles
abstract: Preliminary estimates said a 4.7-magnitude temblor was centered near Malibu. The authorities were determining whether there was any significant damage.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles residents were rattled Thursday morning by an earthquake centered north of the coastal city of Malibu.

headline: Navient Reaches $120 Million Student Loan Settlement With Consumer Watchdog
abstract: The company has been banned from servicing federal student loans and must pay $100 million to harmed borrowers, as well as a $20 million penalty.
lead_paragraph: Navient, formerly one of the nation’s largest student loan servicers, reached a $120 million settlement with federal regulators on Thursday to resolve claims that it misled federal student loan borrowers and mishandled their payments for years.

headline: Why House Republicans Are Targeting China Weeks Before the Election
abstract: The G.O.P. pushed through an array of legislation to get tough on China, seeking to persuade voters that they are the party that will protect Americans from economic and military threats from Beijing.
lead_paragraph: The House this week tackled a long-promised package of bills to get tough on China, but few if any have a chance of becoming law after Republicans opted to prioritize a handful of politically divisive measures that Democrats oppose.

headline: Chewy Brownie Cookies, Because I Don’t Like Playing Favorites
abstract: The fudgy, chocolaty goodness of a brownie meets the crisp edges of a cookie in Vaughn Vreeland’s perfect new recipe.
lead_paragraph: I admire a lot of things about Vaughn Vreeland. His ease in front of the camera. His commitment to a theme. His spot-on Jennifer Coolidge impression. But something I love about him is how, when it comes to sweet treats, he doesn’t make me choose.

headline: Charles Biasiny-Rivera, Champion of Latino Photography, Dies at 93
abstract: A New Yorker of Puerto Rican descent, he helped start a collective that brought recognition to Hispanic photographers and illuminated life in the city’s barrios.
lead_paragraph: To Charles Biasiny-Rivera, who worked as a street photographer in the barrios of New York City in the early 1970s, his craft was a matter of trust as much as eye.

headline: ‘Chaos’ Reigns!
abstract: ‘Chaos’ is an unruly word for a volatile time. The election is the least of it.
lead_paragraph: ‘Chaos’ is an unruly word for a volatile time. The election is the least of it.

headline: Russian Forces Are Stepping Up Attacks on Strategic City, Ukraine Says
abstract: Bombardments are increasing in and around Pokrovsk in eastern Ukraine, with water supplies now cut, while Russian troops simultaneously press a new counterattack in the Kursk region.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces have stepped up their assault on the strategic Ukrainian city of Pokrovsk, cutting off water supplies and destroying a key overpass in a grim urban enclave already short on natural gas and electricity, Ukrainian officials said on Thursday.

headline: Violent Convulsions and Lost Speech: Listeria Survivors Describe Harrowing Illnesses
abstract: The outbreak, linked to Boar’s Head products, has been especially devastating for high-risk groups like pregnant women and older adults.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Solberg wasn’t worried about the risk to her pregnancy when she bought Boar’s Head sliced ham from a Florida supermarket in May. Her doctor had told her the risk was negligible, Ms. Solberg said, and she’d eaten deli meat without any issues in her last pregnancy. So she used it to make a poolside lunch for her parents and toddler.

headline: Police Commissioner Resigns as Investigations Batter Adams’s Circle
abstract: Edward Caban had been asked to quit after federal agents seized his phone as part of a criminal investigation, one of several involving members of the administration.
lead_paragraph: Edward A. Caban, the New York City police commissioner, resigned on Thursday at the request of City Hall, which had asked him to step aside after federal agents seized his phone last week as part of a criminal investigation.

headline: Missouri Judge Rejects Innocence Claim by Man on Death Row
abstract: Marcellus Williams, who was convicted in a 1998 killing, now faces execution later this month.
lead_paragraph: A Missouri judge on Thursday upheld the conviction of Marcellus Williams, a death row inmate, rejecting a local prosecutor’s argument that there is strong evidence that Mr. Williams is innocent.

headline: Linda Ronstadt Criticizes Trump Before He Appears at Venue Named for Her
abstract: The singer denounced the former president, singling out the impact of his administration’s family separations policy in Arizona, and endorsed Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: The singer Linda Ronstadt denounced Donald J. Trump on Wednesday night in a statement released before his scheduled visit to Tucson for a campaign rally on Thursday, saying she had felt compelled to speak out because his event would be held at a venue named after her.

headline: Adderall in Higher Doses May Raise Psychosis Risk, Study Says
abstract: New research suggests that dosage plays a role in a rare side effect of A.D.H.D. stimulants.
lead_paragraph: Julianna McLeod, 26, had her first psychotic episode while taking Vyvanse for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder last year.

headline: After Bomb Threats and Political Vitriol, Ohio Mayor Says Enough
abstract: Springfield, which has attracted thousands of Haitians, has been at the center of a fiery immigration debate and baseless rumors amplified by Donald J. Trump and JD Vance.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of the Ohio city at the center of a firestorm over immigration says that his town needs help — not the hate that has been stirred by politicians and extremists.

headline: Kamala Harris Is Serious. Donald Trump Is Not.
abstract: Her careful cramming and his cocky hamming tell you all you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Before this week’s presidential debate, Vice President Kamala Harris holed up. Hunkered down. Studied. Practiced. Her advisers made no secret of that. I read dozens of articles about it.

headline: New Look at Landslide Potential Shows 44% of U.S. Is at Risk
abstract: A new federal database helps users determine the likelihood of their community experiencing a landslide.
lead_paragraph: Almost 44 percent of the United States could experience a landslide, according to new data from government scientists.

headline: Residents Survive a Harrowing Night as Francine Blasts Louisiana
abstract: Waters rose and then receded quickly in New Orleans and communities to its southwest, where Hurricane Francine made landfall.
lead_paragraph: Tina Christopher and her mother spent the night at their darkened home in Morgan City, La., listening to hurricane-force winds howl and branches pelt the roof. ”I’ll never stay for a storm again,” Ms. Christopher, 57, said after emerging on Thursday morning.

headline: 2 Chinese Dramas (and a Family of 3) Broaden a Theater Festival’s Scope
abstract: By presenting “The Orphan of Chao” and “Snow in Midsummer,” the Shaw Festival is helping “the past to smash its way into the modern world.”
lead_paragraph: For 35 years, the Shaw Festival had one central criterion for its programming: Any and all plays had to have been written during George Bernard Shaw’s lifetime.

headline: Should We Refrain From Gossip?
abstract: Readers offer different answers in response to a guest essay. Also: Protests on campus; China’s adoption policy; Trump the fixer; hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Mortgage Rates Continue to Fall
abstract: The average rate on 30-year mortgages declined to 6.2 percent this week, the lowest point since early 2023.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates fell this week to the lowest point in over a year and a half, as markets reacted to economic data showing a slowing economy.

headline: U.S. Presses Nigeria to Release Imprisoned Binance Employee
abstract: Diplomats are calling for the release of Tigran Gambaryan, an employee of the crypto exchange who was arrested in February.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government has urged Nigeria to release an employee of the giant cryptocurrency exchange Binance who was arrested there in February and has faced mounting medical problems in prison, according to two senior State Department officials.

headline: DeSantis Spars With Abortion Rights Backers Over Florida Ballot Measure
abstract: Florida’s governor has come under fire from critics who say he is using state resources to work against a proposed abortion-rights amendment to the state Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Less than eight weeks before Floridians will vote on an abortion-rights amendment to the state Constitution, a bitter standoff is escalating between Gov. Ron DeSantis and the amendment’s backers over whether a string of state actions directed at the measure amount to a taxpayer-funded effort to defeat it at the polls.

headline: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 2, Episode 5 Recap: Royal Pains
abstract: This week’s focus was largely on the deepening political drama in Numenor and Khazad-dum, where things have gotten predictably messy.
lead_paragraph: After last week’s delightful panoply of ents, barrow-wights and stoors (and Tom Bombadil!), this week’s episode of “Rings of Power” shifted away from fantastical action and got back to the slow, hard grind of politics. Because this is a prequel series, it has a fixed endpoint to reach, involving a lot of dangerous jewelry getting distributed to folks who will not end up seeing eye-to-eye on how use it. But before we get there, all of these humans, dwarves and elves still have a lot of talking to do — whether we enjoy hearing it or not.

headline: OpenAI Unveils New ChatGPT That Can Reason Through Math and Science
abstract: Driven by new technology called OpenAI o1, the chatbot can test various strategies and try to identify mistakes as it tackles complex tasks.
lead_paragraph: Online chatbots like ChatGPT from OpenAI and Gemini from Google sometimes struggle with simple math problems. The computer code they generate is often buggy and incomplete. From time to time, they even make stuff up.

headline: Elevated Lead Levels Found in One-Third of Cinnamon Samples
abstract: Consumer Reports found lead in a variety of products, at a time when federal regulators are seeking authority from Congress to combat the problem of heavy metals in foods.
lead_paragraph: One dozen of 36 cinnamon products tested by a consumer group contained elevated levels of lead, according to a study released on Thursday that reinforced concerns about metals in foods after tainted cinnamon applesauce poisoned dozens of children last year.

headline: Israeli Commandos Carried Out Raid on Secret Weapons Site in Syria
abstract: The missile production facility was destroyed in the attack, according to Western officials. Syrian state media reported that 18 people were killed in the strike.
lead_paragraph: Israel carried out a commando raid in Syria on Sunday that obliterated a Hezbollah missile production facility near the Lebanese border, killing a number of people at the site, according to American and other Western officials.

headline: Something Important Is Happening With JD Vance, Laura Loomer, Project 2025 and Donald Trump
abstract: To me, this is the biggest political dynamic coming out of Tuesday’s debate.
lead_paragraph: Right-wing absurdities — Donald Trump’s comments about Haitian migrants eating pets, JD Vance’s comments about “childless cat ladies” (among other things), Project 2025’s ideas, the conspiracist Laura Loomer being in Trump’s inner circle — are breaking through to regular Americans and undecided voters to a degree that undermines the Trump campaign’s goal of positioning the former president as the more moderate, change-oriented candidate in the race. To me, this is the biggest political dynamic coming out of Tuesday’s debate.

headline: Satellite TV Is in Trouble. DirecTV’s Dispute With Disney Shows Why.
abstract: While the cable TV business is declining quickly, satellite TV is decaying even faster.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that the TV business is in upheaval. And in the sea of struggling companies, satellite TV distributors may be in the most precarious position.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Two of our recommended titles this week explore surprising connections between humans and other members of the animal kingdom. In “Raiders, Rulers, and Traders,” David Chaffetz makes a thorough case that horses were the deciding factor enabling the spread of empires across ancient Asia, and in “Rat City” Jon Adams and Edmund Ramsden revisit a groundbreaking academic study that shed light on the ways people resemble rats and vice versa.

headline: Francine Leaves Behind Flooding and Power Outages in Louisiana
abstract: The storm made landfall as a Category 2 hurricane on Wednesday before weakening overnight into a tropical depression.
lead_paragraph: The storm made landfall as a Category 2 hurricane on Wednesday before weakening overnight into a tropical depression.

headline: Mark Jury, Whose Stark Photography Captured the Vietnam War, Dies at 80
abstract: He produced an early photo book about what he called the first “rock ’n’ roll war,” documented his grandfather’s dementia and became a filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Mark Jury, a photographer whose searing, intimate images from the battlefields of South Vietnam and the deathbed of his coal miner grandfather filled the pages of two critically acclaimed books in the 1970s, died on Aug. 27 in Scranton, Pa. He was 80.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Who Spied for China Is Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
abstract: The former officer, who also worked as a contract translator for the F.B.I., provided classified documents to Beijing.
lead_paragraph: A former C.I.A. officer and contract translator for the F.B.I. who accepted thousands of dollars in cash and expensive gifts, such as a new set of golf clubs, in return for providing classified information to the Chinese government was sentenced on Wednesday to 10 years in prison, prosecutors said.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Call to Vote Sent Hundreds of Thousands to Registration Tools
abstract: Three organizations that provide clearinghouse voting resources had traffic spikes coinciding with Ms. Swift’s post urging her fans to cast a ballot.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris on Tuesday and her call for her fans to vote drove hundreds of thousands of people to voter registration resources.

headline: Is Inequality the Key to the Climate Change Debate?
abstract: In his new book, the economist Thomas Piketty argues that the world can’t stop climate change without addressing issues of inequality.
lead_paragraph: Climate change wasn’t a big topic in the debate between Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on Tuesday night. Trump all but ignored the ABC News moderators when they asked what he would do about climate change, and Harris mostly talked about it in economic terms, talking up the Biden administration’s investments in clean energy and the new jobs they created.

headline: Will Taylor Swift’s Endorsement Actually Affect the Election?
abstract: What the research says about celebrity endorsements — and what might make this one different.
lead_paragraph: To some Americans, the biggest news to come out of the presidential debate Tuesday night was not Kamala Harris’s well-received performance. It was Taylor Swift’s endorsement of her minutes after the debate ended.

headline: How Media on the Left and Right Covered Taylor Swift’s Harris Endorsement
abstract: Liberal commentators celebrated the megastar’s endorsement of the Democratic ticket. Conservatives either downplayed the impact Taylor Swift might have, or attacked her.
lead_paragraph: After Taylor Swift endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris on Tuesday night, media outlets broke from their coverage of the presidential debate and dedicated ample coverage to the megastar.

headline: In Fight for Congress, Democrats Run as ‘Team Normal,’ Casting G.O.P. as ‘Weird’
abstract: In competitive districts, Democratic congressional candidates have pivoted from portraying Republicans as dangerous and extreme to ridiculing them as too odd to support.
lead_paragraph: Representative Greg Landsman’s pitch to the voters of his politically competitive district in Ohio goes something like this: You may once have preferred Republicans, but the leaders of today’s G.O.P. have gotten, well, too weird.

headline: Why Your Favorite Restaurant Sounds Like That
abstract: Owners are putting more thought than ever into the music playing through their speakers, sometimes tapping professionals for help.
lead_paragraph: Simon Kim knows exactly how many beats per minute are in each song played in his restaurants.

headline: 3 Red Cross Workers Killed in Ukraine by Shelling
abstract: The aid workers lost their lives as they were preparing to distribute heating supplies in preparation for winter in the region of Donetsk.
lead_paragraph: Three Red Cross workers were killed and two wounded on Thursday when artillery fire struck a frontline aid distribution site in Ukraine on Thursday, the organization said.

headline: Their School Has Yet to Reopen After a Shooting. They’re Unsure What to Expect.
abstract: The 1,900 students at Apalachee High School in Winder, Ga., were just settling into the rhythms of a new year before a shooter killed two teachers and two students.
lead_paragraph: Before “lockdown” flashed on classroom screens last Wednesday and Apalachee High School changed irrevocably, its 1,900 students were getting into the groove of a new academic year.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 16, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: North Dakota’s Abortion Ban Is Overturned
abstract: A judge ruled that the State Constitution protected a woman’s right to abortion until the fetus was viable. The state’s attorney general said he would appeal.
lead_paragraph: A North Dakota judge overturned the state’s near-total abortion ban on Thursday, saying that the State Constitution protected a woman’s right to abortion until the fetus was viable.

headline: This Chatbot Pulls People Away From Conspiracy Theories
abstract: In a new study, many people doubted or abandoned false beliefs after a short conversation with the DebunkBot.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after generative artificial intelligence hit the mainstream, researchers warned that chatbots would create a dire problem: As disinformation became easier to create, conspiracy theories would spread rampantly.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Summer Vacation and Heading Back to School
abstract: Welcome to a new year of Current Events Conversation!
lead_paragraph: Our weekly Current Events Conversation is back. Every Thursday during the school year, we round up a selection of student comments from one or more of our daily writing prompts. We welcome voices from teenagers from anywhere in the world. We hope you’ll join us this school year!

headline: Bob Weatherwax, Trainer of Lassie and Other Celebrity Dogs, Dies at 83
abstract: Like his father, who taught him, he bred and coached the collies that played the heroic star of television and movies.
lead_paragraph: Bob Weatherwax, a Hollywood dog trainer who carried on his father’s legacy of breeding and coaching collies to play Lassie, the resourceful and heroic canine who crossed flooded rivers, faced down bears and leaped into the hearts of countless children, died on Aug. 15 in Scranton, Pa. He was 83.

headline: United States Backs Africa’s U.N. Security Council Bid, With a Catch
abstract: The announcement provides U.S. support to permanent council seats for African nations, though not new veto powers. But the path to adding members requires far more than White House approval.
lead_paragraph: The United States would support two permanent seats for African states on the U.N. Security Council, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said on Thursday. But the path to making that promise a reality is complicated.

headline: ‘The Smoking Room’ Is a Brilliant British Office Comedy
abstract: And yet, compared with the British “Office,” it is a model of restraint.
lead_paragraph: The two-season comedy “The Smoking Room” (on the Roku Channel) premiered in Britain in 2004, and in some ways it can feel even older: A designated indoor cigarette-smoking lounge at an office? Nary a phone in sight, and only glancing mentions of the internet? Next you’re going to tell me they’re rendering tallow and writing out the Bible by hand.

headline: Harvard, Brown and Other Top Schools Are Thinking About Black Freshmen the Wrong Way
abstract: I’ve seen firsthand that this scenario does not play out the way alarmists think it does.
lead_paragraph: Several highly selective universities have recently reported that in their first freshman classes admitted after the Supreme Court banned racial preferences in admissions, the number of Black and Latino students has fallen.

headline: As Venezuela Slides Deeper Into Autocracy, U.S. Imposes Limited Sanctions
abstract: The sanctions against 16 government officials appointed by the authoritarian president of Venezuela were seen as unlikely to be effective by observers and analysts.
lead_paragraph: The United States announced on Thursday it was imposing sanctions on 16 Venezuelan government officials appointed by the country’s autocratic president, Nicolás Maduro, in response to the disputed presidential election on July 28.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Summer Olympics Medal Count
abstract: Should a bronze medal count the same as a gold when determining who won the Olympics? What’s the best way to rank countries based on medal count?
lead_paragraph: Update, Sept. 18: An earlier version of this graph did not include the “Possible rank in Olympic medal count” key. We have added that key above the graph.

headline: La Grenouille, Vestige of New York’s Old-School French Dining, Will Close
abstract: Six decades after its birth as an elegant refuge for Manhattan’s elite, the Midtown restaurant says ‘adieu’ this week.
lead_paragraph: La Grenouille, the last survivor of an elegant corps of French restaurants that arrived in New York in the 1960s and helped secure the city’s reputation for sophisticated dining, will close this week. Its current owner and operator, Philippe Masson, “is moving on to explore new terrain and pursue other dreams,” according to a notice posted Wednesday on the restaurant’s Instagram account.

headline: Climate Lawsuits Are Exploding. Are Homicide Charges Next?
abstract: The courts have become one of the most important battlegrounds in the fight over planet-warming emissions. Here are prominent cases to watch.
lead_paragraph: Lawsuits against fossil fuel companies over climate change are piling up. Legislators and activists are pushing prosecutors to pursue criminal charges. Children are suing governments, arguing that their right to a healthy environment is being trampled on.

headline: $47 Million Flowed Into Harris Campaign in 24 Hours After Debate
abstract: The sum included donations from 600,000 individuals. Vice President Kamala Harris already had a significant financial edge over former President Donald J. Trump entering September.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris raised $47 million in the first 24 hours following her debate with former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday night, a sum that will likely expand a widening funding gap between the two campaigns.

headline: Fall’s Best Boots Are Rugged and Buckled
abstract: Here are our favorite pairs, in a range of prices.
lead_paragraph: These are about as classic as it comes, and exceptionally sturdy — they’re made from full-grain leather (the most durable part of a hide) with an oil-resistant outsole — which is no surprise, considering Durango has been making cowboy boots since the 1960s.

headline: Déjà Vu for Mike Johnson as Internal Strife Stalls Spending Plan
abstract: The House speaker faces a choice of cutting a deal with Democrats or bowing to conservatives and Donald Trump and shutting down the government just before the election.
lead_paragraph: With a funding deadline looming, the Republican House speaker was caught between his far right and others in his party eager to avoid a confrontation with Democrats that could shutter the government and cost them politically.

headline: Report Concludes China Broke Rules in Doping Case but Clears WADA
abstract: An investigator hired by the global antidoping regulator found no bias toward China in a case that has outraged Olympic athletes and led to an F.B.I. investigation.
lead_paragraph: The World Anti-Doping Agency’s executive board on Thursday eagerly embraced a report that validated its decision to clear 23 elite Chinese swimmers of doping, even as the report’s author pointed out Chinese officials had violated established rules in their handling of the incident.

headline: The Bars With the Best Free Food
abstract: Free hot dogs. Free fried olives. Free truffle popcorn. Did we mention it was free?
lead_paragraph: Need I say more? I suppose I will, mainly for the sake of hitting my required word count. In, sorry, this economy, free stuff is the ultimate treat. Especially at a bar or restaurant, as the prices of food and drinks continue to rise and rise, seemingly with no ceiling. Even something small, like a bowl of cheese balls at a dive bar (ahem, the Levee) is a touch that makes you feel like a V.I.P., no matter where (or who) you are.

headline: 18,000 Miles Later, an American Woman Has Cycled the World
abstract: It took Lael Wilcox 108 days to circumnavigate the globe. Improbably, she said it was “the most fun ride of my life.”
lead_paragraph: Lael Wilcox hopped on her bicycle in Chicago in May. Three and a half months later, she was back, having ridden 18,000 miles around the world and set what is being hailed as a new women’s record.

headline: A Famous Churchill Portrait, Stolen in Canada and Found in Italy
abstract: A forgery delayed the discovery of the theft of the photograph long enough for it to be sold at an auction in London.
lead_paragraph: For three decades, a fierce-looking Winston Churchill, a hand on his hip, stared down guests in a lounge at the Fairmont Château Laurier hotel in Ottawa.

headline: Trump Says He Won’t Debate Harris Again
abstract: His declaration follows a debate performance on Tuesday that was widely criticized. He has gone back and forth before about whether to participate in debates.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump insisted on Thursday that there “will be no” second debate against Vice President Kamala Harris, two days after a face-off in which he was widely criticized for delivering a poor performance filled with missed opportunities.

headline: Scenes From Southern California as Wildfires Persist
abstract: Firefighters struggled to contain three large fires threatening areas including Los Angeles and San Bernardino County.
lead_paragraph: Longtime residents in the mountain region of Southern California have seen decades of wildfires ravage their neighborhoods, counting themselves lucky when their homes and loved ones have survived. But over the last week, a triple threat of large fires has torn through Los Angeles and neighboring counties, burning longstanding and newly built homes, displacing thousands, and torching more than 100,000 acres of land.

headline: Sybil Haydel Morial, New Orleans Civil Rights Matriarch, Dies at 91
abstract: The wife of Ernest N. Morial, the city’s first Black mayor, she fought for equal rights for Black women.
lead_paragraph: Sybil Haydel Morial, an activist who was also the matriarch of the most prominent civil rights family in New Orleans, died on Sept. 3 in that city. She was 91.

headline: A New Mini-Moon Is Being Captured by Planet Earth
abstract: It’s just a little guy, and not everyone agrees that it’s actually a mini-moon.
lead_paragraph: When approaching Earth, asteroids tend to do one of two things: Most of the time, they miss. Sometimes, they hit, leaving a bright streak in our planet’s sky or a gruesome new wound in its crust. But very rarely, an asteroid is captured by Earth’s gravity and pirouettes around the planet, becoming, in effect, a moon — albeit an ephemeral one.

headline: Early Voting Is Beginning in These States. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Which states do early voting, and when does it start?
lead_paragraph: Election Day is still about two months away, but many voters have options to cast their ballots before Nov. 5. Some have already started receiving mail-in ballots.

headline: Biden Poised to Approve Ukraine’s Use of Long-Range Western Weapons in Russia
abstract: The topic will be on the agenda Friday as Britain’s new prime minister, Keir Starmer, visits the White House.
lead_paragraph: President Biden appears on the verge of clearing the way for Ukraine to launch long-range Western weapons deep inside Russian territory, as long as it doesn’t use arms provided by the United States, European officials say.

headline: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Ileana
abstract: See the likely path for Ileana.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path for Ileana.

headline: Here’s Why Trump Was Forced to Say He Has Only ‘Concepts of a Plan’
abstract: Trying to come up with a viable alternative to the Affordable Care Act would probably just mean reinventing it.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris exceeded my expectations in her debate with Donald Trump on Tuesday. I knew that she was smart, but for whatever reason, many insiders have questioned her political talent. I assume that her remarkable skill at baiting Trump into one trap after another has ended those questions.

headline: Justice Dept. Charges Two Men in Jan. 6 Assault on Times Photographer
abstract: The pair, brothers, were charged with stealing the photographer’s camera, assault with the intent to commit a felony and entering the Capitol unlawfully.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Thursday charged two men with assaulting a New York Times photographer on Jan. 6, 2021, accusing them of pushing her to the ground and stealing her camera as they participated in the storming of the Capitol.

headline: Friday Briefing: U.S. May Let Ukraine Use Long-range Weapons
abstract: Plus, will Taylor Swift’s endorsement affect the U.S. election?
lead_paragraph: President Biden appeared on the verge of approving Ukraine’s use of long-range Western weapons on targets deep inside Russian territory on the condition that it doesn’t use arms provided by the U.S., according to European officials.

headline: The National Park Service Is More Than Just Its Iconic Hat
abstract: During fashion month, the N.P.S. has had its employees showing off their various uniform options. One ranger in North Dakota has stood out among his peers.
lead_paragraph: The runways of fashion month have had people talking about the boldest designs at New York Fashion Week and beyond, but the National Park Service has been keeping it far more simple — yet arguably just as iconic — by posting videos to Instagram of park rangers from across the country showing off their uniforms with the hashtag #npsfashionweek.

headline: Justice Dept. Official Calls Election Meddling a ‘Clear and Present Danger’
abstract: The head of the department’s national security division amplified warnings that other countries were seeking to sway the outcome in November, including Russia’s efforts to help Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s top national security official warned on Thursday that foreign interference in the 2024 election posed a “clear and present danger” and said that Russia was ramping up its disinformation efforts in hopes of helping former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: The N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Resigned
abstract: Also, a billionaire completed the first commercial spacewalk. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Edward Caban, the New York City police commissioner, announced today that he had resigned. Officials in City Hall had asked Caban to quit after federal agents seized his phone last week as part of a criminal investigation — one of several focused on members of Mayor Eric Adams’s administration.

headline: Attorney General Warns Against Politicizing the Justice Department
abstract: Merrick Garland told the department’s staff that there “is not one rule for friends and another for foes,” amid threats from former President Donald Trump to go after enemies if he is elected.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland warned on Thursday against allowing the Justice Department to be politicized, saying “there is not one rule for friends and another for foes.”

headline: Harris Courts Polish American Votes in Pennsylvania
abstract: Polish Americans are an important, if politically overlooked, demographic. But in Pennsylvania, many have tended to lean Republican.
lead_paragraph: Polish Americans are not an ethnic group that typically gets mentioned in modern American presidential debates.

headline: The Long List of Moderators Trump Has Called Unfair After Tough Debates
abstract: The former president has a habit of working the referees before debates, and then complaining about them if things don’t go as he hoped.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump sought to minimize the damage done by Tuesday night’s debate, selling his defensive, angry and frequently fact-challenged performance as a resounding victory over Vice President Kamala Harris, he resorted to a time-tested tactic.

headline: A Soprano Who Despises Encores Interrupts Her Co-Star’s
abstract: Angela Gheorghiu drew criticism after she stormed onstage to stop a tenor’s encore during a performance of “Tosca” in Seoul.
lead_paragraph: It was the third act of Puccini’s “Tosca” at a theater in Seoul, and the South Korean tenor Alfred Kim, responding to enthusiastic applause, was singing a rare encore of “E lucevan le stelle,” one of the opera’s most beloved arias.

headline: ‘The Killer’s Game’ Review: Catch Him if You Can
abstract: An assassin (Dave Bautista) meets his match (Sofia Boutella), but a diagnosis sets off an absurd chain of events in this rom-com action movie.
lead_paragraph: “The Killer’s Game” begins with an atypical boy-meets-girl scenario. The high-end assassin Joe Flood, played by the bullet-headed Dave Bautista, spies his future love, the modern dancer Maize (Sofia Boutella), as he interrupts one of her performances in an ornate hall in Budapest. The interruption is a violent one: He shoots one of the spectators, and while Joe has the discretion to use a silencer, his prey’s bodyguards get a little loud. In the ensuing melee, Joe winds up in possession of Maize’s cellphone.

headline: U.N. and Britain Denounce Israeli Attack in Gaza That Killed U.N. Workers
abstract: Israel said the former school had become a haven for militants and released a list of men it said were Hamas fighters targeted in the attack.
lead_paragraph: Condemnation mounted on Thursday of a deadly Israeli strike on a school turned shelter in central Gaza, but Israel said that the compound, crowded with people driven from their homes, had become a command center for militant fighters.

headline: Georgia Judge Tosses 3 More Charges in Trump Election Interference Case
abstract: While the judge kept most of the case intact, it was a win for the defendants, who have been trying to chip away at the case.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Atlanta threw out three charges in the Georgia election interference case against Donald J. Trump and his allies on Thursday, saying the state did not have jurisdiction to bring them.

headline: Sean Combs’s Legal Team Takes His Case to TikTok
abstract: As the music mogul faces civil lawsuits alleging sexual misconduct, one of his lawyers is defending him — in the court of social media.
lead_paragraph: The typical playbook for a defense lawyer representing a celebrity facing damaging accusations often features a sharply worded denial, promises to eventually reveal all at trial, and perhaps a strategically placed tabloid pushback story.

headline: New York City to Consider Reparations for Descendants of Enslaved People
abstract: The city joins a growing number of cities and states, including New York, that are taking action to examine the effects of slavery and possible reparations.
lead_paragraph: Almost 200 years after slavery officially ended in New York, the City Council passed legislation on Thursday authorizing a commission to study the devastating effects of human bondage and to develop a plan to make reparations for the harms caused.

headline: Joe Schmidt, 92, Dies; Made Middle Linebacker a ‘Defensive Quarterback’
abstract: A Hall of Famer who played for powerful Detroit Lions teams and later coached them, he embodied a tidal shift in N.F. L. strategy with the rise of the passing game.
lead_paragraph: Joe Schmidt, the Detroit Lions Hall of Famer who played a pioneering role in the emergence of pro football’s glamorous middle linebacker spot while starring on two league championship teams in the 1950s, died on Wednesday in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 92.

headline: ‘Why Am I So Single?’ Review: After ‘Six,’ a Scrappy, Sappy Dating Musical
abstract: The duo behind the Broadway hit follow it up with a meta reflection on finding love online that is relatable and fun but lacking narrative drive.
lead_paragraph: In London’s West End, two lonely singles are feeling sorry for themselves. Nancy (Leesa Tulley) and her gay, nonbinary best friend, Oliver (Jo Foster), conduct a two-hour inquest into their romantic failures while quaffing cheap bubbly on a peach-colored couch. At the same time, they bat around an idea for a musical based on these travails, which — you guessed it — turns out to be the musical we’re watching.

headline: Harris Challenges Trump to Debate Again as She Rallies in North Carolina
abstract: At her first big events since this week’s debate, the vice president said “we owe it to the voters” to have another. Shortly beforehand, Donald Trump had said he would not participate in one.
lead_paragraph: At her first post-debate campaign events, Vice President Kamala Harris repeatedly challenged former President Donald J. Trump to a second onstage clash and sought to use her opponent’s erratic performance as a springboard into the race’s final stretch.

headline: New Hampshire Tightens Requirements for Voters
abstract: The law adds the need for photo identification to cast a ballot and demands that first-time voters show proof of citizenship. The law does not take effect until after the November elections.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire signed a bill on Thursday that creates a strict photo identification requirement to vote, allowing for no exceptions. The bill would also require first-time voters to present proof of citizenship when registering to vote.

headline: Screamin’ Scott Simon, Dynamic Sha Na Na Keyboardist, Dies at 75
abstract: A mainstay and manager of a rock ’n’ roll nostalgia band, he wrote the lyrics to “Sandy,” a song heard in the hit film “Grease.”
lead_paragraph: Screamin’ Scott Simon, who as the dynamic keyboardist for the rock ’n’ roll revival act Sha Na Na paid homage to Jerry Lee Lewis with electrifying versions of “Great Balls of Fire” and “Whole Lotta Shakin’ Goin’ On,” and who played a vital role as the band’s managing partner, died on Sept. 5 in Ojai, Calif. He was 75.

headline: 10-Minute Challenge: ‘The Unicorn Rests in a Garden’
abstract: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.
lead_paragraph: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.

headline: ‘Big Weather Break’ Gives California Firefighters the Upper Hand
abstract: Cooler temperatures and higher humidity enabled crews to gain ground on major fires in San Bernardino, Orange and Riverside counties.
lead_paragraph: After days of fire behavior that officials described as extreme and erratic, Southern California firefighters on Thursday said they were able to gain ground on major wildfires as weather conditions shifted in their favor.

headline: How a Cultural Shift Favors Harris
abstract: People can be bitter for only so long. Harris’s happy strength may offer a glimpse of a sunnier national mood to come.
lead_paragraph: American culture changes with astonishing speed. Nearly every decade, there are shifts in values, fashions and norms — in the whole atmosphere of national life. Sometimes when you’re watching a presidential campaign, it is best to ask: What year is it? What values and moods are dominant in America right now? Which candidate just seems right for this moment, and which candidate is simply out of step with the zeitgeist?

headline: ‘Uglies’ Review: Beauty Is a Beast
abstract: Joey King plays a teenager in a dystopian world where cosmetic surgery seems to be the cure for inequality.
lead_paragraph: “Uglies,” based on the young adult book series by Scott Westerfeld, presents a cheekily vapid solution to world peace: At age 16, everyone is surgically enhanced to be pretty, thus eradicating inequality and conflict.

headline: Antisemitic Ads About Doug Emhoff Target Muslim Voters in Michigan
abstract: An ad campaign in the state, funded by a group that appears tied to Republicans, seems intended to remind Muslim voters of Kamala Harris’s pro-Israel views and her husband’s Jewish faith.
lead_paragraph: The tone of the ad is celebratory.

headline: The First Votes Will Soon Be Cast
abstract: As campaigns shift from persuading voters to turning them out, mail voting is in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: When Krissi Miles, the manager of absentee voting in Tuscaloosa County, Ala., began electronically issuing ballots to military service members yesterday, she was taking a routine step that’s part of a milestone for this election.

headline: Mexico Remakes Its Entire Judicial System as States Back Vast Overhaul
abstract: The plan, championed by Mexico’s president, would have voters elect judges at every level, dramatically restructuring the third branch of government.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s states swiftly moved to remake the country’s entire judicial system on Thursday, approving an amendment to the Constitution that would be the most far-reaching judicial overhaul ever attempted by a large democracy.

headline: What to Know About New York City’s Interim Police Commissioner
abstract: Before being appointed by Mayor Eric Adams, Thomas Donlon ran a security company and was New York State’s head of homeland security.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Donlon, a Bronx native who has an extensive background in federal law enforcement, will become New York City’s interim police commissioner following the resignation of Edward A. Caban on Thursday.

headline: Will Electing Judges Make Mexico’s Courts Better, or More Political?
abstract: A sweeping change would have thousands of judges, from local courtrooms all the way up to the Supreme Court, elected instead of appointed.
lead_paragraph: A landmark shift unfolded in Mexico on Thursday as a majority of its 32 states approved an overhaul of the country’s judicial system. In a monumental change, thousands of judges would be elected instead of appointed, from local courtrooms to the Supreme Court.

headline: Border Agents Made Decision to Confront Gunman in Uvalde, Report Finds
abstract: A report by the federal border agency on the school shooting in 2022 found that its agents lacked adequate training and authority to respond to active shooter situations.
lead_paragraph: Amid two years of painful wrangling over the delayed police response to the deadly shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, the role of the federal agents who finally breached the classrooms and killed the gunman has largely avoided scrutiny.

headline: Trump Defends Debate Performance and Calls for Ending Tax on Overtime
abstract: Speaking at an event in Tucson, Ariz., former President Donald J. Trump called for eliminating taxes on overtime pay as he declared Tuesday’s debate a “monumental victory” for him.
lead_paragraph: Although it had been billed as an event focused on housing and the economy, former President Donald J. Trump spent much of a meandering speech on Thursday in Tucson, Ariz., venting his grievances over his debate against Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Correction Officers Who Failed to Aid Dying Inmate Won’t Be Charged
abstract: Correction Department rules “do not clearly require officers to provide immediate care to people with severely bleeding wounds,” the New York attorney general’s office said.
lead_paragraph: Michael Nieves sliced his throat with a razor around 11:40 a.m. on Aug. 25, 2022. For the next 10 minutes, correction workers at the Rikers Island jail complex stood by his cell and watched him bleed without providing medical care.

headline: Review: Patti LuPone and Mia Farrow Clean Up in ‘The Roommate’
abstract: A Bronx grifter and an Iowa homebody share a house and eventually learn from each other in this Broadway star vehicle.
lead_paragraph: “Expansion is progress,” Sharon says sweetly, parroting a phrase from a business journal for the benefit of her new roommate, Robyn.

headline: Laura Loomer, a Social-Media Instigator, Is Back at Trump’s Side
abstract: The former president’s decision to elevate Laura Loomer, a far-right activist known for racist and homophobic posts online, has stunned even some Trump allies.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: Gets High on a Kite
abstract: Boaz Moser makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: ‘Counting and Cracking’ Review: One Family’s Tale Fit for an Epic
abstract: No theatrical wizardry is needed for this compelling drama about a woman’s journey to Australia from war-torn Sri Lanka and the generations that follow.
lead_paragraph: Some shows use an extended running time to challenge the audience and its perceptions. Pulling viewers into a trance state and testing their endurance is the ultimate artistic gambit.

headline: California Man Assaulted Frontier Flight Attendants, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The violent episode resulted in an emergency landing. The man now faces federal flight interference charges.
lead_paragraph: A California man accused of assaulting crew members and threatening to kill everyone aboard a Frontier Airlines flight was arrested Wednesday on federal charges, prosecutors announced.

headline: Chad McQueen, ‘Karate Kid’ Actor, Dies at 63
abstract: The son of Steve McQueen, he was most widely recognized for his role as Dutch in the hit 1984 teenage martial arts film and its sequel.
lead_paragraph: Chad McQueen, an actor who was best known for the role of Dutch in the “Karate Kid” movie franchise and who was the son of the actor Steve McQueen, died on Wednesday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 63.

headline: Quote of the Day: Will Taylor Swift’s Endorsement Actually Affect the Election?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 13, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Young voters don’t trust a lot of institutions, they don’t trust a lot of traditional leaders, they do trust the people that they idolize.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 13, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about cholera outbreaks around the world misstated the projected production of cholera vaccines by EuBiologics, a South Korean pharmaceutical company in 2025. EuBiologics is unlikely to be able to produce more than 70 million doses of the vaccine, not 50 million.

headline: Former High School Classmates Finally Become Sweethearts
abstract: Austin Mills and Taylor Mills both attended Beverly Hills High School in Beverly Hills, Calif., but didn’t connect until years later at a Los Angeles nightclub.
lead_paragraph: Austin J Mills said he remembered Taylor Beverly Mills, then Taylor Dordick, as “the popular older girl with the quarterback boyfriend” when they were both students at Beverly Hills High School in Beverly Hills, Calif., in 2010.

headline: After a Slow Start, Smooth Skating
abstract: Sarah Botwinick and Jason Pollack attended the same college at the same time, but their paths never crossed. After meeting through a dating app, not even a pandemic could stop their momentum.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Casey Botwinick and Jason Gabriel Pollack were undergraduates at Lehigh University at the same time, though they didn’t meet until post-college, in February 2020, on the dating app Hinge. At first, “it was slow going,” Mr. Pollack said. “It took her a week to answer my messages. I would answer immediately.”

headline: Friends for 16 Years. Lovers for One Night.
abstract: We realized much too late that we were right for each other.
lead_paragraph: “Do you think we would have fought if we’d been a couple?” my best friend Jeff asked me the day before he died.

headline: South Meets North India at an Inclusive Hindu Wedding
abstract: When Dr. Yuvaram Reddy, who had lived in South India, and Chetan Jhaveri, who is of North Indian heritage, chose to marry, their families’ approval was crucial.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Yuvaram Nellore Vilambi Reddy and Chetan Bhasker Jhaveri exchanged pride garlands — six roses in subtle rainbow colors alternating with traditional red and white ones — on Aug. 10 in the grand ballroom at the Springfield Country Club in Springfield, Pa.

headline: After a Life of Competitive Sports, Love Is Now Their Priority
abstract: When Nicholas Scarvelis, who competed in the shot put for Greece in the 2016 Rio Olympics, decided to retire in 2022, he was finally able to plan a future with Noelle Zappia.
lead_paragraph: A fan of Greek mythology might say that Zeus had a hand in the future of Nicholas Scarvelis, a Greek American Olympian shot putter. It was a future where he simultaneously stepped away from his first love of competing professionally to a new kind of love when he connected with Noelle Zappia on a dating app in October 2019.

headline: Pakistan Seemed Close to Beating Polio. Now It’s Spreading Quickly.
abstract: The resurgence is part of a global revival of a disease once close to being eradicated, but geographic and cultural factors magnify Pakistan’s challenge.
lead_paragraph: For a brief moment two years ago, Pakistan seemed finally on the verge of defeating polio. One of only two countries in the world where the virus remains endemic, Pakistan recorded no new infections for a little over a year starting in 2021 — the longest virus-free stretch the country had ever experienced.

headline: Pope’s Grueling Asia Tour Points Toward a Less-Western Church
abstract: The long trip by a frail, 87-year-old pope was seen as a bold endeavor and a muscular step for a global church looking East.
lead_paragraph: Over the last couple of weeks, Pope Francis hoisted himself up on sore legs dozens of times. As he crisscrossed large swaths of the Asia Pacific region, he shuffled from cars to his wheelchair, from the wheelchair to makeshift papal thrones and on and off many planes as hot, tropical winds blew on the tarmac.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: President Biden may loosen restrictions on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Biden appeared on the verge of approving Ukraine’s use of long-range Western weapons on targets deep inside Russian territory on the condition that it doesn’t use arms provided by the U.S., according to European officials. Biden is expected to discuss the issue today when he meets with Britain’s new prime minister, Keir Starmer, in Washington.

headline: Barely Escaping: Video Captures a Woman Staggering Through a California Wildfire
abstract: Officials said a battalion chief was retreating from an evacuated area when he spotted her. The woman is being treated at a burn center.
lead_paragraph: Like an apparition, a woman appears out of an inferno, flames swirling, her hair and dress whipped in searing wind, bright embers skidding along the roadway under her feet. For a moment, it seems impossible that she will survive.

headline: Boeing’s Strike Halts Airplane Production at Key Plants
abstract: Thousands of union members began the first walkout at the company since 2008. Federal mediators said the company and the union would meet early next week.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Boeing workers went on strike on Friday after overwhelmingly rejecting a contract their union negotiated, a potentially costly disruption to the aerospace giant as it tries to recover from a series of safety crises.

headline: The U.S. Military Is Not Ready for the New Era of Warfare
abstract: It is not prepared for the fact that artificial-intelligence-powered autonomous weapons systems are changing the fundamental nature of war.
lead_paragraph: The First Matabele War, fought between 1893 and 1894, foretold the future.

headline: A Long Life, Thanks to Where You Live? Not Likely, Says Ig Nobel Winner.
abstract: An Australian researcher found that many areas that supposedly produce lots of centenarians also produce shoddy record-keeping.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Saul Newman published what he thought was groundbreaking research about “blue zones” — places like Okinawa in Japan and Sardinia in Italy, where many people reputedly lead astonishingly lengthy and healthy lives. These areas have long inspired envy, curiosity and dietary fads. And many scientists have tried to understand how some people can live well past 100 in good health.

headline: North Korea Gives First Glimpse of Weapons-Grade Uranium Factory
abstract: Its leader, Kim Jong-un, visited the factory and urged his country to produce more highly enriched uranium to build “exponentially” more nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: North Korea on Friday revealed a weapons-grade uranium-manufacturing site for the first time, as its leader, Kim Jong-un, flaunted his expanding nuclear weapons program ahead of the United States presidential election in November.

headline: Word of the Day: circumvent
abstract: This word has appeared in 169 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word circumvent has appeared in 169 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 31 in “How Brazil’s Experiment Fighting Fake News Led to a Ban on X” by Jack Nicas and Kate Conger:

headline: Late Night Enjoys Biden’s Encounter With a Trump Fan
abstract: When President Biden briefly donned a Trump hat, he “gave everyone in QAnon a brain aneurysm at once,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a TV Critic Navigates an Age of Endless Content
abstract: James Poniewozik, The New York Times’s chief television critic, discusses the state of modern television and the struggle to watch it all.
lead_paragraph: James Poniewozik has a tough job: He gets paid to watch TV.

headline: The Mayor of New York Is Surrounded by Scandal. Will Voters Really Care?
abstract: Corruption has been a mark of municipal politics for hundreds of years. Tolerance for it has been high.
lead_paragraph: In April, the Manhattan Institute polled 700 New Yorkers across political affiliations and demographics — people who were likely to vote in next year’s mayoral race — asking them about elected officials, crime, immigration and the state of the city. Only 16 percent said that they would choose to re-elect Eric Adams as mayor. Of course, a poll is just a snapshot. A lot can happen in the course of a few months. And it has.

headline: Road Trip
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: In a Transformed Neighborhood, a Funeral Home Finds New Life as a Gym
abstract: The former Scotto Funeral Home, a landmark of bygone Brooklyn, is reopening after a multiyear renovation and Catholic blessing — as a boutique gym.
lead_paragraph: In gentrifying Brooklyn, as neighborhoods shift, once booming businesses can fade away.

headline: Some Gazans Say Polio Drive Is Futile While Israel Keeps Bombing
abstract: Palestinians living with the daily fear of Israeli strikes see a level of absurdity in the international drive to vaccinate their children.
lead_paragraph: As the first phase of a polio vaccination campaign in Gaza ends, the effort has an air of futility, even absurdity, for many families there. They can shield their children from a potentially crippling disease, but not from a far more immediate and deadly threat: daily Israeli bombing.

headline: Stranded in the CrowdStrike Meltdown: ‘No Hotel, No Food, No Assistance’
abstract: Airlines pledged assistance, refunds and reimbursements to passengers whose travel had been disrupted by this summer’s software outage. Instead, passengers told us, they were on their own.
lead_paragraph: Young, old, families, unaccompanied minors, elite status holders, it didn’t seem to matter.

headline: The Mortal American Dream of Alberto Castañeda Aco
abstract: He spent years stitching together shirts, trousers and relationships with the children he had once left behind. It all unraveled on a busy street in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: He was usually there on early evenings, a gray-haired man with crinkles around his eyes trudging east along the cracked pavement of Adams Boulevard.

headline: Tracking the French Impressionists, at Work and at War
abstract: Sebastian Smee’s “Paris in Ruins” follows the lives and careers of Manet, Degas and Berthe Morisot during the Franco-Prussian fiasco.
lead_paragraph: Ever since scandal erupted in 1865 over his painting “Olympia,” depicting a blasé prostitute wearing little more than a black ribbon around her neck, Édouard Manet had grown accustomed to bad reviews. But five years later, he felt that the journalist Edmond Duranty had gone too far. Manet spent the day before their duel looking for, of all things, appropriate shoes. “I can’t tell you what trouble I went to,” he wrote a friend, “to find a pair of really broad roomy shoes in which I would feel quite comfortable.” The clattering fray was aborted when Manet’s sword brushed Duranty’s chest, at which point Manet gallantly made a peace offering to Duranty: his new shoes. They didn’t fit.

headline: ‘The Penguin’ Waddles Onto HBO
abstract: Played by Colin Farrell under pounds of prosthetic makeup, the character anchors the latest superhero series, a bridge between “Batman” films that aims to be more than a mere brand extension.
lead_paragraph: When Matt Reeves was preparing his 2022 film “The Batman,” his sprawling, blockbuster exploration of crime-ridden Gotham City and its hometown vigilante, he would sometimes remark — half-jokingly and half-not — that it really needed to be an HBO series.

headline: One House, One Homeowner and More Than 100 Shades of White
abstract: The neutral can be very colorful, a homeowner learned the hard way. Take our quiz to see if you can tell the difference between shades.
lead_paragraph: As a newbie on my first renovation, I had no idea what I was getting into when the contractor asked for wall color. “White,” I said. “Which one?” he asked.

headline: The First ‘Golden Bachelorette’ Knows ‘It’s a Weird Way to Meet Somebody’
abstract: Joan Vassos, a 61-year-old school administrator and grandmother, didn’t find love on “The Golden Bachelor.” She’ll give it another try as the star of ABC’s new spinoff.
lead_paragraph: There was good news and bad news for Joan Vassos, ABC’s newly minted “Golden Bachelorette.”

headline: Inside Elon Musk’s Mushrooming Security Apparatus
abstract: As threats to his personal safety have become graver, the world’s richest man has barricaded himself behind a phalanx of bodyguards that operates like a mini-Secret Service.
lead_paragraph: The day before Elon Musk spoke at a celebration for Tesla’s futuristic Cybertruck pickup in November, a Florida man, Paul Overeem, was arrested near the company’s Austin, Texas, factory and accused by the authorities of planning a “mass casualty event” there.

headline: ‘Gladiator II’ Delivers Friends, Romans and Sharks
abstract: How the Colosseum, filled with water and stocked with predators, becomes the scene of epic naval combat in Ridley Scott’s sequel.
lead_paragraph: When “Gladiator” was released in 2000, fans and critics applauded its visual effects and production design, from the towering Colosseum to the detailed costumes and prowling tigers.

headline: The Campaign Issue That Isn’t: Health Care Reform
abstract: The topic has been a major concern in presidential elections for decades. Its absence as a top issue now is notable.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump tried to repeal Obamacare in 2017. Kamala Harris proposed a fundamental restructuring of U.S. health care in 2019, a move to a single-payer system.

headline: A ‘Dopamine Fast’ Will Not Save You From Addiction
abstract: A misunderstanding of brain chemistry and neural circuitry has made people believe they should avoid pleasure.
lead_paragraph: In August 2021, while promoting her new book “Dopamine Nation,” the Stanford psychiatrist Anna Lembke discussed addiction with NPR’s Terry Gross. Dr. Lembke explained that the neurotransmitter dopamine is the “common pathway for all pleasurable, intoxicating, rewarding experiences.” The more dopamine an experience or substance releases, and the faster it does so, she argues, the more addictive it is. In her book, she says recovery from addiction requires a radical reset that should often include a “dopamine fast” — basically, avoiding pleasures to help rebalance the brain.

headline: Pedro Almodóvar, Master of Mystifying Films, Wrote a Book He Can’t Classify
abstract: In “The Last Dream,” the Spanish director offers insights into his complicated relationship with creativity and mortality.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Almodóvar is widely considered Spain’s greatest living filmmaker, but he sees himself as a writer first — a “fabulist,” in his telling. His extravagant plots took twists that were hard to predict or even pin down. The tale of two men who form a bond looking over two comatose women in “Talk to Her.” The story of a plastic surgeon who operates on a captive man, changing him to a woman against his will in “The Skin I Live In.”

headline: At 95, Jules Feiffer Tries Something New: A Graphic Novel for Young Readers
abstract: With “Amazing Grapes,” the legendary cartoonist has composed a wondrous hymn to what’s lost and found.
lead_paragraph: At the end of May I found myself on a voyage across the Atlantic aboard the Queen Mary 2, a mere week before the 80th anniversary of the D-Day invasion. Among the passengers were several World War II veterans. Four of them were well over the century mark, and another four were 99. My own grandfather was in Normandy in 1944, so to be traveling with the veterans was humbling, to put it mildly.

headline: China Fines PwC $62 Million for Botching Its Work for Evergrande
abstract: Authorities also imposed a six-month suspension on the local operations of the global firm, which was once a dominant auditor in China.
lead_paragraph: For years, the global auditing and consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers was a dominant player in China, helping the country’s biggest companies reap big gains — and enriching itself along the way.

headline: An Acerbic Young Writer Takes Aim at the Identity Era
abstract: Tony Tulathimutte is a master comedian whose original and highly disturbing new book skewers liberal pieties.
lead_paragraph: There was something distinctly unrelaxed about the way that Tony Tulathimutte, one of the more talented young writers at work in America today, announced the publication of “The Feminist,” a new short story, back in the fall of 2019. “To be clear in advance,” Tulathimutte wrote on Twitter, “feminism is good, this character is not good.” A very online author of very online fiction, Tulathimutte sounded for a moment like an 18th-century English novelist assuring the gentle reader, lest anyone mistake the purpose of his tale, that he had chosen to portray a scoundrel only so that scoundrels might be more thoroughly reviled. These days, when the faintest gust of heterodoxy is enough to start an internet stampede, it may be wise to put some moral distance between yourself and your protagonists, but as Tulathimutte soon found out, it’s no guarantee you won’t be caught in the crush.

headline: Can a Film Find Something New to Say About the Border Crisis?
abstract: “Borderland: The Line Within” takes a surprisingly multidisciplinary approach fueled by both personal history and government data.
lead_paragraph: Some of the devastating information presented in the new film “Borderland: The Line Within” (in theaters) is familiar from recent documentaries. Filmmakers concerned with the humanitarian crisis at the U.S.-Mexico border understand how the camera can draw attention to what news reports and punditry miss: the human cost of government policies and law enforcement practices. Putting faces on abstract numbers activates empathy in a way no speech ever really can.

headline: Christian Conservatives Face Reality: Increasingly, They Stand Alone
abstract: As opposition to their agenda grows, especially on abortion, many conservatives are grappling with how to handle this new uncertain political world.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Sam Brownback, the former governor of Kansas and a champion of socially conservative causes, asked a small crowd of his fellow Christian voters if they were feeling discouraged.

headline: What’s Being Buried on the B.Q.E. This Weekend
abstract: An infamous short section of the highway will be closed while workers install sensors that can weigh trucks.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at why traffic on one section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway will probably be slower than usual this weekend. We’ll also get details on the resignation of the city’s police commissioner after federal agents seized his phone.

headline: The Fight for Control Over the Philadelphi Corridor
abstract: The increasingly bitter dispute has not just affected cease-fire talks but also destabilized a once-strong security partnership between Egypt and Israel.
lead_paragraph: The border between Egypt and Gaza has become a major point of contention in the negotiations over a cease-fire to end the war in Gaza — not just between Israel and Hamas, but also between Israel and Egypt.

headline: Ian McKellen Has Clapped Back at Critics. Now He’s Playing One.
abstract: In the new film “The Critic,” he plays the titular acid-tongued reviewer in 1930s Britain, who is terrified of being outed as gay.
lead_paragraph: In Anand Tucker’s new film “The Critic,” Ian McKellen plays Jimmy Erskine, a closeted reviewer in 1930s Britain who covers theater with equal measures of wit and acid. “Despite her crimes against the theater, she was sensationally gorgeous when drunk,” Jimmy writes of a young actress portrayed by Gemma Arterton.

headline: How Much More Does Harris Need to Say to Win?
abstract: A good debate doesn’t decide an election.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris may have won the debate by baiting Donald Trump. But is it enough to sway undecided voters?

headline: $800,000 Homes in Tulum, Mexico
abstract: A solar-powered home in the Mayan jungle, a duplex penthouse with a rooftop pool and a modern villa with a mural by the artist Jorge Tellaeche.
lead_paragraph: Built by the American sculptor Mikael Redman in 2013 at 1,000 square feet, this contemporary home was tripled in size by the current owners six years later. The property is part of Los Arboles, a gated development of 221 lots in jungle territory about seven miles northwest of central Tulum. Each home occupies a five-acre lot, though to help preserve local flora and fauna, owners are permitted to build on just 5 percent of their land. Fully off the grid, homes in the community rely on solar power and propane generators. Most owners in the complex are from the United States and Canada, with a number of Europeans and Mexicans.

headline: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: After taking hallucinogenic mushrooms, 18-year-old Elliott (Maisy Stella) gets a visit from her older self (Aubrey Plaza).

headline: What a Blind Photographer Saw at the Paralympics
abstract: The athletes’ stories help her understand her own.
lead_paragraph: It is late August, and I’m standing in the beautiful Place de la Concorde in Paris trying to plug an Ethernet cable into my camera. The sun is bright, and I can feel the excitement of the crowd buzzing around me.

headline: How Stump Speeches by Harris and Trump Differ (and Don’t)
abstract: An examination of a month’s worth of rally speeches revealed sharp contrasts in how closely the candidates stick to the script — and the facts.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: Would You Ever Want a Tattoo?
abstract: Or do the price, the permanence and the pain scare you off?
lead_paragraph: Please note: Our Student Opinion questions specifically invite the voices of young people. We ask that adults respect the intent of this forum and refrain from posting here.

headline: Harris and Trump’s Campaign Speaking Styles Compared
abstract: An examination of a month’s worth of rally speeches revealed sharp contrasts in how closely the candidates stick to the script — and the facts.
lead_paragraph: An examination of a month’s worth of rally speeches revealed sharp contrasts in how closely the candidates stick to the script — and the facts.

headline: What Really Matters Is How Presidents Think About Power
abstract: A successful presidency is much more about organization, vision and values than it is the scope of a given legislative package.
lead_paragraph: The American presidency is a strange office.

headline: Affirmative Action Was Banned. What Happened Next Was Confusing.
abstract: Here is what we know about the effects of the Supreme Court’s decision curtailing race-based admissions at selective universities. And why many experts and administrators are baffled.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court ruled against race-conscious admissions, the expectation — based on statistical modeling presented in court — was that the proportion of Black students at highly selective schools would go down and the proportion of Asian American students would rise.

headline: Redefining American Style
abstract: A new generation of New York designers is changing the look of the country.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 10, just before the presidential debate between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump, Raul Lopez of Luar held a show in the plaza of Rockefeller Center. The 100-plus American flags that normally surround the sunken skating rink were replaced with flags featuring the Luar logo, and the designer’s runway ran just in front of the building housing “American Progress,” the famous mural by José María Sert.

headline: When Political Memes Take on a Lie of Their Own
abstract: As campaigns increasingly communicate via meme, cat videos are outranking reality.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with live updates on the Trump and Harris campaigns.

headline: At Toronto, Transcendent Movies Cut Through the Industry’s Gloom
abstract: Films by Mati Diop, Raoul Peck and Mike Leigh, among others, mesh the personal and political in engrossing, insistent ways.
lead_paragraph: Each year at the Toronto International Film Festival, I travel the world virtually, moving through space and time in vivid color and in black and white. On the first day alone of this year’s event, which wraps Sunday, movies took me from Mexico to France, Benin, South Africa, the United States, England and Japan. One gift of an expansive, border-crossing festival like Toronto is that it reminds you there is far more to films than those that come out of that provincial town called Hollywood.

headline: How a Naked Man on a Tropical Island Created Our Current Political Insanity
abstract: Trump has made himself the most hated person in America, and that’s the way he wants it.
lead_paragraph: For those still struggling to understand how Donald Trump could remain within sight of being our president again despite flattering dictators, inspiring an attempted coup, getting convicted on 34 felony counts, vowing to shred the Constitution and imprison opponents, and decorating his bathroom with state secrets, not to mention blustering semi-coherently in Tuesday’s debate, it’s worth looking back to a certain island in the South Pacific, and a man named Richard Hatch.

headline: The Return of Oasis Hair
abstract: News of a new tour put the band — and the rough-hewed hairstyles popularized by its sibling frontmen, Liam and Noel Gallagher — back in the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: For the legions of Oasis fans who thought a reunion would never happen after the band broke up 15 years ago and vowed to regroup only when hell froze over, the recent announcement of a 2025 tour came as something almost life-altering. The news was also a boon for a smaller, though no less passionate, group of rock exegetes: those who track the history of music and culture through hair.

headline: Future of Murdoch Empire Comes Down to a Court in Nevada
abstract: A probate official will hear evidence in a clash between Rupert Murdoch and some of his children over who should control his media companies after he dies.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few weeks, the future course of one of the most powerful media empires on the planet will depend on secret proceedings set to take place inside a domed, Beaux-Arts-style courthouse in downtown Reno, Nev.

headline: The Real ‘Border Czar’ Defends the Biden-Harris Record
abstract: Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas explains what his agency has done to address the challenges at the U.S.-Mexico border.
lead_paragraph: Republicans want to label Kamala Harris as the border czar. And by just looking at a chart, you can see why. Border crossings were low when Donald Trump left office. But when President Biden is in the White House, they start shooting up and up — to numbers this country had never seen before, peaking in December 2023. Those numbers have fallen significantly since Biden issued tough new border policies. But that has still left Harris with a major vulnerability. Why didn’t the administration do more sooner? And why did border crossings skyrocket in the first place?

headline: It’s Time (Again!) for the Emmys
abstract: From “The Bear” to “Baby Reindeer,” our guide to TV’s big night.
lead_paragraph: After two long entertainment industry strikes and a global pandemic, the 76th Emmy Awards are back on their regular schedule and will air this Sunday, just eight months after the last ones. Our reporter John Koblin and TV editor, Jeremy Egner, sit down to discuss this year’s crop of contenders, and grapple with the question: Is “The Bear” a comedy?”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 13, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: End-of-Day Meltdowns Are Not Just for Kids
abstract: But there are ways to avoid them.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a while since I really fell to pieces at the end of a long day. But I know the feeling, and I instantly recognized it when a colleague with young children told me about a concept called “after-school restraint collapse.”

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “The Old Man,” “How to Die Alone” and other TV picks for fall.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “The Old Man,” “How to Die Alone” and other TV picks for fall.

headline: Do You Need a New iPhone? + Yuval Noah Harari’s A.I. Fears + Hard Fork Crimes Division
abstract: Welcome to our 100th episode!
lead_paragraph: Apple unveiled its latest gadgets at its big September event on Monday. We discuss the most interesting new features — including AirPods that can function as hearing aids and Apple Watch software that can help detect sleep apnea — and offer our advice on when to buy a new iPhone. Then, the best-selling author Yuval Noah Harari joins us to discuss his new book and his biggest fears about A.I. And finally, we crack open some criminal cases in a new segment we’re calling the Hard Fork Crimes Division. We’ll explain how one man made $10 million by manipulating music streaming services and how online instructions for building a 3D-printed gun have ended up in the hands of criminals around the world.

headline: How to Watch the Emmy Awards
abstract: The Emmys are on Sunday night at 8 p.m. Eastern, two hours after the red carpet festivities begin.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Emmy Awards.

headline: The Fight Against Three Major Wildfires in Southern California: What We Know
