abstract: This compilation from a fictional ’80s video game company is constantly clever. By comparison, Atari’s latest resurrection effort, Yars Rising, is frustratingly banal.
lead_paragraph: Two recent video games lean on the world’s constant need for nostalgia by refashioning the wistful into something new — sometimes brilliantly and sometimes with mixed results.

headline: Judges Show Some Skepticism of TikTok’s Fight Against Potential U.S. Ban
abstract: TikTok on Monday pushed back against a law that would force the popular video app to sell to a non-Chinese owner or be banned, in what is shaping up to be a landmark case.
lead_paragraph: A panel of federal judges on Monday made pointed remarks that called TikTok’s legal arguments into question, in a landmark case that could determine whether the Chinese-owned video app survives in the country.

headline: YouTube CEO Says Google Faces Plenty of Ad Tech Competition
abstract: Kicking off the second week of an antitrust trial, Neal Mohan testified that Google did what was best for consumers and the ad industry.
lead_paragraph: Neal Mohan, chief executive of YouTube, testified in federal court on Monday that Google acted in the best interest of consumers and the ad industry, refuting accusations by the Justice Department that the company crushed rivals as it became an advertising technology behemoth.

headline: Gallery Owner Sentenced in Fine Art Photography Swindle
abstract: Wendy Halsted Beard, 59, agreed to sell photography prints on behalf of older collectors. She kept the profits for herself.
lead_paragraph: A Detroit-area gallery owner was sentenced last week to five years and three months in prison for defrauding photography collectors out of $1.6 million worth of fine art photos, in what the F.B.I. has called a criminal scheme to swindle older collectors.

headline: For Younger Workers to Get Ahead, Do Boomers Just Need to Retire?
abstract: The pay gap between older and younger workers has widened. The solutions aren’t obvious.
lead_paragraph: Is there a war between the generations in the working world? You might think so from looking at recent data. In many high-income countries, the pay gap between the old and the young has widened. The share of younger workers feeling actively engaged at work has fallen. And a new paper titled “Countries for Old Men” argues that “as older workers enjoy more successful careers, younger workers become less likely to hold higher-ranked jobs and fall toward the bottom of the wage distribution.”

headline: Trump, Using Harsh Language, Urges Democrats to Tone Down Theirs
abstract: The authorities have not provided information about the gunman’s motive in the apparent assassination attempt on Sunday, yet former President Donald J. Trump, who has his own history of using violent language, sought to blame Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Monday morning claimed “inflammatory language” from Democrats had provoked what the authorities are investigating as an assassination attempt against him, urging his rivals to tone down their speech even as he called them the “enemy from within” and “the real threat.”

headline: Intel, Aiming to Reverse Slump, Unveils New Contracts and Cost Cuts
abstract: The chipmaker, which has been struggling, said on Monday that it obtained a new government grant, signed a contract with Amazon and would pause some initiatives.
lead_paragraph: Intel, a Silicon Valley giant that has struggled after a series of stumbles, said on Monday that it had signed new contracts and made further belt-tightening plans as it tries to cope with a deep slump in its business.

headline: Jane’s Addiction to Cancel Tour After Onstage Fight
abstract: In a social media post, the rock band said it was halting its reunion tour after the group’s singer, Perry Farrell, hit its guitarist at a Boston show.
lead_paragraph: The rock band Jane’s Addiction announced on Monday that it would cancel the remainder of its reunion tour in the United States and Canada days after its singer, Perry Farrell, physically confronted its guitarist at a concert in Boston.

headline: How Trump Is Undermining the Economy in Some Struggling Cities
abstract: Immigration to small cities creates jobs for everyone.
lead_paragraph: In another time and place, the Trump-Vance campaign’s decision to go all in on the unfounded claim that Haitians in Springfield, Ohio, are stealing and eating pets might be kind of funny. But given where we are as a nation, it’s no joke. The city has been forced to close schools and public buildings in the face of recent bomb threats.

headline: Suspect’s Self-Published Book Assails Trump, Hinting at Approval of His Killing
abstract: The book, “Ukraine’s Unwinnable War,” calls the former president a “buffoon” and vents anger over Iran, but saves its most vitriolic language for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: The man arrested after apparently plotting to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump at his Florida golf course on Sunday was listed as the author of a rambling, self-aggrandizing, self-published 2023 book in which he appears to tell Iran — and perhaps readers — that it was “free to assassinate Trump.”

headline: Video Shows Arrest of Suspect in Trump Assassination Attempt
abstract: The Martin County Sheriff’s Office released body camera footage of the arrest of Ryan Wesley Routh, the man suspected of trying to kill the former president at Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The Martin County Sheriff’s Office released body camera footage of the arrest of Ryan Wesley Routh, the man suspected of trying to kill the former president at Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Body Cam Video Shows Arrest of Suspect in Apparent Trump Assassination Attempt
abstract: The video, less than a minute long, shows armed law-enforcement officers ordering the man to walk backward toward them and then handcuffing him.
lead_paragraph: A brief segment of body camera video showing the arrest of Ryan W. Routh, the suspect in the apparent assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump at his golf club in West Palm Beach, was released on Monday by the sheriff’s office just to the north, in Martin County, Fla.

headline: Gabby Giffords: It’s the Guns. It’s Always the Guns.
abstract: Political rhetoric isn’t the only problem — it’s access to weapons.
lead_paragraph: After every shooting, blame and rationalizations fly. I know, because I was shot in the head at a 2011 congressional event near my home in Tucson, Ariz. Eighteen other people were shot at that event, six of whom died. In the weeks that followed, there were all kinds of arguments as to why and how that could have happened. To me, only one rang true: Someone dangerous had access to a gun.

headline: How Secret Service Details Are Assigned
abstract: Levels of protection depend on a protectee’s position and the assessment of risk.
lead_paragraph: For years, the Secret Service has meted out its limited protection resources based on the person the agency was protecting. The sitting president and vice president are assigned the highest amount of protection. Former presidents, major-party candidates and visiting dignitaries receive less.

headline: Biden Celebrates Investments in Black Colleges While Promoting Harris
abstract: At a conference for historically Black colleges and universities in Philadelphia, the president tallied up his administration’s contributions to “H.B.C.U. excellence.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden took the stage at an event for historically Black colleges and universities on Monday to promote a list investments and grants made to many of those schools under his watch, including a new $1.3 billion round of federal investments aimed in part at giving historically Black schools a competitive edge in research.

headline: With ‘No Ordinary’ Fans, Sade Night Turns 10
abstract: Fans of all ages slow-danced and lip-synced deep into the night, united by their shared love for Sade, an R&B star who has expanded her audience through social media.
lead_paragraph: Beneath the red lights of the Sultan Room in Bushwick on Saturday night, old and new fans of Sade swayed their hips, lip-synced to “No Ordinary Love” and closed their eyes in dance-floor bliss. Almost no phones were in sight.

headline: Amazon Tells Corporate Workers to Be Back in the Office 5 Days a Week
abstract: The internet giant told employees on Monday that it expected them to return to the office full-time in January.
lead_paragraph: Amazon told its corporate employees on Monday that they had to return to working in the company’s offices five days a week starting in January.

headline: Healing or Hurtful? Police Training Featuring Convicted Officer Is Canceled.
abstract: Kim Potter, who fatally shot Daunte Wright during a traffic stop, had been scheduled to talk to officers in Washington State about the use of force.
lead_paragraph: The presentation to law enforcement officers had an eye-opening title: “Remorse to Redemption: Lessons Learned.”

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Suspect is Charged in Apparent Trump Shooting Attempt
abstract: Plus, why you should binge “Shogun.”
lead_paragraph: A man who appeared to have been planning to assassinate Donald Trump was charged with two firearm counts yesterday in Florida. Investigators said the man, Ryan Wesley Routh, waited near Trump’s golf course for roughly 12 hours before a Secret Service agent spotted him and opened fire.

headline: The Best Recipes We've Ever Published, According to You
abstract: For the 10th anniversary of NYT Cooking, we’ve collected recipes that racked up five-star ratings, topped our charts and went viral — plus a few that lit up the comments section.
lead_paragraph: For the 10th anniversary of NYT Cooking, we’ve collected recipes that racked up five-star ratings, topped our charts and went viral — plus a few that lit up the comments section.

headline: Black Voters Matter Says It Will Spend $15 Million in Battleground States
abstract: The nonpartisan group will mount a voter mobilization effort that includes radio ads, billboards and on-the-ground canvassing operations, with a focus on early voting.
lead_paragraph: Black Voters Matter, the nonpartisan national organization focused on mobilizing Black Americans to the polls, will spend at least $15 million on voter engagement efforts through Election Day, its co-founder and executive director, Cliff Albright, said.

headline: What’s Your Favorite NYT Cooking Recipe? We Want to Know.
abstract: To celebrated the app’s 10th anniversary, we shared a wide-ranging list of the best recipes. Tell us which ones you love most.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 10 years since New York Times Cooking made its debut, and to celebrate, we published Our 50 Greatest Hits, According to You, a collection of recipes readers have loved over the years. There are comforting chicken dishes and simple pastas, tricky baking projects and showstopping centerpieces.

headline: What We Know About the Trump Suspect
abstract: Plus, how FX ruled the Emmys
lead_paragraph: The suspect in an apparent attempt to assassinate Donald Trump was charged today with possessing a firearm as a felon and having a gun with its serial number erased. The first carries a 15-year prison sentence. Here are live updates.

headline: Storm Pummels the Carolinas With ‘Historic Rainfall’
abstract: The storm system produced significant impacts on Monday, with life-threatening flash flooding reported in portions of southeastern North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: The storm system produced significant impacts on Monday, with life-threatening flash flooding reported in portions of southeastern North Carolina.

headline: Tense Teamsters Meeting With Harris Ends With an Endorsement Still Dangling
abstract: The Teamsters president, Sean O’Brien, indicated he could announce as soon as Wednesday which presidential candidate — if any — the union would back.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris held a sometimes tense meeting with Teamsters leaders on Monday, defending the Biden administration’s labor policies against pointed questions and concluding with a promise that she would win the presidency and treat the union fairly with or without its backing.

headline: North Carolina Absentee Ballots Delayed After Fight Over RFK Jr.
abstract: After dropping out of the race and endorsing Donald Trump, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has been fighting in court to remove his name from ballots in several states.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina’s 100 counties have begun reprinting November election ballots and will send them about two weeks late to absentee voters, the outcome of a messy political impasse over whether to remove the onetime independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. from the ballot.

headline: What We Know About the Accused Gunman
abstract: The man arrested after Secret Service agents opened fire while protecting Donald Trump was charged with two federal gun crimes on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. continues to investigate an apparent attempt to assassinate Donald Trump on Sunday at his golf club in West Palm Beach, Fla. Today’s newsletter rounds up what we’ve learned so far about the suspect and the charges against him, how the episode unfolded and how Trump and others are reacting.

headline: Emmy Viewership Rises to 6.9 Million Viewers
abstract: The uptick puts the Emmys among the award shows, such as the Oscars, that have had audience gains in the past few years.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in three years, viewership for the Emmy Awards has gone in an upward direction.

headline: It Was Only a Matter of Time Before Abortion Bans Killed Someone
abstract: Why didn’t a Georgia hospital save Amber Nicole Thurman?
lead_paragraph: It was inevitable, once Roe v. Wade was overturned and states started banning abortion, that women were going to die. Over the last two years, we’ve learned of countless close calls. In Oklahoma, 25-year-old Jaci Statton, sick and bleeding with a nonviable partial molar pregnancy, said medical staff told her to wait in a parking lot until she was “crashing” or on the verge of a heart attack. In Florida, Anya Cook was sent home from the hospital after her membranes ruptured at 16 weeks; she then nearly bled to death in the bathroom of a hair salon. Women in Texas and Louisiana have been denied treatment for life-threatening ectopic pregnancies.

headline: Tony Robbins: Motivational Speaker, Author … Hotelier?
abstract: The self-help guru is joining the hotel mogul Sam Nazarian to open a chain of luxury preventive-medicine resorts, aiming for a slice of the $5.6 trillion wellness industry.
lead_paragraph: The life coach and self-help guru Tony Robbins is teaming up with Sam Nazarian, a hospitality veteran known for brands like the Delano and the Mondrian, on a new luxury chain of hotels and wellness centers that focus on preventive medicine, longevity and wellness.

headline: Suspect in Apparent Trump Assassination Plot Crusaded for Many Causes
abstract: Interviews, records and a self-aggrandizing book suggest that Ryan Routh, a peripatetic builder, saw himself as an influential participant in momentous world events.
lead_paragraph: The man arrested after apparently plotting to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump at one of his Florida golf courses on Sunday appeared to tell Iran in a rambling self-published book last year that it was “free to assassinate Trump.”

headline: Secret Service Admits Not Searching Golf Course Perimeter, Drawing New Scrutiny
abstract: The agency’s acting director, Ronald L. Rowe Jr., praised his agents’ actions but conceded that there was no sweep of the course at Donald Trump’s club that a gunman had staked out.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service did not search the perimeter of the Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Sunday before former President Donald J. Trump began his round, an acknowledgment that has put the besieged agency under renewed scrutiny two months after a similar episode in Pennsylvania.

headline: Suspect Never Took a Shot at Trump but Hid Undetected for 12 Hours
abstract: Ryan W. Routh was charged with two federal gun crimes a day after Secret Service agents fired on him as he pointed a rifle toward the golf course where former President Donald Trump was playing.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of the apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump.

headline: Former OceanGate Employees Testify at Hearing on Titan Implosion
abstract: The Coast Guard’s first public hearing on OceanGate’s fatal Titan submersible accident revealed that the crew had sent a message saying, “All good here,” shortly before the vessel imploded.
lead_paragraph: The Coast Guard’s first public hearing on OceanGate’s fatal Titan submersible accident revealed that the crew had sent a message saying, “All good here,” shortly before the vessel imploded.

headline: There Might Be More Than One Way to Make a Planet
abstract: Astronomers have found evidence of a process that supports an alternative, more rapid approach to planetary formation, more top down than bottom up.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to making a planet, astronomers have long subscribed to what Cassandra Hall, an astronomer at the University of Georgia’s Center for Simulational Physics, refers to as the “bottom up” approach: The gas and dust swirling around a young star slowly clumps together over millions of years, and its gravity shapes it into a rounded object.

headline: Vance Blames the Left for Attempts on Trump’s Life
abstract: The former president’s running mate also said that “censorship” lead to political violence.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, in his first public remarks since the apparent assassination attempt on Donald J. Trump, condemned on Monday the inflammatory rhetoric “coming from too many corners of our politics.” But he took specific aim at Democrats, accusing them of going too far in casting Mr. Trump’s potential re-election as the end of democracy.

headline: Trump Rolls Out His New Cryptocurrency Business
abstract: In a livestream, Donald Trump formally introduced World Liberty Financial, a crypto venture led by two digital currency entrepreneurs with little experience running high-profile businesses.
lead_paragraph: A day after an apparent assassination attempt against former President Donald J. Trump, he appeared on a livestream on Monday to champion his latest business venture: cryptocurrencies.

headline: Sean Combs Arrested in Manhattan After Grand Jury Indictment
abstract: The music mogul has been under mounting scrutiny since a 2023 lawsuit by his former girlfriend, Cassie, accused him of sex trafficking and years of abuse. Mr. Combs’s representatives called him an “innocent man.”
lead_paragraph: [Update: Sean Combs was indicted on charges of sex trafficking and racketeering.]

headline: Still Standing, So to Speak
abstract: Howard Neuthaler makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Ohio Governor Sends State Police to Springfield After Rash of Bomb Scares
abstract: After Donald J. Trump spread a debunked rumor about the city’s Haitian immigrants, schools have endured dozens of bomb threats.
lead_paragraph: Children across Springfield, Ohio, arrived at school Tuesday morning to the sight of state troopers, deployed by the governor after a wave of bomb scares rattled the community.

headline: Quote of the Day: Despite Relentless Russian Attack, Life in Kharkiv Endures Underground
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s war, but no one is going to stop us from living because of that.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 17, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about drug cartels infiltrating Costa Rica’s rainforests misstated Costa Rica’s distinction as a Latin American country without a military. It is one of few countries in the region without a military, not the only one.

headline: China’s ‘Silver Economy’ Is Thriving as Birthrate Plunges
abstract: The shrinking population poses threats to growth but has opened opportunities for businesses that serve seniors.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Li Dongmei operated a series of kindergartens and schools for young children, withstanding the realities of China’s declining birthrate. She finally faced the music in 2020.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A suspect was charged in the apparent shooting attempt of Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: A man who was suspected to have been planning to shoot Donald Trump was charged with two firearm counts yesterday in Florida. Cellphone data indicated that the man, Ryan Routh, had waited near Trump’s golf course for roughly 12 hours before a Secret Service agent spotted what appeared to be the barrel of a rifle and opened fire.

headline: These 14 Undecided Young Voters Are Starting to Change Their Minds
abstract: The focus group’s participants weigh Trump and Harris in the wake of the Sept. 10 debate.
lead_paragraph: The focus group’s participants weigh Trump and Harris in the wake of the Sept. 10 debate.

headline: Meta and YouTube Crack Down on Russian Media Outlets
abstract: The owner of Facebook and Instagram said it would bar Russian media outlets including RT, while YouTube is removing channels it had already blocked.
lead_paragraph: Social media services are intensifying their crackdown on Russian media outlets including RT, the state-owned television network that has come under scrutiny in the United States, saying the outlets had carried out covert influence campaigns across social media sites to manipulate discourse online.

headline: Kimmel Takes Stock of Trump’s Rhetoric After Suspect’s Arrest
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel said the former president, who blamed Democrats for “highly inflammatory language,” was himself “not a calming influence.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: infraction
abstract: This word has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word infraction has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 10 in “A Head-Spinning Debut” by Jonathan Abrams:

headline: Pelosi Blamed New York for House Losses. Hochul Wants Another Chance.
abstract: The New York governor has rebuilt the state Democratic Party to help flip key swing seats in November. But can she stanch her own political bleeding?
lead_paragraph: In the bitter weeks after Democrats lost their House majority in 2022, party leaders searched for explanations. There was painfully high inflation. Qualms about the southern border.

headline: Mapping the Decline of Eelgrass Along Maine’s Coast
abstract: Researchers are studying the role of eelgrass beds for carbon capture and the health of the habitat for a variety of species.
lead_paragraph: A light wind kicks up sparkling wavelets while lobster boats weave among granite islets, with ospreys and a bald eagle soaring overhead.

headline: A Fungus Decimated American Bats. Now Scientists Are Fighting Back.
abstract: Researchers have found several promising ways to thwart the fungus, which causes the deadly white-nose syndrome in bats.
lead_paragraph: Giorgia Auteri is still haunted by what she saw in an abandoned mine in 2014. As a graduate student studying how bats hibernate, she had frequently climbed into mines and caves to observe thousands of sleeping bats hanging from the walls.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Celebrity Endorsements
abstract: Do celebrities have an obligation to speak out about politics since they have such large platforms?
lead_paragraph: Do you follow any celebrities on Instagram, X or other social media? How much do they influence your interests, attitudes or behavior?

headline: Critics Question N.Y.P.D. Shootings After Fare Evasion Stop in Subway
abstract: Officers fired during a clash with a man carrying a knife who was first stopped for fare evasion, police said. Two bystanders, an officer and the man were struck.
lead_paragraph: A 49-year-old man was in critical condition late Monday after being shot in the head by the police during a confrontation at a Brooklyn subway station between officers and a knife-wielding man who they believed had not paid his fare, officials said.

headline: ‘She Didn’t Deserve This’: Husband Accused of Raping Wife Testifies in French Court
abstract: Dominique Pelicot, who is accused of inviting strangers to rape his wife while she was drugged and unconscious, took the stand for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Testifying for the first time in a trial that has transfixed and horrified France, Dominique Pelicot said on Tuesday that he had “nothing but love” for his wife but a sex addiction controlled him, and he couldn’t stop himself from drugging her and raping her, and bringing other men into their home to rape her along with him while she was unconscious.

headline: Modern Goose
abstract: There’s a natural world trapped within our cities.
lead_paragraph: There’s a natural world trapped within our cities.

headline: Get to Know the Misunderstood Canada Goose
abstract: There’s a natural world trapped within our cities.
lead_paragraph: The idea for the short film above came about as a way to rethink the standard nature documentary format. As an editor who often works in this genre, I’ve always had the desire to create a more contemplative and authentic film about a wild animal’s struggle for survival. Here, I tried my best to remove my human perspective from the story and see the world through the eyes of an urban Canada goose.

headline: Trading New York for Michigan and a Home With ‘Fun Pops of Color’
abstract: Many of their friends from Grand Rapids were “moving back home and telling us how great it was.” So they followed suit.
lead_paragraph: When Nick and Rebecca Gray lived in New York City back in the 2010s, they made a lot of new friends. What surprised them was how many came from the same place Mr. Gray did.

headline: Sex, Grief and Psychoanalysis on the Rue de Belleville
abstract: Lauren Elkin’s first novel, “Scaffolding,” traces the multiple infidelities of two Parisian couples a generation apart.
lead_paragraph: The signs were glued on public walls across Paris under cover of night, bold black letters painted on sheets of paper, arranged into sentences decrying a national crisis of violence against women. “SHE LEAVES HIM HE KILLS HER.” “SEXISM IS EVERYWHERE SO ARE WE.” “STOP FEMICIDE.” “WHAT GOOD IS IT TO BE ALIVE IF WE HAVE TO LIVE ON OUR KNEES?”

headline: Connie Chung Signed Off, but She Isn’t Done Talking
abstract: In a frank and entertaining new memoir, the TV newscaster recounts how sexism, and Dan Rather, sidelined her groundbreaking career.
lead_paragraph: The day she was named co-anchor of the “ CBS Evening News” alongside Dan Rather, Connie Chung felt that she had reached the pinnacle of broadcast journalism.

headline: To Prevent Injury, Train Your Tendons
abstract: It’s not just muscles that need training. A little time with connectors like tendons, ligaments and joints can go a long way.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to exercise, muscles and bones are clearly the stars of the show. But to feel your best and age well, you also need to take a little time each week to exercise the body’s supporting cast: connective tissues like ligaments and tendons, especially if you’ve injured them in the past.

headline: The Mother of a Transgender Child Faces Her Hometown’s Hatred
abstract: In “One Day I’ll Grow Up and Be a Beautiful Woman,” Abi Maxwell struggles to raise her daughter in a New Hampshire community that refuses to accept her.
lead_paragraph: Abi Maxwell’s “One Day I’ll Grow Up and Be a Beautiful Woman” is a cluster bomb of a memoir lobbed from the front lines of the transgender rights movement right into the heart of the contemporary culture wars. The battleground is the “idyllic” lakeside town of Gilford, N.H., where the author and her husband have relocated from Montana to live in her late grandmother’s “somewhat shabby” house on a street of “large, expensive homes with professional lawn care.”

headline: 7 Beautiful Places for Fall Foliage That Aren’t in New England
abstract: As autumn sweeps in, where will you go to get your fix of fiery golds and reds? This could be the year to try Michigan or Oregon instead of Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, visitors seeking out fall colors throng to hot spots like the Green Mountains of Vermont, the White Mountains of New Hampshire and the Berkshires in Massachusetts.

headline: An Old White Billionaire Mentors a Young Black Woman in the Art of Philanthropy
abstract: In Rumaan Alam’s new novel, “Entitlement,” giving away a fortune isn’t as easy as it sounds.
lead_paragraph: Rumaan Alam is a rarity: a male novelist who specializes in female viewpoints. The viewpoints in question are themselves specialized. They focus on the bourgeois adventures of New York City up-and-comers, adventures in which universal quests — for family, for a home, for material security, for social standing — are intensified and glamorized by the dramatic particulars of life in the big city. The intensity and the glamour come down, in the end, to money. To survive and thrive in New York, you usually need a lot of it.

headline: Will Lower Rates Unleash a Business Boom? It’s Complicated.
abstract: For corporate America, this week’s expected interest rate cut carries risks along with rewards.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to assume that lower interest rates are a panacea. Almost everyone, after all, is affected to some degree by the cost of borrowing. When the Federal Reserve cuts its benchmark rates — as it is expected to do this week for the first time since the pandemic — that makes credit less expensive for consumers and corporations alike. The cheaper debt means companies can spend more to expand, just as consumers might be able to afford bigger homes with lower mortgage rates.

headline: Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan’s Voice Stunned the World (and Will Again)
abstract: “Chain of Light,” an album of four qawwalis the Pakistani singer recorded in 1990, are arriving after being discovered in the vaults of Peter Gabriel’s label.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 27, 2022, the photojournalist Saiyna Bashir was interviewing the musician Michael Brook in his Los Angeles studio when she learned something that prompted an urgent text to Zakir Thaver, her filmmaker colleague in Pakistan:

headline: Common Ground, and Conflict, Between 2 Stars of Land Art
abstract: A retrospective pairing Teresita Fernández and Robert Smithson shows they share sympathetic, deep engagement with geology and civilization.
lead_paragraph: The artist and writer Robert Smithson, famous for his austere and monumental “Spiral Jetty” unfurling in Utah’s Great Salt Lake, died at 35 in a plane crash in 1973. Teresita Fernández was born in Miami in 1968. By the time she was in art school, Smithson was well installed in the canon as a theorist of minimalism and a pioneer of the large outdoor sculptures that he termed “earthworks.”

headline: Forum 3 | What Issues Matter Most to You? Why?
abstract: What are the local, national and global problems, small or large, that you most want political leaders to address?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the third of our Election 2024 Student Conversation Forums, in which teenagers from around the world are invited to explore their political and civic identities, values and beliefs, and to discuss them with others.

headline: Design Doesn’t Have to Be Polite
abstract: Sometimes homes are best when you can see the rough edges.
lead_paragraph: The search for interior design stories is endless and involves everyone on staff. Although Tom Delavan, our director of design and interiors, finds most of the residences that we publish, anyone can pitch a house story. Often we’re tipped off to an interesting project by a publicist, architect, interior decorator, writer or photographer, but the really exciting ones are those we discover in a more roundabout fashion — few things are more thrilling for us than when someone says, “Hey, I know of an incredible house that you guys might be interested in.” It’s in fact become something of an office joke; whenever any of the editors are taking a meeting with anyone, anywhere, about anything, Tom or I will always remind them to ask if they know of any good houses.

headline: Pastel Clothes Aren’t Just for Spring
abstract: Head-to-toe sorbet hues provide a palate cleanser this season.

headline: House Tour | Espace Aygo
abstract: The artist-roommates show off their shared Brussels townhouse where they made virtually everything, including a sink fixture from a pétanque ball and a tub from urethane rubber.
lead_paragraph: The artist-roommates show off their shared Brussels townhouse where they made virtually everything, including a sink fixture from a pétanque ball and a tub from urethane rubber.

headline: A Derelict Townhouse Becomes a D.I.Y. Wonderland
abstract: How a collective of artists turned a crumbling Brussels building into their own creative playground.
lead_paragraph: IT SEEMS ALMOST inevitable that the most disruptive art experiment in Brussels wound up on Rue du Marteau — or Hammer Street, as it might be called in English. At the beginning of 2022, the French visual artist Salomé Sperling, 25, then in her fourth year at Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, discovered a listing for a 5,000-square-foot, six-bedroom townhouse about 90 minutes from campus by car that came with a 600-square-foot atelier. Sperling and four fellow schoolmates — Jaime le Bleu, 27, Ale Mangindaan, 24, Line Murken, 28, and Sijmen Vellekoop, 26 — decided to create a studio of their own in the house, located in the city’s densely populated Saint-Josse-ten-Noode neighborhood. The fact that the building was derelict and covered in at least a decade of grime, with patchy electricity and no heat, only made them like it more.

headline: A (Very) Belated Donizetti Premiere in South Africa
abstract: The 1838 score for “Dalinda,” which uses chunks of “Lucrezia Borgia,” was found in Naples in 2019. A student company in Cape Town just gave the first staged performance.
lead_paragraph: “Could Donizetti ever have imagined that the world premiere of one of his operas would take place in Africa?”

headline: Why Taxpayers Are Funding Cuomo’s Legal Bills
abstract: The former governor resigned because of sexual harassment charges, but under the law the public foots the bill for his defense.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out who’s paying for the lawyers defending former Gov. Andrew Cuomo in sexual harassment lawsuits. We’ll also get details on calls for Mayor Eric Adams to resign amid federal investigations that have shaken his administration.

headline: I Sang at Hundreds of Funerals. This Is What I Learned About Grief.
abstract: Singing not only helps allow it to move through the body but it alchemizes what grief can become.
lead_paragraph: Since I first started singing as a little girl, I yearned to become some incarnation of Whitney, Mariah and Celine. By my 20s, I was working as a funeral singer, still pining for the big time. In 2004, I thought I had come exceedingly close to embodying the diva trifecta from my childhood — I auditioned for “American Idol” and made the cut from tens of thousands to 200 hopefuls. I told producers that funeral singing was my steadiest gig, thinking that the job would soon be moving to my rearview.

headline: Takeaways From Hillary Clinton’s New Book, ‘Something Lost, Something Gained’
abstract: In her latest memoir, Clinton takes on student protests, foreign policy and even clown school.
lead_paragraph: In four previous memoirs — “Living History,” “It Takes a Village,” “Hard Choices” and “What Happened” — Hillary Rodham Clinton has spoken at length about her political career, idealism, policy positions and, occasionally, her closely guarded private life.

headline: ‘A Face in the Crowd’ Isn’t About Trump. It Just Seems Like It.
abstract: Elvis Costello and Sarah Ruhl’s musical adaptation of the 1957 film, a satire about a hustler turned power-hungry TV personality, hits the London stage.
lead_paragraph: Stop me if you think you have heard this one before: A man gains television fame on the strength of his purported connection to everyday Americans and their resentment of elites, and before long he converts that fame into political influence in a right-wing presidential campaign.

headline: Hollywood Has Enough Fake Accents. Bring Back the Weird Voices.
abstract: David Lynch’s voice is unmistakable — and a national treasure. The world of film deserves more like it.
lead_paragraph: “Something is coming along for you to see and hear,” mewled the filmmaker David Lynch in a video posted online this past spring. The clip was a teaser for a music project, and it caught the eye via the director’s old-school cool — his shades and upswept silver locks, framed in close-up. But it was another bit of business that actually held attention: the jangle and blare of Lynch’s reedy voice.

headline: Phaedra Parks’s Diamond Bracelet
abstract: Currently in “Dancing With the Stars,” the reality television star wears an extravagant Mother’s Day gift — one she proudly helped pay for.
lead_paragraph: Phaedra Parks has raised two lavish gift gifters.

headline: Hamas Is Surviving War With Israel. Now It Hopes to Thrive in Gaza Again.
abstract: Khaled Meshal, one of Hamas’s most senior officials, said in an interview that the militant group expects to play a decisive role in the enclave when the war is over.
lead_paragraph: Israel says it has killed thousands of Hamas’s militants, dismantled the command structure of nearly all its battalions and pummeled its tunnel network. The bombing campaign in Gaza has been so devastating that the urban landscape in the territory has become unrecognizable.

headline: The Weight Loss Hacks That Claim to Work Like Ozempic
abstract: Kourtney Kardashian’s new “GLP-1 Daily” pill is the latest product to capitalize on the weight loss drug craze.
lead_paragraph: There’s a long list of products that companies and influencers claim can deliver quick and dramatic weight loss, just like Ozempic. There are gummies filled with fruit extract, neon yellow berberine tablets, green teas, even jars of oatmeal and rice steeped in lime water. The latest addition to that list: a weight loss pill released this week by Lemme, Kourtney Kardashian’s supplement company.

headline: A Supermoon and Lunar Eclipse Will Light Up and Darken Tuesday’s Night Sky
abstract: Earth’s shadow will partially cover one of the biggest and brightest full moons this year.
lead_paragraph: The night sky on Tuesday will treat us to a partial lunar eclipse during a supermoon. It’s an astronomical wonder that almost anyone in the Western Hemisphere under clear skies can experience, and it’s the latest reminder that our home planet is part of a bigger cosmic system.

headline: 11 Notable Fashion Books Out This Fall
abstract: Iris Apfel, Diane Keaton and Henri Bendel are just some of the style icons featured in the pages of this season’s most fashionable titles.
lead_paragraph: With September comes fashion month, and with its many catwalks and after parties, a banquet of books competing for attention. Out this fall are titles — some opus-like, some minimalist, others kaleidoscopic — on a variety of the fashion industry’s most notable figures and spectacles.

headline: A Wide-Open Oscar Season Begins to Narrow
abstract: After film festivals in Venice, Telluride and Toronto, a slate of contenders has emerged. Still, there are few front-runners.
lead_paragraph: Fall foliage may still be weeks away, but the tea leaves of Oscar season are ready to be read.

headline: It’s Time We Start Naming America’s Deadliest Climate Disasters
abstract: You remember Hurricane Katrina. Why not that lethal heat wave?
lead_paragraph: Heat waves kill more Americans than hurricanes, tornadoes and floods combined. But despite their deadly toll, we rarely treat them with the urgency they demand. Eric Klinenberg, a sociologist, has spent the better part of his career studying the effects of heat waves. In this episode, he argues that to take heat waves more seriously, we need to start naming them like we do hurricanes — a simple, zero-cost action that could end up saving lives.

headline: I’ve Studied the Polls. Here’s Why Harris Isn’t Running Away With It.
abstract: Why it’s too early to join the “it’s over” chorus.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a Kamala Harris supporter, you probably felt pretty good about last week. With Donald Trump’s constant bait-taking during the debate and the endorsement by Taylor Swift, with less than two months until Election Day, on the surface, things have started to look like they’re falling into place for a Harris win. On Friday, I was a guest on “Real Time With Bill Maher,” and Mr. Maher, who has never been one to underestimate Mr. Trump’s appeal, declared that he thinks it’s finally over politically for the former president.

headline: In ‘High Potential,’ Kaitlin Olson Gets Smart
abstract: The longtime star of “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” is a brilliant crime-solving maid in this new ABC procedural.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the actress Kaitlin Olson was in her Los Angeles kitchen slicing a lemon.

headline: In the Trump Era, the Supreme Court Can’t ‘Soar Above Politics’
abstract: Did Chief Justice John Roberts not realize his immunity ruling would be seen as a victory for Trump?
lead_paragraph: Does John Roberts live in the same world as the rest of us? One has to wonder, given how frequently the Supreme Court’s chief justice seems removed from the social and political realities of the country.

headline: Gen Z Has Regrets
abstract: One way to quantify the value of a product is to find out how many of the people who use it wish it had never been invented.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: What the Fed Rate Cut Will Mean for Five Areas of Your Financial Life
abstract: Here’s what the half-point interest rate cut will mean for your car loans, credit cards, mortgages, savings and student loans.
lead_paragraph: The moment consumers have been waiting for is finally here: The Federal Reserve cut its key interest rate by half a percentage point Wednesday.

headline: Corey Lewandowski Was Fired in 2016. Why Is He Back at Trump’s Side?
abstract: Donald Trump often finds comfort in Mr. Lewandowski’s feisty instincts and off-color humor. But some Trump aides worry about his penchant for making his own headlines.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Corey Lewandowski was fired by Donald J. Trump’s campaign for encouraging the candidate’s undisciplined habits.

headline: Zadie Smith on Populists, Frauds and Flip Phones
abstract: The novelist on everything from the “amorphous” self to aging and mystery.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you stumble across a line in a book and think, “Yeah, that’s exactly how that feels.” I had that moment reading the introduction to Zadie Smith’s 2018 book of essays,“Feel Free.” She’s talking about the political stakes of that period — Brexit in Britain, Donald Trump here — and the way you could feel it changing people.

headline: Ukraine-Russia War Updates: Moscow Hits Back in Kursk as Air War Heats Up
abstract: Moscow’s troops have retaken a few villages in a border area that Kyiv’s forces invaded last month and are also advancing steadily in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A month and a half into its offensive into Russia’s western Kursk region, the Ukrainian Army faces difficult decisions over where best to commit its limited forces.

headline: Celebrating a Very Fashionable Middle Age
abstract: Once upon a time the London scene was wild and revolutionary. Now its fashion week is 40. What happens when the wild child of dress grows up?
lead_paragraph: There is a scene in the second episode of the compulsively watchable and entirely self-hagiographic new fashion docuseries, “In Vogue: The ’90s,” in which Anna Wintour describes London as the “place you went to look for the best talent.”

headline: The Connections Companion No. 465
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,187
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, September 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: New Details in the Trump Shooting Plot, and Sean Combs Arrested
abstract: Plus, the boom in Ozempic dupes.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: A Second Assassination Plot and the New Era of Political Violence
abstract: A look at what we know about what appears to be a second attempt to assassinate Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: A suspect was charged on Monday in connection with what appears to be a second assassination attempt on Donald J. Trump.

headline: Our Reporter on Trump and a New Era of Political Violence
abstract: The latest apparent assassination attempt against Donald J. Trump indicates how much the American political landscape has been shaped by anger stirred by Mr. Trump and against him. Peter Baker, chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: The latest apparent assassination attempt against Donald J. Trump indicates how much the American political landscape has been shaped by anger stirred by Mr. Trump and against him. Peter Baker, chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains.

headline: Netanyahu Is Said to Consider Firing Israel’s Defense Minister
abstract: Dismissing the minister, Yoav Gallant, would remove a frequent critic of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at a time of mounting tensions with Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is reportedly contemplating dismissing his defense minister, a move that would help stabilize his fractious ruling coalition but potentially create instability at the top of Israel’s defense establishment at a time of mounting tensions with Hezbollah.

headline: Top Jobs in Brussels Reflect New Political Realities for Europe
abstract: Ursula von der Leyen named her choices for the European Commission as she navigates a host of challenges, including the rise of nationalist forces.
lead_paragraph: Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, announced her new team on Tuesday to lead the European Union’s executive arm, capping a difficult process as she navigates the rise of nationalist political forces and Europe’s shrinking share of the global economy.

headline: Another Blow to Trudeau: Liberals Lose a Long-Held Seat
abstract: The election in Montreal had been seen as a referendum on Canada’s deeply unpopular prime minister, who has faced calls from within his party to quit.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s Liberal Party has lost a Parliament seat it had held for decades in a special election in Montreal, a devastating defeat that is likely to increase pressure on Canada’s deeply unpopular leader to resign.

headline: The Presidential Horse Race
abstract: Taking polls seriously can bring enormous benefits. The past few years have been a case study.
lead_paragraph: The term “horse race” tends to have a negative meaning in politics. People use it to describe an obsession with polls rather than what really matters — issues, policies, an election’s stakes.

headline: An Al Qaeda Affiliate Claimed Attacks in Mali. What Does It Want?
abstract: An extremist group that claims allegiance to Al Qaeda said it was responsible for assaults on a military police school and an air base in the West African country of Mali.
lead_paragraph: An extremist group affiliated with Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for a deadly assault on two military sites in Mali’s capital, Bamako, on Tuesday, bringing a conflict that has ravaged vast swaths of the country to the capital for the first time since 2016.

headline: Portugal Going Through ‘Difficult Days’ as Wildfires Burn Across the Country
abstract: More than 5,000 personnel are battling a number of wildfires, the authorities said, and the prime minister called it an “extremely difficult weather situation.”
lead_paragraph: Sweeping wildfires across Portugal this week fueled by scorching heat have caused multiple deaths, disrupted travel and prompted a coordinated response from multiple local and international governments.

headline: The Rape Trial in France of 51 Men, Explained
abstract: Prosecutors say that, for almost a decade, Dominique Pelicot drugged his wife to rape her, alongside dozens of other men he invited to abuse her.
lead_paragraph: Since the very beginning, the trial in the southern city of Avignon has riveted, and stunned, France. Dozens of men stand accused of raping a drugged woman. The man accused of masterminding the alleged abuse was her own husband, Dominique Pelicot. He is accused of drugging her, raping her and inviting the other men to join him.

headline: Banking Deal Oversight to Get a Major Revamp
abstract: The F.D.I.C. and the Justice Department are changing how they evaluate mergers and acquisitions in the banking industry.
lead_paragraph: In the Biden administration’s final months, regulators are poised to increase antitrust scrutiny of the banking industry as part of a broader push to discourage mergers that the White House sees as damaging to consumers and the economy.

headline: Bank Mergers May Get Tougher to Do
abstract: The F.D.I.C. is expected to vote on more stringent new rules for takeovers, while the Justice Department plans to overhaul its own guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Today could be a turning point for how regulators look at banking consolidation.

headline: Instagram, Facing Pressure Over Child Safety Online, Unveils Sweeping Changes
abstract: The app, which is popular with teenagers, introduced new settings and features aimed at addressing inappropriate online contact and content, and improving sleep for users under 18.
lead_paragraph: Instagram unveiled a sweeping overhaul on Tuesday to beef up privacy and limit social media’s intrusive effects for users who are younger than 18, as the app faces intensifying pressure over children’s safety online.

headline: Instagram’s New ‘Teen Accounts’: What Parents and Kids Need to Know
abstract: The social media app says new privacy settings and features will create more age-appropriate experiences for youth under 18.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of teenagers with Instagram accounts may soon find their public profiles made private.

headline: After ‘a Treasure Hunt,’ a Cut-Up Masterpiece Returns to Venice
abstract: More than 200 years after a ceiling painted by the Tuscan artist Vasari was dismembered and sold on the antiquarian market, it is (almost) whole again.
lead_paragraph: Over 40 years ago, Italian culture officials in Venice began searching for the pieces of a nine-panel ceiling that the artist-turned-biographer-of-artists Giorgio Vasari painted during a 16th-century Venetian sojourn.

headline: A $5 Billion NASA Mission Looked Doomed. Could Engineers Save It?
abstract: Weeks before Europa Clipper was to be shipped for launch, scientists discovered a potentially fatal flaw that might endanger the spacecraft’s ability to study an ocean moon of Jupiter.
lead_paragraph: People at NASA headquarters take deep breaths when the words “First Story” appear in their email. Late this spring, Curt Niebur, the lead scientist for flight programs, received such a message.

headline: Bad Bunny and Karol G Are Most Nominated Artists for Latin Grammys
abstract: These streaming titans earned eight nods apiece for the 25th annual awards, although the Mexican American songwriter and producer Edgar Barrera received the most nominations overall, with nine.
lead_paragraph: When the first Latin Grammy Awards were held in 2000, they celebrated the diversity of sounds from throughout Latin America, and arrived with the hype — and hope — that a new generation of stars would cross over into the American pop mainstream. Among the big names that year were Ricky Martin, Marc Anthony and a rising young singer-songwriter named Shakira.

headline: Burning Oil Tanker in Red Sea Is Towed to Safety
abstract: The delicate rescue mission aimed to head off a major environmental disaster after the oil tanker was attacked by Houthi rebels off the coast of Yemen last month.
lead_paragraph: A Greek oil tanker that was stuck in the Red Sea since it was attacked by the Houthi militia group last month has been towed to safety without incident, the European Union’s naval mission said.

headline: Sean Combs Is Denied Bail on Sex Trafficking and Racketeering Charges
abstract: A day after his arrest, the music mogul known as Diddy was accused of running a “criminal enterprise” that threatened and abused women. He pleaded not guilty.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the embattled music mogul, was denied bail on Tuesday after pleading not guilty to charges of sex trafficking, racketeering conspiracy and transportation to engage in prostitution.

headline: Manchester City Case Could Rewrite Premier League History
abstract: The world’s richest soccer league accused its champion of years of financial violations. A hearing that began this week could tarnish the club’s accomplishments and reshape the competition.
lead_paragraph: After six years of investigations, delays and behind-the-scenes battles, a hearing finally began this week into allegations that Manchester City used a yearslong cheating scheme to transform itself into a global soccer powerhouse and a serial Premier League champion.

headline: Boeing Restarts Labor Negotiations as It Seeks End to Strike
abstract: Federal mediators are helping the aerospace manufacturer and leaders of the union representing more than 33,000 workers who went on strike last week reach a deal.
lead_paragraph: Boeing and its largest union restarted contract negotiations on Tuesday with the help of federal mediators, days after thousands of workers rejected a previous offer and went on strike.

headline: Harris Campaign Says She Will Meet the Press (on Her Terms)
abstract: The vice president, who has granted few interviews as the Democratic nominee, is now ramping things up. But she is likely to focus on local outlets and nontraditional venues where voters get their news.
lead_paragraph: She has hosted a convention, weathered a debate, held her first sit-down interview with a major television network.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Presidential Debate, Emmy Awards, Marmosets
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Kellogg’s Diner Lives On With Jackie Carnesi at the Helm
abstract: The co-owner of Miriam opens Rafael, Brass enlists Jeremiah Stone and Fabian von Hauske Valtierra, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The 1928 original, a classic of the genre, has been reborn. The restaurateur Louis Skibar has put Jackie Carnesi, formerly of Roberta’s and Nura in Greenpoint, in charge of the kitchen. (“I love diners,” said Mr. Skibar, whose portfolio includes a few.) At 37, Ms. Carnesi said she no longer had to prove her chops and could concentrate on a menu notable for approachability and affordability. At the same time, you’ll find herbed mayo and marinated tomatoes in the BLT; guajillo-braised short rib hash, a nod to Ms. Carnesi’s Texan roots; huevos rancheros; and nachos. A highlight on Amanda Perdomo’s dessert menu is strawberry pretzel salad. The design, an updated restoration, is by Nico Arze and Matthew Maddy. (Opens Friday)

headline: $50 Billion in Aid to Ukraine Stalls Over Legal Questions
abstract: U.S. and European officials are struggling to honor their pledge to use Russian assets to aid Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A long-awaited plan to help Ukraine rebuild using Russian money is in limbo as the United States and Europe struggle to agree on how to construct a $50 billion loan using Russia’s frozen central bank assets while complying with their own laws.

headline: The Guardian in Talks to Sell U.K.’s Oldest Sunday Newspaper to Digital Start-Up
abstract: The Observer, first published in 1791, could be bought by Tortoise Media, an outlet founded by a British media veteran that began publishing in 2019.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of The Guardian said on Tuesday that it was in formal talks to sell The Observer, Britain’s oldest surviving Sunday newspaper, to the start-up Tortoise Media.

headline: F.D.I.C. Says Banks Need to Keep a Record of Their Fintech Customers
abstract: Banks holding customer funds for money management apps should keep track of customers’ identities and balances, the agency says.
lead_paragraph: When a banking software company collapsed this spring, thousands of people keeping cash in online money management apps found themselves cut off from their own money for months. On Tuesday, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed new rules designed to prevent that from happening again.

headline: New York Philharmonic Opens Its Season Amid Labor Talks and Troubles
abstract: The orchestra is working to negotiate a new contract with musicians, resolve a misconduct inquiry and hire a new chief executive.
lead_paragraph: On a recent night at Lincoln Center, a group of New York Philharmonic musicians, dressed in matching black shirts and carrying union leaflets, fanned out and began to evangelize.

headline: ‘American Crime Story’ Turns to Sports With Aaron Hernandez Saga
abstract: The buzzy FX series delves into the N.F.L. star who murdered a friend less than a year after playing in the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: The saga of Aaron Hernandez has riveted the sports world and beyond for more than a decade. An N.F.L. star on one of football’s best teams killed a man in 2013 even as he chased fame and glory on the field.

headline: Learning to Connect With Friends — Without Alcohol
abstract: Quitting drinking was the easy part. Figuring out how to be myself was harder.
lead_paragraph: About six months after I quit drinking, I sat at a corner table in a candlelit restaurant with one of my closest friends. It was the kind of place where we used to refill each other’s wine glasses all night, sharing appetizers and intimate details of our lives.

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Pulasan
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Pulasan.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Pulasan.

headline: How A.I., QAnon and Falsehoods Are Reshaping the Presidential Race
abstract: Three experts on social media and disinformation share their predictions for this year’s chaotic election.
lead_paragraph: This year’s presidential election has been polluted with rumors, conspiracy theories and a wave of artificial intelligence imagery. Former President Donald J. Trump has continued to sow doubts about election integrity as his allies across the country have taken steps to make election denial a fixture of the balloting process.

headline: ‘Sirocco and the Kingdom of Winds’ Review: Flights of Fantasy
abstract: Two sisters get transported to a new world and transformed into cats in this whimsical and thoughtful animated feature.
lead_paragraph: You can discover a lot about a fantasy world from its mode of entry: an English wardrobe, a disappearing train platform, a rabbit hole. The means to the phantasmagorical dream world of “Sirocco and the Kingdom of Winds,” available on demand, is as playful and fanciful as the destination: You have to hopscotch there.

headline: Junk Food, High Art
abstract: Noah Verrier’s oil painting of an Uncrustables sandwich sold for $4,999. It looks delicious.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Noah Verrier bought a box of crustless peanut butter and jelly sandwiches from a Publix grocery store.

headline: OceanGate Founder Crashed a Submersible Years Before Titan Disaster
abstract: At a U.S. Coast Guard hearing, a pilot described a disastrous trip in which OceanGate’s founder got a submersible stuck under a shipwreck and then threw the controls at his head.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive who was piloting the Titan submersible when it imploded underwater last year, killing him and his four passengers, once crashed another submersible into a shipwreck and then angrily threw the controls when a tearful passenger begged him to let another pilot take over, according to new testimony on Tuesday.

headline: Presidential Campaigns and Allies Plan $500 Million in TV and Radio Ads
abstract: Groups backing Vice President Kamala Harris have reserved $332 million worth of airtime. Just about $194 million in ads will come from groups backing former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The presidential candidates and their allies plan to spend more than half a billion dollars on television and radio advertising over the final seven weeks of the campaign.

headline: A Look at Hezbollah and What a Wider War Would Mean for Lebanon
abstract: Hezbollah and Israel have repeatedly traded strikes since the Gaza war began in October, killing civilians and combatants in Lebanon and Israel.
lead_paragraph: For months, concerns have grown that the war in Gaza might ignite a second conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, the well-armed militia that is loosely allied with Hamas and based just across Israel’s northern border with Lebanon.

headline: Happy Anniversary to Us!
abstract: To celebrate: a collection of our 50 greatest recipes, according to you, our New York Times Cooking family.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I don’t generally write to you on Tuesdays, but I’m in your inbox today for a particular reason: We’re passing a big milestone. This is New York Times Cooking’s 10th anniversary! A decade ago today, on its first day in the marketplace, I sent out my first newsletter: an exhortation to cook, to use our recipes, to explore the world through food and to make the lives of those around us better as a result.

headline: How a Video Game Shows the Imaginative Potential of Picture Books
abstract: In the Plucky Squire, a young hero fights a villainous wizard to become “the master of his storybook,” says Jamie Turner, the co-director of the game.
lead_paragraph: Video games let their players accomplish many adventurous acts with a few taps of a button. Although one of the richest aspects of a game can be its story, many players skip over that in the interest of completing their quest. But what if toying with a book was the heart of a game — and a bridge between Zelda-like heroics and a reader’s imagination?

headline: Can Milan’s Craziest Fashion Brand Grow Up?
abstract: Sunnei, at 10, has become one of the hot shows of Milan Fashion Week. Can its founders move on to the next level?
lead_paragraph: One of the great mysteries of Milan, the city of Prada, Gucci, Armani and so many fashion Goliaths, is the scarcity of young brands. Sunnei, a self-declared outsider, is a star exception that has shown the Goliaths how to have fun in fashion with inventiveness and irony.

headline: The Republicans’ Dehumanizing Lies About Haitians
abstract: Readers discuss the harm from the lies about immigrants eating dogs and cats. Also: The guns; Americans in exile; the pope and the election; the debates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Read the Indictment in the Sex Trafficking Case Against Sean Combs
abstract: Federal prosecutors issued an indictment against Sean Combs that accused the music mogul known as Diddy and Puff Daddy of running a criminal enterprise that included sex trafficking, forced labor and coercion and enticement to engage in prostitution.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors issued an indictment against Sean Combs that accused the music mogul known as Diddy and Puff Daddy of running a criminal enterprise that included sex trafficking, forced labor and coercion and enticement to engage in prostitution.

headline: Five Five-Star Weeknight Dishes
abstract: Weeknight winners I turn to again and again: kimchi fried rice, hot honey shrimp, and pasta alla vodka.
lead_paragraph: Today is the 10th anniversary of New York Times Cooking, and I have to say — I’m feeling kind of sentimental about it! It’s our little app that could, a dormant recipe archive that not only came to life but has grown into something much more vast, with videos, newsletters, cookbooks and more. The kind of quick, inspired recipes we talk about here in this newsletter have become essential to Cooking every day.

headline: Wildfires Burn Across Portugal
abstract: Extreme heat and high winds have exacerbated deadly wildfires in the country.
lead_paragraph: Extreme heat and high winds have exacerbated deadly wildfires in the country.

headline: Pagers Belonging to Hezbollah Militants Explode Across Lebanon
abstract: Hezbollah blamed Israel for an apparently coordinated attack in which hundreds of pagers blew up simultaneously. The Israeli military declined to comment.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah blamed Israel for an apparently coordinated attack in which hundreds of pagers blew up simultaneously. The Israeli military declined to comment.

headline: Suspect in Trump Golf Course Episode Ran a Business in Hawaii
abstract: In the town of Kaaawa, he constructed tiny homes at cut-rate prices and neighbors described him as a handyman who was often eager to help.
lead_paragraph: In Hawaii, Ryan W. Routh espoused lofty goals to help alleviate homelessness in a state with severe housing shortages and income inequality. His business constructed tiny homes at cut-rate prices, with a goal of providing a modicum of shelter for those struggling on the island of Oahu.

headline: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
abstract: Listen to tracks from FKA twigs, Soccer Mommy, Mustafa and more.
lead_paragraph: Overhead fluorescent lighting. Inoffensively gray waiting room chairs. A finger mechanically clicking the same keyboard key over and over in a strangely hypnotic rhythm. These are all things I will never look at quite the same after seeing the surreal video for FKA twigs’ latest single, “Eusexua.”

headline: For Duckworth, Preserving I.V.F. Access Is Personal
abstract: The Democratic senator has long pressed to safeguard the fertility treatment she used to conceive her children, which has now been thrust into the political conversation.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Tammy Duckworth put off having children to prioritize her military career, the risk of losing her fertility because of combat injuries never crossed her mind.

headline: Secret Service Told Trump It Needs to Bolster Security if He Keeps Golfing
abstract: The agency’s acting director, Ronald L. Rowe Jr., met with Donald J. Trump on Monday in the aftermath of the apparent assassination attempt on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The acting director of the Secret Service told former President Donald J. Trump that significant additional security arrangements and planning would be needed if he wanted to continue safely playing golf, according to three people with knowledge of their conversation.

headline: Iran’s Ambassador to Lebanon Is Injured in Pager Attack, State Media Reports
abstract: The ambassador, Mojtaba Amini, lost an eye, according to two members of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps who were briefed on the attack.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s ambassador to Lebanon, Mojtaba Amini, lost one eye and severely injured his other eye when a pager he was carrying exploded in a simultaneous wave of blasts targeting wireless electronic devices, according to two members of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps briefed on the attack.

headline: With Sandbags and Team Spirit, a Polish City Fought Off a Flood
abstract: Thousands of residents of Nysa, in southern Poland, formed a human chain overnight to pass each other sandbags, building a wall along a river embankment to keep the raging waters at bay.
lead_paragraph: The order to evacuate on Monday afternoon ripped through Nysa, a small Polish city, drenched after days of heavy rains. Some people helped older neighbors into cars as they headed for higher ground. Others raced to the roadside embankment to try to prevent the surging river from overflowing.

headline: Alaska Airlines’ Acquisition of Hawaiian Airlines Cleared by Regulator
abstract: The airlines agreed to maintain some routes and meet other conditions to secure the Transportation Department’s approval of their merger.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department said on Tuesday that it would allow Alaska Airlines to close its $1.9 billion acquisition of Hawaiian Airlines, clearing the way for the first major U.S. airline merger in nearly a decade.

headline: Air Mail, Digital Weekly for the Smart Set, Is Said to Be Exploring a Sale
abstract: The company, founded in 2019, is known for its weekend newsletter of deeply reported features, travel recommendations and shopping tips.
lead_paragraph: Air Mail, the cosmopolitan digital media company founded by the former Vanity Fair editor Graydon Carter, has hired the boutique investment bank Raine Group to explore a sale, according to two people familiar with the matter who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss a confidential process.

headline: The Fires That Could Reshape the Amazon
abstract: Vast, diverse parts of Brazil are burning at the same time, forcing officials to rethink how to protect crucial ecosystems like the Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Large parts of Brazil, a country that holds over a tenth of the world’s fresh water, are on fire. They include vast areas of the Amazon rainforest and the Pantanal, the world’s largest wetlands, as well as the Cerrado grasslands and the Atlantic forests along the country’s eastern coast.

headline: America’s Role in the World Is Hard. It Just Got Much Harder.
abstract: The explosion of wireless devices across Lebanon casts in sharp relief the challenges of U.S. foreign policy facing Kamala Harris or Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve found myself beginning speeches about the foreign policy challenges facing the next president this way: “I want to speak today to all the parents in the room: Mom, Dad, if your son or daughter comes home from college and says, ‘I want to be the U.S. secretary of state someday,’ tell them: ‘Honey, whatever you want to be is fine, but please, please, don’t be secretary of state. It is the worst job in the world. Secretary of education, secretary of agriculture, secretary of commerce — no problem. But promise us that you won’t become secretary of state.’”

headline: Rutgers President Announces Resignation After a Year Rocked by Protests
abstract: Jonathan Holloway was Rutgers’ first Black president. He helped the university grow but also faced criticism and questioning in Congress over pro-Palestinian encampments on campus.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Holloway, the president of Rutgers University, will be stepping down at the end of this academic year, ending a turbulent five-year term in which he both strengthened the university and faced criticism and controversy.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘This Quiet, Handsome Cowboy Would Never Notice’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Mac’s spurs lightly jingled as he walked up behind me to view the golden western Colorado valley below. After four years of companionable friendship, I thought this quiet, handsome cowboy would never notice my unspoken love. I would always be the friend who cheered him at rodeos, introduced to his adoring girlfriends as “my riding pard,” (short for “partner”). But on that beautiful Friday the 13th, as we gazed on autumn’s glory together, horses resting nearby, he wrapped me in his arms and quietly said, “I love you.” Four years of friendship became five decades of love. — Barbara Jean Stratman

headline: Technology That Helped Catch Trump Suspect Is Proliferating
abstract: Use of license plate readers, which helped the authorities swiftly track down the man they said appeared to planning to shoot former President Donald Trump, is spreading across the country.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in the apparent assassination attempt on Donald J. Trump on Sunday was apprehended in part because of a technology that has been proliferating across the country: license plate recognition.

headline: Harris Condemns Trump’s ‘Hateful’ Claims About Springfield, Ohio
abstract: “This is exhausting, and it’s harmful,” Kamala Harris said during an interview. “And it’s hateful, and grounded in some age-old stuff that we should not have the tolerance for.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Tuesday that former President Donald J. Trump’s unfounded claims about Black migrants in an Ohio city were “hateful rhetoric” and “tropes” that had been “designed to divide us as a country.”

headline: Did You Ask Your Wedding Guests to Help You Buy a Home? We Want to Know.
abstract: Forget espresso machines and new silverware. Did you put a down payment fund on your wedding registry? Are you planning to do so?
lead_paragraph: Espresso machines. Pizza ovens. A fancy new china set.

headline: A Wildly Popular New York Taqueria Nails Its Sequel
abstract: Carnitas Ramírez, the East Village sibling of a hit restaurant in Brooklyn, turns out tacos that hark back to the dish’s working-class roots.
lead_paragraph: Long before tacos exploded onto menus worldwide, they were quite literally explosive.

headline: Second Apparent Assassination Attempt on Trump Prompts Alarm Abroad
abstract: There is widespread concern that the November election will not end well and that American democracy has frayed to the breaking point.
lead_paragraph: In the nine years since Donald J. Trump entered American politics, the global perception of the United States has been shaken by the image of a fractured, unpredictable nation. First one, then a second apparent attempt on the former president’s life have accentuated international concerns, raising fears of violent turmoil spiraling toward civil war.

headline: Biden Administration Extends Review Period for Nippon Takeover of U.S. Steel
abstract: U.S. Steel’s chief, David Burritt, expressed confidence on Tuesday that the sale of the American manufacturer to a Japanese owner would close “on its merits” despite bipartisan backlash.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is granting a request by Japan’s Nippon Steel to resubmit its filing with the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States for approval to purchase U.S. Steel, people familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Trump Suggests Restoring the State and Local Tax Break He Once Limited
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s 2017 tax law capped the state and local tax deduction at $10,000. He said on Tuesday that he would lift that limit.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump suggested on Tuesday that he would restore a deduction for state and local taxes, an expensive tax break that Mr. Trump and Republicans limited in a 2017 tax law.

headline: ‘Show Me Your Hands!’: Officer Recalls 2002 Standoff With Trump Suspect
abstract: Ryan W. Routh, who was arrested following an apparent attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump, was convicted on an explosives charge after the standoff in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: The police department in Greensboro, N.C., was on the lookout for Ryan W. Routh. He didn’t have a driver’s license, and investigators suspected he had an explosive device. So when Officer Tracy Fulk saw him driving near the Greensboro Coliseum on a cold day in December 2002, she pulled him over.

headline: Ex-Officer Testifies Against His Former Colleagues in Tyre Nichols’s Death
abstract: A former Memphis officer said he had been angry about a lack of arrests even before he began a pursuit that led to a fatal beating.
lead_paragraph: Emmitt Martin III was already angry on Jan. 7, 2023, his nerves simmering in his first days back on patrol in Memphis after being sidelined for months by a car accident. As a member of a street crime unit, he said, he felt the need to prove he was still a capable officer, and he had yet to make an arrest that night.

headline: Senate Republicans Block I.V.F. Protection Bill a Second Time, Breaking With Trump
abstract: Democrats brought up the measure again to highlight Republican opposition to abortion rights and make the case to voters that the G.O.P. stance threatens access to reproductive health care.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans on Tuesday blocked an election-season bid by Democrats to advance legislation that would guarantee federal protections and insurance coverage for in vitro fertilization treatments, the second time in three months that the G.O.P. has thwarted the broadly popular measure.

headline: Caroline Ellison, Star Witness in FTX Case, Should Receive Lenient Sentence, Prosecutors Signal
abstract: Ms. Ellison, Sam Bankman-Fried’s former girlfriend and a top executive in his empire, is set to be sentenced on Sept. 24 for her role in the collapse of the crypto exchange.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Ellison, a close colleague of the disgraced cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried, provided “extraordinary cooperation” to the government, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday, signaling that she should receive a lenient sentence for her role in the sweeping fraud that led to the collapse of the FTX crypto exchange.

headline: Trumpism, Stalinism and the Tariff Debate
abstract: The spirit of Trofim Lysenko comes to trade policy.
lead_paragraph: Do tariffs — taxes on imports — raise prices for U.S. consumers? There’s really no debate on the subject.

headline: A Trip to Target Caused a Stir. Because the Driver Was 8.
abstract: A missing girl and reports of an erratic driver turned out to be related, with police officers in Ohio finding the girl safe, and enjoying a drink.
lead_paragraph: Target is a popular destination for shoppers of all ages. Apparently, the allure is so strong that it can be worth stealing your mom’s car for.

headline: For Presidents, Golf Is a Refuge. For the Secret Service, It Can Be a Headache.
abstract: Sitting and former presidents must be mindful of when and where they play. Ronald Reagan largely gave up the game after a man took hostages while he was at Augusta.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Reagan had gone to Augusta National Golf Club in 1983 for a break: He would stay in a cottage formerly favored by Dwight D. Eisenhower and play the course renowned as the home of the Masters Tournament.

headline: Yale, Princeton and Duke Are Questioned Over Decline in Asian Students
