lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic, the oldest orchestra in America, has long been one of the most revered. But in recent years, its musicians have been paid significantly less than their peers in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles and elsewhere.

headline: The Fed’s Big Rate Cut Wasn’t Political. It Was an Economic No-Brainer.
abstract: The cut was “jumbo.” The implications are bigger.
lead_paragraph: In one sense, you could say that Wednesday’s decision by the Federal Reserve to cut rates was of minimal importance. The interest rate the Fed more or less directly controls — the federal funds rate — is the rate at which banks lend one another money overnight. And it’s hard to think of any businesses or consumers who will change their plans because the annualized interest rate on one-day borrowing has fallen a half a percentage point, from around 5.5 percent to around 5 percent — which means that if you borrow $1,000, your repayment the next day falls by 1.4 cents.

headline: I Worked for the Fed. The Interest Rate Cut Is Only One Step in a Larger Plan.
abstract: The agency’s bold decision to cut its policy interest rate significantly affirms its commitment to keep the labor market strong.
lead_paragraph: For the last three years, the Federal Reserve has been fighting to bring inflation down. Now it has boldly moved to protect the second half of its dual mandate: to keep employment strong.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week include two substantial new biographies: one a reassessment of Ronald Reagan and his legacy, the other an account of the estimable partnership between the Scottish novelist Robert Louis Stevenson and his American wife, Fanny Van de Grift. We also recommend a memoir of raves and romance gone wrong, a new poetry collection by the virtuosic Paul Muldoon, and fiction from Yoko Ogawa, Ismet Prcic and Laszlo Krasznahorkai. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: Inside the Secretive Facility Housing Migrants at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: Reports and interviews shed new light on the holding center, where migrants’ calls with lawyers are monitored and some say they’ve been forced to wear blackout goggles.
lead_paragraph: For decades, migrants intercepted at sea as they try to reach the United States have been sent to a facility at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a place better known for the U.S. prison camp for terror suspects.

headline: North Carolina Governor Race Jolted by Report That G.O.P. Nominee Called Himself a ‘Black Nazi’
abstract: Mr. Robinson, the Republican nominee for governor of North Carolina, vowed to stay in the race and sought to deny the report, which also said he had defended slavery in online posts years ago.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina, the Republican nominee for governor with a long history of inflammatory and offensive remarks in the battleground state, on Thursday vowed to stay in the race as CNN reported that he had once called himself a “black NAZI!” and defended slavery on a pornographic forum.

headline: We Answer Your Very Specific Restaurant Questions
abstract: Pasta for carb loading, options for first dates, dinner before a concert at Madison Square Garden and more urgent needs.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back, dear readers! This week, we wanted to do our favorite type of newsletter: answering your restaurant questions. We reached out on our Instagram stories and you sent in your queries, from the very vague (“steak houses?” … try Gallaghers!) to the hyper specific (“new, fun dinner restaurant for 8 startup colleagues based in Bryant Park?” … how about Berimbau?).

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Gets 30 Years for Drugging and Sexually Assaulting Women
abstract: The former officer, Brian Jeffrey Raymond, admitted that he had sexually assaulted and photographed dozens of women in the United States and overseas, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former C.I.A. officer who drugged, sexually assaulted and photographed more than two dozen women while he served in various posts around the world was sentenced on Wednesday to 30 years in prison, federal prosecutors said.

headline: A New Lace-Forward Fashion Line
abstract: The London-based women’s wear brand Oiza is expanding ideas of British beauty.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Chichester, a small city in the south of England, the fashion designer Olivia Ozi-Oiza Chance often heard talk of this or that “English rose.” The term — used to describe a pale-skinned, pink-cheeked female beauty — unsettled Chance, who has a British father and a Nigerian mother. “It made me question: ‘Am I beautiful? Am I desirable?’” she says.

headline: Travel Docs Update: Online Passport Renewal and Digital Driver’s Licenses
abstract: New options have arrived, for both U.S. passports and driver’s licenses, that may give travelers more flexibility.or
lead_paragraph: Americans needing travel documents increasingly have digital options that can make the process faster and easier.

headline: U.N. Says Israeli War in Gaza Has ‘Catastrophic Consequences’ for Children
abstract: Israel has long blamed Hamas for civilian and children deaths, arguing that the militant group uses innocent people as human shields.
lead_paragraph: U.N. child rights experts on Thursday condemned the “catastrophic consequences” of Israeli military operations in the Gaza Strip, which they said violated international law.

headline: Alaska Man Charged With Threatening 6 Supreme Court Justices
abstract: It remained unclear whether the man, Panos Anastasiou, came close to carrying out his threats, and public records indicate that he is not affiliated with any political party.
lead_paragraph: A 76-year-old convicted drug dealer from Alaska has been arrested after threatening to kill, drown, torture and lynch six Supreme Court justices and two of their family members, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

headline: Man Falsely Accused Fantasy Football Rival of Plotting Mass Shooting
abstract: Matthew Gabriel, 25, of Philadelphia, pleaded guilty to the mass shooting report made in Norway. He also admitted to a fake report of a bomb threat at the University of Iowa.
lead_paragraph: A Philadelphia man who had a disagreement in a fantasy football group chat admitted that he had falsely accused another league player of planning a mass shooting in Norway and making a bomb threat against the University of Iowa, the federal authorities said.

headline: Anna Delvey Needs More Than a Bedazzled Ankle Monitor to Win
abstract: The former fake heiress let her tracking device steal the show in her “Dancing With the Stars” debut. To survive another week, she may need to show some emotion.
lead_paragraph: The ankle monitor finally had its moment to shine.

headline: Heightened Anxiety in Lebanon After Wireless Device Explosions
abstract: The deadly explosions were an apparent attack by Israel on members of Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: The deadly explosions were an apparent attack by Israel on members of Hezbollah.

headline: How North Carolina Republicans Could Replace Their Governor Nominee
abstract: The deadline for a candidate to withdraw is midnight tonight, but Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson has vowed to stay in the race.
lead_paragraph: A report from CNN on Thursday that detailed disturbing comments that Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson supposedly made on a pornography website message board years ago has raised questions about whether he will remain the Republican nominee for governor in North Carolina.

headline: The Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs Charges, Explained
abstract: Our reporter on the federal case against the hip-hop mogul.
lead_paragraph: This week, the hip-hop mogul Sean “Diddy” Combs was arrested in Manhattan and charged in a federal court with running a “criminal enterprise” that included sex trafficking and racketeering conspiracy. Mr. Combs pleaded not guilty to the charges and is being held in a Brooklyn jail.

headline: Officials Open Criminal Inquiry Into Crash That Caused Pipeline Fire Near Houston
abstract: A vehicle crashed into a gas pipeline valve, exploding into a tower of flame that burned for days. Investigators are now looking into whether it was more than an accident.
lead_paragraph: The city of Deer Park, Texas, said on Thursday that it had opened a criminal investigation into a fatal car crash that caused a gas pipeline explosion this week, resulting in a tower of flame that had burned for days.

headline: Friday Briefing: Israel Bombards Hezbollah
abstract: Plus, French drag is here to stay.
lead_paragraph: Israel carried out dozens of airstrikes across southern Lebanon yesterday, one of the most intense bombardments in the country this year.

headline: Israel Bombards Lebanon After Hezbollah Vowed Retaliation
abstract: Plus, a record day for stocks.
lead_paragraph: Israel carried out dozens of airstrikes across southern Lebanon today, one of the most intense bombardments in the country this year.

headline: Walkie-Talkie and Pager Attacks Set Off a Legal Debate
abstract: Experts are at odds over the question of whether it violates the laws of war to hide explosives in wireless devices that may go off near civilians.
lead_paragraph: The exploding wireless devices that targeted members of the Lebanese armed group Hezbollah this week have set off a debate among experts in international law: Are such attacks legal?

headline: John A. Clements Dies at 101; His Research Saved Thousands of Babies
abstract: He identified the cause of a respiratory condition that was killing 10,000 infants a year in the United States. Then he helped design a drug that slashed those mortality rates.
lead_paragraph: Dr. John A. Clements, a towering figure in the field of pulmonary research who in the 1950s solved one of the great mysteries of the human lung and then helped to save thousands of lives by designing a drug to treat lung failure in premature infants, died on Sept. 3 at his home in Tiburon, Calif., north of San Francisco. He was 101.

headline: 10-Minute Challenge: ‘Canopy’
abstract: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.
lead_paragraph: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.

headline: In War-Torn Ukraine, a Manicure Can Be Its Own Kind of Protest
abstract: A Times journalist reported on scores of Ukrainian women who find solace in salons.
lead_paragraph: I have been known to bite my nails in times of stress, and I got my first professional manicure at age 36. So this year, as I prepared for a new role at The New York Times, the state of my fingernails remained pretty much the last thing on my mind.

headline: How the Robinson Report Could Affect the Presidential Race in North Carolina
abstract: A Democratic presidential candidate has not won North Carolina since 2008. But the drama around Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, the Republican nominee for governor, is sure to bolster their hopes.
lead_paragraph: The newly unearthed remarks that CNN says Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina made on a pornographic messaging forum years ago are certain to amplify Republican fears that his bid for governor there could be a drag on the party’s presidential prospects in a crucial state.

headline: Israel Bombards Hezbollah as Group’s Leader Vows Retaliation
abstract: The Hezbollah leader, Hassan Nasrallah, did not say how his group would respond to attacks on hand-held devices, which killed dozens when pagers and walkie-talkies exploded.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military carried out dozens of airstrikes against the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah on Thursday, one of the most intense waves of bombardment this year. The strikes came hours after Hezbollah’s leader vowed that “retribution will come” to Israel after audacious attacks on Hezbollah’s pagers and walkie-talkies.

headline: Springfield, Ohio, Braces for a Possible Trump Visit, Though Details Are Scarce
abstract: Donald Trump promised to visit the city “in the next two weeks.” Some residents welcomed a visit, but others were opposed, as officials said preparations were underway.
lead_paragraph: Residents of the Ohio city where Donald J. Trump has baselessly insisted that Haitian immigrants are eating their neighbors’ pets expressed concern on Thursday after Mr. Trump publicly promised to visit in two weeks.

headline: Top Georgia Republican’s Texts Highlight the Party’s Deep Divide on Trump
abstract: Messages sent by Lt. Gov. Burt Jones of Georgia, a Trump ally, show the state party’s leadership fracturing in real time after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Burt Jones of Georgia, one of the state’s most powerful pro-Trump politicians, privately shared cutting criticisms of fellow Republicans in the weeks after the 2020 election as he sought to help the former president overturn his loss to Joseph R. Biden Jr., according to text messages obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Dash Cam Footage Shows an 8-Year-Old Driving to Target
abstract: The police in Bedford, Ohio, later found the girl inside the store, and her family was summoned to pick her up, according to the police report.
lead_paragraph: The police in Bedford, Ohio, later found the girl inside the store, and her family was summoned to pick her up, according to the police report.

headline: Nike C.E.O. John Donahoe Abruptly Retires Amid Declining Sales
abstract: Elliott Hill, an executive who left the company after Donahoe’s appointment in 2020, will return as chief executive, Nike’s board said.
lead_paragraph: Nike’s board announced the abrupt retirement of its chief executive, John Donahoe, on Thursday, amid merchandising struggles and a falling stock price. Elliott Hill, who retired from the company in 2020, will return as a chief executive next month.

headline: Tupperware (the Brand) May Fail. Tupperware (the Word) Will Survive.
abstract: The company behind the resealable containers filed for bankruptcy, but the term outgrew its origins decades ago.
lead_paragraph: When Tupperware filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday amid slumping sales and rising debt, the news unlocked an airtight seal of nostalgia for many who fondly recalled Tupperware parties and childhood leftovers. Hearts ached for a brand that was seemingly conjoined with the American kitchen — and working women — for decades.

headline: Goon Squad Violence Leads to Federal Investigation of Mississippi Sheriff’s Office
abstract: The Justice Department will determine if allegations of widespread violence and improper searches amount to a pattern  of discrimination in the department.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced Thursday that it had expanded its investigation into the suburban Mississippi sheriff’s department where a self-described “Goon Squad” of deputies has been accused of torturing people for nearly two decades.

headline: What Teenagers Are Saying About Parents Paying Their Children to Read
abstract: Can bribes instill a lifelong love of reading? Teens weigh in on a recent guest essay.
lead_paragraph: Should parents pay their children to read?

headline: It’s Groundhog Day. It’s Anti-Woke Week. It’s Messaging Bill Fall.
abstract: Lawmakers are forcing each other to take unpopular votes on bills destined to go nowhere.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague Annie Karni takes us to Capitol Hill, where lawmakers staring down a looming government shutdown are focused on other things. Plus, we’re watching North Carolina and digging deeper into today’s new poll.

headline: Trump’s Allies Try to Revive Push to Make Nebraska Winner-Take-All Electorally
abstract: Nebraska could deliver a critical electoral vote to Vice President Kamala Harris under its hybrid system of splitting votes in an otherwise red state.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s allies are resurrecting efforts to change how Nebraska awards its five electoral votes, a hybrid system that could deliver a single but decisive vote to Vice President Kamala Harris from a reliable red state in one tiebreaking scenario.

headline: Quote of the Day: California Mountain Town Residents Defy Risks
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 19, 2024
lead_paragraph: “People want to live with nature, but they don’t recognize that nature is explosively flammable.”

headline: Republicans Try to Block Pennsylvania Voters From Fixing Problems With Ballots
abstract: The Republican National Committee argued that counties do not have the authority to allow voters in the swing state to correct ballots that do not comply with the rules.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee and the Pennsylvania Republican Party are suing to try to stop election officials in the state from letting voters correct technical problems with their mail ballots.

headline: Hiker Is Injured in Bear Attack at Glacier National Park
abstract: Rangers and other hikers helped the man walk more than a mile in a mountainous area so that he could be taken to a hospital, the National Park Service said.
lead_paragraph: A 35-year-old man was attacked by a bear while hiking on a popular trail in Glacier National Park in Montana on Thursday morning, the National Park Service said.

headline: Jury Awards $116 Million to Family of Man Who Died in Helicopter Crash
abstract: When an open-door tourist helicopter crashed into the East River, Trevor Cadigan, 26, and four other passengers were unable to escape from cumbersome safety harnesses.
lead_paragraph: The helicopter flight began with celebration. “All right — let’s do it!” the pilot shouted just before liftoff from the heliport in New Jersey.

headline: Kentucky Sheriff Arrested in Shooting Death of Judge
abstract: The police say a sheriff shot District Judge Kevin Mullins inside the courthouse on Thursday afternoon before turning himself in.
lead_paragraph: The sheriff of a rural eastern Kentucky county walked into a courthouse on Thursday afternoon and shot and killed a district judge in his chambers after an argument, the police said.

headline: Former N.Y.C. Covid Czar Partied While Preaching Social Distancing
abstract: In a hidden-camera video posted by a conservative podcaster, Dr. Jay K. Varma boasts about flouting the public health guidelines he insisted others follow.
lead_paragraph: The official in charge of New York City’s pandemic response participated in sex parties and attended a dance party underneath a Wall Street bank during the height of the pandemic, even as he was instructing New Yorkers to stay home and away from others to stop the spread of Covid-19. He acknowledged his transgressions on Thursday after being caught on hidden camera boasting about his exploits.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 20, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about an extremist group affiliated with Al Qaeda claiming responsibility for a deadly assault on two military sites in Mali’s capital, Bamako, misstated the date and circumstances of the last attack by extremist insurgents in Bamako. The attack was in 2016, on a hotel used by military instructors from the European Union, not in 2015 on the Radisson Blu hotel.

headline: How Trump and Harris Are Courting Pop Stars (Very Differently)
abstract: A discussion about the ways in which musicians and social media stars, both mainstream and more obscure, have figured into the current presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s episode of Popcast, the pop music critic Jon Caramanica and the pop music reporter Joe Coscarelli discuss how musicians, both mainstream and more obscure, have figured into the current presidential campaign, including:

headline: How Israel’s Technological Trojan Horse Destabilized Hezbollah
abstract: The explosion of devices carried by thousands of Hezbollah operatives sowed panic and overwhelmed hospitals across Lebanon. Sheera Frenkel, a New York Times technology reporter who has covered cyberwarfare in the Middle East, explains how Israel planned the attacks, according to interviews with 12 officials.
lead_paragraph: The explosion of devices carried by thousands of Hezbollah operatives sowed panic and overwhelmed hospitals across Lebanon. Sheera Frenkel, a New York Times technology reporter who has covered cyberwarfare in the Middle East, explains how Israel planned the attacks, according to interviews with 12 officials.

headline: Trump Says That if He Loses, ‘the Jewish People Would Have a Lot to Do’ With It
abstract: Speaking at a campaign event denouncing antisemitism in America, Donald Trump again attacked Jews who vote for Democrats, saying that the party had a “hold, or curse, on you.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, speaking on Thursday at a campaign event in Washington centered on denouncing antisemitism in America, said that “if I don’t win this election,” then “the Jewish people would have a lot to do with a loss.”

headline: What an ‘X’ Might Mark
abstract: Jackson Matz opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: ‘Forbidden Broadway’ Review: Let Them Somewhat Entertain You
abstract: From its perch way Off Broadway, the long-running satire slings its affectionate arrows at Patti, Audra and the rest.
lead_paragraph: At its best, topical satire, which is what the “Forbidden Broadway” franchise has been slinging for 42 years, is both timely and well targeted. The timeliness means that audience members know the material being ribbed; the targeting makes sure they know why.

headline: Quote of the Day: Seeking Relief at Recess as Temperatures Soar
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 20, 2024
lead_paragraph: “You plant more trees, you need more gardeners. You put in more irrigation, you need more plumbers.”

headline: When a Morning Person and a Night Person Fall in Love
abstract: Despite differing schedules, Kelly Downey and Gregory Harrington, a celebrated violinist, found a way to make things work.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Anthony Harrington, a celebrated solo violinist, had experienced years of unfulfilling relationships with women he said couldn’t understand his commitment to music. Kelly Cathleen Downey was also fed up with attempts at relationships: Dates, often two to three times a week, typically went nowhere.

headline: A Hollywood Actress Finds a Farm, and Her Leading Man, in the Midwest
abstract: Torrey DeVitto, whose father was Billy Joel’s drummer and mother is Stevie Nicks’s best friend, is a famous actress in her own right. She found love with Jared LaPine in Kalamazoo, Mich.
lead_paragraph: The day after Jared Taylor LaPine graduated from Western Michigan University in 2012, he loaded his car and drove to Los Angeles, his sights set on a career in show business. Eight years later, he was back in his native Kalamazoo, Mich., the glamour of Hollywood thoroughly out of his system.

headline: I Wanted to Crave Him, Not Have Him
abstract: Our intense connection fit no category. Would we be allowed to keep it?
lead_paragraph: One of the most intimate relations in Chinese culture is known as the “zhiji” — the “know-self,” one who knows you like you know yourself. This is a connection outside of any social role, something beyond even best-friendship, like a platonic soul mate. The Chinese describe the feeling a know-self inspires as different from friendly, romantic or familial feelings: It is considered a fourth kind of feeling.

headline: One Week After Meeting, a Bloody Nose and an ‘I Love You’
abstract: Gregory Addicott was on another date when he met Christopher Traina. Six weeks later, they became official and began a “press tour,” introducing each other to their respective families and friends.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Michael Addicott was on a date with another man when he met Christopher Francis Traina on Jan. 6, 2018.

headline: The Conversation That Changed Their Relationship Forever
abstract: When Samantha Rosensweig, who is well versed at lip reading, picked up on a chat John-Jay Pontrelli had with his cousin, she used the opening.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Lee Rosensweig’s job as a senior marketing manager at Bumble feeds her passion for relationship building. “I love people connecting with people on any sort of level,” she said.

headline: Europe’s New Defense Chief: ‘A King Without a Kingdom’?
abstract: The European Union has vowed to enhance its military capability. But money is scarce, responsibilities overlap and the new job is less about soldiers than arms manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: Facing an aggressive Russia, a long war in Ukraine and an uncertain American commitment to Europe, Ursula von der Leyen, as president of the European Commission, has created a new post of defense commissioner.

headline: Olivia Nuzzi, New York Magazine Writer, Put on Leave Over R.F.K. Jr. Relationship
abstract: Ms. Nuzzi told her editors about the relationship that had turned personal, the outlet said. A representative for Mr. Kennedy said the pair had met only once.
lead_paragraph: A star New York Magazine political reporter has been placed on leave after disclosing a personal relationship with the former presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

headline: Harris Hits Core Campaign Themes in Emotional Forum With Oprah Winfrey
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris spoke off the cuff, as guests included a teenager shot at her school and the family of a woman in Georgia who died as a result of the state’s abortion ban.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris harnessed the star power of one of her most powerful surrogates — and one of America’s foremost interviewers — to lay out a pitch for her campaign on Thursday, as she confronted a range of pressing issues during a livestream forum with Oprah Winfrey.

headline: What Peru’s Dictator Left Behind
abstract: Fujimori’s authoritarian streak lives on in Peru, even in those who claim to be against the former leader’s political movement.
lead_paragraph: I was born in Peru in 1992, the same year President Alberto Fujimori announced he was dissolving Congress and suspended the Constitution, performing what was later called a self-coup. He sent tanks through the streets and arrested journalists and his political opponents and assumed full legislative and judicial powers. He turned a democratically elected government into a dictatorship that came to define modern Peru. As long as I can remember, I’ve known my country only under the shadow of Mr. Fujimori and his political movement, Fujimorismo.

headline: Friday Briefing: Israel Bombarded Hezbollah
abstract: Plus, a bright new kid-lit author
lead_paragraph: Hours after Hezbollah’s leader vowed that “retribution will come” to Israel in retaliation for audacious attacks using Hezbollah’s pagers and walkie-talkies, Israel carried out dozens of airstrikes in one of the most intense waves of bombardment this year.

headline: Word of the Day: watershed
abstract: This word has appeared in 168 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word watershed has appeared in 168 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 10 in “Defeated by A.I., a Legend in the Board Game Go Warns: Get Ready for What’s Next” by Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young:

headline: 8 California Firefighters Injured When Their Truck Rolls Over on Highway
abstract: The firefighters were ending a 12-hour shift battling the Airport fire, one of the biggest blazes in California this year.
lead_paragraph: Eight firefighters were injured when their truck rolled over on a highway near Irvine, Calif., on Thursday, as they were ending a 12-hour shift fighting one of California’s biggest blazes this year.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: A Mouse
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: The Migrant Crisis Did Not ‘Destroy’ New York. But Challenges Remain.
abstract: It’s been a year since Mayor Eric Adams made his ominous prediction. City officials should treat the arrival of migrants as an opportunity rather than a catastrophe, advocates say.
lead_paragraph: It was a year ago this month that Mayor Eric Adams announced at a town-hall meeting that the migrant crisis would “destroy New York City.” Since they were first bused from Texas in the spring of 2022, more than 216,000 migrants have passed through New York, though their arrival may not turn out to be the most damning crisis of the Adams era.

headline: Late Night Thinks It’s Unlikely That Neighbors Ate Your Cat
abstract: Before starting rumors about Haitians, please make sure your cat is actually missing, Ronnie Chieng implored on “The Daily Show.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: In Australia, an Old-Fashioned Art Is Having a Revival
abstract: Young practitioners are helping make stained glass, which fell out of fashion over two decades ago, a vibrant art form in Australia once again.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Rowatt, a Melbourne hospitality director, said he was tired of cafes featuring “clean lines,” bars fitted out in “varying shades of white” and restaurants with a “beige aesthetic.”

headline: Prada vs. the Algorithm
abstract: Miuccia Prada and Raf Simons take on the style echo chamber. Fendi celebrates choice.
lead_paragraph: The corrosive effects of our online lives have been pretty front and center recently. So it shouldn’t be a surprise, really, that the subject has reached the runways. Or that it was Miuccia Prada and Raf Simons who took it on most directly in their Prada show.

headline: ‘La Maison’: Like ‘Succession,’ but Better Dressed (and French)
abstract: The new Apple TV+’s new series takes the viewer inside two rival Paris fashion houses, with gorgeous people in gorgeous clothes who will do anything for power.
lead_paragraph: “Does she know our favorite dish is eating each other alive?”

headline: How Much Color Can You Fit Into 430 Square Feet?
abstract: A tiny apartment in London shows that you don’t have to paint everything white to make a space feel larger than life.
lead_paragraph: When Fearghas MacGregor was picking his way through the few, dismal apartments in central London that he could afford to rent in 2011, he looked so miserable that the real estate agent showed him a flat that hadn’t yet come on the market. It was in the King’s Cross neighborhood, an easy commute to his job as a general insurance actuary and within walking distance of the School of Oriental and African Studies, where his American-born wife, Regan Leahy, was studying for her master’s degree.

headline: What Lies Beneath Canada’s Former Indigenous School Sites Fuels a Debate
abstract: Despite possible evidence of hundreds of graves at former schools for Indigenous children, challenges in making a clear conclusion have given rise to skeptics.
lead_paragraph: The revelation convulsed all of Canada.

headline: The Power of a Smaller Breast
abstract: Breast reduction is all the rage in cosmetic surgery. Are women asserting their independence or capitulating to yet another impossible standard of beauty?
lead_paragraph: The women walk into the surgeons’ offices with photos cued up on their phones. Miley Cyrus. Keira Knightley. Bella Hadid. I want my breasts to look like this, they say. They’ve already spent hours on YouTube watching plastic surgeons’ infomercials, on Instagram poring over before-and-afters, and on TikTok, where an army of ordinary women post about their breast reductions. “Ask me,” they say. Whether their nipple sensation has changed. What their boyfriends said. Whether they cared.

headline: An Art Installation She Called Home on the Upper East Side
abstract: The artist Apryl Miller is selling her colorful, full-floor apartment at 188 East 76th Street for $8.75 million. Psychedelic chairs and couches sold separately.
lead_paragraph: The kaleidoscope of colors enveloping the walls, floors and ceilings of Apryl Miller’s home may not be to everyone’s liking. But they served a clear purpose for Ms. Miller, an artist who raised her two daughters in the sprawling Upper East Side apartment.

headline: Natasha Rothwell and Samara Joy on Finding Their Voices
abstract: The “How to Die Alone” creator and actress and the Grammy-winning jazz singer talk about genre, improvisation and romantic comedies.
lead_paragraph: The television actress and writer Natasha Rothwell grew up as an itinerant Air Force kid and started her career in improvisational comedy at places like New York’s Upright Citizens Brigade; she credits both experiences with nurturing her resilience and curiosity. After writing for “Saturday Night Live” in 2014 and then appearing in the 2016 Netflix series “The Characters,” she was hired to write on “Insecure” (2016-21), Issa Rae’s breakthrough Black rom-com HBO series. Rothwell, 43, became better known, however, for portraying Kelli, the show’s frank, sexually free sidekick. She then went on to play Belinda, a disillusioned masseuse at a Hawaiian resort, on the first season of Mike White’s “The White Lotus” in 2021. She’ll reappear on that show’s third season, which airs on Max early next year. And she just finished her showrunning debut as the creator and star of “How to Die Alone,” a New York-set comedy-drama series that premiered on Hulu earlier this month. She plays Mel, a single airport employee whose near-death experience shocks her into living a deeper life.

headline: Remember ‘Frindle’? Andrew Clements Had a Sequel Up His Sleeve.
abstract: More than 25 years later, the pen of another name meets a new generation of wordsmiths.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment in early childhood when pure, wide-eyed wonder turns into a new kind of curiosity. One day a 3-year-old is perfectly content knowing that the sky is blue, and then all of a sudden they desperately need to know why.

headline: On an Italian Island, a Home That Celebrates Color and Craft
abstract: Atop the volcanic cliffs on the tranquil Salina, one woman has created a respite where art and nature reside in perfect harmony.
lead_paragraph: ON SALINA, THE second largest and most verdant of the seven Aeolian islands, change comes slowly, if at all. The volcanic archipelago off the northern coast of Sicily is a UNESCO World Heritage site but, even without that designation, which places a ban on things like new construction and painting houses a color other than white, Salina might idle forever, quietly serene and proudly inaccessible.

headline: I Have Studied Social Mobility for Years. Here’s How Kamala Harris Can Build an ‘Opportunity Economy.’
abstract: What we can learn from the science of economic opportunity.
lead_paragraph: At the start of her debate with Donald Trump, Kamala Harris spoke about building an “opportunity economy.” What does that mean, and how can we create one?

headline: A Concert Celebrates Jimmy Carter’s 100th Birthday, With Music and Thanks
abstract: The B-52’s, BeBe Winans, Angélique Kidjo, Chuck Leavell and many others performed in Atlanta at a concert honoring the former president, who has been in hospice care.
lead_paragraph: The night included gospel hymns and “America the Beautiful” and the B-52’s lighting up the Fox Theater, one of the oldest auditoriums in Atlanta, with a performance of “Love Shack.” In one moment, the crowd was on its feet as Angélique Kidjo, the acclaimed Beninese musician, sang and danced. In another, they shimmied and sang along to a cover of “Ramblin’ Man.”

headline: When the Horror Is Coming From Under Your Own Skin
abstract: As “The Substance” hits theaters, here’s a look at eight other films in the goopy subgenre of body horror.
lead_paragraph: In some scary movies, the sources of horror are closer than in your town or even in your house — they’re in your very own skin.

headline: Who’s the Dodo Now? A Famously Extinct Bird, Reconsidered.
abstract: A comprehensive review of dodo science offers new insights into the biology and behavior of the much-ridiculed bird.
lead_paragraph: The dodo was a flightless bird about the size of a male turkey that had a long, hooked beak and the goofy charm of an emperor penguin. Its ancestor first appeared on Earth more than 25 million years ago, and by 1662, because of humans, it had vanished from Mauritius, a remote island in the Indian Ocean, the only place it ever existed.

headline: How the Fastest-Growing County in Wisconsin Is Scrambling the Presidential Race
abstract: Madison, Wis., and its blossoming suburbs are drawing newcomers for tech and health care jobs. With a swing state in the balance, Democrats see promise.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Patricia Field: Her Joyful, Chaotic Fashion Sense Gets a Film to Match
abstract: “Happy Clothes” covers her work on “Emily in Paris” and “Sex and the City,” as well as her time as a tastemaker in the 1970s and ’80s underground.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Field likes, as she puts it, “happy clothes.” If you’ve seen her work, you get it; if you’ve watched TV, you have probably seen her work. The fashion maven is one of the most celebrated and influential costume designers of the past three decades, with “Emily in Paris,” “The Devil Wears Prada” and “Sex and the City” among her credits. Michael Selditch’s new documentary, “Happy Clothes: A Film About Patricia Field” (in theaters and on demand), follows Field as she works on the second season of the Starz comedy “Run the World,” but the feature is really a celebration of her long career.

headline: Natasha Lyonne Is a Boss (a Boss Trying to Stop Time)
abstract: Amid Oscar talk for her quiet turn in “His Three Daughters” on Netflix, the spitfire star has become a force as a producer driven by a sense of mortality.
lead_paragraph: Natasha Lyonne has her funeral all planned out.

headline: These Artists Live in a Homeless Shelter
abstract: A gallery in a shelter near the Brooklyn Navy Yard is showcasing the work of two migrants. One of them did some of his paintings under the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at an unusual art show in Brooklyn. We’ll also look at how short trips on Citi Bikes brought in big money for some riders.

headline: What’s Your Friendship Style?
abstract: Are you a firefly, an evergreen, a butterfly or a wallflower? This quiz can help you find out.
lead_paragraph: When you host a birthday party, are you the type of person to invite everyone you know? Or do you keep it to only a few close friends?

headline: Israel vs. Hamas, Hezbollah, Iran — and Itself
abstract: David Remnick discusses Israel’s overlapping conflicts after nearly a year of war.
lead_paragraph: David Remnick discusses Israel’s overlapping conflicts after nearly a year of war.

headline: Israel vs. Hamas, Hezbollah, Iran — and Itself
abstract: David Remnick discusses Israel’s overlapping conflicts after nearly a year of war.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost a year since Oct. 7. More than 40,000 Palestinians in Gaza are dead. The hostages are not all home, and it doesn’t look like there will be a cease-fire deal that brings them home anytime soon. Israeli politics is deeply divided, and the country’s international reputation is in tatters. The Palestinian Authority is weak. A war may break out in Lebanon soon. There is no vision for the day after and no theory of what comes next.

headline: $2.4 Million Homes in Queensland, Australia
abstract: The eastern Australian state with more than 4,000 miles of coastland offers renovated waterfront apartments, federation-style houses and rural multi-acre estates.
lead_paragraph: This sprawling five-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house sits on six acres in Eumundi, a rural town of 2,500 in the Noosa Hinterland of Queensland’s Suncoast Region. Historically an agricultural area, Eumundi still has original buildings from the 1800s. These days, it’s known for the artisanal Eumundi market — the largest in Australia, with more than 600 kiosks selling handmade, hand-sewn, home-baked and homegrown products.

headline: Take It From a Scientist. Facts Matter, and They Don’t Care How You Feel.
abstract: I am deeply troubled by the growing distrust of science in our society, just when its insights are most needed.
lead_paragraph: I am a physician and a scientist. Over 12 years, I had the privilege of serving Presidents Barack Obama, Donald Trump and Joe Biden as the director of the National Institutes of Health. Before that, I led the U.S. component of the Human Genome Project.

headline: From the Tetons to the Caribbean, 6 Getaways for Grown-Ups
abstract: We found new and revamped adults-only hotels and resorts for those who want to get away from it all.
lead_paragraph: If a hotel full of children is not your idea of a vacation, why not try a getaway just for grown-ups? From posh city hotels to tropical resorts, these new and recently expanded adults-only escapes beckon solo travelers, couples and friends with nature hikes, classes like pottery and macramé, spa treatments, tequila tastings and perhaps the greatest luxury of all: peace and quiet.

headline: Fine, Let’s Do What JD Vance Wants: Talk About Immigration
abstract: Yes, we need a debate over broken immigration policies. But is this really it?
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and JD Vance have sparked panic over immigration in Springfield, Ohio. This week, the hosts talk about why our country’s immigration debate is now focused on a distraction instead of the core of the issue.

headline: Now That Rates Are Falling, Let’s Turn to Other Matters
abstract: The Federal Reserve has at last cut interest rates but our columnist points out a host of concerns that could weigh on financial markets.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has started cutting interest rates at long last, and it’s a relief that financial conditions in the United States will be easing. But it’s far too early to celebrate.

headline: 11 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Edward (Sebastian Stan), a man with a condition that warps his facial features, discovers his problems are internal after he gets cosmetic surgery and meets another man, Oswald (Adam Pearson), who has the same condition in this dark comedy written and directed by Aaron Schimberg.

headline: The Trump Guide to Civil Discourse
abstract: “Their rhetoric is causing me to be shot at.”
lead_paragraph: The classic example of chutzpah is that of the child who murders his parents and then pleads for mercy as an orphan. With the 2024 presidential election, we have a new way to illustrate the point: the candidate who condones violence, dehumanizes his opponents and whips his supporters into a frenzy, then turns around to condemn the harsh rhetoric of his opponents and call for peaceful discourse.

headline: Pat Field: Do What You Love, and You Will Make Things Happen
abstract: The costume designer of “Sex and the City” and “The Devil Wears Prada,” now 82, still heeds her family’s advice.
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Patricia Field explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.

headline: The Strange Afterlife of Tucker Carlson
abstract: A year after leaving Fox News, Carlson has figured out how to exercise power and influence in less public ways.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night in Hershey, Pa., JD Vance will participate in one of the more unusual political events of this presidential campaign. Several thousand people — almost all of whom have paid for the privilege, some as much as $1,600 — will pack into a hockey arena to watch the former Fox News host Tucker Carlson interview Mr. Vance, the Republican Party’s vice-presidential nominee.

headline: Harris, With an Online Avalanche, Outspends Trump by Tens of Millions
abstract: The week of their debate, Kamala Harris outspent Donald Trump by 20 to 1 on Facebook and Instagram. It was just one sign of how uneven their online advertising battle has become.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: When the Only Screens Were Big
abstract: A massive, two-volume coffee table book revisits the heyday of classic Hollywood glamour as seen in Life magazine.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most famous images of midcentury American history — Robert Capa’s dispatches from D-Day, a sailor and a nurse entangled in a V-J Day kiss, Robert F. Kennedy lying mortally wounded on the floor of a California hotel kitchen — first appeared in Life magazine.

headline: I’m the Republican Governor of Ohio. Here Is the Truth About Springfield.
abstract: I have lived my entire life near this city. Our people and our history deserve better than to be falsely portrayed.
lead_paragraph: I was born in Springfield, Ohio. My wife, Fran, and I have lived our entire lives less than 10 miles from this city.

headline: At Funerals and in Hospitals, Talk of Revenge for Pager Attacks
abstract: After two days of exploding pagers and walkie-talkies, Beirut was a city on edge, with people worried there were bombs in their bags or pockets. Victims’ relatives vowed retribution.
lead_paragraph: In the waiting rooms of a Beirut hospital, exhausted families slumped on couches, waited anxiously for doctors’ updates and wept. Nearby rooms held their loved ones, injured when pagers and walkie-talkies used by Hezbollah suddenly exploded across Lebanon this week, blinding and maiming many of their owners.

headline: Can Young Chefs Save the New York Diner?
abstract: Across New York City, younger chefs are tweaking the menus, prices and interiors of diners on the brink, but not too much else.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Jackie Carnesi received an unusual proposal. Would she be willing to leave her job as the executive chef of a popular Brooklyn restaurant to work in a nearly century-old New York City diner?

headline: Trump and Harris Enter the Final Sprint
abstract: With Election Day just six weeks away, Maggie Haberman, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, surveys the state of the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day just six weeks away, Maggie Haberman, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, surveys the state of the presidential campaign.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “The Substance,” a Hollywood satire starring Demi Moore and Margaret Qualley.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “The Substance,” a Hollywood satire starring Demi Moore and Margaret Qualley.

headline: What Trump Did to the G.O.P., Musk Did to Twitter
abstract: It’s more toxic but less relevant than ever.
lead_paragraph: There are many damning anecdotes in Kate Conger and Ryan Mac’s new book, “Character Limit: How Elon Musk Destroyed Twitter,” but one from February of last year perfectly captures the astonishing pettiness of the world’s richest man.

headline: Biden Will Take Cancer ‘Moonshot’ Global at Summit in Delaware
abstract: The president will join the leaders of Australia, India and Japan to announce a new initiative for reducing cervical cancer in the Indo-Pacific, a region with especially high rates of the disease.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, who is winding down his term and his life on the world stage, is taking one of his most prized personal initiatives — the cancer “moonshot” program — global.

headline: OpenAI’s Reasoning Machine, Instagram Teen Changes and Amazon R.T.O. Drama
abstract: “They should have just called it Strawberry. At least that’s delicious.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, OpenAI released a preview of its hotly anticipated new model, o1. We discuss what it has excelled at and how it could accelerate the timeline for building superintelligence. Then, we explain why Meta is making teenagers’ Instagram accounts private by default. And, finally, we chat with the New York Times reporter Karen Weise about why Amazon is forcing its corporate employees to go back to working in the office five days a week and whether other companies will follow suit.

headline: Don’t Fall Into the ‘Cynicism Trap’
abstract: Expecting the worst from others is actually bad for our health, experts say.
lead_paragraph: There are days when the world brings out our sardonic side.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 20, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 468
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Sept. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,190
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Six Weeks to Go
abstract: Our colleagues on the politics desk discuss the state of the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential race enters its final 45 days, we assemble a campaign round table with our colleagues from the politics desk.

headline: Harris Outspends Trump in Ad Battle, and Israel Bombards Hezbollah
abstract: Plus, an iconic kitchen brand files for bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: With $39 Billion Loan for Ukraine, Europe Moves Ahead Without U.S.
abstract: Plans for a larger sum collapsed when Hungary blocked changes requested by Washington as the price for a joint initiative.
lead_paragraph: The European Union’s top official said on a trip to Kyiv on Friday that Europe would offer Ukraine a loan of 35 billion euros, about $39 billion, backed by frozen Russian assets. European leaders said the loan would move forward initially without contributions from the United States, after talks between American and European officials stalled in recent days.

headline: A North Korean Trash Balloon Hits a Seoul Government Compound, Again
abstract: Debris was found more than a day after the North’s latest balloon launch. South Korea says it’s essentially impossible to track every balloon.
lead_paragraph: Trash from a balloon sent by North Korea was found in a government complex in Seoul on Friday morning, more than a day after one of the North’s balloon launches was last detected, adding to concerns about South Korea’s potential vulnerability to the provocative new tactic.

headline: A Surge in Breast Reductions
abstract: We explore why younger women are undergoing the cosmetic procedure.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is cyclical, and so are fashionable body types. Katharine Hepburn gave way to Marilyn Monroe, who gave way to Twiggy. Madonna was overtaken by Kate Moss. Then Kardashian voluptuousness blew up heroin chic. But when Stella Bugbee, the editor of the Times’s Styles section, pointed me to data showing a 64 percent surge in elective breast-reduction surgeries since 2019, we both knew this was more than a fad.

headline: ‘Transformers One’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Josh Cooley narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The director Josh Cooley narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: How Optimus Prime and Megatron Learned to Transform in ‘Transformers One’
abstract: The director Josh Cooley narrates an action scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Three Mile Island Plans to Reopen as Demand for Nuclear Power Grows
abstract: The infamous plant, closed since 2019, is getting a new lease on life after Microsoft agreed to buy its electricity to supply a growing fleet of data centers.
lead_paragraph: In a striking sign of renewed interest in nuclear power, Constellation Energy said on Friday that it plans to reopen the shuttered Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, the site of the worst reactor accident in United States history.

headline: With World’s Attention Shifting, Some in Gaza Fear They Will Be Forgotten
abstract: Even as Israel signals that it is moving its focus to its northern border with Lebanon, there has been no pause to its bombardment in Gaza, where residents are facing another winter with little access to food or shelter.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year of war, fear marks everyday life for Palestinians in Gaza. There is fear of the Israeli warplanes that tear through the skies and carry out deadly airstrikes. There is fear of famine with only a trickle of aid coming in. There is fear of being displaced, yet again, by Israeli evacuation orders.

headline: China Says It Will ‘Gradually’ Resume Imports of Japanese Seafood
abstract: China imposed a ban last year after Japan began releasing treated water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea. They have agreed to expand monitoring of the water.
lead_paragraph: China said on Friday that it would gradually resume imports of seafood from Japan, a year after banning them in response to Japan’s release of treated radioactive water from the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant into the ocean.

headline: Why Nike Just Did It
abstract: Investors are hoping that replacing John Donahoe as chief executive will lift its stock price and restore the brand’s cool factor.
lead_paragraph: Investors, and apparently some employees, breathed a sigh of relief after Nike said John Donahoe would step down next month as C.E.O. It ends a rocky four-year tenure during which the company lost market share, strained relations with key retail partners and — perhaps most worrisome — lost its cool factor.

headline: Sophie Died in 2021. The Album She Left Behind Is Now Complete.
abstract: “Sophie,” a new LP by the visionary hyperpop producer, traces an arc from introspection to pop pleasures to thoughts of eternity. It will be her final release.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Jan. 30, 2021, the visionary hyperpop producer Sophie was living in an apartment in Athens. To get a better view of the full moon, she climbed up a balcony, but slipped and fell. She was 34, and her death brought an outpouring of appreciation for the ways her sonic vocabulary — pointed, wriggly, blippy synthesizer tones and ultra-succinct hooks — had moved so quickly from pop’s experimental fringe to the mainstream.

headline: After the surprise pager attack, Israel and Hezbollah return to a familiar deadlock.
abstract: Israel’s attack on Hezbollah’s communication devices raised expectations of a decisive shift in their war of attrition. Instead, the fighting has returned to a standoff.
lead_paragraph: After the surprise of Israel’s attacks on Hezbollah communications devices this week, the war between the two sides has returned to a familiar state: deadlock.

headline: Is It Better to Buy or Lease a Car? It Depends.
abstract: The lowest overall cost is to buy a car and keep it for a long time. But leasing usually has lower monthly costs. And leasing an E.V. may come with a tax break.
lead_paragraph: Most people have two options when they want a new car: buy it with a traditional loan or lease it.

headline: Georgia Election Board Orders Hand-Counting of Ballots
abstract: Critics say the move could significantly delay the reporting of results in the battleground state and inject chaos into the post-election period.
lead_paragraph: The Georgia State Election Board voted on Friday to force counties to hand-count all ballots cast on Election Day, a move critics say could significantly delay the reporting of results in the battleground state and inject chaos into the post-election period.

headline: In Jan. 6 Case Filing, Trump Lawyers Again Demand Dismissal
abstract: Testing procedure, and perhaps the judge’s patience, the former president’s team sought to short-circuit a process to consider how much of the indictment can survive the Supreme Court’s immunity ruling.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump have employed aggressive tactics in defending him against two federal indictments.

headline: Britain’s Hard-Right Firebrand Has Big Plans for His Anti-Immigration Party
abstract: Nigel Farage, a Trump ally and Brexit champion, thinks Reform U.K. can become a major political force. At a conference on Friday, he sought to explain how.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, he was the keynote speaker at a glitzy Chicago dinner for the Heartland Institute, a conservative think tank with a history of denying climate science, where the top tables went for $50,000.

headline: Mohamed al-Fayed ‘Was a Monster Enabled by a System,’ Lawyers Say
abstract: Attorneys for 37 women said they would sue Harrods, the luxury department store, over the rape and sexual assault they say its former owner committed.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers representing dozens of women who have detailed harrowing allegations of sexual assault by Mohamed al-Fayed, the former owner of Harrods, said on Friday that they would launch a civil case against the luxury British department store for allegedly enabling his abuse.

headline: Trump’s Impulse After Robinson Bombshell Report: Ignore, and Power Through
abstract: CNN’s article scrambled G.O.P. plans for winning North Carolina. People close to Donald Trump are holding out hope Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson will decide to quit the governor’s race.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s advisers knew they had a problem in North Carolina. What they were frantically trying to learn was how big it would be.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Restore Jill Stein to the Nevada Ballot
abstract: Democrats had argued that Ms. Stein, the Green Party’s presidential candidate, was ineligible because the party had failed to submit a required statement.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would not restore the Green Party’s presidential candidate, Jill Stein, to the Nevada ballot in the coming election. Democrats had challenged her eligibility, saying her party had submitted flawed paperwork.

headline: Getty Apologizes for Fireworks Display Gone Awry
abstract: A planned “explosion event” in Los Angeles by the artist Cai Guo-Qiang left several injured and others shaken.
lead_paragraph: The Getty museum this week found itself having to apologize for the “explosion event” by the artist Cai Guo-Qiang at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum after it left several people injured by falling debris and many others shaken by the sound and smoke.

headline: Pulled Pork Is Party Food
abstract: Genevieve Ko’s saucy and satisfying recipe is also great fuel for a nap on the couch.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You don’t have to be a college football fan to understand the allure of pulled pork sandwiches on a weekend afternoon. But the games do make for an excellent backdrop to the experience of cooking them, consuming them, mopping up afterward and nodding off on the couch as the crowd roars mutely on a screen.

headline: San Francisco Symphony Chorus Goes on Strike
abstract: The work stoppage has forced a cancellation of the Verdi Requiem performances.
lead_paragraph: Amid the San Francisco Symphony’s financial troubles, the orchestra’s chorus members on Thursday went on strike, forcing a cancellation of the upcoming performances of Verdi’s Requiem.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, the hosts focused mostly on news surrounding former President Donald Trump, including the second apparent assassination attempt against him, this time while he was golfing at a Florida club of his, as well as Trump lashing out online about Taylor Swift.
lead_paragraph: This week, the hosts focused mostly on news surrounding former President Donald Trump, including the second apparent assassination attempt against him, this time while he was golfing at a Florida club of his, as well as Trump lashing out online about Taylor Swift.

headline: Trump’s Victories at the Supreme Court
abstract: Readers discuss a story about the chief justice’s role. Also: Loving children who are not your own; college football madness.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Who Is Ibrahim Aqeel, the Hezbollah Commander Killed by Israel?
abstract: The senior leader, who had survived multiple assassination attempts, has been sought by the United States for bombings in the 1980s. Here is a closer look.
lead_paragraph: Ibrahim Aqeel, the Hezbollah commander killed by Israel on Friday in Beirut, was one of the Iran-backed Lebanese armed group’s most senior leaders.

headline: Review: Blood, Sex, Murder and Dance (No Screams)
abstract: Marikiscrycrycry examines fresh territory in “Goner,” but his ideas remain theatrically inert.
lead_paragraph: Horror movies have often taken dance as a subject, from “The Red Shoes” to “Black Swan,” “Suspiria” and this year’s “Abigail.” The reverse is much less common, and so “Goner,” a dance solo by the artist known as Marikiscrycrycry, has the advantage of exploring fresh territory. It even comes with a tantalizing content warning about flashing lights, nudity, blood, sex and murder.

headline: What Foods Should I Have on Hand for an Emergency? And Other Disaster-Related Questions, Answered
abstract: Plan for the future for peace of mind on the other side.
lead_paragraph: When wildfires, hurricanes or other climate-related disasters surge, it’s easy to panic-Google what your food and water stocks should look like in an emergency. It’s also just as easy to see asterisks like “refresh supplies every six to 12 months,” get overwhelmed and give up.

headline: Otis Davis, Who Overcame Racism to Win Olympic Gold, Dies at 92
abstract: At the 1960 Summer Games in Rome, he set a world record in the 400-meter race and another in the 4 x 400 relay, where he anchored the United States team’s victory.
lead_paragraph: Otis Davis, who was not allowed to attend the University of Alabama, in his home state, because he was Black, but flourished at the University of Oregon, which became his springboard to winning two gold medals in sprints at the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome, died on Saturday in hospice care in North Bergen, N.J. He was 92.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: Florida
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Florida.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Florida.

headline: 19 More of Our Best Recipes Ever, According to You
abstract: You let us know what we missed from our list of NYT Cooking’s 50 greatest hits.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the 10th anniversary of New York Times Cooking, we published “Our 50 Greatest Hits, According to You,” a small slice of a decade-old recipe database. But with more than 24,000 recipes and counting, we were bound to miss a few of your favorites.

headline: F.T.C. Accuses Drug Middlemen of Inflating Insulin Prices
abstract: The case takes aim at the major pharmacy benefit managers, agency officials said, claiming that they favored more expensive insulin products and forced patients to pay more.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission said on Friday that it had taken legal action against the three largest pharmacy benefit managers, accusing the drug middlemen of inflating insulin prices and steering patients toward higher-cost insulin products to increase their profits.

headline: Harris Has a Polling Edge in Wisconsin, but Democrats Don’t Trust It
abstract: The vice president, who is visiting the state on Friday, has led Donald Trump there more often than not. Yet nearly everyone in Wisconsin politics believes the race will be incredibly close.
lead_paragraph: On paper, Vice President Kamala Harris should be feeling hopeful about Wisconsin.

headline: GE Vernova May Cut 900 Offshore Wind Jobs as It Scales Back
abstract: The company, a spinoff from General Electric, has been plagued by financial losses in its wind unit and, more recently, accidents involving the failure of turbine blades.
lead_paragraph: The energy company GE Vernova said on Friday that it would pare back its troubled offshore wind business, which has been hit with financial losses and accidents. The changes, which are aimed at coping with a difficult environment for the wind industry, could result in around 900 job losses.

headline: Harris Praises Taylor Swift’s ‘Courage’ After Endorsement
abstract: Kamala Harris noted, however, that she still won’t be rooting for the Kansas City Chiefs: “I am a 49ers fan, but who’s mad at anyone for being loyal to their team, right?”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has received countless endorsements from fellow Democrats and liberal celebrities, but she has made clear that the nod from Taylor Swift just hits different.

headline: Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker Apologizes After Bullying Accusations
abstract: Dancers said De Keersmaeker, a “godmother of contemporary dance,” ran her company in a tyrannical style that endangered staff members’ health.
lead_paragraph: New projects from the star choreographer Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker are always highly anticipated. But with her dance company touring Europe, a cloud has hung over her.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a South Indian drama about sexual harassment, a film shot within a video game, a period coming-of-age movie and more.
lead_paragraph: A sexual-harassment allegation sends a mostly male theater troupe into a tizzy in Anand Ekarshi’s whip-smart Malayalam drama, which distills into a microcosm the contortions of a society unable to deal with misbehaving men and the women they victimize. “Aattam” takes its time in setting the stage, introducing us to the Arangu troupe — comprising 12 men and just one woman — on the eve of a big performance, featuring English theater scouts in the audience. In the preshow banter of the group, performed with fantastic naturalism by the actors, everyday sexism becomes apparent. It comes into sharp focus at their after-show party in a resort, where comments about the dressing and drinking habits of the sole heroine, Anjali (Zarin Shihab), circulate.

headline: Israel’s Attacks on Hezbollah Intensify but Stop Short of All-Out War
abstract: Israel is attempting a risky strategy, increasing the intensity of its attacks in an attempt to force Hezbollah to back down, while raising the chances of an aggressive response that devolves into a land war.
lead_paragraph: Exploding pagers on Tuesday. Detonating walkie-talkies on Wednesday. An unusually intense barrage of bombs on Thursday. And a huge strike on southern Beirut on Friday.

headline: Communication Failures Plagued Deadly Trump Rally, Secret Service Finds
abstract: The agency found that it did not adequately prepare its local partners for the Butler, Pa., event, and its leader also cited lapses including complacency by some agents and technological breakdowns.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service failed to give clear and crucial directions to its local law enforcement partners at a July campaign rally in Butler, Pa., allowing a would-be assassin to climb onto a warehouse and shoot at former President Donald J. Trump, an agency internal investigation has found.

headline: Bad Bunny Commemorates a Hurricane, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Jane’s Addiction, Bon Iver, Yola and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Read the Summary of the Secret Service’s Internal Review
abstract: The agency released a brief summary of its monthslong inquiry into the failures leading to the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump in July. The complete report is not yet finished.
lead_paragraph: The agency released a brief summary of its monthslong inquiry into the failures leading to the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump in July. The complete report is not yet finished.

headline: A G.O.P.-Linked Group’s Contradictory Ads Cast Harris as Friend and Foe of Israel
abstract: The Future Coalition PAC is targeting voters in Pennsylvania and Michigan, both swing states, with contradictory messages about the vice president’s level of support for Israel.
lead_paragraph: A super PAC that appears to have Republican ties is trying to cast Vice President Kamala Harris in contradictory terms on Israel, pitching her as anti-Israel in a new ad that seems aimed at least partly at Jewish voters shortly after portraying her as pro-Israel in ads targeting Muslim voters.

headline: The Netherlands Returns Hundreds of Cultural Artifacts to Indonesia
abstract: The repatriation, the second of its kind by the Dutch, shows a working model for returning looted treasures from Europe to former colonies around the world.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch government returned centuries-old stone Buddhist statues, a bejeweled serpentine armband and other looted artifacts to its former colony Indonesia on Friday, a rare example of cultural objects taken during colonialism making their way back home.

headline: Courting Dark Emotions, and Toying With Audience Expectations
abstract: Revivals of Michael John LaChiusa’s “See What I Wanna See” and an early work by the “Past Lives” filmmaker look to the spirit world to reflect on our own.
lead_paragraph: The title of Michael John LaChiusa’s “See What I Wanna See” suggests a single perspective, but the show actually offers a kaleidoscopic approach to the truth. It ravels out one story about a murder and a rape only to follow it up, in Rashomon-like fashion, with variations on the same tale that features a businessman, his wife and a sociopath.

headline: ‘The Penguin’ Review: The Dark Blight
abstract: The HBO series starring an unrecognizable Colin Farrell is further proof that there is no fun in the Batman universe.
lead_paragraph: When was fun banished from Batman’s world? Certainly the tide turned with “The Dark Knight Returns,” Frank Miller’s 1986 series of comics. As exciting as they were, Miller’s books enshrined a claustrophobic, dystopian approach that has smothered many subsequent screen treatments.

headline: Democrats Seize on Robinson Scandal, Hoping to Sink Trump in a Key State
abstract: Kamala Harris’s campaign quickly released a new ad to run in North Carolina featuring Donald Trump’s effusive praise for Mark Robinson, the Republican candidate for governor.
lead_paragraph: A scandal engulfing Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson of North Carolina, the Republican nominee for governor, has Democrats feeling even more optimistic about Vice President Kamala Harris’s chances of winning a pivotal swing state.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Throw Three Seemingly Lifeless Palestinians Off a Roof
abstract: Several videos have emerged of the gruesome scene, but it remains unclear if the three were alive or dead at the time.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers threw, pushed and kicked three Palestinians off the roof of a building on Thursday during a military raid in the occupied West Bank town of Qabatiya, according to multiple verified videos of the gruesome incident.

headline: Airstrike in Lebanon Kills Hezbollah Commander, Israel Says
abstract: The Israeli military carried out an airstrike in Beirut that it said killed several senior Hezbollah officials, including Ibrahim Aqeel, a commander wanted by the United States for his role in bombings in the 1980s that killed hundreds. The Times verified aftermath footage from the strike that shows a completely flattened high-rise building.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military carried out an airstrike in Beirut that it said killed several senior Hezbollah officials, including Ibrahim Aqeel, a commander wanted by the United States for his role in bombings in the 1980s that killed hundreds. The Times verified aftermath footage from the strike that shows a completely flattened high-rise building.

headline: The Deserter
abstract: He didn’t want to fight in Putin’s war — he just wanted to survive. But to make it back to his family and live in peace, he would have to run.
lead_paragraph: He didn’t want to fight in Putin’s war — he just wanted to survive. But to make it back to his family and live in peace, he would have to run.

headline: What’s Next for Rate Cuts? The Fed Is Watching Jobs and Prices.
abstract: A Federal Reserve official predicted quarter point rate cuts if data looked ‘fine’. But he also set out a scenario for a pause — or faster reductions.
lead_paragraph: Having made their first interest rate cut in more than four years this week, Federal Reserve officials are keeping their options open as they try to figure out how rapidly to lower borrowing costs in the months ahead.

headline: Who Is the ‘Skinny Influencer’ Who Was Barred From TikTok?
abstract: Liv Schmidt has inspired debates with videos that some believe encourage disordered eating. One social media site tried to remove her.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not a sin to want to be thin,” read a recent social media bio for Liv Schmidt, a polarizing content creator who amassed more than 670,000 followers on TikTok before the company disabled her account last week.

headline: The ‘Crank Realignment’ and the Paranoid Center
abstract: A few weeks ago, just after Robert Kennedy Jr.’s endorsement of Donald Trump, Matt Yglesias wrote an essay on what he called “the crank realignment” — the recent migration of a lot of conspiratorial, tinfoil-hatted and outsider-knowledge-oriented elements in American politics toward the populist right, and the consolidation of most educated professionals and academics within the Democratic coalition.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, just after Robert Kennedy Jr.’s endorsement of Donald Trump, Matt Yglesias wrote an essay on what he called “the crank realignment” — the recent migration of a lot of conspiratorial, tinfoil-hatted and outsider-knowledge-oriented elements in American politics toward the populist right, and the consolidation of most educated professionals and academics within the Democratic coalition.

headline: Plagiarism Claims Are Brought Against University of Maryland’s President
abstract: The university’s president, Darryll J. Pines, who studies aerospace engineering, was accused of copying significant portions of a paper in 2002.
lead_paragraph: The University of Maryland said it was conducting a review of claims that its president, Darryll J. Pines, plagiarized significant portions of a 2002 scholarly paper.

headline: Trump’s Suggestion That Jews Could Cost Him Race Creates Fear of Antisemitic Reprisal
abstract: Twice on Thursday, the former president said he believed “the Jewish people would have a lot to do with” a loss if Kamala Harris defeated him.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s repeated assertion on Thursday that “the Jewish people would have a lot to do with” his loss if Kamala Harris prevailed on Election Day set off a mix of outrage and concern among Jewish leaders on Friday, raising fears that ardent supporters of the former president could be incited against Jews in an era of rising political violence.

headline: Nasal Flu Vaccine Is Approved for At-Home Use
abstract: The F.D.A. authorized AstraZeneca’s treatment to be given outside a health care setting, although it will still need a prescription.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday authorized at-home use of FluMist, opening the door for needle-shy people to have easy access to a nasal spray vaccine that is potentially lifesaving.

headline: For Economists, Defending Big Business Can Be Big Business
abstract: The Justice Department’s antitrust chief thinks conflicts of interest are degrading scholarship.
lead_paragraph: Are the world’s most powerful corporations buying the brains of economists and legal scholars? It certainly sounds that way if you listen to the chief antitrust enforcer at the Department of Justice.

headline: A Look Ahead at Autumn’s Big Books
abstract: The season’s most anticipated titles include new fiction from Sally Rooney, Richard Powers, Jean Hanff Korelitz and more, plus celebrity memoirs by Al Pacino, Cher and Ina Garten.
lead_paragraph: This weekend marks the official start of autumn — the equinox is on Sunday — so what better time to take a peek at the fall books we’re most excited to read? On this week’s episode, Gilbert Cruz chats with his colleagues Joumana Khatib and Anna Dubenko about the upcoming season of reading and the books on the horizon that they’re looking forward to most eagerly. They also discuss the proper way to pronounce “atoll.”

headline: Remembering Toto Schillaci, Who Helped Usher Us Into the Future
abstract: For one month in 1990, Schillaci was the most beloved player in Italy, and one of the most famous players in the world.
lead_paragraph: Azeglio Vicini did not have any particular words of wisdom for Salvatore Schillaci. He did not send him on to the field at the Stadio Olimpico, into the white heat of a home World Cup, weighed down by some complex tactical schema. Vicini was not that sort of coach. His instructions were simple: Entra, e fai gol. Go on, and score.

headline: Overlooked No More: Ellen Armstrong, ‘Marvelous, Mystifying’ Magician of Mirth
abstract: Carrying on a family tradition, she brought her singular act, full of illusion and humor, to Black audiences in the segregated South and on up to Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: What Is the Radwan Force, the Elite Hezbollah Unit Linked to Ibrahim Aqeel?
abstract: The Israeli military considers the force a major threat to its northern border and has portrayed Aqeel, whom it claimed to have killed on Friday, as its de facto commander.
lead_paragraph: Israel has long seen Hezbollah, with thousands of trained fighters and a deep arsenal of rockets and other weapons, as the most formidable foe on its borders. And Israeli officials say Hezbollah’s elite Radwan force, in particular, poses a major threat.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Dangerous Odometer Photography
abstract: How good does the number have to be to justify taking your phone out to get a picture?
lead_paragraph: Daniel writes: My father has this habit of taking photos of the odometer in his car when it hits certain numbers he finds interesting — while driving. We’ve told him it’s dangerous. His “solution” is to ask his passenger to do it for him. The numbers aren’t even good. (For example: 121213.)
