headline: Environmentalists Fear Subsidies for Carbon Capture Won’t Be Checked
abstract: Some activists are questioning whether the federal government can accurately verify a tax program for facilities that store planet-warming gases.
lead_paragraph: Lucrative new tax subsidies for companies that catch the planet-warming gas carbon dioxide and store it deep underground were one of the few aspects of President Biden’s 2022 climate legislation that the oil industry embraced.

headline: Man the U.S. Says Financed Hezbollah Admits Trying to Evade Sanctions
abstract: Mohammad Ibrahim Bazzi pleaded guilty in Brooklyn federal court to conspiring to violate Treasury Department prohibitions.
lead_paragraph: For years, U.S. authorities said, Mohammad Ibrahim Bazzi funneled millions of dollars to Hezbollah, the militia backed by Iran and based in Lebanon that is currently clashing with Israel.

headline: These Voters Don’t Want to Commit to Trump or Harris. Here’s Why.
abstract: Those still weighing their options are more likely  to be young, Black or Latino — and struggling. Many see their choice as the “lesser of two evils.”
lead_paragraph: More than other voters, they tend to be young, and Black or Hispanic. They get more news from social media than most voters do. They worry about their economic security.

headline: Inside a Harris Ad That Tries to Saddle Trump With Mark Robinson’s Baggage
abstract: A new ad placed on Friday by Kamala Harris’s campaign, without mentioning the scandal threatening the North Carolina Republican’s run for governor, seeks to taint Donald Trump by association.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign on Friday began running this 30-second ad, “Both Wrong,” on digital platforms and television stations in North Carolina. It declined to provide details on how much commercial time it had purchased, but the campaign has nearly $8 million reserved on television in North Carolina through Election Day, according to AdImpact.

headline: 2 Stole $230 Million in Cryptocurrency and Went on a Spending Spree, U.S. Says
abstract: Malone Lam, 20, and Jeandiel Serrano, 21, schemed to obtain 4,100 Bitcoin from a single victim, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Two men have been charged with stealing $230 million worth of cryptocurrency that they used to go on a lavish spending spree involving travel, nightclubs, luxury cars, jewelry and palatial rental properties in Los Angeles and Miami before they were caught, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Kentucky Town Is Shaken After Local Sheriff Is Charged With Killing Judge
abstract: The two men were seen getting ready to go to lunch on the day of the shooting. Hours later, Judge Kevin Mullins was dead from multiple gunshot wounds.
lead_paragraph: When Judge Kevin Mullins and Sheriff Shawn Stines, two longtime officials in a rural eastern Kentucky county, were seen getting ready to go to lunch on Thursday, there was no obvious indication of ill will.

headline: What the U.S. Has Argued in the Google Ad Tech Antitrust Trial
abstract: As the government wraps up its case, it has built a picture of how Google has become dominant among companies that buy and sell ads online.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two weeks, lawyers for the Department of Justice have questioned more than a dozen witnesses as they try to prove that Google has broken antitrust laws, part of a second major federal antitrust trial against the tech giant.

headline: Earth Had a Ring 466 Million Years Ago, Study Says
abstract: Impact craters found around the Earth that were made around the same time could be linked to debris falling from a ring, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: If you were to look up from Earth some 466 million years ago, you might have seen a gleaming ring stretching across the sky, some scientists say.

headline: Move Over, Matcha. Strawberry Milk Is Here.
abstract: Long beloved in Japan, the drink is becoming a fixture on cafe menus in Hawaii and now the mainland, too.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up on the Hawaiian island of Oahu, Jaron Hanus, 36, a co-owner of the Japanese-inspired cafe Neko Koneko in Honolulu, drank milk with every meal at the insistence of his grandmother. To make it more enticing, she would buy the strawberry-flavored kind from a local Japanese grocery store or make her own by simmering fresh strawberries in milk and honey. Hanus’s wife and business partner, Erin Yonamine, 45, also grew up on Oahu and remembers her grandmother plying her with ichigo (the Japanese word for strawberry) milk and ichigo milk candies from Shirokiya, an erstwhile Japanese department store in Honolulu. When the couple opened Neko Koneko in 2021, they created their own version of their childhood drink — updated with oat milk but just as vibrantly pink.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, September 21, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Harris Slams G.O.P. Abortion Bans as a Painful ‘Health Care Crisis’
abstract: “Donald Trump is the architect of this crisis,” Kamala Harris said in Georgia, where reporting this week found that the deaths of two women were a result of delayed treatment for medication abortions.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris delivered an impassioned speech about abortion rights on Friday in Georgia, accusing Republicans who support abortion bans of causing unnecessary suffering as she described the far-reaching, painful and even deadly consequences of such policies.

headline: Kamala Harris Tells Oprah if Somebody Breaks Into Her Home, ‘They’re Getting Shot’
abstract: The remarkable utterance underscored Democrats’ increasing comfort with the country’s gun culture, and how Harris is trying to use it to puncture notions about female candidates.
lead_paragraph: The exchange, during a livestreamed forum with Oprah Winfrey and Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday, began with the kind of emotional set piece that has become a grim go-to for Democrats campaigning on gun safety.

headline: Nelson DeMille, Blockbuster Author Who Thrilled Millions, Dies at 81
abstract: In best seller after best seller, world-weary investigators tackled military malfeasance and Russian spies, cracking jokes and beers to the delight of legions of devoted fans.
lead_paragraph: Nelson DeMille, a beloved and prolific author whose propulsive thrillers featuring terrorist hijackings, Russian spy schools, gruesome murders, Mafia kingpins, wartime crimes and military malfeasance made him a publishing juggernaut, died on Tuesday in Mineola, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 81.

headline: California Firefighter Is Accused of Starting 5 Fires in Wine Country
abstract: A Cal Fire employee was arrested Friday on suspicion of starting several blazes in Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: A California firefighter was arrested Friday morning after allegedly setting five fires in wine country during what has already been a bad year for wildfires in the state.

headline: Timeline: What Donald Trump Has Said About Mark Robinson
abstract: The former president was an early backer of Mr. Robinson’s bid to become governor of North Carolina, a race that was jolted when CNN reported that Mr. Robinson had made disturbing posts online.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was an early backer of Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson’s campaign to become governor of North Carolina, a race that was jolted this week when CNN reported that Mr. Robinson had described himself as a “Black Nazi” in a post on a pornographic forum.

headline: Israel Killed a Top Hezbollah Commander in Lebanon
abstract: Plus, a baseball game for the ages
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said today that it had bombed an apartment building in Beirut’s southern suburbs and killed a major figure in Hezbollah’s military command. The strike stoked fears that Israel is driving toward a full-blown war against Hezbollah.

headline: Early Voting Begins in Minnesota, South Dakota and Virginia
abstract: All three states began sending out mail ballots on Friday and now give people the option of voting in person.
lead_paragraph: Early voting began in Minnesota, South Dakota and Virginia on Friday, letting voters in those states cast ballots while Election Day remains a month and a half away, on Nov. 5.

headline: Michel Siffre, 85, Dies; Descended Into Caves to Study the Human Mind
abstract: He was a pioneer in chronobiology, the study of how our bodies understand the passage of time.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Sept. 14, 1962, reporters and onlookers began to gather around a hole in the ground, far up in the Maritime Alps between France and Italy. A few hours later, workers rigged a rope down into the darkness; soon they pulled out a small, sturdily built man named Michel Siffre.

headline: Senior Hezbollah Leader Is Killed in Beirut in Israeli Airstrike
abstract: The attack, which Lebanese officials said killed at least 14 and injured more than 60, stoked fears Israel is driving toward a full-blown war on its northern border, even as the fight in Gaza goes on.
lead_paragraph: Israeli fighter jets bombed an apartment building in Beirut’s densely populated southern suburbs on Friday in what the military called an attack on Hezbollah militants, including a senior commander who was wanted in the deadly 1983 bombings of the U.S. embassy and U.S. Marine Corps barracks in Beirut.

headline: Officials Confirm Body Found Near Site of Kentucky Highway Shooting Was Suspect’s
abstract: The identification, made through DNA testing, affirmed the belief of officials. The body was discovered Wednesday after a 12-day manhunt.
lead_paragraph: DNA testing of a body found this week near the site of a Kentucky highway shooting that led to an extensive manhunt confirmed the identity as the suspect, officials said on Friday.

headline: With Robinson Candidacy, North Carolina Republicans Fear Damage to Years of Gains
abstract: Explosive posts by the Republican candidate for governor, Mark Robinson, are sending waves of anxiety through a state party that has long been tactical and disciplined.
lead_paragraph: The great Republican wave that swept the South starting in the late 20th Century — the very wave that Lyndon Johnson predicted after signing the Civil Rights Act in 1964 — came relatively late to North Carolina.

headline: Qualcomm Asked Chip Rival Intel if It Would Consider a Sale
abstract: While Intel has struggled in recent years, other chipmakers are thriving because of a boom in demand.
lead_paragraph: The chipmaker Qualcomm has approached its rival Intel in recent days about the possibility of acquiring the slumping Silicon Valley giant, two people familiar with the matter said Friday, requesting anonymity because the talks were confidential.

headline: How One Man’s Vote in Nebraska Could Change the Presidential Election
abstract: A single Republican state senator appears to be holding back a push by Donald J. Trump to net a potentially pivotal electoral vote even before ballots are cast.
lead_paragraph: In Eastern Nebraska, far from the presidential battleground states, a drama is playing out that could, in a perfectly plausible November scenario, have history-altering repercussions for the nation’s future and the next president — and it may all come down to one man.

headline: Bodycam Footage Shows Police Shooting in N.Y.C. Subway
abstract: The New York Police Department released edited body camera footage that shows the moments before and after officers shot a man who they said was wielding a knife at a subway station in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department released edited body camera footage that shows the moments before and after officers shot a man who they said was wielding a knife at a subway station in Brooklyn.

headline: Rallying in Two Key States, Harris Presses Her Case on Abortion Rights
abstract: Visiting Wisconsin after giving a speech in Georgia, the vice president signaled she would focus on the life-or-death risks of abortion bans in the final weeks of the race.
lead_paragraph: Rallying supporters in two battleground states, Vice President Kamala Harris signaled on Friday that her closing campaign message would focus on the life-or-death risks that abortion bans pose to American women — and on the argument that former President Donald J. Trump is to blame.

headline: Security Firm Linked to Top Adams Aide Won Millions in N.Y.C. Business
abstract: The company received a $154 million contract to provide “emergency fire watch services” to the New York City Housing Authority. The firm was once owned by the deputy mayor for public safety.
lead_paragraph: Before Philip B. Banks III was named deputy mayor for public safety for New York City, the security company he once owned rarely did business with the city.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 21, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the Federal Trade Commission’s findings on the collection and sharing of consumer’s data by some of the biggest online platforms misstated the date and the underlying complaints of the F.T.C.’s settlement with Epic Games. The settlement was reached in late 2022, not in January; and the agency had charged that Epic violated a child privacy law and deceived consumers with unwarranted charges, not just that it violated a child privacy law.

headline: Motel 6 Is Sold to Oyo, an Indian Hotel Company Expanding in the U.S.
abstract: A roadside chain for more than 50 years, Motel 6 was owned by Blackstone, the private equity giant. Oyo will pay $525 million in an all-cash deal.
lead_paragraph: Motel 6, the budget hotel chain that has lined American highways for decades, will be sold to Oyo, an India-based hotel operator, the companies announced on Friday.

headline: Works on a Loop, Say
abstract: David Karp’s puzzle sends us up, down and all around.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is David Karp’s fifth crossword for The New York Times in just about two years. All of his grids have run on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday, so he’s building out a portfolio of tough stuff. I did great for most of my solve, chuckling away at the fun phrase entries and enjoying the geography trivia that sent me down several interesting rabbit holes. However, I got snagged right at the finish line by some thorny misdirection. I was one letter away from finishing for the longest time! We’ve all been there.

headline: N.Y.P.D.’s Release of Subway Shooting Video Footage Doesn’t Quell Anger
abstract: After seeing video of officers firing at a knife-wielding man, the cousin of a bystander who was badly hurt in the shooting said the mayor’s explanation did not make sense.
lead_paragraph: Newly released video footage of New York City police officers opening fire on a knife-wielding man at a Brooklyn subway station did not quell anger over their inadvertent shooting of two bystanders, including one who was hit in the head during the burst of gunfire.

headline: Quote of the Day: Couples Withstand Wrenching Plights Brought On By War
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 21, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I was a stranger there and I am a stranger here. I’m a stranger everywhere.”

headline: The Incumbent, the Marxist and the Heir: Sri Lanka’s Tight Race for President
abstract: The country will hold its first presidential election on Saturday since its strongman president fled the country two years ago. Here are the main contenders.
lead_paragraph: Sri Lanka is holding a presidential election on Saturday for the first time since its strongman president fled the country two years ago in the face of protests over an economic collapse.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How Gina Torres, of ‘Suits’ and ‘9-1-1: Lonestar,’ Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Torres starts with a low-key workout, takes a dance break and ends the day with one of her favorite murder-filled TV shows.
lead_paragraph: When Gina Torres recalls the heyday of “Suits,” the legal drama she starred in, she instantly remembers how “insane” the fan base was abroad. But with the resurgence of the show in streaming on Netflix and NBC’s Peacock, suddenly the hype has followed suit in the United States.

headline: After Apple, Jony Ive Is Building an Empire of His Own
abstract: Five years after leaving Apple, the iPhone designer is forging a new life in San Francisco, one imaginative building at a time.
lead_paragraph: Five years to the week after he walked away from the top job designing the iPhone, Jony Ive leaned over a hulking model of a San Francisco city block. The dozen buildings, with each brick carved to scale in Alder wood, had become a prototype for his future.

headline: Her Children Were Sick. Was It ‘Forever Chemicals’ on the Family Farm?
abstract: Pastures were fertilized with toxic sewage decades ago. Nobody knew, until the cows’ milk was tested.
lead_paragraph: Allison Jumper’s family was a picture of healthy living. Active kids. Wholesome meals. A freezer stocked with organic beef from her in-laws’ farm in Maine.

headline: This Family Is Miserable. You Should Meet Them Anyway.
abstract: The domestic drama runs high in “A Reason to See You Again,” Jami Attenberg’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: If the characters in Jami Attenberg’s novels existed on Google Maps, their collective pin would probably drop at a spot called Dysfunction Junction. The smart, deeply flawed people who populate her stories — usually Jewish and located somewhere within the urban flux of New York, Chicago or New Orleans — tend to be driven by art and ambition, along with infidelity, addiction and an almost pathological knack for family schisms. The urge to be likable does not consume them; one could say they are largely immune to the charms of being charming. But the texture of real, messy life lurks in the fallouts, failures and neuroses that spill across the page (and often down their throats; this gang like their alcohol).

headline: ‘Do You Need a Ride?’
abstract: Escaping a kidnapper at age 12.
lead_paragraph: I was 12, walking alone on a gray afternoon when a man driving in the same direction slowed down to meet my pace.

headline: Read Excerpts From Memos Written for Trump About His Powers to Prosecute
abstract: The drafts were written to explain the limits of a president’s ability to go after rivals, invoking legal and constitutional factors and political norms.
lead_paragraph: The following are excerpts from draft memos written by lawyers in the White House Counsel’s Office in the spring of 2018 in response to demands from President Donald J. Trump for investigations into rivals.

headline: As President, Trump Demanded Investigations of Foes. He Often Got Them.
abstract: He has threatened to target his perceived enemies if elected again. A look at his time in the White House shows how readily he could do so.
lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 2018 and President Donald J. Trump, faced with an accelerating inquiry into his campaign’s ties to Russia, was furious that the Justice Department was reluctant to strike back at those he saw as his enemies.

headline: Our Taste for Flesh Has Exhausted the Earth
abstract: Are we ready for the future of meat?
lead_paragraph: More than almost anything else we put into our mouths, meat matters. What flesh we eat — or forsake — tells the world who we are, what class and caste we belong to, what gods we believe in. Halal or kosher. Pure-veg or paleo. Hormel or farmers’ market.

headline: 10 Unexpected Places Romance Blossomed This Summer
abstract: Readers share their stories of serendipitous meet-cutes at retreats, museums, cooking classes and grocery stores.
lead_paragraph: There seems to be a lot of misery related to dating these days: unreciprocated energy, commitment issues and swiping fatigue (to name a few).

headline: Meet the Birkin Bag of the Book World: Collectible, Covetable and Priced to Match
abstract: Assouline has made its name publishing tomes that sell for $1,000 or more. But that’s just the beginning of this family-run company’s ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, when Assouline, a leading purveyor of high-end coffee table books and fancy library accouterments, opened its first branded outpost on the seventh floor of Bergdorf Goodman in New York, Prosper Assouline, a founder of the company, experienced a kind of epiphany.

headline: Norman Reedus, ‘Walking Dead’ Star and Hieronymus Bosch Fan
abstract: “We wanted to reinvent the show,” the actor said of his spinoff, “The Walking Dead: Daryl Dixon.” Filming in Madrid gave him time to explore the Prado.
lead_paragraph: When Daryl Dixon was introduced in the third episode of “The Walking Dead” in 2010, few viewers could have predicted this half-feral-looking character would end up leading the series. Or that Daryl, played by Norman Reedus, would headline a spinoff set in France.

headline: Going Solo: How to Plan for Retirement When You’re on Your Own
abstract: More Americans are entering their later years without people they can automatically turn to for assistance with their health and finances. Here’s how to start.
lead_paragraph: For Sara Zeff Geber, the “aha moment” came a few years ago as she listened to a friend recount all the tasks she was taking on to help her increasingly frail 91-year-old mother.

headline: What Can Your ‘Training Load’ Tell You About Your Fitness?
abstract: The metric is available on most fitness trackers. Here’s what it means.
lead_paragraph: You just finished a long, hard bike ride. But how hard was it, exactly? That depends on what you measure: How far did you ride, and how fast? How hilly was the route, and what heart rate zones were you in?

headline: What We Know (and Don’t Know) About ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Food
abstract: There’s a growing understanding of the health threats of PFAS chemicals in what we eat and drink.
lead_paragraph: They’re called “forever chemicals” because they basically never break down. They’re linked to ailments including liver disease, certain types of cancers and delayed development in children.

headline: When Is Your HOA Responsible for Repairs in Your Home?
abstract: State laws govern some of what a homeowners’ association can and can’t do, but the facts of each case are usually what matter most.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a townhouse governed by a homeowners’ association in Northern California. Maintenance and repair of the roof falls under the HOA’s responsibilities. Recently, a leak in my roof resulted in water damage. The HOA repaired the leak, but is refusing to address the water damage in my home, suggesting that it’s my responsibility. Shouldn’t the HOA be responsible for repairing that damage as well?

headline: Mother Nature Is His Accomplice
abstract: In Brandon Ndife’s otherworldly domestic sculptures, on view in his New York show, nature shows its ungovernable power.
lead_paragraph: There wasn’t much free ground on which to stand in Brandon Ndife’s Brooklyn studio. Nearly every inch of the space had been swallowed up by a wild profusion of sculptures, which rose from the floor like a dense, unruly forest. The artworks heaved with his facsimiles of botanical life — tree trunks, branches, wheat, vines and vegetables. Twisting and torquing, this biotic matter appeared to be devouring the very things that it had emerged from: quotidian household objects and furniture.

headline: Naomi Campbell Won’t Stop Her Children From Modeling
abstract: As long as they get good grades. Plus: a new top editor at i-D magazine and a nascent ‘it’ bag.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Campbell, even after modeling for more than 40 years, still gets nervous before walking a runway.

headline: Rivalries Are the Heart of College Football. But Many Are Going Away.
abstract: Upheaval within the Big Ten, Pac-12 and Southeastern Conferences has threatened some cherished rivalries, while rekindling others. In Oregon, the Civil War may soon be over.
lead_paragraph: Travis Beard, wearing a T-shirt commemorating Oregon State’s epic comeback against its rival, the University of Oregon, two years ago that ended with football fans storming the field, was nursing a beer last Saturday on a Reser Stadium concourse, trying to ward off despair.

headline: Kate Mulgrew Walks the Creative and Emotional Plank in ‘The Beacon’
abstract: Holding tightly to the Dublin accent of her character, the actress talks about starring in Nancy Harris’s feminist thriller at Irish Rep.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in her dressing room on Tuesday at Irish Repertory Theater in Manhattan, talking to me about her latest role, the actress Kate Mulgrew initially sounded like herself: an American from Iowa who happens to share a voice with Kathryn Janeway, the Starfleet captain she played on “Star Trek: Voyager.”

headline: Where Joy Meets Anger: Harris and Trump Battle for Undecided Voters
abstract: The allegiances of this group of voters — roughly three million people in seven battleground states — are up for grabs, and polling shows they’re pessimistic about the country’s future.
lead_paragraph: Devon Howard is not feeling the joy.

headline: The Squishy Truth About Why You’re Seeing Fewer Spotted Lanternflies
abstract: Your stomping may have helped trim this invasive insect’s population. But experts say other factors probably explain their reduced numbers around New York City.
lead_paragraph: The spotted lanternflies seem to have gone AWOL.

headline: Albania Is Planning a New Muslim State Inside Its Capital
abstract: Prime Minister Edi Rama says he wants to give members of the Bektashi, a Shiite Sufi order, their own Vatican-style enclave as a way of promoting religious tolerance.
lead_paragraph: The Muslim cleric preparing to lead what, if everything goes as planned, will become the world’s smallest state, has laid-back plans for the tiny new country.

headline: How the Kremlin Finds Ways to Spread Its Messages
abstract: Social media companies may try to ban RT, the Russian state media broadcaster. But the network has proved in the past to be a wily adversary when confronted with efforts to silence it.
lead_paragraph: Major American social media companies sometimes describe the task of identifying disinformation or other malevolent material pushed online by state actors as an endless game of cat and mouse.

headline: As President, Trump Demanded Investigations of Foes. He Often Got Them.
abstract: Michael S. Schmidt, a New York Times investigative reporter, explains how Donald Trump used his power as president to intimidate and punish his rivals. Now, in the final weeks of his presidential campaign, Trump has ramped up promises to exact retribution if he returns to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Michael S. Schmidt, a New York Times investigative reporter, explains how Donald Trump used his power as president to intimidate and punish his rivals. Now, in the final weeks of his presidential campaign, Trump has ramped up promises to exact retribution if he returns to the White House.

headline: Drug Overdose Deaths Are Dropping. The Reasons Are Not Perfectly Clear.
abstract: The decrease across the country is a major breakthrough in efforts to reverse the effects of fentanyl. Researchers and health officials say there is no easy explanation for the trend.
lead_paragraph: Drug overdose deaths are decreasing sharply across the country, according to recent state and federal data, a dramatic improvement in the nation’s efforts to reverse the consequences of fentanyl’s spread in the illicit drug supply.

headline: Here Are Cases of Trump Rivals Who Were Subject to Investigation
abstract: Those who found themselves under government scrutiny after alienating President Donald J. Trump ranged from the former F.B.I. director to a onetime contestant on “The Apprentice.”
lead_paragraph: Those who found themselves under government scrutiny after alienating President Donald J. Trump ranged from the former F.B.I. director to a onetime contestant on “The Apprentice.”

headline: A Writer Walks Into a Rave
abstract: Party-hopping across boroughs with Emily Witt, whose new memoir takes her from literary New York to the city’s underground nightlife scenes.
lead_paragraph: The night out started with New York’s literati and ended with a fog machine.

headline: Every Falsehood, Exaggeration and Untruth in Trump’s and Harris’s Stump Speeches
abstract: We fact-checked every sentence of two recent rally speeches and found that Mr. Trump spoke for almost three times as long as Ms. Harris, but told more than 10 times as many falsehoods or inaccurate statements.
lead_paragraph: We fact-checked every sentence of two recent rally speeches and found that Mr. Trump spoke for almost three times as long as Ms. Harris, but told more than 10 times as many falsehoods or inaccurate statements.

headline: Trump’s Opponents See New Ways to Cast the G.O.P. as ‘Team Misogyny’
abstract: The issue of gender dominated the campaign over a week that included a scandal in North Carolina and reporting on the fatal fallout of abortion bans.
lead_paragraph: In a race between a Democrat who could be America’s first female president and a Republican who has been found liable for sexual abuse, the issue of gender was always going to be inescapable.

headline: Sally Rooney Thinks Career Growth Is Overrated
abstract: The star novelist discusses her public persona, the discourse around her work and why reinvention isn’t a goal.
lead_paragraph: The arrival on Sept. 24 of Sally Rooney’s new novel, “Intermezzo,” is one of this fall’s biggest publishing events — not only for the legion of devoted readers hungry for new fiction from the 33-year-old Irish author, but also for the literati ready to devour all the takes and think pieces the book is sure to spawn.

headline: A Hovercraft Built From Scratch Sails ‘Like Magic’
abstract: Robert Tymofichuk, a teacher in Alberta, Canada, spent nearly 2,000 hours building an operational hovercraft from salvaged car parts and with no blueprint.
lead_paragraph: On a cold spring day in a small garage in Alberta, Canada, an engine revved up and an improbable machine — fabricated from auto parts, a hand-sewn rubber skirt and an abandoned fiberglass hull — came to life.

headline: Attacks on Hezbollah Alter Balance of Power in Long-Running Fight
abstract: A focus on mutual deterrence had kept intermittent clashes along the Lebanon-Israel border from spiraling into a major war. That changed this past week.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than two months, Israel located and killed Hezbollah’s most senior and secretive military figures as they held covert meetings near Beirut. And in between those strikes, Israel incapacitated hundreds, if not thousands, of the group’s rank-and-file members by remotely blowing up their pagers and walkie-talkies.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 469
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Sept. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Canadian Doctors Group Apologizes for Health Harms to Indigenous People
abstract: Indigenous patients faced abuse, experimental treatments and other harms in Canada’s health system, which still has disparities.
lead_paragraph: The medical researchers poked and prodded their unwitting patients. Using sharp instruments, they removed skin from some and grafted the bits onto others in the group of Inuit patients in Igloolik, a hamlet in the Canadian high Arctic.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,191
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Deserter: An Epic Story of Love and War
abstract: The audio feature, narrated by Liev Schreiber
lead_paragraph: In “The Deserter,” the journalist Sarah A. Topol reports the story of Ivan, a deserter who served as a captain in the Russian Army, fought in Ukraine and then ultimately fled the war and his country with his wife, Anna. (Ivan and Anna are pseudonyms used for their protection.)

headline: Shoulder Season
abstract: It’s still summer today, but fall arrives tomorrow. Take a minute to pause on the threshold.
lead_paragraph: I received the “They’re back!” text from my friend Greg in Oxford, Miss., on Monday evening. “They” were the Halloween inflatables festooning his neighbor’s lawn, as depicted in an accompanying photo: a jack-o’-lantern with a ghost flailing from each eye, Skeleton Medusa, two spiders the size of Volkswagen Beetles. Greg knows I’m appalled at the ever-earlier arrival of spooky-season décor.

headline: How a U.S. Ally Uses Aid as a Cover in War
abstract: The United Arab Emirates is expanding a covert campaign to back a winner in Sudan’s civil war. Waving the banner of the Red Crescent, it is also smuggling weapons and deploying drones.
lead_paragraph: The drones soar over the vast deserts along the Sudanese border, guiding weapons convoys that smuggle illicit arms to fighters accused of widespread atrocities and ethnic cleansing.

headline: Easing the Stress Parents Face
abstract: Parents discuss a guest essay by the surgeon general.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Freedom Is Not What We Think It Is
abstract: Freedom is not just an absence of evil. Freedom is the presence of good.
lead_paragraph: I know a town in southern Ukraine where every single house has been destroyed by shelling or bombing. Even the ruins are riddled by bullet holes. Posad-Pokrovske, in the Kherson region, was occupied by Russians for most of 2022, before they were driven out by the Ukrainian army.

headline: The Devastating Accounts of Mass Rape I Heard in Darfur
When Gunmen Impose a Policy of Rape
abstract: At the U.N., will President Biden and other world leaders stand up for the victims or for the countries fueling war, rape and hunger?
lead_paragraph: Sudanese refugees who wade across a stream to enter Chad mostly say they leave because of starvation at home. But in tearful whispers, they add that something else is also driving both the starvation and the exodus: mass rape.

headline: Padma Lakshmi: As a Cook, Here’s What I See in Kamala Harris
abstract: The candidate is a proud cook, and cooking is a way to connect.
lead_paragraph: I see what everyone else sees on Kamala Harris’s résumé: a history of public service that qualifies her for the presidency. But I would argue that the qualities she shows as a cook might say even more about her success as a leader.

headline: Israel’s Pager Bombs Have No Place in a Just War
abstract: Israel is using the tactics of the terrorists it condemns if it indeed was behind the wave of pager and walkie-talkie explosions in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: The exploding pagers and walkie-talkies targeting members of Hezbollah in Lebanon were certainly an espionage and technological coup. Few people on the spot or reading about them from far away could fail to be amazed. But the explosions on Tuesday and Wednesday were also very likely war crimes — terrorist attacks by a state that has consistently condemned terrorist attacks on its own citizens.

headline: How the Powerful Outmaneuvered the American Protest Movement
abstract: It’s time for organizers to invent a new model.
lead_paragraph: The year 2024 started out looking as if it would be a momentous one for political protests. All winter and spring, college campuses were aflame in anger and conflict and as summer approached, the Democratic National Convention threatened to be engulfed by street demonstrations in a potential repeat of the tumultuous 1968 party convention.

headline: The 2024 Election Is a Retreat From Ideology
abstract: Whatever the Trump-Harris election season is delivering, it isn’t a grand ideological debate.
lead_paragraph: The election of 2016, both Donald Trump’s shocking victory and Bernie Sanders’s socialist insurgency, created a sudden swell of ideological ambition. Conservative thinkers rushed to fill in the outlines of Trumpian populism, building various intellectual frameworks for an incipient “post-liberal” age. Meanwhile among progressives there were two big projects: a cultural revolution in the name of antiracism and social justice that gathered force throughout Trump’s presidency, and a Sanders-inspired revival of big-spending social democratic blueprints.

headline: 2 Books for a Real-Life ‘Brilliant Friend’
abstract: Adventures in Russian literature; a novel of domestic discontent.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Trump Heads to North Carolina as Mark Robinson’s Campaign Reels
abstract: The former president is holding a rally in the battleground state as Mr. Robinson, whom he endorsed for governor, deals with the fallout from a report that he made disturbing online posts.
lead_paragraph: With somewhat awkward timing, former President Donald J. Trump plans to campaign in North Carolina on Saturday as his pick for governor, Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, faces accusations of making disturbing posts on a pornographic website.

headline: Women Entrepreneurs Are Hitting a Funding Wall
abstract: For women starting new businesses, early funding from venture capital firms led by other women is vital. But few are large enough to lead subsequent rounds of financing.
lead_paragraph: When Oriana Papin-Zoghbi was looking for venture capital funding to develop a new type of test for ovarian cancer, she found her pitch did best with women investors. “They were able to resonate with the problem we are trying to solve,” she said.

headline: Exploding Pagers Deliver a Supply Chain Warning
abstract: The attacks on Hezbollah in Lebanon are likely to generate greater momentum for moving factory production closer to home.
lead_paragraph: The lethal detonation of hand-held pagers and walkie-talkies used by Hezbollah militants this week in Lebanon demonstrated powerful spycraft, but it also raised questions about a gaping vulnerability in the global supply chain.

headline: Sean Combs and the Limits of the ‘Family Man’ Defense
abstract: Famous people have long tried to launder their images through their spouses and children.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Sean Combs was arrested in Manhattan on racketeering and sex trafficking charges. If he’s convicted of the racketeering charge, it could land him a life sentence. His legal team defended him that day with references to his role as a father. “Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs is a music icon, self-made entrepreneur, loving family man and proven philanthropist who has spent the last 30 years building an empire, adoring his children and working to uplift the Black community,” they said in a statement. “He is an imperfect person, but he is not a criminal.”

headline: Ukraine Hits 2 More Russian Munition Depots, Aiming to Disrupt War Effort
abstract: Strikes on weapons arsenals are crucial to weaken Moscow’s overwhelming superiority in battlefield firepower, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine said on Saturday that it had struck two large ammunition depots deep inside Russia overnight. It was the second such attack in less than a week as Kyiv seeks to escalate hits on Russian military bases and warehouses to try to disrupt Moscow’s military logistics and slow its troops’ advance on the battlefield.

headline: Who Are the Black Swing Voters?
abstract: Black voters are not monolithic. Astead W. Herndon, a national reporter for The New York Times and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” asks a political strategist, Prentiss Haney, and Maryland’s governor, Wes Moore, about how Democrats and Republicans can persuade different kinds of Black swing voters.
lead_paragraph: Black voters are not monolithic. Astead W. Herndon, a national reporter for The New York Times and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” asks a political strategist, Prentiss Haney, and Maryland’s governor, Wes Moore, about how Democrats and Republicans can persuade different kinds of Black swing voters.

headline: Harris Enters Homestretch With a Far Bigger, Costlier Campaign Than Trump
abstract: Kamala Harris is collecting more money, spending more money and sitting on more money than Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris entered the homestretch of the general election building a campaign that was bigger than former President Donald J. Trump’s in nearly every discernible category.

headline: For Families of Those Missing After Israeli Strike in Beirut, an Agonizing Wait
abstract: With the death toll rising and rescuers still searching for people beneath the rubble, families were keeping a desperate watch over the site of an Israeli strike in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: After a nightlong vigil, with an untold number of hours of waiting still ahead, Najwa Qubaisi pushed away every relative who tried to coax her from the concrete skeleton of the building that had once been home to her grandson and his family.

headline: Eric Kim’s ‘Absolutely Amazing’ Pasta Alla Vodka (With Ricotta)
abstract: I adore this recipe, and so do thousands of readers.
lead_paragraph: Every time I’m tempted to mount my high horse and declare that I don’t need a recipe, I remind myself of the time I tried to make pasta alla vodka without any guidance. (You can probably guess where this is going.) I didn’t cook the sauce long enough, nor did I add enough cream to balance the vodka, and ended up with something like a warm Bloody Mary poured over pasta. It was certainly very boozy, but it wasn’t very delicious.

headline: Who Was Ahmed Wahbi, a Hezbollah Commander Killed in Israel’s Airstrike in Beirut?
abstract: The senior Hezbollah leader trained the group’s elite fighting unit and led its support for Hamas after the Oct. 7 attacks, the Lebanese militia said.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah said Saturday that Ahmed Wahbi, a commander it described as a leader and trainer in the group’s elite Radwan force, had been killed in an airstrike along with the force’s founding commander, Ibrahim Aqeel, and other Hezbollah members.

headline: Elon Musk’s X Backs Down in Brazil
abstract: In an abrupt reversal, the social network’s lawyers said it was complying with court orders that it had previously defied. Brazil’s Supreme Court could allow the site to return next week.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk suddenly appears to be giving up.

headline: Israeli Strike on Former School Kills 22, Gazan Health Officials Say
abstract: Gaza’s ministry of health said most of those killed in the strike on the Zeitoun School in Gaza City were women and children.
lead_paragraph: Israel said it struck a school-turned-shelter in Gaza City on Saturday because it believed Hamas militants were using the building as a command center. Palestinian health authorities said the attack killed 22 people, mostly women and children, who had sought shelter at the school, and did not confirm any combatant deaths.

headline: He Makes Less Than $15,000 and Is Trying to Hold Springfield, Ohio, Together
abstract: Mayor Rob Rue, whose job is supposed to be part time, finds himself dealing with bomb threats, false rumors and added pressures on city resources.
lead_paragraph: Bomb scares at elementary schools. A police dog checking the bushes outside City Hall. Threats against local officials.

headline: Earth’s Fall Equinox Ushers In Astronomical Autumn
abstract: During an equinox, places around the globe experience nearly equal amounts of daytime and nighttime. The second occurrence this year happens on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday, the autumnal equinox is upon us, and with it, a shift to shorter days, longer nights and the astronomical start of fall in the Northern Hemisphere.

headline: We Are Running Out of Firefighters at a Perilous Time
abstract: Congress should pass a spending bill to make a permanent pay increase a reality.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the United States was on the verge of a nightmare scenario. Several Western wildfires were raging at once. In California, San Bernardino County was in a state of emergency; the nearby Bridge fire had destroyed 54 structures, stretching the state’s resources thin. Smoldering fires were reigniting across Washington and Oregon, and the Davis fire bore down on ski resorts near Reno, Nev., burning 14 structures. There wasn’t a single elite operations unit available — the kind you call in to manage major wildfires.

headline: Billy Edd Wheeler, Songwriter Who Celebrated Rural Life, Dies at 91
abstract: His plain-spoken songs were recorded by Elvis Presley, Kenny Rogers and many others. The duo of Johnny Cash and June Carter made his “Jackson” a huge country hit.
lead_paragraph: Billy Edd Wheeler, an Appalachian folk singer who wrote vividly about rural life and culture in songs like “Jackson,” a barn-burning duet that was a hit in 1967 for June Carter and Johnny Cash as well as for Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazlewood, died on Monday at his home in Swannanoa, N.C., east of Asheville. He was 91.

headline: Liz Cheney Suggests a New Political Party May Be Needed
abstract: Ms. Cheney, a longtime Republican, said that the G.O.P. “has rejected the Constitution in the name of supporting Trump” and that Mike Johnson should not be speaker.
lead_paragraph: Former Representative Liz Cheney, who has emerged as perhaps the most vocal and visible conservative critic of former President Donald J. Trump, suggested on Friday night that a new political party might need to be created to replace the Republican Party if he is defeated.

headline: U.S. Soldier Pleads Guilty to Desertion After Fleeing Into North Korea
abstract: Pvt. Travis King on Friday pleaded guilty before a military judge to desertion, among other charges, after he made an unauthorized crossing into North Korea in 2023.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. Army soldier who had been detained in North Korea after he fled there in 2023 pleaded guilty to desertion, disobeying an order and assault at a hearing on Friday, according to the Army.

headline: Another Way of Looking at Jim Crow
abstract: The purpose of segregation was as much to weaken labor as it was to institutionalize race hierarchy.
lead_paragraph: In the first draft of my Wednesday column, I had a riff toward the end comparing the Trump campaign’s anti-Haitian rhetoric — and the extent to which it may have inspired bomb threats targeting the Haitian community of Springfield, Ohio — to the agitation and demagoguery of segregationist politicians in the Jim Crow South. As I refined the piece, I realized that the comparison, while apt, didn’t quite belong in the column. It detracted from the main thrust of the argument and may have done more to confuse than illuminate.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Board Ship Managed by Company of Vessel in Baltimore Bridge Collapse
abstract: The move comes three days after the Justice Department’s civil lawsuit against the owner and operator of the Dali, which struck the Francis Scott Key Bridge in March.
lead_paragraph: F.B.I. agents on Saturday boarded a container ship that is managed by the same parent company as the cargo vessel that collided with the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore in March, which had toppled the structure and killed six workers.

headline: Arizona Court Allows 98,000 to Vote in State and Local Races Despite Database Glitch
abstract: Officials recently discovered that some people with driver’s licenses issued before 1996 might not have proof of citizenship on file, a state requirement since 2004.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s Supreme Court ruled on Friday that nearly 100,000 residents whom officials could not verify were U.S. citizens because of an administrative glitch would remain eligible to vote in state and local elections in November.

headline: Macron Appoints Cabinet as He Seeks to Move France Out of Political Impasse
abstract: The government still faces two challenges in the coming weeks: the risk of a no-confidence vote and a tight budget deadline.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Saturday appointed a new cabinet that marked a strong shift to the right, in a nation so divided that it took more than two months to form a government whose prospects of long-term stability are far from clear.

headline: Biden Hosts a Final ‘Quad Summit’ at His Delaware Home
abstract: The president has often said that “all politics is personal.” On Saturday, he opened his home in Wilmington to the leaders of Australia, India and Japan.
lead_paragraph: President Biden hosted the leaders of Australia, India and Japan at his home in Wilmington, Del., this weekend, seeking to use his fourth and final “Quad summit” to cement the alliance between the United States and Indo-Pacific nations and to counter China’s rising influence in the region.

headline: Harris Agrees to a Second Debate, but Trump Declines
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris, who was widely seen as the winner of the Sept. 10 debate against former President Donald J. Trump, has accepted a debate invitation from CNN.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Saturday that she had accepted an invitation from CNN to participate in a second presidential debate next month, putting pressure on former President Donald J. Trump to join her for a rematch.

headline: Human Case of Rare Mosquito-Borne Illness Reported in New York State
abstract: A person in Ulster County has been hospitalized with Eastern equine encephalitis, health officials said. It is the first confirmed human case of the disease recorded in the state since 2015.
lead_paragraph: A person in New York has been hospitalized with Eastern equine encephalitis, a rare but serious mosquito-borne illness, the state’s Health Department said Friday.

headline: Leader of Kenya, Donor to Haiti Police Force, Makes First Visit
abstract: The trip by President William Ruto of Kenya came against a bleak backdrop in Haiti, where gangs operate with impunity and the Kenyan officers remain largely out of sight.
lead_paragraph: The president of Kenya visited Port-au-Prince on Saturday for his first tour of the base where an understaffed and ill-equipped contingent of nearly 400 of his country’s police officers are trying to bring peace to Haiti, nearly seven months after a gang uprising took thousands of lives and toppled the government.

headline: Robert Lansdorp, Coach of Tennis Champions, Is Dead at 85
abstract: His students, including Tracy Austin, Maria Sharapova, Pete Sampras and Lindsay Davenport, developed their ground strokes through his regimen of intense repetition.
lead_paragraph: Robert Lansdorp, a tennis coach whose focus on developing ground strokes through ceaseless repetition helped turn four of his students — Tracy Austin, Pete Sampras, Lindsay Davenport and Maria Sharapova — into No. 1-ranked players in the world, died on Monday in West Carson, Calif. He was 85.

headline: JD Vance to Appear With Tucker Carlson, Who Amplified False Holocaust Claims
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential nominee will share a stage with Mr. Carlson, who was criticized for interviewing a writer who falsely claimed the Holocaust was not an intentional act of genocide.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, candidates running for national office spent much of the general election distancing themselves from the fringes of their parties.

headline: A Week of Chaos Pushes Lebanon’s Doctors to the Limit
abstract: Exploding wireless devices maimed thousands. An Israeli airstrike on Friday flattened two buildings. Many doctors, exhausted, wonder how the country will cope if violence continues.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Dania El-Hallak was already exhausted. After wireless devices exploded across Lebanon, there had been little time to process what she had seen — the hundreds of wounded, many of their faces disfigured beyond recognition.

headline: Israeli Attacks in Lebanon Mark a Sharp Strategic Shift
abstract: The events of this week seem to indicate that Israel’s leaders have decided they can no longer live with the threat of Hezbollah on their northern border, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from a devastating Israeli airstrike on central Beirut rose to at least 37 on Saturday, with the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah confirming that two of its senior commanders were among those killed. Dozens more were wounded in the strikes, which leveled two apartment buildings and plunged Lebanon into further chaos days after pagers and walkie-talkies belonging to Hezbollah members exploded en masse.

headline: Newsom Signs Bill That Adds Protections for Children on Social Media
abstract: The California legislation comes amid growing concerns about the impact of cellphones and social media on adolescents’ mental health.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed legislation on Friday aimed at protecting minors from social media addiction amid growing concerns about the impact of technology on adolescents’ mental health.

headline: Breakout Performance
abstract: Jeremy Newton and Tracy Gray’s puzzle offers a great escape.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: For Americans Haunted by Beirut Bombings, a Killing Resurfaces Decades of Pain
abstract: The death of a Hezbollah leader wanted for his role in the 1983 attacks drew a range of reactions from survivors and victims’ families but brought little resolution.
lead_paragraph: Two deadly bombings in Beirut, Lebanon, that killed scores of U.S. military personnel more than 40 years ago have cast a long shadow over survivors and victims’ families.

headline: At a Rally in North Carolina, Trump Avoids Topic A: Mark Robinson
abstract: The former president did not mention Mr. Robinson, the state’s embattled Republican nominee for governor, whom he once called “Martin Luther King on steroids.”
lead_paragraph: Through an awkward quirk of scheduling former President Donald J. Trump found himself headlining a rally in North Carolina on Saturday just two days after the man he endorsed to become the state’s next governor, Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, was accused of making a series of disturbing posts on a pornographic website.

headline: Daniel J. Evans, 98, Washington State Governor Who Went to Senate, Dies
abstract: A moderate Republican, he championed education, civil rights and environmental causes as a three-term governor and on Capitol Hill. He was eyed as a potential vice president.
lead_paragraph: Daniel J. Evans, a moderate Republican who dominated Washington State politics as a three-term governor and a United States senator and who was repeatedly considered for the vice presidency, died on Friday night at his home in Seattle, about five blocks from where he grew up. He was 98.

headline: Trump’s Base in North Carolina Still Supports Mark Robinson, but Some Doubt He Can Win
abstract: At a Trump rally in Wilmington, N.C., many said they would still vote for the embattled Republican nominee for governor.
lead_paragraph: Faithful supporters of former President Donald J. Trump lined up on Saturday afternoon to cheer him on at a rally at the Aero Center in Wilmington, N.C., their red shirts billowing from a beachside breeze.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Understated Woman’s Wound in Subway Shooting, Lawyer Says
abstract: Kerry Gahalal, who was struck when officers shot a knife-wielding man at a Brooklyn station, was not simply “grazed” as officials said, according to a lawyer for the woman’s family.
lead_paragraph: A 26-year-old woman who was wounded when New York City police officers shot a knife-wielding man at a Brooklyn subway station was not “grazed” by gunfire as officials have said, according to a lawyer for her family. Instead, the lawyer said on Saturday, she has a bullet lodged in her leg and is unable to walk.

headline: New Dynamics of Race Test Georgia’s Status as a Swing State
abstract: Many voters in the Atlanta suburbs were newly hopeful when Vice President Kamala Harris entered the race. But conservative values are still deeply rooted in the state.
lead_paragraph: Many voters in the Atlanta suburbs were newly hopeful when Vice President Kamala Harris entered the race. But conservative values are still deeply rooted in the state.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 22, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sept. 1 about the charter city Próspera incorrectly described how council elections work there. While land ownership currently gives residents the right to vote for certain seats on Próspera’s council, residents do not need to own land in order to vote at all.

headline: Buildings in Suburban Beirut Badly Damaged by Israeli Strike
abstract: Crews in southern Lebanon sifted through rubble a day after an Israeli attack that targeted a meeting of Hezbollah commanders. The airstrike killed at least 37 people, Lebanon’s health ministry said.
lead_paragraph: Crews in southern Lebanon sifted through rubble a day after an Israeli attack that targeted a meeting of Hezbollah commanders. The airstrike killed at least 37 people, Lebanon’s health ministry said.

headline: Leftist Leader Elected President as Sri Lanka Rejects the Old Order
abstract: Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s strong showing reveals voter weariness with leadership that has led to a national economic crisis and crushing hardship for many people.
lead_paragraph: The Marxist candidate, Anura Kumara Dissanayake, was elected president of Sri Lanka on Sunday, riding a wave of popular anger at the established political order that ran the South Asian nation’s economy into the ground.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Grabbing School Gear in Case of a Shooting
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “People say, ‘Oh, you’re just profiting off the carnage.’ And you know what I say? ‘Look, don’t blame me. I’m just the fire extinguisher manufacturer, OK?’”

headline: What to Watch For in a Key German State Election
abstract: The far right and far left are poised to make significant gains in state voting on Sunday, possibly affecting the stability of the national government in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Voters are going to the polls on Sunday for state elections in Brandenburg, the eastern German state that surrounds Berlin like a doughnut, in a regional contest that could affect the stability of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government.

headline: A French Fair as Workers’ Paradise, Feting Cuisine, Music and Communism
abstract: The Fête de l’Humanité, a blend of Burning Man, Woodstock and a political convention, attracts the masses with bands, lectures and food, but here K.F.C. is C.F.K.: Communist Fried Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Christine Marlier was angry when President Emmanuel Macron called a snap election this summer. She’s even angrier now that he appointed a right-wing prime minister, despite the fact that a leftist bloc won the most seats in Parliament.

headline: Interim N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Says Federal Agents Searched His Homes
abstract: Thomas G. Donlon, who took the interim role after Edward A. Caban resigned earlier this month, said the authorities had seized material unrelated to the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s interim police commissioner said late Saturday that federal agents had searched his homes and seized material from them the day before.

headline: Heavy Rain in Japan Causes Deadly Flooding and Landslides
abstract: One person is dead and seven others are missing in Noto Peninsula, Japanese news media reported. The region is still recovering from a catastrophic earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Record rainfall in Japan’s Noto Peninsula caused deadly flooding and landslides in a region still recovering from a catastrophic earthquake earlier this year, the national broadcaster NHK reported on Sunday.

headline: ‘I Told Myself Not to Judge a Book by Its Cover and Sat Down Next to Him’
abstract: Pleasantly surprised on the subway, an invisible helper appears and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Venezuelan Gang’s Path to U.S. Stokes Fear, Crime and Border Politics
abstract: Tren de Aragua’s emergence in New York City and elsewhere has led law enforcement officials to strategize how to stem the gang’s growth.
lead_paragraph: At the country’s southern border, U.S. Border Patrol agents have been on the lookout for members of a notorious Venezuelan gang. In the nation’s heartland, police officers from Denver to Chicago have made dozens of arrests for alleged crimes linked to the group, from retail theft to murder and prostitution.

headline: A Note From Irving Berlin, the ‘Nation’s Songwriter’
abstract: The lyricist and composer wrote thousands of compositions — and one stern letter to The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Few songwriters and composers were as prolific as Irving Berlin, whose vast musical catalog includes well-known songs such as “Puttin’ on the Ritz,” “Cheek to Cheek” and “Anything You Can Do (I Can Do Better).” By some accounts, he wrote well over 1,200 songs during his career, including the scores for 18 films and 19 Broadway shows.

headline: 4 Killed in Shooting Near University of Alabama at Birmingham
abstract: Gunmen shot into a group of people in a popular entertainment district in what appeared to be a targeted attack, the police said. The authorities are still looking for the shooters.
lead_paragraph: Gunmen opened fire in a popular entertainment district in Birmingham, Ala., on Saturday night, killing four people and wounding at least 17 others in what appeared to be a targeted attack, the police said. The authorities said they were still looking for the shooters.

headline: Israel’s Military Closes Al Jazeera’s Office in the West Bank
abstract: The Israeli authorities have been putting pressure on the local operations of the network, saying its coverage threatens national security.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military raided the office of the influential Arab broadcaster Al Jazeera in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Sunday and ordered its closure for 45 days, the latest move in Israel’s effort to clamp down on the channel.

headline: Widowed, 60, Seeking Affection
abstract: “The Golden Bachelorette” offers a glimpse at how dating changes after losing the love of your life. This is what it’s really like.
lead_paragraph: Four months after her husband of 30 years died in 2012, Kathryn Shephard Cowan went on a date to the symphony with a man who seemed perfectly nice.

headline: What Happened When an Ohio Megachurch Decided to Tackle Racism
abstract: In “Undivided,” the political scientist Hahrie Han follows members of a mostly white congregation that resolved to fight bias and promote racial justice.
lead_paragraph: Crossroads Church in Cincinnati has a style that stands out for its flash and irreverence even among its megachurch peers. At one Easter service, a production team shot confetti from the stage and presented a large cake with icing studded with communion wafers. “Jesus is alive!” they announced. “It’s a party!”

headline: How Trump Could Upend Taxation in America
abstract: With slogans and in social-media posts, the former president has dribbled out ideas that, together, would fundamentally change how taxes are collected in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: At the start of the summer, when former President Donald J. Trump visited Republicans on Capitol Hill, he hinted at a vision for a vastly different tax system than what the United States has employed for decades.

headline: Only Connect: Meredith Monk’s Antidote to What Divides Us
abstract: “Indra’s Net,” coming to the Park Avenue Armory, shows off the polymathic Monk’s artistry as she enters her 60th season as a performer and creator.
lead_paragraph: As the story goes, Indra, the king of the gods, takes a net and stretches it across the universe. At each joint is a jewel, unique and infinitely faceted, that reflects all the others in an endless web of interdependence.

headline: Harris Cracked Down on Violent Offenders; Showed Leniency on Less Serious Crime
abstract: Her record as a prosecutor navigating both paths has left her open to criticism that she either betrayed liberal ideals or prioritized them over law and order.
lead_paragraph: From the moment that Kamala Harris took her place among 57 counterparts at the 2004 California District Attorneys Association annual conference, it was an open question how, if at all, the first Black, Asian American and female D.A. in the state’s history would fit in.

headline: The Tumult That Transformed Racquet, the Tennis Magazine
abstract: The indie magazine Racquet aims to become a major player in the business of tennis — after a messy dispute between its two founders.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Open looked like fun and games for Racquet magazine.

headline: First He Spoke for the Trees; Now He Speaks for the Sea
abstract: The wonders of the ocean and the terrors of A.I. meet in a Richard Powers’s new novel, which considers the future of an environmentally challenged Polynesian island.
lead_paragraph: The ecological novel has become a staple of contemporary fiction, and rightly so. When people aren’t really listening to the drumbeat of scientists, it’s essential that our best authors take up their sticks as well. Heck, bang a cymbal.

headline: This Shark Lives 400 Years. Its DNA May Explain Why.
abstract: Scientists have mapped the genome of the Greenland shark, which could offer clues to the animal’s extreme longevity.
lead_paragraph: The Greenland shark is not exactly charismatic. Its hulking frame is covered by sandpaper skin. Its fins, stunted, sit awkwardly along its sides. And its eyes, perpetually cloudy, are often host to wormlike parasites that dangle as the shark slowly roams the depths of the North Atlantic and Arctic oceans.

headline: At a Remote Scottish Pub, a Pint Worth Hiking 20 Miles
abstract: The Old Forge on the rugged peninsula of Knoydart is a community-owned meeting point for locals and visitors — at least those willing to trek across the wilderness.
lead_paragraph: The simple pleasure of a hot pub meal and a cold pint can be found just down the street for most people in Britain. Then, there is The Old Forge: perhaps the most remote pub on the mainland, lying at the end of a multiday wilderness hike through craggy mountains and glistening lochs.

headline: In Michigan, Democrats Hope to Benefit From a Post-Biden Surge of Youth Energy
abstract: Democrats in the battleground state are counting on a sea change in the mood of young voters that could bolster their candidates in critical races that will determine who controls Congress.
lead_paragraph: When the Michigan State University College Democrats held their weekly meetings last spring at a sprawling residential hall on campus, organizers were lucky if they could get more than 30 students to show up.

headline: For Mideast Foes, Diplomacy Takes a Back Seat to Military Force
abstract: After years of failed deals and tit-for-tat violence, neither the Israelis nor the Palestinians believe their adversaries will ever negotiate in good faith.
lead_paragraph: The last, best chance for a peace plan between Israel and the Palestinian authorities came in 2008. Then-Prime Minister Ehud Olmert was prepared to give up territory in the West Bank, and allow some refugees to reclaim land. He was even willing to relinquish control of Jerusalem’s Old City to an international committee as part of recognizing Palestine as a sovereign state.

headline: A Changed Montana May Decide Control of the U.S. Senate
abstract: Republicans are trying to seize control of the U.S. Senate by ousting Jon Tester, the last Democrat holding statewide office in a state that not long ago had many of them.
lead_paragraph: For much of his life, Randy Gray knew his hometown in northern Montana, Great Falls, as a stronghold for Democrats.

headline: The Surprising Reality of Political Violence in America
abstract: After two apparent assassination attempts against Donald J. Trump, it’s easy to think our politics are becoming more violent. The research is not so clear.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump was nearly assassinated in Pennsylvania in July, a Dartmouth political scientist named Sean Westwood happened to be in the middle of a research project asking Americans about political violence.

headline: U.N. Meets Amid a Backdrop of Growing Chaos and Violence
abstract: Beginning Tuesday, world leaders will discuss three wars, climate change, rising sea levels and proposals to expand representation on the Security Council.
lead_paragraph: When the United Nations General Assembly convenes on Tuesday, attention will focus on the major wars raging in Ukraine, Gaza and Sudan, amid a reckoning that neither the global body nor world powers have been able to end the violence.

headline: Drugs, Sex, Baby Oil: The ‘Freak-Offs’ at the Core of Sean Combs’s Troubles
abstract: Prosecutors say the sexual encounters in hotel rooms were coercive and abusive and are the heart of their sex trafficking case. The music mogul’s lawyers call them consensual.
lead_paragraph: A woman and a male prostitute gather for sex in a luxury hotel suite that, in the government’s telling, has been lit for filming and stocked with baby oil and drugs. Another man watches and sometimes captures the events on video. These sexual marathons, complete with a cleanup staff, sometimes went on for days.

headline: Kelsey Grammer Analyzes 40 Years of Frasier: ‘I Have Nothing to Regret’
abstract: The actor has been playing the snobby psychiatrist off and on since 1984 and has no plans to stop. He thinks the current “Frasier” reboot “could last another decade.”
lead_paragraph: Kelsey Grammer likes his raw meat cut very fine. On a recent afternoon, at the restaurant of a Midtown hotel, he requested that his steak tartare be put through the grinder twice. He wanted it, he said, like velvet. The tartare, topped with its quail egg, was presented roughly chopped. “I’ll deal with it,” Grammer said uncomplainingly.

headline: A Republican and a Democrat Sit Across From Each Other. There’s No Punchline.
abstract: One Small Step, an initiative that facilitates conversations between people with opposing views, is trying to tackle political polarization.
lead_paragraph: Alton Russell is a white, 85-year-old toilet paper salesman from Columbus, Ga., where for years he was the chair of the local Republican Party. Wane Hailes is a Black, 68-year-old newspaper owner from Columbus, where he formerly served as the president of the city’s chapter of the N.A.A.C.P.

headline: The Politics of Motherhood Become a Campaign-Trail Cudgel
abstract: The presidential race has exposed a fault line in American political culture over the deeply personal decision to have children.
lead_paragraph: She is not humble. She has no stake in the future of the country. She and other childless women are looking down on Americans who have chosen to reproduce.

headline: A Surprise Season of Stranger Things
abstract: Standout shows from Bally and Bottega Veneta bring Milan Fashion Week to a close. Gucci, Versace and Moschino do some recycling.
lead_paragraph: And thus began the season of the weird. After decades in which clothes that telegraphed sex or stealth wealth dominated the Milanese runways, it’s the stranger things that seem the most on target now.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,192
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A Princeton Professor’s Advice to Young Conservatives
abstract: Grievance is not a good foundation for an identity.
lead_paragraph: As a professor who is known to dissent from progressive ideologies that are dominant at universities such as Princeton, where I’ve taught for nearly 40 years, I’m frequently asked by students for advice about how to navigate a campus they worry will be hostile to them. Some are pro-Israel, or politically and socially conservative, or religiously observant.

headline: Want to End Poverty? Focus on One Thing.
abstract: Electrifying the world could produce the largest development gains since the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, world leaders made an ambitious, unanimous commitment to help developing nations improve their prospects in health, employment, nutrition and access to affordable and clean energy by 2030. Every September, the United Nations and others assess how much progress has been made.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 470
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Sept. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: MAGA Wants Transgression, and This Is What Comes With It
abstract: Want more Mark Robinsons? Vote for Trump.
lead_paragraph: The North Carolina Republican Party is facing one of the most predictable crises in the history of party politics.

headline: The MAGA Movement Has Become a Problem for Trump
abstract: He can no longer run as if he were a man alone.
lead_paragraph: In 2024, the deep state that defeats Donald Trump might be his own.

headline: Israel’s Pager Attacks Have Changed the World
abstract: Our supply chains are vulnerable, which means that we are vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s brazen attacks on Hezbollah last week, in which hundreds of pagers and two-way radios exploded and killed at least 37 people, graphically illustrated a threat that cybersecurity experts have been warning about for years: Our international supply chains for computerized equipment leave us vulnerable. And we have no good means to defend ourselves.

headline: These Two Rape Cases Are a Lot Closer to Home Than We Like to Admit
abstract: It’s easy to miss how much these cases have in common with everyday reality.
lead_paragraph: I was raped in college by an ostensibly nice guy who was not a stranger to me. I think that’s a banal statement of fact, but if that sentence makes you uncomfortable, I understand why. I describe it this way to point out how common my experience is. We regard rape in the public dialogue as an exceptional event, something that happens only in extraordinary situations. Pop culture — police procedurals in particular — has taught viewers to think of “real” rape as a thing that strangers do in dark alleys. But the reality is that most sexual assaults happen in situations where the victims know their attackers.

headline: Explosion at an Iranian Mine Kills Dozens, State Media Says
abstract: A methane leak set off the explosion, the country’s official media said, and a rescue effort was underway for those believed to be trapped in the mine.
lead_paragraph: A methane explosion at a coal mine in eastern Iran killed dozens of miners, and the death toll was expected to rise, Iranian state media said on Sunday.

headline: Congo Releases More Than 700 Inmates After a Deadly Stampede
abstract: At least 129 people died when inmates tried to escape from Makala Prison, where conditions are abysmal and overcrowding is a major problem.
lead_paragraph: More than 700 inmates were released from the largest prison in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the country’s authorities said on Saturday, as officials sought to ease overcrowding in a facility where at least 129 people died in an attempted jailbreak this month.

headline: An Escape from the Front Line in Ukraine
abstract: An excerpt from one of the most ambitious stories in The Times Magazine’s history.
lead_paragraph: Today, The New York Times Magazine published one of the most ambitious stories in its long history — an account of a Russian military officer’s desertion and escape. Sarah Topol spent over a year and a half investigating the Russian military and reporting in eight countries across four continents.

headline: Videos Show Hezbollah Missile Hit Residential Area in Northern Israel
abstract: An overnight barrage included around 150 rockets, cruise missiles and drones, Israel’s military said. Air defenses intercepted most, but the town of Kiryat Bialik suffered a direct hit.
lead_paragraph: A missile fired by Hezbollah slammed into a residential neighborhood in the Israeli town of Kiryat Bialik on Sunday morning, setting cars and a building ablaze and blowing out the windows of nearby apartments, numerous videos verified by The New York Times show.

headline: Pan-Seared Chicken With Harissa, Dates and Citrus
abstract: Sweet and sour with a peppery kick you can mellow out with dollops of yogurt.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. An hour before noon in the Hudson Valley, fog burning off the river in the sun, and it seemed entirely appropriate to tack east from the Catskill foothills toward Poughkeepsie and an early lunch from Rossi & Sons, where the muffuletta sub is beyond compare.

headline: Charging the Parents of Mass Shooters
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay criticizing charges against Colin Gray. Also: Jan. 6; turmoil in Central America; learning from dogs; blindness and courage.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On the Trail, Trump and Vance Sharpen a Nativist, Anti-Immigrant Tone
abstract: From calling for mass deportations to spreading false claims about migrants’ eating pets, former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, are taking a hard line.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump warned supporters on Saturday in Wilmington, N.C., that immigrants were “taking your jobs,” his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, campaigned about 500 miles north in Leesport, Pa., where he told his crowd that immigrants were taking their homes — and their children’s homes.

headline: The Heavy Toll of Desertion From the Russian Army
abstract: Here is what we can learn about the Russian military and its soldiers from the story of ‘Ivan’ and ‘Anna’ in The New York Times Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year and a half, I reported from eight countries across four continents, including more than a year interviewing 18 deserters of the Russian military, for my story “The Deserter.” Together, their experiences gave me a vivid picture of the Russian war operation, its corruption, its chaos and its brutality. The deserters also gave me a window into how they found themselves fighting in the first place and why they then took the extreme measure to flee. My story focuses on one deserter named Ivan and his wife, Anna — pseudonyms we used for their protection.

headline: More Than 700 Current and Former National Security Officials Back Harris
abstract: A letter signed by former secretaries of state and defense endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris and said former President Donald J. Trump poses a threat to the nation’s defense and its democratic system.
