lead_paragraph: More than 700 current and former national security leaders, as well as former military officials, endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris in a letter released on Sunday, arguing that only she had the temperament and values needed to serve as commander in chief.

headline: In a Hezbollah-Dominated Area of Beirut, a Mix of Defiance and Unease
abstract: Many residents of Dahiya were grappling with uncertainty over what comes next.
lead_paragraph: The funeral drew thousands into the streets of the Hezbollah-dominated neighborhood in Beirut’s southern suburbs on Sunday afternoon, where many mourners shook their fists and proudly waved the armed group’s yellow flag. They had gathered to commemorate Ibrahim Aqeel and Mahmoud Hamad, two Hezbollah commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike last week.

headline: For the Children of Architects, Filmmaking as Therapy
abstract: Jim Venturi shines a light on his parents, the postmodern innovators Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown. How architects’ hidden lives are often revealed by kids.
lead_paragraph: Why have so many children of architects made films about their parents?

headline: Two Outer Banks Homes Collapse Into the Ocean in North Carolina
abstract: Nine homes in the area have been lost to the ocean in the past four years because of rising seas and storms that erode shorelines.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina park officials were warning visitors to avoid the beaches of the Outer Banks in Rodanthe this weekend after two houses collapsed into the ocean within hours of each other.

headline: Mercury Morris, Elusive Rusher on a Perfect Dolphins Team, Dies at 77
abstract: Part of a talented backfield triumvirate that also included Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick, he helped lead Miami to two Super Bowls and an undefeated season.
lead_paragraph: Mercury Morris, who gave speed and dexterity to the rushing attack of the Miami Dolphins in the early 1970s, helping to power the team to two Super Bowls victories and the only perfect season in the history of the National Football League, died on Saturday night. He was 77.

headline: Controversies Erupt as Trump and G.O.P. Make Critical Push to Voters
abstract: A Republican who reportedly called himself a “Black Nazi,” a false story about migrants eating cats and dogs, and a feud with Taylor Swift bring back a sense of chaos.
lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of a head-spinning presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump’s campaign over the past two weeks has been tumultuous.

headline: Tongsun Park, Lobbyist Scarred by Koreagate Scandal, Dies at 89
abstract: An amiable Korean-born graduate of Georgetown University, he was imprisoned after a second scandal involving the U.N.
lead_paragraph: Tongsun Park, an urbane, amiable international lobbyist who stood at the center of two bribery scandals separated by nearly 30 years, and who was once a Gatsby-like figure in Washington whose flamboyant parties were attended by lawmakers, officials and the occasional Hollywood celebrity, died on Thursday in Seoul. He was 89.

headline: Northern Israel Braces for More Attacks From Hezbollah
abstract: Residents of Kiryat Bialik, a community near Haifa, were feeling vulnerable as the back-and-forth attacks escalated recently between Hezbollah and the Israeli military.
lead_paragraph: Even before Hezbollah launched more than 100 rockets, cruise missiles and drones toward northern Israel on Sunday, people who lived in the area feared they would be targeted.

headline: Hezbollah Retaliates Against Israel With Rocket Barrage
abstract: Hezbollah fired more than 100 rockets, drones and missiles into Israeli territory on Sunday morning. The attack came in response to strikes on militia members in Lebanon last week.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah fired more than 100 rockets, drones and missiles into Israeli territory on Sunday morning. The attack came in response to strikes on militia members in Lebanon last week.

headline: Criticizing Oprah, Trump Falsely Claims He Appeared on Her Show’s Final Week
abstract: As he took aim at Oprah Winfrey’s interview of Vice President Kamala Harris, former President Donald J. Trump repeated a debunked claim that he was one of the show’s last guests.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump vented Saturday night about Oprah Winfrey’s recent interview with Vice President Kamala Harris, he resurrected a false claim that he had made before: that he appeared on the last week of Ms. Winfrey’s television show.

headline: Some Palm Beach Ballots Misspelled Tim Walz’s Name as ‘Tom’
abstract: Officials in Palm Beach County, Fla., said that they had emailed 257 ballots to overseas voters before catching the error and correcting it.
lead_paragraph: When elections officials in Palm Beach County, Fla., emailed ballots last week to military and overseas voters, they failed to notice a typographical error: The name of Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, the Democratic nominee for vice president, was misspelled as “Tom Walz.”

headline: Kathryn Crosby, Actress and Bing Crosby’s Widow, Dies at 90
abstract: She was a Texas-born starlet when she married the beloved crooner, but put aside her career at his urging.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Crosby, a Texas-born beauty queen and aspiring actress who put aside her movie career when she married Bing Crosby, the movie star and honey-voiced baritone, died on Friday at her home in Hillsborough, Calif. She was 90.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Threats
abstract: Plus, a Russian military officer’s story of desertion and escape.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said yesterday that Israel would take “whatever action is necessary” to diminish the threat posed by Hezbollah, while its deputy leader warned that the conflict was entering “a new stage.”

headline: The German Chancellor’s Party Ekes Out a Win Over the Far Right
abstract: The narrow win by Olaf Scholz’s party came in a state election, the third in a series that was seen as a reflection of the national mood and a snapshot of the government’s popularity.
lead_paragraph: The embattled center-left party of Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany scored a hard-fought and narrow victory over the far-right ethnonationalist party, Alternative für Deutschland, or AfD, in an election in an eastern state of the country, potentially energizing Mr. Scholz’s government in Berlin.

headline: Israel and Hezbollah Threaten to Hit Harder, Raising Fears of All-Out War
abstract: A leader of the Iranian-backed militia said its latest barrage was “just the beginning,” and an Israeli military official said, “Our strikes will intensify.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and a top Hezbollah leader vowed on Sunday to increase the intensity of their cross-border attacks, raising fears that the renewed conflict could escalate into all-out war.

headline: College Investigating Report of a Student Scratching a Racial Slur on Another
abstract: A family says their son, a member of the swim team at Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania, was victimized when a teammate etched the slur across his chest with a box cutter.
lead_paragraph: School administrators at a small liberal arts college in Pennsylvania are investigating a report of a student scratching a racial slur onto another student’s chest at an on-campus residence this month.

headline: Congress Unveils Short-Term Spending Deal
abstract: Speaker Mike Johnson dropped his demands for proof-of-citizenship voting requirements to strike a deal that includes more money for the Secret Service and funds the government through Dec. 20.
lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders from both parties unveiled a short-term agreement to fund the government on Sunday, after Speaker Mike Johnson abandoned demands for a longer-term deal that also included new proof-of-citizenship requirements for voter registration.

headline: Position of Intense Scrutiny
abstract: Freddie Cheng experiments with the initial phase of constructing.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Top Aides Resign From Embattled North Carolina Candidate’s Campaign
abstract: Most of the senior staff members on Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson’s campaign for North Carolina governor resigned on Sunday after reports that he had made a series of disturbing online comments.
lead_paragraph: Most of the senior staff members on Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson’s campaign for North Carolina governor resigned on Sunday, dealing a seismic blow to the embattled Republican who has faced widespread criticism after an explosive CNN report that he had made a series of disturbing comments on a pornographic website.

headline: Cat Missing in Yellowstone Returns Home to California After an 800-Mile Trek
abstract: The owners of Rayne Beau, the 2-year-old Siamese cat, have no idea how their cat made it back, but call his return a “miracle.”
lead_paragraph: When a cat dashed into the woods of Yellowstone National Park during a camping trip in June, his California owners, Benny and Susanne Anguiano, thought they’d never see him again.

headline: ‘He Saved Many Lives’: Small Kentucky Community Mourns Slain Judge
abstract: The fatal shooting of the judge has rocked the town of Whitesburg. On Sunday, friends, family and community members gathered to remember the victim.
lead_paragraph: As a rural Kentucky town reeled from the fatal shooting of a judge, residents over the weekend mourned the victim whom many saw as a kind man who loved his community.

headline: My Senior Year
abstract: Kids feeling the pressure and hype to make their final year of high school as good as the movies.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Harris Campaign Says It Took In $27 Million at Wall Street Fund-Raiser
abstract: The campaign said it was the vice president’s highest-grossing fund-raiser since she ascended to the top of the Democratic ticket.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris does not have much time to drop into living rooms or small cities for fund-raisers these days. But in the homestretch of the presidential race, finance events like the one she attended on Sunday are worth it.

headline: Florida Sheriff’s Deputy Charged in Fatal Shooting of His Girlfriend
abstract: Leslie Boileau, a sheriff’s deputy in Marion County, Fla., said that he had “accidentally discharged” a loaded gun at his girlfriend, as they were cleaning and dry-firing guns during a lesson.
lead_paragraph: A sheriff’s deputy in Florida has been charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of his girlfriend, the police said.

headline: On Chicago’s South Side, White Sox Fans Know Misery. But Not Like This.
abstract: The baseball team tied the modern day record for losses on Sunday, dropping a 120th game. In the team’s most loyal neighborhood, some people couldn’t bear to watch.
lead_paragraph: It was the bottom of the second inning on Sunday afternoon before Lauren Eaves, the bartender at BallPark Pub in the Bridgeport neighborhood of Chicago, remembered to turn one of the bar’s six flat-screen TVs to the White Sox game.

headline: No Corrections: Sept. 23, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 23, 2024
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Threats
abstract: Plus, a Russian military officer’s story of desertion and escape.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said yesterday that Israel would take “whatever action is necessary” to diminish the threat posed by Hezbollah, while its deputy leader warned that the conflict was entering “a new stage.”

headline: Britain’s Prime Minister, Bruised by a Dispute Over Freebies, Badly Needs a Reset
abstract: The Labour Party’s annual conference should have been a jubilant occasion. But Keir Starmer is on the defensive after intense scrutiny of gifts that he and his wife accepted.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s Labour Party won a whopping parliamentary majority in Britain’s election in July, it was with only 34 percent of the vote, leading one commentator to call it a “loveless landslide.” Now, some allies of Mr. Starmer worry that he is going too far in returning the favor.

headline: Quote of the Day: An Annual Festival That Is a True Communist Party
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We were married in the Cuba booth, had our wine reception in the People’s Republic of China booth.”

headline: Forced From Home by War, They Found Solace in Soccer
abstract: For dozens of women who fled Myanmar and settled in Thailand, soccer has become a refuge from both the troubles of daily life and conservative cultural norms.
lead_paragraph: It was just a regular practice, but the players were excited to get on the soccer field. They divided into teams and chose from an array of bibs that all bore the same message: “Women Win.”

headline: Putin Is Doing Something Almost Nobody Is Noticing
abstract: It’s not just opposition figures who are caught in the Kremlin’s dragnet.
lead_paragraph: In November 2022 my editors asked me to be careful about what I ate and stop ordering takeout. Initially, I didn’t think much of it. But I soon realized the importance of their advice when, just one month later, my colleague Elena Kostyuchenko discovered she had been poisoned in Germany, in a probable assassination attempt by the Russian state.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Lots of Medical and Police Dramas
abstract: ABC, NBC and Fox are all premiering new shows about doctors, cops or firefighters. The Voice is also returning, with Snoop Dogg joining the judges’ panel.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Sept. 23-29. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Deadly Rainfall and Landslides Strike Japan
abstract: Record levels of rain fell on Japan’s Noto Peninsula, turning buildings into piles of debris and neighborhoods into streams of floodwaters.
lead_paragraph: Record levels of rain fell on Japan’s Noto Peninsula, turning buildings into piles of debris and neighborhoods into streams of floodwaters.

headline: Word of the Day: conscious
abstract: This word has appeared in 792 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word conscious has appeared in 792 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 3 in “Keeping the Spirit of Harlem Dance Alive” by Imani Perry:

headline: 6 Dead in Japan After Record Rainfall Causes Flooding
abstract: The downpour drenched the Noto Peninsula on Saturday, triggering landslides and washing away people and homes, Japan’s national broadcaster said.
lead_paragraph: Six people have died after a record amount of rain triggered flooding and landslides in a coastal region in Japan still recovering from a deadly earthquake earlier this year, according to local authorities.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Secret Weapon to Fight Flooding Is Hidden in Plain Sight
abstract: It looks like and feels like a regular street. But beneath the surface, six layers are working to keep rainwater from overwhelming New York City neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: They’ve Got a Plan to Fight Global Warming. It Could Alter the Oceans.
abstract: By tweaking the chemistry of rivers and oceans, humans could remove billions of tons of carbon dioxide from the air. But huge challenges loom.
lead_paragraph: In a quiet patch of forest in Nova Scotia, a company is building a machine designed to help slow global warming by transforming Earth’s rivers and oceans into giant sponges that absorb carbon dioxide from the air.

abstract: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll of 713 registered voters in Arizona conducted from Sept. 17 to 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll of 713 registered voters in Arizona conducted from Sept. 17 to 21, 2024.

lead_paragraph: Results of a New York Times/Siena College poll of 682 registered voters in North Carolina conducted from Sept. 17 to 21, 2024.

lead_paragraph: Results of New York Times/Siena College polls of 2,077 likely voters in North Carolina, Georgia and Arizona conducted from Sept. 17 to 21, 2024.

headline: Should I Get a Hybrid or Go Full Electric?
abstract: Here’s what to know if you’re in the market for a climate-friendly vehicle.
lead_paragraph: For many car buyers, hybrids seem like a great compromise between gasoline and electric vehicles. Hybrids, which combine internal combustion engines and electric motors, produce less pollution and use less fuel than conventional automobiles. And, owners never need to worry about running out of battery power on a lonely highway.

headline: How Healthy Are Apples?
abstract: They’re America’s most popular fruit. Here’s why that’s a great thing.
lead_paragraph: “An apple a day” might seem like overkill, but America’s most popular fruit — currently weighing down branches in orchards everywhere — is packed with health benefits. Here’s what nutrition experts have to say about apples, plus some recipes from New York Times Cooking to help you eat more of them all year long.

headline: They Wish N.Y.C. Were ‘Less Expensive,’ but They Have Big Theater Dreams
abstract: Two young actors were prepared to work hard to make it in New York theater. The rental market proved to be cutthroat.
lead_paragraph: It all started last June, with a trip to New York City to see an Off Broadway play, “The Comeuppance” by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins.

headline: Can a Scotch Egg Be Fancy?
abstract: Plus: a new ski-in, ski-out hotel in the French Alps, titanium watches and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: While there are countless ways to cook eggs, chefs currently seem fixated on the most hedonistic option: hard boiling and then coating them in a layer of ground meat before breading and frying them. Known as Scotch eggs, the treats are said to have been pioneered by the London epicurean shop Fortnum & Mason in 1738, after which they quickly became a fixture of British pub cuisine. The chef Ed Szymanski, 31, of Lord’s in New York recalls the Scotch eggs he encountered growing up in London as both ubiquitous and “quite bad.” His version features Madras-style spiced lamb in place of the usual pork sausage. “It’s like a supercharged croquette with an egg in the middle,” he says. In Seattle, the chef Sean Arakaki, 30, is also seeking to elevate the flavors of his childhood. Born and raised in Hawaii, he grew up eating loco moco: a hamburger patty served over gravy-drenched white rice with a sunny-side-up egg. At Itsumono, his restaurant in Seattle’s Japantown, his loco moco Scotch egg arrives atop rice and gravy with a side of macaroni salad. “You cut through the crumb to get to a runny yolk,” he says. For his Portland, Ore., food cart Tokyo Sando, the owner Taiki Nakajima, 36, makes a rendition with ajitama — soy-marinated boiled eggs — enveloped in a gyoza-inspired mix of ground pork and chicken with ginger and soy. Encrusted with panko and deep-fried, the eggs are sandwiched between slices of Japanese bread with mayo, roasted black garlic and cabbage. And in Mumbai, India, the chef Hussain Shahzad, 37, of O Pedro wraps his version in chile- and vinegar-laced ground lamb, drizzling on vindaloo sauce when the egg comes out of the fryer. “It’s not a monotonous dish,” he says. “You get crisp crust, juiciness from the meat and the runny yolk … playing on the palate at the same time. There are so many layers to it.” — Mehr Singh

headline: In Bali, a House That Taught a Fashion Executive How to Relax
abstract: At his Japanese-inspired villa, the cofounder of Maison Kitsuné has found pleasure in letting go.
lead_paragraph: “I USED TO be very good with stress,” says Gildas Loaëc, the chief executive officer and co-founder of the brand Maison Kitsuné, which has, over 21 years, grown to include more than 75 fashion boutiques and 35 cafes worldwide, after beginning as a record label that worked with indie bands like Phoenix and Cut Copy. Raised in Brittany, Loaëc met his business partner, the French Japanese Masaya Kuroki, 49, while running a Parisian record store, D.J.ing at night and collaborating with the helmeted electronic duo Daft Punk. Now 51, he has long prided himself on knowing what sorts of music, clothes and coffee certain cool-chasing young people from Tokyo to New York want to consume next.

headline: How Does the Internet’s Most Popular Food Critic Keep Creating Drama?
abstract: The restaurant reviewer Keith Lee tastes takeout dishes in his car, and sometimes offends whole cities in the process.
lead_paragraph: It was a series of questions about tinned fish during a Saturday night dinner service that alerted Amanda Burton, a co-founder of Rooted Rotisserie in Baltimore, that this was a strange order — though she didn’t think it could be life-changing.

headline: A Moment in Time, Preserved in Polyester
abstract: Vintage soccer jerseys have become a streetwear staple, and a target of major investors. Their real appeal lies in the memories they conjure.
lead_paragraph: The temperature drops perceptibly as Doug Bierton discreetly sweeps the bracelet on his left wrist over a wall-mounted sensor and enters the vault.

headline: On City Strolls, ‘Fat Ham’ Writer Was Inspired by ‘Ghosts of Absence’
abstract: Walking around downtown Philadelphia, James Ijames reflected on his new play, “Good Bones,” gentrification and the absence that “haunts the cities.”
lead_paragraph: The Tower Records on Broad Street, the Borders bookstore on Chestnut, and the Kitchen Kapers boutique at the corner of Walnut and 17th Streets in Philadelphia: The playwright James Ijames shopped at all of them in the early 2000s while pursuing his M.F.A. at Temple University.

headline: How Lying Became Disinformation
abstract: Today “disinformation” and “misinformation” are often invoked by the left in the same way “fake news” is by the right.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Donald Trump challenged the validity of President Barack Obama’s birth certificate, Mr. Trump has lied more frequently and egregiously than perhaps any other major figure in American political history. From the relatively trivial lie that began his administration (that 1.5 million people attended his inauguration) to the extremely consequential falsehood that ended it (that the 2020 election was stolen), his presidency was in large part defined by mendacity.

headline: In a First Among Christians, Young Men Are More Religious Than Young Women
abstract: At Grace Church in Waco, Texas, the Generation Z gender divide can be seen in the pews. It has the potential to reshape both politics and family life.
lead_paragraph: On a beautiful Sunday morning in early September, dozens of young men in Waco, Texas, started their day at Grace Church.

headline: Sean Combs’s Arrest Has the Music World Asking: Is Our #MeToo Here?
abstract: Activists and survivors are hopeful for change after the industry, which has a pervasive party culture, largely avoided the accountability that swept Hollywood and politics.
lead_paragraph: The arrest of Sean Combs last week, on charges including sex trafficking and racketeering conspiracy, represents a stunning reversal of fortune for the hip-hop impresario, who as recently as a year ago was feted as an industry visionary before a sudden series of sexual assault accusations.

headline: JD Vance Is Wrong — Kamala Harris Isn’t Changing Her Accent
abstract: She’s actually doing something quite presidential.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Republicans have taken to accusing Kamala Harris of using fake accents while on the campaign trail. In this episode of “The Opinions,” John McWhorter, an Opinion writer and linguist, argues the vice president is simply revealing a piece of herself by slipping into “Black English,” a form of code switching that is actually quite presidential.

headline: Tourism’s Next Battlefront: Water
abstract: As climate change brings water shortages to vacation hot spots, we look at Greece’s tourism-dependent islands, where residents sometimes compete with visitors for a dwindling supply.
lead_paragraph: As a prolonged heat wave scorched Greece in mid-June, with temperatures reaching over 104 degrees Fahrenheit, residents of Sifnos, a small island in the western Cyclades, faced a reality they had long anticipated and feared: Their taps ran dry.

headline: Are Parents Stressed Out?
abstract: The U.S. surgeon general issued an advisory on the mental health and well-being of parents, declaring it an urgent public health issue.
lead_paragraph: Are your parents stressed out these days? How about your friends’ parents? If so, what do you think are the causes? Overall, do you think parenting is harder in 2024 than it was in the past?

headline: ‘I Cannot Have That Man Be My Governor’: A Stark Race Roils a Crucial State
abstract: Josh Stein is fighting to prevent a MAGA takeover of North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Candidates strive to be bold contrasts to their opponents. By that measure, Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson has been running a spectacularly successful campaign for governor of North Carolina, and the past several days were absolutely phenomenal.

headline: ‘Coppelia’ at 50: When City Ballet Took a Turn for ‘Fun and Funny’
abstract: Original cast members look back at George Balanchine and Alexandra Danilova’s staging of the 19th-century ballet. “Everyone knows when something is good,” one said.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine’s decision to stage the 19th-century ballet “Coppelia,” in 1974, was a surprise. Although Balanchine, the co-founder and leader of New York City Ballet, occasionally created narrative ballets, like “The Nutcracker” and “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” the company was identified with a lean, no-frills approach to classical dance. It was turned toward innovation and experimentation, rather than story, characters and elaborate costumes.

headline: What Did ‘The West Wing’ Do to Us?
abstract: As Aaron Sorkin’s political fantasy turns 25, its romance has aged better than its politics.
lead_paragraph: “‘I am the Lord your God. Thou shalt worship no other god before me.’ Boy, those were the days, huh?”

headline: $3.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A modernist house in Los Angeles, a hillside retreat in San Clemente and a three-bedroom home in San Mateo.
lead_paragraph: This cedar-clad house in Silver Lake has been owned by the same family for 40 years. It was designed by Richard Holme, who trained with some of the city’s most prominent architects, including Richard Neutra and A. Quincy Jones, as his own residence.

headline: Why Is Trump Spreading Rumors About Haitian Immigrants? Rousseau Knows.
abstract: The 18th-century philosopher knew that divisive politicians understand that those who struggle economically “look more below than above them.”
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s claims about Haitian immigrants in Springfield, Ohio, this month were bizarre and outlandish, but they worked. Within days, the city had become what Gov. Mike DeWine called the “epicenter of vitriol over America’s immigration policy.”

headline: I’m a Doctor, and I’m Worried About What Comes Next for Our Health Care System
abstract: The next fights over health care won’t be legislative brawls or executive actions — they will be a deluge of battles in the courts.
lead_paragraph: After maintaining an oddly low profile early in the election season, health care is a wallflower no more. Last week, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, JD Vance, suggested a second Trump administration might roll back the protections under the Affordable Care Act ensuring that patients with pre-existing conditions are covered. Perhaps he was trying to formulate some “concepts of a plan” that days earlier former President Donald Trump offered during the presidential debate when asked what he had in mind for supplanting the health care law.

headline: Accurate Polls Hinge on a Tricky Question: Who’s Actually Going to Vote?
abstract: As the election nears, most pollsters are reporting responses from “likely voters.” The challenge is in figuring out who they are.
lead_paragraph: In the flood of election polls you’ll see over the next few weeks, most polling groups will include responses from “likely voters.” And often from nobody else.

headline: U.S. Research Aided Chinese Military Technology, House Republicans Say
abstract: A congressional report argues that Beijing has exploited ties with American universities to advance technologically, and that further guardrails are needed.
lead_paragraph: A House committee focused on threats from China argues in a new report that U.S. federal research funding had helped to advance Chinese technologies with military applications, fueling a potential national security rival to the United States.

headline: Sally Rooney, Heart on Her Sleeve, Writes a Weeper
abstract: Her new novel, “Intermezzo,” considers love in its various permutations.
lead_paragraph: A Sally Rooney backlash, in certain quarters, has been building. Her books are too white, it is said, and her politics too soft. She can be, in pursuit of a love story, a bit corny — or so it is said.

headline: The World Is a Mess. That Makes the Climate Crisis Harder to Solve.
abstract: A transformed China, conflicts in Ukraine and elsewhere, and intractable clashes over money have pushed the prospects of progress to a new low.
lead_paragraph: Global power is fractured. Temperatures have risen to record levels. Bitterness and anxiety are rising in vulnerable countries lashed by deadly heat and floods.

headline: The Long, Strange Saga of Kamala Harris and Kimberly Guilfoyle
abstract: More than two decades ago, the future vice president and the future conservative firebrand were rising legal stars in San Francisco. Then Ms. Guilfoyle accused Ms. Harris of trying to deny her a job.
lead_paragraph: They were young lawyers, rising political stars and social acquaintances in the most exclusive quarters of San Francisco civic life.

headline: Is It Time to Rename the Pussy-Bow Blouse?
abstract: A reader proposes retiring a fashion term often interpreted as a double entendre. Our fashion critic explains the origins of the tie-neck blouse and its name.
lead_paragraph: The pussy-bow blouse is one of those fashion terms that has taken on multiple connotations over the decades, all of which have culminated in its current incarnation: political lightning rod. It was not always thus.

headline: Trump Shows Signs of Strength in Sun Belt Battlegrounds, Polls Find
abstract: New polls from The New York Times and Siena College showed Donald J. Trump ahead in Arizona and leading in tight races in Georgia and North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Voters across the Sun Belt say that Donald J. Trump improved their lives when he was president — and worry that a Kamala Harris White House would not — setting the stage for an extraordinarily competitive contest in three key states, according to the latest polls from The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: Looking for a Superhero? Check the Public Library.
abstract: You know something is wrong in America when beloved schoolteachers and librarians become the target of hate groups.
lead_paragraph: My library card is printed with my account number on the back and the words “I Read Banned Books” on the front. I swapped out my old card for this one in 2022, when the Nashville Public Library launched a “Freedom to Read” campaign in response to the surge in book bans across the country. The special-edition cards were meant to be temporary, but the response in Nashville was so positive that the library made the option permanent.

headline: As U.N. Meets, Pressure Mounts on Biden to Loosen Up on Arms for Ukraine
abstract: Finland’s president and NATO’s departing secretary general are urging Mr. Biden to allow Ukraine to use weapons to hit bases deeper inside Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will be under increasing pressure this week to loosen restrictions on Ukraine’s use of weapons when global leaders converge on the United Nations for their annual gathering.

headline: Supreme Court’s Gun Rulings Leave Baffled Judges Asking for Help
abstract: In June, the court tried to explain its new history-based approach to the Second Amendment. But judges said the latest decision “offered little instruction or clarity.”
lead_paragraph: Federal appeals courts were busy this summer trying to make sense of the Supreme Court’s recent Second Amendment decisions. It has not gone well.

headline: A Venezuelan Gang Reaches New York
abstract: Law enforcement officials are working to curb the growth of Tren de Aragua, a gang that began in a Venezuelan prison and has been linked to crimes in other countries and several states in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll get details on a Venezuelan gang that has emerged in New York City. We’ll also find out why the final screenings of the film “La Chimera” last week were packed.

headline: A Majority in Arizona Supports Establishing Right to Abortion, Poll Finds
abstract: A ballot measure codifying “the fundamental right to an abortion” is supported by 58 percent of the state’s likely voters, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
lead_paragraph: A majority of likely voters in Arizona said they planned to support an amendment to the state’s Constitution codifying “the fundamental right to an abortion,” according to the latest poll from The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: What’s Behind Trump’s Best Poll Results in Weeks
abstract: In a shift from a Times/Siena survey last month, he leads in three Sun Belt battleground states.
lead_paragraph: We’re getting to the point in the election cycle where we’re starting to get a lot of polls — enough that it will occasionally start to feel as if the polls are swinging from left to right and back, every day.

headline: State of the Race: A Small Debate Bounce for Harris, but It’s Still Deadlocked
abstract: She gained a point in the polls after widely being seen as the debate winner.
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly two weeks since the first presidential debate, and the polls have reached their verdict on the fallout: The race remains very close.

headline: Another Trump Acolyte Finds Himself in Big Trouble
abstract: The Mark Robinson story is yet another case of self-declared morality being at variance with actual behavior.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. So much ground for us to cover this week. First up, Mark Robinson, North Carolina’s lieutenant governor and the Republican Party’s nominee in the governor’s race. I don’t even know if we’re allowed to discuss the latest, er, revelations in a family newspaper.

headline: Missouri Supreme Court and Governor Reject Bids to Block Execution
abstract: Marcellus Williams, scheduled to be executed on Tuesday for a 1998 murder conviction, still hopes for a last-minute reprieve from the U.S. Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: The governor of Missouri on Monday turned down a bid for clemency for a man scheduled to be executed this week for murder, and a short time later the state’s highest court rejected the man’s latest legal challenge, all but clearing the way for his execution on Tuesday night.

headline: André 3000 Quit Rap. Will His Fans Stand for It?
abstract: The critic Wesley Morris and the writer Rembert Browne on A3K’s jazz flute album.
lead_paragraph: André 3000 is the rapper best known as half of the group Outkast, and — as the critic Wesley Morris describes him — “one of the greatest rappers of all time.” Last November, André 3000 released his first album in 17 years, but “New Blue Sun” isn’t a rap album — it’s jazz flute. Now he is on tour, introducing fans around the world to a totally different musical side of himself.

headline: Pope Cancels Meetings, Citing Flu and With More Travel Looming
abstract: Francis, 87, is scheduled to visit Belgium and Luxembourg soon, trips that come within weeks of his returning from a grueling Asia-Pacific tour.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis canceled appointments on Monday because of a mild flu, according to the Vatican, which said the move was a precautionary step as the pontiff prepares to travel to Belgium and Luxembourg this week.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 471
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Sept. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,193
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Fire, and Polls Find Trump Ahead in Sun Belt States
abstract: Plus, the White Sox go for a record (low).
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: How Telegram Became the Underworld’s Favorite App
abstract: Drug dealers, scammers and white nationalists openly conduct business on the platform, according to a Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: A Times investigation has found that Telegram, one of the world’s biggest messaging apps, with nearly a billion users, is also a giant black market and gathering place for the likes of terrorists and white supremacists.

headline: New State Laws Are Fueling a Surge in Book Bans
abstract: Two reports from advocacy groups show that book banning continues at higher rates than before the pandemic. Newly implemented state laws are impacting the numbers this year.
lead_paragraph: States and local governments are banning books at rates far higher than before the pandemic, according to preliminary data released by two advocacy groups on Monday.

headline: Global Threats
abstract: We explore a report that details the threats faced by the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The first sentence of the report — released over the summer by a bipartisan, congressionally appointed commission — was blunt: “The threats the United States faces are the most serious and most challenging the nation has encountered since 1945 and include the potential for near-term major war.”

headline: Raising the Stakes, Israel Gambles That Hezbollah Will Back Down
abstract: Israel’s intensifying strikes show how determined it is to stop Hezbollah’s cross-border attacks — and how far it is from achieving that goal.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s deadly strikes and evacuation warnings in Lebanon on Monday showed its determination to break the resolve of Hezbollah and force the militia, which controls scores of villages across southern Lebanon, to stop its cross-border attacks on Israel.

headline: Supermarkets in Australia Sued Over Claims of Fake Discounts
abstract: In a rare case of legal action tied to rising prices, the government sued Woolworths and Coles for what it described as a pattern of deceiving consumers.
lead_paragraph: The Oreo family pack on sale at one of Australia’s largest grocery store chains seemed to be a pretty good deal, with a discount of 50 Australian cents. Trouble was, the new price was still a full Australian dollar more than what the cookies cost a month earlier.

headline: Intel’s Chips on the Table
abstract: Rivals and at least one big investor are circling the embattled semiconductor giant. The Biden administration is sure to keep an eye on any deal in such a strategically important sector.
lead_paragraph: First came news that Qualcomm had made an informal takeover approach for Intel, its historically bigger rival. Now comes one that Apollo Global Management has offered to invest billions in the embattled chip giant.

headline: Tracking the Remnants of John
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for John.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for John.

headline: Biden Administration Proposes Ban on Chinese Software in Vehicles
abstract: Federal officials acknowledged that few Chinese vehicles were on U.S. roads now, but said that the administration wanted to take proactive measures to strengthen national security.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced a sweeping initiative on Monday to ban Chinese-developed software from internet-connected cars in the United States, justifying the move on national security grounds. The action is intended to prevent Chinese intelligence agencies from monitoring the movements of Americans or using the vehicles’ electronics as a pathway into the U.S. electric grid or other critical infrastructure.

headline: U.S. to Seek Attempted Assassination Charge for Trump Golf Course Suspect
abstract: Prosecutors disclosed new information in a memo written to persuade a federal judge to detain the suspect indefinitely while he awaits trial.
lead_paragraph: The federal government will pursue a charge of attempted assassination against a man accused of lurking with a gun near where former President Donald J. Trump was golfing in Florida last week, prosecutors said in a court hearing on Monday. Among the government’s evidence, they said, was a note the suspect had written suggesting that he had planned the attack.

headline: Parents Race to Get Children From Schools as Fear Spreads in Beirut
abstract: Lebanon’s Education Ministry ordered some schools to close amid warnings from Israel that it was intensifying strikes against Hezbollah and calls for residents to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: Parents raced to pick up their children from school in Beirut on Monday, as fear spread in the Lebanese capital that Israel might soon strike the city.

headline: Israel-Hezbollah Tensions Spiral in Week of Attacks: What to Know
abstract: Exploding pagers, a major Israeli strike in Beirut and Hezbollah attacks deep inside Israel have brought the two sides closer than they’ve been in years to a full-scale war.
lead_paragraph: The past week has seen a significant rise in tensions between Israel and Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia supported by Iran. Back-and-forth attacks have brought the two sides to the brink of their first full-scale war since 2006, when they fought a 34-day conflict that involved an Israeli ground invasion and killed over 1,000 Lebanese and 150 Israelis.

headline: Man Smashes Ai Weiwei’s Porcelain Sculpture at Italian Museum
abstract: The man behind the episode, at a reception for Mr. Ai’s new exhibition in Bologna, has targeted artists before, a museum spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: A reception for a new exhibition by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei in Bologna, Italy, was disrupted on Friday when a man walked in and smashed a large, porcelain sculpture, leaving museum guests and the artist stunned.

headline: Stalking the Wild Banana
abstract: One man’s “never-ending quest” for the least-known varieties of the world’s most-eaten fruit.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Sachter-Smith is a banana aficionado who has identified some 500 varieties of banana on expeditions around the tropical world. “It’s like collecting Pokémon,” Mr. Sachter-Smith said at his farm, Hawaii Banana Source, on the North Shore of Oahu. He was walking through rows of young plants, some of the 150 varieties he grows, in a T-shirt splotched with mud and banana sap. His one-eyed dog, Mendel, trotted along at his boots. “My default mode of being alive is ‘What is that banana?’” he said.

headline: Inside a Trump Ad Hammering Harris Over Americans’ Economic Woes
abstract: No viewer could miss the ad’s repeated connection of the vice president to “Bidenomics.” And as it portrays voters struggling to make ends meet, she is seen laughing gleefully.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign began running this 30-second ad linking Vice President Kamala Harris to President Biden and the administration’s economic record on television stations in at least five key battleground states last week. The campaign has spent $2.8 million on those commercials, according to AdImpact.

headline: Russian Military Plane Breaches Japan’s Airspace Three Times in One Day
abstract: The infringements were the first by Russia in five years, according to the Japanese defense ministry. A fighter fired a warning flare in response.
lead_paragraph: A Russian military patrol plane breached Japanese airspace off the country’s northwestern coast three times on Monday, prompting Japan’s military to dispatch a fighter jet to issue radio warnings and, for the first time, to use a signal flare to deter the Russian aircraft.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Unwilling to Impose Discipline for Stop-and-Frisk, Report Says
abstract: The department’s discipline for illegal street detentions is lax at every level, according to an extraordinary review ordered by a federal judge.
lead_paragraph: At every level, the New York Police Department has failed to punish officers who have violated the rights of people stopped on the street, according to a new report — a failure that reaches all the way to the top of the force.

headline: Was It Really a Hot Zone Summer?
abstract: From Covid to dengue, viral outbreaks seemed to be popping up all over. But maybe Americans are just more attuned to threats now.
lead_paragraph: Bird flu. Mpox, formerly monkeypox. Eastern equine encephalitis. West Nile. Listeria. Dengue. Oropouche. And, of course, Covid.

headline: This Soup Is a Hug
abstract: My lemony white bean soup with turkey and greens is a warm hug on a crisp evening (and a New York Times Cooking classic).
lead_paragraph: Hello from the road! I’m writing this from the airport, en route to Istanbul and points beyond for a rose-water-grape-molasses-tahini-infused getaway that I’ll fill you in on when I get back. Follow along; I’ll be posting plenty of food photos on Instagram (@clarkbar). Let’s meet for baklava!

headline: Punching Octopuses Lead Fish on Hunting Parties
abstract: Octopuses and fish are routinely seen working together on the ocean floor, and now scientists say that the cephalopods are the leaders of the pack.
lead_paragraph: Effective leaders consider all of their options before making a decision. They work with others from different backgrounds. They’re ready to give anyone who steps out of line a swift punch to the gills.

headline: Will A.I. Be a Bust? A Wall Street Skeptic Rings the Alarm.
abstract: Jim Covello, Goldman Sachs’s head of stock research, warned that building too much of what the world doesn’t need “typically ends badly.”
lead_paragraph: As Jim Covello’s car barreled up Highway 101 from San Jose to San Francisco this month, he counted the billboards about artificial intelligence. The nearly 40 signs he passed, including one that promoted something called Writer Enterprise AI and another for Speech AI, were fresh evidence, he thought, of an economic bubble.

headline: Is Math the Path to Chatbots That Don’t Make Stuff Up?
abstract: Chatbots like ChatGPT get stuff wrong. But researchers are building new A.I. systems that can verify their own math — and maybe more.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Tudor Achim gave a brain teaser to an A.I. bot called Aristotle.

headline: California Sues Exxon Over Plastics Pollution and Recycling ‘Myth’
abstract: The lawsuit, seeking ‘multiple billions of dollars,’ opens a new front in the legal battles with oil and gas companies over climate and environmental issues.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general of California, Rob Bonta, sued Exxon Mobil on Monday alleging that the oil giant carried out a “decades-long campaign of deception” that overhyped the promise of recycling and spawned a plastic pollution crisis.

headline: Alan Sparhawk of Low Lost His Other Half. He’s Learning to Sing Again.
abstract: Alongside his wife, Mimi Parker, the musician created one of indie-rock’s most arresting bands. Two years after her death, he returns with “White Roses, My God.”
lead_paragraph: Alan Sparhawk did not think his new song was any good. It was early 2017, and he was working on “Double Negative,” the 12th album by his longtime band, Low. The record would become a late-career breakthrough, the intimate harmonies between Sparhawk and his wife, Mimi Parker, supplanted from their slow, soft acoustic settings into beds of brittle noise.

headline: JD Vance Has Turned to a Minnesota Republican to Help Him Prepare for the Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s running mate invited Representative Tom Emmer to stand in for his fellow Minnesotan, Gov. Tim Walz, ahead of the vice-presidential debate next month.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio has recruited Representative Tom Emmer to help prepare for his debate next week with Gov. Tim Walz, enlisting a Minnesota Republican to play the role of a Minnesota Democrat.

headline: Trump Says He Wouldn’t Run for President in 2028 if He Loses This Year
abstract: The former president, who is the Republican nominee for the third time, would be 82 on Election Day in 2028. That’s older than President Biden is now.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that he did not think he would run again in 2028 if he lost this year.

headline: Israel Launches Deadly Strikes Across Gaza, Local Officials Say
abstract: The latest in a series of strikes on schools being used as shelters killed three in Nuseirat, according to the Palestinian Civil Defense. Israel has said the buildings were being used by Hamas militants as a command center.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Israeli military shifted its focus to fighting Hezbollah in Lebanon, it has continued to bombard Gaza, where strikes across the strip over the last few days have killed several Palestinians, according to local authorities and Palestinian news media.

headline: Using Haitian Immigrants as a Campaign Issue
abstract: Responses to a guest essay by Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio and a column by Jamelle Bouie. Also: Donald Trump and Jewish voters; pagers in war; airport trays.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Travis Scott Has No. 1 Album, After Close Loss to Sabrina Carpenter
abstract: The “Days Before Rodeo” rerelease is the rapper’s fourth title to reach the top.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, a photo finish on the Billboard album chart saw Sabrina Carpenter edge out Travis Scott by a margin of less than a thousand copies. Now — after challenging those results — Scott has finally snagged No. 1, thanks to vinyl sales.

headline: A Day After Most of His Staff Resigned, Mark Robinson Is Continuing to Campaign
abstract: The Republican lieutenant governor said he would hire new staff soon, following a CNN report linking him to disturbing comments on a porn site.
lead_paragraph: Mark Robinson returned to the campaign trail on Monday in North Carolina, insisting that he will remain in the governor’s race even after most of his staff resigned following a CNN report linking him to numerous disturbing comments on a pornographic website.

headline: Do You Know These Villains of Classic British Literature?
abstract: Antagonists, antiheroes and just plain evil characters can really stick with you. See how many you remember from five time-honored novels.
lead_paragraph: Antagonists, antiheroes and just plain evil characters can really stick with you. See how many you remember from five time-honored novels.

headline: Brewing Caribbean Storm Churns Toward Gulf Coast
abstract: The chances that Potential Tropical Cyclone Nine will turn into Hurricane Helene and affect the Gulf Coast later this week are increasing.
lead_paragraph: The next storm that could threaten the United States was taking shape early Tuesday about 150 miles west of Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, with forecasters saying there is a chance that it becomes Helene, the next hurricane in the Atlantic this year.

headline: Biden and Harris Meet With Emirati President in Washington
abstract: The meetings with Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed were expected to focus on Gaza, the war in Sudan and artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris met with Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed, the president of the United Arab Emirates, at the White House on Monday against the backdrop of violence in Gaza, civil war in Sudan and the development of artificial intelligence.

headline: A Ballerina Saves the Day, a Partnership Is Born. What’s Next?
abstract: New York City Ballet opened its fall season with classics by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins, along with a company premiere by Lar Lubovitch.
lead_paragraph: It was like any matinee at New York City Ballet until something odd happened: One lead dancer turned into a ballerina tag team. On Saturday afternoon at Lincoln Center, Sara Mearns, dancing the gorgeous, taxing role in George Balanchine’s “Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2,” suddenly wasn’t there for an entrance. Instead, in came Unity Phelan, in costume but with little discernible makeup, taking Mearns’s place — whipping off fouetté turns with ease. Phelan has a breezy way of making hard things look easy. This came in handy.

headline: Ukraine Needs to Be Realistic About Its Goals, Czech President Says
abstract: President Petr Pavel, a former NATO general who has been vocal in his support for Ukraine, said Kyiv needed to accept that some territory could remain under Russian control, at least “temporarily.”
lead_paragraph: President Petr Pavel of the Czech Republic, a former senior NATO general who has been one of Ukraine’s most robust backers in its war with Russia, says he thinks it is time for Ukrainians and their supporters to face what he says is reality.

headline: Benny Golson, Saxophonist and Composer of Jazz Standards, Dies at 95
abstract: After forming a lauded band and writing tunes like “I Remember Clifford,” “Whisper Not” and “Killer Joe,” he had a second career composing and arranging music for television.
lead_paragraph: Benny Golson, a tenor saxophonist and composer who played with some of the biggest names in jazz and was a founder of one of the leading groups of the hard bop era, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Mother of Accused Apalachee Gunman Faces Elder Abuse Charges
abstract: Marcee Gray, 43, is accused of taping her mother to a chair during a drug-induced rage.
lead_paragraph: The mother of the accused gunman in the mass shooting at Apalachee High School this month has been arrested on charges of elder abuse stemming from an incident in 2023, when she is said to have taped her mother to a chair, local news media reported.

headline: Key Nebraska Republican Rejects Trump’s Push to Shake Up Electoral Map
abstract: Mike McDonnell, a state senator, said he would not support an effort to change the state’s electoral system to winner take all, an outcome that could have cost Kamala Harris an electoral vote.
lead_paragraph: The Nebraska state senator who Republicans hoped would help ease former President Donald J. Trump’s path to the White House by agreeing to change how the state allocates its Electoral College votes said on Monday that he would not do so, ending a brief but intense lobbying effort from allies of Mr. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Murder in U.S. Continues Steep Decline, F.B.I. Reports
abstract: Homicides fell 11.6 percent nationwide in 2023, and violent crime overall fell by 3 percent after a surge in crime during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The number of murders reported in the United States dropped in 2023 at the fastest rate on record, continuing a decline from the surge in homicides during the pandemic, the F.B.I. reported on Monday.

headline: Tanzania’s President Vowed Opening for Opposition, but Detained Its Leaders
abstract: The East African country’s leading opposition party said that its presidential candidate in the last election and its chairman were among dozens detained before a protest called to draw attention to the killing and abduction of government critics.
lead_paragraph: Tanzania’s main opposition party said on Monday that the police had detained its top leaders and dozens of others ahead of a planned demonstration — the second such crackdown in two months by the government of President Samia Suluhu Hassan, who came to power promising a political opening.

headline: A South Korean Olympian Gets to Play an Assassin, but Some Before Her Have Flopped
abstract: Olympians who tried the movies, especially in the 1980s, often fared poorly.
lead_paragraph: An Olympic star emerges. In this case, Kim Ye-ji of South Korea, who became an overnight sensation with her effortlessly cool shooting form and ice-cold demeanor.

headline: The U.S. Lost the Battery Race to China. Can It Make a Comeback?
abstract: The cutting edge of American battery technology is rusty.
lead_paragraph: Mateo Jaramillo was giving me his spiel about his battery company when he mentioned, in passing, that the battery was “not super efficient.”

headline: Israeli Warplanes Target Another Top Hezbollah Commander in Beirut, Officials Say
abstract: Hezbollah said in a statement that the chief of its forces in southern Lebanon was alive and well.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Air Force attempted on Monday evening to kill Ali Karaki, Hezbollah’s top commander in southern Lebanon, with an airstrike in the capital, Beirut, according to two current Israeli officials and one former Israeli official with knowledge of the operation.

headline: Pentagon to Send More U.S. Troops to Middle East as Tensions Rise
abstract: Maj. Gen. Patrick S. Ryder, the Pentagon press secretary, declined to say exactly how many troops were deploying, citing operational security.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon is sending additional U.S. troops to the Middle East as tensions continue to rise after Israeli airstrikes against Hezbollah killed at least 350 people in Lebanon, Defense Department officials said on Monday.

headline: Last Bull Is Recaptured After 8 Escaped From Massachusetts Mall Rodeo
abstract: The bulls were part of a one-day rodeo held at the Emerald Square Mall on Sunday in North Attleboro.
lead_paragraph: The people of southern Massachusetts can rest assured: All eight of the bulls that jumped over a fence and escaped from a rodeo at a mall on Sunday afternoon have been located, the North Attleboro Fire Department announced late Monday.

headline: California Bans All Plastic Bags After Its First Effort Backfired
abstract: The state led the nation in 2014 by banning single-use plastic bags, but a loophole actually led to more plastic waste.
lead_paragraph: Paper or paper? In California, shoppers will have only one bag option at the checkout line starting in 2026.

headline: Gunman Convicted of Murdering 10 at a Colorado Supermarket
abstract: Ahmad Al Aliwi Alissa was sentenced to life in prison for the 2021 mass shooting. His lawyers had argued that he was not guilty by reason of insanity.
lead_paragraph: The man who fatally shot 10 people at a Boulder, Colo., grocery store in 2021 was found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison on Monday. Jurors rejected his lawyers’ argument that mental illness had made him unable to distinguish right from wrong.

headline: Inspired by a Children’s Book, They’re Having a ‘Strega Nona September’
abstract: A pasta-making witch from a beloved 1975 fable is being hailed online as the blueprint for a very specific strain of autumnal coziness.
lead_paragraph: By the autumnal equinox on Sunday, Danni Capalbo had already had her fall game plan in place for weeks. She would spend the coming months wrapped in cozy layers in her apartment in Boston, stirring up steaming vats of carbohydrates.

headline: Caterina Valente, Singer Who Was a Star on Two Continents, Dies at 93
abstract: Born in Paris to Italian parents and raised in Germany, she had her own show on television in the 1950s and was later a small-screen mainstay in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Caterina Valente, a polyglot performer who sang in more than a dozen languages and who was a television mainstay on two continents in the 1950s and ’60s, died on Sept. 9 at her home in Lugano, Switzerland. She was 93.

headline: Boeing Says It Has Made Its ‘Best and Final’ Offer to Striking Workers
abstract: The proposal includes raises of 30 percent over the four-year contract, up from a 25 percent offer, but it’s unclear whether it will satisfy workers.
lead_paragraph: Boeing on Monday made what it described as its “best and final” contract offer to more than 33,000 striking union employees.

headline: Flooding Is Expected After Tropical Storm John Hits Mexico
abstract: John made landfall in the state of Guerrero, along the Pacific coast, as a Category 3 storm on Monday and dissipated on Tuesday. Heavy rain was still forecast for southern and southwestern Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Tropical Storm John continued to whip western Mexico with strong winds and heavy rain on Tuesday, bringing a risk of flash flooding that was expected to persist for several more days. It had weakened after making landfall on the Pacific coast as a Category 3 storm late on Monday.

headline: One Bright Spot Amid the Industry’s Gloom: Natural Wine
abstract: Young people may be drinking fewer alcoholic beverages, but natural wine appears to be among their favorite choices.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy late summer night, Frog, a natural wine bar in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, was a busy place. Couples occupied the small tables lining one wall and the pool table was hopping. A bartender poured tastes of a red wine from Andrea Calek, a vigneron in the Ardèche region of France, to two women who were deciding what to order. In the big back yard, the picnic tables were packed. A happy buzz drifted upward into the night sky.

headline: Trump Learned Nothing From the Obamacare Debate. Neither Did Vance.
abstract: Their “concepts” would abandon people with pre-existing conditions.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has been ridiculed, rightly, for his answer, during his debate with Kamala Harris, about whether he had a plan for health care coverage that would either replace or improve upon the Affordable Care Act: “I have concepts of a plan.” He has been running for president or sitting in the White House for nine years, and that’s all he has?

headline: Pakistan Appoints New Head of Its Powerful Spy Agency
abstract: The appointment of a top general, Lt. Gen. Muhammad Asim Malik, to the post comes as the country faces numerous internal and external challenges.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s government appointed a new head of its powerful spy agency on Monday, filling the job as the country confronts complex internal issues and increasing external security challenges, analysts say.

headline: A Congressman Had an Affair. Then He Put His Lover on the Payroll.
abstract: Representative Anthony D’Esposito, a New York Republican, gave part-time jobs to both his lover and his fiancée’s daughter, in possible violation of House ethics rules.
lead_paragraph: As a proud son of Nassau County’s vaunted Republican machine, Representative Anthony D’Esposito of New York knows well the power of political patronage. Every member of his immediate family has held a town or county job, and as a local official, he routinely helped friends find spots on the government payroll.

headline: Read the prosecutors’ detention memo
abstract: The court filing included a note that prosecutors said the suspect had written suggesting that he had planned to attack former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The court filing included a note that prosecutors said the suspect had written suggesting that he had planned to attack former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: As Investigations Swirl, Another Adams Official Resigns
abstract: Dr. Ashwin Vasan, who led New York City out of the pandemic as its health commissioner, is the third top official to quit in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: The health commissioner chosen by Mayor Eric Adams to lead New York City out of the Covid-19 pandemic resigned on Monday, the third top administration official this month to leave, or announce plans to, amid multiple federal investigations of the mayor’s inner circle.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds
abstract: Plus, vintage soccer jerseys and the memories they preserve.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes against Hezbollah in Lebanon killed nearly 500, including dozens of women and children, and injured more than 1,600 others, Lebanon’s Health Ministry said. It was the deadliest day of Israeli attacks there since at least 2006, when Israel last fought a war with Hezbollah, an Iranian-backed militant group. Follow live updates.

headline: Jury Clears All but One Defendant in ‘Trump Train’ Case Over Biden Bus in 2020
abstract: A San Antonio man was found liable for his role in helping to organize a convoy of Trump supporters that closely followed a Biden-Harris campaign bus in 2020.
lead_paragraph: A federal civil jury on Monday mostly cleared a group of six defendants on trial for their roles in the so-called Trump Train that followed a Biden-Harris campaign bus in Texas in 2020, finding only that a San Antonio man had engaged in unlawful conspiracy.

headline: World War II Airman’s Remains Identified After 79 Years
abstract: Staff Sgt. John A. Tarbert of the Air Force died weeks before his son was born, but he was accounted for only this year.
lead_paragraph: The same day that Jenevieve Judd gave birth to her son, John Elliott, in October 1944, she received a crushing telegram from the U.S. military informing her that her husband had gone missing while serving in World War II.

headline: At U.N. Conference, Global Crises Collide With Fraught American Politics
abstract: President Biden will speak at a time of deep uncertainty about the future of America’s role in the world.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden addresses world leaders at the United Nations on Tuesday morning, his aides promise a speech filled with declarations about America’s role in shaping the future.

headline: Israel Launched Intense Airstrikes on Hezbollah
abstract: Also, new polls were Trump’s best in weeks. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of Israeli fighter jets bombed Hezbollah targets in Lebanon today, killing hundreds of people, Lebanese officials said. The strikes, which included an attempted assassination of a top Hezbollah commander, were the deadliest in Lebanon since 2006, during the last Israel-Hezbollah war.

headline: Janet Jackson Repeats False Claims About Kamala Harris’s Race
abstract: After Ms. Jackson told The Guardian that Ms. Harris is “not Black,” her representatives said a man who apologized on her behalf was not authorized to speak for her.
lead_paragraph: There was a swift backlash on Saturday after the pop star Janet Jackson challenged Vice President Kamala Harris’s racial identity in an interview with The Guardian. On Sunday, a man who identified himself as her manager apologized for her statements.

headline: Fredric Jameson, Critic Who Linked Literature to Capitalism, Dies at 90
abstract: Among the world’s leading academic critics, he brought his analytical rigor to topics as diverse as German opera and sci-fi movies.
lead_paragraph: Fredric Jameson, who held sway as one of the world’s leading literary theorists for over 40 years, bringing his brand of rigorous, incisive Marxist criticism to topics as broad as German opera, sci-fi films and luxury hotel design, died on Sunday at his home in Killingworth, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Getting Old Never Looked So Ugly
abstract: “The Substance” figures in the long line of movies about what you might call menopausal derangement syndrome — the ostensibly crazy-making tragedy of a woman living past 50.
lead_paragraph: Warning: Spoilers ahead.

headline: Biden Works Against the Clock as Violence Escalates in the Middle East
abstract: President Biden is beginning to acknowledge that he is simply running out of time to help forge a cease-fire and hostage deal with Hamas, his aides say. And the risk of a wider war has never looked greater.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s ferocious assault on Hezbollah, its most violent exchange with the Lebanese militant group since 2006, is not only a major widening of the war but also a significant widening of the breach between President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Russia’s Next-Generation Nuclear Missile Failed a Test, Evidence Suggests
abstract: Satellite photos showing a 200-foot-wide crater at a launch site indicate that the Sarmat missile, said by the Kremlin to travel at five times the speed of sound, might not be ready for duty.
lead_paragraph: Two months after he launched his invasion of Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin declared that Russia had succeeded in creating a “truly unique weapon” that would force anyone threatening the country “to think twice.”

headline: For Fredric Jameson, Marxist Criticism Was a Labor of Love
abstract: The literary critic, who died on Sunday at age 90, believed that reading was the path to revolution.
lead_paragraph: At the time of his death, at 90, on Sept. 22, Fredric Jameson was arguably the most prominent Marxist literary critic in the English-speaking world. In other words, he was a fairly obscure figure: well-known — revered, it’s fair to say — within a specialized sector of an increasingly marginal discipline. I don’t say that to diminish his importance, but rather to make a case for it.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Into N.Y. Mayor’s Foreign Ties Said to Include 6 Countries
abstract: Federal prosecutors investigating Mayor Eric Adams and his campaign’s ties to Turkey issued subpoenas in July for records related to 5 other countries.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors investigating whether Mayor Eric Adams conspired with the Turkish government to funnel illegal foreign donations into his campaign have recently sought information about interactions with five other countries, people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: California Schools Must Restrict Phones Under New Law Signed by Newsom
abstract: Calls for crackdowns have mounted with reports of cyberbullying and studies indicating that smartphones are harmful to children’s mental health.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation on Monday giving California school districts two years to begin banning or restricting cellphone use during school hours, an initiative that is intended to address rising concerns over social media and children’s mental health.

headline: 2 Plead Guilty in Drug-Related Death of Prominent Transgender Activist
abstract: Michael Kuilan and Antonio Venti admitted providing fentanyl-laced heroin to Cecilia Gentili, whose death prompted an outpouring of grief among L.G.B.T.Q. New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Two men accused of providing the fentanyl-laced heroin that killed the transgender activist and actress Cecilia Gentili have admitted distributing the drugs that caused her death, officials said on Monday.

headline: Government Watchdog Calls F.A.A. Air Traffic Control Systems Critically Outdated
abstract: A report by the Government Accountability Office said that the agency’s heavy reliance on the systems could jeopardize the safety and efficiency of the nation’s airspace.
lead_paragraph: A federal watchdog raised concerns about the Federal Aviation Administration’s air traffic controller systems, saying that many are critically outdated and that the agency’s heavy reliance on them could jeopardize the safety and efficiency of the nation’s airspace.

headline: Penn Suspends Amy Wax, Law Professor Accused of Making Racist Statements
abstract: The case tested the limits of academic freedom and tenure.
lead_paragraph: The University of Pennsylvania is suspending Amy Wax, a tenured law professor accused of making racist, sexist and homophobic remarks, for a year with half pay. It is a significant sanction but one that falls short of the firing that some students wanted.

headline: Israeli Strikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds as Warplanes Target Hezbollah
abstract: It was the deadliest day in decades of hostilities between Israel and the militants, who stepped up their own barrage of rockets.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of Israeli fighter jets bombed Hezbollah targets in southern and eastern Lebanon on Monday, killing hundreds and wounding more than a thousand others, Lebanese officials said, in the deadliest attacks in the country since 2006, when Israel and Hezbollah fought their last all-out war.

headline: Visa Faces an Antitrust Lawsuit by the Justice Dept.
abstract: The agency plans to argue that the company illegally penalizes customers that try to use rival payment processors.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is preparing to sue Visa, accusing the financial services giant of breaking the law to shut out rival payment processors, two people familiar with the matter said.

headline: A Church Where Mark Robinson Still Has Defenders
abstract: At a Black evangelical church in North Carolina, the candidate for governor still has support.
lead_paragraph: It was about an hour into the 11 a.m. service on Sunday, and Bishop Patrick  Wooden Sr. of the Upper Room Church of God in Christ in Raleigh, N.C., was at the pulpit, wearing a suit of deep plum. The music had drawn quiet. The morning announcements had been made. And now, the bishop said, he had something to address.

headline: Quote of the Day: Where Soccer Is a Refuge for Refugees
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 24, 2024
lead_paragraph: “We can’t just change women’s minds — we need to focus on men’s perspectives as well.”

headline: The Restaurant List 2024
abstract: Our 50 favorite places in America right now.
lead_paragraph: Our 50 favorite places in America right now.

headline: Vance, Declining to Denounce Robinson, Lashes Out at Media Instead
abstract: JD Vance, campaigning in North Carolina, criticized journalists for asking about Mark Robinson, the embattled Republican running for governor there.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio lashed out at the news media on Monday as he campaigned in North Carolina, deflecting questions about a scandal engulfing the campaign of Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, the embattled Republican running for governor in the state.

headline: A Leading Law Scholar Fears We’re Lurching Toward Secession
abstract: Can we fix the Constitution before it destroys us?
lead_paragraph: Here’s how rickety our constitutional system has become: The fate of the 2024 election could hang on the integrity of a single Republican state senator in Nebraska.

headline: After Just a Week, the N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Faces a Crisis of His Own
abstract: Thomas G. Donlon, brought in to bring stability to the Police Department when his predecessor resigned, had his homes searched by federal agents.
lead_paragraph: In his first week as New York City’s interim police commissioner, Thomas G. Donlon responded to a police shooting that injured four people, including one of his own officers.

headline: Earthquake Off Japan Coast Triggers Tsunami Advisory
abstract: The earthquake occurred off the coast of Torishima Island, which is uninhabited, at 8:14 a.m. on Tuesday, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. The advisory was lifted at 11 a.m.
lead_paragraph: An earthquake off the coast of Japan on Tuesday morning triggered tsunami advisories for residents across several remote islands, according to the authorities.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 24, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the shifting business challenges and opportunities in China as its population ages misstated a figure about China’s population. In 2022, the number of people age 60 and older in China topped 290 million; 290 million is not the number of 60-year-olds in China.

headline: New York Resident Dies of Eastern Equine Encephalitis Infection
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul declared the mosquito-borne illness a public health threat after the first confirmed case in the state in nearly a decade resulted in a death.
lead_paragraph: The first person to be diagnosed with Eastern equine encephalitis in New York in nearly a decade has died, prompting Gov. Kathy Hochul to declare the rare, mosquito-borne viral illness an imminent public health threat on Monday.

headline: Pete Buttigieg on 2024 and the ‘Crank Realignment’
abstract: The politician discusses how Democrats can rebuild trust.
lead_paragraph: The politician discusses how Democrats can rebuild trust.

headline: Elon Musk Hails Italy’s Leader at Awards Ceremony
abstract: Mr. Musk described Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni as “authentic, honest and thoughtful.” She used her Atlantic Council spotlight to defend Western values.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, and Giorgia Meloni, the prime minister of Italy, were the stars of a black-tie dinner in New York on Monday that highlighted Mr. Musk’s increasing involvement in politics.

headline: Thousands of Lebanese Are Displaced Amid Israeli Strikes
abstract: Amal Mohamed Zayyat, a resident of southern Lebanon, sought shelter in Beirut after Israel stepped up its attacks against what it said were Hezbollah targets.
lead_paragraph: Amal Mohamed Zayyat, a resident of southern Lebanon, sought shelter in Beirut after Israel stepped up its attacks against what it said were Hezbollah targets.
