headline: Harris Is Set to Visit Border, Trying to Cut Into Trump’s Immigration Edge
abstract: During a trip to Arizona, Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to make her first visit to the southern border since becoming the Democratic nominee.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris is planning to visit the U.S.-Mexico border on Friday during a trip to Arizona, according to two people briefed on the preparations, as she seeks to counter former President Donald J. Trump’s advantage with voters on the issue of immigration.

headline: Trump Gets a Lift From Arizona Ticket-Splitters Backing a Democrat for Senate
abstract: Representative Ruben Gallego, the Democratic candidate for Senate, leads in this key contest, a New York Times/Siena College poll found, while Kamala Harris trails Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump appears to be benefiting from ticket-splitters in Arizona, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll released on Monday, a finding that highlights his strength with Latino and younger voters as well as the unique weaknesses of the Republican nominee for Senate.

headline: Trump Tells Women That They Won’t ‘Be Thinking About Abortion’
abstract: “You will be protected, and I will be your protector,” said former President Donald J. Trump. Polls have shown he is struggling to cultivate support among women, for whom abortion rights remain a top issue.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed at a rally on Monday that he would protect women voters by making their communities safer and that they won’t “be thinking about abortion.”

headline: China Is Striking Deals to Cement Its Role as Asia’s Trade Hub
abstract: Beijing’s leaders are working with regional neighbors on the country’s western, northern and southern borders to develop new rail and sea links.
lead_paragraph: China has made several moves in recent months to advance its ambitious aim to become the trade and transportation hub of Asia.

headline: Spurned by Social Media, Publishers Chase Readers on WhatsApp
abstract: News outlets are experimenting with a feature in the world’s most popular messaging app that allows them to send links and headlines directly to followers.
lead_paragraph: Many digital news publishers have been desperately searching for a life raft. Traffic to news sites has fallen sharply, along with the ad revenue those clicks generate, partly because Google and Facebook decided to make news less prominent on their platforms.

headline: The U.S. News College Rankings Are Out. Cue the Rage and Obsession.
abstract: Every year, U.S. News & World Report publishes rankings that often change very little, though they draw attention and frustration from universities and applicants.
lead_paragraph: After months of tumult on American college campuses, relative stability in one realm returned on Tuesday, when U.S. News & World Report published its oft-disparaged but nevertheless closely watched rankings.

headline: In Lebanon’s Capital, Israel’s Strikes Stoke Fears of a Full-On War
abstract: With Monday’s attacks across southern Lebanon, the prospect of the escalating conflict enveloping the city has suddenly become real for many Beirut residents.
lead_paragraph: It began with messages sent by Israel to radio stations and some cellphones in Beirut on Monday morning, warning of imminent military action.

headline: China Cuts Interest Rates and Mortgage Down Payments
abstract: The country’s central bank also freed commercial banks to lend more money in a package of moves aimed at rekindling growth in a stagnant economy.
lead_paragraph: China’s central bank announced a series of measures on Tuesday aimed at making it easier for households and companies to borrow money, in the boldest attempt by the Chinese authorities since the pandemic to revive economic growth, halt a housing market crash and stop a broad decline in prices.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Israeli Airstrikes in Lebanon Kill Hundreds
abstract: Plus, vintage soccer jerseys and the memories they preserve.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes against Hezbollah in Lebanon killed nearly 500, including dozens of women and children, and injured more than 1,000 others, Lebanon’s health ministry said. It was the deadliest day of Israeli attacks there since at least 2006, when Israel last fought a war with Hezbollah, an Iranian-backed militant group. Follow live updates.

headline: Trump Stokes Fears About Haitian Migrants in a Pennsylvania Community
abstract: His focus on Charleroi, Pa., comes after his debunked claims about Haitian migrants in an Ohio community helped stir a firestorm over immigration there.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump vilified the migrant population of a small western Pennsylvania industrial town during a rally in the swing state on Monday, likening a group of Haitians who have made it their home to those in Springfield, Ohio, another place that was not well-known until he put it onto the political map.

headline: Stephen Colbert Is Tickled by Trump’s Vow to Make Women Great Again
abstract: “I‘m not sure if he’s running for president or marketing a new brand of tampon,” Colbert said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Rare Police Killing of Asian American Woman Has Rattled Her Community
abstract: Victoria Lee, a young Korean American woman, was fatally shot by a police officer during a mental health emergency. The event has sent shock waves through Fort Lee, N.J.
lead_paragraph: The 911 calls came in just after 1 a.m. A man requested an ambulance for his sister, who had bipolar disorder and was experiencing a mental health emergency at her apartment in Fort Lee, N.J. It was not the first time.

headline: An Interview With a Master Interviewer, Robert Caro
abstract: Alexandra Alter spent time with the author at a new exhibit celebrating the 50th anniversary of his book “The Power Broker.”
lead_paragraph: On a sunny morning this month, I met the writer Robert Caro at the New-York Historical Society beside Central Park. We were there to walk around a new exhibit celebrating the 50th anniversary of his book “The Power Broker,” a biography of the urban planner Robert Moses. The book is practically sacred among journalists, biographers and historians — revered for its meticulous research, elegant prose and insights into the nature of political power.

headline: Recess
abstract: What memories do you have of recess?
lead_paragraph: What do you remember about recess growing up?

headline: New Yorkers Brace for Gridlock and Headaches as U.N. Convenes
abstract: The U.N. General Assembly brings scores of world leaders to Manhattan’s East Side each year. Residents are concerned about disrupted commutes.
lead_paragraph: Nuria Flores has lived across from the United Nations headquarters for 12 years. And every year, she said, she dreads the week when world leaders and dignitaries descend on her neighborhood for the gathering of the U.N. General Assembly.

headline: In New Orleans, a ‘Black Beach’ Is Being Rescued From the Ruins
abstract: During segregation, Lincoln Beach was the only place on Lake Pontchartrain where Black people were allowed to swim. Now, after years of neglect and the intervention of local volunteers, it’s on the edge of revival.
lead_paragraph: During segregation, Lincoln Beach was the one place on Lake Pontchartrain in New Orleans where Black people were allowed to swim. Live acts like Fats Domino and Nat King Cole drew crowds to a recreation area that included a roller coaster and swimming pools. But with passage of the Civil Rights Act in 1964, Black New Orleanians were finally allowed to swim at nearby Pontchartrain Beach. Lincoln Beach closed not long after.

headline: Anti-Aging Enthusiasts Are Taking a Pill to Extend Their Lives. Will It Work?
abstract: Rapamycin is typically prescribed as an immunosuppressive, but off-label users believe it can do much more.
lead_paragraph: In March, Robert Berger, 69, a self-proclaimed “better-living-through-chemistry type of person,” started taking a small dose of rapamycin once a week with the goal of increasing his “health span” — the amount of time he might live without serious disease.

headline: These Maternity Homes Offer Sanctuary, but It Can Feel Oppressive
abstract: Unregulated homes are proliferating amid abortion restrictions and a housing crunch. Some limit residents’ movements, contacts and day-to-day decisions.
lead_paragraph: In Naples, Fla., Sunlight Home offered refuge and a fresh start for pregnant women on the brink of homelessness. It also required them to get permission before leaving the property and to download a tracking app on their phones, former residents said and its policies show.

headline: Teenagers: What Moments in the 2024 Election Do You Want to Remember?
abstract: It’s Week 3 of the Headway Election Challenge. Help us create a time capsule of this election year.
lead_paragraph: If you’re following this election closely, it can feel like a roller coaster, especially if you’re invested in the outcome. Many teenagers over the past few weeks and months have told us the election has major stakes for their families and their own futures.

headline: ‘Chaotic,’ ‘Misleading,’ ‘Informative’: What Teens Said About 2024 Election Coverage
abstract: More than 400 teenagers have participated in the Headway Election Challenge.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Ishya Jain, a 17-year-old senior at Plano East Senior High School in Plano, Texas, noticed something unsettling.

headline: The Most Famous Cafe in Paris Preps for a New Generation
abstract: For Les Deux Magots, 2024 is more than a milestone.
lead_paragraph: Les Deux Magots began as the Colette of the mid-19th century, a purveyor of silks and notions, fashion and accessories to a stylish clientele. Eclipsed by the rise of department stores, it reopened in 1884 as a modest cafe and liquor counter.

headline: Biden Warns the World Is at an ‘Inflection Point’ Amid Global Crises
abstract: In his final U.N. speech, President Biden framed his decision to drop his bid for re-election as a lesson that “some things are more important than staying in power.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden used his final speech to the United Nations on Tuesday to celebrate his defense of Ukraine against Russia’s invasion and his work to restore the United States’ global alliances, but he also warned that the advances of his administration could easily fall apart if America returned to isolationism.

headline: How to Cross-Stitch — and Make it Queer
abstract: Siret creates a needlepoint canvas filled with L.G.B.T.Q. symbols and historical references.
lead_paragraph: Siret creates a needlepoint canvas filled with L.G.B.T.Q. symbols and historical references.

headline: What if Jurors Could See Life Through the Defendants’ Eyes?
abstract: Jesse Ball’s Kafkaesque novel imagines a legal system that deploys a shockingly personal device.
lead_paragraph: No one enjoys jury duty, but few will find the process as harrowing as Abel Cotter does. In a dystopian future, Abel is summoned with others to undergo a series of bizarre tests that assess their worth as potential judges: “Only one person will be left, one fit person.” The chosen will enter the mysterious “repeat room” and render a verdict for the defendant.

headline: The Gay Male Artists Subverting the Primness of Cross-Stitch
abstract: Queer makers are using embroidery to challenge centuries of gender norms.
lead_paragraph: As a child in Nantes, France, the 26-year-old artist Victor Siret would often lose himself in the gothic foliage of a six-foot-long needlepoint canvas made by his grandmother, who started teaching him needlework when he was 10. When Siret went to art school in 2016, he kept up the practice, even as his professors told him “this was work for housewives,” he says. Drawing on a deep visual knowledge of American mass media, he filled tightly composed canvases with buildings shaped like cheeseburgers and packs of cigarettes, set against radioactive shades of yellow and pink. A suited corpse floats in a Hockneyesque swimming pool, and winking emblems of gay culture — a cowboy boot, a sauna sign — crowd the edges of strip malls. Through cross-stitch, Siret says, he could “digest the flow of digital images and materialize the pixel” and “explore bad taste.”

headline: The ‘Library Rats’ Who Helped Win World War II
abstract: In her lively “Book and Dagger,” the historian Elyse Graham rescues a cast of scholar-spies from obscurity.
lead_paragraph: The world of spying is traditionally divided into two categories: human intelligence and signals intelligence, known as humint and sigint.

headline: An Illustrated Guide to Fall’s New Books
abstract: What happens on Page 76 of books by Garth Greenwell, Domenico Starnone and Alia Trabucco Zéran, as envisioned by the artist Jammie Holmes.
lead_paragraph: “It was a dreary room made drearier by its own blankness, she hadn’t done anything yet to make it her own, the metal bookcases were empty, the off-white walls bare. The only personal touch was a lamp she had placed on her desk, a shawl draped across it to filter the light. …”

headline: Ukrainian Poet and Rock Star Fights Near Front and Performs Behind It
abstract: Serhiy Zhadan, 50, is a beloved Ukrainian poet as well as a novelist, lyricist and rock star. Furious over the invasion, he enlisted to fight even as his band still plays and his readings fill halls.
lead_paragraph: When the Ukrainian army hit a crisis of recruitment earlier this year amid rising losses on the battlefield, one of the most popular cultural personalities in the country stepped up and enlisted.

headline: Rebecca Lobo Helped Build the W.N.B.A. Now She’s Calling Its Next Chapter.
abstract: Lobo, one of the W.N.B.A.’s first stars, will now be broadcasting perhaps the most anticipated postseason in league history.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Lobo’s shoelace was untied.

headline: Is Green Tea Really ‘Nature’s Ozempic’?
abstract: Here’s what experts said about the beverage’s link to weight loss.
lead_paragraph: Q: I keep seeing TikToks calling green tea “nature’s Ozempic.” Is there any truth to that?

headline: For Niecy Nash-Betts, the Fear Was Motivating
abstract: Reading the script for FX’s “Grotesquerie,” her latest effort with Ryan Murphy, was terrifying on multiple levels. But that’s what drew her in.
lead_paragraph: Niecy Nash-Betts is serious about finding “stolen moments” in life, she said, as a balance to her busy acting schedule. And she is quick to nudge others to do the same. During a recent lunch at an Italian restaurant in Calabasas, she fired off a few date-night suggestions for a reporter who had lackluster birthday plans — maybe a couples ceramics class?

headline: What Pete Buttigieg Learned Playing JD Vance
abstract: The politician discusses how Democrats can rebuild trust.
lead_paragraph: Pete Buttigieg has had a fascinating rise in politics. He went from being the mayor of South Bend, Ind., a small but noble town, to an unexpectedly competitive presidential candidate, winning Iowa in 2020, to secretary of transportation. This year, he’s also proven to be one of the best communicators in the Democratic Party.

headline: The W.N.B.A. Wanted More Attention on TV. It Got Headaches, Too.
abstract: As ratings for women’s basketball soared, the league was confronted with the divisive language of sports debates.
lead_paragraph: When star prospects like Caitlin Clark and Angel Reese were set to become professionals this year, the W.N.B.A. said it was ready.

headline: Orange! Red! Yellow! 5 Colorful Fall Trips to Inspire Your Own
abstract: Among our favorite leaf-peeping road trips: A New Hampshire drive that avoids the state’s most crowded spots and a journey on the Blue Ridge Parkway, complete with ideas on where to get out of the car.
lead_paragraph: The leaves are turning, which means it’s time to get in the car and enjoy one of nature’s greatest shows. One thing that can quickly sap the serenity is inching along in traffic, as several thousand people pick the same leaf-peeping spot that you do.

headline: What Belongs to Opera? Garth Greenwell’s Novel of Desire
abstract: Greenwell’s “What Belongs to You” reaches the opera stage with a team that includes the composer David T. Little and the director Mark Morris.
lead_paragraph: The composer David T. Little isn’t sure whether it was really his idea to write the opera “What Belongs to You.”

headline: Will the Mets Make It to the Playoffs?
abstract: Some of the Mets’ most well-known fans, including a mathematician who studies the statistics each year, are hoping that this season won’t end in heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out why one ticket holder at a Rangers game tonight will have his mind on another sport entirely. We’ll also get details on what the United Nations General Assembly will mean for traffic on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Nicholas Kristof: Readers Respond to My Column on Trump Voters
abstract: The best way to persuade people is to engage with them.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, the columnist Nicholas Kristof argues that Democrats should focus their criticism on Donald Trump instead of the people who are voting for him.

headline: Nicholas Sparks on His New Book, Backgammon and Splenda Chicken Salad
abstract: Wander through the best-selling author’s palatial riverfront home in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Wander through the best-selling author’s palatial riverfront home in North Carolina.

headline: We Need a New Global Measure for Poverty
abstract: Eradicating poverty is at the top of the U.N.’s stated goals. But their measure of poverty is only half the story.
lead_paragraph: Eradicating poverty is at the top of the U.N.’s stated goals. But their measure of poverty is only half the story.

headline: Ellen DeGeneres Is in Her Boss Era on Her New Netflix Special
abstract: In the most insightful part of “For Your Approval,” she says that she was a poor fit to run a workplace but that women leaders are judged differently.
lead_paragraph: It takes a peculiarly modern chutzpah (or obliviousness) to say — on a Netflix special — that you were kicked out of show business.

headline: Why the Election Is Coming Down to Defining Kamala Harris
abstract: The vice president is leading in national polls, but that isn’t the whole story.
lead_paragraph: The battle to win over the remaining undecided voters in the 2024 presidential election looks as though it’s coming down to which campaign can successfully define Kamala Harris; look no further than the ads you see on TV in battleground states.

headline: The Black Box of the Undecided Voter Won’t Yield Its Secrets
abstract: Undecided voters have tuned out the noise of American politics.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, the actors and observers of U.S. politics descend upon a single group of people, the undecided voters of America.

headline: Careerism Is Ruining College
abstract: Economic anxieties are generating crushing pre-professional pressure on campuses, destroying college life and damaging students’ mental health.
lead_paragraph: When I pictured myself in college, I envisioned potluck picnics and late nights listening to Taylor Swift, overanalyzing class crushes. Maybe even joining a Quidditch team.

headline: Restaurant Portions Are About to Get Smaller. Are Americans Ready?
abstract: The towering burger and ballooning bagel have withstood public health campaigns, but a new movement to shrink servings is finally gaining traction.
lead_paragraph: Portion sizes in American restaurants shot up in the 1980s and never came down. The average serving of spaghetti and meatballs doubled. Bagels ballooned into six-inch-wide monstrosities. Burritos started to weigh more than a Harry Potter hardcover.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Ideas About Patriotism
abstract: Patriotic Americana has been the vice president’s theme since she became the  Democrats’ presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: The biggest thing in sight and the first thing most people probably saw when they walked into the arena where Kamala Harris held a recent rally in Greensboro, N.C., was the word “FREEDOM” on a giant blue banner with block letters in white and giant stars and flags on either side.

headline: Kamala Harris Talks About ‘Joy.’ But Are Undecided Voters Feeling It?
abstract: Approximately three million undecided voters in seven battleground states will most likely decide the outcome of the 2024 presidential election, and surveys show that these voters are pessimistic about the country’s future. Jonathan Swan, a reporter covering the presidential campaign for The New York Times, examines how these voters are responding to Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Approximately three million undecided voters in seven battleground states will most likely decide the outcome of the 2024 presidential election, and surveys show that these voters are pessimistic about the country’s future. Jonathan Swan, a reporter covering the presidential campaign for The New York Times, examines how these voters are responding to Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Arséma Thomas’s Watch
abstract: Wearing her perfectly imperfect watch helps the “She Taught Love” star feel close to her late father.
lead_paragraph: Arséma Thomas joked that the reason she hadn’t fixed her late father’s watch is because she feared what could be inside of it. (She knew from watching James Bond movies with her dad that the secret service agent’s timepieces could be explosive.)

headline: A Looming East Coast Port Strike Could Shake the Economy
abstract: Businesses are preparing for a strike by dockworkers on the East and Gulf Coasts, which could begin Oct. 1 if negotiations don’t yield a new contract.
lead_paragraph: With dockworkers on the East and Gulf Coasts threatening to strike on Oct. 1, businesses have been accelerating imports, redirecting cargo and pleading with the Biden administration to prevent a walkout.

headline: The Senate May Come Down to a Blue State Surprise
abstract: How party control of the Senate may come down to Maryland Democrats taking a big gamble.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t think I’m going to be the 51st vote.”

headline: Rare Copy of U.S. Constitution, Found in a File Cabinet, Is Up for Auction
abstract: An appraiser discovered the 1787 document before a house sale in North Carolina in 2022. It goes up for auction this week.
lead_paragraph: Ken Farmer, an antiques appraiser, opened a folder that had been stored for decades in a dusty file cabinet in an old mansion in North Carolina and pulled out a creased, worn sheet of paper. He could tell almost immediately that he was looking at a print dating back to the 18th or 19th century.

headline: How a Leftist Delivered Sri Lanka’s Biggest Political Jolt in Decades
abstract: Anura Kumara Dissanayake offered his broad leftist coalition as the best hope for a different political culture, one not ruled by nepotism and corruption.
lead_paragraph: Two of the front-runners in Sri Lanka’s presidential election were the sons of former presidents. A third contender, the incumbent, was the nephew and political heir of yet another president.

headline: How the Cost of Housing Became So Crushing
abstract: The roots of the property crisis run deep and have proved very hard to fix.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, frustration over the cost of housing in the United States has become a centerpiece of the presidential race, a focus of government policy and an agonizing nationwide problem.

headline: Israeli Strikes Kill Hundreds in Lebanon, and Biden to Address U.N.
abstract: Plus, the U.S. News college rankings are out.

headline: Britain’s National Theater Director Takes a Final Bow
abstract: As Rufus Norris prepares to leave the London playhouse he has led since 2015, he reflects on his quest to make the theater represent the audience it serves.
lead_paragraph: When Rufus Norris became the director of the National Theater in 2015, he said he had one main aim: to make the playhouse representative of Britain.

headline: Israel’s Strikes on Lebanon
abstract: We explore what led to the strikes, what’s happening now and what might come next.
lead_paragraph: Israel is now at war on its western and northern borders as a tense stalemate with Hezbollah, a militant group in Lebanon, has escalated into open conflict.

headline: In Rare Graft Case in Singapore, Former Minister Pleads Guilty
abstract: S. Iswaran, the former transport minister, had maintained his innocence on the corruption charge for months but on Tuesday pleaded guilty to five lesser offenses.
lead_paragraph: He was the first minister to be charged with corruption in Singapore in nearly 50 years. For months, he had vowed to clear his name.

headline: Forum 5 | What Gives You Hope for the Future?
abstract: What do you think your generation might do better than those who came before it did?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the fifth and final installment of our Election 2024 Student Conversation Forums, in which teenagers from around the world are invited to explore their political and civic identities, values and beliefs and discuss them with others. All our posts remain open, so you are welcome to contribute to this post or any of the others.

headline: Rethinking ‘Checks and Balances’ for the A.I. Age
abstract: A project at Stanford points to the need for institutional innovation, especially in government, to increase the odds that A.I. enhances democracy.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1780s, shortly after the Industrial Revolution had begun, Alexander Hamilton, James Madison and John Jay wrote a series of 85 spirited essays, collectively known as the Federalist Papers. They argued for ratification of the Constitution and an American system of checks and balances to keep power-hungry “factions” in check.

headline: Is Visa a Monopoly?
abstract: The Justice Department is expected to sue the global payments giant as soon as Tuesday, accusing the company of stifling competition.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is readying its next big antitrust fight — and it’s against Visa, one of the pillars of the global payments system.

headline: China to Investigate U.S. Retailer, Sending a Message Over Xinjiang
abstract: PVH, which owns Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, is targeted for allegedly avoiding purchases from the region where the Chinese government has cracked down on Muslim minorities.
lead_paragraph: China said on Tuesday that it would investigate whether PVH, the American retailer that owns the Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands, has taken “discriminatory measures” against products from Xinjiang in China’s far west.

headline: Zelensky Prepares for Tough Act Putting Ukraine War Back on Global Agenda
abstract: In his speech to the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday and then a meeting with President Biden a day later, the Ukrainian president will be pleading for more military and political support.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, a one-time actor now making perhaps his most important visit to the United States in recent years, knows how to build dramatic tension.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Instagram, Lebanon, Baseball Record
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: As Lebanon Reels From Israeli Attacks, the Future Is Murky for a Wounded Hezbollah
abstract: Some experts said that Israel’s onslaught had left Hezbollah in disarray. Others noted its large weapons stockpiles and history of adapting to battle Israel’s much more high-tech military.
lead_paragraph: Swaths of southern Lebanon are smoldering ruins. Highways are clogged with thousands fleeing the possibility of an even bigger war between Israel and Hezbollah. As towns and villages held funerals on Tuesday, Lebanon was just beginning to grapple with the fallout from its deadliest day in decades.

headline: Strange Cellmates in a Brooklyn Jail: Sean Combs and Sam Bankman-Fried
abstract: Mr. Combs is sleeping in the same dormitory-style room as Mr. Bankman-Fried, the crypto mogul who was convicted of fraud.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs is living in the same unit of a Brooklyn jail as Sam Bankman-Fried, the crypto mogul convicted of fraud, sleeping in a dormitory-style room with a group of other defendants assigned to the same section, according to a person familiar with the living arrangements.

headline: Inside a Kamala Harris Ad Promoting Her Economic Plans
abstract: Polls show voters want to know more about what she would do. This ad, running across the battlegrounds, gives answers.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is running versions of this 60-second ad, titled “Different Visions” — with the same audio but different images — on stations in each of the seven battleground states and in Omaha. The campaign has spent $2.3 million on the ad since early September, according to AdImpact.

headline: Report on Antisemitism at CUNY Calls for Changes Across the System
abstract: The report, commissioned by New York’s governor, found that the city’s university system was ill-equipped to handle rising antisemitism. But it also said the problem was not widespread.
lead_paragraph: An independent review ordered by Gov. Kathy Hochul has found that the City University of New York needs to “significantly” overhaul and update its policies in order to handle the levels of antisemitism and discrimination that exist on its campuses.

headline: A Pygmy Hippo Is Stealing Hearts (and Biting Zookeepers)
abstract: Moo Deng, whose name translates to “bouncy pork,” has united the internet while following a familiar path to stardom.
lead_paragraph: Defiant, sassy, slippery, chubby, loves to scream. We can all relate.

headline: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Helene
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Helene.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Helene.

headline: That Message From Your Doctor? It May Have Been Drafted by A.I.
abstract: Overwhelmed by queries, physicians are turning to artificial intelligence to correspond with patients. Many have no clue that the replies are software-generated.
lead_paragraph: Every day, patients send hundreds of thousands of messages to their doctors through MyChart, a communications platform that is nearly ubiquitous in U.S. hospitals.

headline: Sheriff Who Suggested Tracking Harris Supporters Is Stripped of Election Role
abstract: The Ohio sheriff who urged his followers to record the addresses of people with yard signs supporting Vice President Kamala Harris will no longer head security at the county’s early voting location.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio sheriff has been stripped of his role providing security at his county’s early voting location, members of a local elections board said, after he compared immigrants to insects and urged residents to record the addresses of people who have yard signs supporting Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: How Meta Distanced Itself From Politics
abstract: Ahead of November’s election, Meta has de-emphasized political content on Facebook, Instagram and Threads and doesn’t want to talk about candidates or campaigns.
lead_paragraph: In January 2021, after pro-Trump rioters stormed the U.S. Capitol, Mark Zuckerberg announced a new priority for Meta: He wanted to reduce the amount of political content on the company’s apps, including Facebook and Instagram.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Is Done With Politics
abstract: He was once a backer of liberal causes. Then everyone seemed to turn on him. Now he wants to stay away from politics — if that’s possible.
lead_paragraph: It was only a little more than a decade ago that Mark Zuckerberg had few qualms about airing his politics.

headline: Escalation in the Middle East Looms Over the General Assembly Meeting
abstract: The war in Gaza has endured more than 11 months, and violence between Israel and Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese militia, has risen sharply over the last week.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations General Assembly convened in New York on Tuesday against the backdrop of a world embroiled in several wars, including Israel’s expanding and increasingly deadly wars with Hamas and Hezbollah.

headline: No Plates Allowed
abstract: Tortellini soup, mushrooms and dumplings, niku udon and more spoon-friendly dishes.
lead_paragraph: Hi, lovelies. This is Margaux, filling in for Emily this week.

headline: Is Paying Kids to Read a Wise Strategy?
abstract: Readers discuss an essay by a parent who gave her daughter a $100 reward. Also: Donald Trump and the psychiatrists; a second debate; heartland immigrants.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: These Voters Are Anti-Trump, but Will They Be Pro-Harris?
abstract: Democrats see an opportunity to win over right-leaning Americans who have recoiled from Donald Trump. The challenge is coaxing them off the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: Emily Brieve, a Republican county commissioner in Michigan, voted for Donald J. Trump in 2020. Her campaign website highlighted her opposition to abortion rights. And until this year, she had never considered voting for a Democratic presidential candidate.

headline: What Are People Saying About the New Sally Rooney Book?
abstract: “Intermezzo,” the Irish novelist’s fourth novel, is one of this fall’s most anticipated books.
lead_paragraph: Seven years into her writing career, a new book by Sally Rooney is all but guaranteed to be an event.

headline: Trump Pitches ‘New American Industrialism’ and Luring Foreign Manufacturing
abstract: The former president highlighted his plans to increase tariffs and reduce corporate taxes for businesses that make products in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump pledged on Tuesday to lure other countries’ factories to the United States, promising to offer companies tax breaks and access to federal land if they moved their manufacturing operations.

headline: How Does a Baseball Team Lose 120 Games? Every Way You Can Think Of.
abstract: The Chicago White Sox are poised to break the record for the most losses in modern baseball history. Watching them do it has been strangely glorious.
lead_paragraph: In the fourth inning of a ridiculous baseball game — ridiculous even by the standards of the 2024 Chicago White Sox — I wandered out into the stands to meet Beefloaf.

headline: N.J. State Police ‘Weaponized’ Disciplinary Investigations, Reports Find
abstract: The state’s attorney general has seized control of the agency’s human resources and equal opportunity functions after investigations into racial and gender bias.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s attorney general has ordered an overhaul of the internal affairs unit of the State Police and seized control of its human resources department after concluding that disciplinary investigations had been “weaponized” against some troopers.

headline: ‘We Will Dance Again’ Review: Remembering Oct. 7
abstract: In this documentary by Yariv Mozer, Israelis who attended the Nova music festival near the Gaza border describe how they survived the attack last year.
lead_paragraph: “We Will Dance Again” reconstructs the Hamas-led attack on Israel on Oct. 7 from the perspectives of attendees of the Nova music festival. At least 360 people were killed at the event that was near the border with Gaza, according to Israeli authorities. Directed by Yariv Mozer, this documentary opens with an acknowledgment of the fraught subject matter. “The human cost of the Hamas massacre in Israel and the war that followed in Gaza has been catastrophic for both Israelis and Palestinians,” the text says. Citing death tolls from both sides of the conflict, it adds, “This film cannot tell everyone’s story.”

headline: Zelensky Says Western Allies Must Allow Ukrainian Strikes Deep Into Russia
abstract: The leaders of Ukraine and Denmark said in a joint interview that allied nations must lift restrictions on arms, increase their production and help Ukraine build weapons inside the country.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said Tuesday that he would urge the leaders of the United States, Britain and France to allow Ukrainian forces to use weapons supplied by those nations for strikes deep into Russian territory.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: Maryland
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Maryland.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Maryland.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: California
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for California.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for California.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: New Mexico
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for New Mexico.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: Ohio
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Ohio.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Ohio.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: Texas
abstract: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Texas.
lead_paragraph: See the latest election polls and polling averages for Texas.

headline: Baldwin, With Shapiro in Tow, Looks For ‘Trump-Tammy Voters’ in Wisconsin
abstract: The Democratic senator, who is seeking a third term in a politically competitive state, rallied with the Pennsylvania governor, who has a track record of appealing to voters in rural, conservative-leaning areas.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania was stumping for Senator Tammy Baldwin outside a refurbished gas station here in central Wisconsin on Saturday when a heckler drove by shouting, “Trump 2024!”

headline: Families of Hostages and Gazans Feel Forgotten as War Heats Up in Lebanon
abstract: Talks to reach a potential cease-fire in Gaza and free the remaining 100 or so hostages have stalled.
lead_paragraph: After six Israeli hostages were found dead recently in Gaza, shocking the country, the families of the remaining captives hoped that the tragedy might pressure Israel to accept a cease-fire agreement to secure their release.

headline: Ted Cruz Is Again Fighting for Political Survival in Texas
abstract: The fiery senator, who was nearly unseated in 2018, has been trying to rebrand himself in a close race against a Democratic congressman and former N.F.L. player, Colin Allred.
lead_paragraph: On a late summer afternoon, Colin Allred, the Democratic challenger to U.S. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, mingled his way through a barbershop in a historically Black neighborhood of Houston.

headline: Review: A Devastated Drone Pilot Opens the Met Opera’s Season
abstract: Jeanine Tesori and George Brant’s bloodless “Grounded,” about a fighter pilot turned dissociating drone operator, stars the mezzo-soprano Emily D’Angelo.
lead_paragraph: On a fall evening in 1883, the Metropolitan Opera opened its doors for the first time with a performance of “Faust,” the classic tale of a man who sells his soul to Mephistopheles to gain power and pleasure.

headline: A Montreal Museum Reckons with Its Legacy, and Uplifts Inuit Artists
abstract: This fall, the Montreal Museum of Fine Art’s Native art collection — once consigned to a far corner — will be front and center in a new show.
lead_paragraph: In a fast-paced world, asinnajaq likes to take things slow.

headline: Israel’s Strikes on Lebanon Are Some of the Deadliest in Decades
abstract: What we know about the strikes, the death toll and how it is calculated.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s strikes on Lebanon on Monday amounted to one of the most intense air raids in contemporary warfare, outstripping even the bombing of Gaza during the opening days of the Israeli-Hamas war in October, war experts said.

headline: YongChuan Serves Up the Seafood of Ningbo and the Spice of Sichuan
abstract: Alex Stupak serves New England fare at the Otter and Sloane’s, Bridges pulls from the larder of Europe and North America, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Ningbo, a port city south of Shanghai, is known for seafood, often steamed, with a particular penchant for yellow croaker and crab. Tony Li, the chef who owns this new spot, is from that city. Ningbo dishes by the executive chef Xing Zhong Qi and his chef de cuisine, De Qin Zhang, include pork patty, steamed wild yellow croaker and Ningbo 18 Cuts, a wild imported sea crab in 18 pieces to pre-order. These are juxtaposed with hot Sichuan fare like mapo tofu, spicy soft shell crab and spicy squid tentacles.

headline: Maryland Sues Shipping Companies to Cover Costs of Bridge Collapse
abstract: The lawsuit is the latest legal fallout from the disaster in March, which killed six people and halted operations at the Port of Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: The state of Maryland is demanding that the owner and the operator of the ship that toppled the Francis Scott Key Bridge in March pay up.

headline: Russia Signs Satellite Deal With Three West African Military Juntas
abstract: The partnership between Russia’s space agency and the governments of Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger deepens these countries’ turn toward the Kremlin in their effort to fight off Islamist insurgencies.
lead_paragraph: Russia will deploy telecommunications and remote-sensing satellites over three West African countries led by military juntas that had already cut ties with American and European allies and turned toward the Kremlin for military support to contain Islamist insurgents.

headline: Desert Racers Demolish Art Carved by Ancient People in Chile
abstract: Preservationists say governments at all levels have failed to prevent authorized and illegal off-road racers from driving through giant figures of animals, humans and objects.
lead_paragraph: Every year, hundreds of racers from around the world gather in northern Chile with their all-terrain motorcycles, jeeps, quads and buggies. They race in circuits for hundreds of miles around the Atacama Desert, carving tire tracks into one of the driest places on Earth.

headline: Manchin Won’t Endorse Harris After Her Call to End Filibuster Over Abortion Rights
abstract: “Shame on her,” Joe Manchin, the independent senator from West Virginia, said after Kamala Harris reiterated her support for ending the Senate practice. “She knows the filibuster is the Holy Grail of democracy.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, an independent who considered making a presidential run this year, said on Tuesday that he would not endorse Vice President Kamala Harris after she reiterated her support for eliminating the Senate filibuster to pass abortion rights legislation.

headline: Amal Clooney, Cate Blanchett and Sting Cap a Starry Week of Galas
abstract: Hollywood luminaries gathered for the Albie Awards; and the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera drew a crowd of philanthropists and Broadway stars to Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Fall gala season has arrived with its annual marathon of lavish events drawing influential and powerful figures. Across New York, actors, musicians, politicians, philanthropists and executives, dressed in their finest, schmoozed over multicourse dinners and exclusive performances as major institutions appealed to some of the city’s wealthiest residents for financial support and cultural cachet. See who was out, what they wore and how much was raised.

headline: U.K.’s Starmer Attempts to Sprinkle Some Harris-Style ‘Joy’ Into Speech
abstract: After a somewhat bumpy start to his premiership, Keir Starmer tried to reclaim the narrative, acknowledging voters’ desire for hope and promising change was on the way.
lead_paragraph: Taking a page from the Democratic presidential ticket in the United States, Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Tuesday promised to bring joy back to everyday life in Britain, which he said was sorely lacking after a cost-of-living crisis and the strain of coping with the country’s run-down public services.

headline: What are Your Unusual Holiday Traditions?
abstract: For many people, celebrating the winter holidays means marking it in eccentric and sometimes downright inexplicable ways.
lead_paragraph: Some holiday-time traditions are so classic that they tend to serve as shorthand for the season: baking cookies, lighting a menorah or kinara, ice skating as a light snow falls. But many of us also have rituals that are specific to us and our loved ones, whether stemming from a blending of cultural or religious traditions or from a desire to do something different. Or maybe you don’t even know how your particular tradition started, but you do it every year without fail.

headline: The Death of Outdoor Dining Is a Blow to New York’s Vitality
abstract: All for a set of narrow, self-serving complaints about parking and noise.
lead_paragraph: First it was the death of congestion pricing — and with it, around $10 billion from federal matching programs for much-needed improvements to the subways and other mass transit, eliminating as many as 100,000 jobs. Then it was the slow abandonment of bus lanes (the city is on track to build just 27 miles of the 150 miles promised by Mayor Eric Adams). And now, bit by bit, New York City’s overwhelmingly popular outdoor dining is collapsing.

headline: Harris to More Fully Detail Economic Plans
abstract: With a speech on Wednesday and a lengthy policy document, Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign is set to lay out her economic vision as voters say they want to know more about her approach.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to ramp up her economic message this week, with a speech declaring herself a pragmatist who is not “bound by ideology” and a lengthy new document describing her approach in more detail.

headline: Willie, Waylon and the Boys: the Ultimate Outlaw Country Primer
abstract: Hear songs from Willie Nelson, Waylon Jennings, Kris Kristofferson, Johnny Cash and more, inspired by a new book.
lead_paragraph: I’m a sucker for anything remotely related to country music’s outlaw movement, and I recently tore through the audiobook of Brian Fairbanks’s tome “Willie, Waylon, and the Boys: How Nashville Outsiders Changed Country Music Forever,” an informative page-turner that inspired today’s playlist.

headline: Send Us Your Questions About Climate Change
abstract: What should The Times ask change experts, world leaders and policymakers at its Climate Forward conference on Sept. 25?
lead_paragraph: What should we ask some of the world’s leading experts on climate change, electric vehicles, energy and environmental policy?

headline: U.S. Accuses Visa of Monopoly in Debit Cards
abstract: The financial giant, which processes the majority of debit card spending in the United States, unfairly imposed fees on merchants and deterred rivals, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit against Visa on Tuesday, accusing the financial giant of unfairly stifling competition in debit cards, the latest in a string of cases aimed at deterring monopolistic behavior by big companies.

headline: Hemmed In by the Hard Right, Johnson Again Turns to Democrats for Votes
abstract: The House speaker is trying to get a short-term spending agreement passed despite opposition from some conservative members of his own party.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson is preparing to steer around a bloc of conservative opposition to a bipartisan short-term agreement to fund the government by relying — yet again — on Democrats to provide the bulk of votes to pass the legislation.

headline: More Money Urgently Needed to Reach Younger and Minority Voters, Organizers Warn Harris Donors
abstract: A new memo, released by two of the leading Democratic groups working in battleground states, lays out worrying signs for Vice President Kamala Harris among younger voters and voters of color.
lead_paragraph: Two national Democratic groups leading digital turnout operations in battleground states warned in a memo on Tuesday that the grass-roots organizations working to reach young Black and Latino voters were critically underfunded.

headline: Both Presidential Candidates Are Ignoring American Wellness
abstract: The U.S. allows chemicals and pesticides banned by Europe, but the issue hasn’t come up in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: An opinion essay in The Wall Street Journal recently proposed a list of health policies for Donald Trump to adopt, should he become president again. One of them: “Revisit pesticide and other chemical-use standards,” because the United States allows many pesticides and chemicals that Europe bans. Another: “Prohibit members of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee from making money from food or drug companies.” These are likely to seem reasonable to most readers, regardless of their ideologies.

headline: Israel Says It Killed Another Top Leader of Hezbollah, the Latest Blow in a Concerted Campaign
abstract: For nearly a year, Hezbollah has been attacking Israel in solidarity with Hamas in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said Tuesday that it had killed a senior Hezbollah commander in an airstrike in Beirut, the latest blow in what appears to be a concerted Israeli attempt to take out the group’s leadership.

headline: Behind Kamala Harris’s Rise: Silicon Valley’s Wealthiest Woman
abstract: The alliance between Kamala Harris and Laurene Powell Jobs is a genuine friendship that has thrust the press-shy billionaire philanthropist into the political spotlight.
lead_paragraph: After Vice President Joe Biden swore in Kamala Harris as a United States senator in January 2017, they posed for a customary photo in the Capitol with her family. Then she asked her future boss for a favor: Would he indulge in one more photo?

headline: How to Watch the Vance-Walz Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: CBS News will broadcast the 90-minute debate, starting at 9 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday. The Times will stream it alongside real-time commentary and analysis from reporters.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio will face off on Tuesday in the only scheduled vice-presidential debate, convening three weeks after their running mates, Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump, sparred in Philadelphia.

headline: T.I. and Tiny Awarded $71 Million Over L.O.L. Dolls’ Likeness to R&B Group
abstract: A jury found that the toy giant MGA Entertainment had violated the musicians’ intellectual property rights with its L.O.L. Surprise! O.M.G. dolls.
lead_paragraph: The dolls are small. The award is big.

headline: Here’s How the Forecast for Tropical Storm Helene Is Shaping Up
abstract: When the storm’s center was located on Tuesday, it gave meteorologists a crucial next step in firming up the storm’s forecast.
lead_paragraph: When potential tropical cyclone 9 officially became Tropical Storm Helene late on Tuesday morning, forecasters who had been watching the storm’s recent development from a swirl of thunderstorms in the western Caribbean Sea were able to begin piecing together more information about how big Helene might grow — and where it might go next.

headline: Brett Favre Reveals He Has Parkinson’s Disease
abstract: Mr. Favre, the former N.F.L. quarterback who fell from grace after Mississippi officials accused him of helping divert funds meant for low-income residents, announced the diagnosis before Congress.
lead_paragraph: Brett Favre, the former N.F.L. quarterback accused of diverting millions of dollars in federal money away from welfare recipients, said on Tuesday that he had been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease.

headline: Up In the Air With the Hurricane Hunters
abstract: To understand how powerful a storm might get, experts get their data by flying right into it.
lead_paragraph: There is no in-flight entertainment, and yet my hosts in blue flight suits tell me to prepare for a show. I have been briefed to avoid gassy foods, and the sick sack is pointed out to me.

headline: Caroline Ellison, Star Witness at FTX Trial, Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
abstract: A top adviser to Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced founder of FTX, Ms. Ellison pleaded guilty to conspiring with him to steal $8 billion and became a crucial witness for the prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Ellison, a former top adviser to the cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried, was sentenced to two years in prison on Tuesday for her role in the $8 billion fraud that led to the implosion of the once high-flying FTX crypto exchange.

headline: David Banks, New York City’s Schools Chancellor, to Resign
abstract: The resignation of Mr. Banks, planned for the end of the year, comes amid a flurry of federal investigations into Mayor Eric Adams and his administration.
lead_paragraph: David C. Banks, the chancellor of New York City’s public school system, said on Tuesday that he would resign from his post at the end of December.

headline: Israel’s Attacks on Hezbollah Achieved Short-Term Aims, Officials Say, but End Goal Is Unclear
abstract: Some hawkish generals think that Hezbollah can be forced to back down, current and former Israeli officials said, while others in the government think Israel must reach a deal with Hamas before expanding the war.
lead_paragraph: Israel achieved many short-term goals in a series of strikes on Hezbollah during the last week, according to five current and former senior Israeli officials. But they also expressed concern that there was no clear further strategy on bringing calm and returning tens of thousands of displaced people back to Israel’s north.

headline: Zelensky Addresses the Security Council, Calling for Attention to Stay on Ukraine
abstract: “Russia can only be forced into peace.” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the Council members to sustain their backing for his country’s resistance to Russia’s full-scale invasion.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine told the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday that “Russia can only be forced into peace” and urged that the Russia-Ukraine war not be overlooked as the world turned its attention to wars in Gaza, Sudan and Myanmar.“Russia is committing an international crime,” Mr. Zelensky said in a short but impassioned speech. “This war can’t simply fade away, this war can’t be calmed by talks. Actions are needed. Russia can only be forced into peace.”Mr. Zelensky also told the council’s 15 members that Ukraine had obtained information that Russia was planning to attack its three nuclear plants. “We have proof of this, if Russia is ready to go that far, it means nothing you value matters to Moscow,” he said.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: The U.N. General Assembly Convenes
abstract: Plus, news outlets experiment with WhatsApp.
lead_paragraph: World leaders gathered in New York to hear President Biden and other speakers address the 79th meeting of the United Nations assembly, in the shadow of war and turmoil across the world.

headline: In Manhattan, Pedaling After Cycling Hustlers
abstract: Some New Yorkers found a way to beat Citi Bike’s algorithm. And one reporter found those New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: It dawned upon me that I had worn the wrong shirt for undercover work. It was a hot morning in August, and I was standing on Broadway near Times Square, tracking seven men who did not want to be tracked.

headline: House Panel Recommends Holding Blinken in Contempt
abstract: Democrats accused Republicans of trying to damage the Biden administration at the height of a campaign season.
lead_paragraph: Republicans on the House Foreign Affairs Committee on Tuesday recommended holding Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in contempt of Congress for failing to testify in their investigation of the chaotic U.S. exit from Afghanistan, in what Democrats charged was a political stunt ahead of the election.

headline: Vance and Walz Will Debate Standing Up, in a Rarity for V.P. Clashes
abstract: The vice-presidential debate will be the first without chairs since Joe Biden’s face-off against Sarah Palin in 2008. Both candidates are preparing this week, with Tim Walz heading to Northern Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio will stand behind lecterns for their debate next week, according to four people briefed on the plans, the first time since 2008 that the vice-presidential candidates have not been sitting for a debate.

headline: Woman Accuses Sean Combs of Raping Her in Filmed Attack
abstract: In a new lawsuit, the woman said Mr. Combs and his bodyguard drugged and assaulted her in his recording studio in 2001.
lead_paragraph: A woman accused the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs of drugging and raping her at his recording studio in Manhattan in 2001 in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday, saying that she learned last year that the assault had been recorded and shown to others.

headline: Judge Rejects Trump’s Last-Minute Bid to Delay Assessment of Jan. 6 Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors can come ahead with a lengthy filing containing evidence backing their argument that the indictment of the former president can survive the Supreme Court’s immunity ruling.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday rejected an effort by former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers to push off until after November an assessment of whether the indictment accusing Mr. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election can survive the Supreme Court’s ruling granting him broad immunity from prosecution.

headline: What Lebanon Looks Like After Israel’s Historic Airstrikes
abstract: The destruction from one of the most intense air raids in modern warfare stretches across southern Lebanon and in pockets of the east.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year of back-and-forth attacks between Israel and Hezbollah, the fighting along the border in the last two days has been remarkably one-sided.

headline: CrowdStrike Executive Questioned by Lawmakers Over Global Tech Outage
abstract: Adam Meyers, a senior vice president of the cybersecurity firm, testified in front of a House Homeland Security subcommittee about the July mishap.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers on Tuesday grilled an executive from the cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike about a widespread technology outage this summer that crippled global travel, hobbled government agencies and sent major companies scrambling to get their operations back online.

headline: Dick Moss, Who Helped Usher In Baseball Free Agency, Dies at 93
abstract: A labor lawyer, he was crucial to toppling a decades-old system that bound players to teams year after year, setting the stage for their rich contracts of today.
lead_paragraph: Dick Moss, a labor lawyer who, with Marvin Miller, the powerful leader of the union that represents baseball players, set the stage for the sport’s free agency revolution, died on Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Biden Warned the World Is at an ‘Inflection Point’
abstract: Also, thousands are fleeing southern Lebanon. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden used his fourth and final address to the United Nations General Assembly today to argue that “things can get better,” even in a world that appears enveloped in crises. He celebrated his efforts to defend Ukraine and rebuild America’s global alliances, however he also said that the progress could easily collapse if the U.S. turns to isolationism.

headline: As U.N. Meets, Israel Pounds Targets in Lebanon, Sending Civilians Fleeing
abstract: Israel said it was striking Hezbollah targets with “high intensity” to keep the campaign as short as possible, as the Lebanese militants maintained their own cross-border barrage.
lead_paragraph: Thousands fled their homes on Tuesday as Israeli warplanes pounded more Hezbollah targets in Lebanon, in an offensive that has plunged the country into uncertainty over what Israel will do next and how the militant group might respond.

headline: Former Memphis Officer Apologizes for His Role in Tyre Nichols’s Death
abstract: Desmond Mills Jr., who testified against his former colleagues, broke down in court, saying, “I made his child fatherless.”
lead_paragraph: Desmond Mills Jr. watched the footage from his body camera, the Memphis courtroom silent except for the sounds of punches and Tyre Nichols’s agonized cries for his mother.

headline: Biden Boasts of Climate Wins and Warns of Reversals Under Trump
abstract: At an event in New York, the president said federal investments in climate action would be at risk if former President Donald J. Trump retook the White House.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday celebrated his record overseeing historic action to fight climate change and warned that the Republican trying to succeed him, Donald J. Trump, would unwind those accomplishments and condemn “future generations to a more dangerous world.”

headline: Sequel to Ghost of Tsushima Expands a Fresh Sony Franchise
abstract: The anticipated game, Ghost of Yotei, will follow a woman on a quest for vengeance in the snowy reaches of northern Japan.
lead_paragraph: Even before Ghost of Tsushima won players over with its samurai protagonist and cinematic flair inspired by Kurosawa films like “Yojimbo,” its designers felt confident enough to start planning a sequel.

headline: Read the document
abstract: A new memo from two of the leading Democratic groups working in battleground states.
lead_paragraph: A new memo from two of the leading Democratic groups working in battleground states.

headline: Hezbollah Is Everyone’s Problem
abstract: The United States must help Israel defeat it.
lead_paragraph: In 2006 Hezbollah launched a guerrilla raid into Israel. It led to a 34-day war that devastated Lebanon, traumatized Israel, and concluded with a U.N. resolution that was supposed to disarm the terrorist militia and keep its forces far from the border.

headline: Why Debunked Falsehoods About Haitian Migrants Gained Traction
abstract: The racist and inflammatory narrative spread on the backs of memes, greed, biases and news deserts.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague Tiffany Hsu, who covers misinformation and disinformation, explains why false claims about Haitians in Ohio spread so widely even after they were debunked. We’re also covering Democratic groups’ warning about key voting blocs, and the way Republicans have talked about abortion in recent days. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Missouri Man Executed After Long Fight for Exoneration
abstract: Marcellus Williams, who was convicted of a 1998 murder in suburban St. Louis, maintained he was innocent. But the courts and the governor were not persuaded.
lead_paragraph: The state of Missouri executed Marcellus Williams on Tuesday evening by lethal injection, over the objections of the local prosecutor whose office obtained Mr. Williams’s murder conviction in 2003.

headline: Climber Dies After Fall at Devils Tower in Wyoming, Park Service Says
abstract: A 21-year-old rock climber from Wisconsin was descending the national monument when he fell, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A rock climber died on Sunday evening after he fell from Devils Tower National Monument, a hulking rock formation in northeast Wyoming, park officials said.

headline: What Is Parkinson’s Disease?
abstract: Brett Favre announced his diagnosis on Tuesday. Here’s what we know about the disease and its relationship to head injuries.
lead_paragraph: The retired N.F.L. quarterback Brett Favre told a congressional committee on Tuesday that he had been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease, a progressive, incurable condition that causes tremors and stiffness, often resulting in impaired movement and speech.

headline: Bernie Moreno Under Fire Over Comments About Suburban Women
abstract: Mr. Moreno, a Republican running for Senate in Ohio, suggested that older women shouldn’t care about abortion because they were too old to have children, comments Nikki Haley pointedly criticized.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Moreno, the Republican Senate candidate in Ohio, is facing criticism over demeaning remarks he made last week about women who support abortion rights, including from Nikki Haley, the former Republican presidential candidate and one of the most prominent women in her party.

headline: Alex Jones’s Infowars Will Be Auctioned Off to Pay Sandy Hook Families
abstract: A sale of the Infowars website and other property is set for November, and could determine the conspiracy theorist’s fate as a broadcaster.
lead_paragraph: A Houston bankruptcy judge ruled on Tuesday that assets from the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones’s Infowars empire can be auctioned off to help pay families of the Sandy Hook mass shooting victims the defamation awards he owes them.

headline: Trump Golf Course Suspect Is Charged With Attempted Assassination
abstract: The new federal indictment in Florida comes on top of two gun charges against Ryan W. Routh, an itinerant contractor with an extensive criminal record.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of lurking with a gun near former President Donald J. Trump at one of his Florida golf courses was charged on Tuesday with the attempted assassination of a presidential candidate, a crime that carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment.

headline: Leadership Failures Helped Lead to FAFSA Debacle, Watchdog Finds
abstract: Two reports by the Government Accountability Office found that mismanagement and wildly unrealistic projections derailed the student aid application process this year.
lead_paragraph: Leaders in the Education Department systematically failed to manage deadlines and badly underestimated technical shortcomings while overhauling the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, according to a pair of damaging reports released by the Government Accountability Office on Tuesday.

headline: Brio
abstract: Peter Gordon’s puzzle comes with surround sound.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Review: What’s Eating Trump? The Singing ‘Ghost of John McCain’
abstract: The former senator haunts the former president, or vice versa, in this sophomoric musical satire.
lead_paragraph: Usually, critics wait until a show is running to slam it, but Meghan McCain broke the embargo. By more than five months.

headline: Chemical Leak From Rail Yard Near Cincinnati Prompts Evacuations
abstract: A train car in Whitewater Township, Ohio, was discovered to be leaking styrene, which is used to make plastic and fiberglass and is highly flammable.
lead_paragraph: Residents of several communities outside Cincinnati were ordered to leave or seal off their homes on Tuesday after officials warned that a train car in the area was leaking a dangerous chemical that could cause an explosion.

headline: Paul Simon Plays Rare New York Show in a Downtown Loft
abstract: The 82-year old singer received several standing ovations at an exclusive SoHo Sessions performance that drew fans including Kevin Bacon, Jerry Seinfeld and Amy Schumer.
lead_paragraph: Paul Simon walked onstage to a rousing ovation in a royal purple jacket for a casual downtown evening — as laid back as something with about 150 guests could be — at the SoHo Sessions loft in NoLIta on Monday just after 8 p.m. for a small benefit concert.

headline: Google, Visa, JetBlue: A Guide to a New Era of U.S. Antitrust Cases
abstract: Below are 15 major cases brought by the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission since late 2020, as President Biden’s top antitrust enforcers have promised to sue monopolies and block big mergers.
lead_paragraph: Below are 15 major cases brought by the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission since late 2020, as President Biden’s top antitrust enforcers have promised to sue monopolies and block big mergers.

headline: Trump Is Briefed on Iranian Assassination Threats
abstract: U.S. intelligence agencies had previously tracked a potential Iranian assassination plot. The Trump campaign said in a statement that the threat is now heightened.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was briefed on Tuesday by U.S. intelligence officials about “specific threats from Iran to assassinate him,” according to his campaign.

headline: Study Finds Climate Change Doubled Likelihood of Recent European Floods
abstract: Storm Boris dumped record amounts of rain over Central and Eastern Europe this month. A new study found climate change made the deluge more likely.
lead_paragraph: Europe faced catastrophic floodwaters that affected two million people earlier this month and transformed neighborhoods and urban centers into muddy rivers. At least 24 people died, and some were reported missing.

headline: Quote of the Day: A File Cabinet Yields a Rare Copy of the U.S. Constitution
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 25, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Part of what is so powerful about it is that it’s just this thin piece of paper. It’s a simple thing.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 25, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Monday about the Fête de l’Humanité, an annual French Communism celebration, misstated its inaugural year. As the article correctly stated, it was 1930, not 1945. In addition, because of an editing error, the approximate age of the event was misstated in the article. It is almost 100 years old, not almost 80 years old.

headline: France Prepares to Raise Taxes on Businesses and the Rich
abstract: France’s new prime minister, Michel Barnier, has opened the door to reversing some of President Emmanuel Macron’s tax cuts in an effort to fix the country’s widening budget deficit.
lead_paragraph: In the seven years that he has been France’s president, Emmanuel Macron has bet on tax cuts for the wealthy and for corporations as a recipe for stimulating the economy. His new government is about to tear up that playbook.

headline: A Litmus Test in Japan: Should Spouses Be Able to Have Different Surnames?
abstract: The nine candidates vying to become prime minister have been differentiated by their stances on a law requiring married couples to share a family name.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s leaders have plenty to think about. The country’s population is shrinking and rapidly aging. One neighbor, North Korea, is a nuclear menace, while another, China, is escalating territorial incursions and information warfare. On top of that: climate change, ballooning national debt, inflation and a slowing economy.

headline: Taiwan and U.S. Work to Counter China’s Drone Dominance
abstract: Officials hope that Taiwan can become a bigger player in the supply chain for drones, a move that would also help blunt any threats posed to the island by China.
lead_paragraph: Spurred by worries about China’s strength in mass-producing drones, American and Taiwanese companies and government officials are working to join forces in making the air and sea vehicles that could be crucial to defending Taiwan.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: The U.N. General Assembly Convenes
abstract: Plus, news outlets experiment with WhatsApp.
lead_paragraph: World leaders gathered in New York to hear President Biden and other speakers address the 79th meeting of the United Nations General Assembly. Calls to end the Middle East conflict and wars in Ukraine and Sudan were expected to dominate the weeklong conference, all goals that still look out of reach.

headline: The N.B.A. Is Partnering With a Repressive Regime
abstract: How can the N.B.A. square its profession of high ideals with doing business with a repressive government?
lead_paragraph: In a bygone era, N.B.A. teams enforced an unofficial quota on Black players, apparently fearing that a “too Black” team might alienate its white audience. Today, this same league is celebrated as one of the world’s most progressive sports organizations.

headline: Confronting Our New Reality
abstract: Solutions to the problem of climate change have never been more clear. But the scale of the problem keeps getting bigger.
lead_paragraph: For a hot minute, it looked like the Doomers might be proved wrong.

headline: What if Everyone Did Something to Slow Climate Change?
abstract: Researchers are looking at the impact that individuals’ actions can have on reducing carbon emissions — and the best ways to get people to adopt them.
lead_paragraph: Make more beef-free meals. Compost food scraps. Replace a natural gas stove with an electric one.

headline: A Next Generation Approach to Heating and Cooling Buildings
abstract: A fifth-generation network at the Bankside Yards project in London offers new possibilities for the pace of decarbonization in the United Kingdom and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Tourists strolling along the banks of the River Thames in the heart of London will soon have reason to be grateful for a busy construction site on their path.

headline: As Global Temperatures Rise, Nigeria Faces a Cooling Crisis
abstract: With electricity scarce, Africa’s most populated country struggles to provide lifesaving cooling without worsening the very crisis causing the heat.
lead_paragraph: In Lagos, Nigeria’s largest city, temperatures have exceeded 95 degrees Fahrenheit multiple times this year — a level that, combined with the region’s pervasive humidity, strains the human body’s ability to cope. Without relief, even healthy individuals face potentially dangerous consequences.

headline: When Electrification has Power Beyond Its Climate Benefits
abstract: Jamal Lewis and Aloja Airewele are part of a group focused on electrification. They are leading conversations at the Times’s Climate Forward Changemaker Lunch.
lead_paragraph: Jamal Lewis’s path to climate work started when he came close to losing his life.

headline: Pontevedra, a Spanish City That Picked Pedestrians Over Cars
abstract: For over two decades the city’s mayor has reclaimed public space for people and limited vehicles in the city center, which reduced traffic and improved air quality.
lead_paragraph: Pontevedra may be a smaller city in northwest Spain, but it has been a pioneer in favoring pedestrians over cars for more than 20 years. The city has played a large role in inspiring other municipalities and continues to be a model on how to successfully confront the challenges of climate change by reducing traffic and cutting emissions.

headline: Taking on Food Emissions at Their Origin and Consumption
abstract: Andy Jarvis, Bruce Friedrich, Will Harris and Katie Cantrell are part of a group focused on food who are leading conversations at the Times’s Climate Forward Changemaker Lunch.
lead_paragraph: You might think it strange that the food system, which is responsible for a third of global emissions, is not brought up more as a focus of climate action. You don’t see it in protest slogans, you don’t hear politicians railing about it, and it’s not often a leading subject at climate change gatherings.

headline: Train Car Spewing Chemical Triggers Evacuations in Ohio
abstract: A plume of highly flammable styrene shot out of the train car, filling the air in the area west of Cincinnati with an odor one resident described as burnt metal.
lead_paragraph: A plume of highly flammable styrene shot out of the train car, filling the air in the area west of Cincinnati with an odor one resident described as burnt metal.

headline: Desi Lydic: Donald Trump ‘Really Knows How to Flatter a Lady’
abstract: The “Daily Show” host said the former president had been so unpopular with women that he was now trying to turn on “the old Trump charm.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Israel Says It Shot Down Missile Over Tel Aviv
abstract: The missile fired from Lebanon was the first time Hezbollah had launched an attack aimed at Tel Aviv, the military said.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said it had intercepted a missile that Hezbollah fired at Tel Aviv from Lebanon on Wednesday, in one of the militant group’s most far-reaching attacks into Israeli territory in decades of conflict.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Republicans Pick Up Unlikely Allies in Key House Races: Unions
abstract: Democrats still dominate with organized labor. But in must-win swing races, Republicans are peeling off some union support, and feeling the benefits.
lead_paragraph: The president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters praised one Republican congressman on national television. A major transportation union rated another among its most loyal supporters in Congress. And an influential building trades group said a third would help begin “restoring the sense of unity” the country had lost.

headline: Favorite Restaurants
abstract: What is the best place to eat where you live?
lead_paragraph: The New York Times recently announced its list of the 50 best restaurants in America right now.

headline: N.Y.C. Plan That Could Add 109,000 New Homes Clears Key Vote
abstract: The City Planning Commission approved a major rezoning proposal that would ease restrictions on development. The plan faces headwinds in the City Council.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s plan to ease New York City’s housing shortage by making way for more than 100,000 new homes cleared the City Planning Commission on Wednesday, setting up a much tougher fight between the administration and the City Council.

headline: Is This What Female Strength Looks Like?
abstract: Saint Laurent and Dior struggle with the answer.
lead_paragraph: First the pussy bow, and now the tie?

headline: China Says It Launched a Rocket With a Dummy Warhead Into the Pacific
abstract: The ballistic missile launch is a sign of the commitment of Xi Jinping, China’s leader, to continue strengthening the country’s Rocket Force and to project power in Asia.
lead_paragraph: China launched an intercontinental ballistic missile carrying a dummy warhead that landed in the Pacific Ocean on Wednesday, the country’s defense ministry announced, in a sign of President Xi Jinping’s commitment to keep strengthening China’s missile force after a period of corruption scandals and command turbulence.

headline: Can You Get Rid of Your Front Lawn Without Offending the Neighbors?
abstract: It isn’t easy or fast, but it can be done. Here’s what worked for one couple.
lead_paragraph: What will the neighbors think?
