As the story goes, when Mount Etna erupted a year later, the citizens of Catania retrieved that veil — which had somehow evaded the flames — to use in a procession during which it miraculously stopped the molten flow and saved the city.

headline: Side Tables With Style and Storage
abstract: Small but impactful pieces that hold more than just a lamp.

headline: Lhasa’s Music Captivated Audiences Everywhere but Here
abstract: At Pop Montreal, tribute concerts on Sept. 29 and 30 will honor the memory of Lhasa de Sela, the American-born multilingual singer-songwriter.
lead_paragraph: Montreal’s wide-ranging music scene has been one of its calling cards for decades, with border-crossing success stories like the ambitious rock band Arcade Fire, the arty electro-pop artist Grimes and the renowned post-rock modernists Godspeed You! Black Emperor. Yet one of the musicians most beloved there is the spellbinding Lhasa de Sela, who wrote and sang in English, French and Spanish, but remains largely unknown in the United States.

headline: Loved ‘Nobody Wants This’? You’ll Want These Romance Books
abstract: These novels feature cross-cultural connections, charming banter and plenty of heart.
lead_paragraph: There’s a long history in Hollywood of cross-cultural rom-coms — films and TV shows such as “Keeping the Faith,” “Bend It Like Beckham” and “The Nanny” that mine clashing traditions to find hilarity and heart. Colliding heritages naturally lend themselves to moments of comedic gold: Just think of a nonplused Andrea Martin in “My Big Fat Greek Wedding” reassuring John Corbett’s vegetarian leading man, “That’s OK: I make lamb.”

headline: 36 Hours in Stowe, Vermont
abstract: Spend a weekend sampling I.P.A.s and cider doughnuts, touring an enchanted sugar forest and relaxing in an Adirondack chair in this quaint city at the foot of Mount Mansfield.
lead_paragraph: Spend a weekend sampling I.P.A.s and cider doughnuts, touring an enchanted sugar forest and relaxing in an Adirondack chair in this quaint city at the foot of Mount Mansfield.

headline: Malcolm Gladwell Holds His Ideas Loosely. He Thinks You Should, Too.
abstract: As he releases “Revenge of The Tipping Point,” the best-selling journalist talks about broken windows theory, Joe Rogan and changing his mind.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Gladwell, the best-selling author, has an office on a quiet street in Hudson, N.Y., where he sits at a desk under a poster of Mao Zedong, the former communist leader of China. Why? Maybe to signal how ideas can be dangerous? Nope, no particular reason. There are two other Chinese communist posters on the wall, too. “I found them online for like $10,” said Mr. Gladwell, 61. “I just think it’s funny.”

headline: ‘Apartment 7A’ Review: All Devil, Few Details
abstract: A lackluster prequel to the 1968 horror classic “Rosemary’s Baby” doesn’t have much to add.
lead_paragraph: “Apartment 7A” is a prequel, of sorts, to “Rosemary’s Baby,” still one of the most chilling films ever made about losing agency over your own body. The 1968 horror classic takes place in the fictional Bramford, a rambling apartment building on Manhattan’s Upper West Side that seems to have been colonized by a coven of devil worshipers. Early in that film, Guy and Rosemary Woodhouse (John Cassavetes and Mia Farrow), a young couple new to the building, meet a troubled woman in the laundry room. Her name is Terry Gionoffrio. “Apartment 7A” is her story.

headline: Kara Walker: A Fortuneteller in the Land of ChatGPT
abstract: The artist’s dystopian installation at SFMOMA shows her evolution as a public artist. In her carnival sideshow she casts a wary eye on tech’s future.
lead_paragraph: In artworks exploring unequal power dynamics across a wide swath of history, Kara Walker has long called attention to the most inhuman tendencies of people. Now, in a new installation in the country’s tech capital, she is highlighting the superhuman capabilities of A.I. as only she can.

headline: ‘Saturday Night’ Review: Live TV at Its Mildest
abstract: When it debuted 50 years ago, “S.N.L.” was chaotic, rangy, even offensive. But nothing’s wild or crazy in Jason Reitman’s fictional reimagining of its first episode.
lead_paragraph: Movies about tectonic cultural shifts tend to be too neat and tidy, too frictionless. “Saturday Night,” the director Jason Reitman’s fictional reimagining of the debut of “Saturday Night Live,” is a nice, safe movie about a revolution. Busily plotted and sporadically funny, it is a backstage look at the night a gang of comics whom most of the world had never heard of began taking over TVs across the country. It was a comedy home invasion on a national scale, and it was glorious (when it didn’t suck).

headline: ‘Sleep’ Review: Bumps in the Night
abstract: A taut and thrilling thriller about sleep issues is also a clever drama about early marriage.
lead_paragraph: Apnea, insomnia, sleep hygiene, sleep aids, sleep tricks: It’s all science but feels like sorcery. Even the most rational person can begin to suspect, three weeks into sleepwalking spells or 3 a.m. wakefulness, that some curse has been placed upon them, and the only cure is some mystical spell. It’s the stuff of horror, and the director Jason Yu harnesses it deftly for his debut feature, “Sleep,” a neatly constructed thriller about the sort of insanity that slumber issues can visit on even the most harmonious household.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: Gabriela Ortiz’s orchestral music, Jonas Kaufmann’s Puccini tribute and Nathalie Stutzmann’s first album from Atlanta are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: I know what I’ll be rooting for on Oct. 9, when Gustavo Dudamel and the Los Angeles Philharmonic begin Gabriela Ortiz’s season as the resident composer at Carnegie Hall: namely, something on the level of the spitfire violin concerto “Altar de Cuerda,” which opens this survey of her music, performed by the same orchestra and conductor. Just as the soloist, María Dueñas, ventures from tremulous, weeping articulations to slashing outbursts with impressive security, so too does the Philharmonic snap back and forth with alertness when approaching Ortiz’s contrasting, hurtling designs in the opening movement. In the slow middle movement, the mercurial, slowly morphing orchestral harmonies reach out to American Minimalism and Finnish spectralism alike. And the finale boasts hints of Romantic effusion.

headline: Vance’s Mother Deals With Her Past and His Future
abstract: In his 2016 memoir, Senator JD Vance of Ohio described a rough childhood owing to his mother’s devastating drug addiction. Today, he and his mother, Beverly Aikins, are a remarkable team.
lead_paragraph: Here is the way JD Vance introduced his mother to the world in his 2016 memoir, “Hillbilly Elegy”:

headline: Get Paid to Move
abstract: There’s financial help to relocate to West Virginia (and elsewhere).
lead_paragraph: Last year, Anne Berlin bought a home in Elkins, W.Va., paying $215,000 outright for a three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath house built in the 1960s. Ms. Berlin, 44, a technical S.E.O. specialist who works remotely, could have afforded a place where she was “mortgaged to the hilt,” she said. “That’s not my vibe. I don’t want to be in massive debt. I wanted a place that I could really afford.”

headline: ‘Freaks and Geeks’ at 25: ‘It Was Slipping Away the Entire Time’
abstract: The beloved high-school sitcom debuted in September 1999 and lasted one season. Paul Feig, Judd Apatow and others look back on the show’s birth, death and long afterlife.
lead_paragraph: To twist a famous line from Jean Renoir’s “The Rules of the Game,” the awful — and hilarious — thing about high school is this: Everyone has their reasons. All adolescents are worlds unto themselves, whether they’re jerks, jocks, stoners, smart kids or underachievers. Each is an entire cosmos of yearning and hurt trapped inside a juvenile body.

headline: At the Whitney, a Stirring Ailey Tribute Moves Dance to the Edge
abstract: Music’s in the air, and there’s painting and sculpture in imaginative variety as an art museum gives rare treatment to an ephemeral medium.
lead_paragraph: With the spirited, sense-surround show called “Edges of Ailey” at the Whitney Museum of American Art, the New York art season gets off to an exuberant, enveloping, though puzzling start.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Midtown, the West Village and Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, two-bath 1,288-square-foot apartment with an open living/dining area, marble bathrooms, floor-to-ceiling windows, ample closets, central air-conditioning and a washer/dryer, on the 34th floor of a 51-story cat-friendly doorman building with a super, concierge, porters, a gym and bike storage. Dustin Crouse and Erin Boisson Aries, Douglas Elliman, 570-337-5306; elliman.com

headline: From Damsel to Hero: How Princess Zelda Grew Up
abstract: It’s been a long road, but the princess in the Nintendo franchise named after her is no longer helpless or simply an assistant.
lead_paragraph: It’s finally The Legend of Zelda.

headline: The Dangers of Donald Trump, From Those Who Know Him
abstract: What 91 people who know the former president say about his character.
lead_paragraph: What 91 people who know the former president say about his character.

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Redding, Conn., and a three-bedroom in Point Lookout, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 4,146-square-foot home from 1954 with artistic accents by the owner, Jitka Exler, known for her work on the “Sesame Street” Muppets. There is abundant natural light throughout, a stone walkway, a foyer with curved windows, a living room with a brick fireplace and a vaulted ceiling, a sky-lit eat-in kitchen with granite countertops and custom cabinetry, a dining room with a coffered ceiling, an indoor Endless Pool, an in-law suite with a separate entrance, an en suite primary bedroom with a spa-style bath, a finished basement with a bar, a two-car garage, a patio, a vegetable garden and a greenhouse, on 3.8 acres. Jay Contessa, 203-461-3880, Laura Ancona, 203-733-7053, William Pitt Sotheby’s International; williampitt.com

headline: Mayor Eric Adams Is Indicted
abstract: The mayor, who ran for office on a promise to rein in crime, has been federally charged after a corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at what the indictment of Mayor Eric Adams will mean for an administration already shaken by corruption investigations. We’ll also meet someone who makes television commercials, but that’s not his real job.

headline: What Are You Looking Forward to This Fall?
abstract: New TV shows? Football? Pumpkin spice? Tell us what you’re excited about this season.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially fall. For many, that means changing leaves, new TV shows, football, Halloween and pumpkin spice everything. What do you look forward to most this time of year?

headline: ‘Freaks and Geeks,’ TV’s Least Likely to Succeed, Won by Losing
abstract: The high school cringe comedy was the undersung member of the Class of ’99. But its influence is everywhere.
lead_paragraph: By the 25th reunion, you get a good sense of how time has treated a graduating class. This is certainly true of TV’s Class of ’99.

headline: Why Oakland Is Saying Goodbye to Pro Baseball
abstract: The Major League Baseball team the Athletics played their final games this week in the Oakland Coliseum, which has been their home base in California for the past half-century. They’re expected to relocate to Las Vegas for 2028 at the whim of their billionaire owner, John Fisher, and in the meantime play in a minor-league ballpark in Sacramento. Jack Nicas of The New York Times explains how the plan to build a stadium in Las Vegas is driven by a single factor — money — and what it’s meant to Oakland.
lead_paragraph: The Major League Baseball team the Athletics played their final games this week in the Oakland Coliseum, which has been their home base in California for the past half-century. They’re expected to relocate to Las Vegas for 2028 at the whim of their billionaire owner, John Fisher, and in the meantime play in a minor-league ballpark in Sacramento. Jack Nicas of The New York Times explains how the plan to build a stadium in Las Vegas is driven by a single factor — money — and what it’s meant to Oakland.

headline: With Few Wins to Highlight, House Republicans Head Home to Chase Votes
abstract: The G.O.P. has plenty of dysfunction to point to after nearly two years of controlling the chamber, but not many successes to show voters ahead of the Nov. 5 election.
lead_paragraph: Representative Chip Roy, the far-right Texas Republican and reigning king of the fervid floor speech, stood before the House last November and tore into his party.

headline: Israel’s Displaced Want to Go Home. But Will Attacks on Hezbollah Offer That Path?
abstract: Israel said the goal of its strikes on Hezbollah was to allow residents of the north to go home. Some are hopeful that plan will work, but others worry that war may not bring safety.
lead_paragraph: When Orly Gavishi-Sotto saw images of Hamas-led forces attacking southern Israel on Oct. 7, she worried about her kibbutz, a mere 500 yards from Israel’s northern border with Lebanon.

headline: Why Does My iPhone Keep Asking Me to Check In With My Ex?
abstract: An iPhone feature has some users baffled as they are asked to share their location with work acquaintances, dead relatives and people on other continents.
lead_paragraph: Simon was waiting for a ride home one evening when he received a strange notification on his iPhone. It appeared with the iMessage logo, almost like a text message, but it was a suggestion from Siri, Apple’s virtual assistant. “Start a Check In with Daniel,” the phone prompted him. “Let them know when you arrive at your destination.”

headline: Everyone Looks Good in Black and White
abstract: A photo booth on Manhattan’s Lower East Side is drawing long lines of young people who yearn for physical media.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, a group of four giddy young women dressed in miniskirts and baggy pants took turns cramming behind a brown curtain and into an apparatus three decades older than they were.

headline: The Border Is a Top Campaign Issue. It’s Also Their Home.
abstract: What one of the biggest talking points of 2024 actually sounds like.
lead_paragraph: This year, Democrats and Republicans are fighting to convince voters that their party alone can fix what both parties say is a big problem: the Southern border.

headline: The Sun Will Destroy the Earth One Day, Right? Maybe Not.
abstract: Astronomers spotted a potential Earth-size rocky world orbiting a white dwarf, suggesting a future in which our planet outlives its star.
lead_paragraph: In six billion years the sun will expand into a red giant. That process should consume Mercury, and maybe Venus. For a long time we have thought it might incinerate Earth, too.

headline: It’s Easy to See What Drove Jonathan Holloway to Quit
abstract: Rutgers’s president was worn out by turmoil and animosity.
lead_paragraph: Last week Jonathan Holloway, the president of Rutgers University, announced he would be stepping down at the end of this academic year — the latest in a series of university president departures.

headline: Alabama Carries Out Second Execution Using Nitrogen Gas
abstract: Alan E. Miller, convicted in three 1999 murders, appeared to shake and gasp after the gas began flowing, media witnesses said. The only other prisoner to be executed by nitrogen had a similar response.
lead_paragraph: Alabama conducted the second execution in the United States using nitrogen gas on Thursday, with media witnesses describing the prisoner shaking and gasping for several minutes before dying on the gurney.

headline: ‘Nobody Wants This’ Review: Resuscitating the Rom-Com
abstract: Kristen Bell and Adam Brody star in a Netflix series whose familiar rhythms and punchlines are exactly the point.
lead_paragraph: Recent high-profile attempts by streamers to resuscitate the feature-length romantic comedy with brand-name performers like Anne Hathaway, Nicole Kidman and Brooke Shields have all had the same problem: They were awful. The dead touch of cringey mediocrity could be felt immediately. You could hear the flatline alarm in the background.

headline: A Fix for Trump’s Stop the Steal Strategy
abstract: The Electoral College is distorting our democracy.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Wegman, a member of the Times editorial board, has argued that to make the American election process more straightforward and just, the United States should elect its president based on the outcome of the popular vote rather than the Electoral College. But in this episode of “The Opinions” he goes a step further, arguing that the Electoral College renders elections more vulnerable to legal manipulation for political ends.

headline: A King of Cool Casual’s Next Act
abstract: With a new store, Steven Alan is trying to reconjure the magic of the boutique that put him on the fashion map.
lead_paragraph: Before Steven Alan became a designer known for his stylishly rumpled button-up shirts, he was a merchant known for his eye.

headline: What Does Baseball Lose When the A’s Leave Oakland?
abstract: A team’s plan to build a palace in Las Vegas highlights a cultural shift in the American sports experience, driven by a single factor: money.
lead_paragraph: The Athletics want their next home to be a $1.5 billion dome on the Las Vegas Strip built from five interlocking arches meant to evoke baseball pennants. One arch would carry a Jumbotron the size of four basketball courts. Another would be mostly glass, revealing the sparkle of the casinos beyond.

headline: Stanley McChrystal: Why Kamala Harris Has Won Me Over
abstract: Some deeply consequential decisions are starkly simple.
lead_paragraph: Some deeply consequential decisions are starkly simple. That is how I view our upcoming presidential election. And that is why I have already cast my ballot for character — and voted for Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Presidential Elections Aren’t Really That Close
abstract: The folly of the Electoral College creates too many points where history could turn on narrow outcomes.
lead_paragraph: For all the debates over our intractable political divisions and razor-thin vote margins, American presidential elections of late have not been particularly close. Since 2000, the average popular-vote margin is more than 4.6 million. That’s a lot of votes. The appearance that the outcomes are closer is an artifact of the Electoral College, specifically the winner-take-all method of awarding electors, which significantly magnifies the influence of a few arbitrary states.

headline: A Hudson Valley Spot That Channels Japanese Listening Bars
abstract: Plus: floral glassware, a bed-and-breakfast in Crete and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: As a fashion industry veteran, the men’s wear designer Jesse Rowe has been to countless stores. The one he can’t stop thinking about is Marcello, a hidden shop in Fukuoka, Japan. “You walk into a nondescript building, go up a couple of flights of stairs to the rooftop, walk along a stone path, then go down a fire escape to this completely transporting clothing shop,” says Rowe. The designer has brought that spirit of discovery to Zebra Room, a boutique in Germantown, N.Y., that’s equal parts coffee shop, cabinet of curiosities and listening lounge. Housed in a converted barn, Zebra Room devotes most of its square footage to a collection of midcentury Scandinavian furniture that Rowe’s brother imports from Copenhagen (highlights include an Inca chair by Arne Norell). There are also secondhand clothes and goods, from vintage marinière shirts to handmade leather dog collars. A coffee bar (which serves everything from Mexican café de olla to cold brew tonics topped with yuzu) is set up in a cube leftover from an exhibition held by the shop’s next-door neighbors Alexander Gray Associates. Rowe and his wife, the interior designer Loren Daye, clad the plaster installation with hemlock wood to keep with the natural feel of the space, which also has a 1970s cast-iron stove and retains the barn’s bluestone dirt floors. The cube houses Rowe’s record collection and sound system, which the designer has modeled after those in Japan’s kissa cafes. He alternates between vinyl and streaming, but the shop’s soundtrack is always played through a restored vintage SunValley/Dynaco tube amplifier and Klipsch LaScala speakers; similar tube amps, turntables and speakers are also for sale. “I want it to feel like someone’s living room — you might have to yell over the music,” says Rowe. instagram.com/_zebra_room.

headline: Starting a New Chapter in the Twin Cities for Less Than $180,000
abstract: A recent retiree toured condos of all stripes in Minneapolis and St. Paul, looking for something he could get excited about. Here’s what he found.
lead_paragraph: A recent retiree toured condos of all stripes in Minneapolis and St. Paul, looking for something he could get excited about. Here’s what he found.

headline: A’s Fans Cheered. Then They Protested. Now They Mourn.
abstract: Fan groups that once partnered with Oakland’s ownership turned into its most vocal critics. With nothing left to fight, they will stage a funeral of sorts.
lead_paragraph: At first, it was all love. They were some of the most visible and passionate fans in the Oakland Coliseum bleachers, and the Athletics wanted help keeping the energy up, as the team struggled through a down stretch.

headline: An ‘Utterly Bonkers’ Miscarriage of Justice in Texas
abstract: Are we ever going to take civil rights laws at face value?
lead_paragraph: There are individual court cases that are perfect symbols of larger injustices, and this month a Black woman named Erma Wilson lost a Court of Appeals decision that highlighted decades of judicial distortion of American civil rights law.

headline: Newsmax Defamation Case Over 2020 Election Begins
abstract: Smartmatic, an election technology company, has accused the right-wing cable news channel of knowingly spreading false vote-rigging claims.
lead_paragraph: The latest case tied to false claims made on cable news about the 2020 U.S. presidential election is headed to trial.

headline: Sick of the Electoral College? Stop Whining.
abstract: Blame the Committee of Unfinished Parts.
lead_paragraph: Dear Help Person,

headline: Republican Candidates Keep Straying Into Dangerous Territory: Abortion
abstract: In a campaign they would like to center on the economy and the border, Republican candidates keep drifting back to abortion rights, an issue that favors Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Republicans don’t want to touch abortion, their most troublesome issue since the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

headline: Let’s Discuss: ‘Love, Hate or Fear It, TikTok Has Changed America’
abstract: What role does TikTok play in your life? Read the article and post your comments and questions for our journalist Sapna Maheshwari by Oct. 3.
lead_paragraph: Have you been influenced to buy a Stanley tumbler because of TikTok? Been sucked into a Taylor Swift conspiracy theory? Found a new recipe or outfit idea? Taken part in ToiletTok? Or Barbiecore? Or smellmaxxing? Have you found out about a major news event on the app? Or been swayed to support a certain political candidate because of it?

headline: Hezbollah’s Relationship to Lebanon Mixes Military Might With Politics
abstract: The militant group is a dominant force in the country, and officials have struggled for decades to limit its power.
lead_paragraph: Israel launched more than 1,000 airstrikes against Lebanon this week in an attempt to weaken Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia that has been exchanging missile barrages with Israel for nearly a year.

headline: After 44 Years on Death Row, Japanese Man Is Exonerated at Age 88
abstract: Iwao Hakamada is believed to be the world’s longest-serving inmate given a death sentence.
lead_paragraph: An 88-year-old man believed to be the world’s longest-serving death row inmate was exonerated by a district court in Japan on Thursday, 44 years after he was first sentenced to death.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,196
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Watch: ‘High-Functioning Anxiety Isn’t a Medical Diagnosis. It’s a Hashtag.’
abstract: Is there a problem with how we talk about mental illness?
lead_paragraph: Amid an enormous societal push to destigmatize mental illness and encourage more conversation about emotions, young people have been flooded with mental health information on social media and elsewhere. But in the four-minute Opinion video “High-Functioning Anxiety Isn’t a Medical Diagnosis. It’s a Hashtag,” Lucy Foulkes, an academic psychologist at Oxford University, argues that much of this information is unreliable and even counterproductive. She makes the case that the problem may not be a lack of awareness but rather too much.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 474
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Sept. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Profitable Business of Holding Patients Against Their Will
abstract: Acadia Healthcare is holding people against their will to maximize insurance payouts, a Times investigation found.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains descriptions of captivity, mental-health trauma and suicidal thoughts.

headline: Eric Adams Is Indicted, and Florida Braces for Hurricane Helene
abstract: Plus, the “snackification” of the American diet.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Zelensky Pleads for More U.S. Weapons in Meetings With Biden and Harris
abstract: The stakes are high for the Ukrainian leader, who is trying to fend off Russia’s invasion while also navigating tricky U.S. politics that could determine future of American aid.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made an urgent appeal for more American aid and weapons on Thursday in what could be one of his final chances to persuade President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris to add firepower to his fight against Russia.

headline: Dozens, Mostly Children, Drown During a Hindu Festival
abstract: At least 46 died in a ceremony that involves bathing in local rivers and streams in Bihar State, where recent rains had raised water levels.
lead_paragraph: At least 46 people drowned in the eastern Indian state of Bihar as millions of Hindu devotees were celebrating a three-day festival for the well-being of children, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Inside the Minds of Swing Voters
abstract: We explain the results of a poll of undecided voters.
lead_paragraph: How will undecided Americans choose between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump — or decide to vote for neither — in the final six weeks of the campaign?

headline: ‘Lee’ Review: A Remarkable Life at War
abstract: Kate Winslet embodies the tenacity of the photographer Lee Miller, who documented World War II for British Vogue.
lead_paragraph: “Lee,” starring Kate Winslet as the photographer Lee Miller, is smartly trained on a span of 10 years: from 1938 until shortly after World War II.

headline: ‘Rez Ball’ Review: Warriors on the Court
abstract: This inspirational sports movie follows a high school basketball team in New Mexico with deep Native American heritage.
lead_paragraph: The sports drama “Rez Ball” rapidly shows the tough road ahead for the Chuska Warriors, a New Mexico high school basketball team. When Jimmy (Kauchani Bratt) and Nataanii (Kusem Goodwind) hang out, a bleak Nataanii is mourning the deaths of his mother and sister. When he doesn’t show up for a game, word comes of his death by suicide.

headline: ‘The Universal Theory’ Review: A Quantum Noir
abstract: A physicist becomes embroiled in a conspiracy throughout this German meta-thriller. Shot in black-and-white, the film pays homage to Hollywood classics.
lead_paragraph: A slippery meta-thriller from Germany, “The Universal Theory” has all of the elements of a classic film noir, but with an uncanny twist.

headline: Hong Kong Editors Sentenced in Landmark Case
abstract: The two journalists for Stand News were convicted in August of conspiracy to publish seditious articles, in a case signaling new limits on press freedom.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Hong Kong on Thursday handed down sentences to two editors in a landmark case that showed how a crackdown by China has curtailed press freedoms in the once-freewheeling city.

headline: Despite Foreign Pressure, Both Israel and Hezbollah Have Reasons to Reject a Truce
abstract: Hezbollah has repeatedly said it intends to continue fighting until there is a cease-fire in Gaza, while Israel wants the powerful Lebanese militia to pull back permanently from the border.
lead_paragraph: The proposal for a three-week cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah would be hard for either side to accept because it falls short of their respective conditions for a truce, according to analysts.

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Isaac
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Isaac.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Isaac.

headline: Helene’s Intensification Was ‘Aggressive.’ Here’s Why.
abstract: Very warm ocean temperatures in the Gulf of Mexico provide fuel for an “aggressive intensification,” a hurricane expert said.
lead_paragraph: What was once a broad cluster of storms in the Caribbean on Monday slowly coalesced into a hurricane on Wednesday. On Thursday, the intensity ramped up.

headline: ‘We Are Not a Normal Company’: OpenAI’s Latest Drama
abstract: More high-level departures caught some at the high-flying A.I. start-up off guard, as the company seeks to raise billions to fund its operations and ambitious goals.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI has had more than its share of drama over the past year, even as it extends its lead in artificial intelligence.

headline: Hoda Kotb, Cheerful Fixture of NBC’s ‘Today’ Show, Says She Will Depart
abstract: Her exit, planned for early next year, is a seismic shift for NBC and opens up a pair of morning TV’s most coveted anchor chairs.
lead_paragraph: Hoda Kotb, whose megawatt smile and convivial presence have greeted groggy-eyed viewers of NBC’s “Today” show for the past 17 years, said on Thursday that she would step down from her hosting duties early next year.

headline: New Data Finds Sharper Economic Rebound From Pandemic
abstract: Updated figures show that gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation, grew faster in 2021, 2022 and early 2023 than previously reported.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy emerged from the pandemic even more quickly than previously reported, revised data from the federal government shows.

headline: Tufts Lacrosse Players Recovering After Navy SEAL-Led Workout Draws Inquiry
abstract: Nine players were hospitalized with a serious muscle condition called rhabdomyolysis in the days after the 45-minute workout, according to the university.
lead_paragraph: In the days after a 45-minute workout led by a Tufts graduate turned Navy SEAL, members of the men’s lacrosse team became ill and nine were hospitalized with a serious muscle condition. On Wednesday, nine days after the voluntary workout, the last three players were released, and the university’s independent investigation began in earnest.

headline: These Are the N.Y.C. Officials Who Resigned Ahead of the Adams Indictment
abstract: The police commissioner and the schools chancellor were among those who said they would leave the administration.
lead_paragraph: A number of top officials in Mayor Eric Adams’s administration resigned in September before news of Mr. Adams’s indictment broke. They include:

headline: Southwest Airlines Lays Out Overhaul, and Stock Gains
abstract: The carrier’s move, including service enhancements and share buybacks, came after a hedge fund called for cost savings and better profits.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines announced a three-year plan on Thursday to revitalize its operation and customer offerings as it defends against an activist investor calling for new leadership and a strategy overhaul.

headline: Coming Up Next on CNN: A Paywall
abstract: CNN will begin experimenting in October with a subscription model, in a major initiative from its chief executive, Mark Thompson.
lead_paragraph: The most-visited news website in the United States is trying out a paywall.

headline: Hurricane Idalia Destroyed His Home. He’s Riding Out Helene Next Door.
abstract: In a St. Petersburg mobile home complex, many chose not to leave despite the warnings.
lead_paragraph: The pieces of paper taped to mailboxes and front doors on Wednesday carried a stark warning: “You must evacuate your mobile home by tomorrow morning due to Hurricane Helene.”

headline: These Are the Charges Against Eric Adams
abstract: A federal indictment accuses Mr. Adams of crimes dating back a decade, including bribery conspiracy, fraud and soliciting illegal foreign campaign donations.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has been indicted on federal charges of bribery conspiracy, fraud and soliciting illegal foreign campaign donations.

headline: ‘Killer Heat’ Review: Mediterranean Mischief
abstract: Joseph Gordon-Levitt plays a detective running from his past in a murder mystery that is mostly a stiff slog to get through.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the modern murder mysteries that truly love the genre — the ones that don’t so much subvert but wholeheartedly lean into the familiar tropes of your favorite cheap detective novel — there’s a fine line separating the good and the not-so-good. Not only a properly calibrated twist, but a sense of wit and a legible directorial imagination is what distinguishes, say, your “Knives Out” and “A Haunting in Venice” from a film like “Killer Heat.”

headline: This Fish Evolved Legs That It Uses to Taste Stuff on the Seafloor
abstract: While the sea robin has legs, it still doesn’t need a bicycle.
lead_paragraph: The sea robin has fascinated scientists for decades. It has the body of a fish, the wings of a bird and the legs of a crab.

headline: A Patchwork of Cannabis Laws Creates Health Risks, Study Finds
abstract: A new report calls for public education and closing of legal loopholes to keep the public safe.
lead_paragraph: As more states have legalized the sale of cannabis, a fractured and inconsistent legal framework has emerged across the country that has prioritized sales income and tax revenue over public health, a new report finds.

headline: A Weeknight Winner: Skillet Chicken Dinner
abstract: Melissa Clark’s skillet-braised chicken with greens is exactly the sort of easy, hearty dinner I want to cook right now.
lead_paragraph: My cast-iron skillet is nothing fancy: 12 inches, with handles on both sides to make hoisting it in and out of the oven a bit easier. It was maybe about $20 ($10 after the Macy’s mail-in rebate). But it’s taken on an incredible sheen from years of use, and it’s my favorite tool in the kitchen, my go-to pan for beautiful chicken dinners.

headline: Cyber Attack Displays ‘Islamophobic’ Message on U.K. Trains, Officials Say
abstract: The British authorities are investigating after commuters at 19 train stations saw an Islamophobic message when they tried to log on to a public Wi-Fi system.
lead_paragraph: The British authorities are investigating a cyberattack on Wednesday that they said displayed an anti-Muslim message on a public Wi-Fi system serving more than a dozen train stations around the country.

headline: When the Devoted Wife Becomes a Winning Brand
abstract: In “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives,” conservative politics and some corners of social media, a woman’s relationship to the home defines her role in public life.
lead_paragraph: “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives,” the new Hulu reality show, centers on a clique of influencers in Provo, Utah. In their community, they are steered at young ages into marriages and pregnancies. But on TikTok, they converge into a #MomTok squad, executing coordinated dances in crop tops amid beige McMansions as they rack up followers and brand deals. Now they’ve been upgraded to reality television stars, a cast of frenemies who act out mean-girl scenes and hunt for loopholes in the strict codes of their church.

headline: Cruise Lines Change Their Itineraries to Avoid Helene’s Impact
abstract: Carnival and Royal Caribbean were among the companies altering plans for port stops in Florida and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Several cruise lines operating out of Florida’s west coast and the Gulf of Mexico altered their itineraries on Wednesday to avoid Hurricane Helene’s path.

headline: Here Are the Charges Eric Adams Faces, Annotated
abstract: The Times annotated the indictment.
lead_paragraph: The Times annotated the indictment.

headline: ‘The Wild Robot’ Review: Wonder and Whimsy That Does Compute
abstract: Chris Sanders’s movie about a robotic assistant and the gosling she raises is defined by dazzling visuals and frank ideas about the circle of life.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever thought about the many ways animals show emotion? Consider an inquisitive snout wriggling in the air, tails coiled protectively around cubs and ears perky or drooping depending on mood. For creatures who didn’t evolve to walk upright, wearing one’s heart on one’s sleeve is a considerably more anatomical business.

headline: Francis Ford Coppola Re-enters a Changed Hollywood. It Could Be Rough.
abstract: Mr. Coppola has spent $120 million on his new movie, “Megalopolis.” Most box office analysts predict that he’ll get far less in return.
lead_paragraph: Lionsgate executives say they have done all they can. They’ve booked 1,700 theaters, deployed guerrilla marketers to college campuses and pushed to flip negative reviews to their advantage. They have tied the film’s themes to the presidential race in TV ads.

headline: Israel Says It Killed Another Hezbollah Commander in Beirut
abstract: The Israeli military said the commander, Mohamed Hussein Sarour, was killed in a strike. There was no immediate confirmation from Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military carried out an airstrike in Beirut on Thursday that it said was intended to kill the commander of Hezbollah’s aerial unit, the latest in a string of attacks that appear to be aimed at eliminating the militia’s leadership.

headline: A Museum Director’s Heirs Lay Claim to His Rembrandts
abstract: He ran the Mauritshuis and bequeathed it 25 paintings, but said they must always be on display. Today, only five are on show — so the descendants of his close friend say the artworks should be theirs.
lead_paragraph: Rembrandt’s 1661 double portrait “Two African Men” is a rare depiction of free Black men in 17th-century Amsterdam and a particularly prized work in the collection of the Mauritshuis, a jewel-box museum of Golden Age masterpieces in The Hague.

headline: Major Decision for Judge in Trump’s Election Case: How Much Evidence to Reveal
abstract: Prosecutors filed a sealed brief showing what they learned in the investigation. The former president’s lawyers say it amounts to a premature special counsel report that could hurt him before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Special counsel investigations that culminate in lengthy factual reports have become common in American political life. Special counsel reports have provided public documentation about the 2016 Trump campaign’s ties to Russia, the F.B.I.’s bumbling in the early stages of that investigation and President Biden’s handling of classified documents.

headline: Inside a Pro-Harris Ad Portraying Trump as Fighting for Billionaires Like Him
abstract: A key super PAC backing Kamala Harris makes use of a teacher’s narration and of video of Donald Trump promising to cut the taxes of people he calls “rich as hell.”
lead_paragraph: Future Forward, the main super PAC backing Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign, is running this 30-second ad, “Fight for Us,” on television stations in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan and Pennsylvania this week at a cost of $3.5 million, according to AdImpact.

headline: Who Is Eric Adams: New York’s Baffling, Boundless Mayor
abstract: So much about the singular, ever-present figure leading the city for the last three years remains head-scratching.
lead_paragraph: He swept in as the mayor of “swagger.” He was an enthusiastic participant in New York’s nightlife, swanning around clubs into the wee hours, and then holding early-morning meetings in City Hall.

headline: Melania Trump Gives a Rare Interview: 3 Takeaways
abstract: While promoting a memoir, the former first lady told Fox News that she blamed Democrats and members of the news media for the assassination attempts against her husband.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump, the former first lady, said that she blamed “leaders from the opposition party and the mainstream media” for creating conditions that led to two assassination attempts against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Frank Coppa, Who Turned Against a Mobster Family, Dies at 82
abstract: His decision to describe murders to the F.B.I. led at least 10 other members of the Bonanno family to do the same and ultimately immobilized a mafia family.
lead_paragraph: The first domino to fall in the Bonanno crime family was Frank Coppa, a corpulent capo who once survived a car-bomb attack and procured fried chicken for hungry hit men before an execution.

headline: As a Finnish Zoo Returns Pandas to China, It Blames Costs, Not Geopolitics
abstract: Two pandas are heading back to China eight years early amid lower-than-hoped-for visitor numbers at a zoo in rural Finland, and after the pair didn’t produce a cub.
lead_paragraph: Lumi and Pyry, two pandas who have spent the past six years living in a zoo in central Finland, are heading back to China this year, more than eight years earlier than planned.

headline: What to Know About Damian Williams, the Man Prosecuting Eric Adams
abstract: Mr. Williams already had a compelling biography, but the first-ever indictment of a New York City mayor has added an astonishing new chapter to his life’s story.
lead_paragraph: In November 2021, shortly after President Biden appointed him to serve as the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, Damian Williams said one of his obligations in the new post was crystal clear: “To be fiercely independent of politics.”

headline: The Crucial Context for Kamala Harris’s ‘Context’
abstract: Her opponent’s malice and incoherence trump all else.
lead_paragraph: I can’t say what Vice President Kamala Harris’s favorite word is — the one time I met with her, I didn’t ask — but I’d put a big stack of chips on “context.” She said it not once, not twice, but three times in her signature May 2023 “coconut tree” riff, and I’ve heard it tumble from her lips on other occasions as well. It’s like some oratorical caftan, warming and comforting her.

headline: Review: Philadelphia’s BalletX Shows Variety but Little Depth
abstract: The company brought three New York premieres to the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: In many ways contemporary ballet is a wide-open frontier, brimming with possibilities. But with so many options, the work it generates can tend toward the generic — even when there is an obvious concept at play. On Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, that was the case with the program by BalletX, a Philadelphia company dedicated to presenting new work. Yes, there are premieres, but do they push the form? Are they built to last? No and no.

headline: Mayor Adams’s Indictment Leaves City Hall Leaderless
abstract: It is the low point of a failed mayoralty.
lead_paragraph: The indictment of New York City’s Mayor Eric Adams on Thursday for charges that include bribery and soliciting foreign donations represents the lowest point of a failed mayoralty that has delivered stunningly little to the city it was meant to serve.

headline: What to See on London Stages This Fall
abstract: Some recommendations for visitors and residents who want to get the most from the city’s varied theater scene.
lead_paragraph: This fall’s London theater season promises star vehicles aplenty alongside robust reimaginings of the classics and even a notable song or two. What follows is just a sampling of the city’s abundance of new openings, anticipated revivals and Off West End discoveries — something to keep everyone cozy as the nights draw in.

headline: Suicides Using Guns Have Grown More Common Among U.S. Women
abstract: New C.D.C. data show that firearms remain the leading means of suicide for both men and women.
lead_paragraph: Women are increasingly using guns to die by suicide in the United States, challenging long-held assumptions that they will usually resort to less lethal means, according to data released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Farmers Scramble to Save Pecan and Cotton Harvests Ahead of the Storm
abstract: The wind and rain expected along Hurricane Helene’s path could damage vulnerable crops while the region enters the height of the harvest season.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Helene is likely to damage tracts of farmland, just as the fall harvest is underway in Southern states like Georgia, sending farmers on a mission to salvage as much of their crops as possible before the storm lashes the region, they said.

headline: Harris Now Has an Economic Plan. Can It Best Trump’s Promises?
abstract: A central question in the final stretch of the election is if Vice President Kamala Harris’s proposals will cohere into an economic argument that can top former President Donald J. Trump’s.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has a plan for the economy: a glossy, 82-page booklet detailing proposals on housing, taxes and health care that her campaign handed out to supporters gathered at a campaign event in Pittsburgh this week.

headline: ‘Megalopolis’ Review: The Fever Dreams of Francis Ford Coppola
abstract: The director’s latest is a great-man story about an architect, played by Adam Driver, driven by ideals and big plans. It’s a personal statement on an epic scale.
lead_paragraph: Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis” is a bursting-at-the-seams hallucination of a movie — it’s wonderfully out-there. At once a melancholic lament and futuristic fantasy, it invokes different epochs and overflows with entrancing, at times confounding images and ideas that have been playing in my head since I first saw the movie in May at the Cannes Film Festival. There, it was both warmly received and glibly dismissed, a critical divide that’s nothing new for Coppola, a restlessly experimental filmmaker with a long habit of going off-Hollywood.

headline: In New Mexico, Sopapillas Do It All
abstract: In pockets of the Southwest, no meal is complete without these crisp pillows of fried dough.
lead_paragraph: At many restaurants throughout the United States, customers can count on a bread basket. But in New Mexico, those baskets often hold sopapillas, pillows of fried dough meant to be dipped into spicy dishes like green chile enchiladas or drizzled with honey and eaten as a dessert.

headline: Tiny Cedar Key Has Been Hit Before. Now, It Faces a Huge Storm.
abstract: Many residents have evacuated Cedar Key, a community on a string of islands jutting into the Gulf of Mexico. But about 50 people have remained to risk Hurricane Helene.
lead_paragraph: As the clock ticked closer to Helene’s landfall in Florida’s Big Bend, Michael Bobbitt made a pit stop at his white bungalow in the heart of Cedar Key, a small island community jutting perilously into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: What Happens When Artists Start Going to Therapy?
abstract: In a number of exhibitions on view this year, people are pushing back on the cliché of suffering being essential to art, embracing recovery and wellness instead.
lead_paragraph: A DECADE AGO, the artist Thomas Houseago never would have imagined himself painting flowers. The sculptor, 52, who grew up in Leeds, England, and has been based in Malibu, Calif., since 2003, became known for making hulking monsters and masks — their inner workings displayed like those of half-dissected cadavers. His textured figures were chalky white plaster on one side; on the other, the material appeared to have been stripped away to reveal iron rebar and hemp. Critics described the work as “vulnerable” for its willingness to lay bare the creative process. But Houseago now says he was using this art to avoid confronting his own pain, perpetuated by the sexual abuse that a group of men, including his father, had inflicted upon him in early childhood.

headline: Trump’s Plans Could Spur Inflation While Slowing Growth, Study Finds
abstract: A nonpartisan economic analysis warned that deporting migrants and increasing tariffs would damage the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s proposals to deport millions of migrants and impose new tariffs on imports from around the world would slash U.S. economic growth and employment and cause inflation to rebound sharply, according to a new analysis published on Thursday by the nonpartisan Peterson Institute for International Economics.

headline: The Two Ways Eric Adams Could Be Forced From Office
abstract: The New York City Charter includes provisions that could be used to remove the mayor against his will if he chooses not to step down.
lead_paragraph: If Mayor Eric Adams resigns before his term ends, the city’s public advocate, Jumaane Williams, would become acting mayor and a special election would be scheduled.

headline: Adams Denounces Charges, as Protesters Denounce Him
abstract: At a news conference outside Gracie Mansion, attempts by Mayor Eric Adams to defend himself against a federal indictment were interrupted by people shouting “disgrace.”
lead_paragraph: Minutes before federal prosecutors detailed an indictment Thursday against Mayor Eric Adams of New York City, the mayor convened his own news conference outside Gracie Mansion to denounce the charges and insist they would not distract him from managing the city.

headline: Pro-Trump Group Expands Ad Buy by $70 Million in the Race’s Final Weeks
abstract: The MAGA Inc. super PAC plans to run ads to make the case that Kamala Harris is soft on crime and to tie her to the Biden administration’s record.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest super PACs supporting former President Donald J. Trump is adding $70 million to its television and digital reservations in the final six weeks of the campaign, including the first significant Republican super PAC ad buy in North Carolina since Labor Day.

headline: A Rosh Hashana Dish Keeps the Memory of Home
abstract: Legumbres para rosana, a dish of Spanish Moroccan origin, is a delicious reminder of a family’s journey.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Marina Pinto Kaufman has become the keeper of Spanish Moroccan food traditions for her cousins, children and friends, inviting them to her home in New York City, and now, Martha’s Vineyard, for the Jewish holidays, especially Rosh Hashana and Passover. And her legumbres para rosana, a colorful mostly vegetable dish, is often on the table.

headline: 5 Moments of Joy From Hoda Kotb’s Run on ‘Today’
abstract: The morning show host announced that she’s stepping down after more than 25 years at NBC filled with laughter, tears and the occasional glass of wine.
lead_paragraph: Hoda Kotb is a woman who knows how to have fun. She laughs easily, often to the point of tears. But that playfulness is balanced by wisdom born of a decades-long career in broadcast journalism. It was with that thoughtfulness that she announced her upcoming departure from NBC’s signature morning show, “Today.”

headline: Is Underparenting Good or Bad for Kids?
abstract: Responses to a guest essay about less intensive parenting. Also: A nuclear threat; gear against school shootings; wills for singles; Trump vs. Obamacare.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Manhattan Building at the Center of the Charges Against Adams
abstract: The lavish Turkevi Center, built by the Turkish government, was opened despite defects in its fire safety system. Prosecutors say Eric Adams pressured fire department officials to look the other way.
lead_paragraph: At the center of the charges facing Mayor Eric Adams of New York is an ornate, 35-story building across the street from the United Nations headquarters that Turkey opened to great fanfare in 2021 to showcase its international ambitions.

headline: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: ‘Light Endures’
abstract: Something is wrong with the candles in Celebrimbor’s workshop. Things are even worse outside.
lead_paragraph: At the start of this “Rings of Power” season, Sauron — still in his Halbrand form — allowed himself to be captured in Mordor so that he could manipulate Adar into marching his orc armies toward Eregion. Sauron then arrived in Eregion well ahead of the orcs, transformed into Annatar and began manipulating Celebrimbor into forging rings for dwarfs and men, tainted with Sauron’s corrupting influence.

headline: Put ‘Eat Dinner’ on Your Calendar
abstract: Ten-minute tofu, 15-minute fried rice and more recipes for when life overwhelms.
lead_paragraph: Has September taken it all out of you, too? After a relatively quiet summer, everything is happening all at once, all of the time. My color-coded Google Calendar looks like a Monet, with strokes of yellow birthday parties, dates and shows overlapping blue work deadlines overlapping purple exercise classes.

headline: Helene’s Storm Surge Could Break Records in Florida’s Big Bend Region
abstract: The surge could be 15 to 20 feet higher than normal tide levels, flooding dozens of communities along the Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: When a major hurricane hits, it is often the storm surge — the sea or gulf water driven ashore by winds — that poses the greatest threat to people’s lives and livelihoods.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 30, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: A Brief History of Ethical Concerns Involving Eric Adams
abstract: The mayor has been investigated repeatedly during his two decades in politics.
lead_paragraph: The federal criminal charges against Mayor Eric Adams are a first for an occupant of City Hall and for Mr. Adams himself over his four-decade career in law enforcement and politics. But they are not the first time he has been investigated.

headline: Many Who Used to Stay Put in Florida’s Coastal Areas Are Leaving for Helene
abstract: More residents who live in the Big Bend region near the coast are taking the warnings of storm surge seriously and evacuating to places inland.
lead_paragraph: In his 58 years, John Posey, a lifelong resident of the Forgotten Coast of Florida on the remote eastern edge of the Panhandle, had never evacuated for a hurricane — not for Dennis in 2005, nor for Michael in 2018.

headline: Lloyd Macklowe, Leading Purveyor of Art Nouveau, Is Dead at 90
abstract: He and his wife began buying pieces to furnish their apartment. They wound up with a museum-quality collection and a pre-eminent retail business.
lead_paragraph: Lloyd Macklowe and his wife, Barbara, had so little cash when they began furnishing their Manhattan apartment in 1965 that they paid for a $55 ceramic Tiffany vase in $5 weekly installments. But that modest purchase was just the beginning: It inspired a collecting frenzy that transformed the couple into dominant dealers in Art Nouveau decorative arts and antique jewelry through their Macklowe Gallery, which became an East Side mecca for deep-pocketed buyers.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 9, 2024
abstract: How are the candidates’ career timelines similar? How are they different?
lead_paragraph: Note: Our moderated discussion of this graph will take place on Oct. 9.

headline: Task Force on Trump Assassination Attempts Sinks Into Partisanship
abstract: Democrats walked out on a committee hearing after Republicans called two of their own members who have nudged conspiracy theories as witnesses.
lead_paragraph: The House task force on the attempted assassinations of former President Donald J. Trump devolved into division on Thursday, after Republicans invited two members of Congress who have promoted conspiracy theories about the shooting to testify as witnesses during a hearing.

headline: ‘The Queen of the Villains’ Is a Complex Japanese Wrestling Drama
abstract: The five-part Netflix series tells the story of a female wrestler in the 1980s who might have gone a little too deep into character.
lead_paragraph: Dump Matsumoto was a reviled — and thus beloved — heel in the All Japan Women’s Pro-Wrestling league in the 1980s. “The Queen of the Villains” (on Netflix, in Japanese with subtitles, or dubbed) is a colorful five-part scripted drama based loosely on her young life and early career, and it traces both her rise and the increasing popularity of women’s pro wrestling in Japan at the time.

headline: The R.N.C. Asked a Conspiracy Theorist to Train Poll Watchers. Here’s What He Told Them.
abstract: Jack Posobiec of “Pizzagate” notoriety recently spoke to a group of G.O.P. volunteers. “It doesn’t matter who votes,” he told them. “It matters who counts the votes.”
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Jack Posobiec was a fringe figure and a right-wing agitator best known for helping spread “Pizzagate,” a conspiracy theory about Democrats running a satanic child abuse ring underneath a Washington pizza parlor.

headline: Crunchtime for Election Interference: October Is the Month of Mischief
abstract: U.S. officials are stepping up their warnings about foreign interference in the election, focused on three main adversaries: Russia, China and Iran.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials battling foreign interference in the coming election say they are entering what may be the most perilous period of the campaign: October, when the prospect for mischief runs high and the time to react runs short.

headline: Food Voyages
abstract: Six journeys in search of a single bite.
lead_paragraph: Six journeys in search of a single bite.

headline: Searching for a Family Feast in Senegal That Tastes Like Home
abstract: I crossed the ocean to savor a new twist on a childhood favorite.
lead_paragraph: I crossed the ocean to savor a new twist on a childhood favorite.

headline: Wok Hei Is Vanishing From Hong Kong. My Mom Wanted to Taste It Again.
abstract: My mom grew up with the signature flavor of the city’s outdoor food stalls. It won’t be around much longer.
lead_paragraph: My mom grew up with the signature flavor of the city’s outdoor food stalls. It won’t be around much longer.

headline: Hunting for One of the World’s Most Exquisite Peppers
abstract: A trip to Peru in search of the essence of ají amarillo.
lead_paragraph: A trip to Peru in search of the essence of ají amarillo.

headline: Our Son Hates Eggs. Could a Dozen French Chefs Change That?
abstract: A trip to Paris in search of one magical bite that would cure a picky eater.
lead_paragraph: A trip to Paris in search of one magical bite that would cure a picky eater.

headline: How to Cure My Sex Drive? Dive for Sea Urchins.
abstract: It’s reputed to be an aphrodisiac. To get a potent bite, I learned how to pry them fresh from the ocean.
lead_paragraph: It’s reputed to be an aphrodisiac. To get a potent bite, I learned how to pry them fresh from the ocean.

headline: Was It the Best Gelato I’d Ever Had Because I’d Just Survived a Brain Tumor?
abstract: A trip to the Amalfi Coast (and down memory lane) in search of the truth about a dessert I’ve never forgotten.
lead_paragraph: A trip to the Amalfi Coast (and down memory lane) in search of the truth about a dessert I’ve never forgotten.

headline: Poor Health Care Underlines Array of Problems at Major Transit Point for Prisoners
abstract: Among the most alarming findings by the Justice Department’s watchdog: the decision to discontinue antidepressant medication for 15 inmates, without consulting or examining the patients.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s busiest federal prisons, a transit point for 27,000 inmates a year, is buckling under a staggering array of problems, including substandard health care, crumbling facilities and harassment of employees by other staff, a Justice Department watchdog announced on Thursday.

headline: Holy Hollywood! Batman Is the First Superhero With a Walk of Fame Star.
abstract: The caped crusader, who debuted in 1939, joins other illustrious figures — including Adam West, the actor who played him on TV.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine something new happening to Batman after 85 years of adventures in comic books, television and film. But he has a new notch on his utility belt: He has received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

headline: The Best Sheets for Your Bed
abstract: We found linen, percale, sateen and flannel options.
lead_paragraph: We found linen, percale, sateen and flannel options.

headline: Our Kids Are Being Deprived of One of Life’s Coolest Lessons
abstract: A modest plea for the return of language arts.
lead_paragraph: When I was in seventh grade, I had a language arts workbook that asked us to fill in the blanks with one of four words. Approaches varied, but the idea was to give students a sense of the range of our language’s vocabulary and how to use it. OK, it could get a little twee: I remember a sentence instructing us in the meaning of “expatiate.” Not expiate or expatriate but expatiate. I’m not sure that lesson was necessary. But those exercises did leave me with a sense of our language as a great buzzing menagerie of words, many of which I didn’t yet know. I was excited about learning them.

headline: Parts of Appalachia are under landslide warnings as Helene brings flooding.
abstract: Catastrophic flooding is forecast in mountain areas and significant landslides are possible through Friday in parts of the Carolinas, Tennessee and Georgia.
lead_paragraph: In the mountains of western North Carolina, which are already soaked from heavy rains Wednesday night and Thursday, people are watching predictions of a foot or more of additional rain from Helene with increasing dread.

headline: Before Helene’s Landfall, Bicycles Ruled the Road on Florida’s Gulf Coast
abstract: Several residents in the region have relied on pedal power to get around as the storm approached on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: As Tony Powell, 61, got ready to survey his neighborhood in Crystal River, Fla., about 80 miles north of Tampa, on Thursday morning, he opted to make his rounds on two wheels.

headline: The Global Threat of Antibiotic Resistance
abstract: Health experts, gathering at the U.N., have begun to shift their focus to try to provide access to basic drugs in countries where preventable deaths from infections occur too frequently.
lead_paragraph: An impoverished family in Africa is unable to afford a 50-cent course of antibiotics to save the life of a child with a simple bacterial infection. Is such a tragedy best described as a case of antimicrobial resistance, the slow-motion health emergency caused by the misuse of lifesaving antibiotics?

headline: Sudan’s Army Launches Operation to Retake Capital
abstract: The latest outbreak of fighting comes as nations gathered at the U.N. General Assembly called for an end to the war and for aid to be fast-tracked to millions in need.
lead_paragraph: Sudan’s military launched a major operation in the capital, Khartoum, on Thursday, a senior Sudanese military official said, in an effort to regain territory it lost during the early months of a civil war that has torn apart one of Africa’s largest countries.

headline: What Eric Adams and Donald Trump Have in Common
abstract: The mayor and the former president may have some different political beliefs, but their personality and style — and now perhaps their legal paths — are aligned.
lead_paragraph: As he headed by motorcade to Lower Manhattan in the spring of 2023 for a seven-hour deposition in a fraud trial, former President Donald J. Trump was greeted by crowds who chanted: “New York hates you.” That had been more or less established during his 2016 presidential run, when about 79 percent of New York City voters chose Hillary Clinton. Still, despite the pride the city seems to take in its status as the epicenter of Trump antagonism, it elected Eric Adams — a mayor with a certain affection for the former president’s playbook.

headline: An Oil C.E.O. Answers Our Questions
abstract: The Times hosted leaders and policymakers to talk about growing threats of climate change, and spoke with the C.E.O. of Occidental Petroleum.
lead_paragraph: For seven hours on Wednesday, my colleagues and I interviewed world leaders, chief executives, scientists and activists in front of a live audience at our annual Climate Forward event in New York City.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Celebrity Endorsements, Trendy Water Bottles and Their Sleep Routines
abstract: This week, teenage responses to three recent Picture Prompts.
lead_paragraph: Should celebrities speak out about politics? What is with the teenage fascination with trendy water bottles? How do you get a good night’s rest?

headline: An Exclusive Peek at the Met’s Reimagined Rockefeller Wing
abstract: With more than 1,800 works from five continents, and new scholarship, refreshed galleries present the arts of Africa, the Ancient Americas and Oceania as three distinct areas.
lead_paragraph: The Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has been closed and under renovation since 2021, is not scheduled to open until May 2025. But a recent early peek at the wing’s refurbished galleries already reveals brighter, more open exhibition spaces for the museum’s storied collection of objects from Africa, the Ancient Americas and Oceania — including stone sculptures, detailed metalwork and colorful ceramic vessels.

headline: Can Eric Adams Survive a Foreign Bribery Scandal?
abstract: Mr. Adams is the first sitting mayor in modern New York City history to be charged with a crime.
lead_paragraph: As the first sitting mayor in New York City history to be charged with a crime, Mayor Eric Adams found himself stranded in a bit of uncharted territory.

headline: Newsmax and Smartmatic Settle Defamation Case Over 2020 Election
abstract: Jury selection in the case began on Thursday morning, and the trial had been expected to take up to four weeks.
lead_paragraph: Smartmatic on Thursday settled its defamation lawsuit against Newsmax, the right-wing cable news channel that had spread false claims of election fraud, the companies said.

headline: Have We Hit Peak Hand Roll Yet?
abstract: There are at least a dozen spots in New York City, but some sushi hand rolls are better than others.
lead_paragraph: As someone who eats a lot of food professionally, every once in a while you need a reset. And for me, that means either ordering from Dig or opting for a restaurant meal that I know isn’t going to send me into a food coma: sushi, and, more specifically, hand rolls. They come in a bunch of styles, funnel-shaped and cigar-shaped and taco-shaped, containing some combination of protein (usually crab, salmon, tuna or yellowtail), rice and accouterment like fried shallots or miso butter, though there are plenty of vegan and vegetarian versions. Even the most hedonistic meal at a hand roll restaurant is tame by most standards.

headline: Democrats Seek Another Opening in a Challenging Senate Map
abstract: New investments in Texas and Florida show how the party is reaching to keep its majority alive.
lead_paragraph: Facing an uphill battle to maintain control of the Senate, Democrats are turning to two states that perennially break their hearts: Texas and Florida.

headline: Port Operators Ask Regulator to Force Dockworkers to Negotiate
abstract: The group that represents port terminal operators said the International Longshoremen’s Association was refusing to negotiate a new contract before a Monday deadline.
lead_paragraph: Days ahead of a possible strike by longshoremen on the East and Gulf Coasts, port employers said on Thursday that they were asking a federal labor regulator to force the dockworkers’ union to resume negotiating a new contract.

headline: Harris Meets With Zelensky, Anticipating a Handover of Global Crises
abstract: The meeting signaled that the White House was preparing her to take over a thorny diplomatic relationship should she win the election in November.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday at the White House, a sign that President Biden’s administration is positioning her to take over a politically fraught diplomatic relationship if she wins the election in November.

headline: Giuliani Disbarred in D.C. Over Efforts to Overturn 2020 Election
abstract: Appellate judges based their decision on New York’s ruling earlier this year to bar him from practicing law in the state.
lead_paragraph: A panel of judges on the District of Columbia Court of Appeals on Thursday barred Rudolph W. Giuliani from practicing law in Washington because of false statements he made about the 2020 election results while he was former President Donald J. Trump’s personal lawyer.

headline: The Stage Combat Is Verbal in These Off Broadway Plays
abstract: Belarus Free Theater’s “KS6: Small Forward” and three other shows are reminders that there are many ways to portray conflicts and confrontations onstage.
lead_paragraph: When feeling cornered by real-world drama, I catch myself thinking that theater should stand aside from time and space, like a self-contained capsule of pure art. But a recent tour of Off and Off Off Broadway offerings is a bracing reminder of how exhilarating a show can be when it connects one person — onstage, in the audience — with the world.

headline: Justice Department Details Wide Pattern of Abuses by Mississippi Police Force
abstract: The police in the small city of Lexington, Miss., routinely made unjustified arrests, used excessive force and trampled on civil rights, investigators said.
lead_paragraph: The city of Lexington, Miss., has fewer than 1,500 residents and only 10 police officers. But it prompted a 47-page report by the Justice Department’s civil rights division, which found that residents were routinely jailed on illegal “investigative holds” or for unpaid fines, and that they faced excessive force, sexual harassment, retaliation when they criticized the police and racial discrimination.

headline: New York City Mayor Charged in Bribery and Fraud Scheme
abstract: Federal prosecutors say Mayor Eric Adams of New York took illegal campaign contributions and luxury travel benefits from foreign actors and used his power to help Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors say Mayor Eric Adams of New York took illegal campaign contributions and luxury travel benefits from foreign actors and used his power to help Turkey.

headline: Zelensky’s Star Power Fades on Capitol Hill
abstract: As the war drags on, Ukraine’s president receives a quieter welcome in Washington and faces angry questions from some Republicans.
lead_paragraph: When President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine visited Capitol Hill less than two years ago, he was feted with standing-room-only crowds, rollicking ovations and an aid package worth nearly $50 billion to help his country fight off a Russian invasion.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Campaign Thinks She Can Win on the Economy. Here’s How.
abstract: Harris advisers point to a number of brightening public polls showing that Donald Trump’s lead is eroding on the critical question of whom voters trust most on the economy.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with the latest updates on Trump, Harris and the 2024 election.

headline: Eric Adams Should Resign
abstract: The federal indictment reveals how the city’s leader repeatedly failed in his duty to uphold the public trust.
lead_paragraph: The indictment of Eric Adams, unsealed Thursday by federal prosecutors, describes a dispiriting and profound violation of the trust New York voters once placed in the mayor to lead the nation’s largest city.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, when the debate about “likable characters” and their desirability (or not) in fiction was still lighting up the more literary corners of social media, I attended a panel discussion in which the novelist Ottessa Moshfegh put the whole issue convincingly to rest: “I don’t even like likable characters in real life,” she said, or words to that effect. “Why would I want to put them in my books?”

headline: Harris Has a Lot of Strengths. Giving Interviews Isn’t One of Them.
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris is a sharp debater and a tireless campaigner, but televised interviews are a weakness. Her professional experience may explain why.
lead_paragraph: The first question Vice President Kamala Harris faced on Wednesday night, in her first solo interview with a major cable network as the Democratic presidential nominee, was posed as a gentle hypothetical: What would she say to the many Americans who do not see how her economic policies would serve them?

headline: Netanyahu Defiant as World Leaders Press for Israeli-Hezbollah Truce
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed to keep striking the Lebanese militants, who began launching rockets across the border almost a year ago in support of their Hamas allies in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Thursday that the Israeli military would keep striking Hezbollah militants in Lebanon with “all our might,” even as the United States, its European allies and several Arab states worked furiously to negotiate a three-week cease-fire.

headline: Do Sassy, Jane and xoJane Mean Anything to You?
abstract: Jane Pratt, one of the most influential editors of the last few decades, returns to media with her aptly titled project Another Jane Pratt Thing.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, at 24 years old, Jane Pratt founded the cult teen magazine Sassy, one of the most influential publications of the Gen X era. Sassy’s tone, which was bright but sharp, was all hers.

headline: Biden Administration Set to Make Asylum Limits More Permanent
abstract: The change will make what had been a short-term fix, which appears to have led to a drop in border crossings, a central feature of the asylum system.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is expected to take action next week to make it harder to lift its policy banning asylum for migrants who cross the southern border illegally, three people with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Helene Could Expose Deeper Flaws in Florida’s Insurance Market
abstract: Catastrophic storms have crippled the state’s home insurance market in the past, and some researchers say it is dangerously vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Helene isn’t just a threat to the safety of the people in its path. Depending on how much damage the storm causes, it could also threaten Florida’s insurance market — and recent research suggests that market is dangerously vulnerable.

headline: The Greatest City in the World, Some Really Lousy Mayors
abstract: You have to go way back to the days of the secular saint Fiorello La Guardia to come up with a New York mayor unencumbered by significant baggage.
lead_paragraph: As shocking as it is for Mayor Eric Adams to have been indicted on federal bribery and fraud charges, it is not surprising. Ethical breaches and New York City Hall have gone hand in hand for so long that it’s almost as if you can’t have one without the other. What makes Mr. Adams unique, of course, is an actual indictment, a first for a New York mayor and one that takes the city and state into uncharted waters. The citizenry has to wrestle with a question of its own: Namely, why do so many mayors let us down, and do we vet them closely enough?

headline: Friday Briefing: New York City’s Mayor is Indicted
abstract: Plus, the control behind K-pop goes public.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of New York City, Eric Adams, was indicted on federal charges of bribery, fraud and soliciting illegal foreign campaign donations. He is the first sitting mayor of the city to be charged with a federal crime.

headline: Nick Gravenites, Mainstay of the San Francisco Rock Scene, Dies at 85
abstract: A blues devotee from Chicago, he tasted fame in the late 1960s with the Electric Flag, a band that made its debut at Monterey but proved short-lived.
lead_paragraph: Nick Gravenites, a Chicago-bred blues vocalist and guitarist who rose to prominence during the explosion of psychedelia in San Francisco in the 1960s as a founder of the hard-driving blues-rock band the Electric Flag and as a songwriter for Janis Joplin and others, died on Sept. 18 in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 85.

headline: What the Prosecution’s Case Has Revealed About Tyre Nichols’s Death
abstract: Prosecutors called nearly 20 witnesses to make their case against three former Memphis police officers charged in connection with the fatal beating of Mr. Nichols.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors rested their case on Thursday against three former Memphis police officers who face civil rights and obstruction charges in the beating and death of Tyre Nichols last year.

headline: Eric Adams Charged With Bribery and Fraud
abstract: Also, Hurricane Helene heads toward Florida. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of New York City, Eric Adams, was indicted on five federal charges of bribery, fraud and soliciting illegal foreign campaign donations that prosecutors said began at least a decade ago and continued after he became mayor. He’s the first sitting mayor in the city’s history to be criminally charged.

headline: Production Linked to Neil Gaiman Is Halted Amid Sexual Assault Claims
abstract: The British author of dozens of literary works has denied the allegations that five women made against him on a podcast series.
lead_paragraph: The production of a movie based on a book by the noted British author Neil Gaiman has been paused by Disney amid allegations that five women have made against him relating to conduct from 1986 to 2022, including one woman who said Mr. Gaiman groped her on a tour bus in 2013 and later paid her $60,000.

headline: Scenes From the Southeast as Hurricane Helene Roared Through
abstract: Helene made landfall on Florida’s Gulf Coast late Thursday, causing widespread destruction across several states.
