lead_paragraph: From Florida to North Carolina, Hurricane Helene caused widespread destruction this week, bringing deadly floods, mudslides and tornadoes as it tore across the Southeast and its remnants reached all the way to the mountain areas of Appalachia.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Stresses Risks in Allowing Long-Range Strikes by Ukraine
abstract: Intelligence agencies concluded that granting Ukraine’s request to use Western missiles against targets deep in Russia could prompt forceful retaliation while not fundamentally changing the course of the war.
lead_paragraph: U.S. intelligence agencies believe that Russia is likely to retaliate with greater force against the United States and its coalition partners, possibly with lethal attacks, if they agree to give the Ukrainians permission to employ U.S., British and French-supplied long-range missiles for strikes deep inside Russia, U.S. officials said.

headline: What Does a Hurricane’s Category Tell Us?
abstract: The hurricane scale classifies storms based on wind speeds and predicts potential impacts, which can help people prepare for the expected damage.
lead_paragraph: When a hurricane threatens land, one of the top questions on people’s minds is what category is it, and that’s for good reason. Hurricanes are categorized by their wind speeds on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, which provides useful information on the storm’s winds, their expected impact and potential damage.

headline: Even Many Hurricane Veterans Were Leaving Florida’s Big Bend Ahead of Helene
abstract: The region has endured two other hurricanes recently, but many more people appeared to be evacuating this time, leaving their small coastal towns eerily empty.
lead_paragraph: In his 58 years, John Posey, a lifelong resident of the Forgotten Coast of Florida on the remote eastern edge of the Panhandle, had never evacuated for a hurricane — neither for Dennis in 2005, nor for Michael in 2018.

headline: Just How Nice is Business Class on Turkish Airlines?
abstract: Turkish Airlines, the professed favorite of Mayor Eric Adams, features a business class that has plush, lie-flat seats and multiple course meals served on porcelain tableware.
lead_paragraph: “Turkish Airlines is my way of flying,” Mayor Eric Adams said in a 2017 interview with The Daily Sabah, a pro-government Turkish newspaper.

headline: Trump Campaign Is Said to Have Changed Rally After Secret Service Concerns
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump will hold an indoor rally in Wisconsin on Saturday. The Secret Service had raised concerns about securing the outdoor rally initially planned, according to a senior official with the agency.
lead_paragraph: The Trump campaign changed its plans for an outdoor rally in Wisconsin this weekend, according to a person familiar with the planning, and a senior official at the Secret Service said the agency had raised concerns about its ability to properly secure the initially planned outdoor venue.

headline: A Gotti Grandson Pleads Guilty to Covid Relief Fraud
abstract: A U.S. attorney said that Carmine G. Agnello had “shamefully” used the pandemic “as an opportunity to line his pockets.”
lead_paragraph: The grandson of John Gotti, the infamous former boss of the Gambino crime family, pleaded guilty on Thursday to fraudulently collecting more than $1 million in Covid disaster relief loans, much of which he invested in cryptocurrency.

headline: Years After Being ‘Fired,’ They’ve Unloaded Their Trump Media Stock
abstract: Two former “Apprentice” contestants who helped found Truth Social have sold their nearly 6 percent stake in Trump Media & Technology Group.
lead_paragraph: An investment company formed by two former contestants on “The Apprentice” TV show sold almost all of their 5.5 percent stake in former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

headline: Acadia Hospitals Reach $20 Million Settlement With Justice Dept.
abstract: The F.B.I. is also investigating the large chain of psychiatric hospitals for holding patients longer than what is medically necessary.
lead_paragraph: Acadia Healthcare, one of the country’s largest for-profit chains of psychiatric hospitals, has agreed to pay nearly $20 million to settle a federal investigation accusing the company of defrauding taxpayer-funded health insurance programs like Medicare and Medicaid, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

headline: Biden Signs Stopgap Spending Measure to Keep Government Open
abstract: The bill averts a campaign-season shutdown but ensures another spending fight in Congress during its lame-duck session in December.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed a short-term spending bill on Thursday that averts an immediate government shutdown but ensures another partisan fight in Congress during the lame-duck session in December.

headline: Mayor Adams, Confronted With Detailed Graft Charges, Says He Won’t Quit
abstract: Mr. Adams accepted free airline tickets, lavish overseas accommodations and illegal foreign campaign donations, prosecutors said. He denied the charges.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City, a former police captain who ran on a law-and-order platform but whose tenure has been consumed by accusations of corruption, spent years accepting free airline tickets, lavish overseas accommodations and illegal campaign donations from Turkey, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: JD Vance to Address Major Republican Donors Just Before Debate
abstract: As part of his trip to New York City for the vice-presidential debate next week, Mr. Vance will speak to the American Opportunity Alliance, a network of major G.O.P. contributors.
lead_paragraph: The Republican vice-presidential nominee, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, is scheduled to speak to a conference of major Republican donors in New York next week, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: 10-Minute Challenge: Hiroshige’s ‘Sudden Rain’
abstract: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.
lead_paragraph: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.

headline: Pope Punishes Members of Catholic Group in Peru After Vatican Investigation
abstract: The Vatican expelled 10 members from Sodalitium Christianae Vitae, a group founded in Peru, after investigators reported cases of physical abuse and cultlike control.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis this week expelled 10 members from a Catholic movement in Peru following a Vatican investigation that reported physical abuse, including “sadism and violence,” cultlike attempts to break the will of subordinates, mishandling of church property and covering-up crimes.

headline: The Story of the African Diaspora, Told Through Its Fashions
abstract: By examining the work of designers of African descent, a new exhibition in Manhattan finds common threads and, more interestingly, divergences.
lead_paragraph: In a darkened gallery, a dress designed by Madame Willi Posey bedecks a mannequin standing under a spotlight. Notably, Ms. Posey, who worked as a fashion designer in Harlem in the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s, is the person who taught Faith Ringgold, a venerated multimedia artist whose story quilts have hung in many of the great American museums, how to sew. She was her mother.

headline: Hurricane Helene Expected to Make Landfall Tonight
abstract: Helene is expected to bring record-breaking storm surges that will inundate communities along the Gulf Coast and bring rain and flooding to cities across the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Helene is expected to bring record-breaking storm surges that will inundate communities along the Gulf Coast and bring rain and flooding to cities across the Southeast.

headline: The Mayor Was Indicted. New Yorkers Had Jokes.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams’s indictment quickly became fodder for memes and quips on social media.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams has been uniquely unpopular, with some of the lowest polling numbers for a New York City mayor ever recorded.

headline: Cheap Flights and Deleted Texts: 10 Takeaways From the Adams Indictment
abstract: The indictment against Mayor Eric Adams includes revelations that range from the amusing to the horrifying.
lead_paragraph: The indictment of Mayor Eric Adams unsealed on Thursday provides a banquet of strange, amusing and troubling vignettes unearthed during the investigation by the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York and the F.B.I.

headline: F.D.A. Approves the First New Schizophrenia Drug in Decades
abstract: Available antipsychotic treatments work by blocking dopamine receptors. The new drug, Cobenfy, takes a different approach.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first novel antipsychotic treatment in decades, a drug developed to treat schizophrenia without disabling side effects like weight gain.

headline: Mayor’s Public Defense Leans on Conspiracy Theories and Race
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has said he is being targeted by the federal government for being critical of the Biden administration during the city’s migrant crisis, although he offers no evidence.
lead_paragraph: As Mayor Eric Adams has begun to mount a public defense against his federal indictment on bribery and fraud charges, his resistance has relied on messages both said and unsaid.

headline: The Tech Bro Style in American Politics
abstract: Why some billionaires are helping to promote political extremism.
lead_paragraph: It seems hard to believe now, but in 2021, Time named Elon Musk its Person of the Year. True, that designation doesn’t necessarily equate to a stamp of approval. But the magazine’s coverage of Musk at the time was very favorable, almost fawning, highlighting his assertion that “my career is Mars and cars.”

headline: Inside the Intimate U.N. Week Dinner Party at Eleven Madison Park
abstract: Celebrities including Pharrell Williams and Forest Whitaker ate plant-based dishes (and admired the kitchen) during an event to toast UNESCO, the U.N. cultural agency.
lead_paragraph: Pharrell Williams stood in the kitchen of Eleven Madison Park, the acclaimed Manhattan restaurant with three Michelin stars, and admired the setup as chefs in clean gray aprons and white chef coats silently prepared dinner.

headline: Democrats Need Jon Tester to Defy the Odds Again
abstract: Control of the Senate could turn on Montana.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Tonight, my colleague Mike Baker, who covers the West, has a dispatch from the state that might have the country’s most important Senate race: Montana. Then, I look at how Democrats are spending elsewhere on the map. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Gov. Hochul Can Remove Eric Adams From Office. Will She?
abstract: The governor indicated that she was examining her options, but removing a reliable ally could create political problems.
lead_paragraph: As federal prosecutors unveiled the corruption charges against the New York City mayor, Eric Adams, on Thursday, one potentially key figure was about as far removed from the action as she could be.

headline: Safety Board Warns of Rudder Control Defect in Some Boeing Planes
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board said it had found a defective part in the system that helps steer the aircraft after investigating an incident at Newark airport.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board on Thursday issued a safety alert and recommendations for some Boeing planes, warning that a defect could cause the rudder control system that helps steer the aircraft to jam.

headline: California Will Formally Apologize for Being Complicit in Slavery
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed several bills intended to atone for the state’s role in the oppression of Black Americans, but California legislators so far have sidelined proposals on cash reparations.
lead_paragraph: California will issue a formal apology for being complicit in slavery during the 19th century and for enforcing segregationist policies against Black residents as one of several new laws that Gov. Gavin Newsom signed on Thursday to atone for the state’s past discriminatory treatment of African Americans.

headline: In Tallahassee, Residents Worry About a Defining City Feature: Its Trees
abstract: The city’s canopy and shaded roads could become hazards as Helene brings the potential for hurricane-force winds.
lead_paragraph: Tallahassee, Fla., with its towering oaks, stately pines and shaded streets, faces a severe threat to its iconic canopy of trees as Helene approaches.

headline: McDonald’s, Pelosi, Debate Moderators: Trump Speech on Border Veers Off Course
abstract: After reading from prepared remarks on immigration for 10 minutes, Donald J. Trump used the rest of a news conference to talk about everything else on his mind.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump began his news conference on Thursday in the lobby of Trump Tower, standing in front of seven American flags. He laid a bound folder down on a lectern and declared that he was going to focus on the southern border, where his Democratic rival, Vice President Kamala Harris, is headed on Friday.

headline: Biden, Eyeing His Legacy, Signs Executive Orders on Gun Safety
abstract: The president used a poignant White House ceremony to pass the baton to Vice President Kamala Harris, who has made gun safety an issue in her campaign.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, frustrated with congressional inaction on gun violence and seeking to secure the issue as part of his legacy, said on Thursday that he was using his executive authority to improve school preparedness and to stem the tide of untraceable weapons and devices that make firearms more deadly.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 27, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about Dan Newlin, a personal injury attorney in Florida and a friend of Donald J. Trump who has spent millions on billboards and TV spots in support of Mr. Trump, misstated the county where Mark Lamb is the sheriff. It is Pinal County, Ariz., not Pima County.

headline: Trump’s Huge Civil Fraud Penalty Draws Skepticism From Appeals Court
abstract: A five-judge New York appellate panel questioned both the size and validity of a judgment of more than $450 million against Donald J. Trump at a hearing.
lead_paragraph: A New York appeals court expressed skepticism on Thursday about a civil judgment of more than $450 million that a trial judge had ordered former President Donald J. Trump to pay after finding that he had fraudulently inflated his wealth.

headline: Between Dusk and Dawn
abstract: Jake Bunch opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Man Sentenced to Life in Prison in Fatal Shooting of Rapper Young Dolph
abstract: The man, Justin Johnson, was sentenced on Thursday in the fatal 2021 shooting of the rapper who was gunned down outside a Memphis cookie shop in broad daylight.
lead_paragraph: A man was found guilty on Thursday and sentenced to life in prison in the 2021 shooting death of Young Dolph, an emerging Memphis rapper who was regarded as one of hip-hop’s most promising artists.

headline: What to Expect From Helene as It Moves North
abstract: After landfall, the storm will move quickly into Georgia and the Carolinas, where it promises to bring even more rain.
lead_paragraph: As Helene thrashes the Florida Panhandle with “unsurvivable” storm surge and “catastrophic” winds Thursday evening, people across the Southeast were bracing for the storm’s arrival in their region in the coming hours and days.

headline: City Investigators Seize Cash From New York Sheriff’s Office
abstract: The Department of Investigation is looking into whether Sheriff Anthony Miranda’s agency improperly took money from cannabis stores that it raided, closed and padlocked.
lead_paragraph: City investigators seized cash on Thursday from safes at the New York City Sheriff’s Office, which has raided hundreds of illegal cannabis shops and confiscated millions of dollars in proceeds and merchandise, according to a spokeswoman for Mayor Eric Adams’s administration.

headline: Quote of the Day: House Republicans Head Home With Little to Brag About
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 27, 2024
lead_paragraph: “This is political theater. I refuse to be a thespian in this failure theater.”

headline: Now They’re Dance Partners for Life
abstract: Grayson Warrick is the son of a retired ballet dancer. Alyssa Hubbard grew up dancing. And the two first met in preschool in New York.
lead_paragraph: Technically, Alyssa Prescott Hubbard and Grayson Evan Warrick first met in preschool. They were in the same class at Garden House School, then on East 64th Street in Manhattan, but she doesn’t really remember him.

headline: What’s at Stake in Austria’s General Election
abstract: Austrians will head to the polls on Sunday to elect a new Parliament, with the Freedom Party in position to potentially form a far-right government for the first time since World War II.
lead_paragraph: Austria heads to the polls on Sunday for a pivotal parliamentary election that could reshape the nation’s political landscape. The vote is being closely watched because it could lead to a government headed by a far-right chancellor, a first since the end of World War II.

headline: He Tried to Date Two Men. He Wasn’t Very Good at It.
abstract: After getting caught in a moment right out of a rom-com, it was clear Kevin Turner had a choice to make. He chose Dr. Nicholas France.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Perry Turner was not typically the type to date more than one person at a time. In fact, the very first time he tried it, things went awry within a matter of weeks.

headline: An Unexpected Spark Leads to a Journey of Acceptance
abstract: The actress Jessica Phillips and Chelsea Nachman, a theatrical publicist, felt an instant attraction after first meeting seven years ago. But it took a few years before their romance took off.
lead_paragraph: In the Broadway musical “Dear Evan Hansen,” Jessica Leigh Phillips played a single mother trying to support her anxious teenage son as he navigated a life of self-acceptance.

headline: It Was Risky to Hold a Wedding in Ukraine. They Did It Anyway.
abstract: Ethan Bregman asked Olha Beskhmelnytsina to be his girlfriend on Feb. 23, 2022. The next day, the world had changed.
lead_paragraph: After a romantic getaway in Venice in late February 2022, Olha Beskhmelnytsina and Ethan Bregman said their goodbyes and flew home — she to Kyiv, Ukraine, and he to New York City.

headline: I Decentered Men. Decentering Desire for Men Is Harder.
abstract: Organizing my life around some idyllic future husband has always felt wrong to me.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t want to get married?” Roy said.

headline: He Was Open to Love — but Kept His Job a Secret
abstract: After Jonathan Filiberto, a medium known as Jonathan Mark, matched with Jessica Rega on a dating app, it took months before he shared what he did for a living.
lead_paragraph: Like most people looking for love, Jonathan Mark Filiberto wanted to find someone who loved him for who he was rather than what he did or who he knew. So, he excluded his unusual job from his Bumble profile.

headline: This Is What Can Land You in Jail for Sedition in Hong Kong
abstract: Three men were the first to be convicted under the city’s recently expanded national security law, which has greatly curtailed political speech.
lead_paragraph: Wearing a T-shirt with a protest slogan.

headline: Friday Briefing: Mayor’s Adams’s Arraignment
abstract: Plus, control behind K-pop goes public.

Numerous elected officials have called for him to quit, including several Democrats running against him in next year’s primary. He insisted he would stay in office and fight the charges.

General Assembly.

lead_paragraph: For the first time in the three years since it staged a coup, the military in Myanmar has offered a major concession to the country’s opposition forces, calling on them to heal the nation’s rifts through “party politics” and prepare for the coming elections.

abstract: In the state of Victoria, you need more than one day to take in all that the A.F.L. Grand Final has to offer.
lead_paragraph: It is an unusual public holiday, one in honor of a professional sports event. The day off is on Friday, a day before the big game, and is celebrated with a parade featuring the two teams going head-to-head on Saturday.

headline: China Stocks Soar in Biggest Single-Week Jump Since 2008
abstract: Economic stimulus moves triggered a broad rally in trading in Shanghai and Shenzhen.
lead_paragraph: An abrupt move by China’s leaders to prime the economy with stimulus has produced a powerful rally in the country’s stocks, which have posted their biggest single-week gain in nearly 16 years.

headline: Legal Fight to Revive Congestion Pricing Can Proceed, Judge Rules

lead_paragraph: Nearly four months after Gov. Kathy Hochul indefinitely paused a congestion pricing toll program for New York City just before it was to take effect, a state judge on Friday ruled that the plan’s supporters could continue their court fight to revive it.

abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.

lead_paragraph: For nearly three years since he resigned as governor of New York in the face of a ballooning sexual harassment scandal, Andrew M. Cuomo has been trying to forge a path back to public office.

headline: Helene Makes Landfall in Florida as Category 4 Hurricane
abstract: The hurricane, the most powerful ever to hit Florida’s Big Bend region, brought strong winds and dangerous storm surges.
lead_paragraph: The hurricane, the most powerful ever to hit Florida’s Big Bend region, brought strong winds and dangerous storm surges.

headline: But Would Kamala Wear It?
abstract: In her sophomore collection Chloé’s Chemena Kamali offers a high summer vibe, but not too many suits. Schiaparelli and Rabanne also let the sun shine in.
lead_paragraph: After the hoo-ha generated last month by Kamala Harris’s appearance at the Democratic National Convention in not one but two Chloé suits — the tan number she wore for her surprise speech on Day 1, and the navy look she wore for her official acceptance speech — one could be forgiven for assuming that Chloé’s newish designer, Chemena Kamali, might lean into the whole tailoring-with-a-softer-edge thing.

headline: How a Book About Gloves Inspired a Masterpiece by Philip Roth
abstract: For years, Roth couldn’t get beyond the premise for his novel “American Pastoral.” Then he stumbled on a copy of “Shtetl in the Adirondacks: The Story of Gloversville and Its Jews.” The rest is literary history.
lead_paragraph: On one of my first days working at the Philip Roth Personal Library in Newark — which houses over 7,000 books that Roth collected throughout his life, many of them marked with his underlinings and marginalia — I spotted a curious title on the shelves: “Shtetl in the Adirondacks.”

headline: Redecorating? A Quick Trip to the Grocery Store May Be All You Need.
abstract: Why professional designers swear by supermarket décor.
lead_paragraph: The price of groceries is up — no doubt about it. But compared with the cost of decorative accessories or professional floral arrangements, the things you can find at a supermarket are a relative bargain.

headline: Which Food Is the Most Underrated? ​
abstract: A guest essay argues that anchovies (yes, anchovies!) deserve more love. What underappreciated food would you make the case for?
lead_paragraph: What are your favorite foods and flavors? Are there any that you think deserve more love and respect?

headline: The Wily Spy Who Risked His Life to Meet North Korea’s Secretive Leader
abstract: Park Chae-so was so successful in infiltrating the North that Kim Jong-il, the enigmatic ruler, once gifted him blueberry wine. So why was the celebrated undercover agent later jailed by South Korea?
lead_paragraph: When the South Korean spy met with Kim Jong-il, he declined the late North Korean leader’s offer of a toast, citing a promise to his mother that he would never drink.

headline: Go Wild with Fall’s Animal-Print Accessories
abstract: Jaguar, cheetah and leopard spots are showing up on the season’s fiercest shoes, boots and bags.

lead_paragraph: The actress gives a tour of her home in Provence, which she’s filled with delicate details like floral furniture and a pink marble sink.

headline: Melissa George Brings Cinematic Glamour to a 17th-Century French Manor
abstract: “This is a woman’s home,” the actress says. “If a man walks in, I want him to feel like a guest.”
lead_paragraph: FROM A DISTANCE, Visan, France, resembles a Provençal village like any other, charming but unassuming: a crop of pale stone buildings on a hilltop surrounded by vineyards. During the medieval period, however, the region was the seat of powerful dignitaries, including the Dauphin of Viennois, a count whose family owned the village’s now-ruined castle. In 1349, Humbert II — the last dauphin before the title was transferred to the French crown — burdened with debt and without a male heir, ceded his remaining land to the king. Five years earlier, in a similar exchange with the pope, who then led the Catholic church from the nearby city of Avignon, he had offered up Visan. The village became part of the papacy’s wealthy enclave, remaining so until the French Revolution; its historic center is still lined with the commanding houses built for nobles and members of the papal court.

headline: Katy Perry’s Latest Album Isn’t as Bad as Her Timing
abstract: The pop singer’s latest LP, “143,” has been gleefully panned, but its musical faults aren’t as remarkable as Perry’s failure to read the current cultural moment.
lead_paragraph: Less than 24 hours after its release last Friday, Katy Perry’s seventh studio album, “143,” had already earned a place in pop musical infamy.

headline: New R.S.V. Vaccines Had Limited Takers Last Year. Will This Year Be Better?
abstract: Some of the problems that patients ran into, including a lack of insurance coverage, have been resolved.
lead_paragraph: When the Food and Drug Administration approved several new vaccines against respiratory syncytial virus last year, the shots were celebrated as a “powerful new tool” to protect infants and older people. Pharmaceutical giants projected billions of dollars in sales, assuming a large swath of the eligible population would roll up their sleeves.

headline: How Tolkien and Lewis Re-enchanted a War-Weary World
abstract: A graphic novel makes a powerful case that if these two men had never met, 20th-century pop culture might have taken an entirely different course.
lead_paragraph: THE MYTHMAKERS: The Remarkable Fellowship of C.S. Lewis & J.R.R. Tolkien, by John Hendrix

headline: 21 New Books Coming in October
abstract: Novels by Karl Ove Knausgaard and Jean Hanff Korelitz; nonfiction by Ina Garten, Alexei Navalny and Ta-Nehisi Coates; Sapphic horror and more.
lead_paragraph: A coming-of-age overcast with the inconstant cloud of mental illness, Lerner’s first novel follows Amy Shred, an aspiring biologist turned book editor in 1970s suburban Connecticut whose older sister, Ollie, is beautiful, effortlessly cool and deeply unstable. As Ollie weaves in and out of psychiatric hospitals, Amy — by turns exasperated, awed and destroyed by her sister — probes what exactly it means for love to be unconditional.

headline: ‘The Bouncer,’ ‘Pearl’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: This month’s under-the-radar streaming suggestions include unexpectedly poignant action flicks, highly stylized horror pictures and documentaries about art thieves and sperm donors.
lead_paragraph: It was very easy, for quite some time, to dismiss Jean-Claude Van Damme as just another blank-slate action star. But something truly fascinating has happened as he’s grown older — in his best roles, he’s leaned into his vulnerability, playing his age rather than ignoring it. He no longer seems like a guy who can win every fight, so his fights are far more interesting. His face, like Clint Eastwood’s, has grown richer as its lines grow deeper and harder, and like Eastwood, he does his best acting when he seems to be doing nothing at all. This rough-and-tumble crime thriller from the gifted action director Julien Leclercq (“Sentinelle”) gives Van Damme plenty of character moments — it’s quieter and moodier than your typical bone-cruncher — but when the action beats arrive, they’re lean, mean and effective.

headline: What to Know About Francis Ford Coppola and ‘Megalopolis’
abstract: The controversies surrounding the new epic include accusations of on-set problems, a pulled trailer and more.
lead_paragraph: Francis Ford Coppola waged war with studio heads throughout the making of “The Godfather.” Production on his 1979 Vietnam War epic, “Apocalypse Now,” was so troubled — there was a typhoon and a near-fatal heart attack — that it was chronicled in a documentary.

headline: They Call Themselves the ‘Strange Sorority.’ Trump Was Their Initiation.
abstract: The world has moved on. They haven’t.
lead_paragraph: In Natasha Stoynoff’s fantasy, the women who have accused Donald Trump of sexual misconduct finally get to confront him. The details of the scenario change a bit, depending on how she tells it, but a few things remain consistent.

headline: ‘Will & Harper’: Old Friends Explore a New Identity Together
abstract: Will Ferrell and Harper Steele, a former “Saturday Night Live” writer, use a road trip to navigate their relationship now that she is out as a trans woman.
lead_paragraph: The road movie is a time-honored Hollywood genre, and it’s a good format for a documentary, too. Something about getting in a car and driving down the interstate feels quintessentially American and holds the potential for revelation. I’ve seen plenty that serve up only pablum about finding common ground and tolerating each other. But a country so full of contrasts and contradictions is excellent fodder for whoever is holding the camera.

headline: An Artists’ Refuge in Greenwich Village Is Listed for $25 Million
abstract: The townhouse, on West 11th Street, was the childhood home of the author Isabel Fonseca and, earlier, the residence of the sculptor Daniel Chester French.
lead_paragraph: The Greek Revival townhouse at 125 West 11th Street has long been a haven for artists. Daniel Chester French, a sculptor best known for designing the statue of Lincoln in the memorial in Washington, moved there in the late 1880s, and it was also home to Valerie Bettis, the modern dancer and choreographer who worked with stars like Rita Hayworth.

headline: When ‘Saturday Night Live’ Debuted, They Were There. Here’s What They Remember.
abstract: With a new film about the show, and a 50th anniversary season starting, Chevy Chase, Garrett Morris, Jane Curtin, Laraine Newman and others look back.
lead_paragraph: As the historic 50th season of “Saturday Night Live” gets underway, its very first episode has become a piece of show-business mythology: the story of how a group of misfit writers and performers, led by a 30-year-old Canadian upstart named Lorne Michaels, put together a counterculture comedy-variety show in Manhattan amid interpersonal conflict, last-minute changes and substance abuse, and somehow established a television institution.

headline: Colleges Are Reporting Post-Affirmative Action Data. Be Careful Interpreting It.
abstract: Many use different formulas to calculate racial makeup, and it’s not obvious there’s a “right” way.
lead_paragraph: In the past few weeks, colleges have started reporting the racial makeup of the first class admitted after the Supreme Court ended affirmative action in 2023.

headline: $1.65 Million Homes in Panama
abstract: The southern coast of the Central American nation offers beachfront villas, amenity-filled gated communities and activities near Panama City.
lead_paragraph: This five-bedroom, six-bath house with a pool, service quarters and guesthouse is in the oceanside neighborhood of El Majagual, about 12 miles southwest of Panama City.

headline: She Went Viral at 8. Now She’s Making Movies with Aubrey Plaza.
abstract: Maisy Stella stars in “My Old Ass,” a new coming-of-age film. After years as a child actor, she says it was going to high school that helped her prepare.
lead_paragraph: Maisy Stella couldn’t have guessed that the thing that would prepare her for her first major film role would be … being a regular teenager.

headline: The Charges Against Mayor Adams
abstract: In a 57-page indictment, federal prosecutors outlined a pattern of corruption that they said began years before Mr. Adams became mayor and continued after he took office.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll get details on the bribery and fraud charges that Mayor Eric Adams is facing.

headline: 5 Days With Elon Musk on X: Deepfakes, Falsehoods and Lots of Memes
abstract: Almost a third of 171 posts last week from the X owner were false, misleading or missing vital context.
lead_paragraph: Hours before former President Donald J. Trump spoke at a rally in New York last week, rumors started circulating online that a bomb had been discovered nearby. While the report was debunked, Elon Musk nonetheless amplified it in a post to his nearly 200 million followers on X.

headline: Nuclear Power Is the New A.I. Trade. What Could Possibly Go Wrong?
abstract: Artificial intelligence’s hunger for energy has set off a boom in utility stocks and may lead to the reopening of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: Want to make a wager on the future of artificial intelligence? Nvidia is the obvious bet. It designs the chips and software that make A.I. run, is the stock market favorite and has gained 144 percent this year alone.

headline: This ‘Real Housewife’ Is Back for More
abstract: Jessel Taank hits a fashion week party — with Pavit in tow — and pours tequila behind a bar.
lead_paragraph: Early on a Monday evening during New York Fashion Week, Jessel Taank breezed into the Sabyasachi boutique in the West Village, passing a life-size elephant sculpture near the sidewalk. But the “Real Housewives of New York City” star couldn’t quite say what it was doing there.

headline: Rubin Museum’s Tibetan Shrine Will Move to Brooklyn Museum
abstract: The collection of art and ritual objects will move to the Brooklyn Museum for six years starting in June after the Rubin closes its building to focus on traveling exhibitions and long-term loans.
lead_paragraph: The Tibetan Buddhist Shrine Room at the Rubin Museum, a centerpiece of its extensive collection of art from Himalayan Asia, will move to the Brooklyn Museum for six years starting next June as the Rubin closes its building and prepares to become a “museum without walls.”

headline: Diddy and Our Culture’s ‘Himpathy’ for Powerful Men
abstract: How the allegations against Sean Combs change the way we talk about #MeToo, rumors and powerful men.
lead_paragraph: This week on “Matter of Opinion,” we take a break from the election and turn our attention to the allegations against Sean Combs: Where has #MeToo succeeded or fallen short? And what happens when the lines blur between rumor mill and conspiracy theory? The Opinion columnist Tressie McMillan Cottom and the Opinion writer Jessica Grose join the conversation.

headline: Which Battleground State Voters Could Sway the Election?
abstract: An analysis of voter data reveals the demographic trends at play in this year’s presidential race.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of voter data reveals the demographic trends at play in this year’s presidential race.

headline: MAGA Is Not as United as You Think
abstract: The journalist Emily Jashinsky discusses the “huge gulf” between various factions of the New Right.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been fascinated by the problem Donald Trump faces with Project 2025. Trump has been caught in an awkward position, disavowing the document itself, but unable to fully disavow the people behind it. So I wanted to do an episode not just on Trump, but on the unwieldy coalition that has formed around him — what is sometimes referred to as the “New Right.”

headline: What Threats Mean for Trump’s Campaign
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s advisers are considering whether to modify his travel after threats to his life from Iran and two assassination attempts, according to several people briefed on the matter. Maggie Haberman, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, recounts the ways in which these threats have affected Mr. Trump and his campaign.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s advisers are considering whether to modify his travel after threats to his life from Iran and two assassination attempts, according to several people briefed on the matter. Maggie Haberman, a senior political correspondent for The New York Times, recounts the ways in which these threats have affected Mr. Trump and his campaign.

headline: The Women Who Made MoMA
abstract: A new photo book pays tribute to the female investors, curators, collectors and more without whom the Museum of Modern Art in New York likely would not exist.
lead_paragraph: The subtitle of INVENTING THE MODERN: Untold Stories of the Women Who Shaped the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA, $45) is no girlboss revisionism. Without the visionaries profiled within — especially Abby Aldrich Rockefeller, Lillie P. Bliss and Mary Quinn Sullivan — New York’s citadel for the avant-garde would likely not exist.

headline: Harris Heads to the Border, Trying to Project Toughness Against Trump
abstract: Visiting the border on Friday in Arizona, the vice president will try to neutralize a key vulnerability, and will demonstrate her party’s harder line on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with the latest updates on Trump, Harris and the 2024 election.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Sept. 27, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: What to Do When a Joke Hurts Your Feelings
abstract: Teasing can actually strengthen relationships, experts say. But sometimes things go too far.
lead_paragraph: This past summer, Mia Smith-Bynum took a cruise to the Caribbean with her extended family, some of whom she was meeting for the first time. But for the first day and a half, she couldn’t find her mother, who hadn’t yet purchased Wi-Fi, on the massive ship.

headline: The Visual Explanation For Why Fentanyl Is Unlike Any Drug We've Dealt With Before
abstract: The drug has swept across the country and brought a massive wave of overdose deaths in its wake.
lead_paragraph: The drug has swept across the country and brought a massive wave of overdose deaths in its wake.

headline: The Best Way to Keep Congress From Getting Things Done
abstract: Supporters of the filibuster argue that without unlimited debate, democracy succumbs to silence. Or something.
lead_paragraph: If the filibuster did not exist, it is hard to believe that anyone would invent it.

headline: Meta’s Race for Your Face, Google’s Hit A.I. Notebook and HatGPT
abstract: Building great A.R. glasses is the hardest problem in consumer technology.
lead_paragraph: This week, Casey reports back from a wild day at Meta Connect, discussing what’s new with Meta’s efforts in artificial intelligence, virtual reality headsets and the Holy Grail — augmented reality glasses. Then, Steven Johnson, a writer and editorial director at Google Labs, stops by to talk about the company’s new hit NotebookLM, which uses A.I. to turn even boring PDFs, such as user manuals and Kevin’s bank records, into chatty, disturbingly good podcasts. Finally, so much happened in tech news this week that we reached for the bucket hat in the latest installment of HatGPT!

headline: The Problem With a Crowd of New Online Polls
abstract: They’ve become cheap to produce but they underperform the competition, falling short of their original promise.
lead_paragraph: The polls were one of the big winners of the 2012 presidential election. They showed Barack Obama ahead, even though many believed a weak economy would propel Mitt Romney to victory.

headline: Things Are Looking Up for Africa’s Upside-Down Baobab Trees
abstract: A researcher followed up on a study warning that the massive trees were in danger, and found many venerable specimens thriving.
lead_paragraph: Baobabs are arboreal icons that have punctuated Africa’s landscapes for around 12 million years. With crowns that can grow as large as three tennis courts, they are important for more than their role in ecosystems. The trees are featured in cultural traditions across Africa, and they also support the livelihoods of thousands of people who harvest baobab fruit.

headline: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Adam Driver stars as Cesar, a genius architect with lofty plans to rebuild a futuristic city in Francis Ford Coppola’s latest.

headline: Inside the Lebanese Valley Where Israel Is Bombarding Hezbollah
abstract: The Bekaa Valley, a Hezbollah bastion in eastern Lebanon, had mostly been spared over 11 months of war. But The New York Times saw widespread devastation there after intense Israeli airstrikes this week.
lead_paragraph: Few signs of life can be seen along the highway in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon. Nearly every shop lining the road is shuttered and the sidewalks empty. The red-and-white painted barriers of some Lebanese army checkpoints are vacant, abandoned by the soldiers guarding them. Even the road is mostly quiet — save the occasional car racing out of the valley.

headline: Pope Francis Is Met With Anger Over Sexual Abuse on Visit to Belgium
abstract: During a trip to Luxembourg and Belgium, Francis spoke with 15 people who were abused by Roman Catholic clergy.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Friday met with 15 people who were sexually abused by members of the clergy in Belgium, a largely Roman Catholic country where the church has been plagued by a history of scandal.

headline: Zelensky Meets Trump Amid Fears for Continued U.S. Support for Ukraine
abstract: The session in New York was part of a nearly weeklong U.S. visit by the Ukrainian president in which he has made appeals to both Democrats and Republicans.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met with former U.S. President Donald J. Trump on Friday as concerns mount in Kyiv that a second Trump administration could spell the end of American support for Ukraine’s fight against Russia.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,197
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 28, 2024
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 475
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Sept. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Criminal Indictment of New York City’s Mayor
abstract: Eric Adams accepted free airline tickets, lavish overseas accommodation and illegal foreign campaign donations, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in New York history, federal prosecutors have indicted the city’s sitting mayor, accusing him of accepting illegal campaign donations and luxury gifts in return for political favors.

headline: Helene Roars on After Lashing Florida, and the Charges Facing Eric Adams
abstract: Plus, Batman joins the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Helene Brings Record Storm Surge to Florida
abstract: Waters rose rapidly along Florida’s Gulf Coast after Helene made landfall, flooding homes and forcing people to flee.
lead_paragraph: The first indications of damage along Florida’s Gulf Coast from Helene’s storm surge were emerging Friday morning, hours after the storm made landfall as the most powerful on record to hit the Big Bend area of the state.

headline: A Huge Hurricane
abstract: We’re covering Hurricane Helene. One of our reporters was inside the eye.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Helene slammed into Florida’s Gulf Coast as a Category 4 storm with winds of 140 miles an hour. It swallowed parts of Florida in a nine-foot storm surge, lashed the region with heavy rain and has cut power for millions of people. It is now in Georgia, where it is weakening to a tropical storm. You can track it here.

headline: ‘Saturday Night’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Jason Reitman narrates a sequence from his film about the making of the first episode of “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: The director Jason Reitman narrates a sequence from his film about the making of the first episode of “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Watch a Chaotic Rehearsal in ‘Saturday Night’
abstract: The director Jason Reitman narrates a sequence from his film about the production of the first episode of “Saturday Night Live.” Spoiler alert, making the show wasn’t easy.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Tropical Storm John Hits Mexico for the Second Time This Week
abstract: The storm made landfall again late Friday morning but was dissipating in the evening. At least eight people have died.
lead_paragraph: Severe weather battered parts of Mexico for the fifth consecutive day as Tropical Storm John made landfall on Friday, releasing more rain and catastrophic flash-flooding, forecasters said, though it is expected to weaken as the storm sweeps the country’s southwestern coast for a second time this week.

headline: The Big Apple Business View on Eric Adams
abstract: The criminal charges against the embattled mayor of New York have given corporate leaders pause about the city’s political future.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 48 hours, the biggest spectacle for New Yorkers hasn’t been the presidential race, but rather the criminal case against Mayor Eric Adams. He was indicted Thursday on five counts, including fraud, bribery and soliciting illegal campaign donations from abroad for years.

headline: Risk of Heart Defects Higher in Babies Conceived With I.V.F.
abstract: The birth defects were more likely, but still very uncommon, in infants conceived through certain fertility treatments, a large study found.
lead_paragraph: Major heart defects are more common — but still rare — in babies conceived through certain fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, researchers reported on Thursday in the largest study of its kind.

headline: Deal to Reopen Libya’s Central Bank Eases Fears of Renewed Conflict
abstract: A standoff over control of the bank had destabilized the country’s economy and raised the prospect of fresh fighting between Libya’s eastern and western factions.
lead_paragraph: The two sides of Libya’s political divide have agreed on a new leader for the country’s central bank — a settlement that officials hope will end months of escalating tensions that had raised fears that Libya could once again be sliding toward armed conflict.

headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Gauge Cooled in August
abstract: Inflation is slowing so much that some economists said it could pave the way for another big Fed rate cut, if other data suggest one is warranted.
lead_paragraph: Inflation cooled in August, the latest sign of progress in the Federal Reserve’s yearslong fight to bring rapid price increases back under control.

headline: Surviving Spouses May Not Be Responsible for Partners’ Medical Bills
abstract: A call from a debt collector may add to the challenges that bereaved people are already dealing with. But spouses “should not assume that they have to pay.”
lead_paragraph: The death of a spouse can be devastating, and in the aftermath, calls from collection agencies about medical bills and other debts could not come at a worse time.

headline: Judge Presiding Over Adams Graft Case Fought for Civil Liberties
abstract: Judge Dale E. Ho, who will oversee the case, has a sterling educational pedigree and a history of pointed remarks as a civil rights lawyer.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, a little more than a year after the Senate confirmed Dale E. Ho as a federal judge in a 50-to-49 vote, he was thrust into the spotlight when he was randomly chosen to preside over the case against Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: Maggie Smith, Grande Dame of Stage and Screen, Dies at 89
abstract: She earned an extraordinary array of awards, from Oscars to Emmys to a Tony, but she could still go almost everywhere unrecognized. Then came “Downton Abbey.”
lead_paragraph: Maggie Smith, one of the finest British stage and screen actors of her generation, whose award-winning roles ranged from a freethinking Scottish schoolteacher in “The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie” to the acid-tongued dowager countess on “Downton Abbey,” died on Friday in London. She was 89.

headline: ‘Intermezzo’ Book Club Conversation Space: Book Pairing Recommendations
abstract: Share recommendations of books you think would pair well with our October book club selection, “Intermezzo,” by Sally Rooney.
lead_paragraph: Did “Intermezzo” make you think of other books? Are there other titles you love — fiction or nonfiction — that explore similar themes? Share your recommendations for books you’d pair with “Intermezzo” in the comments here (click that chat bubble above to comment).

headline: ‘Intermezzo’ Book Club Conversation Space: Spoiler Chat
abstract: Want to discuss spoilers related to our October book club selection, “Intermezzo,” by Sally Rooney? Post them here.
lead_paragraph: Want to talk about something that happens later in “Intermezzo”? Dying to dig into a particular plot point or react to a big reveal? Post your spoiler-filled thoughts, questions and observations in the comments here (click the chat bubble above to comment).

headline: ‘Intermezzo’ Book Club Conversation Space: Main Discussion
abstract: Discuss our October book club selection, “Intermezzo,” by Sally Rooney, with the Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Share your thoughts about “Intermezzo,” by Sally Rooney, in the comments here by clicking the chat bubble above to comment. This will be our main conversation space.

headline: ‘Intermezzo’ Book Club Conversation Space: Chat About Sally Rooney’s Other Books
abstract: Looking to discuss Sally Rooney’s previous books? Chat about them here.
lead_paragraph: This month, the Book Review Book Club is reading “Intermezzo,” by Sally Rooney. Do you also want to talk about Rooney’s other books: “Conversations With Friends,” “Normal People” and “Beautiful World, Where Are You”? You can discuss them here. Click the chat bubble above to leave a comment.

headline: Some of America’s Best Art Is in the Yard
abstract: For people who have historically been excluded by museums and galleries, their own properties have became a source of inspiration.
lead_paragraph: AT THE DEAD end of a quiet residential street in Birmingham, Ala., is a half-acre lot filled with rusted metal beams, two-by-fours and old crutches jutting into the sky. At first glance, the artist Joe Minter’s “African Village in America,” situated on the lawn of his home, next to the historically Black cemetery where his father, wife and two sons are buried, looks like little more than an affectionately tended junkyard, the kind of neighborhood eyesore people are generally programmed to walk past. But inside is one of the more intriguing public art installations in the country. Discarded dolls, car parts and other found objects are grouped together by shape and color. As one gazes at the collection, forms emerge — steel bodies, cinder-block towers, outlines of rooms. Closer inspection reveals hundreds of sculptures, including a few concrete Dobermans guarding a cage that represents the cell at the Birmingham City Jail where Martin Luther King Jr. was imprisoned in 1963 for protesting local segregation laws.

headline: Talks Between European Banks May Kick-Start More Cross-Border Deals
abstract: Investors are cheering a possible tie-up between UniCredit of Italy and Germany’s Commerzbank, but politics may stand in the way.
lead_paragraph: For the past two decades, European banks have lurched from crisis to crisis, leading to government bailouts and stifling the sector’s growth.

headline: Andrew Scott Will Perform One-Man ‘Vanya’ Off Broadway Next Spring
abstract: The Olivier Award-winning revival, in which the actor plays all of the parts, is to begin previews March 11 at the Lucille Lortel Theater.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Scott, the Irish actor who has parlayed his “Fleabag” hot-priest-ness into a thriving stage and screen career, will perform a one-man version of “Uncle Vanya” Off Broadway next spring.

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Jebi
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Jebi.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Jebi.

headline: Inside a Josh Stein Ad Blasting Mark Robinson as ‘Unfit’ for North Carolina Governor
abstract: No “Black Nazi” quotations or porn-site references here. Just Robinson’s own bloodthirsty words.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the most explosive contests in the country: the race for North Carolina governor. And that is largely because of Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, the Republican nominee, who has long history of making incendiary remarks. His Democratic opponent, Attorney General Josh Stein, began running this 30-second ad portraying Mr. Robinson as unfit for public office, even before reports that Mr. Robinson had once called himself a “black NAZI,” defended slavery and written a host of other scandalous posts on a pornographic website. The Stein campaign has spent more than $2 million running the ad since Sept. 12.

headline: The Most Galling Part of the Whole Eric Adams Affair
abstract: With all its talent, how did the city end up with a mayor accused of being an incessant petty grifter?
lead_paragraph: The federal charges of bribery, fraud and conspiracy that Mayor Eric Adams faces are grave. But graver still is the damage the mayor has done to the city he claims to love and will continue to inflict if he remains in City Hall. If the mayor will not resign, Gov. Kathy Hochul should begin the process of removing him from office.

headline: The Sudden Appeal of the Bulldog Spirit
abstract: Such is the hold the Premier League has on the popular consciousness that enticing a player away from it is seen as a coup.
lead_paragraph: Atlético Madrid had pulled out all the stops to celebrate its new signing: strobing lasers and sparkling fireworks and, for reasons that were not entirely clear, a couple of thrumming motorcycles. Standing in the middle of it all, waving happily at the crowd, Conor Gallagher seemed just a little dazed.

headline: Israel Likely to Have Enough Weapons for Multiple Conflicts
abstract: Although Israel, like many countries, is highly secretive about its weapons stockpiles, experts believe it could outlast adversaries in offensives on at least two fronts simultaneously.
lead_paragraph: Over the last week alone, Israel launched more than 2,000 airstrikes against Hezbollah in Lebanon and continued its near-daily bombings against Hamas in the Gaza Strip. Its air defenses also fended off attacks, in one instance intercepting a ballistic missile headed for Tel Aviv.

headline: Van Gogh ‘Sunflowers’ Targeted Again as Protesters Are Sentenced to Jail
abstract: A judge said he hoped to deter protests when he handed down lengthy terms for the two activists, who dumped soup on the painting in 2022. Later that day, activists did it again.
lead_paragraph: When a London judge handed down prison sentences on Friday to two climate activists, who threw soup on Vincent van Gogh’s “Sunflowers,” he said he wanted to deter protesters from trying similar stunts.

headline: How to Win the Electoral College
abstract: Explore possible outcomes in the battleground states to see how Harris or Trump could reach 270 electoral votes and the White House.
lead_paragraph: Explore possible outcomes in the battleground states to see how Harris or Trump could reach 270 electoral votes and the White House.

headline: ‘Titaníque’ Was Her Big Hit. Is ‘Big Gay Jamboree’ Really Her Swan Song?
abstract: Two years after debuting the “Titanic” parody, Marla Mindelle says her new show, with Margot Robbie as a producer, may be her last as an actor.
lead_paragraph: There is a trail of trash cans plastered with Marla Mindelle’s face along the 10-minute walk from the Daryl Roth Theater in Union Square, where her musical “Titaníque” has been playing since 2022, to the Orpheum in the East Village, where her latest, “The Big Gay Jamboree,” is in previews.

headline: Secrets of the Ultimate Celebrity Photographer
abstract: In a declining business, Kevin Mazur has thrived by gaining the trust of Beyoncé, Madonna and Taylor Swift. His motto: “Why wouldn’t you want to make people look good?”
lead_paragraph: When Taylor Swift opened her Eras Tour in Glendale, Ariz., in March 2023, Kevin Mazur was granted full access to photograph the show.

headline: Zha Jiang Mian, Porky and Rich, Salty-Sweet and Satisfying
abstract: It’s the sort of meal you ought to make after a day of airline snacks or conference-room repasts, and definitely on Friday nights.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m still smarting over the two really expensive sandwiches I bought the other day at a gourmet shop in the next town over: one of them an ostensibly Italian number on white-bread focaccia, fridge-cold and tasteless; the other a “spicy” fried chicken cutlet on soggy pretzel bread with kimchi. That one was bathwater-warm and tasteless.

headline: Thailand’s Chiang Rai, Where Artists Go to Find Peace
abstract: Four insiders on where to stay, eat “micro-seasonal” dishes and shop for handmade pottery and textiles.
lead_paragraph: Travelers to the northern provinces of Thailand have long been drawn by two things — elephant camps and campy temples. The most famous examples of each are within or near the 13th-century city of Chiang Rai, where the Wat Rong Khun, or White Temple, stands as an artist’s parable of the world’s ills, as depicted in the form of pop culture villains and other icons of kitsch. (If crossing a sea of grasping arms at the entrance doesn’t terrify you, beware the Freddy Krueger-themed hanging planters.) Chiang Rai is also where the Emerald Buddha, a national treasure now housed in Bangkok’s Grand Palace, was reportedly discovered in 1434. According to legend, a bolt of lightning cracked the stupa in which it had been hidden years prior.

headline: How Google Defended Itself in the Ad Tech Antitrust Trial
abstract: The tech giant, which wrapped up its arguments in the federal monopoly trial, simply says it has the best product.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, Google has called more than a dozen witnesses to defend itself against claims by the Justice Department and a group of state attorneys general that it has a monopoly in advertising software that places ads on web pages, part of a second major federal antitrust trial against the tech giant.

headline: Westminster Abbey’s Brontë Plaque Had a Typo for 85 Years. It’s Fixed Now.
abstract: Punctuation delayed, but not denied: A memorial to Charlotte, Emily and Anne Brontë at Poets’ Corner in the celebrated London church finally gets its accent marks.
lead_paragraph: For 85 years, the names of three of English literature’s best-known writers, Charlotte, Emily and Anne Brontë, were featured in Poets’ Corner, the Westminster Abbey nook dedicated to great poets, authors and playwrights, but something wasn’t quite right: They were missing the accent mark.

headline: 10 Great Maggie Smith Performances to Stream
abstract: In “Downton Abbey,” “A Room With a View” and dozens of other films and television series, she delighted audiences with her portrayal of sharp, tart-tongued and often wryly funny Englishwomen.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Smith, who was 89 when she died on Friday, made her professional stage debut on Broadway in the 1950s, when she was still in her early 20s. In the decades that followed, she worked steadily in movies and television, while regularly returning to the theater.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: In this month’s picks, time loops, aliens and ecological collapse.
lead_paragraph: Television and the theater have served Mary-Louise Parker better than film. Let us cheer, then, Bernardo Britto’s “Omni Loop,” which gives the actress the kind of complex movie role she has long deserved.

headline: Acadia Healthcare Says It Faces New Federal Investigations
abstract: Shares of the company, one of the largest chains of for-profit psychiatric hospitals, were down 25 percent at one point.
lead_paragraph: Acadia Healthcare, one of the country’s largest chains of for-profit psychiatric hospitals, is facing a fresh round of federal investigations into how the company admits patients and bills for their stay, the company disclosed on Friday.

headline: ‘Completely Gone’: In Florida, Cedar Key Assesses Helene’s Devastation
abstract: A resident surveyed the many homes and businesses that were destroyed in the community of tiny islands in the state’s Big Bend region.
lead_paragraph: Cedar Key, a small community on a collection of tiny islands jutting into the Gulf of Mexico, is emerging as one of the areas most devastated when Helene struck Florida’s Big Bend region on Thursday night.

headline: Neil King Jr., Who Wrote of a Long Walk of ‘Renewal,’ Dies at 65
abstract: His book, “American Ramble,” lyrically recounted a 330-mile trek from Washington, D.C., to New York City while he was in remission from cancer.
lead_paragraph: Neil King Jr., a journalist whose book, “American Ramble,” told of his 330-mile trek from his home in Washington, D.C. to New York City while in remission from cancer, an account that lyrically evoked the people, history and back roads of the Mid-Atlantic region, died on Sept. 17 in Washington. He was 65.

headline: Divisions Emerge Over Whether Adams Should Resign
abstract: Amid the growing calls for Mayor Eric Adams’s resignation, some have taken the opposite tack.
lead_paragraph: As Mayor Eric Adams pleaded not guilty on Friday to bribery and fraud charges, division emerged among New York City’s power brokers over whether he should resign.

headline: Israel’s New Campaign Against Hezbollah Started With Raid in Syria
abstract: An attack on a secret weapons lab was one of the most daring Israeli operations against the Iranian proxy group in years, covert in name only.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Trump and Harris Step Up Efforts to Woo Mormon Voters
abstract: The recent moves reflect how members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are no longer locked in for Republicans. Their votes could matter in key battlegrounds.
lead_paragraph: Both presidential campaigns have stepped up efforts to court an unlikely group of potential swing voters: Mormons.

headline: Tracking Tropical Depression Joyce
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Joyce.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Joyce.

headline: Helene Has Killed at Least 111 People in 6 States
abstract: Officials in the Southeast said the toll was likely to rise.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from Helene had risen to at least 111 people across six states by Sunday evening.

headline: I’ve Lived With Hurricanes for Years. The Decisions Keep Getting Harder.
abstract: More than the sheer repetition of extreme weather, the stakes have grown — for our homes, our communities and our lives.
lead_paragraph: As the tropical disturbance that became Hurricane Helene moved north toward Florida’s Gulf Coast on Tuesday, I had an argument with myself about evacuating from Tallahassee: If I ran from the storm, would I get caught up in it anyway? I was thinking of Charlize Theron’s character in the movie “Prometheus,” crushed by a spaceship that crashed while she ran in a straight line away from it.

headline: D.A. Employee Threatened to Blow Up Queens Migrant Shelter, Police Say
abstract: The employee, Derek Klever, told a witness that he was fed up with migrants partying at the shelter across from his apartment, according to court documents. “This is a war,” he said.
lead_paragraph: An employee at the Queens district attorney’s office was accused on Thursday of threatening to detonate a device at a New York City migrant shelter after the police found explosive materials in his home, according to a complaint filed in Queens criminal court.

headline: Maggie Smith Brought Sharp-Tongued Wit Stateside
abstract: Americans are experts in the comedy of bluster, as many of our late night hosts can attest. We’re less practiced in precision.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Smith might have found it amusing that her death at age 89, in addition to being universally noted by appreciators of excellent acting, is being spontaneously memorialized in GIFs. Social media was flooded with pictorial snippets of memorable moments from “Downton Abbey,” as well as the “Harry Potter” films.

headline: Possible Cluster of Human Bird-Flu Infections Expands in Missouri
abstract: Seven people in contact with a patient hospitalized with bird flu also developed symptoms, the C.D.C. reported. Some are undergoing further tests.
lead_paragraph: A possible cluster of bird-flu infections in Missouri has grown to include eight people, in what may be the first examples of person-to-person transmission in the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Friday.

headline: Adams Lawyer Alex Spiro Has a Long Roster of Celebrity Clients
abstract: The former prosecutor represented the owner of the New England Patriots and is now Elon Musk’s personal lawyer.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Eric Adams is arraigned Friday, he will be joined at the defense table by his lawyer Alex Spiro, who has become one of the country’s most famous trial lawyers.

headline: Review: Roald Dahl Is Antisemitic, but Not a Cartoon Villain, in ‘Giant’
abstract: A new play in London portrays the beloved children’s author as a rounded character, while making no apology for his bigotry.
lead_paragraph: It started with a book review.

headline: U.S. Charges Iranians With Hacking Trump Campaign
abstract: The indictment highlighted the heightened threat posed by hostile international actors — Iran, Russia and China chief among them — who hope to disrupt the U.S. election.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury in Washington has indicted three members of a cyberespionage unit associated with Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps for mounting wide-ranging attacks targeting politicians, officials and journalists that led to the hacking of the Trump campaign this summer.

headline: Richard Pettibone, Master of the Artistic Miniature, Dies at 86
abstract: He painted tiny reproductions of works by Warhol, Lichtenstein, Duchamp and many others, raising questions about originality and creativity.
lead_paragraph: When the painter and sculptor Richard Pettibone was in art school in Los Angeles in the early 1960s, he was taught that there were two things he should never do.

headline: New York Film Festival Pitches Its Ever-Expanding, Global Tent
abstract: Standout selections include “Nickel Boys,” the Mumbai-set “All We Imagine as Light” and the documentary “Dahomey,” about African repatriation.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the New York Film Festival sets up a big tent at Lincoln Center and invites its hometown to the greatest show on earth, or at least to watch some of the finest movies from across the globe. This year is no different, with standout selections that include the opening-night attraction, “Nickel Boys,” RaMell Ross’s tender, beautifully expressionistic adaptation of the Colson Whitehead novel; “All We Imagine as Light,” Payal Kapadia’s delicately observed, stirring drama about three women living in Mumbai; and “Dahomey,” Mati Diop’s intellectually electrifying documentary about the fraught complexities of repatriation.

headline: A Town Near Tallahassee Starts Picking Up the Pieces From Helene
abstract: Roofs tore off and windows blew in. Trees were down or snapped like matchsticks on a road into town.

headline: The Cure’s First Fresh Music in 16 Years, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Lady Gaga, Rosalía, Stevie Nicks and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: On Trip to U.S., Zelensky Finds Ukraine’s Fortunes Tied to the Election
abstract: A whirlwind week of top-level meetings failed to alleviate concerns in Kyiv that a Trump presidency could lead to a dramatic shift in American policy.
lead_paragraph: When President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine set off for the United States this week on a high-stakes diplomatic mission, he had one goal above all others: rekindle a sense of urgency among his allies about Kyiv’s fortunes as the war with Russia heads into what promises to be another brutal winter.

headline: An Indicted Mayor and an Indicted Former President, and the Parallels Between
abstract: Eric Adams and Donald Trump, two political shape-shifters, have both insisted they’re victims of partisan prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: It was not long after Eric Adams became mayor of New York City in 2022 that the comparisons with Donald J. Trump started.

headline: In Less Than 20 Minutes, Eric Adams Formally Enters Legal Limbo
abstract: During his arraignment, New York’s typically lively mayor was stoic and stone-faced. Months of legal entanglements lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: It was just before 12:20 p.m. in New York City on Friday when Mayor Eric Adams, a newly arraigned federal criminal defendant, stood up, buttoned his suit jacket, smiled tightly at a court officer and left the courtroom.

headline: At a Barrier Island in Florida, Helene Brought ‘a Solid Wall of Water’
abstract: The hurricane passed far to the north but did enough damage in St. Pete Beach that some there began realizing what a direct hit could have done.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, Michael Morton, 47, and Chris Grant, 49, were sitting in a waterfront park in St. Pete Beach, a resort city on a barrier island just west of St. Petersburg, Fla., drinking bottled water in the shade and trying to decide what to do next. Mr. Morton, a native of St. Pete Beach, and Mr. Grant, who has lived in the area for nearly 30 years, agreed: They had never seen anything like Hurricane Helene.

headline: The Best, Easiest Dinner Party of Your Life
abstract: Spicy cucumbers, peppery sea scallops and coconut tapioca fill out this David Tanis menu.
lead_paragraph: There ought to be quite a few warm days between now and Thanksgiving — or so one hopes. So take advantage of them, I say, with a lighter approach to dinner (or even lunch) and save the deep, dark savory autumnal dishes for chillier days.

headline: Helene is bringing ‘life-threatening flash flooding’ to North Carolina.
abstract: In Western North Carolina, heavy rains are causing rivers and lakes to overflow, and landslides have blocked major roads. Across the state, two deaths have been linked to the storm.
lead_paragraph: As Tropical Storm Helene pounds North Carolina, the western part of the state is being hit hardest, with heavy rains causing rivers and lakes to overflow and landslides blocking major roads. Across the state, two deaths have been linked to the storm.

headline: Hot Microphones and No Audience: Here Are the Rules for the V.P. Debate
abstract: CBS News has announced the rules and format for Tuesday’s debate between Senator JD Vance and Gov. Tim Walz.
lead_paragraph: The brief era of muted microphones appears to be over.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, September 28, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: The Indictment of Mayor Eric Adams
abstract: Readers react to the corruption charges against New York’s mayor. Also: A path for Iran; the state of speech on campus; a tally of Trump insults.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Adams’s Lawyer Says He Flew Like a Congressman. But There Are Rules.
abstract: Members of Congress often get upgrades, but only if they are offered to all eligible travelers.
lead_paragraph: As part of Mayor Eric Adams’s defense against corruption allegations, his lawyer has compared his acceptance of heavily discounted international flights from Turkish Airlines to the kind of perks members of Congress receive.

headline: Lady Gaga’s ‘Joker,’ and a Tour of Musical Clowning
abstract: Clowns, harlequins, jokers and Pierrots have served as the main characters in countless songs over the years, but they’re rarely there to conjure cheap laughs.
lead_paragraph: Today — after announcing it just a few days ago — Lady Gaga released “Harlequin,” a companion album to the forthcoming film “Joker: Folie à Deux,” in which she stars as the troubled Harleen Quinzel. Fans clamoring for the next “Bad Romance” will have to wait a little longer: She’s promised that her next album, slated for release in February 2025, will be her return to pop. In the meantime, “Harlequin” is a satisfying showcase for the jazzier and more traditional side of Gaga — and another example of music’s continued obsession with clowns.

headline: A Florida Fishing Village, Rattled by Idalia, Suffers Another Devastating Blow
abstract: Homes were crumpled under the weight of trees, others left sodden by several feet of storm surge.
lead_paragraph: Steinhatchee, a small fishing village along the coast of Florida’s Big Bend, has been here before. Residents are still recovering from Hurricane Idalia, which battered the region more than a year ago.

headline: Big Business Backed Mayor Eric Adams. Now It Waits to Learn His Fate.
abstract: New York’s business sector is concerned that the possible removal of Mr. Adams from office would leave it without one of its biggest boosters.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Eric Adams took office, the city’s business community breathed a sigh of relief.

headline: Maggie Smith: A Life in Pictures
abstract: She had a long, award-winning career as a screen and stage actress, finally becoming a household name with her memorable turn in “Downton Abbey.”
lead_paragraph: Maggie Smith, who died on Friday at 89, was among the most venerable British actors of her era, embarking in the 1950s on a decades-long career and a run of memorable, award-winning performances. She won two Oscars, a Tony, three Golden Globes, four Emmys and several British Academy of Film and Television Awards.

headline: Atlanta was spared a direct hit, but at least 11 people died across Georgia.
abstract: Flooding inundated some neighborhoods in the state capital, and nearly a dozen people died in communities elsewhere in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Helene’s shift eastward late on Thursday largely spared Atlanta, which had been bracing for the hurricane’s eye-wall to pass directly over the city.

headline: ‘It Was Like Judgment Day’: Residents Flee Deadly Israeli Strikes Near Beirut
abstract: Residents described a scene of flattened buildings and destroyed vehicles after Israel unleashed strikes targeting Hezbollah’s leader outside the Lebanese capital.
lead_paragraph: When Israel unleashed deadly strikes on residential buildings south of Beirut late Friday in an attempt to target Hezbollah’s leader, the deafening explosions rattled the entire neighborhood, said Rabia Ali, a Syrian refugee and mother of three, and left her children “shaking with fear.”

headline: With Sean Combs in Jail, Civil Suits Continue to Pile Up
abstract: The latest lawsuit includes accusations of drugging and coerced sex as recently as this year. Mr. Combs’s lawyers have said the claims are attempts to obtain quick settlements.
lead_paragraph: A woman filed a lawsuit against the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs on Friday alleging that he repeatedly coerced her into forced sexual encounters over a period of several years, in part by compelling her to take drugs that caused her to fall unconscious.

headline: National Symphony Orchestra Players Reach Deal After Brief Strike
abstract: The musicians won a raise of about 8 percent over two years after a short work stoppage, the Washington ensemble’s first in 46 years.
lead_paragraph: The musicians of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington reached a deal with management for a new labor contract on Friday after a tense, short-lived strike threatened to disrupt the season.

headline: Chappell Roan Cancels a Pair of Big Shows After Tumultuous Weeks
abstract: The pop star said things had “gotten overwhelming” and bowed out of festivals in New York and Maryland after a period in which her politics came under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Chappell Roan, the pop star who has rocketed to stardom over the summer, abruptly canceled a pair of major festival performances scheduled for this weekend, citing “pressures” and the need to prioritize her health.

headline: ‘Quiet Place’ in Pennsylvania Is Thrust Into Loud Immigration Debate
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump turned his sights on Charleroi, Pa., where many Haitians have settled in recent years, and he fueled a fire that was already smoldering.
lead_paragraph: Amos Vougar felt as though he had found just about everything he needed when he arrived in the small Pennsylvania town of Charleroi. The people were welcoming, the rent was cheap, and he soon moved up the job ranks at a food processing plant, allowing him to send money to his wife and children back in Liberia.

headline: As Mark Robinson’s Campaign Crumbles, North Carolina Republicans Seethe
abstract: The scandal surrounding Mr. Robinson has incensed party officials and donors, some of whom described longstanding concerns about his campaign.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks before Election Day, the Republican Party in North Carolina is in an extraordinary standoff with its own nominee for governor.

headline: Democrats See a Chance to Beat Trump on Judicial Confirmations
abstract: They hope to use the time after the election to approve judges, but Senator Durbin says their aggressive efforts have already produced a remarkable demographic shift on the federal courts.
