lead_paragraph: Results of New York Times/Siena College poll of 680 likely voters in Nebraska’s Second Congressional District conducted from Sept. 24 to 26, 2024.

headline: Toplines: September 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Nebraska’s Second Congressional District
abstract: Results of New York Times/Siena College poll of 680 registered voters of Nebraska’s Second Congressional District conducted from Sept. 24 to 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of New York Times/Siena College poll of 680 registered voters of Nebraska’s Second Congressional District conducted from Sept. 24 to 26, 2024.

headline: Your Friend Has More Money Than You Do. How Can Your Relationship Survive?
abstract: Financial disparities in friendships can create conflict where it shouldn’t exist. Here’s how two friends navigated a growing wealth gap.
lead_paragraph: Adult friendships aren’t easy to maintain. Busy schedules and competing demands interfere with making time for friends. And when money is involved, friendships can become even more complicated.

headline: A Wisconsin City Welcomed New Refugees. Then the Angry Billboards Went Up.
abstract: Eau Claire had a plan. But opponents, mostly from rural areas, were convinced that the newcomers would destroy their Midwestern way of life.
lead_paragraph: The billboards featured a foreboding message. Taxpayer money, it said, was footing the bill for a nonprofit to traffic Somali refugees — and officials in Eau Claire, Wis., had been hiding the facts for months.

headline: The American Drug Mules Smuggling Fentanyl Into the U.S.
abstract: Mexican drug cartels are turning thousands of Americans into fentanyl smugglers, sending an army of couriers who can easily cross between both countries.
lead_paragraph: The teenager practiced driving from his apartment in San Diego down to Tijuana and back, on the orders of the criminals he was working for in Mexico. He rehearsed how he would respond to questions from U.S. border officers. He tracked when the drug-sniffing dogs took a break.

headline: Why Jackson Pollock Owed Everything to Claude Monet
abstract: A new biography of the French Impressionist argues that Monet himself owed everything to the three most important women in his life.
lead_paragraph: In the years before World War II, as modern art began to reach a broad international audience, a powerful origin story emerged about the 20th-century avant-garde. In this telling, the epochal revolt initiated by Picasso and Matisse had been spurred by a few trailblazing forebears — Paul Cézanne, Vincent van Gogh, Paul Gauguin and Georges Seurat, mainly. Notably left out was Claude Monet (1840-1926), whose shimmering Impressionist paintings had made the unstable act of seeing an end in itself.

headline: Race, Class, Land and a Teenage Love Triangle
abstract: In Louise Erdrich’s new novel, “The Mighty Red,” a high school jock proposes to the Ojibwe daughter of a woman who works for his family’s sugar farm.
lead_paragraph: On its surface, “The Mighty Red,” by the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Louise Erdrich, is a love story turned on its head. It begins not with a tentative meeting but with a diamond ring. Eighteen-year-old Gary Geist plans on marrying his high school girlfriend, Kismet Poe, so travels from his farm in the Red River Valley to a jeweler’s store in Fargo, N.D., to pick out a “wearable fleck of eternity.” He is a jock; she is bookish. His mother, Winnie, is ecstatic about the union; hers, Crystal, distraught. After three proposals, the girl caves, and the Geists organize a wedding. Alas, the bride is sleeping with her friend Hugo.

headline: In a White Gated Community, the Only Black Couple Wind Up Dead
abstract: The protagonist of Rivers Solomon’s novel “Model Home” has tried to outrun childhood trauma, but their ghosts lure them right back.
lead_paragraph: In the first chapter of Rivers Solomon’s fourth book, “Model Home,” the narrator, Ezri, and their teenage daughter, Elijah, give in to insomnia and watch a true-crime show on TV: “We both find solace in the inevitability of broken girls.” Ezri has not always been so fatalistic: “Abuse of power surprises me every time,” they told their own mother at 13; “I guess I hope every time it will be different.” This immediate contrast of past and present introduces an underlying mystery: How did Ezri lose their “earnest heart”?

headline: The Surprising Place Analysts Look to for Election Forecasting
abstract: Washington State’s primaries have a record of predicting the national mood, making it a bellwether of sorts.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Using Dance to Provoke, Delight and Tell South Africa’s Stories
abstract: Growing up in a Black township, Vusi Mdoyi found a sprinkle of joy under apartheid in a street-dancing style known as pantsula. As a choreographer, he has elevated it into high art, injected with ideas.
lead_paragraph: The young boy couldn’t resist the dance moves he saw being performed around him: the rapid foot taps, the ligament-spraining knee twists, the torso shimmies, all coming together in what some might describe as a sort of urban tap dance.

headline: Desi Lydic Wants to Be in Central Park, Listening to Chappell Roan
abstract: “I love getting out and about early in the day, getting some fresh air and sunlight and seeing the city,” the “Daily Show” host said of her morning ritual.
lead_paragraph: In one of her auditions for “The Daily Show,” the comedian and actress Desi Lydic did an impression that, as she put it, “was kind of going for that ex-lawyer, four-time beauty pageant winner and overqualified but leggy Fox News blowhard.”

headline: 4 New Horror Books Filled With Eldritch Terrors and Other Frights
abstract: Our columnist reviews September’s new horror releases.
lead_paragraph: Powerful. Brutal. Bursting at the seams with cosmic horror, ennui, violence and self-annihilation. There are many ways to describe Laird Barron’s latest collection, NOT A SPECK OF LIGHT: Stories (Bad Hand Books, 370 pp., paperback, $19.99), but superb works just fine.

headline: A Slippery Devil Finally Gets His Moment at MoMA
abstract: The German artist Thomas Schütte expects blowback when a retrospective of his work opens. Maybe he even enjoys that prospect.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning in a tidy workshop a half-hour from his home in Düsseldorf, Thomas Schütte, one of Europe’s most celebrated artists, was face to face with a devil. It was deep blue, stout as a gnome, with phallic horns, grasping arms and gaping eyeholes. Soon to be cast in bronze, the sculpture was up on a forklift so its maker could look it in the eyes.

headline: Ina Garten’s Memoir of Fortune, Work and Being Obsessed With Her Husband
abstract: In “Be Ready When the Luck Happens,” the TV cooking icon asks, “How easy is that?” The answer? Not very.
lead_paragraph: Many books open with epigraphs. Maybe Plato, the Bible or Oscar Wilde; usually lofty, and generally by a long-dead stranger.

headline: The Heart-Healthy Diet Hardly Anyone Is Talking About
abstract: The DASH diet was shown to lower blood pressure decades ago, yet few people follow it. Here’s how to give it a try.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Deepak Gupta discusses blood pressure management strategies with his patients, they often jump to say that they know they should cut down on salt, he said.

headline: 5 Podcasts for Word Nerds
abstract: These shows explore the origin stories of common phrases and terms, the evolution of language and the biases that affect our perceptions of speech.
lead_paragraph: Linguistics might sound like a dry subject, exciting only to an academically devoted few, but the rising popularity of online word games suggests otherwise. Since it’s not particularly easy to play Wordle while doing chores, these five podcasts offer an alternative way to indulge your love of language. They explore the origin stories of common phrases and terms, the shifts over time and the biases that affect how we perceive speech.

headline: My Co-op Banned My E-Bike, Which I Need. Can They Do That?
abstract: The co-op has to protect the safety of everyone in the building. But it also must comply with its own bylaws.
lead_paragraph: Q: My New York City co-op building has voted to ban my electronic bike, which I use to get my child to and from medical appointments. I have filed for a request for an accommodation under the Fair Housing Act, with letters from my son’s doctor and from mine. The co-op board won’t reverse the ban, nor did it offer an alternative. They asked that future communications be made by my lawyer. This ban would add at least an hour each day to my commute, and I cannot afford a car. Do I have options? Can the building just ignore my request?

headline: The True Costs of America’s Gun Obsession
abstract: It’s not just murders and mass shootings. Guns play a role in many of the country’s biggest problems.
lead_paragraph: No other country comes close to matching America’s levels of gun ownership. In fact, the United States has more firearms than people.

headline: Trump Gave Them a Second Chance. They Could Not Stay Out of Trouble.
abstract: A California woman facing trial on fraud charges is one of six people who received clemency during the Trump administration only to be accused of another crime.
lead_paragraph: In December 2019, Adriana Camberos began serving a 26-month sentence in federal prison for her role in a scheme to sell millions of counterfeit bottles of the caffeinated drink 5-hour Energy that had been filled with a fake concoction and sold to unsuspecting consumers.

headline: Ina Garten Figured Out How to Let Go of the Shame
abstract: A memoir? How easy is that.
lead_paragraph: It’s unnerving to watch Ina Garten get weepy.

headline: How to Understand Election Polls
abstract: A few rules of thumb can help you decipher all that political data.
lead_paragraph: A few rules of thumb can help you decipher all that political data.

headline: How Being a Middle Child Shaped an Actress’s Style
abstract: Issa Rae prefers attire with “symmetry” and avoids flashy clothes. Plus: vintage Ralph Lauren and the sudden end of a cult brand.
lead_paragraph: “I just like things to be balanced, to be even on both sides,” Issa Rae said on a call this month. “Being a middle child, right in the middle of five, I always wanted things to be fair.”

headline: Three Things to Look for in Any Election Poll
abstract: A new poll comes out. How should you interpret it? Here are some rules of thumb.
lead_paragraph: Election polls are everywhere. In news articles, on social media and maybe even in your group chat, you’re probably seeing loads of numbers, some of which seem to contradict one another.

headline: Harris and Trump Are Neck and Neck in Michigan and Wisconsin, Polls Find
abstract: The race between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump has tightened in two of the Northern battlegrounds, New York Times/Siena College polls found.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: An Artist Whose Subjects Step Out of His Paintings
abstract: Adam Dressner, a lawyer turned portrait artist, began painting eccentric New Yorkers a few years ago. Many of them made an appearance at a recent exhibition.
lead_paragraph: As evening commuters streamed into Grand Central Terminal on Tuesday, they dashed past several large oil portraits displayed on easels in Vanderbilt Hall on the way to catch their trains. Had they ventured inside the space, they would have experienced the strange sensation of mingling in the crowd with the paintings’ subjects.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’: Here’s What Critics Thought of the First Episode
abstract: The late-night institution begins its 50th season on Saturday. Here’s how The New York Times and others covered its debut in 1975.
lead_paragraph: It is strange to read the early press coverage of “Saturday Night Live.” No matter how much the show has changed over the years, the focus of the criticism is still much the same.

headline: Democratic Senate Candidates Lead in Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin, Polls Find
abstract: Strong showings in new Times/Siena College polls leave a narrow path open for Democrats to keep hold of the chamber, but Republicans maintain an advantage with the map.
lead_paragraph: Democratic Senate candidates in the Upper Midwest states of Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin hold leads over their Republican competitors, keeping a narrow path open to maintaining Democratic control of Congress’s upper chamber next year, according to new New York Times/Siena College polls.

headline: Harris Leads in Race for Eastern Nebraska’s One Electoral Vote, Poll Finds
abstract: If Ms. Harris were to win the “blue wall” and lose the Sun Belt swing states, the single electoral vote in Greater Omaha could determine the winner of the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris holds a lead over former President Donald J. Trump for the single Electoral College vote in eastern Nebraska, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College, a potentially critical prize if the overall presidential contest remains on a knife’s edge.

headline: We Tried to Shop Our Way to Cheaper Car Insurance. It Didn’t Work.
abstract: The normally unstoppable force of two veteran money reporters hit the immovable object of wretched industry conditions. Living in Brooklyn didn’t help.
lead_paragraph: We were bound to fail. We just didn’t know it when we started our quest.

headline: On ‘Downton Abbey,’ Maggie Smith Made an Icy Aristocrat Irresistible
abstract: The hit melodrama brought Smith the kind of fame she never wanted, but it is easy to understand why it happened.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, Maggie Smith’s brilliant, high-wire career can be seen as a protest against celebrity.

headline: Ahead of Debate, Walz Is Viewed More Favorably Than Vance in Midwest, Polls Find
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz is viewed more favorably than Senator JD Vance by likely voters in Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, according to New York Times/Siena College polls.
lead_paragraph: In the contest between Minnesota dad energy and “Hillbilly Elegy” energy, Midwestern voters appear to have a clear preference.

headline: ‘We’re Still Living in Fear’: Escaping the Attacks in Lebanon
abstract: Tens of thousands of people have been displaced in Lebanon. Khaled Hussein, 20, fled Syria as a child. He describes the bombardment that forced his family to flee again.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people have been displaced in Lebanon. Khaled Hussein, 20, fled Syria as a child. He describes the bombardment that forced his family to flee again.

headline: Could We See a 270-268 Election? The Polls Are Tighter Than Ever.
abstract: The latest Times/Siena polls show Harris slightly ahead in Michigan and Wisconsin, with a healthy lead in Nebraska’s Second District.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: As Florida Storms Worsen, Some in Tampa Bay Wonder: Is Living There Worth It?
abstract: Residents of the booming region are confronting a new reality: Even when storms make landfall far away, their impact is being felt.
lead_paragraph: Living near the gleaming expanse of Tampa Bay in Florida used to require a certain calculus: Fear the Big One, a powerful hurricane that would tear into the densely populated region and drown people and property. But also rest assured that most Gulf of Mexico storms are near-misses — one has not directly hit Tampa since 1921 — and keep enjoying life on the coast.

headline: ‘The Interview’: John Oliver Is Still Working Through the Rage
abstract: The host of ‘Last Week Tonight’ talks about what he’s learned in the ten years of making the show and why he doesn’t consider himself a journalist.
lead_paragraph: The host of ‘Last Week Tonight’ talks about what he’s learned in the ten years of making the show and why he doesn’t consider himself a journalist.

headline: John Oliver Is Still Working Through the Rage
abstract: The host of ‘Last Week Tonight’ talks about what he’s learned in the ten years of making the show and why he doesn’t consider himself a journalist.
lead_paragraph: Nobody is doing late-night comedy quite like John Oliver. Oliver first became known to U.S. audiences as the senior British correspondent for “The Daily Show,” bringing a keen outsider’s eye and observational humor to American political dysfunction. But since 2014, he has been hosting his own show, “Last Week Tonight,” on HBO, winning 30 Emmys and the respect of a devoted audience for his very funny, meticulously researched deep dives into subjects that few would consider obvious comedic fodder.

headline: Harris’s Historic Run Could Outpace Hollywood’s Oval Offices
abstract: Black and Asian American women have rarely, if at all, played the U.S. commander in chief in television and film. As Kamala Harris makes her presidential bid, Hollywood lags behind.
lead_paragraph: When Barack Obama was the Democratic nominee for president in 2008, James Earl Jones and Morgan Freeman had already portrayed commanders in chief on film.

headline: Viewfinders Make Fall Foliage Pop for the Colorblind in Virginia
abstract: Specialized viewfinders installed across state parks let visitors with red-green colorblindness see more distinct colors.
lead_paragraph: Like so many other leaf-peeping enthusiasts, Tim Yates ventured out to Virginia’s Smith Mountain Lake State Park late this summer to see the early whispers of the fall foliage, which would soon give way to bright bursts of orange and red.

headline: Stark Reality After Israel’s Latest Assault: Even Beirut Isn’t Safe
abstract: “Nobody has any idea what to do,” said one of the many residents who fled the Dahiya, an area near the Lebanese capital where Hezbollah holds sway, amid overnight Israeli airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: The streets of Beirut, Lebanon, were eerily empty on Saturday morning. Most stores were shuttered, and few cars passed along the usually bustling streets. Drones buzzed overhead.

headline: White Sox Lose 121 Games in a Season, Making History
abstract: In its weird, shambolic spectacle, the record-setting game seemed to encapsulate the team’s entire dreadful season.
lead_paragraph: Friday night in Detroit, as people bought hats and ate hot dogs and sang along to rock anthems, the Chicago White Sox pulled off a staggering feat. They lost their 121st game of the season, vaulting themselves into modern baseball history by breaking the record for most losses, one previously held by the 1962 Mets.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,198
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 29, 2024
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 476
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Sept. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Newfoundland and Labrador’s Unlikely Foray Into England’s Soccer Scene
abstract: The province is sponsoring an obscure professional team in an effort to attract skilled immigrants.
lead_paragraph: This week, my colleague Rory Smith used his soccer expertise to look at the sport’s contribution to fashion. Specifically, he reported that vintage soccer jerseys have become popular street wear and that buying and selling them has turned into a major business.

headline: Mass Shooting in South Africa Leaves 17 Dead
abstract: Most of the victims were women killed in one homestead, according to the police, who have started a manhunt for the gunmen.
lead_paragraph: At least 17 people from a single family were killed when gunmen attacked two homesteads in South Africa early Saturday, the police said, adding to a rising number of mass shootings in the country.

headline: At Capacity
abstract: If we can’t remember the things we read and watch and even loved, do they still “count”?
lead_paragraph: Everyone I know seems to be talking about their memory lately, how it isn’t what it used to be. Mine isn’t, and there’s some comfort in commiseration. Yes, we’re getting older, isn’t it something to observe, how we can no longer so easily recall names or events or what it was we were just about to say.

headline: How to Fix Social Security to Protect the Young and Old
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay arguing that young people are unfairly burdened by supporting boomers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kamala Harris Said She Owns a Gun for a Very Strategic Reason
abstract: She has been doing an effective job of vice signaling from the left.
lead_paragraph: At the presidential debate and on the campaign trail, Kamala Harris has hardly sounded like the Marxist or the Communist that Donald Trump has accused her of being. She hasn’t even sounded particularly progressive. At various times, she has said that she backs fracking, taunted Mr. Trump for his weakness in the face of dictators and bragged about owning a gun — going so far as to tell Oprah Winfrey, “if someone breaks in my house, they’re getting shot.”

headline: Francis Ford Coppola’s ‘Megalopolis’ Is Exactly the Risk Hollywood Needs
abstract: Spending a personal fortune to fund a passion project isn’t folly. It’s the ultimate kind of cinematic courage.
lead_paragraph: By now you may have heard about how Francis Ford Coppola spent, some say foolishly, over $100 million of his own money to produce “Megalopolis,” his fable of a future utopia, four decades in the making, which finally landed in theaters this week.

headline: What Shohei Ohtani and His Magnificent Season Mean for You
abstract: What we can learn from the greatest season in baseball history.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Sept. 19, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ Shohei Ohtani became the first player to hit 50 home runs and steal 50 bases in a single season. During his barrier-breaking game against the Miami Marlins, Ohtani also batted six-for-six, hit three home runs and drove home 10. Commentators called it the greatest single game in the greatest single season in Major League Baseball’s 121-year history.

headline: Sally Rooney Deserves Better Than This
abstract: To truly appreciate her novels, we have to stop imagining that they’re all about her, or about us.
lead_paragraph: Sally Rooney is not an interesting person. She’ll tell you this herself — recently, in an interview with The New York Times for her new novel, “Intermezzo,” she replied to a question about her hobbies with: “What do I like to do? I feel like I’m so uninteresting.” In another interview, with The Guardian, she expressed the wish not to be “the focal point” for conversation about the role of “young women in our culture.”

headline: ‘Don’t Kill My Child. Kill Me Instead.’
abstract: The world has largely abandoned Sudan, but this woman risked everything to stand up to evil.
lead_paragraph: Side by side with the worst of humanity, you regularly encounter the best. And so it was that while covering murder, rape and starvation in Sudan, I was awed by a heroic refugee, Naima Adam.

headline: The Most Important Question Kamala Harris Hasn’t Answered
abstract: What would a President Harris do about the war in Ukraine?
lead_paragraph: Not all the policy questions left unanswered by Kamala Harris’s studiously vague presidential campaign are created equal. It is not especially urgent, for instance, to know how Harris’s views of the ideal health care system have evolved since the great Medicare for All debates of 2020, given the strong likelihood that as president she would share power with a Republican Congress and any sweeping domestic policy initiatives would be stillborn.

headline: The Indictment of Eric Adams Shouldn’t Surprise Us
abstract: Eric Adams is accused of injecting foreign funds directly into his election campaigns, compromising not only the mayor’s office but also American elections.
lead_paragraph: The new, unsealed indictment against Eric Adams, accusing him of a range of crimes over nearly a decade, is significant for any number of reasons: Mr. Adams is the first mayor in New York history to face federal indictment while in office and also, to my knowledge, the first sitting mayor in American history  indicted on charges of acting at the behest not of his constituents but of a foreign power.

headline: No Turkish Delight for New York’s Mayor
abstract: The latest worm in the Big Apple.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the most anthropologically fascinating dinner parties I ever attended. Cindy Adams, the New York Post gossip G.O.A.T., feted her 94th birthday at her rococo Park Avenue apartment in April.

headline: After Your Death, Who Takes Care of the Dog?
abstract: A pet trust designates a new guardian for companion animals and sets aside funds for their care. Better yet, it’s legally binding.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Tracy Jennings received shocking news: A lifelong friend, a woman who had a farm with animals great and small, had died suddenly in an accident.

headline: Hezbollah’s Victims Express Relief at Its Disarray
abstract: Amid widespread condemnation of Israel’s massive strikes, Syrian communities persecuted by Hezbollah forces voiced cautious, and sometimes exuberant, celebration.
lead_paragraph: Even as most of the Middle East is overtaken by outrage at weeks of destructive Israeli strikes against Hezbollah and its leaders, some communities are celebrating the disarray of the powerful militia that persecuted them.

headline: Laura Donnelly, ‘Hills of California’ Star, Is Not Some Delicate Flower
abstract: But she did “burst into tears” reading Jez Butterworth’s rewrite of his new Broadway play, which left her with 10 days “to create an entirely new character.”
lead_paragraph: Most plays that transfer to New York from London arrive in close to their original form. There might be small changes to the text, to make particular lines comprehensible to American ears, but usually not much more than that.

headline: Power and Communication Outages Hamper Assessment of Landslides
abstract: With communication lines down in the mountains amid Helene, early reports were unclear about how many landslides had occurred and the extent of damage from the storm.
lead_paragraph: More than a foot of rain turned major roadways in cities in the southeastern United States like Asheville, N.C., and Atlanta into floodplains on Friday when already saturated soils were overwhelmed by the torrential bands of Helene.

headline: Molly Recommends Small Takes on Big Ideas, and a Novel of Sisterhood
abstract: James Richardson’s aphorisms; Nora Lange’s novel “Us Fools”
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Israel Tracked Nasrallah for Months Before Assassination, Officials Say
abstract: The Israeli military decided to strike at the Hezbollah leader because it believed there was only a short window before he disappeared to a different location, three senior Israeli officials said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli leaders had been aware of Hassan Nasrallah’s whereabouts for months and decided to strike him this past week because they believed they had only a short window of opportunity before the Hezbollah leader would disappear to a different location, according to three senior Israeli defense officials.

headline: As Hezbollah Pursued a Limited War, Israel Went for a Knockout
abstract: The militia group seemed content to trade blows with Israel while avoiding a major conflict. A strike that killed its leader proves it miscalculated.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after Hamas launched the surprise attack on Israel that started the Gaza war last October, Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, laid out his group’s approach to the war.

headline: Can Lina Khan Hold On?
abstract: Ms. Khan’s term as the chair of the Federal Trade Commission ended Wednesday. In a wide-ranging interview, she discussed her aggressive approach to antitrust and its critics.
lead_paragraph: From Wall Street to Silicon Valley, everyone wants to know what’s next for Lina Khan.

headline: SpaceX Launches Mission to Bring Back Starliner Astronauts
abstract: Two astronauts — one American, one Russian — are headed to the International Space Station with two empty seats for crewmates who are already in orbit.
lead_paragraph: Lifted by a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, two astronauts left Earth on Saturday afternoon, headed to the International Space Station.

headline: Dish and DirecTV Near a Deal to Combine (Again)
abstract: The companies are in talks to create one of the largest pay-TV providers in the country. In 2002, the U.S. government blocked a similar deal.
lead_paragraph: Business has gotten only more difficult for Charlie Ergen, the founder of the satellite TV giant Dish, since the government blocked his bid to combine his company with DirecTV in 2002.

headline: Trump Voters Drive a Rise in Ticket Splitting
abstract: Ticket splitters in key presidential battlegrounds and Ohio tend to be supporters of Donald J. Trump who are skeptical of his picks for Senate, polling shows.
lead_paragraph: In the 2022 midterm elections, former President Donald J. Trump endorsed dozens of candidates down the ballot, positioning himself as Republicans’ undisputed kingmaker.

headline: The Fans Want to Watch Football. Trump and Walz Will Be There, Too.
abstract: Donald Trump and Tim Walz are attending college games on Saturday that will draw plenty of viewers in the swing states of Michigan and Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: Hassan Nasrallah, Who Led Hezbollah for Decades, Killed at 64
abstract: In 32 years in charge of Hezbollah, Mr. Nasrallah built the Iranian-backed militia into an influential regional force and a potent adversary of Israel.
lead_paragraph: Hassan Nasrallah, who led the militant Hezbollah organization in Lebanon for more than three decades and built it into a domestic political force and potent regional military power with ballistic missiles that could threaten Tel Aviv, was killed on Friday in heavy Israeli airstrikes just south of Beirut. He was 64.

headline: A Decimated Hezbollah Is a Serious Blow to Iran
abstract: How Iran responds to the death of the Lebanese militia’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, in an Israeli airstrike will affect the region, and beyond.
lead_paragraph: The death of the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah in an airstrike has dramatically weakened a key Iranian deterrent against its archenemy, Israel.

headline: Amadou Mahtar M’Bow, 103, Dies; His Tenure Leading UNESCO Was Stormy
abstract: He was the first Black African to head a major international organization, but complaints about his administration led the U.S. and Britain to pull out of it.
lead_paragraph: Amadou Mahtar M’Bow, a Senegalese civil servant and politician who became the first Black African to head a major international organization when he was elected director general of UNESCO — but whose contested tenure there led the United States and Britain to pull out — died on Tuesday in Dakar, Senegal. He was 103.

headline: Yes, You Can Swim in Louboutins
abstract: Christian Louboutin enlisted the French Olympic synchronized swimming team to introduce his new Miss Z stilettos at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Christian Louboutin made a splash at Paris Fashion Week on Friday night when he staged “Paris is Louboutining,” a synchronized swimming spectacle at the Piscine Molitor.

headline: At Least 104 Die as Monsoon Rains Inundate Nepal
abstract: Disasters in the small Himalayan nation have become more frequent as the effects of climate change intensify.
lead_paragraph: At least 104 people have died in Nepal, the authorities said, after three days of incessant monsoon rains unleashed flooding and landslides across the small Himalayan nation, which has been increasingly pummeled by the effects of climate change. In addition, at least 73 people have been injured, and 64 are still missing, the Nepal Police said. Most of the deaths were reported on Saturday.

headline: Go Ahead, Gild That Lily
abstract: Andy Baraghani’s tahini apple tart sparkles. No, really: The sesame seeds and sugar on the crust give it real luster (and crunch).
lead_paragraph: I can’t resist a flourish. I’ve never once abided by that “remove one thing before you leave the house” rule — why would I take off something I paid money for and love? This shows up in my cooking as well: Rice always gets a shower of furikake, salads always get croutons, chili always gets a thatched blanket of shredded Cheddar (and scallions and sour cream and fried onions and hot sauce). Some might call it an inability to leave well enough alone. I call it living a little.

headline: One Senator’s Vision for Supreme Court Accountability
abstract: One senator’s vision for Supreme Court accountability.
lead_paragraph: Longtime readers of this newsletter will know that I am a strong advocate of Supreme Court reform. The court, as I’ve argued many times, exists within the constitutional system and not outside it. It does not have the sole power to interpret the Constitution, and it is subject to congressional regulation.

headline: Vance Appears at Event of Evangelical Leader Who Spoke of Harris’s ‘Witchcraft’
abstract: Senator JD Vance of Ohio campaigned in Pennsylvania at an event organized by Lance Wallnau, who described Vice President Kamala Harris’s debate performance as “witchcraft.”
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio campaigned Saturday in Pennsylvania at an event organized by Lance Wallnau, a self-described prophet who has said that former President Donald J. Trump was chosen by God, defended the Jan. 6 attack and described Vice President Kamala Harris’s debate performance as “witchcraft.”

headline: Strike on Hezbollah Deepens Disconnect Between Biden and Netanyahu
abstract: Israeli officials gave their American counterparts no advance warning of the strike that killed Hassan Nasrallah, the longtime leader of Hezbollah, according to U.S. officials. But Mr. Biden said the killing was “a measure of justice” for victims of Hezbollah terrorism.
lead_paragraph: No one inside the White House was crying for Hassan Nasrallah on Saturday. But the Israeli strike that killed Mr. Nasrallah, the longtime leader of Hezbollah, once again deepened tensions between President Biden’s administration and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.

headline: ‘This Is a Disaster’: Western North Carolina Reels From Helene
abstract: Hundreds of roads were blocked across the region, which includes Asheville. Officials warned of more mudslides and damage to come.
lead_paragraph: Abandoned vehicles caked with mud. Mountainous rural roads and slices of highways washed away into rivers. Parking lots filled with people desperately searching for cellphone service, trying to tell relatives and friends they are OK — or wanting to find out who is not.

headline: Can Hezbollah Recover From the Death of Its Most Commanding Leader?
abstract: Hassan Nasrallah’s killing raises questions about whether the group can strike back at Israel. But U.S. officials say it’s too soon to count the group out.
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, he was the face and brain of Hezbollah.

headline: Bill Lucy, Pioneering Labor and Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 90
abstract: He helped popularize “I Am a Man” as a demand for respect during the 1968 strike by Black sanitation workers in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: Bill Lucy, a trailblazing Black union leader who fought for civil rights in the American South and against apartheid in South Africa, and who pressured organized labor to address concerns about equal treatment for minority groups, died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 90.

headline: Antônio Delfim Netto, Brazilian Economic Czar, Dies at 96
abstract: He was credited for the high-growth economy during the early years of Brazil’s long military dictatorship. But critics said his policies brought only short-lived gains.
lead_paragraph: Antônio Delfim Netto, the Brazilian finance minister who was credited for the high-growth economy known as the “Brazilian miracle” during the early years of the country’s 21-year military dictatorship, but then excoriated for the hyperinflation and recession that followed, died on Aug. 12 in São Paulo. He was 96.

headline: Protesters Mourn Nasrallah’s Death Around the World
abstract: Protesters gathered on Saturday not only in Lebanon, but also in Iran, in the West Bank and elsewhere to mourn his assassination.
lead_paragraph: Protests took place on Saturday in multiple countries mourning the assassination of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant organization Hezbollah.

headline: Tracking Typhoon Krathon
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Krathon.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Krathon.

headline: Here Is Who Remains in Hezbollah’s Leadership
abstract: Israel has recently killed several commanders of the Lebanese militia, including its longtime leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia, has sustained blow after blow over the past few weeks, as Israeli strikes killed several of the group’s longtime military and political leaders.

headline: 2,000-Pound Bombs Likely Used in Attack That Killed Nasrallah, Video Shows
abstract: A Times analysis of video from the Israeli military shows that at least eight planes it said were used in the attack on Hassan Nasrallah were armed with bunker-buster bombs.
lead_paragraph: A video published by the Israeli military showed that planes it said were used in the attack that killed Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, on Friday night carried 2,000-pound bombs, according to munitions experts and a New York Times analysis.

headline: Shock and Uncertainty in Beirut After Nasrallah’s Death
abstract: Israel’s killing of Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was a stunning escalation of the country’s campaign against the Iran-backed group.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s killing of Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was a stunning escalation of the country’s campaign against the Iran-backed group.

headline: Patient Exposed to Bat in Minnesota Dies From Rabies, Officials Say
abstract: The death, which was reported on Friday, is only the fifth fatal human rabies case in Minnesota since 1975, health officials said.
lead_paragraph: A patient who was exposed to a bat in western Minnesota this year died from rabies this week, becoming the fifth person since 1975 to die from the treatable disease in the state, health officials said on Friday.

headline: As Hezbollah Threat Loomed, Israel Built Up Its Spy Agencies
abstract: After the 2006 war with Hezbollah, Israel invested heavily to intercept the group’s communications and track its commanders in a shadowy war that ultimately led to the killing of the group’s leader.
lead_paragraph: In the immediate days after the deadly Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel, Israeli intelligence officials feared a pre-emptive strike was imminent from another longtime enemy, Hezbollah. They frantically prepared to stop it with plans to strike and kill Hassan Nasrallah, the powerful Hezbollah leader who the Israelis knew would be in a bunker in Beirut.

headline: The Ayes Have It
abstract: Joe Deeney’s puzzle passes unanimously.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Who Was Hassan Nasrallah, Leader of Hezbollah?
abstract: The leader of the militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed by an Israeli airstrike in Lebanon on Friday. Neil MacFarquhar, a reporter for The New York Times who met and interviewed Nasrallah in 2002, explains who he was and the significance of his death.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed by an Israeli airstrike in Lebanon on Friday. Neil MacFarquhar, a reporter for The New York Times who met and interviewed Nasrallah in 2002, explains who he was and the significance of his death.

headline: Killing of Nasrallah Pushes Mideast Conflict Into New Territory
abstract: His death is a blow to Hezbollah, the militia force and Iranian proxy he led. Whether it will cripple the group, or fuel another cycle of retribution, remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia, on Saturday confirmed the death of Hassan Nasrallah, its longtime leader, in a strike marking a major escalation of Israel’s campaign against Iran’s proxies in the Middle East.

headline: Newsom Vetoes Bill Requiring Cars to Warn Speeding Drivers
abstract: The legislation would have made California the first state in the nation to require intelligent speed assistance technology in vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Saturday vetoed California legislation that would have mandated that all new cars in the state have a system that alerts drivers when they exceed the speed limit by more than 10 miles per hour.

headline: More Than 400 Roads Closed in North Carolina After Damage From Helene
abstract: The closures, including on two interstates, left motorists scrambling for options.
lead_paragraph: In addition to the power outages caused by Helene that have crippled the western part of North Carolina, swaths of roadways in the region were largely impassable on Saturday, prompting alerts from transportation officials that warned drivers to stay out of their vehicles.

headline: Trump’s Answer to Harris’s Border Trip: Calling Her ‘Mentally Disabled’
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump assailed Vice President Kamala Harris in harshly personal terms in what he conceded was “a dark speech.”
lead_paragraph: The day after Vice President Kamala Harris visited the southern border and pledged to crack down on asylum and beef up security, former President Donald J. Trump unleashed a string of sharply personal attacks on her at a rally on Saturday, expressing contempt for her intelligence and calling her “mentally disabled.”

headline: Vance Criticizes Ukraine’s President a Day After His Meeting With Trump
abstract: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate, criticized President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine during a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: A day after former President Donald J. Trump met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, criticized the Ukrainian president Saturday during a campaign stop in Pennsylvania.

headline: Eastern Tennessee Officials Brace Residents for ‘Life Lost’ After Helene
abstract: Though no bodies have been recovered in Unicoi County, authorities say they expect fatalities among about a half-dozen people who remain missing.
lead_paragraph: There has been “life lost” in Tennessee, an emergency official in the state said on Saturday evening, making it the sixth state where people have been killed by Hurricane Helene, which ravaged the Southeast and left more than 50 dead this week.

headline: Corrections: Sept. 28, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 10 about the multilingual singer-songwriter Lhasa de Sela, who will be honored with memorial concerts at Pop Montreal, misstates the title of a Lhasa song. It is “Soon This Space Will Be Too Small,” not “Soon This Place Will Be Too Small.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 29, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 10 about the multilingual singer-songwriter Lhasa de Sela, who will be honored with memorial concerts at Pop Montreal, misstates the title of a Lhasa song. It is “Soon This Space Will Be Too Small,” not “Soon This Place Will Be Too Small.”

headline: Tolerating the Office When It Feels Like High School
abstract: How to stay cordial when your adult colleagues gossip like teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: As Austrians Vote, Far Right Awaits Its Biggest Success
abstract: The Freedom Party has made itself the country’s most popular party, with calls to bar asylum seekers. It is poised to come out on top in parliamentary elections for the first time.
lead_paragraph: He calls himself the “Volkskanzler,” or people’s chancellor, a term associated with the Nazis.

headline: Quote of the Day: From ‘Elegant Oakey’ to Adams, City Has a Long and Colorful History of Scandals
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You were almost required to be corrupt. The systemic corruption was amazing, yet routine.”

headline: Iran’s Leaders Are Vulnerable, Divided and at a Crossroad on Response to Israel
abstract: Leaders in Tehran suggested it would be the Lebanese militia that would strike back at Israel after the killing of Hassan Nasrallah and bombings in Beirut.
lead_paragraph: In the turbulent landscape of the Middle East, Iran’s aging supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, could always rely on the close alliance, unwavering loyalty and deep friendship of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militia Hezbollah.

headline: Hurricane Helene: Mapping More Than 600 Miles of Devastation
abstract: See the devastating path carved out by Hurricane Helene from Florida’s Gulf Coast to Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: See the devastating path carved out by Hurricane Helene from Florida’s Gulf Coast to Tennessee.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Picks Maya Rudolph and Jim Gaffigan to Play Kamala Harris and Tim Walz
abstract: The casting ended months of speculation after President Biden, played on Saturday by Dana Carvey, withdrew from the race. James Austin Johnson continued as Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” dug deep into its contact list of celebrity alumni and friends in the comedy world as it kicked off its 50th season with an opening sketch that featured Maya Rudolph’s anticipated return as Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Why I Write My Own Obituary Every Year
abstract: It’s not as maudlin as it might seem. If you take a few minutes to try it, you might find the same.
lead_paragraph: I wrote my obituary last week. I often do so once a year; it has become a kind of ritual.

headline: A Scrappy Downtown Radio Station Returns From the Dead, Again
abstract: Frank Prisinzano and Jorge Parreira have resurrected East Village Radio, an underground institution, after shuttering it roughly a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: Frank Prisinzano has had to mourn the loss of East Village Radio twice over the past 20 years. But ever since it shuttered the second time, in 2014, he has aimed to resurrect it.

headline: Students Paid Thousands for a Caltech Boot Camp. Caltech Didn’t Teach It.
abstract: Hundreds of universities have lent their names to online programs, plugging budgets but alienating students who feel misled.
lead_paragraph: Raymond Sewer said he had good reason to believe that the California Institute of Technology would be deeply involved in the cloud computing “boot camp.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘I Was at a Business Lunch at a Well-Regarded Restaurant’
abstract: A question before ordering, a children’s oasis in Bay Ridge and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Meet the Star of Sushi-Con: A 400-Pound Tuna
abstract: At an all-you-can-eat Japanese food expo in Manhattan, thousands lined up to witness the ceremonial carving of an enormous bluefin tuna — and try a sample.
lead_paragraph: “It’s coming! It’s coming!” someone yelled. It was before dawn on a recent Sunday, and a dozen men in matching navy-blue T-shirts were waiting by a loading dock in Manhattan for the headliner of Sushi-Con, which bills itself as the largest expo of Japanese cuisine in the United States.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 477
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Sept. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Grieving Mother. A Famous Uncle. An Unlikely Crusade.
abstract: Tragedy turned Nadia Milleron, Ralph Nader’s niece, into an activist. Now she’s on a long-shot campaign for Congress.
lead_paragraph: Nadia Milleron, an independent candidate for Congress, slipped off her shoes and climbed onto the bench of a picnic table. It was a muggy August evening, and gnats and mosquitoes were swarming the 50 or so people who had gathered for a campaign event in the garden behind a pizzeria in western Massachusetts.

headline: In Adams Indictment, Legal Experts See Strengths, Potential Pitfalls
abstract: Prosecutors pursuing corruption charges against Mayor Eric Adams appear to have some solid evidence, but winning a conviction is far from a given, experts say.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a year, federal prosecutors have closed in on Mayor Eric Adams of New York, seizing his phones and searching the homes of his aides in moves that suggested they might take the extraordinary step of charging him while he still held office.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Recap: Maya Rudolph Returns to Play Kamala Harris
abstract: The 50th season began with several surprise guests and alumni — including Dana Carvey, Jim Gaffigan and Andy Samberg — playing figures in the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” dug deep into its contact list of celebrity alumni and friends in the comedy world as it kicked off its 50th season with an opening sketch that featured Maya Rudolph’s anticipated return as Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: What to Wear Next
abstract: A brilliant Loewe collection, some good ideas from Courrèges and Junya Watanabe, and a step forward at Alexander McQueen.
lead_paragraph: Finally, a new look.

headline: Studying at an English-Speaking University? In Quebec, That May Cost Extra.
abstract: Quebec says a new policy to charge some students higher tuition at top universities in Montreal is needed to preserve the province’s French identity.
lead_paragraph: Quebec is working hard to fortify its official language — much to the displeasure of some who don’t speak it.

headline: The Black Church Has a Gen-Z Issue: ‘They Don’t Come Into the Building Anymore’
abstract: These congregations are struggling to attract younger members. That has consequences for social cohesion and Black political power writ large.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning, about 100 worshipers gathered for services at Mother Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.

headline: They Have a Sacred Pact With a Bog. It Might Be a Curse.
abstract: In “The Bog Wife,” a West Virginia family must reckon with secrets, betrayals and the destruction of their legacy when a supernatural covenant that protected them begins to falter.
lead_paragraph: Much like its main characters, Kay Chronister’s new novel, “The Bog Wife,” lives in two worlds at once. It’s situated both in the real world, with fraught familial and marital relationships, complex social dynamics and crucial activities like paying bills and pre-emptively felling dangerous trees, as well as in a dreamy Southern gothic world filled with ancient magic, supernatural compacts and, potentially, murder.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates on Why Not Everyone Will Love His New Book
abstract: In “The Message,” Coates grapples with questions about which stories are told, and how, through his visits to Senegal, South Carolina and the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s breakthrough memoir, “Between the World and Me,” made an immediate impact when it was published in 2015, at the fraught tail end of the Obama era, and catapulted the Baltimore-born writer to prominence in the public conversation on race. “I’ve been wondering who might fill the intellectual void that plagued me after James Baldwin died,” Toni Morrison declared. “Clearly it is Ta-Nehisi Coates.”

headline: Is Malcolm Gladwell Out of Ideas?
abstract: In “Revenge of the Tipping Point,” the best-selling author looks back at his old theories.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Gladwell could have written a fresh book. Instead, he created a brand extension of his 2000 hit, “The Tipping Point.”

headline: The Forgotten Dealer Who Discovered Picasso and Matisse
abstract: A show at the Grey Art Museum re-establishes Berthe Weill as a guiding light of the Parisian avant-garde. Her rediscovery has been led by women.
lead_paragraph: “A collection of paintings isn’t like a stock portfolio,” the Parisian art dealer Berthe Weill declared in her 1933 memoir, “Pow! Right in the Eye!” She was lamenting that novice collectors of the era were overly concerned about whether the value of her emerging artists would rise. “I was afraid they had neither confidence nor perseverance,” she wrote.

headline: Opera Is Still Obsessed With the Suffering of Women
abstract: Two new works, “The Listeners” and “Grounded,” echo the age-old spectacle of female disintegration and show the tension of fitting modern stories into old forms.
lead_paragraph: Opera’s job is to show us what’s bigger, wilder and more intense than ordinary life. It’s a terrarium in which we watch a condensed version of ourselves, with more ecstatic loves and more savage suffering.

headline: Stellantis, Owner of Chrysler and Jeep, Slashes Profit Forecast
abstract: The automaker, created by a 2021 merger, is dealing with labor unrest, slumping sales and a revolt from its dealers.
lead_paragraph: Stellantis, an automotive colossus that owns more than a dozen brands including Chrysler, Fiat, Jeep, Peugeot and Ram, is facing challenges at seemingly every turn.

headline: Sean Combs’s White Parties Were Edgy, A-List Affairs. Were They More?
abstract: The events helped the music mogul raise his profile. But one woman who worked at them has said in court papers that the parties had a dark side, too.
lead_paragraph: In the 2000s, few events held the cultural cachet of the White Party thrown by Sean Combs — fetes in Beverly Hills, the Hamptons and other playgrounds of the rich, studded with famous names and fabulous tableaus.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates Returns to the Political Fray, Calling Out Injustice
abstract: “The Message” marks his re-entry as a public intellectual determined to wield his moral authority, especially regarding Israel and the occupied territories.
lead_paragraph: Ta-Nehisi Coates has returned to the fray. In 2017, after getting into a public dust-up with Cornel West, who accused him of being in thrall to a “neoliberal establishment,” Coates, declaring he “didn’t get in it for this,” summarily deleted his Twitter account. A year later, he left his longtime post as a staff writer at The Atlantic. He spent the next several years far from the combative world of intellectual celebrity and immersed in his own creative projects: writing comics, publishing a novel and working on Hollywood scripts.

headline: Partying With Sean Combs: Old Stories Gain New Life
abstract: For decades, Combs and other celebrities have commented on his party lifestyle. Here’s some of what they have publicly said.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, when Sean Combs — also known as Diddy or Puff Daddy — hosted the MTV Video Music Awards, the network advertised the broadcast with a playful star-studded spoof called “Diddy Parties,” in which the events he hosted were referred to as “hedonistic romps.”

headline: Trump Allies Bombard the Courts, Setting Stage for Post-Election Fight
abstract: Republicans are filing a barrage of election lawsuits in the final weeks of the presidential campaign. The cases may be a road map for a legal battle over the results.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have unleashed a flurry of lawsuits challenging voting rules and practices ahead of the November elections, setting the stage for what could be a far larger and more contentious legal battle over the White House after Election Day.

headline: Donald Trump and His Real-Life Apprentice
abstract: The former president views JD Vance as a kindred political spirit, while Mr. Vance has spoken of Mr. Trump as a kind of father figure.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance has driven some of the most attention-grabbing story lines of the 2024 presidential election, encroaching on the precious spotlight that his running mate, Donald J. Trump, has long kept for himself.

headline: A ‘Perfect’ Take on Nantucket Style?
abstract: Scrutinizing the costumes in Netflix’s “The Perfect Couple.”
lead_paragraph: “It’s not a documentary,” said Signe Sejlund, the costume designer for the Netflix limited series “The Perfect Couple.” “It’s a murder mystery.”

headline: The Border in the Campaign and in Real Life
abstract: What do some people who live on the border make of the shifting politics in the battle over their backyard? Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” talked with a group in El Paso, mostly Democrats, and compared what they said and what Americans overall say in polls.
lead_paragraph: What do some people who live on the border make of the shifting politics in the battle over their backyard? Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” talked with a group in El Paso, mostly Democrats, and compared what they said and what Americans overall say in polls.

headline: Have We Gotten Aubrey Plaza Wrong This Whole Time?
abstract: Don’t let her deadpan sense of humor fool you. In projects like Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis,” she puts everything she has on the line.
lead_paragraph: “I bleed for movies,” Aubrey Plaza told me on an August morning, just seconds before the ground began to tremble.

headline: Five Court Cases to Watch Ahead of Election Day
abstract: A blizzard of voting lawsuits are landing in swing states in the final weeks before the election. Here’s a guide to the cases that could matter most.
lead_paragraph: While Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris enter into the final weeks of the presidential campaign, their lawyers are in a final push, too.

headline: Beneath the Potential Strike at U.S. Ports: Tensions Over Innovation
abstract: Port operators have long embraced automation, while dockworkers view it as a threat to their livelihoods.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the centuries, as ships have navigated oceans bearing all manner of freight, the companies that operate ports have pressed to limit what they spend on the people who load and unload cargo.

headline: Coppola’s ‘Megalopolis’ Plays to Near-Empty Theaters
abstract: Francis Ford Coppola spent roughly $140 million on the film, which debuted to an estimated $4 million in weekend ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: There is no kind way to put it: Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis” died on arrival over the weekend.

headline: What We Know About Hurricane Helene’s Destruction So Far
abstract: After hitting Florida’s Gulf Coast, Helene tore through the Southeast and particularly ravaged western North Carolina with floods and mudslides. The overall death toll rose to more than 100.
lead_paragraph: After making landfall as a Category 4 hurricane and tearing through the Gulf Coast of Florida and parts of Georgia last week, Helene left large parts of North Carolina in a state of paralysis over the weekend, washing out roads, causing landslides and knocking out power and cell service for millions.

headline: The Novelist Who Foresaw the ‘Big One’ for Florida’s Gulf Coast
abstract: John D. MacDonald was eerily prescient about the risks of human-driven climate disasters in the region.
lead_paragraph: When I learned early Friday morning that Cedar Key, Fla., had been flattened overnight by Hurricane Helene, one of the first things that came to my mind was a song lyric by Jimmy Buffett — early Buffett, before he became a walking tourist attraction. One of his better songs is “Incommunicado,” released in 1981. It begins: “Travis McGee’s still in Cedar Key/That’s what old John MacDonald said.”

headline: Why the World’s Biggest Powers Can’t Stop a Middle East War
abstract: The United States’ ability to influence events in the Mideast has waned, and other major nations have essentially been onlookers.
lead_paragraph: Over almost a year of war in the Middle East, major powers have proved incapable of stopping or even significantly influencing the fighting, a failure that reflects a turbulent world of decentralized authority that seems likely to endure.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,199
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Question Kamala Harris Needs to Answer to Beat Donald Trump
abstract: She has prosecuted the case against Donald Trump and clarified some policy views, but not her why. That’s what voters want to know.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris is at the halfway point between when she officially became the Democratic presidential nominee and Election Day. Her ascent has been remarkable. She is beating Donald Trump in most national polls and is in statistical dead heats in every battleground state.

headline: There’s a Dangerous Misconception About the Military’s Obligations to the President
abstract: The prospect of a second Trump administration has rekindled an important debate from four years ago.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of a second Trump administration has rekindled a debate from four years ago about the proper role of the military in our democracy.

headline: Laws Need to Catch Up to Artificial Intelligence’s Unique Risks
abstract: Artificial intelligence poses unique risks, so the people warning us of safety threats deserve unique protections.
lead_paragraph: For about five years, OpenAI used a system of nondisclosure agreements to stifle public criticism from outgoing employees. Current and former OpenAI staffers were paranoid about talking to the press. In May, one departing employee refused to sign and went public in The Times. The company apologized and scrapped the agreements. Then the floodgates opened. Exiting employees began criticizing OpenAI’s safety practices, and a wave of articles emerged about its broken promises.

headline: Iran Is Losing. That May Matter More Than Israel’s Mistakes.
abstract: Military success rarely brings true peace, but it can preserve societies.
lead_paragraph: Military defeats matter. Israel’s inexcusable complacency on Oct. 7, 2023, allowed Hamas, a terrorist force with a small fraction of the military strength of the Israel Defense Forces, to kill more Israeli civilians than the vast armies of Egypt and Syria and their allies did at the height of the Arab-Israeli wars of 1967 and 1973.

headline: Netanyahu, Ignoring Allies and Defying Critics, Basks in a Rare Triumph
abstract: Israel’s strike on Hassan Nasrallah was the culmination of several startling moves that suggest the Israeli prime minister feels unconstrained by foreign criticism.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Netanyahu’s decision to assassinate Hassan Nasrallah, the Hezbollah leader, capped an increasingly brazen sequence of escalatory moves that reflected the Israeli prime minister’s renewed confidence in Israel’s military strength as well as in his own ability to navigate and defy foreign criticism, analysts said.

headline: Inside the Sally Rooney Fan Base
abstract: We explore some of the most passionate fans in literature.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, a crowd of mostly young women, many carrying bookstore tote bags, filled a venue on the bank of the River Thames. They — we — were there to hear the Irish novelist Sally Rooney discuss “Intermezzo,” her latest novel.

headline: Lie-Flat Seats and Chilled Champagne: Testing Eric Adams’s Upgrade Life
abstract: The New York mayor is accused of accepting free luxury travel in exchange for political favors. How large was he living? A writer puts the experience to the test.
lead_paragraph: Life is grand in the Bentley Suite at the St. Regis Istanbul, with its marble floors and walk-in closet, its 24-hour butler service, and its views stretching all the way to the blue waters of the Bosporus.

headline: I Grew Up Much Like JD Vance. How Did We End Up So Different?
abstract: The vice-presidential nominee should be thinking of how to extend a ladder to those he left behind, not how to pull it up behind him.
lead_paragraph: I hail from western Ohio, not far from JD Vance’s hometown, Middletown. Like him, I grew up in a family marred by addiction, with a grandmother who was also my rock.

headline: California Passes Law Protecting Consumer Brain Data
abstract: The state extended its current personal privacy law to include the neural data increasingly coveted by technology companies.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Governor Gavin Newsom of California signed a new law that aims to protect people’s brain data from being potentially misused by neurotechnology companies.

headline: Five People Dead in Plane Crash Near Wright Brothers Memorial
abstract: A single-engine plane was trying to land when it crashed into a wooded area near the memorial in North Carolina on Saturday, the National Park Service said.
lead_paragraph: Five people were killed after a small plane crashed at an airport in North Carolina on Saturday near the Wright Brothers National Memorial in Kill Devil Hills, the National Park Service said.

headline: Sticky Guava Ribs for Any Season
abstract: Kia Damon’s recipe is an easy oven-baked barbecue situation that leads to tender meat and a caramelized bark that’s sweet and salty.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’d cook outside every night if I could, working grills and planchas and pizza ovens and smokers into the depths of winter, against all elements. I know I’m not alone in that desire. But I know too that the numbers don’t add up to even a plurality. I’m in a faction: the brazier caucus.

headline: Rape Cases in the Headlines and in Our Everyday Lives
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay about famous cases and offer personal stories. Also: Helping immigrants; A.I. at war; Donald Trump, TV and real life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Top Adams Aides Get Married as Investigation Swirls Around Them
abstract: Eric Adams’s schools chancellor and first deputy mayor married in Martha’s Vineyard this weekend. Both have had their phones seized by federal investigators.
lead_paragraph: At a wedding in Martha’s Vineyard, key players in City Hall sought refuge this weekend from the several federal investigations plaguing Mayor Eric Adams’s administration.

headline: A Capsule of the Past, a Vessel for the Future
abstract: In 1999, The Times Magazine commissioned a time capsule to be opened at the next millennium. It has been hidden from public view since 2018.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the new millennium, in 1999, The New York Times Magazine commissioned the celebrated architect Santiago Calatrava to design a time capsule.

headline: Nepal Flooding and Landslides Kill at Least 190 People
abstract: The mountainous country is experiencing more extreme weather driven by climate change, including melting glaciers that add to the frequency and severity of flooding.
lead_paragraph: Police say 193 people have died in Nepal after days of unceasing rain caused heavy flooding and triggered major landslides around the country, including in the densely populated region around Kathmandu, the   capital.

headline: On Sports Podcast, Harris Will Discuss Race and Police Brutality
abstract: A nearly hourlong conversation on “All the Smoke” could help Vice President Kamala Harris reach Black men in the closing weeks of her presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will discuss racial identity, police brutality and more Monday on the sports and pop culture podcast “All the Smoke,” which is hosted by two retired N.B.A. players.

headline: In North Carolina, Remnants of Helene Become an ‘Unprecedented Tragedy’
abstract: Thousands of people struggled to cope without basic necessities as authorities searched for the missing, and the overall death toll from the storm surpassed 100.

headline: Republicans Criticize Trump Over His Insults of Harris
abstract: Several Republicans distanced themselves from their party’s standard-bearer after he called Vice President Kamala Harris “mentally disabled.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump drew criticism from several fellow Republicans on Sunday for his demeaning insults of Vice President Kamala Harris, a day after he called her “mentally disabled” and “mentally impaired” at a rally.

headline: Kylie Jenner and Ayo Edebiri Toast a Starry Crowd at Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Actors, designers and musicians turned out at a party to celebrate the Business of Fashion’s annual index of industry leaders.
lead_paragraph: After a cold and dreary week in Paris, the sun finally broke through on Saturday morning, just in time for the tail end of Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Israel Strikes the Houthis, an Iranian Ally, in Yemen
abstract: The strike on power stations and a seaport, which killed four people, was the second known time that Israel has retaliated against the militant group’s attacks by striking in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military conducted airstrikes in Yemen on Sunday after Iranian-backed Houthis there fired three missiles at Israel over the past couple of weeks.

headline: What This Israel-Hezbollah-Hamas-Iran Conflict Is Really About
abstract: The devastating blow to Hezbollah by Israel has a place in the global struggle between the “coalition of inclusion” and “coalition of resistance.” It could be the keystone.
lead_paragraph: To understand why and how Israel’s devastating blow to Hezbollah is such a world-shaking threat to Iran, Russia, North Korea and even China, you have to put it in the context of the wider struggle that has replaced the Cold War as the framework of international relations today.

headline: Drake Hogestyn, ‘Days of Our Lives’ Actor, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Hogestyn was best known for playing John Black on the daytime soap opera and appeared in more than 4,200 episodes over 38 years.
lead_paragraph: Drake Hogestyn, who played John Black, the sturdy and fiercely loyal character who by turns was a spy, private investigator and mercenary, for nearly 40 years on the long-running soap opera “Days of Our Lives,” died on Saturday, a day shy of his 71st birthday.

headline: Netanyahu Opponent, in Reversal, Is Joining Israeli Government
abstract: The addition of Gideon Saar to Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition strengthens the prime minister’s political position.
lead_paragraph: Gideon Saar, a member of Israel’s opposition, announced on Sunday that he would be joining Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government, giving the Israeli leader’s fragile coalition an added layer of support.

headline: California Governor Vetoes Sweeping A.I. Legislation
abstract: The bill would have been the first in the nation to place strict guardrails on the new technology, but Gov. Gavin Newsom said the bill was flawed.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sunday vetoed a California artificial intelligence safety bill, blocking the most ambitious proposal in the nation aimed at curtailing the growth of the new technology.

headline: Monday Briefing: The Aftermath of Nasrallah’s Death
abstract: Plus, we retraced one of Mayor Eric Adams’s lavish trips to Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed on Friday near Beirut, Lebanon, in an attack that Israel’s military said had hit the militia’s headquarters. Nasrallah was a beacon for anti-Israel forces across the Middle East and beyond, and his death is a major blow to Hezbollah.

headline: Plume From Chemical Plant Prompts Evacuation of 17,000 People
abstract: A fire in the plant near Atlanta caused water to interact with a chemical that set off the plume. A shelter-in-place order was extended Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: A billowing plume from a chemical plant in Conyers, Ga., on Sunday prompted an evacuation order that affected about 17,000 people and a shelter-in-place order for 77,000 more residents that was extended Monday morning, officials said.

headline: Far Right Wins Austrian Vote but May Fall Short of Forming a Government
abstract: The Freedom Party got nearly 30 percent of the national vote, but mainstream parties have vowed to join in a coalition government without the party’s pugilistic leader, Herbert Kickl.
lead_paragraph: Austrian voters handed the Freedom Party of Austria a solid win in national elections on Sunday, rebuking establishment parties and notching another victory for a xenophobic party in Europe as the tide of far-right populism rises on the continent.

headline: Israel Strikes Multiple Fronts, Including Long-Distance Attack on Yemen
abstract: The escalation of violence between Israel and Iran-backed proxies across the Middle East threatened to bring the combatants closer to an all-out regional war.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military on Sunday attacked its enemies in two countries and Gaza, including with a long-distance airstrike in Yemen amid escalating violence between Israel and Iranian-backed proxies across the Middle East, inching the combatants closer to an all-out regional war.

headline: Helene Has Killed More Than 110 People. Here Are Some of Their Stories.
abstract: After the Category 4 hurricane made landfall on Florida’s Gulf Coast and pummeled the Southeast, some victims’ portraits were coming into focus.
lead_paragraph: A woman in her 70s who repaired nuclear cooling towers and rode motorcycles. A Florida resident who helped her community recover from Hurricane Ian two years ago. A man who had just moved to South Carolina to work as an electrical lineman.

headline: Kris Kristofferson, Country Singer, Songwriter and Actor, Dies at 88
abstract: He wrote songs for hundreds of other artists, including “Me and Bobby McGee” for Janis Joplin and “Sunday Morning Coming Down” for Johnny Cash, before a second act in film.
lead_paragraph: Kris Kristofferson, the singer and songwriter whose literary yet plain-spoken compositions infused country music with rarely heard candor and depth, and who later had a successful second career in movies, died on Saturday at his home on Maui, Hawaii. He was 88.

headline: Trump Says He’s in Danger. So Why Did He Seek Out the Embrace of 100,000 Fans?
abstract: After two assassination attempts, the former president seems to be relishing the dangers of his job. Some at the Georgia-Alabama football game wondered if his appearance was wise.
lead_paragraph: Chicken tenders and cynicism were flying through the air.

headline: After Harris Calls for a Crackdown on Fentanyl, Trump Twists Her Position
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris vowed to combat the flow of fentanyl into the country when she visited the border on Friday. Former President Donald J. Trump ratcheted up his false claims in response.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris visited the southern border on Friday, she called fentanyl a “scourge on our country” and said that as president she would “make it a top priority to disrupt the flow of fentanyl coming into the United States.”

headline: John Ashton, ‘Beverly Hills Cop’ Actor, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Ashton was most widely recognized for his role as Sgt. John Taggart in the “Beverly Hills Cop” franchise.
lead_paragraph: John Ashton, the actor best known for his role as the gruff Sgt. John Taggart in the “Beverly Hills Cop” franchise, died on Thursday in Fort Collins, Colo. He was 76.

headline: No Corrections: Sept. 30, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Stocks in Japan Tumble After Party’s Election of New Prime Minister
abstract: Stocks dropped after Japan’s governing party chose Shigeru Ishiba, a critic of the country’s longstanding ultralow interest rates, as its leader.
lead_paragraph: Stocks in Japan fell sharply on Monday after the country’s governing party chose a leader some view as hawkish on interest rates, underlining how central bank decisions continue to set the course of the world’s fourth-largest economy after decades of easy money policy.

headline: Beirut Building Damaged in Strike
abstract: Footage showed emergency personnel responding to the strike on the Cola neighborhood of Beirut, Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Footage showed emergency personnel responding to the strike on the Cola neighborhood of Beirut, Lebanon.

headline: A Blast in Central Beirut Damages a Building
abstract: If the explosion is confirmed to be an Israeli attack, it would be the first Israeli strike within the Lebanese capital since the 2006 war with Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Emergency crews in Beirut were working early Monday in an area of the city where an apparent Israeli strike damaged a residential building, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Review: ‘The Hills of California,’ Alive With the Sound of Music
abstract: In Jez Butterworth’s compelling new play, four girls trained to sing close harmony wind up as acrimonious adults.
lead_paragraph: Two sounds greet you at the start of “The Hills of California,” Jez Butterworth’s relentlessly entertaining new play: the crashing of waves on the beaches of Blackpool and the tinkling of a tinny piano being tuned.

headline: A 180-Year-Old Jewish Paper Is Roiled by Fabrications and a Secret: Who Owns It?
abstract: When several journalists resigned this month from the British newspaper over false news articles, they also raised a broader question about its ownership.
lead_paragraph: For decades, members of Britain’s Jewish population have marked life’s milestones by taking out notices in The Jewish Chronicle, a weekly publication founded in 1841 that bills itself as the world’s oldest Jewish newspaper.

headline: N.Y.C. Tap Water May Taste Different During Upcoming Tunnel Shutdown
abstract: The city has famously delicious drinking water. Forced repairs to the Delaware Aqueduct may lessen its quality.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s tap water — a source of pride for residents — might taste a bit different for a while.

headline: Quote of the Day: After 85 Years, Fixing a Typo The Brontës Would’ve Hated
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Three of our greatest writers, and their names are spelled incorrectly. You can’t make it up.”

headline: Harris Tries to Goad Trump Into Another Debate
abstract: At a rally in Las Vegas, Vice President Kamala Harris played up the vice-presidential debate set for Tuesday and pushed for another face-off with former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris on Sunday tried to taunt former President Donald J. Trump into participating in another debate as she rallied supporters in Nevada.
