abstract: Plus, we retraced one of Mayor Eric Adams’s lavish trips to Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed on Friday near Beirut, Lebanon, in an attack that Israel’s military said had hit the militant group’s headquarters. Nasrallah was a beacon for anti-Israel forces across the Middle East and beyond, and his death is a major blow to Hezbollah.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Real Housewives’ and the Vice-Presidential Debate
abstract: The Bravo franchise will air two different premieres. And on Tuesday is the first debate between JD Vance and Tim Walz.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Sept. 30-Oct. 6. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Britain Is the First Major Economy to Stop Using Coal. It’s a Risky Experiment.
abstract: Few in Britain will mourn the passing of coal, but it’s hard not to feel a little nervous about what, at its heart, is an experiment, one fraught with danger.
lead_paragraph: Over 100 miles north of London, Britain’s last coal-fired power station, the Ratcliffe-on-Soar plant, will be powered down on Monday, ending Britain’s reliance on coal for power. The plant, outside Nottingham, will cease operations permanently.

headline: Chemical Plant in Georgia Emits Thick Cloud of Smoke
abstract: The plume filled the sky in Conyers, Ga., and prompted evacuation orders for thousands.
lead_paragraph: The plume filled the sky in Conyers, Ga., and prompted evacuation orders for thousands.

abstract: This word has appeared in 308 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word seismic has appeared in 308 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 12 in “Earthquake Rattles Coastal Area Near Los Angeles” by Jill Cowan:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: New York’s ‘One-Man Innocence Project’ Is Finally Cleared Himself
abstract: Jon-Adrian Velazquez spent years in Sing Sing for a shooting he did not commit. Along the way, he helped others seek their freedom and became the face of a movement.
lead_paragraph: Jon-Adrian Velazquez is the subject of a new book, a podcast and a coming documentary series.

headline: N.Y.C. Streets Won’t Be Like This Forever (for Better or Worse)
abstract: New York City is constantly changing, opening the door to both new battles over traffic and radical solutions.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: The Verdict on Alessandro Michele’s Valentino
abstract: Major change is in the air, in all sorts of ways.
lead_paragraph: Goodbye Hôtel Salomon de Rothschild, the ornate 19th-century hôtel particulier in the 8th Arrondissement of Paris that for years had played rococo host to the Valentino fashion shows.

headline: Following Norway’s National Painter Through a Landscape of Mountains and Fjords
abstract: Harald Sohlberg is celebrated within his native country and almost unknown outside it. A writer goes in search of the artist’s inspiration in Norway’s ‘overwhelming nature.’
lead_paragraph: People go to Giverny to see the gardens that moved Monet and to Arles for the fields behind van Gogh’s madness. They trek through the Louvre as if by magnetic force, seeking — what else? — the Mona Lisa selfie.

headline: The Only Patriotic Choice for President
abstract: Kamala Harris has demonstrated care, competence and respect for the Constitution — the fundamental qualities necessary for high office.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine a candidate more unworthy to serve as president of the United States than Donald Trump. He has proved himself morally unfit for an office that asks its occupant to put the good of the nation above self-interest. He has proved himself temperamentally unfit for a role that requires the very qualities — wisdom, honesty, empathy, courage, restraint, humility, discipline — that he most lacks.

headline: Vintage Shopping Is Booming. Banana Republic and Others Get In on the Action.
abstract: Last year, apparel resale in the United States grew seven times the rate of the broader retail industry. Independent resellers and corporate giants are getting creative to meet the demand.
lead_paragraph: At her vintage store in Santa Cruz, Calif., Mely Olmeda sells a range of clothing, much of it from the early aughts, including sheer tops, low-rise denim flares and anything with lace or loud prints. She also rents rack space to other vendors, which helps pay the rent and other overhead.

headline: The Secret Art of David Hammons
abstract: Through interviews with some of his colleagues and collaborators — and several rare images — T considers the last half-century of an elusive artist’s practice.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, the artist David Hammons started gathering hair from Black barbershops. In New York, he tacked the strands onto grease-slicked paper bags to make multidimensional collages, topped off with a few bones from barbecue ribs and a sprinkle of glitter. In Los Angeles, he affixed small tufts to pieces of wire and stuck them into the sands of Venice Beach; he let those wash away with the tides. He didn’t care much about making a work that he could sell. Then as now, Hammons wasn’t interested in catering to the art market — or even necessarily speaking to it. Over the course of his approximately 60-year-career, Hammons, 81 and currently based in the New York area, has participated in very few interviews. In a defining one from a 1986 issue of Real Life Magazine with the curator and historian Kellie Jones, he discusses his disdain for traditional galleries. “The rooms are almost always wrong, too much plasterboard, overlit, too shiny and too neat,” he says. “The work should be somewhere in between your house and where you’re going to see it.”

headline: How Two Soul Mates, Separated by War, Found Each Other Again
abstract: Sofia Malina and Polina Muzhychkova met in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, but were separated after it came under brutal assault by Russian forces. They were reunited after a long and harrowing saga.
lead_paragraph: Their love story was only a month old when the Russian Army smashed its way into their home city of Mariupol, in eastern Ukraine, two years ago and tore them apart.

headline: The Happiest Little House of Horrors
abstract: Welcome to the Spruce House in Finland, where macabre jokes about the end of the world are built into a comfortable island cabin.
lead_paragraph: A metal pool ladder is fixed to a wooden veranda outside Jan-Erik Andersson’s house in western Finland. But there is no pool here, and we are 1,000 feet from the sea. The steps to nowhere, says Mr. Andersson, are a provocation, “an artwork to protest about rising waters.”

headline: The Case Kamala Harris Can’t Stop Prosecuting
abstract: Being tougher on so-called frauds, cheaters and financial predators would make the criminal justice system a bit more equal.
lead_paragraph: As Kamala Harris seeks to become the first career prosecutor to win the presidency, she has faced persistent questions: What kind of prosecutor was she? And how would that background shape her presidency? Instead of fitting into the familiar categories, she has been campaigning as another first: the first white-collar-crime prosecutor in chief. Instead of policies to reverse mass incarceration, the signature objective of progressive prosecutors, her approach seems to be for more equal incarceration, a new twist on an old populist economic theme.

headline: The Plan to Save Frank Lloyd Wright’s Only Skyscraper Isn’t Going as Planned
abstract: Less than two years ago, the building was thought to have been rescued from financial woes. Now the new owners have it on the auction block and some Wright-designed furnishings have already been sold.
lead_paragraph: Frank Lloyd Wright’s only realized skyscraper is just 19 stories, but even 70 years after it was built, Price Tower sits higher than most buildings in Bartlesville, Okla., and the view from the top still stretches to the horizon where the rolling prairie starts to take shape.

headline: U.S. Ramps Up Hunt for Uranium to End Reliance on Russia
abstract: Miners aim to meet a growing demand for emissions-free energy, though a failure to clean up old sites haunts the industry.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,400 feet below an Arizona pine forest, miners are blasting tunnels in search of a radioactive element that can be used to make electricity.

headline: 7 Memoirs Therapists Think You Should Read
abstract: Mental health experts on the stories that helped them and their patients through tough times.
lead_paragraph: Walk into any bookstore and you’ll find tables loaded with self-help books for every imaginable problem. But there are times when the wisest advice might be tucked away in the memoir section.

headline: The Magnificently Weird Fiction of Yoko Tawada
abstract: The Japanese author, frequently mentioned as a possible Nobel laureate, has a new novel, the second in her “Scattered All Over the Earth” trilogy.
lead_paragraph: “Suggested in the Stars” is the second in Yoko Tawada’s trilogy of friendship amid climate change dystopia, begun by “Scattered All Over the Earth,” published in English in 2022. The books combine the innocence of The Baby-Sitter’s Club with the Surrealism of Leonora Carrington’s art. They are, simply put, deeply weird. And while the word “weird” has recently had a moment as an insult on the political stage, Tawada’s work reminds us that weirdness is not always a bad thing.

headline: Your Guide to the Gameplay Forums
abstract: We’re giving you a tour of this lovely little corner of the internet — and a behind-the-scenes peek at the decisions that help us maintain it.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who plays games is familiar with the sense of satisfaction that comes with solving a tricky puzzle, but getting validation from other solvers can be just as intoxicating. Wouldn’t it be less fun to solve Wordle in two turns if you couldn’t share your score?

headline: A Good Reason for Rural Rage: The Crushing Power of Corporate Meat
abstract: Highlighting efforts to reduce the power of Big Ag over farmers can be a winning strategy for Harris.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that rural Americans are angry with the Washington elite. Less discussed are some of the sensible reasons for it. For far too long, family farms have been crushed under the monopolistic power of Big Ag. And for decades, politicians from both parties either turned a blind eye to the oligopolies that rule over rural America — or climbed right into bed with them.

headline: The Truth About Tuna
abstract: How much should you worry about mercury in tuna and other seafood? Experts weigh in.
lead_paragraph: Ahi steak. Akami sashimi. Albacore on sourdough. Whether you smoked yellowfin on the grill or spread skipjack on a sandwich, chances are you’ve had tuna recently.

headline: What to Expect if R.F.K. Jr. Is Promoted to a Position of Power
abstract: Giving Mr. Kennedy a top health job would entrench partisanship around public health.
lead_paragraph: Robert Kennedy Jr. reportedly wants to be the secretary of Health and Human Services, or a similarly powerful health position in a Trump White House. Mr. Kennedy claims he’s been promised influence over the two issues he is most eager to address: federal agency corruption and chronic disease. “I’m going to be deeply involved in helping to choose the people who can run F.D.A. and N.I.H. and C.D.C.,” he told Tucker Carlson on a recent panel.

headline: The Power of Saying No
abstract: T looks at some of contemporary art’s genuine iconoclasts — celebrated recluses and others who’ve managed to create an alternate way of being a creative person in a world that sometimes scoffs at privacy.
lead_paragraph: There’s a common misconception about the art business that states that, within the industry, there are essentially no rules. True, it’s a vast and murky marketplace with few regulations, but to succeed as an artist within it has often meant, for many, following quite a number of rules. Chief among them is showing up. There are exhibition openings and lunches and galas; there are cocktail hours and auctions and vernissages; there are V.I.P. previews and panels and dinners that last the length of a Frederick Wiseman documentary.

headline: $4.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Georgian Revival house in San Francisco, a contemporary home in Los Angeles and a house near the ocean in Long Beach.
lead_paragraph: This house is half a block from Golden Gate Park, a five-minute walk from the park’s rose garden and a 10-minute walk from the California Academy of Sciences. It is also within walking distance of a Russian bakery, several coffee shops and a playground. China Beach, which has a tide pool and sweeping views of the Golden Gate Bridge, is 10 minutes away by car.

headline: Does High School Need to Be Less Demanding?
abstract: A high school teacher says students “need to do less so that they can do better.” Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: We often hear from students about how their schedules are overloaded — they have too much homework, and they’re running from one extracurricular activity, sport or volunteer project to another. As a result, they don’t sleep enough or spend enough time with their friends and families.

headline: Trump’s Volunteers: ‘Beautiful Ladies’ From a Secretive Evangelical Church
abstract: Women from an insular North Carolina church — with a history of “blasting” members judged sinners — are helping to stage the former president’s campaign events.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has gruesome rhetorical staples he likes to deploy at his political rallies, including homicidal sharks, bird-killing windmills and Hannibal Lecter. Amid the litany, one less morbid aside tends to escape notice.

headline: His Mother’s Murder Woke Him Up From a ‘Political Coma’
abstract: The son of a peace activist brutally killed on Oct. 7 is determined to make sure that her dream for Israel does not die with her.
lead_paragraph: The day Vivian Silver’s home burned, her backyard was scattered with her grandchildren’s toys, a blue plastic boat upturned near a rubber duck. Vivian often spent days preparing for their visits, planning trips to the petting zoo and baking birthday cakes molded into the shape of a Barbie or a dinosaur. Her sons, Yonatan and Chen Zeigen, reminded her that she didn’t need to do so much, but Vivian measured her life by the way she made other people feel. The boys teased their mother: As a self-declared no-nonsense feminist, a renowned Israeli peace activist who was used to the sound of mortar fire, how had she stayed so soft?

headline: The Mexican Novelist Who Found Himself in New Orleans
abstract: Much of Yuri Herrera’s work has focused on Mexican social realities. In “Season of the Swamp” he turns his attention to the uniquely American city that has been his home for 13 years.
lead_paragraph: There’s an argument to be made that New Orleans is as much a part of Yuri Herrera as the cities in Mexico that raised him. He’s lived here for 13 years. It’s where he met his wife and adopted two dogs; where he gained a deeper understanding of the codes and contradictions of being Black, white and brown in America; where he lost a good friend to violence; and where he earned, if not quite enemies, something like them.

headline: The 25 Best Restaurants in Miami Right Now
abstract: The culinary capital of South Florida has outstanding Cuban and Caribbean cuisine — of course — but also world-class Japanese, Italian, Ethiopian and more.
lead_paragraph: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.

headline: CNN Wades Back Into the Documentary Business
abstract: The network is again financing and releasing documentary series and films after backing away from the genre two years ago.
lead_paragraph: When the filmmaker Daniel Roher won an Oscar last year for his feature documentary “Navalny,” about the Russian dissident Aleksei Navalny, it signified a high note for CNN Films. The division had chosen to finance and release the damning chronicle of Russia’s attack on the country’s foremost critic when most of its peers would not.

headline: As Mexico’s President Steps Down, Some Laud His Legacy, but Others Fear It
abstract: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador lifted millions out of poverty while eroding democratic norms, allowing his nationalist political movement to expand its sway.
lead_paragraph: To some, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico is a reformer who steered the country toward progress during his six-year presidency. To others, he’s a bulldozer who eroded democratic institutions, and is leaving a host of problems for his successor.

headline: ‘Patrice: The Movie’ Review: At a Crossroads
abstract: The emotional core of this crowd-pleasing documentary concerns a couple who cannot marry without jeopardizing their disability benefits.
lead_paragraph: The title of “Patrice: The Movie” is a little misleading. Although this documentary, directed by Ted Passon, certainly offers a biographical portrait of Patrice Jetter, a school crossing guard, disability rights advocate and Special Olympics athlete from New Jersey, its emotional core concerns her relationship with Garry Wickham. Jetter and Wickham want to marry, but doing so — or even living together — could jeopardize their disability benefits.

headline: ‘The Power Broker’ Is Magisterial. It Is Also Flawed.
abstract: We need to recapture faith in government to be a great builder again.
lead_paragraph: When I was 22 and working at a local newspaper in Queens, I opened up “The Power Broker” for the first time. I sat in a park in the borough’s leafy eastern reaches, within a short drive of a Robert Moses-constructed bridge (the Bronx-Whitestone) and a Robert Moses-constructed expressway (the Clearview). I commuted to work from my apartment in the southwest corner of Brooklyn, enduring the Moses parkways and expressways, driving myself to madness in one rush-hour traffic scrum after another. I came to believe this long-dead urban planner had locked me in an asphalt prison that I could never escape.

headline: Dancing in an Emotional Washing Machine
abstract: Botis Seva, a rising British choreographer who mixes hip-hop and contemporary dance, brings his Olivier Award-winning “BLKDOG” to New York.
lead_paragraph: “Daddy, can you read me a story?”

headline: U.S. Approves Billions in Aid to Restart Michigan Nuclear Plant
abstract: No one has ever restarted an American nuclear reactor that was seemingly closed for good. But with electricity demand spiking, interest is growing.
lead_paragraph: The Energy Department said on Monday that it had finalized a $1.52 billion loan guarantee to help a company restart a shuttered nuclear plant in Michigan — the latest sign of rising government support for nuclear power.

headline: An Open Letter to Jimmy Carter, on His 100th Birthday
abstract: You have made the most of a long life, Mr. President, serving in nearly every way imaginable as an example of moral seriousness and service to others.
lead_paragraph: Dear President Carter,

headline: Here’s What to Know About the Looming Port Strike
abstract: Thousands of dockworkers who load and unload cargo ships could walk off the job on Tuesday, halting nearly all activity at ports from Maine to Texas.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of unionized dockworkers on the East and Gulf Coasts could go on strike as early as Tuesday, stranding cargo and sending ripples through supply chains for consumer goods and manufacturing parts.

headline: Why Do So Many Women Wear Giant Eyeglasses?
abstract: A reader wonders why more women start opting for chunky frames at a certain age. Our fashion critic explains the appeal.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a trend, and it’s not actually Mr. Magoo you should be thinking of, but Edna Mode from “The Incredibles.” She’s the fashion reference here.

headline: Apple Killed Albums. Now It Wants to Rank Them.
abstract: Wesley Morris on the injustice and absurdity of Apple’s Top 100.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times critic Wesley Morris loves a ranked list. “Some people in my life will say I have a list problem,” he says. So when Apple Music released its list of the 100 best albums of all time, Wesley listened to each album in its entirety, from number 100 to number one.

headline: The Only Patriotic Choice for President
abstract: Listen to Kathleen Kingsbury, the Times Opinion Editor, make the case for Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several months, The New York Times’s editorial board has been making the case over and over again that Donald Trump is unfit to be president. Now, the board turns to the optimistic case for why Kamala Harris is the better choice.

headline: An Ohio Businessman Faces Death Threats for Praising His Haitian Workers
abstract: The lifelong Republican employs fewer Haitians than others in Springfield, but his life has been upended since Donald J. Trump spread falsehoods about immigrants in his hometown.
lead_paragraph: For Jamie McGregor, a businessman in Springfield, Ohio, speaking favorably about the Haitian immigrants he employs has come to this: death threats, a lockdown at his company and posters around town branding him a traitor for hiring immigrants.

headline: Where Americans Have Been Moving Into Disaster-Prone Areas
abstract: As Americans have flocked south and west, more people have been exposed to the risk of hazards like hurricanes, floods, wildfires and dangerous heat.
lead_paragraph: As Americans have flocked south and west, more people have been exposed to the risk of hazards like hurricanes, floods, wildfires and dangerous heat.

headline: Dockworkers Strike Could Begin Tuesday, With Talks at an Impasse
abstract: Members of the International Longshoremen’s Association could walk off the job, halting most shipments at East and Gulf Coast ports and rattling the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: Longshoremen on the East and Gulf Coasts are likely to strike on Tuesday, halting most activity at some of the busiest U.S. ports, if their union and employers fail to end a monthslong standoff over a new labor contract.

headline: Jimmy Carter Approaches the Century Mark, Eclipsing His Presidential Peers
abstract: Nineteen months after entering hospice care, the 39th president is set to turn 100 on Tuesday. His birthday wish? A chance to vote for his party’s candidate one more time.
lead_paragraph: When Jimmy Carter entered hospice care at his Georgia home last year, his family and friends thought he had only days to live. More than 19 months later, he is set to celebrate his 100th birthday on Tuesday, the first president in American history to hit the centennial mark.

headline: As the Mayor Is Indicted, the Council Passes Rat Birth Control
abstract: During a momentous week, the business of government went on at the City Council, which approved bills on jaywalking and rats.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll catch up on what the City Council did amid the firestorm surrounding Mayor Eric Adams’s indictment last week.

headline: Disoriented in America: Two Political Plays Reflect a Changed Country
abstract: The Off Broadway plays “Fatherland” and “Blood of the Lamb” explore the grief, anger and fear of no longer recognizing the country you love.
lead_paragraph: When, in the course of human events, the political bands that have connected a people appear to be dissolving rapidly, it’s fair to ask: Who in their right mind would want to revisit the chaos of Jan. 6, 2021, in the form of a play?

headline: Millions Could Lose Insurance Subsidies, Depending on the Election
abstract: The issue is getting less attention than a possible repeal of the Affordable Care Act, but it’s much more likely to happen.
lead_paragraph: Subsidies that help around 20 million Americans pay for health insurance could disappear after next year, depending on the outcome of November’s election.

headline: State of the Race: A Calm Week and Perhaps the Clearest Picture Yet
abstract: It’s getting easier to trust that the news isn’t driving the numbers, and we take a closer look at the Hispanic vote.
lead_paragraph: With five weeks to go until the election, the polls show a close and stable race for president.

headline: Will the Real Midwest Please Stand Up?
abstract: The vice-presidential debate, pitting Senator JD Vance of Ohio against Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, shines the spotlight on a complicated region.
lead_paragraph: My father grew up in a small town in southwestern Ohio. He met my mother in Madison, Wis., where I was conceived. I mention these facts not to assert my authentic Midwestern identity but to question if such a thing really exists.

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
abstract: This month’s picks cover Wisconsin moviemaking, New York music-making and Florida moneymaking.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: Donors Say a Scarred Island Could Become a Park
abstract: Austin and Allison McChord have pledged to transform an abandoned industrial site into an ecological waterfront park as a gift to Norwalk, Conn., their hometown.
lead_paragraph: On a peninsula projecting into Long Island Sound, an empty road passes through a wild salt marsh where snowy-feathered egrets dot tawny fall grasses and ospreys soar. A small herd of wild turkeys ambles nearby.

headline: They’ve Made Hats for McCain and Trump. And Obama and Harris.
abstract: One of the last remaining union-run hat factory in the country is in New Jersey. Over more than three decades, its workers have made hats for competing campaigns.
lead_paragraph: On an afternoon in September, in a 70,000-square-foot factory in New Jersey, the brims of thousands of camouflage hats were being steamed into a gentle bend so they could be boxed up and shipped across the country.

headline: Nothing to See Here but Upgrades
abstract: Eric Adams gives new meaning to the concept of the frequent-flier program.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Well Bret, the mayor of New York is certainly in a ton of trouble. Any thoughts? I couldn’t help noticing that a lot of Eric Adams’s misdeeds seem to involve him getting cushy flights to places like Turkey and Sri Lanka. Remembering the scandal over Justice Clarence Thomas’s super-luxe flights in a plane belonging to a billionaire named Harlan Crow.

headline: Lost Lives and an Epic Crisis in North Carolina
abstract: Scenes of devastation in the western part of the state, where the traces of Hurricane Helene destroyed some communities and stranded others.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Hurricane Helene unleashed catastrophic floods and mudslides in North Carolina that destroyed or decimated many communities.

headline: Senior South Korean Police Officer Sentenced to 3 Years Over Crowd Crush
abstract: Lee Im-jae, a former district chief, is the most senior official to be convicted in connection with the 2022 disaster that killed nearly 160 Halloween partygoers.
lead_paragraph: A Seoul court sentenced a senior police officer to​ three years in prison on Monday, ​convicting him of contributing through negligence to a Halloween crowd crush that killed nearly 160 people in 2022 in one of South Korea’s worst peacetime disasters.

headline: Facing a Big Test, Iran’s ‘Axis of Resistance’ Flails
abstract: Iran united militias to take on Israel, but as the Israelis pummel one, Hezbollah, the rest have so far largely failed to come to its aid.
lead_paragraph: The idea was simple: When a big war with Israel broke out, all the members of the Iranian-backed network of militias in the Middle East known as the “axis of resistance” would join the fight in a coordinated push toward their shared goal of destroying the Jewish state.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 478
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,200
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for October 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Israel Attacks on Multiple Fronts, and Helene’s Trail of Destruction
abstract: Plus, the plain-spoken poetry of Kris Kristofferson.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Alliance vs. Isolation: Harris and Trump’s Competing Views on Foreign Policy
abstract: How the candidates position themselves regarding the wars in Ukraine and the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: As wars in Ukraine and the Middle East deepen, the U.S. presidential campaign is raising a crucial question: Whose idea of American foreign policy will the world get next?

headline: The Stakes on Abortion
abstract: We explain where Kamala Harris and Donald Trump stand on the issue.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether women should be allowed to end a pregnancy has roiled American politics for more than half a century. But this year’s presidential race is the first since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, and abortion politics and policy are changing rapidly.

headline: DirecTV Strikes Deal to Acquire Dish Network
abstract: The deal, which is subject to regulatory approval, would create one of the largest pay-TV distributors in the U.S. The companies were blocked in an attempt to merge in 2002.
lead_paragraph: DirecTV said on Monday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Dish Network, a deal that would create a satellite TV giant with millions of customers and potentially provide a financial lifeline for Dish, which is struggling with billions of dollars in debt.

headline: China Removes Curbs on Home Buyers, Sparking Stock Market Surge
abstract: After seeing prices decline for years, Chinese officials have made a burst of policy changes aimed at making it easier to buy homes.
lead_paragraph: During China’s decades-long housing boom, demand for apartments was so high that cities restricted who could buy homes and limited how many they could buy.

headline: Michel Houellebecq’s Outlook for an Ailing France: C’est Fini
abstract: In what the author says is his last novel, both a family and a society are on the verge of collapse.
lead_paragraph: The French writer Michel Houellebecq has the sort of notoriety, Karl Ove Knausgaard wrote, that makes it easy to talk about him as if you’ve read him — even if you’ve not.

headline: Israeli Commandos Making Preparatory Raids Into Lebanon, Officials Say
abstract: Brief incursions in recent days were to prepare the ground for a possible wider ground invasion, the officials said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli commando units have made brief incursions across the border into Lebanon in recent days to prepare the ground for a possible wider invasion in the near future, according to six Israeli officers and officials and a senior Western official.

headline: Hezbollah Is Ready for Possible Israeli Invasion of Lebanon, Deputy Leader Says
abstract: The televised statement by the deputy leader, Sheikh Naim Qassem, was the first public address by a senior Hezbollah figure since Israel’s killing of the group’s longtime chief, Hassan Nasrallah.
lead_paragraph: Three days after Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed by Israeli bombs near Beirut, the group’s deputy leader said on Monday that it would name a new chief “at the closest opportunity,” without specifying when.

headline: Le Pen and Her Party Go on Trial in France on E.U. Embezzlement Charges
abstract: Marine Le Pen and others are accused of using European funds for unrelated party expenses. The trial, expected to last two months, comes as her National Rally has gained more political sway.
lead_paragraph: The French far-right leader Marine Le Pen and over 20 other people went on trial in Paris on Monday on charges that they embezzled funds from the European Parliament between 2004 and 2016.

headline: California Forces a Rethink of A.I. Regulation
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s decision to veto wide-ranging set of rules for artificial intelligence companies underscores the political difficulty of policing the technology.
lead_paragraph: The most sweeping effort yet to regulate artificial intelligence, a California bill that could have informed laws around the world, is going back to the drawing board.

headline: Kris Kristofferson: 12 Essential Songs
abstract: The country singer and songwriter, who died on Saturday at 88, tucked enduring aphorisms into tales about facing up to loss.
lead_paragraph: Kris Kristofferson, who was 88 when he died on Saturday, embedded enduring aphorisms into his songs. “Freedom’s just another word for nothing left to lose,” he observed in “Me and Bobby McGee.” In “Help Me Make It Through the Night,” he wrote, “Yesterday is dead and gone/And tomorrow’s out of sight.” And in “For the Good Times,” he urged, “There is no need to watch the bridges that we’re burning.”

headline: After U.S. Trip, Zelensky Returns to an Enduring War
abstract: Cities across Ukraine have suffered airstrikes in recent days, and Moscow is pressing a slow advance in the east. Kyiv has hit back against arms depots, trying to disrupt Russian logistics.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky returned to Ukraine this weekend from a high-stakes diplomatic trip to the United States with limited new aid for his armed forces and mounting challenges on the battlefield.

headline: Oasis Adds North American Shows to Reunion Tour
abstract: Liam and Noel Gallagher’s band will stop in three American cities plus Toronto and Mexico City in August and September 2025.
lead_paragraph: In August, when Oasis revealed a slew of reunion dates in Britain and Ireland starting next summer, the group said that plans were still underway for shows in “other continents outside of Europe.” That led to rampant speculation on social media — including purportedly leaked itineraries — about where the Britpop stars might go.

headline: An Israeli Strike Inside the City Limits Frays Nerves in Beirut
abstract: A blast in the Cola neighborhood was the first known Israeli strike in the central part of the city since a war with Hezbollah in 2006.
lead_paragraph: Hours after a blast hit an apartment building in Cola, a neighborhood in western Beirut, Lebanese soldiers had cordoned off the area. Chunks of cinder blocks thrown from the building were scattered around.

headline: Adams’s Lawyers Ask Judge to Dismiss Federal Bribery Charge Against Him
abstract: Lawyers for Mayor Eric Adams of New York filed a 25-page memo arguing that the conduct described in the indictment against him did not meet the definition of bribery.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Mayor Eric Adams asked a federal judge on Monday to throw out the bribery charge against him, providing an early glimpse at how the defense plans to attack the first federal indictment of a sitting mayor in modern New York City history.

headline: Inside a Kamala Harris Ad That Draws an Implicit Contrast on Character
abstract: Voters have signaled that they want to know more about the vice president. By leaning on her background as a prosecutor, this ad aims to fill in those gaps and assuage any worries.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is running this 30-second ad on television stations in at least four battleground states and has spent more than $5 million since first airing it in mid-September, according to AdImpact.

headline: Israel’s Attack in Central Beirut Was Its First There in Years
abstract: Here’s a look at where the Israeli military has been striking in the Beirut area recently.
lead_paragraph: The overnight strike in the Cola neighborhood in Beirut appeared to have been the first known Israeli strike in the city center since 2006. Israel has struck the densely populated Dahiya area to the south many times recently, with most of those strikes coming after a massive bombing attack on Friday that killed the Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah there.

headline: We Watched Tim Walz’s Old Debates. Here’s What We Learned.
abstract: He may not be a lofty orator, but he has shown an ability to deliver punchy critiques with Everyman appeal.
lead_paragraph: Before he was known to the nation as an affable Midwestern dad and a vice-presidential nominee, Tim Walz was a fast-talking political long shot in an ill-fitting suit, spoiling, in his Minnesotan way, for a debate-stage fight.

headline: We Watched Vance’s Old Debates. Here’s What We Learned.
abstract: Senator JD Vance assumed his first public office just last year. But to win that job, he had to survive about a dozen debates, sharpening his chops when facing opponents onstage.
lead_paragraph: Some politicians enjoy mixing it up with crowds on the campaign trail, while others revel in fund-raising.

headline: Around the World, Diplomats Gird for a Trump Assault on Climate Action
abstract: Some leaders insist that the global clean energy transition will happen with or without the United States.
lead_paragraph: Climate negotiators from Europe, Latin America and some island nations are bracing for the potential return to the world stage of Donald J. Trump, who withdrew the United States from the fight against global warming during his first term.

headline: Frankenstein’s Assistant
abstract: Creatures lurk in the depths of Kevin Curry and Jeff Chen’s first New York Times collaboration.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is the first collaborative effort in The Times by Kevin Curry and Jeff Chen, and as such, it represents the achievement of a longstanding goal for the two of them. Mr. Chen’s first accepted puzzle, a collaboration with his wife, Jill Denny, came after 22 Times rejections. Now he has 155 New York Times grids to his name, more than half of which are collaborations. He’s also the creator of the daily word game Squeezy. Mr. Curry is a newer constructor with three grids under his belt.

headline: U.S. Officials Believe Israel Will Not Conduct Full Invasion of Lebanon
abstract: After a weekend of intense talks, the American officials said they believed that Israel was planning only smaller, targeted incursions in southern Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: American officials said on Monday that they believed they had persuaded Israel not to conduct a major ground invasion of southern Lebanon.

headline: Want to Check That Fact? For V.P. Debate Viewers, Just Scan the Code.
abstract: CBS is experimenting with a novel way to offer real-time fact-checking of the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday. Just don’t expect the moderators to frequently jump in.
lead_paragraph: The journalistic dilemma of how to fact-check national candidates on the debate stage has cropped up again and again in the 2024 election.

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Kirk
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Kirk.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Kirk.

headline: Britain Shuts Down Last Coal Plant, ‘Turning Its Back on Coal Forever’
abstract: The Ratcliffe-on-Soar plant was the last surviving coal-burning power station in a country that birthed the Industrial Revolution and fed it with coal.
lead_paragraph: Britain, the nation that launched a global addiction to coal 150 years ago, is shutting down its last coal-burning power station on Monday.

headline: Can You Uncover the 13 Book Titles Hidden in This Text Puzzle?
abstract: The 1970s were known for their fashion, political turmoil, pop culture and a lot of significant books. See if you can spot popular fiction and nonfiction works of the era lurking in this short passage.
lead_paragraph: The 1970s were known for their fashion, political turmoil, pop culture and a lot of significant books. See if you can spot popular fiction and nonfiction works of the era lurking in this short passage.

headline: Saudi Arabia Pledges to Send Funding for Palestinians
abstract: An expected cash infusion for the Palestinian Authority would signal renewed Saudi backing for Palestinian statehood and help mend ties between Riyadh and the body that administers the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has pledged to send financial aid to the struggling Palestinian Authority, reversing a decision made during the Trump administration to slash funding to the governing body that administers some areas in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

headline: Ritzy! Cheddar! Chicken!
abstract: Everyone’s favorite buttery cracker makes a fantastic coating for chicken breasts.
lead_paragraph: In my 20s, my happy place was the Bed Bath & Beyond near Lincoln Center. (R.I.P.) An eagerness to play house — and to grow up — meant using my meager teaching paychecks to buy a new pot, a new pan or a new knife whenever I felt lost in the world. Nothing calmed my anxious nerves like gliding down those escalators and thumbing my way through the gadgets and housewares that would come to overstock my first adult kitchen.

headline: Why Mount Everest Is Growing Taller Every Year
abstract: Researchers say that two rivers merged some 89,000 years ago and gave the mightiest peak in the Himalayas a huge growth spurt.
lead_paragraph: Mount Everest is many things. It’s called Chomolungma in Tibetan, and Sagarmatha in Nepali. It’s an iconic part of Earth’s topography, a potentially lethal climbing challenge and a geologic marvel.

headline: U.S. and Allies Sound Alarm Over War Ties Among Axis of Adversaries
abstract: The Biden administration is struggling to halt cooperation among Russia, China, North Korea and Iran. It feels urgency over the wars in Ukraine and the Middle East while also aiming to protect Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Call it the Axis of Anger.

headline: Dikembe Mutombo, a Towering N.B.A. Presence, Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Mutombo, who did not begin playing basketball until adolescence, retired with the second-most blocked shots in league history.
lead_paragraph: Dikembe Mutombo, who arrived at Georgetown University as an international student with aspirations of being a doctor but became a towering presence in professional basketball and a dedicated humanitarian in his native Democratic Republic of Congo, died on Monday. He was 58.

headline: Verizon Cellphone Users Report Outages Across the U.S.
abstract: More than 100,000 cases of Verizon outages have been reported across the country, according to the website Downdetector.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Verizon users across the United States reported having little or no cellphone service on Monday morning in major cities, including in Atlanta, Chicago, Denver, New York and Phoenix.

headline: California Bans Legacy Admissions at Private Universities
abstract: The change will affect Stanford University, the University of Southern California and other private colleges in the state.
lead_paragraph: California will ban some of the nation’s most selective colleges from using legacy admissions, as Gov. Gavin Newsom on Monday signed legislation that will prohibit special consideration for applicants on the basis of their connections at private universities in the state.

headline: Billie Eilish Brings a Master Class in Intimacy to the Arena Stage
abstract: Hit Me Hard and Soft: The Tour opened in Canada on Sunday night, showcasing the 22-year-old pop star’s gift for dynamics, dramatics and audience engagement.
lead_paragraph: A few songs into the first night of Hit Me Hard and Soft: The Tour at the Videotron Center in Quebec City, Billie Eilish challenged the sold-out crowd of 18,000 to play the quiet game. “It’s literally the only time in the entire show I’m going to say this,” assured the superstar, 22, who sat cross-legged on the floor at center stage, “because I don’t want silence, ever.”
